<Author>stace120
<Content>Perfect for those new to Hawaii I have stayed at this hotel a total of 32 nights in the last year. I will say on the plus side that this is a great hotel for those new to Hawaii or those looking for a great place to stay without having to see the rest of Oahu. For those Gold and Diamond Hilton member beware. You can't get a room upgrade unless you pay about $40 extra a night. And an upgrade isn't really an upgrade. It just means you may be on the right side of the building to see fire works.. I was on the side that had to hear the noise from the from paid celebrations all night long. Not only couldn't I be moved without paying (as a Diamond member); when I tried to transfer to te Embassy Suites they threatened to fine me $ for leaving early. This was not satisfactory. I think if you are coming to Hawaii for the first time this is a good place. If you are a frequent visitor for business try the Embassy Suites.  
<Date>Jan 8, 2009

<Author>catraveller7
<Content>A Nice Resort All in all, the Hilton is a good place to stay in Honolulu. It faces the best beach in Honolulu (although as others have mentioned, Waikiki beach is a bit over-rated, better beaches are on the North Shore of Oahu or on other islands). The hotel is very crowded and not for those who are looking to get away from it all; on the other hand, there is lots going on and if you are looking for a place where you can relax and not leave the premises (if you don't want to) it's good for that--the shopping arcade on the premises is very convenient. Check-in can be a hassle, with long lines. (Note, if you are staying in the Kalia Tower or the Ali'i Tower bypass the main check-in as these two towers have their own check-in desk). Each of the towers has its own pros and cons--rooms are fairly standard in each of the towers (slightly nicer in the Ali'i Tower). I was in the Rainbow Tower which is the closest to the beach (reason I chose it). But I've stayed in some of the others on prior visits and they are all pretty good.Some of the pros  --Rooms were very comfortable and well maintained (beds, towels, etc.). Housekeeping was excellent throughout the stay. --Great location on Waikiki Beach. --Self-contained resort...don't need to leave the premises if you don't want to (e.g., Japanese restaurant, pizza place, noodle house, steakhouse, convenience stores, etc. all on premises). --Staff were very friendly and pleasant.Some of the cons would be: --Pools are too crowded. The main pool, known as the super pool was probably sufficient in its day, but as they have added more towers it is now very crowded....if you don't claim a lounge chair by 9am you probably won't get one. The chairs are also very close together. --Internet access: Very expensive in the room (I paid $68 for 5 days access; alternatively, it is $15.95 plus tax per day). Judging by the # of people with laptops in the lobby areas, I think there may be free wireless access in the lobbies....but not in the rooms.  --Overall cost....yes, this is an expensive place. Internet access (as noted above) is expensive. Food is also very expensive--$14 for a hamburger at the pool, $10 for a footlong hot dog ($14 with all the works), etc. Most alcoholic drinks $12, soft drinks $5. It adds up very quickly. Also, if you want a chaise lounge ($15 per day) or umbrella ($35 per day) on the beach it becomes very expensive...I wish they offered some sort of discount for the 2nd, 3rd, etc. day rentals as $50 per day for a lounge and umbrella is a bit much for an extended stay. --Breakfast lines are very long (think of a Las Vegas buffet). Several of the restaurants were closed (Grand Dragon and Bali by the Sea due to the economy, Tropics Bar  Grill will reopen in April '09 after being remodeled). Wish they would lower the prices a bit (for food and beach rental) but I did enjoy my stay and will return.The HHV is family friendly. I would definitely recommend it to most, but if you are looking for a very quiet, serene type of get-away the HHV isn't for you.  
<Date>Jan 6, 2009

<Author>mcguires54
<Content>Nice but bring plenty of money Beautiful place. Plenty of places to eat and shop on grounds and very nice rooms. We stayed in Tapa tower and were very happy with the rooms. The Gym is great as is the spa. The beach is nice but very crowded. They charge you for everything here!!! Want to use the gym $12.00. Want to use the shower at the gym? $18.00. Want to use a chair on the beach or a lounge? $25.00. Want to use a boogie board? $20.00. Want to use a kayak or a tricycle or pedal boat on the lagoon? $25.0 - $50.00. The staff is rude at the rentals and they don't take names if you are waiting to use something. That leads to you having to wait right by the stand the whole time, or you lose your spot. Guests start fighting over the rentals. Run very poorly and the nickle and diming is uncalled for as the place is very expensive.The restauarants and shops are very pricey. A soda is more than $5.00Do yourself a favor. Never eat breakfast on grounds. Very expensive. Walk out across the street. There is a 24 hour diner with excellent breakfasts that are very cheap. Cheaper than on the mainland.All in all a very nice place, but they need to be a bit kinder to the guests when it comes to charging for everything. The staff said everyone complains about it, and that they also agreed it is ridiculous.

<Author>Kansaskeith
<Content>It's gotten cheaper -- in more ways than one This was the seventh of the last eight Christmases at the Hilton Hawaiian Village's upscale Ali'i Tower. It was more economical, but the service plain and simply wasn't what it has been in previous years.The room itself was fine and scenic. I asked in advance for an upgrade to Ocean View Ali'i from Partial Ocean View Ali'i, and it was waiting on arrival. Also asked for a quiet room, and it was that, too. Room itself was fine, and the view of the Pacific from the 12th Floor for a retireee rate of $269 a night plus tax, including free hors d'oerves poolside each night, and (with my Hilton Gold membership) free continental breakfast, was in my opinion a good bargain. Also got a complimentary fresh fruit amenity plate on arrival.The price had dropped twice since I booked it in March -- Hilton didn't tell me this, but when I saw it on their website I rebooked it each time. Considering the category -- Ocean View Honolulu Beach Resort at Christmas -- I have no complaints about price.So, what's the problem?Mainly, housekeeping and service. Specifically, little things that were omitted. When you read this list, it will seem petty, but remember, the Ali'i Tower is supposed to be the upscale tower of the Hilton (Ali'i means elite in Hawaiian). Earlier this decade they used to have a fancy-white-uniform doorman at the tower door, and they serviced rooms three times daily (that was overkill, I admit -- even a bother-- but it shows how seriously they USED to take service. But now, no doorman, once-a-day housekeeping, and, my gripes: *No laundry/dry clean bags in the holder provided for them. *No ice bag liners for the ice buckets two nights out of five. *TV remote that wouldn't work, and when I called Guest Service Hotline rang so long it went to a recording. Finally got a human to take the TV trouble call, but then no one showed up and I had to call again. *Forgot to leave regular coffee packets the last day, only decaf.*Hilton bedside chocolates only one night out of five.*Poolside continental breakfast had now gone over $20 for those who weren't Gold members, the fresh-produce quality seemed to have declined, and they had switched to disposable plates and dishes, and plastic utensils.Is it still a decent hotel? Yes.Is it a good bargain? It certainly can be if you book carefully, and keep checking back. Sure was for me.Is it the luxury deluxe tower it used to be? Absolutely not.  
<Date>Dec 29, 2008

<Author>missiechick
<Content>Just ok I came here with a friend since she had some Hilton Points to use. How can anyone complain about Hawaii? The stay was OK. we were in what they considered the nice tower but we looked at a garage roof...it was a strain to see the beach. I don't prefer this environment because tourists don't want to leave! there is so much more to see and experience here. Too many of the same shops, and those cookies they leave you aren't so hot. But besides that, the location is a bit out of the way and you sit forever in traffic to get to it. walking isn't convienient to get down into the heart of Waikiki. The beach however, is great in front of the Hilton, hardly any coral, although each time I go back to the beach it seems to change. no matter where I stay I end up walking down the beach until I reach the strip by the Hilton. It's just not as crowded. But staying here, probably wouldn't do it again unless I got an amazing deal. I hardly spend time in a room anyhow. There is just so much to see and do. 8th time there will be a charm, and my goodness I still haven't done all there is to do.

<Author>LuSadler
<Content>Stuck up! We were so looking forward to going there! We'd travelled to New York and Las Vegas and Hawaii was our third and final destination on our honeymoon. Our journey leaving Las Vegas came to a halt when the airline we were due to travel on went bust! So after a long wait and long flight I was very excited to be arriving at our hotel! When we got there the guy behind the reception was VERY rude and patronising to us. Ok, we did not look our best as we'd been travelling for ages but he was so rude to us. Only when he saw that we had booked one of the nicest suites for our stay, he then couldn't do enough for us.Once we reached our room I was very disappointed. Although it was large-it was nothing special at all. The bed was uncomfortable and there was no great luxury to it. The rest of the hotel however was very nice with Flamingos and parrots and lovely restaurants! We finished our honeymoon by staying at the Wikiki Beach Hotel (which we had previously decided to book so we could access the other side of wikiki) I must say I loved it there and if I do ever go back to Hawaii- The Wikiki beach hotel will be my first choice as the Hilton was over priced for what it was.

<Author>acker19
<Content>Great Resort! GREAT RESORT, ESPECIALLY IN WAIKIKINever visiting Hawaii before, I was quite excited about coming especially since we were supposedly staying on a world class beach right? Think again. Before making our reservation at the Hawaiian Hilton, I was dancing back and forth deciding which resort to stay at. WE ARE SO LUCKY I made the right choice! Let me say, that my first impression of Hiltons Hawaiian Village, our first morning, was absolute paradise!After a day or so, we took a walk all the way down the Waikiki strip and viewed every hotel on the beach. The only hotels that were worth anything were the Hilton Hawaiian Village and the Military Hotel directly next door. Of course many of these hotels looked nice from the shopping front entrance of their property and were located in a very nice shopping and restaurant strip BUT their backyards were purely crap. Yeah, they looked alright from the front of their building but seriously lacked any bit of beachfront esthetics. Tiny, tiny, beach areas and yes of course, crowded due to lack of space. Most of them had very unattractive backyard grounds and pool areas, with the exception of a few who at least had like a nice looking dining area facing the ocean. The public beach areas of Waikiki were still not fabulous, but much better than what the strip hotels offered as a鈥?beach area鈥? We are a military family and we could have stayed at The Hale Koa but because of my husbands rank, it cost us the same to stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village because we got a great deal through Hilton package vacation deals on their website.  Although the Hale Koa still had much more beautiful grounds than the other hotels it still didn鈥檛 come close to what the Hilton Hawaiian Village looked like but it鈥檚 a great value and a very nice hotel for certain lower ranks of the military. It had many other features that were amazing however鈥?br/>The Hilton Hawaiian Village is quite kid friendly for kids who are 5 or over. Our child is 4 and a small 4 year old and wasn鈥檛 quite tall enough to really have a good time in the pools that all seemed to be 3鈥? to 4 feet deep. Lucky for us, due to the convenient location next door to the military hotel, we were able to present our military Ids and take our son the wonderful kiddie pool at the Hale Koa!How fortunate to have had access to their great pool that was only 1 陆 鈥渄eep and so many kids were delighted in there. The age limit was 6 years old so he made lots of friends close to his age and had a great time!Another option was to take our son to the lagoon. A totally renovated awesome ocean fed lagoon that could compare very much like a pool but it鈥檚 technically a beach. Read more below about this feature.On Our last two days I insisted that we purchase a good float jacket for our son and we enjoy the pools here at the resort. Bummer for our son but he had enough time in the kiddie pool next door. He really wasn鈥檛 crazy about this but we had to take turns because the pools here were sooooooooooo nice that it was a shame to have to go anywhere else. It was convenient for us to stay here and still be able to make use of the military facilities next door like the PX, restaurants and reasonable parking. We are not Hilton reward members so we had to pay premium prices to park, eat and use the workout room. PROS of staying at the Hilton Hawaiian VillageGorgeous grounds! Come see for yourself!Kid friendly and adult friendly at the same time. Several bird exhibits with elegant landscaping. Calm 鈥渂ay like鈥?beach and lagoonShopping and lots of it!Very comfy feather like beds! Restaurants: Lots of different eating establishments on the property and many pool and beach side convenient quick menus. Pools galore! 3 pools open to all guests but stay in the 鈥淎LI Tower鈥?and you gain access to an additional private pool and Jacuzzi on the second floor overlooking the resort. Awesome lagoon for the kids!Let鈥檚 talk about the pros!ENVIORMENT: As mentioned before, there is no comparison with the landscaped and property grounds beauty from any other hotel on the strip. Impossible to compare because there is none!You feel like you are in a tropical paradise here. Lots and various bird exhibits set in a very animal friendly environment and just very tastefully done. Staff was constantly caring for the gardens, koi ponds and even mopping outside areas! Great customer service everywhere on the resort. Staffs from the reception desk to the janitorial workers were always very friendly and courteous at all times. My husband turned to me one day and said 鈥渆veryone is just so happy here!鈥?br/>SHOPPING: If you truly don鈥檛 want to leave the resort鈥?anything you will need is here including a United States postal office! Shopping and eating galore!If you can get a deal staying in the Ali tower, you gain access to a private pool on the second floor with a private Jacuzzi and eating area. ABC stores on premises.EATING: When we stayed here their was construction going on so some of the buffets normally offered like at the Lanai restaurant were closed. They looked impressive but for us, we didn鈥檛 get to try it out. Bummer it looked like they had a lot of cultural foods too which would have been neat to try.At the Tapa Caf茅 which is right below the Tapa tower, they had a variety of buffet options for breakfast only however, their most expensive buffet had EVERYTHING! I鈥檓 not a very hungry breakfast person however but it pretty much was like eating breakfast and lunch selections so I would say if you鈥檙e a football player and require a huge calorie intake, this is the best value for your money which cost something like $23.00 per person. Keep in mind that they had less expensive breakfast options for those with smaller appetites. Down by the pools and the beach front, they had a great continental breakfast buffet with great selections for $15.00 and a great view! I wasn鈥檛 crazy about their lunch/dinner menu for the moneys worth but the breakfast buffet was quite reasonable and available until 10:00 am. I did like the outdoor seating with a nice atmosphere.I personally preferred to venture off down the strip to find a restaurant to eat at. We ate at a few restaurants on the resort but they were quite spendy and not as tasty for the price as some of the other restaurants away from the resort. The malls within a mile or so away had great restaurants at more mainstream prices. For those of you not wanting to leave the resort, there were many many smaller restaurants on the resort that had more reasonable prices. KID FRIENDLY H20 ACTION!Very h20 friendly for the kids at quite reasonable prices. Beach and Water gear for the kids was very reasonable at many convenience shops here at the resort. ABC stores were the best! They will even blow up the ducky rings and other various flotation devices for the kids free of charge. Very h20 friendly for the kids at quite reasonable prices which was a nice.Beach and lagoon here at this resort perfect for very little ones.The lagoon has a nice smooth shallow entry for young ones but it will still get deep in parts so use caution. (5 ft) Smooth sailing here in the lagoon and in the beach area of the resort. No harsh waves whatsoever just smooth bay like water. As mentioned before, the kid pool here isn鈥檛 quite shallow enough for 3-4 year olds BUT it is heated to a very nice temperature and your toddler can still go in with an approved floatation device. (Lifeguards are specific to which types are not allowed so check with them first)The lagoon is awesome for little ones. It鈥檚 very pretty and scenic but you have to rent a chair if you want one here. Smooth white groomed sand beach area and it鈥檚 just gorgeous. Are you a runner? Nice running track around the lagoon too; 3 times around equals a mile! (According to the towel attendant).CONSWireless no and Ethernet cable short! Expensive too! 10.00 for an hour or 68.00 for 5 days!No laundry facilities (unless you reside in the timeshares)No Jacuzzi (except if you stay in alli tower)Local phone calls 1.50 eachWell, that is all I have to say folks! Feel free to email me for any suggestions or questions. acker19@yahoo.com

<Author>JBien
<Content>Magnificent as always My husband and I do the Honolulu Marathon each year and like to stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village because of its proximity to the starting line, and is within a nice walk from the finish line.We book the Ali'i tower for its views and private pool (I know, I know, Waikiki is right there and we stay in the Ali'i tower for the POOL?). The Ali'i tower also has its own check in desk, which allows you to bypass the lines at the general reception desk.From start to finish, folks at this hotel have been so gracious and the service to all their guests has been nothing short of personable and genuine. Rita at the front desk of the Ali'i tower was so sweet. We booked a room rate called 'Best Available', which means you pay a low price, but they choose where to put you. It can be a gamble, but on this visit, it paid off. Rita told us our scheduled room wasn't available, as it was still being cleaned. But she said there was a room that was ready but it was one floor down and three doors over. She then said that in her personal opinion, she thought we should wait for the original room, as it had a superior view. I was tired from the travel and wanted to get to a room to relax, but after she said that, my husband and I chose to wait for the original room. So we went and ate. Rita called my cell phone to let us know when the room was ready (which was less than an hour later) and I was very glad we waited. We were given room 1309 - it's an 'ocean view' room, but it was better than the 'ocean front' we've stayed in before!! With a framed view of Diamond Head in the distance, a gorgeous view of Waikiki Beach and great views of Fort DeRussy below; I couldn't have asked for a better room to be in! Their rooms are quite comfortable and spacious. With a king size Hilton Heavenly bed and a sitting area to boot, you can't ask for much more. The bathroom dressing area has a small fridge that we used to store water and snacks, and their room safe is free of charge. It's large enough to store a laptop, should you decide to bring one.Their bathroom products are CrabtreeEvalyn La Source shampoos, conditioners, bath gels, etc. I love those products. They are replaced every day. We bought extra Kona coffee and sweetener to enjoy in our room, and housekeeping picked up on the fact that we don't drink decaf, so she removed the decaf packets and supplied us with double the amount of regular coffee. How perceptive! She also left extra condiment packets, seeing that we would need more creamer. :)The restaurants we ate at were mostly CJ's Deli and Round Table Pizza. CJ's Deli has great Loco Moco, although they don't put beans in it. For $15, it's quite a good meal. I highly recommend it if you haven't had Loco Moco before (get the traditional Loco Moco, not the meatloaf Loco Moco for an authentic Hawaiian experience). Round Table pizza is 'okay' if you want some pie, but it's so-so, though their Caesar dressing is classic; made with anchovies or anchovy paste.The weather this visit was not very good! We were on Oahu Dec 11th through the 15th and it rained most days, so we didn't get too much beach time or pool time. But we still enjoyed it. After all it's Hawaii, so how bad can it be, right?BTW: Tropics Beach Bar and Grill in the Ali'i tower is under construction for remodeling, and is due to open April 2009. So no appetizers by the Ali'i Tower pool, and no awesome breakfast. However, I highly recommend the restaurant in the Tapa Tower for American breakfast buffet. It's full of good eats and if you leave hungry, it's your fault. Hah!I highly, highly recommend this hotel for anyone that hasn't been to Hawaii; you're in the middle of a great spot on Waikiki, great views, great food nearby, great service with a smile ... you can't go wrong with this hotel. -Jen  
<Date>Dec 23, 2008

<Author>sydmikery
<Content>Nice, but busy I earned a trip to this resort through work. My husband and I were very excited as neither of us had been to Hawaii and we decided to take our 3 kids with us. Once in a lifetime trip, right? Well, the staff was very friendly and the facilities and rooms were nice. Nothing special. What caught me the most was how busy it was and the price. Thank goodness for the 24 hour coffee shop around the corner that offered reasonable meals. I would not stay here again, but since I did not pay for it, what the heck!  
<Date>Dec 21, 2008

<Content>Amazing Honeymoon...       View from our room...  
<Date>Dec 20, 2008
<Rating>4	4	4	5	4	4	3	-1

<Author>GKH055
<Content>If you are a nitpick, then don't travel. This place is cool. Out of 1000 reviews, I think I read 800 of them regarding this place. I almost changed my reservation because of the few bad ones. I am glad I didn't. I am simply amazed at some of the unfounded comments about HHV and the expectation level of some of these people. So I felt compelled to debunk them. First of all, I am a Hilton Diamond member and have travelled the world. Some paid, some free on points. I have always been treated with respect at Hilton properties whether I paid or not. I have had very few issues at any Hilton property. That being said, I expect very little when I travel and plan for the worst. I have never written a review of a hotel because I feel they contain far too many personal preferences to create a valid, central view.For reference, I am not the type of person to crawl around on the floor and look for missing carpet fibers or sniff the walls to see how fresh the paint is. I expect some noise, it's a HOTEL full of people. I expect that hotels, especially tropical resorts, to have some level of wear and tear due to the climate and the volume of guests. I expect hotel staff to be tired of overly demanding people so I tend to commiserate with them, not berate them. I am not a food snob. I do not live to eat nor does food define my persona. I do not pick places to go based on their selection of restaurants. Perhaps my palate is unrefined. Or perhaps, it's just that I am not a pretentious person. For instance, I drink wine that I enjoy, not to find the subtle tones of oak or a wild berry finish. The common theme of my review is cost - I try not to be cheap, but in these times, stretching a dollar means a lot and I think it's important to know what you're getting into. Besides, you won't find another beachfront hotel in Waikiki that is any different. Here we go;1. For Gold and Diamond members - I'm not sure why someone said they were scolded for taking milk out of the executive lounge - there isn't one there. No big deal, few Hilton resort-type properties have one. I have been to many good executive lounges and more than a few not-so-good ones. Not having one is no issue here, especially when the views are so good and it is much more enjoyable to sit on your balcony with your favorite drink. I bought drinks and snacks and put them in the fridge in my room. If you don't have a room with a view, create one and sit on the beach with your favorite drink. Rating - N/A2. True - breakfast lines were somewhat long - especially around 9am. By that I mean 20 minutes, NOT an hour as reported. So either get up earlier or go later - they're open til 11am. I had a breakfast coupon so the continental buffet at HHV was free (normally $20). Upgrading to the hot buffet ($29) was obviously around $10. You can save a lot of money if you don't have a breakfast coupon by going across the street to the diner. I ate a few lunches at the diner and the food was good - but it is a diner. If you are a food snob, then don't go to it. I didn't see any parsley on the plate and there isn't a sommelier. Rating 8 out of 10 for the horrendous 20 minute wait.3. Yes, food is VERY expensive at HHV. Again, there are many restaurants within a few blocks (at most) and you can find cheaper food very easily. If you are catatonically lazy and don't want to walk a block or two, then expect $20 cheeseburgers and $30 pizza at HHV. I find that ridiculous, but maybe my inferior palate is missing the fusion of the pizza cheese or something. Rating 2 out of 10. That much for food is criminal. But, you have choices so I gave them a 2.4. Never had trouble getting a beach towel. Never. Ever. True, the pool chairs are right next to each other and they fill up quickly, get there early. You have to crawl in from the end, there is no room on the side. But then the complaint would be there weren't enough chairs if they removed some for space. Again, Waikiki beach is steps away and there is plenty of room. And yes, as one person complained, staff does help to control children when their parents are incapable of being a parent. I find that incredibly refreshing. I guess it does take a village to raise a kid - if you're a bad parent. Rating 10 out of 10. NO, an 11 out of 10 for having the guts to handle unruly kids and keep the resort atmosphere for all.5. Check-in times were normal. check-out times were just as normal. Maybe a few minutes? However, if you wait until a busload of people get dropped off and then get in line behind them - your check in experience will probably be a little sluggish. Call me crazy. Or worse, get behind a certain tourist from a certain country who wants to debate their bill line-item by line- item and not want to pay tax. Not the hotel's fault. Rating 9 out of 10.6. Go to Ala Moana Center - they have a Long's Drugs and you can buy things like drinks and snacks more cheaply than the ABC Stores nearby. You can maybe walk if you are ambitious- or take the trolley or bus. If you have a car, the parking is easy and free.The ABC Store off-site of HHV is slightly cheaper than the one on-site and a good option. Rating N/A.7. Staff wasn't rude overall. Yea there were a couple of minor incidents, but I shrugged them off to Hawaiian cultural differences. The day I can look in the mirror and say I haven't had my share of moments is when I can be critical of others. Give them a break, they have to deal with people- and I kid you not - who demand they answer why the water in the ocean was cloudy (it had rained that day and there was minor run-off. Very minor. I could still see the bottom of the ocean from 8-10 feet.). Another complained about Honolulu traffic. How that is the resort's fault still baffles me. If you want some fun, hang out in the lobby and listen to what the hotel guests ask or request of the staff. And then decide how long YOU could maintain a pleasant demeanor. Yes, it's their job - but it's their job to help, not be a slave. Besides, the day it rained they offered us a free umbrella to use - without us asking. Rating 8 out of 10.8. I suppose that the hotel room decor could be considered a little dated. I only noticed because of the numerous comments on here about it. I didn't find it dirty, unsafe or hazardous so I'm not sure what dated truly means. I guess that they don't have granite countertops? Do you change your carpet and furniture bi-annually? They were re-doing two rooms on our floor and the workers let me look in. One version had hard wood floors and the other had a mixture of carpet and tile. But beware - if you think it's expensive now, wait until all the rooms are re-done. Who do you think is paying for the opulence? Rating 8 out of 10.9. Ah yes, speaking of cost - someone complained the place is too expensive. I paid $200/night at HHV. When I returned, I paid the same amount at a Hampton Inn in Maryland. Maryland...Hawaii...big difference, same price. Hilton lists their properties in Honolulu as category 6's with one exception - Doubltree that is listed as a 5. That means they're the most expensive and cost the most points if you redeem for a free night. Could it be - just maybe - that you're paying that much because it's Hawaii and an in-demand destination and not - oh I don't know - as in demand as Orangeburg, South Carolina?! No, the hotel rooms aren't opulent, they're reflective of a resort. But I doubt you'll come home with the plague because the carpet wasn't changed after the last guest. Rating 8 out of 10.10. Another one said this place has a bad beach. Huh? It's at the end of Waikiki! I guess that means the entire beach is bad? I will say that the sand (on the entire beach) was more grainy than I had thought and became painful to walk on for a distance. I live at a beach so I'm used to it, but this was unusually grainy. But that isn't an indictment about the beach at all, just an observation. Rating 10 out of 10.11. Don't simultaneously complain about construction work and also about dated rooms. You can't undate a room without construction. I didn't hear the workers three rooms down and they tore out the entire room all day, every day. I heard some noise outside and some people 25 floors down at the beach. I also heard the ocean, some birds, the wind and some boat horns. They are also re-doing a couple of restaurants. Again, the complaint would be the dated restuarants if they left them as-is. So what, sound travels. Give me the Nobel prize for figuring that out. Rating 9 out of 10.12. Based on my honors level, I was upgraded to an ocean view. No, not every room or every tower has an ocean view. If that's what you want, then pay the higher charge for an ocean view. It's listed plainly on the web site as to what type of room you are getting when you click on it. There is no secrecy about it. Rating 10 out of 10.13. Someone said you need an armed guard to escort you around. I am not even responding to that it's so ridiculous. Rating 11 out of 10.14. I parked my own car because I know valet service takes longer and I like to be in control of my own time and destiny. If you think you will have a personal valet that will deliver your car in nanoseconds, then park it yourself and save the self-imposed frustration. It isn't that big of a deal to do it yourself. Rating 5 out of 10 due to cost factor. $24 a day to park is too steep.15. HHV doesn't nickel and dime you to death, they dollar you to death. Parking, internet, in-room safe, food...but show me a Hilton that doesn't. If you want free parking and internet, stay at a Hampton....or a Holiday Inn. Rating 7 out of 10.16. Get the coupon books at the fornt desk, they may help a little depending on your buying wants and needs.17. Speak Japanese and be very aware that you are really in east Tokyo. Rating 0 out of 10.Some will argue I was there during the 'off-season. Maybe. But the Honolulu marathon was going on that week and there were 30,000 people for it. Plus there were numerous conventions around. It seemed slammed to me. I think the place was cool. It has lots of shops - and some bargains if you look. Overall, some prices on some items in the shops are cheaper than stores around the island. There are a few restaurants closeby (Outback, the 24hr diner, McDonalds, Red Lobster, Subway, etc.) and more down Kalakaua Avenue. Go to the International Marketplace for trinkets and tee's - the best deals are the vendors in the back of that massive area. It's about a 20 minute walk without window shopping. Along Kalakaua Avenue are the fancy stores (Coach, Burberry, Polo, Tiffany, etc.). The trolley system is easy to figure out, it's color coded based on what you want to do (shopping, dining, etc). Hilo Hatties has their own shuttle to their main store on Nimitz Hwy. it's a great place for souvenirs too.When I go back, I'm staying at HHV. It's on the beach, easy to get to, fairly decent location on Waikiki (albeit the end) and has beautiful grounds. You can stay here on a budget, you just have to work at it a little. It's worth the effort for the views and the convienence. Don't listen to the bad reviews, having been there, I have no idea what those people are referring to. If they are truly that picky, they need to stay home.

<Author>BostonTravelers123
<Content>Fabulous Stay       Hilton Hawaiin Balcony View  
<Date>Dec 16, 2008
<Rating>4	4	5	5	5	5	5	5

<Author>hermitchness
<Content>Not as good as it could be We stayed here at the end of our Island excursions, saving the resort feel for the last leg of our travels. As Honors members of Hilton and other fine hotels, we have come to assume a certain level of quality and service; these standards were not reflected at this location.For example check in proved to be a much larger ordeal than any of the other Hiltons we stayed at on other trips. When we inquired about changing our breakfast reservation the desk attendant informed us that it was too late and I quote her here, You snooze you lose, you should have changed your reservation before arrival. She did not bother to inform us that the restaurant in the Rainbow tower was closed for renovation and that there would be hour long lines for our included breakfast.Additionally, the so called spa treatments are over priced sales pitches. I am a bodyworker and have travelled extensively and received body work from many hands and of many disciplines. People should not be fooled into thinking this is a legitamate spa. I booked the Around the World massage for 80 minutes at a rate of $200. This was by far the worst massage I have ever had and requested the practictioner stop before the time was up. There was no reflexology, no shiatsu and no other methods despite the listing in the spa menue of services In fairness the young woman simply did not know how to do anything outside of Swedish.We were billed for the full amount of service and I am not pleased. Additionally pool towels are hard to come by and over all service at this hotel is not what we have received at other Hilton hotels. We found the staff to be rude, unaccomodating and uninterested in hospitality.Honestly I felt like we had booked a stay at a large mall and will not visit this hotel again.  
<Date>Dec 14, 2008
<Rating>2	2	2	2	3	1	1	1	
<Aspects>
14	26(people):1	34(feel):1	68(travel):2	72(resort):1	302(receive):1	314(spa):1	342(island):1	377(hand):1	425(save):1	734(excursion):1	1352(body):1	1421(leg):1	2098(fool):1	2178(extensively):1

<Author>HawaiianIslands
<Content>Not the same due to a change in management I have stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village 3-4 times a year for the past few years. Up until recently it had always been a great hotel due to its location, rooms, and service. Earlier this year changes were noted during a stay at the Kalia Tower, for instance some of the extra bathroom amenities. When asking the maid about it she went onto explain that a change in management had ocurred and there were many cutbacks. Another change was the elimination of the executive lounge that served breakfast and snacks at the Kalia Tower. Another employee that we knew from previous visits confirmed that cost cutting changes had been made by management. On this last visit while staying at the Alii Tower requests were made to change the sheets using the change the sheets request card located on the night stand. Each time the card was put out on the bed the sheets were not changed. There was a stain in the top left corner of the sheets and each time we came back to the room it was evident the sheets had not been replaced as requested. Upon entering the room hair from the previous guest was found in the bathtub and toilet area. Not sure if the maids just have too many rooms to clean now and need to cut corners to keep up.I would definitely return to the hotel but hope these little things are corrected.  
<Date>Dec 13, 2008

<Author>travelcrazy45
<Content>dont waste your money on Hawaii Hotel property is nice, rooms are ok but the service is HORRIBLE. Everyone here is rude and unfriendly. WHAT? Are we on candid camera here? Taxi drivers wont even acknowledge female customers unless a man is present. No wonder the economy is bad here. The only people that come are the ones that dont know there are much better places to visit. Save your money and the long flight. Go to the bahamas instead. They treat you much better and are happy that you are there to visit!

<Author>bandit
<Content>Nice Hotel - Great Views- Stayed here for 4 nights. Checked in on 11/28 and departed on 12/02. This place is huge. We took a shuttle from the airport. Other reviews were right. It is a LONG walk from the airport shuttle drop off area to the front desk. My husband and I got our luggage together and started walking - THEN one of the bellmen at the shuttle drop off asked if we needed help. We declined.....Check in was easy - I am Gold and my husband is Diamond Hilton Honors so we had a quick check in; however, there was a long line to check in if you weren't. Our room was on the 35th floor in the Tapa Tower. We had a beautiful ocean view. We got a free continental breakfast each morning. We enjoyed that perk. The servers in the breakfast restaurant were very prompt and friendly. We did the time share presentation and was given a voucher for the hotel. We opted to use the voucher (+ a few more $$$) to get a couples massage in the spa. The spa is nice with steam sauna, hot tubs, etc. the massage was great!!! The rooms were large and the beds were very comfortable. Walls were a bit thin and we could hear our neighbors next door. The ABC Store was great for snacks, drinks, etc. Pool was nice. It was not crowded when we were there. The hotel is a good 10 - 15 min walk to the main part of Waikiki. This was a nice hotel, but I would probably not stay here again on another trip to Honolulu. It is just too big and is not close to a many restaurants and shops (except those on property).  
<Date>Dec 12, 2008

<Author>Marielov
<Content>Great Hotel I was wary of this hotel due to all the negative comments but we had a great stay here. I found the staff friendly. We were upgraded to an ocean view room and was pleased to see we had a balcony. <Author>KitKatVA
<Content>Review for the Business Traveler The Hilton Hawaiin Village is a great hotel for the business traveler. It's in a good location nearby the main roads, and a short walk down the beach/road to some great restaurants. The cost of eating and drinking at the hotel itself is the equivalent of a major mainland city like NY or DC ($10 drinks). Rooms conveniently have internet access (not sure if that is typical for all Waikiki hotels). For those nights you come back from work and are too tired to venture out into Waikiki, the hotel is very self-serving. As other travelers mentioned, it truly is a village. ABC (convenience) store, coffee shop, ice cream store, many other shops, etc. provide things to do when you don't want to sit in your hotel room but also don't want to go big after a day on the job.  
<Date>Dec 8, 2008

<Author>Spinner8
<Content>Big is not always beautiful Firstly I should explain two things. I am a Diamond Card holder with the Hilton Group which enables me to receive upgrades on rooms. Secondly my wife and I are well travelled and neither of us will see 50 years old again.This resort is big. Too big to cope with the numbers of people staying in the 5 towers (each a hotel ) which comprises this resort . Another tower is being constructed for Vacation Club subscribers. The 'village' also includes about 50 shops and restaurants, which provides some on site fun, but the main 'high street' is only a 10 minute walk away and is amazing in its size and quality of shops.Our room was great. On the 34th floor out of 35 and with a nice balcony with a sea view. The room is a good size but is not well insulated. The door mechanisms are so robust that you have to slam the door to close it. You will hear doors slamming shut at least 3 rooms either side of you. If there are boisterous people above you you will hear then through the ceiling.You will need to be sharp to get a seat around the pool. There are not enough sunbeds and each one is butted against the one next to it so there is no privacy and, frankly, you have to be careful if the person next to you suddenly flattens the sunbed as fingers could be hurt. The beach is not part of the Hilton village so you will need to hire sunbeds for the beach at about 10 pounds a day. Reed mats can be bought cheaply at the on site supermarket.The breakfast arrangements are awful and you will find yourself queuing for up to 20 minutes to be seated for breakfast. Not a good start to the day, but an opportunity for one person to queue and the other to reserve a sunbed.There is no Executive lounge (for the information of cardholders).Entertainment is provided several times a week, always at a cost.This resort came at the end of a week in Hong Kong and 2 weeks in Sydney and we were lucky with the weather. It provided a warm and relatively attractive recuperation after 3 weeks of non stop activity and sightseeing. It ticked many of the boxes needed but the aforementioned deficiencies mean that I would not go there again.  
<Date>Dec 6, 2008

<Author>chopcop22
<Content>A beautiful, well maintained hotel My wife, and I, stayed at the HHV for 8 days. Believe me, when they call this place a village, it is. The grounds are immaculate, with beautiful flowers, birds, coi fish, and my favorites, the penguins.We stayed in the rainbow tower, 30th fl., and had 2 balconies, one overlooking the beach, and the ocean, and the other, overlooking the lagoon, and downtown. The queen sized bed, was comfortable, and there was plenty of room. My only complaint about the room, was the refridgerator was too small.The super pool was nice, and we never had a problem finding chairs to lay on. You have to try the poolside grill. The cheeseburgers were delicious, and the hot dog, had to be more than a foot long. The chili that they put on the hot dog, tasted like home made.We rented a car, from Advantage, which only cost $189, for the time that we were there. It's very easy to get around. A good map will get you anywhere that you want to go. We drove up to the North shore, to watch the surfing championships, and to stop at Masumoto's, for shaved ice, which is worth the trip.We went to Pearl Harbor, around 11:00, and had no problem getting in. They move you through fairly quickly. You watch a 10-15 minute movie, and then take a Navy shuttle out to the Memorial. It was a very moving experience, and I couldn't believe how everyone was so quiet. It really showed respect to our hero's who are entombed in the USS Arizona, which just lyes 6 feet under you.We also toured the mighty Batteleship USS Missouri. Take the tour with a guide, it's worth the extra cost.We were disappointed with the Spirit of Honolulu, dinner cruise. We were supposed to get filet, and lobster, instead, the lobster was replaced with crab claws. I wouldn't recommend the Atlantis submarine, either. It cost us over $200, and you couldn't see hardley anything. The things that they take you to see are artificial (reefs). The ship, and plane, were purchased, and sunk, to make reefs. Go para-sailing, it's more fun, along with being cheaper.The ABC store is the place to purchase your basic goodies. They have everything that will suit your needs.For breakfast, there is a nice restaurant, that's also open 24 hours a day, about a block to the left, after you go out of the main entrance.We had a wonderful time, and would definately stay here again.  
<Date>Nov 26, 2008
<Rating>5	5	5	5	5	5	5	-1

<Author>yannazmom
<Content>Great Location, some issues.... Booked two rooms at govt rate. Booked for 19-22 although we were arriving from Korea on the 20th to ensure a room at 0700 on the 20th.Arrived and I had no room. They then said I could get a room but I'd have to move at noon. I thought this was unacceptable since I had paid for a room beginning the night before. I asked for an upgraded room if I had to move. I was then magically given a room. I figured it would be bottom of the barrel and I was right. It was in the Diamond tower which I think it one of the oldest. It was bare bones, but decent.The location, ammentities, and shops were great! I used the Mandara Spa, pool, and gym. Pricey, but nice.Checkout was insane. There were so many ppl standing there and the system was down. Not effecient at all.Would probably try this place again, not too sure.

<Author>plentysuncream
<Content>noisy time Just got back from 3 weeks in the states of which 7 nights were at this hotel , upon arrival got upgraded from the Diamond tower to the ali tower free of charge which was very good , The biggest issue was the construction work going on directly below the pool at the ali tower and this could be heard all over the resort and it will be going on well into 2009 so beware if you like peace and quiet you will not get it here , I agree with others ref cost of food and drinks it was very pricey but in true British style we found the harbour pub just past the lagoon and this place was cheap , we spent a full afternoon in it with plenty food and drinks and the bill was 40 dollars , Also note in the ali tower you get free snacks between 17:00 hrs and 19:00 hrs which were nice , this hotel does have a very good beachfront location just remember the building work .

<Author>logcolb
<Content>Depends on what youu pay for this hotel This hotel may be worth staying in depending on what you have to pay for it. We had two rooms for 4 nights, booked on Priceline for $200/night each. We were upgraded to the Rainbow Tower on the water at no additional cost. The tower you are in is very important, since only a few have a decent water view and many are back away from the water with no water view. We had a very nice view looking out on a marina with the ocean and coast beyond. The grounds and common areas are actually very nice with lush landscaping. The resort is set up as a number of high-rise towers with the pools and landscaping between. There is also quite a number of shops and restaurants in a village type atmosphere. My reason for not rating the resort higher are two. First, the rooms are very dated, and two, the resort tends to try to get every last dollar out of you by charging you for everything they can. The furniture in our rooms was very dated and more like what you would find in an older Holiday Inn and not a luxury resort. While the bathrooms had been redone, they left the old sinks and faucets, which are very dated. The 3 sinks even had rust around the drains they had been there so long. The hotel had no chairs to use on the beach unless you paid an unreasonable fee to use them. The resort is actually very attractive and in a nice location, an easy walk to the shopping at Waikiki but in a nice quieter area. If you can get a very reasonable price, the Hilton may be worth considering. If you are not getting a decent discount I would stay elsewhere in a place that had more up to date rooms.  
<Date>Nov 22, 2008

<Author>vacationadvice
<Content>It was a great vacation at HHV! We just got back from a 3-night stay (thursday - sunday) at HHV. Honestly I had my doubts before we got there, since the latest reviews (a week before our arrival there) were kind of negative. BUT... it was such an awesome experience staying at HHV. We booked the package from Costco, and we had ocean-front room on the 15th floor in the Rainbow tower. beautiful, beautiful view, day or night. Also, after 7 pm, there is live music from the bar on the beach. We took our daughter with us and she was a bit jet-lagged, so after she fell asleep at 8 pm, my hubby and I just sat on the balcony sipping coffee and enjoying the music and the sound of the wave from the ocean... totally relaxing. oh.. the maid service was great too. We usually tip about $5 everyday, and the lady was so nice to leave us extra coffee or towels if we requested them. the food was above average too. Some reviewers said the price was high, which might be a bit true for room service, because i noticed they charged $6 per person in addition to the usual fee charged for room service at other hotels. We ordered breakfast twice and it was $70 each time for my hubby and me (i.e., American breakfast, $27, Pancakes $19, then the rest of the cost goes to the service charge and tax and $6 per person order, and something else). If you eat at other places on site, then the price seems pretty much the same as other hotels in Waikiki. btw, the noodle shop on site has very yummy food and the price is about $10 per soup (or for one order of fried rice or curry beef combo). we dined there a lot since i fell in love with their chicken/veggie noodle soup (this one, the noodles are made of some kind of soybeans and the waitress called it 'clear noodle soup').This is our 3rd visit to the area, and I think HHV is the best hotel among all the three we have stayed (Marriott couldn't hold a candle to HHV -- we stayed there two years ago. the beach across the street of Marriott is rocky and narrow, service also wasn't as great, and not much for kids to play with there). At HHV, the beach is wide and nice and soft, and there are lagoon, koi, duck, penguin ponds. On top of that, fireworks on Fridays. My daughter totally loved everything, and HHV is truly a great resort for family vactions. All in all, HHV is more than what I expected... the check-in wasn't bad and the staff was nice (really nice). the property is big yet it doesn't feel exhausting at all to walk around. remember to get the rainbow tower (it is close to everything, beach, rainbow blazar, the main desk, etc.)... and if you can, get the oceanfront at the rainbow tower -- the view and the music (plus fireworks display which is right there)... is worth every penny -- we had a great time there and we will def stay there again next time. (last note... it was slow when we were there. i was prepared to wait in lines, but didn't see any... the taxi driver said it hadn't been as crowded as before, so maybe it is time to go:) ).  
<Date>Nov 19, 2008

<Content>Overall Happy, hard to get food I've stayed here twice, but one thing stuck me this last trip...They don't offer room service after 10:00PM. All the hotel bar's close pretty early. I mean, it's not too much to ask to get a hamburger at 10:30PM. Any other Hilton I've stayed at offers room service at 10:30, most still are serving at that time in the bars. It's made worse by the size, you have to walk several blocks just to find food.My first time here, they upgraded me to a suite, it was an awesome room. The second time I was was here I also had a nice room.It's defanitely a nice hotel, great views, excellent location, I was otherwise happy except for the inability to get food after 10:00 PM

<Author>Beachfirst
<Content>Hilton Hawaiian Village -- good points and a few disappointments I stayed in the Rainbow Tower which was a nice tower. I stayed at this property for 17 days. The location and property as a whole was indeed beautiful. It was clean and enjoyed the view of the Lagoon from my balcony -- sunsets are incredible. I did have a few issues with room service (quality of food) which were quickly resolved by management after phoning them. I did have some issues with my room (noise level of housekeeping storage room next to my room) which were not resolved by management and that was a disappointment. On the down side, many of the lounges and restaurants were closed. I do feel that too many of them were closed at the same time which was disappointing.

<Author>Syd70
<Content>Nice Hotel We stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village in the Ali Tower for two nights. The location of this hotel was great. It has a lovely pool, is situated right on the beach and also has its own lagoon. There are 2 starbucks on the hotel grounds, but the coffee is more expensive than the other starbucks down the road. They have a waterfall, ponds with fish and also a display with real penguins. It is a very busy hotel and a lot of people, families moving around so if you are after a romantic getaway or honeymoon I think you would be disappointed.Our hotel room in the ali tower was ordinary. The bed was comfortable, the room clean but nothing to rave about. We had a balcony with a partial ocean view that was nice. It wasn't cheap though. The staff were helpful  friendly. When we arrived the computers were down and we had to wait for about half an hour to check in  they upgraded our room because of the inconvience, so we appreciated that. This hotel is within good walking distance to the main shopping area in Waikiki  only a trolley ride away from the Ala Moana Shopping Centre.

<Author>FrankyA97
<Content>It'sa Hilton We stayed here for three nights in May 2007. Travelled to pick up some of the sights and had limited time in the complex itself, although, if you wanted to, you could easily spend your whole day within the hotel. You can walk and the grounds are very attractively laid out and beautifully maintained. The staff were very professional and efficient.We can understand the pervious comments regarding prices for restaurants etc in the hotel. However, when on hoilday we tend not to eat in the hotel anyway and usually find it easier for us to eat on the go. While the car park is not a great walking distance from the main reception, it seems a bit mean to make a daily charge for this.Overall this hotel has a very grand, almost palacial feel to it, and guests are made very welcome and therefore not uncomfortable in the 'luxurious' surroundings. We regret not having more time to fully enjoy all the hotel had to offer in our short stay and would like to come back one day!

<Author>jmpatrick63
<Content>Another fabulous vacation at the HHV! We spent two weeks at the HHV in July of 2008. This was our third trip to the islands and our second stay at the HHV. Despite having a party of seven, including three seniors and two small children, we had a fabulous time. We stayed in the Alii Tower, which really is worth the extra money. The staff was spendid. We never encountered a single rude employee anywhere. Just the opposite, actually. The rooms were clean and well-appointed. Since we traveled with several Hawaii first-timers, we opted for ocean view rooms and that's exactly what we got. Our window had a stunning view of Diamondhead, downtown Waikiki and the ocean. On our previously trip, our Alii Tower room was directly facing the ocean. We loved that as well, but I think this was even better. Basically, the view from our room was like a postcard.Many of the complaints voiced here are valid, but as long as you know these things before you book at the HHV you won't suffer from sticker shock. Yes, the on site restaurants are pricey. The beach chairs were $30 a day. With a little effort you can save a ton of money. Skip the breakfast buffet at the HHV and walk across the street to the small family restaurant on the corner. Great food, speedy service, great location. Skip the $30 beach chairs and stop at Walmart. Pick up beach chairs for $15 a piece and keep them in your room during your stay. When it's time to leave just donate them to another family just arriving. You've saved yourself a bunch of money and helped someone else out, too. The ABC store in the Village is a godsend. We stopped several time a day for fresh fruit, cereal, milk, munchies and sodas. The prices were MUCH better than the hotel's. Be sure to save your receipts. After checkout stop by and get your free gift. We ended up with a t-shirt and mug.A big compaint often mentioned is the timeshare pitches. Strong pressure is too strong a word in my opinion. If you ignore them they're easy to miss. On the other hand, if you've got a couple hours to spare (closer to three, actually), you can score some cool stuff. I'm a Hilton Honors member and they offered me 20,000 HH points for just listening to the spiel. Since we were staying for two weeks we found the time. 20,000 points is nothing to sneeze at. If you don't want the points, they'll give you a $125 credit at the hotels restaurants. At HHV prices, that amounts to a nice meal for two.Around the site, the pools were beautiful. The Super Pool chairs fill quickly in the morning, so be prepared to stake one out at 8AM or so. One thing we did notice was they were tagging unoccupied chairs. After 45 minutes or so of non-use they were cleared for someone else. That's cool. If you stay in the Alii Tower you'll have you're own pool on the second floor. Way less crowded, and a hot tub for the adults.The beach in fromt of the hotel is the best in Waikiki. It never got too crowded. Lots and lots of families. Be sure to check out the fireworks on Friday nights. They launch from the sandbar between the Lagoon and the ocean.During our stay, they started an on-site Luau on the lawn between the Lagoon and Rainbow Towers. We wanted a Luau on our vacation and since we had two small children, we opted to try it out. Being on site was nice. Within minutes we were back in our rooms. Since it was a new Luau there were no discounts or coupon offered. That's probably changed by now. We did enjoy the food and the entertainment.I was a bit concerned about the ongoing construction. There was nothing to worry about concerning the new Grand Waikikian Tower, as it was mostly complete. However, they were painting and refurbishing our side of the Alii Tower while we were there, so we had a couple ropes hanging over the balcony for a few days. Not too bad of a distraction. I chalk it up to bad luck on our part.We all really loved our stay and would go back again in a heartbeat.Maybe someday...  
<Date>Nov 13, 2008

<Author>travelmonkey2
<Content>Awesome Place to Stay!!! We loved this place so much we are going back in a few weeks. I do not know why the other reviews give this resort such a bad rap! The staff were very nice and the check in was easy. We were given a room we did not book and within 15 minutes we were in the right room on the 31st floor of the Rainbow Tower. Whenever we needed anything it was taken care of right away. The room was nice and the views were awesome. Of course the food is a little pricey but you are in Hawaii and at a resort!!! I've stayed at a lot of upscale hotels in other cities and the food is always expensive. I guess these other people in the reviews never travel or are used to staying at Best Westerns! I live in Orlando and have paid more for food at Disney than in Hawaii! A good place to get breakfast off property is the Wailana across the street. The property is beautiful and there are a lot of shops and restaraunts in the village. It was nice to be right on the beach and they clean it every morning. You shouldn't go expecting to be waited on hand and foot like you are at the Waldorf. Just go and do your own thing and have a good time. The hotel is centrally located but out of the hustle of central waikiki. Within walking distance to the Ala Moana Mall. Great place to shop. Rent a car for more independence.  
<Date>Nov 11, 2008

<Author>PigPen54
<Content>Good stay Having just arrived from the East Coast of the US, we were so jet-lagged that we only enjoyed the pool and the beach briefly before we moved on to Lanai. We were given an upgrade to the Ali'i tower, which is right on the ocean and also has it's own pool, a plus because the regular pool is a mob scene. The beach is great, soft white sand and plenty of it, an easy swimming beach also.Lots of choices for shopping and dining, I see why people would stay here for a week. My drawback is the construction that was going on in the Ali'i Tower, apparently they are doing work on all the balconies and that is definitely a drawback for people trying to enjoy the main pool.

<Author>coldStPaul
<Content>OK - But overwhelming After staying at a quiet resort on Kauai, this was very overwhelming. It's like a little city within a big city. We actually got lost a couple times. There are 6 hotel towers! Staff was not terribly friendly and not very helpful. The location is okay, but the Sheraton resorts are much more centrally located as this hotel is way at the end of the strip of hotels on Waikiki. The standard rooms are small, no complementary coffee ($1.99) for the little packets in the room. Our room had hair still in the bathroom that needed to be cleaned and there was stuff underneath the bed from the prior guests. Obviously, cleaning problems. Although it is large, this is somewhat nice as there are a lot of tropical and exotic birds and fish in various gardens/habitats. Although we did not take a tour anywhere, the benefit is that most tours depart from here and then pick up at other resorts. But it's a short walk from the Sheraton or Royal Hawaiian.

<Author>BWMan
<Content>Decent Stay....Below Expectations Overall Let's start from the top....Checking in was a less than desirerable experience. I was picked up at the airport by a shuttle and when we got to the hotel I was dropped off at the furthest point from the actual reception desk. I was offered help with my bags but I refused thinking that the desk was very close. Not the case....it was a long walk with my suitcase and 2 bags. When I finally made it to my room I was very impressed with the size and quality of the bathroom and the fact that I was on the 14th floor of the Alii Tower. Although not much of a ocean view it was wonderful to be up that high an see the surroundings. The private bar, pool, and hot tub were great in the tower.The bellhops were very helpful in getting taxis and information on where to go for a decent time in the evening. The housekeeping staff was very suspect considering that when I arrived back from a 9 hour day at the conference my room had been left ajar ever since they were done cleaning. As I opened the door I was happy to see my laptop still staring me in the face so I assumed nothing else was missing. That was mistake that could have turned into a much bigger problem if someone else had noticed that the door was open all day. I did notify the desk within the tower and they apologized.Location is great....kind of away from the city life because you are right on the beach. The location is unbeatable.Eating and shopping in the area was fun but it was soooo expensive. I do recommend two places...the ABC Store located right onsite. Stock up on stuff to keep in the fridge. Also, if you like sushi there is a great Japanese restaurant right next to the ABC store. The best sushi I have ever had.If I was going on vacation I would probably not chose this hotel but it was fine for a convention/business trip.  
<Date>Oct 30, 2008

<Author>georgehenrylee
<Content>poor Have recently returned from a week's stay at the HHV for what was the second part of our honeymoon. The week before, we stayed at and got married at the Wynn in Vegas. This was an unforgettable week with everything from start to finish superb. Firstly,as I had previously read, we were picked up at the airport and dropped off at the furthest possible point from the check in desk. It is hotel policy not to allow you to be dropped off within the drive thru opposite reception. There was no concierge within site and you had to carry your bags yourself for a ten minute walk. Once there, there was no real queue. We were congratulated on our wedding and told we would be given a special room.We had already upgraded to a deluxe ocean view room. Given our key quite quickly and made our way, again with no offer of help with baggage. Our room was 1607 in the Rainbow tower and was a twin room with a side ocean view! Not exactly a honeymoon room. We called down to reception, expressed our dissatisfaction, and after being kept on hold for 15 minutes, were told we would be moved to a corner deluxe room at no extra cost and to wait for a porter to come with new keys and help with baggage. 30 minutes later, no sign of anyone. We walked to the room with our luggage and waited outside the room. I phoned reception from a house phone, explained the situation and was put through to security who shouted that I should not have called them as it had nothing to do with them! 30 minutes later we got into our room, overlooking a building site of the new time share! Again we complained and were offered dinner for 2 at the buffet! being told we had already been upgraded and what more did we want.The hotel is very large,old and unfriendly. Staff do not want to know you, none of the remembering your name and smiling. Also,my wife who is 29 was asked for id every time she asked for a drink,from the same bar staff, and the most stupid thing is that it is only 1 drink per person. When I went to the bar and ordered a beer and wine,they would not serve me untill they saw my wife, who was sunbathing. When she came over, they made her go to her room to get id!The pool was overcrowded, even closed 1 day at 4pm for a conference. Basically, this is an overpriced holiday camp for Japenese tourists.If you are wanting a relaxed picturesque honeymoon or quiet holiday, do not go here.  
<Date>Oct 27, 2008

<Author>Anu1
<Content>didn't meet my expectation We stayed at Hilton Hawaiian Village in Honolulu .........Service is awful.........and everything is so expensive at this hotel..........for a breakfast you spend arm and a leg so you can emagine a price of burger for lunch. my advice there is ABC store on site that is open till midnight buy whatever you need and leave it in your fridge for breakfast. request one cofee maker if you don't have it in your room............. there are lots of choices for lunch and dinner around walking distance.Porters just look at you while your are struggling to take your luggage with your two children and do not even help..........rooms are specious, and clean and maids work hard to keep them clean........landscaping was beautifulbeach is rocky and there are jelly fish in the water, so be careful.when you have seen caribean beach this is nothing. it is too developed for my liking....buildings everywhere........we did Catamaran tour thru American Express travel it was worth it.........my kids really wanted to do Submarine so one of us took them but too expensive for the stuff that you see, it is all artificially done underwater, two ship rack and an airplane and some piramid.......you see some fish and sea turtle around fish rack, turtles were the only amazing thing, they are huge.........we didn't see any dolphines or sharks...........you might as well go snorkling and you see it beautifully......and save tonnes of money.kids visited aqarium and zoo that they enjoyed............

<Author>tricia28
<Content>Sadly, I probably won't return. My family stayed at the HHV from August 22nd through September 1st (a 9 night stay). This is my sixth stay at the hotel and sadly the spirit of aloha and service is gone. Several months before our stay Hilton was bought out by a private investment firm (Blackstone) and they are in the process of cutting all the extras they can to make the hotel look profitable in order to sell it again. Many of the staff members who greeted me in the past had been laid off or simply forced out. All of the concierges are being changed to timeshare staff so don't expect any real help in activity planning as it's all about the sales pitch. This has always been my favorite Hilton and everywhere I went the staff was overworked, unhappy and afraid of losing their jobs. Several of them spoke candidly to me about what was going on at the property. Operators at the hotel twice told me a restaurant on the property was open (and listed as open on my breakfast vouchers) and we walked over only to find it was closed for the entire day because they didn't want to staff it. The line to use breakfast vouchers (I am a Hilton Diamond member) at the Rainbow Lanai was a fifteen minute wait just to put your name in to wait for a table. We waited 30 minutes each day to be seated despite trying to go at different or earlier times each morning. After seeing what was going on we simply chose to eat our meals off property and walked a few hundred feet up the beach to rent umbrellas, chairs and kayaks at half the price Hilton was charging and from much nicer concession operators. The room we had in the Rainbow Tower was breathtaking and it was adequately cleaned each day, but once we left the room, the magic was gone. If you are planning a stay at the Alii Tower, be aware the doorman is gone and the concierges are slowing being canned or forced to sell timeshares. The decline in service is evident everywhere. If you get a great price go, but otherwise wait till improvements are made!  
<Date>Oct 21, 2008

<Author>jl98903
<Content>BIG prices for this big place My initial impression of this property was amazement( particularly after carrying my 40 lb. suitcase to the tower). An absolutely beautiful setting. I was attending a very large gathering of world class scientists, as a guest of one of the scientists. Pre-registration was to happen the day before the event started. However, there were no signs nor information. We finally found a reader board that read preregistration will be held in the Paradise Lounge. Maps of the property showed no Paradise Lounge. When we went to the information center the people there didn't know where the Paradise Lounge was either. The first day of the conference about 150 people showed up for the presentation only to find the room would hold 50 or so. With a couple of thousand people presenting their work the sound equipment seemed to feel the stress, several mics simply didn't function.The 5th night of the conference we attended a luau, for which we were charged $39. There were few places to sit. Finally we found two chairs together after we asked folks to move over. The chairs were so close together that the legs touched...and your shoulders touched the people on either side of you. The free drinks that were to be there were gone. The food arrived family style. Our server told us, as each item was served, you take only one piece and pass it down. (if you took more than one there was not enough food to go around) The entertainment was seen by those sitting very close to it. Those of us sitting away from that area of lawn saw heads of the performers only. I was disappointed to see a very similar presentation the next night at the King's Jubilee. Friday night guests are asked (if they want a chair) to pay $20 to attend the jubilee. We found a rock to sit on! And were told that we were not allowed that barricades would soon be erected and we must leave.Our room didn't have any info on local points of interest...ONLY points within the compound. Nothing about the local bus schedule nor about the free shuttle service. And no shuttle to and from the airport!The room was fine(only a few dust bunnies on the louvered doors). However, I found it to be rather odd to not have a top sheet, only a duvet cover that matches the bottom sheet. We were upgraded to the Ali'i Tower, with a private pool and spa, a hospitality room, and several other perks. No mention was EVER made of where these were located. And there were no signs telling where these perks were to be found. It felt as if one was forced to ask for all info...none volunteered.$12 mai tais! The diner across the street has GOOD ones for $3.25!I felt as if it is ONLY about the buck at this resort! Disappointment is what I feel from an experience that should have been Nirvana!Aloha,Judith  
<Date>Oct 20, 2008

<Author>all4travel
<Content>Remodel on Rainbow Tower My wife and I stayed in the Rainbow Tower. There were fantastic views from our corner room but the refurbishment of the air conditioners was noisy during the day. Some bathrooms were being remodeled also. This was pitched to us as a modest update to the rooms. Granted, they weren't tearing out walls with jackhammers but it was quite a distraction nonetheless. I like HHV and have stayed there before but will not return until there are zero updates going on.

<Author>HaywardDave
<Content>Conrad would be disappointed I travel weekly with my business and as a result stay in many different hotels across the country. I have always judged the hotels by their customer service and I must admit HHV rates near the bottom of my list. The people I came in contact with (especially at the front desk during check-in) were incredibly lazy and made me feel like they were doing me a favor by simply speaking to me. I stayed there for 4 nights: 3 were billed to my credit card and the last night was from my points. By the way I am a Hilton Diamond member. It took the better part of 20 minutes to convince the clerk that I was NOT going to change rooms after 3 nights and that she should do whatever she needed to do to ensure I had the same room throughout my stay. I have combined reward points many times in the past and have never had any problems staying in the same room. I was also disappointed that the staff was not very helpful with dinner recommendations, activities, or even directions. I asked severalstaff members and it was like the entire place just started working there. I truly felt that they simply didn't care about my needs. Granted I am from the mainland, but they should realize that they have their job BECAUSE OF, not IN SPITE OF the tourists. Remember HHV, we don't complain, we just NEVER return. I don't think Conrad Hilton had this in mind when he built the HHV.

<Author>LAURIELLN
<Content>OK Hotel....But Not For Me Stayed at the HHV for 6 days in October. Moved from the Moana Surfrider. Liked the Moana better, although both offered different things, so it depends on what your looking for in a hotel.The HHV is at the end of the strip, so it's about a 10-minute walk to the Shopping District of Waikiki. You can cut through the park located across the street to get to the shopping district faster.Upon check in, there was no line (luckily) but the check in staff was unfriendly, no smiles, and had no answers about their own hotel! I found the concierge was more informative ( friendly), which astounds me because the check-in staff sees more people than the concierge. But, I digress.........The Super pool is bigger than any other on Waikiki, but I have seen bigger pools on other islands. But, for Waikiki, the pool was great. The beach is the biggest on Waikiki also. But, they charge $50-$60.00 for two beach chairs and an umbrella. Moana's are free to guests staying at their hotel. The staff at the restaurants and bars are also unfriendly. Housekeeping said, Good Morning every time we saw them.We stayed in the Rainbow Tower, ocean view. Nice, typical room. Needs updating, but suited me. Tiles in bathroom had somel mold spots, but nothing to complain to mgmt about. I think you're paying more for the beautiful grounds, than for your room. The grounds of the HHV are absolutely beautiful, with Coi Ponds, Pine Trees, talking parrotts, waterfalls, etc. Gorgeous!The air conditioning in your room will NOT stay on if the sliding glass door to go onto your balcony is left open. There is a sensor that shuts the A/C off upon opening. So, no listening to those waves crashing at night.The pool is open til 10pm. Warm enough to swim until then too! The beach has a spot-light on it, so swimming in the ocean at night is also possible. There are no waves, and the waters are very calm on their side. The Moana has a VERY small beach, and its very crowded. But....there are many waves, which I like. Who doesnt want to swim out and ride a wave into shore? But, if you have kids, the HHV has a much calmer, bigger beach. The HHV also had lots of entertainment. Singers come on usualy around 4-5pm, and sing near the 3-bar areas typically til around 10-11pm. The music is just OK, but its something to listen too while your drinking your Mai Tai.Would I stay here again? Maybe....but as a 2nd choice only.  
<Date>Oct 16, 2008
