<Author>letsgo36
<Content>You'd be impressed My wife  I stayed at the HHV 2 wks ago. We are owners @ a Hilton Grand Vacation Club property in Orlando  traded points for 7 days at the HHV resort, staying in the Kalia Tower. The HHV is a 22-acre resort with about every amenity you can think of. Our unit had a huge living/dining room, full kitchen, nice size bath, large king bdrm, and 2 lanai balconies. The HHV is on the north end of Waikiki, in my opinion the best part of Waikiki beach, certainly the widest beach. Waikiki Beach gets pretty narrow farther south where other hotel complexes are situated. HHV offers beach/pool towels free, free poolside chairs, but you have to pay for renting lounge chairs  umbrellas for the beach. ($15 for lounge chair for a day) HHV has numerous restaurants, bars (including 2 beach/pool side), lots of shops, even an ABC Store onsite. Don't be concerned that you are not in the center of Waikiki beach, as we walked the length of the beach with no problem one morning, and walked parts of it more than once. I guess it to be about 1-1/2 miles in length from one end to the other.  Parking is expensive so we opted not to rent a car; figured we'd spend most of the week around Waikiki. Did rent a car one day at the Hertz kiosk in the Tapa Tower (one of the 4 or 5 towers in the HHV complex, also just a short walk from the Kalia Tower). I don't think it was overly expensive (about $95 for the day for a Mustang convertible) considering we were in a resort  on vacation  we didn't have the high parking fees for a week rental. Drove the island  had a blast. We also took bus to Paradise Cove one evening for their luau. There are trolleys  city buses to get around. The best deal was hopping on board the FREE trolley offered by Hilo Hatties. Although its primary intent was to take you to their store (beyond Ala Moana shopping center), it ran pretty much the length of Waikiki beach and past many of the other Waikiki shopping  eating districts, and you could jump on  off when you pleased. (The day we left HI, though, I read that Hilo Hattie's filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, so they may be discontinuing their free trolley, but it's worth checking out if you go.) Food in HI is expensive, even if you buy it and cook yourself. If you were local, maybe you would know the cheaper stores, but groceries in stores near Waikiki is expensive. We generally ate 1 meal a day at restaurants in HHV as well as in other places on the beach, and it was costly, but what the heck, it was vacation! For a cheaper alternative check out local places. We ate once at a place across the street from the HHV, a local diner-type place, (Wahaini's or something like that?)  it was good food. We also had lunch at Giovanni's on the north shore, excellent shrimp, but don't get turned off by the looks of the place. It's a white box truck type like you'd see at a county fair. But a local couple recommended it to us and it was very good.Some comments say they heard lots of noise as the newest HHV tower is being built, but we didn't, but then it is almost complete. The only negatives I can think of for HHV is that our particular lanai, although we had two of them, were quite small, crowded if you put both lanai chairs on them. I think the check-in/out staff could have been friendlier, but they were quite efficient, as we had our room key within 2-3 minutes of arrival. The lounge chairs around the main pool were a bit crowded.Plusses, besides all the shopping  dining options included: the very friendly and helpful concierge desk, the beautiful property landscaping with lots of water falls and decorative ponds, choice of several pools, very responsive housekeeping staff, being right on the beach, quiet solitude of the HHV lagoon, and the proximity to all the things inside the HHV. I'd recommend HHV to anyone.  
<Date>Oct 16, 2008

<Author>MartinK72
<Content>Heavy Construction Work We stayed at this hotel for 3 days at the beginning of October. We had booked it through NWA Lifestyle vacations.We had booked a room at the Ali Tower which is suppose to be the Executive floor of all the towers. Unfortunately NWA did not advise us before booking that the hotel (not only the Ali Tower!) is under refurbishment.As soon we checked in and we arrived on our floor (7th floor) we could see that some of the rooms were under refurbishment. The doors were open, the corridor was covered with plastic, furniture was removed etc. Our room was fine and we had a beautiful sea view. Unfortunately the next morning at 9:00 hrs the drilling started which continued until 17:00 hrs in the afternoon. We tried to move rooms but there was no way to escape the noise. We were told that the hotel is changing all the balconies of the Ali Tower which will take approx. 1 year! Even when we suggested moving to another tower, they advised us that there is other work going on at the other towers and we would face the same problem.The hotel itself is very nice. As far as we could see it was the only hotel on Waikiki Beach which had a proper beach. Restaurant facilities where great and it's location was wonderful.I wish we could have stayed at this hotel but unfortunately the construction work was too disturbing. Our tour operator moved us to a new hotel after 3 days.

<Author>duc748
<Content>Downhill Slide since Blackstone Purchased this Hotel As a Hilton Diamond member who travels frequently for work I spend over 100 days a year in hotel rooms. Most of those nights are at Hilton Properties. I have to tell you that since this hotel was purchased by the Blackstone Group last year, the quality and value of the accommodations has diminished greatly. The perks and room upgrades normally available to Hilton Honors Members are no longer available. Here is a list of things you need to budget if you plan on staying there:-Want to park your car? $29/Day-Want to use the Internet $17/Day-Want a hot breakfast $27 ($11 Diamond Members)-Want to use the workout gym? $20/day-Want a newspaper? Too bad. They are no longer delivered to the rooms are not available on Sundays. -Want to check out a mere one day early after spending three weeks and $4K at the hotel. Nope鈥hat too will also cost you a $100 early departure fee plus tax. The bottom line is鈥he Hilton Hawaiian Village will nickel and dime you to death. This is one of few Hilton's that is solely owned by Blackstone and you can tell by the way it managed. I was treated like a 3rd Class citizen by the Front Desk Manager during my (3) week stay at the Tapa Tower in September.With overall tourism down 15% in Hawaii, there are deals to be had elsewhere. If you are booking a room on Hilton hotel points, I would recommend the Embassy Suites or the Hilton Prince Kuhio. There is one very nice thing about the Hawaiian Village. The pools, entertainment and garden area are great. They are all very enjoyable but you DON鈥漈 need to be a guest to use them. My advice鈥tay somewhere else, grab some cold drinks from the ABC Store (located within the hotel grounds) and enjoy the pools and the entertainment.

<Author>BKKMissouri
<Content>Mixed Bag Stayed at the village from October 4 - 10. Grounds are beautiful, the staff is great, but if at all possible, stay away from the Diamond Head Tower. The rooms are run down. I had to get someone to come in and work on the air conditioning, shower head was falling off, etc.. I was at a conference and had many people tell me that they started in Diamond Head and asked to be moved. I got in too late and was stuck. Upside was, I wasn't in my room that much. Plenty of restaurants to choose from and shopping galore. Just be ready to spend a lot on both. Prices are obviously higher in Hawaii but these prices are high just because of the property. Walk down the street and you will find the same thing for a lot less. Find the ABC store. It will keep you in reasonably prices supplies while you are there. The Roundtable pizza is pricey but worth it. The deli prices will scare you.Rent a car and drive all around the island. If you are going to Pearl Harbor, get up early and be there by 7:15. It gets very busy. Touring the Missouri is well worth it.Knowing that I can get away from the resort dining prices by walking down the street, and if I could be guaranteed that I would not have to stay in the Diamond Head tower again, I would consider returning.

<Author>SiennaSydney
<Content>Extremely Disappointed! We stayed at this hotel for 8 nights in Sep/Oct 08. When we entered the hotel we were very impressed with it. Looks beautiful - lots of beautiful flowers/birds/walkways/facilities etc so we thought we were in for a great stay. But when we got to our room we were extremely disappointed. There were 4 of us - 2 adults and 2 young children. The room was tiny (this was a suite with 2 double beds). The bathroom was disgusting and so small you could only fit one person in it. The room looked as though it had not been updated since the hotel commenced operation. There were no coffee making facilities, no glasses, no room service menu, no brochures of things to do in Oahu. This was the Diamond Head Tower and we did have a fairly nice view - that was the only good thing about the room.The staff at the hotel were very unfriendly and not helpful at all. Because the hotel is so large, staff members seemed to know only about their particular area and were not very knowlegable about the whole hotel. We had spent the previous week on The Big Island and the difference in the service and atmosphere of these two islands was astounding. I would never go back to Oahu and never stay at this hotel again.The one saving grace it had was plenty of shops downstairs and nice grounds. But the beach had shells/rocks on the bottom which was very disappointing.

<Author>PeripateticDuo
<Content>Overpriced and in Need of Refurbishing We stayed at the HHV for 5 nights to celebrate our 10th anniversay - we were booked into the Ali'i Tower originally at the AAA rate for $300/night plus taxes (about $35/night). This is supposedly their elite tower with extras - however, it was anything but. The room was very worn and shabby, stained carpet, torn wallpaper, grimy bathroom tile - and our partial ocean view could only be seen from the edge of the balcony. When I spoke to one of the managers, I was told that this was a standard and aceptable description. I was offered another room with a better view for an extra $40/night, but when I inspected it, it was in the same deteriorating condition as the first.We accepted the room and then I called the front desk that evening to request a change to the Kalia Tower - according to their website, an oceanview room was available for a AAA rate of only $220. The manager changed our reservations (without the $100 cancelation/change fee the first manager insisted I would have to pay) and the next day we were thrilled to move to a beautiful room (and building - all apparently recently rennovated) with a full ocean view. I highly recommend this tower if you are going to stay at the HHV.We will not return however - overall it was not a very enjoyable experience. The price of food was ridiculous - $9 for a mango smoothie - only 12oz! The Italian restaurant onsite was unbelievable - we ordered an entree of veal scallopine that the menu says will feed 2 or more - when we saw it we burst out laughing. It was one very small pice of veal - no more than 2 or 3 oz - that had been cut into 4 very tiny pieces - nothing with it - and the cost was $32! The waiter felt sorry for us - this was our big anniversary dinner - and brought us a plate of really good pasta, thankfully. Our advice is to eat offsite - The Hulu Grill was wonderful with tables overlooking the beach - and the Top of Waikiki revolving restaurant was one of the best places we have eaten anywhere! The prices at each restaurant were reasonable for Hawaii, the portions ample, and the food fresh and fabulous - and both were Hawaii casual in dress.Most importantly, the staff at the HHW was indifferent for the most part. There was no attempt to make the guests feel welcome or special - when we first checked in, I mentioned that this was a very special anniversary for us, and the desk manager (who was helping out with the long line) said Everyone says that - I guess all of you think that's the way to get an upgrade. I said that's not why I had said that - but then asked if there were upgrades available for HHonors members - he looked at my card and laughed and said - You're only Blue - that's very common and not worth much. Hard to believe this person was a HIlton management representative - BUT, after speaking with a few Honolulu locals, we learned that the HHV had been sold to an investment group by the Hilton Family last year, and that they just lease the name. They said that many of the senior managers had been fired and other staff reduced - and that there was a cost cutting program in place. This was readily apparent - the enitre Village was showing its wear and the prices were much too high for the value. The Village was such a disappointment - unlike our 5 night stay at the HIlton Waikiki Prince Kuhio - see our review for that terrific hotel!  
<Date>Oct 5, 2008

<Author>speciallady
<Content>Fabulous Hawaii We have just returned and I couldnt wait to sing the praises of the Hilton Hawaiian Village, wasnt sure what to expect as had read a few reviews before we left. We decided to judge it for ourselves and we were delighted with what we found. It really is like a small town on the beach, if money is no object you dont need to leave the place!! The grounds are lovely with a selection of birds,even penguins! The restaurants on sight are very good but a little expensive. It was our anniversary so we booked the Bali by the Sea and the atmosphere and the food were excellent.We ate at the Japanese restaurant a couple of times that was good too and more reasonably priced. Being British its the tipping thing that can be abit tiresome. The hotel is a short stroll to the main shopping centre of waikiki with many restaurants and bars to choose from. We had our breakfast at the IHOP most days, bought sandwiches from the ABC onsite for a picnic lunch on the beach and mostly went down town for dinner. Our favourite was just across the road from our tower(Kalia) called 'Singha Thai' we loved it and there was even some Thai dancers to watch while you enjoyed your dinner. The rooms are well appointed and have a fridge so you can stock up on your favourite tipple and there was an icemachine(Free) in the hallway. Would definately go back if given the chance. There was abit of building work going on but it didnt bother us at all.  
<Date>Sep 30, 2008

<Author>dreadheadUk
<Content>nice surroundings but hotel far too big. we arrived at night and was dropped off outside by our bus. we had to ask 2 people where reception was. this place is a maze of shops! our room was very big and we had a lovely big bed, the only downside was that the aircon was a bit noisy. it overlooked the garden area and chapel, which seemed to have a conveyer belt of couples going through it!!! but was a lovely view. the maid dervice was very good, we had a smelly shower curtain, but as soon as we complained they were changing it within the hour. there is a safe in the room, but the hotel charge you for using it, so you have to use the hotel safety deposit boxes, which are free, but its a pain not having all your money etc nearby!!!we only ate at the hotel once, breakfast on our first day. DONT DO IT. food was great, but so expensive. there are so many places on the hotel doorstep that do breakfast, lunch or dinner, sometimes all 3!!!! you will save yourself so much money. pools are lovely, no complaints there, and you are entitled to beach or pool towels which is good.the beach is lovely, all be it shipped in from molokai!!!!! the sunbeds are a rip off to hire everyday, we bought 2 lilo's for $4 and used them instead!!!we did a few trips on this island and would highly reccomend hanauma bay for snorkelling and the north shore shark adventures for an excellent shark cage experience. i was not scared for one second and had the best time.i would also reccomend hiring a car whilst here, we didn't and although we got around very easily and cheaply on The Bus, we couldn't really go and explore the hidden gems of the island.

<Author>travelling81271
<Content>Best pool and beach frontage in Honolulu Spent 5 nights at the Hilton and thoroughly enjoyed my stay. There are 2 public pools and although I was there during the schoold holidays, didnt have to battle for a deck chair in the morning. The beach frontage is excellent and the hotel is an easy 10min walk in to the central shops and 10min walk to the Ala Moana Shopping Centre. I would certainly return to this hotel again, though I would try to avoid school holidays!I didnt eat in the hotel but ate at Ala Moana a couple of times (they have several restaurant options) and The Cheesecake Factory in the centre is certainly the most popular option for tourists (but warning..everything comes in LARGE size so you can easily share everything with 2 people!)

<Author>Helen43Adelaide
<Content>Paradise at it's best! We arrived Sept 19 for a 4 night stay after travelling throughout Alaska and Florida for a few weeks, on our way home to Australia.This was our 3rd stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village and it will not be our last.We had originally booked a City View room in the Kalia Tower, on our arrival at 4pm in the afternoon at the resort we arrived at the Kalia Tower to check in, there was no waiting at all. The delightful clerk advised us as we had been there already a few times before that they would like to offer an upgrade to an Ocean View Room in the Rainbow Tower. We arrived to our room a few minutes later to room R1608.It was a lovely and spacious room, with awesome views and a king bed.The check in staff and the bell man was a delight and very friendly and helpful.Infact all the staff we dealt with throughout the resort were friendly and courteous.Many reviewers complain that the resort is too big and too far away from everything and is expensive.Well those who post such negative reviews obviously don' travel much or don't appreciate the spaciousness of the HHV and how being on prime ocean front realestate is a treat.So you have to walk 10 minutes to get to the main strip, so whats wrong with that, a little walk is great to walk off that big dinner etc.Atleast when you stay at the HHV you can't look across from your room and see into other hotels which down on the strip area they are so close together and you have a hike to the beach.HHV is awesome and I will not stay anywhere else when I am in Honolulu.We had no trouble getting a sun lounge around the super pool at any time, the food and cocktails were not expensive at all, infact the cocktails at Tropics were a bargain. $9 for a huge frozen mai tai or lime margarita, it was equal to 3 large drinks and boy it knocked my socks off that I had to go and take a nap.Do yourself a favour and stay at the HHV.

<Author>RwBklyn
<Content>OK but Pricey!! The Hilton Hawaiian Village is an okay hotel. The rooms were a good size, the decor was a little outdated. A fresh coat of paint and some new furniture would do wonders for the place. For the $$ the hotel charges, I expected it to be a little more updated.The best part of the hotel is the shops within the resort. Easy and convenient for last minute souvenirs. The ABC Store is the best place for breakfast,lunch, snacks  drinks. The hotel food can get pricey. The location of the hotel is great. Its an easy walk to the shopping district and restaurants if you don't want to eat within the hotel complex. There's plenty of buses that stop right in front of the hotel and the beach bus is 2 blocks away. Waikiki Beach is adjacent to the hotel so that was good. Now for the bad, the line to check in was very long. The walk from the bus area to the front desk is about a 10 minute walk. Not fun with luggage and kids.We were at the Alli tower and there is a private pool/fitness area for guests of that tower. No one bothered to mentioned that there is an extra charge to use those amenities. The pool was small for the # of guests the hotel has. There's never lounge chairs open unless you get there early or really late in the afternoon.Renting a beach chair and umbrella for the beach is costly. You're better off getting a beach mat at the ABC store for $2 bucks. Even better,when you check in, the hotel gives you a coupon book, there's a coupon in there for a free beach mat if you spend a certain amount at ABC. Do that and save yourself the $. After your stay, just throw it away.  
<Date>Sep 25, 2008

<Author>malingow
<Content>Nice, but expensive, expected a little better We went to Honolulu in May for a conference. This hotel was very busy because of the conference. Our first room was on the top floor of the Tapa tower and it was beautiful and spacious. Though it was a little farther from the beach, the view was still lovely. The following morning after we arrived, we noticed our electricity was not functioning properly (the lights would not work at all in the bathroom and worked intermittently in the main part of the room). We called to have the electricity checked and no one came until we called a second time that afternoon. They told us we had to move because it was a major electrical short. They moved us to the rainbow tower, which was closer to the ocean, but the room was not as spacious or as updated. The water barely came out of the shower head and poured into the tub from the faucet part. We decided not to complain because we didn't want to have to repack everything for another move (we had a 2 and 4 year old along). They did send us a cookie plate with about a dozen cookies with an apology card for the trouble of having to move. We didn't really like the second room compared to the first, and when we told them, they did not offer to upgrade for us.From the rave reviews on this site, I expected better customer service. I'm sure our scenario is not the norm, however. Overall it was clean, our second room was a little noisy (for 2 kids), but it really depends what you are looking for (whether you'll be in the room during the day for naps, etc). I think I would not be happy if I had to pay the price and we didn't get reimbursed for our stay because of the conference. I am giving this a 3 as if I did pay, which is more my honest opinion of the experience.

<Author>Siberart
<Content>Mixed feelings about my stay Overall a pleasant stay, but my what a busy place. Lots of families and travelers like ourselves. If you are a people watcher, this is a great place. We checked in after 8pm, so no wait. The clerk was a bit tired and cranky but so were we, since out plane was late. Otherwise, the staff is friendly and they really keep the place clean and neat. You have to get to the pool at 8:30am, opening, to get the place you want. The chaise lounges are comfortable, but jammed together. Seems since they took out the pool at one of the towers, the super pool gets a whole lot more use. I noticed the table we used each day was never cleaned. Same ketchup stain there for a week, which I thought odd, since there are cleaning people everywhere. The room was pleasant and the beds comfortable. The beach is excellent but the rental for 2 lounges and an umbrella cost $60 a day. THAT IS MORE THAN MY MORTGAGE PAYMENT. Also, unless you are going to be renting beach toys everyday and visiting the Spa daily, DO NOT BUY THE PARADISE PASS. That is the biggest rip off yet. We bought it and really lost money for sure. Also, one sheet says Mai Tais on day of arrival only but the one you get to use each day, says Mai Tais on ....any day. Not a big thing but should be consistent in their message.

<Author>biddersuite
<Content>Great Resort Some of the previous reviews need to be put into perspective. HHV is a very clean, well laid out resort with over 90 shops, several restaurants, and a very convinient ABC store on the premises with very resonable prices for anything from milk to snacks and sandwiches and a very good variety of alcoholic beverages. There are many ways to avoid the high priced restaurants. Some of the restaruants have good prices or early bird specials. If you can't find one in your budget, there are many within walking distance in front of the hotel. Some priced lower, some not. That said, I find it amazing how some dwell on the avoidable negatives. It's a resort on the very best real estate on Waikiki Beach, For that, a premium is deserved. Overall, we found the resort very well run and a bit like disneyland in the respect it felt majical in its intesting and detailed design of its shopping areas. Checking in was not a problem. There are other options for checking in such as their self-help kiosk, a line just for HiltonHonors members, and even online check-in and self-help kisoks at the airport. So those that complain about long waits, are obviously in need of getting with the times. We checked in the HH line and waited maybe 5 minutes. It was a breeze. The room we received for a $40 a night upgrade charge was a beachfront rainbow tower room. It was the best! Lucky for us it wasn't crowded. The views were incredible. HHV has the best beach as it is much deeper and far less crowded then near the Duke statue resorts further down. It's an easy walk to downtown Waikiki either on the beach or off and in my opinion located in the best area close to vast parks and lots of shops and restaurants. This resort is well worth the price of the rooms. Yes, the food and drink can be expensive, but it's there for those that want it, or as I stated, there are options to save if you aren't lazy and walk over to their ABC store. You can get a throw away ice chest and load up for the beach on the cheap. The employees were pleasant and there is a good vibe about the place. We went in Sept, and it was slow compared to the summer months and that makes for a more pleasant experience. In a nutshell, if you want premium real estate on the beach, this place has it and for that expect to spend some money or stay off the beach in a cheaper hotel and walk hundreds of yards to the beach. We felt the rates were in line for one of the most visited areas in the world on the most famous beach in the world. No complaints here.  
<Date>Sep 20, 2008

<Author>skywolfe
<Content>Tourist Trap What a waste of money for awful service. I booked my wedding here - The coordinator was unreachable at the best of times and I'm not even sure what she did in the end. The staff were totally clueless about everything - and also patched me through to the wrong extensions on more then one occasion.The wedding itself - let's see - the minister was awesome, the photographer was awesome... That's it. No chairs, no alter - we signed our marriage license on a binder...The room was small and overpriced. The safe cost money - the internet cost money - room service was insanely overpriced - even for room service. Read the fine print. It cost 1.50 to receive phone calls, even room to room.They told us they upgraded us to a honeymoon sweet - which they did not. I guess they forgot they said that?They like you to also arrive on your first night through the service door area because they don't like the buses (even the little ones) to come near the front door. (So after a six hour flight we got to haul our bags - no bell service here - from the back of the hotel at 1 am to the front - a good ten minute walk)There was ONE good restaurant in the whole area - if you walk out to the main street you can find better food without the resort price. I have been to Honolulu many times. I have stayed in crap hotels, and received far better service, free safes, free incoming calls, free internet, and breakfast. All within a walk to the beach.I guess I took away two good things - the layout was very pretty - but its hard to mess that up in Hawaii. And the Bali by the Sea restaurant gave me an EXCELLENT experience. That is all.

<Author>hb2maui
<Content>It certainly is a village! Six hotel towers with it's own little community of shopping and restaurants, and several swimming pools. We waited over an hour just to check in -- even on the Hilton Honors line! Due to a problem we experienced at another Hilton hotel in Napa, CA, we got a sweet upgrade to a 1-bedroom suite in the Tapa Tower. The lady at the reservations desk said this room typically goes for $1k+ per night. The view was great -- we had 2 lanais on the 15th floor with an amazing 180 degree view of the ocean and part of city. They provided Crabtree  Evelyn toiletries which was nice. The space was huge with a living room area, dining area, wet bar, large bedroom, 1-1/2 baths. Unfortunately, the suite is old and rundown, and can use some major redecorating. Honestly, I wouldn't have paid good money for this suite. The resort itself is beautiful. But lots of children! The beach entry was very rocky so we found ourselves making our way south toward's Duke 's where the sand was nice and soft. And oh, one celebrity sighting -- we saw Tony Soprano in the hotel lobby (James Gandolfini). Self parking is $24; Valet is $29.During our 2007 visit, we stayed at the Waikiki Marriott Resort which for us was definitely a more comfortable stay.Suggestions for delicious meals: Blue White Shrimp truck on Kuhio Rd., Side Street Inn, Ono Hawaiian Food and Fresh Kahuku Shrimp over at North Shore

<Author>re1421
<Content>Nice enough but lacked a certain something! We stayed at this hotel for 6 nights and for me that was long enough. The rooms themselves were great. We stayed in the Tapa Tower and had masses of space, a large closet and 'kitchen' area and a reasonably small bathroom and balcony just enough for two. It was all clean and serviced daily (although often forgot to restock the coffee/tea!!). The drinks were very expensive from the bars as you would expect I guess. Also, the bars shut quite early at this resort. The beach here is less crowded and wider than further down towards Waikiki proper which is good and the lagoon is a nice addition. The pools were very disappointing. Nothig super about the super pool I'm afriad! I had a bad experience with one of the assistants in the Guest Welcome Centre who failed to answer my question and when I asked her again walked off in the other direction!!Overall, a pleasant enough stay but if I was to go back to Waikiki I would try somewhere else.

<Author>leizy1
<Content>What a wonderful place!! Since we are Hilton Diamond Members, we earned enough points to stay 7 nights 8 days. This is a huge hotel. They have about 3,000 rooms in 5 towers and were completely sold out the week we were there. As we arrived, check in was quick. The parking is in its own structure, so drop the luggage off at the front desk unless you like hauling luggage. It is a long walk from the parking garage to the room carrying a lot of luggage. The parking garage is located next to the shops in the middle of the Hilton Village. Parking was pricey, $29 for valet and $24 for self parking per night, but I think all the hotels are in the same price range for parking. We were upgraded to the Rainbow Tower with an Ocean Front and Lagoon view. The view was beautiful. The room is a little dated, but nice and clean and a good size. The bed was super comfy. It had a little refrigerator for drinks that you can pick up at the ABC store. My only complaint was the shower. The shower pressure was horrible. They have low flow shower heads. We had relatives stay in the Tapa Tower and the room was nice, the building is newer than the Rainbow Tower and they did not have a problem with the shower. The 鈥淪uper鈥?pool is big and perfect for kids. They also have a kid鈥檚 pool next to the super pool. The pool is open from 8:30 a.m. 鈥?10 p.m., which I didn鈥檛 understand why they didn鈥檛 open up earlier. They did have lifeguards for the pools. If you want a seat, get there around 8:20 and wait to put your stuff down, or you鈥檒l be waiting for people to leave. The grounds were beautiful. Make sure to visit the penguins鈥?exhibit. They also have exotic birds on the grounds and flamingos. You always saw someone cleaning or walking the grounds, so if you needed anything, someone was always there to ask. We ate at the Rainbow Lanai for breakfast and they were fast. We had complimentary continental breakfasts, but upgraded our breakfast for $10. Good deal. We also ate at the All you can eat crab dinner. We were disappointed in the buffet. They show Alaskan crab on the picture, but they only had snow crab. So check the buffet out first to see if it is worth the money. We ate at the Kobe restaurant within walking distance from the hotel and that was good, my son who is 4 actually was entertained by the chefs, but didn鈥檛 eat much. He kept asking me where the bacon was in his fried rice. I guess he is used to our cooking?After walking around the grounds, I can see why they call it the Hilton Hawaiian Village. It has everything you need, but we did venture off to try different things. We went parasailing up in Hawaii Kai with Sea Breeze Water sports and it was great 鈥?we had friends that had a Entertainment guide so it cost us about $67 for the 2 of us! We also tried the Hawaiian Waters Adventure Park and it was great for the kids. Get the tickets at Costco $25 for adults and $18 for kids. Oh and if you like to try new things, try Giovanni鈥檚 shrimp truck up in Kahuku. Yummy! $12 a plate - Bring wet naps and a sharpie if you can鈥?There was a long line, but Oh so worth it! We had the shrimp scampi and my son had the garlic hotdog that was dipped it in the garlic oil and it was gone within minutes. Matsimoto鈥檚 is good too up in Hale鈥檌wa, if you like shaved ice. There is a long line, but definitely worth it. The cost is only $2.00 for a large shave ice, more if you want to add extra items. We all shared one and it was good.I have to say for a free stay, it was well worth it! We didn鈥檛 go to any timeshare meetings or introductions, we actually just vacationed! What a nice thing to be able to do in such a beautiful place鈥?The only regret, we didn鈥檛 stay longer.  
<Date>Aug 28, 2008

<Author>lassie
<Content>Liked the Ali'i tower and the resort We had booked the Ali'i tower after reading reviews on TA. Fortunately we checked the rates a week or so before leaving and were able to secure a better rate than our original booking. We booked a partial ocean view and a garden view for the week. When we checked in our rooms were not ready (not what you want to hear after 20 hours travelling) but they did not take long and we were given adjoining rooms (both partial ocean views) which overlooked the main pool area and the Friday night entertainment. The check in lady was very nice and other than checking out we had very little interaction with staff, who seemed pleasant and accomodating. I had a problem signing up with the in room internet and we ended up getting charged twice but that was sorted prior to check out. We were not aware of where there were any evening hors d'hoevres and did not need or get the turn down service but that was fine. The hotel complex is large but not that overpriced for getting snacks or souvenirs (ABC store and Whalers are fine for this). There is plenty on the site that you don't need to leave but we did venture out on several occasions. Taxis are readily available from the main lobby and I found them cheaper than those outside the hotel. Hertz booth was handy but very busy even at 6.20am!The fireworks was spectacular on Friday night.We ate breakfast most days at Wailana coffee House across the road, which was the same price for full breakfast as the coffees from Starbucks and a croissant. The Ali'i pool was a good plus as it was small and intimate. We used the gym too, which is situated next to the pool. We asked if there was self service laundry facilities in the complex but were told that we could use the laundry bags but they were overpriced for doing a whole weeks clothes so we went along to the laundry on Ena Road and were around $25 to have this done for us and ready in 4 hours to collect. We paid for 1 shirt to be dry cleaned at the hotel and it cost $9.50 and took a day and a half to return to us.The Outback and Red Lobster are a very short walk as is Tony Roma's in the other direction. You can walk to the shops at Alana Moana. There is a Bubba Gumps there to eat as well.One thing that I noticed about Hawaii was how clean and tidy everything was compared to most places I have visited. Tourism this year was a bit down according to those we spoke to.We thought the grounds were very pretty and we would certainly recommend it to others.  
<Date>Aug 25, 2008

<Author>cit27
<Content>nice beachfront location and propery, but amenities way overpriced RAINBOW TOWER - Great location. Tower is closest one to the pool and beach. Room was typical size with small counter and refrigerator and safe. Clean and comfortable beds, but they are only doubles and not queens. Rooms appeared recently refurbished. The worst part was the elevators. Only five elevators in this tower and the wait can be 10+ mins for one to come (especially going down in the morning or before dinner). In the lobby there were many times when there were 50-60 people waiting.Originally booked with Hilton Honors points into a Garden View Tapa Tower room but upgraded on check in to a Ocean Front Rainbow Tower room with a view of the beach and Diamond Head. Staff at other Waikiki hotels much better - everyone here seemed as if you were bothering them.GROUNDS - The grounds were well maintained with lots of shopping and animals to see. On site restaurants were way overpriced and not very good, with the exception of Benihana. There are not too many dining options within walking distance that is any good. Coupon book that the front desk gives out saved a little. Walking to the heart of Waikiki (International Marketplace and the surrounding areas) is quite a long walk in the hot sun. If you want to leave the village, plan on walking a lot. ABC Store is on the property, which I didn't know in advance. Save money there instead of buying everything overpriced through Hilton.POOL - Hard to find seating anytime after 9am or before 5pm. Especially if you need more than 2-3 lounges together. You would expect a larger pool for such a huge resort.BEACH - The beach is great with gentle waves. Hotel guests can rent a umbrella and two lounge chairs for something like $60. Tube rental was $10 or you can go to the ABC Store at the hotel and buy one for $3. Not very crowded compared to other beaches at Waikiki. Towels are free.ACTIVITES - If you don't book the lei making, hula lessons, or other family activities as soon as they make the sign up sheet available, you will be out of luck.CHECKIN - Very very very slow. Hilton Honors line was no better.TRANSPORTATION - $34 taxi van to the airport. Concierge recommended that over the $9 shuttle service they normally recommend that takes way longer.  
<Date>Aug 22, 2008

<Author>ncr4200
<Content>Love it and hate it We had two rooms for 10 nights with our family of four (kids 19 and 21). The hotel is a machine...but a well run machine. If the guests all disappeared, it would take the staff several days to notice. There is no sense of hospitality or personal attention, but you can't expect it in a resort of this size. The elevators in the Rainbow Tower will drive you crazy - they need about 3 more. Your younger kids will love the place. There are a lot of good reasons to stay here, but if you are looking for serenity or relaxation, forget it.

<Author>Tizbit
<Content>Large, but Lovely We booked our stay at the Hilton through the Hilton Honors Program. 1 of our nights was free. The other nights were about $200 each. We were in the Kalia tower which is closest to the road, but newly renovated. Our room was clean and well appointed with a king size bed and a sitting area with a loveseat that pulled out into a twin bed. Our view was lovely we could see the ocean and what I guess you might call downtown Honolulu. The Spa was in our building so we had a pool in our building on the 4th floor by the spa, but it was really cold. The super pool was a bit of a hike. Our building also had its own check in and concierge which is nice. I liked this resort because the location is excellent. There was a Starbucks in our building. Benihana was 10ft away, and if you don't want to eat ridiculously priced food you can walk across the street to the Wailana Coffe House. The breakfast there is excellent and the other meals are fine. A solid alternative to eating $50+ meals everynight. Around the corner from the Coffee House was Eggs n Things which also had a fantastic breakfast..The Hilton is also close to the shops and Marketplace. Honestly after driving around Wakiki I thought we had one of the best locations on the beach. If I come back to Honolulu I will most definitely stay here again.I've heard some people complain that the resort is too large, but I tend to like mega resorts and I thought everything was super convenient here. I actually found our resort in Maui to be more spread out and more crowded.  
<Date>Aug 13, 2008

<Author>OhioFrugaltraveler
<Content>This was a very nice resort I am a diamond member and have stayed at many Hilton properties over the last 10 years, and I find it hard to believe some people say negative things about this resort. It is not as luxurious as the Hilton Cabo or Cancun, but it is very nice.I stayed for 6 nights on a Hilton GLON award (7-24-08). I was upgraded to the rainbow tower room 2113. It had 2 balconies that overlooked the ocean and diamond head. We could watch the fireworks from our room! The room was twice the normal size with 2 bathrooms and a King bed with a sleeper sofa. There was not a divider in the room. The bed was great and the room was clean. It had a small wet bar and a small refrig. I received free continental breakfast every morning (diamond member perk)for the family of 4. I never upgraded for 10.00/5.00 child. The food was enough to fill you up. The pineapple was great as well as the psuedo krispie kreem donuts. The pool was a little small, but not overcrowded. Lots of shade. The beach was very nice, but the chairs and umbrellas are a rip off. The lagoon is nice, but never swam in it. The resort is very nice looking with lots of animals all over the place. Make sure you see the penguins! Ate dinner at the steak house using an entertainment card (28.00 value). It was good. Walked to the cheesecake factory. Got right in if you go for an early dinner. ABC store on location has ok sandwiches and decent prices on all kinds of things like pop and water. Much cheaper than expected. It did not feel too crowded and I was very happy with my stay. All the employees were genuinly nice and friendly. I would go back in a heartbeat.  
<Date>Aug 8, 2008

<Author>yggep1
<Content>Best Fourth of July Fireworks Show Ever While not a hotel I would chose for just my husband and I, the Hilton Hawaiian Village was just the thing for our four children. Pools, flora, fauna, penguins, and, of course, the beach!Service was great, rooms (adjoining) were fine-really like the refrigerators. Prices of food very steep, but if this surprises you than you haven't done your homework. ABC store great for munchies and juices. We flew in July 1 and figured we'd stay on Waikiki for 4th of July and the Fireworks show that we could view from our lagoon view room in the Rainbow Tower was the best that I have seen in my 40 years. Actually got chills!Activities (lei making etc) were non-existent the week we were there-perhaps bc it was 4th of July week. Beach to the left is good, to the right, rocky. Walk a bit to Fort De Russy for more sandy shore.Overall, a very fun time was had by us.

<Author>Rhine-and-Roses
<Content>Pleasant Stay I left my Waikiki Beach hotel to move to the HHV for the last four nights of my stay in Hawaii. I was crestfallen to see how big the place was, but I was soon quite happy with the decision. I went to check in quite early, hoping they would have a room at 9 a.m. so I could move my luggage from the other hotel. I was surprised to find they did have a room! I moved into the Kahlia Tower (sp?) where I enjoyed a lovely view of the mountains and the park below. The room was really beautiful- lovely dark wook furnishings, quality linens. The bathroom also appeared to be recently refurbished. I was a little disappointed to hear street traffic from my balcony, but it was not loud enough to bother me at night. Kahlia Tower had its own lobby with checkout desk, porters, a Starbucks, and a fitness room. I am sure there were other amenities I've forgotten. There were far more Japanese in the hotel than you can imagine- I heard more Japanese than English. Everyone was polite and tolerant of language differences.As large as the HHV was, it was not as noisy as Waikiki Beach. The beach itself and the pools were crowded, but remained fairly quiet. I loved the little manmade laguna on the side of the Rainbow Tower. The jogging paths around it were an excellent idea.I was a little surprised to find the toiletries included only shampoo and conditioner, with one bar of soap. I asked for lotion and shower gel but none was left, so they either do not provide them, or were out.The beaches and pools had everything you could possibly need for a day in the sun. There were also plenty of restaurants, of all types, although the prices were high. There was shopping ranging from ABC (convenience) store to Louis Vuitton. There was even a post office in the business center. You would not have to leave HHV if you did not want to- everything you need is there. HHV is an easy walk (10 min) to the Ala Moana Shopping Center, although there is also a bus right out front if you don't feel like walking in the sun. It was a lovely walk across the Ala Wai canal.Because of my own mistake, I had two separate reservations for this hotel, so I ended up moving to Rainbow Tower. I was glad I did as there was absolutely no street noise at all. I had a view of the laguna, the ocean, and the marina. The room was older, and not quite as nicely finished, but still quite nice. This room had a wet bar with a refrigerator- great addition. Making the move was painless- the bell staff took care of luggage for me- I didn't even have to be in the room to accept it.I highly recommend this hotel because of its location. It is an easy walk/bus/trolley ride to the center of the Waikiki Beach activitiy, without the street noise. Although it is HUGE, service is clearly stressed and I felt well taken care of.  
<Date>Aug 5, 2008

<Author>explorer077
<Content>Beautiful location but some facilites not as good as they used to be Having enjoyed our time at this location so much a number of years ago, we decided to return for a one week stay. This time we were disappointed to see that some things were not as luxurious. Although set in a beautiful location, The hotel doesn't seem quite as luxurious as it used to be. However, the staff were fantastic. Only informed that the Ali Tower was having building work done when we checked in and were assigned a room on top of a building site. It would have been nice if they had sent an e-mail to inform guests before they arrive.Staff were very good and re-assigned us a room when we spoke with them. The rooms are a lovely size, and very clean but in need of redecoration. Little luxuries such as slippers were nowhere to be found and a chocolate on the pillow (as they advertise) did not exist until the last night,. There was no evidence of turndown service.The pool in the Ali Tower was lovely, but a limited number of parasols.  The are a variety of restuarants on site. All are expensive but the quality of food and service at Bali by The Sea, and the Italian Restaurant are great. We also visited the Steak House, but would not recommend it. Food was expensive, but of a very poor quality and service was no where near as good as that offered in the other restaurants. Although expensive, the breakfast at the Rainbow Tower was wonderful and the staff were very friendly. There are a range of shops, so no need to wander too far and having the beach so close is a definite bonus.The taxi service they recommend for collection from the airport was great. Very punctual and offered lots of information about the local area

<Author>ancol
<Content>Loved this hotel Stayed at this hotel for a week in May 2007 after our cruise around Hawaii. We stayed in the Ali Tower which is fab, you have a separate pool for this part of the hotel on the roof overlooking the main pools. We enjoyed the nibbles before dinner (from 5 pm - 7 pm for Ali Tower guests only). Our room was lovely and clean, spacious and maids would leave flowers and chocolates each evening on your pillow. Staff are lovely and you're greeted with a garland!Hotel is amazing - lots of little shops to wander to. You walk out of the hotel and you are on Waikiki beach - which is fab. I would recommend this hotel to anybody. Hawaii is absolutely gorgeous and this is the perfect place to stay. The cruise was amazing too, great way to see all the islands. We hired a car for the week we stayed in the hotel, but to be honest you don't really need it - maybe one or two days if you want to travel out.

<Author>gashi123
<Content>Blue Hawaii fun in the sun! I had read so many reviews about this property - so many unhappy people saying it wasnt worth it - but I can say all the bad are totally set aside once you sit by the pool and soak in the sun!Same deal as everyone else - wrong room at check in - but we refused what was given and had it amended. Loved our Hilton Honors membership as it got us free breakfast daily which was continental only and although basic could be upgraded to hot meals. Had a high room in the Rainbow Tower building with Diamond Head View which I booked and paid extra in advance to secure. Was worth the $$ as nothing like waking up in the morning and looking out at the beautiful scenery. I would sit out there and read my book while waiting for the rest to wake up. Rooms are tired but are fine and clean. Bathroom could do with a revamp. The services at the hotel are amazing! You dont need to venture far for anything as everything is there. The beach is gorgeous - only hotel with such a large beachfront in Waikiki. There was so much activity for the kids - hula dancing - ukelele lessons - lei making - they had a ball. We bought some sand toys and off they went. Rented paddle cycles which they had fun on in the lagoon. Evening entertainment by the pool every night. Dont feel you need to buy the big Friday night show package. You can see it for free by standing behind the ropes. We bought the seat with the cocktail - but would have been just as happy seeing it from another position. could have also watched the show from our room balcony. Fireworks made it special!The animal life is also amazing. They have penguins!! The village shops are great - lunch by the pool fun - dinners were average. Great bookstore - also a second hand one. Suggest reading something written by a local. There is always something to see or do - or just relax by the pool. Was a much needed rest after a long trip on the mainland. I highly recommend it for some serious RR - especially for families. We will be back!  
<Date>Jul 31, 2008

<Author>podsk
<Content>Overhyped in Waikiki I stayed at the HHV for 8 nights from July 19th to July 26th. My wife , two kids, ages 7 and 9 stayed in the Ali'i tower. I picked this tower b/c it seemed like it had the best amenities, and on this count I think it did.A number of people have noted the lines at check in. I can attest that I saw lines of weary travelers at times from 11pm to 8AM. The Ali'i tower has its own check in so I did not have to deal with this. One suggestion is to sign up for the Hilton Honers program, as there is this is free and there is a seperate, MUCH shorter line for check in.As to the room, it was of good size and we looked out over the courtyard/pool, with an ocean view looking over the railing. The room was of above average size, and there was a mini fridge and two sinks/vanities. The bedding was above average. One quirk was that though they no longer have a mini-bar, the cabinet for the minibar acts as a stand for the coffee maker, but we could have used an actual cabinet for more storage. Facing the pool, I was subjected to the evening entertainment from the Tapa bar. Most nights they had a lounge act playing till 1100. Now normally I stay up later than this, but if you want to go to sleep to get up early to do something, the music may keep you up. It did for me. Also complaining to the management (twice) did not elicit any help.The Ali'i tower has its own pool and hot tub on the 2nd floor and a happy hour with some free appetizers from 5-7pm. This was a nice amenity.As to the resort as a whole, the Ali'i tower and Rainbow tower are the closest to the beach if this is important to you. I found this very convenient. My family and I snorkled and swam at thie beach on several occasions and there was a small amount of fish near the dock. Towels are free, but as noted by some, chair rentals are 15 each and umbrellas are 20 or 25 dollars I believe.We did not use the main pool that much, but it is quite spacious. Towels and chairs were plentiful. I think the key is not to be afraid to ask if someone has abandoned their towels and saved the chairs the whole day and remove them.The village is designed to keep you on property. There is nothing wrong with this, but things arent cheap. Breakfast for a family of 4 can easily run 50-60 dollars. Meanwhile across the street is a popular breakfast spot, where you can eat for half that amount.Another annoyance I had with the property was parking. 25 dollars a day for self and 29 for valet. Are you kidding me? At least they didn't tack on the ubiquitous resort fee.Don't get me wrong, there is nothing horrible about the hlton. The grounds are well kept. The room I stayed in was clean and well maintained. The pool and beach are clean and easily accessible. It just wasn't that special a place to spend a week in paradise.  
<Date>Jul 28, 2008
<Rating>3	1	4	4	4	2	4	3	
<Aspects>

<Author>TravelForLifeNow
<Content>Stay away YOU WILL BE DISAPPOINTEDAs a seasoned and well traveled person, I don't mind spending a lot of money on high quailty travel. From the minute my family and I arrived at the resort I wanted to leave. Since check-in is 3 pm and we didn't arrive to the resort until 7:30 pm I didn't expect any problems - WRONG! Our room was not ready until after 10 pm. We didn't get the room catogory or floor level that I requested when I made my reservation 7 months earlier. The staff is rude and unaccomdating. The food is horrible and extremely over-priced. This hotel is a nickle and dime hotel - they charge for everything  it's all expensive- fitness room, business center, in-room safe deposit boxes, beach chairs, etc - be prepared. The beach is ok at best. You will be continually harassed to take a 90 minute tour of the vacation club they are building every time you ask a simple question - when you say no they will look at you like you are crazy. Not for the Four Seasons or Ritz Carlton crowd

<Author>CalisunCali
<Content>Don't let the pictures fool you! Don't let the pictures fool you! My family checked into this hotel for our four-day vacation stay after waiting in line for almost an hour. When we finally got to our room, we were very disappointed with the old outdated one bedroom suite located in the Diamond Head Tower. It had poorly patched up walls and doors. The bathroom was very small and, the so called kitchen area looked unsanitary with the busted out countertop screen. Moreover, we were even more disgusted the next day after seeing a cock roach crawling along the wall in our suite. We requested a room change, but wasn't able to get one until the next day. Not only did we not rest well after seeing this, but we lost almost a full day of our vacation waiting around the next day for the hotel to place us in another room. Finally, we were placed in a One Room accommodation, but had paid in advance for a One Bedroom Suite. When we asked for an adjustment for the price difference between these two rooms, we were informed by the manager on duty that the second room we were placed in was also a suite, although it didn't have the separate bedroom which we specifically requested in order to comfortably accommodate our family. We have stayed in many hotels over the years, and can't believe that the Hilton sells the second room they placed us in as a suite. While it was nicer and more comfortable than the first room, it was truly just a typical hotel room with a view.In addition, to our issues with the accommodations, the hotel really needs to put more effort into training their staff on customer service skills. Guests pay a lot of money for their vacations and should be appreciated for choosing this hotel over the many other hotels in the area. Instead, we were made to feel at times that we were bothering the staff and/or interrupting them from something more important than their customers. My family and I were really looking forward to our vacation in Hawaii, but we left the Hilton Hawaiin Village feeling unsatisfied, not rested, and frustrated. I apologized to my family for choosing this hotel over all the others...Unfortunately, I let the pictures fool me!!!  
<Date>Jul 22, 2008

<Author>SnickersDetroitarea
<Content>Nice hotel, but not for honeymooners. Let me preface by saying we came here after spending six fantastic nights at the Westin Maui for our honeymoon, and we found the two resorts to be very different. First, the good:The hotel and the grounds are beautiful and well maintained. The grounds were clean, lots of animals, tons of shops (you can pretty much buy anything you may have forgotten right there on the resort), Lappert's Ice Cream is awesome, too! Our room also had a fantastic view of Diamond Head and the ocean. You can also walk into Waikiki, but since the Hilton is on the end of the beach, some people may think the walk is too long (it's about a 15 minute walk onto the main street, Kalakaua Ave). We didn't mind the walk, but if you don't like walking long distances to shop or get something to eat, you may want to take this into consideration and stay somewhere that's located on Kalakaua like the Moana Surfrider.You can organize any and all activities right there on the resort, too. The concierge and the American Express office can book anything, so that was convenient. They will also recommend activities. We went to Pearl Harbor (a must), walked to the Waikiki Aquarium, and did the Oahu Ghost Tour (cheesy). We also went to Paradise Cove for the luau which was ok--a bit corny in the beginning, but the dancing and singing was great!I can't really comment on the restaurants, since the only one we tried was Tropics right on the beach for lunch. It was ok, nothing special, so don't expect too much.Ok, now the bad: When we arrived on Sunday afternoon, we were irritated to find there was a huge line in the lobby for check in, and not enough people working to move guests along quickly. We waited for about 20-30 minutes in line. When we finally got to the front, we asked an employee if this line was normal. She said there were two conventions at the hotel that week and the resort was completely full. This made me think, Well, you obviously knew these conventions were booked, so why weren't more people scheduled to work at the front desk today? It was especially annoying because we had just come from a frustrating and stressful situation at the Maui airport (we almost missed our flight), and all we wanted to do was check in and relax. So much for that.There are also kids everywhere. We assumed this would be the case, given it is the summer, but we hoped the HHV would have some sort of adult pool/area like the Westin did. Nope. We hardly spent any time in the pool because we didn't like constantly being splashed by kids doing cannonballs, and the main pool is also astoundingly small for such a huge resort. We had to put our towels on the grass (?!?!?!) because there were no chairs left. If you don't get down to the pool by 9:00 a.m., forget about getting a chair. Same thing with beach umbrellas. So much for sleeping in! There are a couple other pools, but one pool (in the A'ali tower) is only for guests staying in that particular tower.Our room was very nice...except for the bathroom. The bathroom was extremely pinchy, the showerhead was set way too low (we're both tall) so that we had to crouch in the shower. I also noticed mold in the tile and the sink was rusty. Of course, the state of a hotel's bathroom is not going to ruin our honeymoon. I just thought it was odd that such a nice hotel room had such a crappy bathroom.One more thing you may want to do: buy or bring inflatable pool toys. I looked into renting a simple inner tube to float around in for the day, but it was $10!! I was not about to spend $10 to float around on a stupid inner tube for an hour or so that I could have just bought at the dollar store.So while the HHV is a nice resort, I would recommend it more for families, and definitely not for honeymooners! We should have stayed at the Moana Surfrider (Westin) or the W. If you're thinking about staying here for your honeymoon, don't. Find someplace that's smaller, more intimate, with less children and/or an adults-only area or pool.  
<Date>Jul 18, 2008

<Author>RawwDogg
<Content>Honeymoon in Hawaii... The Hilton Hawaiian Village on Oahu is the biggest resort I've ever stayed at, encompassing 3000 rooms, 3 pools, a lagoon, beach front property, and a complete shopping center with everything for a Louis Vutton store to an ABC Store (Oahu natives will know what that is, an island version of Wal Mart with higher prices). The pros, it's located just a bit down Wakiki, which does mean more walking, but it also allows you easy access to Ala Moana Shopping center and close access to H1 which will take you all over the island. Being so big, you could concievably never leave the resort for food, shopping and the like, but lets be honest, it's Hawaii, who wants to be cooped up in their resort the whole time. The rooms are large with decent amenties, they are in the middle of a remodel like most Hiltons with upgrades to flat screen TVs and heavenly showers. The Mandara Spa at the hotel is a very nice bright spot. Friendly and well trained staff, good amenties. It's not too overpriced for a hotel spa and definitely worth it. I don't usually notice housekeeping services unless they don't do a good job, but this staff was quick to turn around rooms and always had the rooms spic and span. Now the cons in no particular order. Don't be fooled by Ocean View offers, I am a Diamond member with Hilton and I was upgraded to an ocean view room which was really a view of a bay. Which is fine, but don't tell me it's an ocean view room. This hotel is a haven for families because it's so big so there's kids everywhere, at the pool, at the restaurants, and at the beach. Which when you're there as a couple can be taxing after the fifth game of Marco Polo breaks out . The prices at the hotel restaurants/shops are very high. You can't get a burger, fries and beer for under $24 with tip. Which I think is a bit high, even for Hawaii. The hotel is a bit under staffed, twice I called the front desk to have the phone ring for over 2 minutes while finally giving up and the valet takes forever and they don't have call down service so you have to come down and wait. Overall, I had an average stay, a little on the expensive side, but the property is very well maintained, location is good, and the rooms were clean and nice sized.  
<Date>Jul 18, 2008

<Author>flyfis4fun
<Content>Amazing Experience with outstanding customer service! Our family just returned from a wonderful 8 day stay in the Lagoon Tower. Our party of 7 included 3 teens (18, 15 and 12) and 4 adults ranging from 40-60 years of age. We all felt that this was the nicest destination resort we have ever been to and would return there in a heartbeat.The previous reviewer ran into some customer service issues so I would like to take a moment and praise the staff. They were always friendly and very helpful to our family. We chose a late flight home and inquired about storing our luggage. The staff not only arranged that for us but also offered us a courtesy room so we could change and shower from our last day at the beach before we flew home that night. A lot has been said about the prices here so I want to state that both of these services were at no additional cost and the staff took care of everything.Is the place expensive? It's the Hilton. Need I say more? However, we did find value in some of the services they offered. By using our time share to stay in the Lagoon Tower we were able to have breakfast and lunch in the suite and only eat out for dinner. There are also no shortage of places to eat up and down Ala Moana Blvd, all within walking distances. I have to admit, I about fell over in my chair when I saw the $10 price tag for a Mai Tai but we quickly learned that they made the best, and might I say by far the most potent, of any we had on the island. We could get them cheaper next door at the Military resort but they were only $3.50 cheaper and not nearly as good or potent. The resort does have a cyclical pulse to it that you might consider when planning your trip. Thursday-Sunday is chaos as people check in and out. On Saturday, our tower alone had 163 rooms vacate and then fill back up. We arrived on a Tuesday and left on a Tuesday and had no lines to speak up and very relaxed staff. The bottom line for us is we loved the grounds, the rooms and the staff. It was a wonderful experience.  
<Date>Jul 17, 2008

<Author>jean8239
<Content>Great trip- very quiet week This is third time I have stayed at the HHV. I was there the third full week in May. I don't know if it was that specific week, but the property was really quiet.I was in the Rainbow tower on the 22nd floor facing the marina- beautiful view. At first I was disappointed that I wasn't on the beach view side, but I ended up thinking I probably had the better view and the quieter side.The room was pretty basic. There was a small balcony, a small rather dated bathroom, and a table and chair. The odd thing was that there was not even a leisurely, comfy chair to sit in. I was there for work, so that actually mattered to me when I had to read through files at night. The positive- steps from the sand.This is crazy, but another reviewer is right when she pointed out that they do not put top sheets on the beds. Very odd. I requested a top sheet from housekeeping and it was on the bed the next day. As always the staff was very friendly, but there were definately some quirks this trip. First- the sheet thing. Amenities were hit or miss. They gave me my free breakfast certificates, and told me I could use them at Tropics and the Tapa Cafe- standard. The the Tapa Cafe hostess told me they weren't offering the free buffet because they were slow and that I could only use the vouchers at Tropics (which is very limited and opened later than I needed to leave most days). A snippy server at Tropics confirmed that I could only use the vouchers there. About halfway through the week, I found out from a colleague that the vouchers were being honored at the Rainbow Lanai, right in my building, and which has a terrific buffet. This was very disappointing to me because either the staff is not communicating at all or I was intentionally misled.Also, the towel guy at the beach was really rude. But I may be cranky too if I was a towel guy, so what the heck.Now that I've vented over the oddities of this trip, there were some very positive aspects. The Rainbow tower is actually very convenient to the parking garage. The front desk staff was fabulous. The folks at the American Express stations who help set up excursions were wonderful. A gentleman there managed to get me a plane ticket and great tour of the Island of Hawaii with only one day's notice.As one traveler noted, this is a hotel that can substitue for seeing the real Hawaii if you want to stay in a sheltered, uncomplicated environment. But you can certainly access the rest of Hawaii if you so choose. There are tours around the island, tours of the National monuments, rental cars available so you can do your own exploring, trips to swim with sharks, trips to other islands, transportation to Luau's. You can walk to the International Marketplace, the Zoo, the Aquarium, boutique shopping and great restaurants. The bus and various trolleys stop at the property. So I really don't know what the complaint about this being fake Hawaii is all about.Additionally, if you just want to chill on the property, you can shop, eat at great restaurants, order huge ice cream concoctions, enjoy the best section of the Waikiki Beach, snorkel, Kayak in the lagoon, take a mini submarine ride, ejoy great pools, great bars and great music, hit the spa, etc. There really is somethng here for everyone.The lines at registration can be long, but that is because busses and shuttles arrive with a bazillion guests who need to check in all at once. Try the zip check in if you made your reservations on line and are already familiar with the property. There is also a separate line for Hilton HHonors members. Or you could splurge on a taxi from the airport and not arrive with the bazillion other people.If you do get a taxi from the Hilton, be assured they use the best, cleanest taxis in the city. On my return trip to the airport, the attendant hailed me a stretch limo for the same fare as a regular taxi. Yes- that was fate or karma or serendipity, but it can happen.Also, for most airlines, you can check in and print your ticket at a kiosk in the main lobby.  
<Date>Jul 17, 2008

<Author>GreattimesVirginia
<Content>Great Place to Stay! We just got back from a week's stay the the Hilton. What a lovely place to stay! I had read a lot of reviews before booking this hotel. I agree with most of them. The Hilton is huge, but that's okay! The grounds were just beautiful. We liked seeing the penguins and other types of wildlife.  We had an oceanfront/Diamond Head view room in the Rainbow Tower. For us, that was the only way to go. We enjoyed looking at the ocean and enjoying a cup of coffee on the balcony in the mornings. We stayed in room 2013. It was large, with a king size bed and two bathrooms! Our original room was a standard-sized room with two double beds. (I don't understand why hotels are going to double beds - too small!). This room was not what we paid for and was moved immediately. Our new room (2013) was quite lovely. I agree with all that has been written about the restaurants on the property. Way too expensive and not very good. A short walk will take you to PF Chaings, Cheesecake Factory, YardHouse, etc. The pools are really my only complaint. Some guests reserve chairs by the pool really early in the morning by placing towels on the chairs. By 9:00, you're out of luck trying to find a chair by the pool! The resort needs to put a stop to that practice. Another complaint that doesn't have anything to do with the Hilton, but you should be aware of, is was when we walked into town to eat each day, we were accosted by people handing out fliers to restaurants and shows. That was really annoying. You couldn't enjoy a pleasant walk or window shopping without a flier being shoved in your hands.The Hilton is right next door to the military hotel, the Hale Koa. It has a lovey, lush park ( Fort DeRussy ) that is great to walk through when you're walking downtown to eat. Very pretty.Enjoy your stay!
