<Author>Helen_RDavenport
<Content>Great view - it's the only great thing though! Stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Vacation Village for 2 nights at the end of a 3 and a half week trip to New Zealand and Fiji (also both Hiltons).This was our second time to Hawaii and we arrived after an 11 hour flight from Auckland at around 10.30pm and had used a shuttle to take us to the hotel. The shuttle dropped us the 鈥渂us and shuttle鈥?stop not the front of the building but we were unaware of this as the shuttle stop is dark and not signposted. So we have 3 large suitcases and hand luggage to get to check in and not one staff member in sight. There were however the bell stand luggage trolleys so we decided to help ourselves as no one else is going to!! We later found out there is a phone here to call for assistance 鈥?but like I said its dark and you can鈥檛 see the phone!This place is huge, think Disneyworld in Hawaii! So after quite a walk (approx 3 or 4 mins) to the front desk and nearly losing the luggage off the trolley at one point only to be helped by another guest, not one of the 3 staff that walked past us, we eventually found the front desk to check in where one of the bell hops was quite rude about us borrowing a trolley for the luggage and told us we shouldn鈥檛 have done it! At check in we met another rude member of staff, who really looked like she had better things to do than serve us and barely grunted at us. My husband is a Hilton Honors Diamond VIP member and as we had paid almost $750 for a 2 night stay we were expecting the usual room upgrade. However, when she did manage to speak the front desk lady told us we weren鈥檛 getting an upgrade just breakfast. So we called a manager over who said we are being upgraded and off we head to our room 鈥?with assistance this time. The lobby area is very pretty with a large open air area decorated with tropical plants and a small seating area and views through the center of the resort over a pond to the pool and beach beyond.We booked to stay in the Rainbow tower in a room facing Diamond Head. The views were stunning and the room very large, I鈥檓 guessing double the size of the usual room as we had 2 balconies. However, the room was extremely dated, I would guess it was last decorated sometime in the late 80鈥檚 or early 90鈥檚, and the furniture worn, scratched and clearly in need of replacement. The sink faucet and drain were brown and rusted and the shower barely spluttered a trickle. It did however have the Hilton Serenity bed which are the most comfortable beds I have ever slept in! There were also 2 bathrooms, a bar area with a mini bar and plenty of closet space. The TV鈥檚 have been updated to Plasma and it does turn so you can view it either in bed or the sitting area. However, the room is so large with a 4 seat dining table in the center that viewing the TV from either the bed or the seating area wasn鈥檛 easy as it was so far away! The room had not been cleaned that well either with smears over the large mirror and glass doors and dust on the bedside cabinets.After our long flight we were hungry and usually in large hotels there is a limited room service menu available 24 hours. Not here, we just caught the soon to be closing ABC store a couple of minutes walk away to get a sandwich and a drink, otherwise we weren鈥檛 getting anything.The view from the room was really its selling point, all the way down Waikiki to Diamond Head and backwards to the rest of the resort. I can only assume they are upgrading some of the rooms as the two next to us had tape over their entrances and construction dust and the hammering that woke us up kind of gave it away too. Obviously its morning and you want to take a shower only there is no shower gel. As I said this was my third Hilton on the trip and they all have shower gel and as we had been traveling for 3 weeks and with current luggage and liquid restrictions flying we hadn鈥檛 brought any of our own. So we called the front desk and asked for shower gel, slippers and robes as these were missing too. After a 10 minute conversation trying to make someone understand we EVENTUALLY got slippers and robes but were told it was hotel policy not to provide shower gel and they had provided all that was required!! So a shower with soap it is. Frankly I was astounded that such a large resort decides not to give a simple thing like shower gel!!! We also asked for bathroom scales to check the weight of our luggage again we were told they didn鈥檛 have any. We later found out that we were lied to as we booked a day room to shower before we left and were directed to a room in another tower which lo and behold had shower gel and bathroom scales, clearly it was too much trouble to get them for us in the Rainbow tower.The resort is really beautifully landscaped with a lot of tropical planting and pools with fountains and filled with fish and many different birds. I did see the penguins and flamingos, now on a personal stand point I don鈥檛 agree with them being kept there as the area was smelly and didn鈥檛 appear well cared for (I live in Orlando and have visited Sea world hundreds of times, I know what they should look and smell like!) and there are also many parrots around the property chained to their posts and open for people and kids to throw things and torment them - and I saw some kids doing this 鈥?so don鈥檛 feel its appropriate for them to be there. It seems the main interest is how much Hilton can make from tourists having their pictures taken with them.Our departing flight the next day wasn鈥檛 until 10pm so we called to arrange a late check out. Again as Hilton Honors members this isn鈥檛 usually a problem. We were told that was arranged and we could check out at 12 noon 鈥?a whole hour later than normal! We were however told we could use the day spa for $8.00 and book a day room to shower in before we left. So we agreed to do this and booked the day room. This however was also a joke. We made our way to the Mandara Spa where we duly paid our $8 and the staff there don鈥檛 seem to have a clue what they are doing and messed around chatting rather than dealing with guests. So we both changed only to find out all facilities are gender specific and we would have to spend the afternoon apart. To top this off a corporate group of ladies had come in and I couldn鈥檛 sit down anywhere let alone get in the tiny full hot tub or even tinier steam room. So we got a refund and left and spent our last afternoon in Starbucks rather than the spa. Had we known this was the case we would have arranged to do another tour.We had complimentary breakfast that can be taken in various locations. The first morning we chose the caf茅 in the adjacent building. Waste of time it was a few cold bagels, cereal and coffee and juice. Not good even for free. The next morning we went to the Rainbow caf茅 and had breakfast and it was delicious a completely different experience. We had also used this caf茅 the previous evening for dinner and again had good service and a nice buffet 鈥?with unlimited crab legs if you like them! It鈥檚 more expensive than the mainland but not overly so and we were expecting this.We used the American Express desk to book a tour; they were reasonably helpful if a little disinterested in you as a person but it was nice and convenient being on site.The beach is of course lovely and there are plenty of sunbeds and a water sports center with surfing lessons. Like I said this place is BUSY, if you are looking for peace and quiet this is not the resort for you, but there is a good variety of eating places/bars and things to do.There are a huge range of shops on site, from high end designers to small souvenir shops, so all tastes should be catered for. The 鈥渧illage鈥?area is good with a good selection of stores and alternative places to eat. The ABC store was especially popular with pretty much everything you could need.In view of our experience on our first morning I asked at the front desk for a customer comment card. They didn鈥檛 have any. So there is a 鈥渕anager鈥?desk in the lobby and was directed to them, after a couple of minutes the 鈥渕anager鈥?decided I was worthy of speaking to and gave me a card which I promptly filled in with my disappointments and that I would be posting a review on tripadvisor and handed the card back to her. Did we hear anything in response to this? A big fat NO. Check out was easy 鈥?only thing that was 鈥?and a great thing they do have are terminals in the lobby with direct links to the major airlines to enable you to check in for your flight online and print your boarding passes.Overall a large, very impersonal resort with equally impersonal, unfriendly staff. Good central location with lots of shops and restaurants on your doorstep and easy access for tours and the airport and great views of Diamond Head and of course the wonderful beach. However, out of date rooms, poorly serviced and overpriced even by Hawaii standards.

<Author>TiredTraveler28195
<Content>Should have listened to the negative reviewers here... Everything stated in the earlier negative reviews was 110% accurate, right down to the outdated decor in the rooms. This may be the largest hotel (compound!) on Waikiki's gold coast, but it is far from the best in terms of service. First - the lack of service. For a place that boasts its world renowned so called aloha spirit, and for the prices you pay to stay here, the staff should be knocking themselves out and doing back flips to make you feel like a valued guest. Instead, upon arriving, you will be herded like cattle into the main lobby check-in, where you will be summarily ignored until the desk agent deigns to speak to you - and only when he or she is good and ready, and THEN only in the haughtiest of tones. Yes, this includes us Hilton Honors members - while we waited in a separate line for HH'ers, the wait time was no less and the service no better. In fact, it might have been worse, because you expect more from the Honors Desk. Nonetheless, after being herded into the check-in area (read: zoo) and made to wait a l-o-n-g time to get your key from staffers who clearly hate their jobs (perhaps a career change to the post office or motor vehicle dept. might be in order for some of these people), you are then given half-hearted directions to your tower. And by half-hearted, I mean, here's a map accompanied by a pointing finger and a dimissing next! yelled out in your face. And yes, we stayed in an upgraded tower - so again, this is not a question of sour grapes - admittedly, however, it is not untoward that one would want to feel welcome at *the* most expensive hotel on the strip after flying 15 hours. Then, as you shuffle off to your room, you will be further summarily ignored by all the other staffers wandering the grounds. Even at the Holiday Inn, staff greets guests with a smile or even simple hello. Once arriving at your room - after waiting 10 mins. for an elevator - you can be treated to an outdated suite or room that smells like smoke, despite it being a non-smoking room, a dirty bathroom with a tub that doesn't drain, and walls so thin you can almost hear your neighbor breathing. You may wish to then go down to the overcrowded pools or beach area, where you can basically plan on remortgaging your house if you want to take part in any beach amenity they offer - nothing is free or included at this hotel, right down to the beach chairs. Best bet if you do stay here: take your rental car to other beaches on the island, stopping at an ABC Store on the way for your beach needs. You'll save $$ and be treated to much more beautiful surroundings elsewhere, i.e. down the Pali Highway to some of those beaches. In any event - the pros of this hotel are its location, which is central/close to the strip; the 22 acres of shops/etc.; and its family-oriented themes/amenities...drawbacks are 1.) first and foremost, the staff - what is WITH these people??! and 2.) the fact that it does not deliver what it promises. 22 acres of shops and beachfront and 7 different towers sound really great - except the fantasy outlives the reality. I would recommend instead the Westin, Marriott Resort or any other of the high end resorts down on the strip. They aren't as big or as exciting as the grand Hilton, but what they lack in substance they more than make up for in service - something the Hilton could learn from.  
<Date>Jul 12, 2008

<Author>blahblahUk
<Content>Love this place I loved this place! We were here for a week as part of our Honeymoon before going to the Hilton Waikoloa on Hawaii Big Island, you can see my review on that place because this hotel was a hundred times better despite them both being Hiltons. We stayed in The Alii tower and I would highly recommend getting a suite in this tower, the rooms were fantastic! the view was amazing on to Waikiki beach, we didn't have a balcony because we were on the top floor but you could still open the double sliding windows and take in the scenery. Also there is a private pool for people in the Tower. The staff were great, really helpful and well presented. The room service was good in terms of cleanliness though it could have done with the cleaners coming in a little more often? Food wise there was a great selection of bars and restaurants and if you didn't like them thereis a trolley bus that goes regularly to take you into town. The only thing I would say is that the bars on site were a bit of a disappointment, no real selection of cocktails or drinks and it was the same selection in all of the bars.I would highly recommend this place, also if you are looking for excursions go to Allied T Pro in the foyer, we dealt with a lovely lovely lady called Mary (ask for her!) and she was excellent, we did some great excurisons and they were really well priced.

<Author>bcreilly
<Content>A great family stay. Our family spent 4 nights here before a cruise and were very satisfied. The check in during the mid-afternoon rush was lengthy - about 20 minutes and the parking garage was jammed We were booked in the Rainbow Tower and were upgraded to a Diamond Head view room without even asking. The balcony and the view from it were wonderful, especially for the Friday night fireworks. The room itself was spacious and seemed relatively new with very comfortable beds. The bathroom seemed to be a little more dated - some rust spots around access panels - and was all in one room, which makes 4 people getting ready in the morning take a little longer. The refrigerator is always a plus when traveling with the family. The huge complex itself was wonderful with shopping, pools, restaurants, wildlife, and the beach all on site without crossing any roads. There was no whirlpool/hot tub in the main pool complex, which I thought was rather strange. The parking is pricey ($22/day), but we had a great rate on a car which made it work for us. We ended up eating most meals at the restaurants nearby as the onsite places were very pricey. Check the room rates often as the AAA rate dropped twice from the time of our original booking until our stay.  
<Date>Jul 10, 2008

<Content>The Best Ever! My husband was returning from deployment and I wanted to surprise him with a relaxing vacation to Hawaii. <Author>HungryDave
<Content>Nice location near shops, restaurants, and the beach We used points to stay here for one night, and had a decent stay. The rooms were nice, although they are old, and could use a new a/c system. The ones they have only go Lo/Med/Hi, and you have it running all day/night, and cannot control the temperature. Views of the ocean were amazing! Shops within the hotel complex were great, and open late for tourists. The pool was cool, but could've been bigger, as it seemed crowded. The breakfast buffet vouchers I got as a Hilton Diamond member were GREAT. Really GREAT! Get there early, and you will have some of the best (and worst for you) doughnuts and pastries, HOT from the oven. I mean, we thought they got them for a Hawaiian Krispy Kreme. Yummmmm. Tons of fresh fruits, cereals, Japanese cool stuff, oatmeal, and more. Our kids liked this hotel as well!

<Author>TheBigW
<Content>Good stay at the Hilton. My family and I came back last week from a stay at the Hilton. We were there for 6 nights and had a wonderful time. The check-in was quick but it was probably because we came at night on a weekday. I did see long check-in lines at times in the afternoon. It took us longer to check-out than to check-in. Eating and shopping at the 'village' is expensive so it's best to go out. The ABC store is a good place to buy milk, snacks and some souvernirs. There is another ABC store around the corner from the Hilton where we found good and inexpensive T-shirts to buy. It's best to eat breakfast at the Wailana Coffe House across the street from the Hotel. We would eat a late breakfast there and since the portions were large, we would skip lunch and wait for dinner. If you need a car, rent them from Dollar.com at least a day before you leave to Honolulu. I would rent the cheapest car from them since many times they would upgrade you anyway for the same price. We got upgraded in Oahu and when we took a day trip to Maui. We found the Hilton employees to be very friendly for the most part. I think the Hilton is a good place to stay at if you have kids. Not sure if I would stay there if I just went with the wife and wanted to avoid being in a place with kids running around. The beds at the Hilton were very comfortable and we got upgrade to a room at the Rainbow tower overlooking the beach. We all slept very well while there. I miss Hawaii and the Hilton already.  
<Date>Jul 7, 2008

<Author>sirrand1
<Content>Great place for families with teens Stayed 7 nights at the HH Village. It was very easy to get to from the airport and is right in the heart of Waikiki. Had a wonderful time. There was a lot to do at the resort itself, including shopping, a bookstore, Starbucks, restaurants, and instant access to a wonderful beach. We roomed in the Rainbow Tower and it was definitely worth the extra money to have a room right over the beach. Our room had a little frig and sink area - great for doing meals or snacks in the room. There is plenty of parking (although it was an extra $20/day for self-parking). I recommend having your own car for getting around, as there is a city bus service but I think it's used more by locals than by tourists. Get hold of a good highway map in advance - or rent a GPS with your rental car - as the highway exit configurations can send you off in directions you hadn't planned to go.There is an ABC store on the HH Village premises for snacks, breakfast food, sandwiches, etc. It's very popular. You are also easy walking distance to an Outback Steakhouse, Red Lobster, Cheeseburger-Cheeseburger, and a great coffee house across Ala Moana that's open 24/7 and has wonderful breakfasts.  
<Date>Jul 6, 2008

<Author>sjdave
<Content>NIce, but be careful with your dining choices Couple of things-Hotel and grounds are very nice. Stayed in Alii Tower Oceanfront room while my brother stayed in Kalia Tower Ocena View- i thought both rooms were fine but not sure the Alii is worth the 100+ premium over the lesser towers. One tip for booking-check the rate with Costco even if it includes a rental car. I was shocked that Costco offered me the same room with a rental car for approx $600 per week less than the best deal I was able to find when booking the room and car seperate. My biggest problem with the hotel is the overpriced and mediocore hotel dining-avoid the buffets-$35 for some of the worst overcooked food I have ever had. The privately operated dining options on the grounds such as Benihana and the NY Deli are significantly better in quality but still high in cost. Your best bet is to go 5-10 minutes off the grounds to the nearby Outback, Island Burger, or Cheesecake Factory-same quality as back home and prices not nearly as inflated-I actually thought the Cheesecake prices looked very comparable to the prices I find at my local one

<Author>lyle47
<Content>few complaints i enjoyed a very nice stay at the HHV. the PROs are many: large, clean rooms that are well-appointed. long, wide, marble vanity in the bathroom and even includes a drawer. our room had two small refrigerators. one was obviously supposed to be a minibar, but it was empty. there is a long, wide work desk and plenty of bureau and closet space. the grounds are stunning. the on-side restaurants are plentiful and varied, as are the shops. the parking garage is large and well-designed with easy in-and-out using your room keycard. nice towels, nice beds. some decent entertainment in the lovely outdoor lounge areas. pretty much a self-contained resort that is a looong walk away from the hustle-and-bustle of the primary waikiki area. easy egress right off ala moana blvd.now the CONs: nickled-and-dimed a bit. ten bucks a day for a wired internet connection seems petty. wireless is supposed to be free in the lounge areas, but i couldn't log onto the one time i lugged my laptop downstairs. self-parking is $22 per day. the gym costs extra. the conceirge desks--there are several--is rather useless. i asked about a fairly new restaurant in waikiki--they had never heard of it, but it turns out it is in a sister Hilton property a mile away and has already graced the local magazine cover. a loooong walk away from the primary waikiki area (which is also a PRO). all in all, though, i had a great stay and would certainly return.

<Author>enjoytravel_8
<Content>Best in Waikiki I personally do not like Waikiki. Honolulu in general is a bit dated...The decor has not changed or progressed for the better. In fact, the whole city still hasn't changed much since Hawaiian Five -O period. However, because there is a direct flight from where we live, we choose to go there every year whenever we need some sun and beach. That being said, out of all the hotels in Waikiki, I believe Hilton Hawaiian Village is the most updated. The room is very clean and not claustrophobic. The services at Mandara spa is one of the best I've experienced. The restaurants are on the spendy side, but you could always leave the village and eat elsewhere. As for the rude Hawaiian staff, I found the poor attitude elsewhere in Hawaii as well.

<Author>MarylandMegs
<Content>Perfect in paradise! We stayed at the HIlton Hawaiian Village for a week in the middle of June. We all loved the resort. We stayed in the Ali'i tower. Rooms were clean and comfortable and the private pool was nice. We selected the Ali'i tower because we thought the other buildings would be too far from the super pool. Rainbow Tower is the same distance to the pool. The beach was beaufiful. Too cloudy to snorkel there. The lagoon was nothing special. There's no need to leave the resort once you check in. The only downside is that food and drinks are extremely high priced even by Hawaii standards. The breakfast buffett was very plentiful- lots of selection.  We tried to sign up for the lei making and ukele lessons but they were already booked up for the week once we checked in. that was a bit disheartening So, try to book early. They have a very limited number of spaces available- not enough given the number of people that stay at the resort.  The tropical penguins were adorable. Try to get to one of the feeding times- they will allow you to pet them.A Catholic Mass and also an inter-denominational church service are available on Sunday. The Hilton has thought of everything- really no need to leave the resort.  We would definitely stay here again.  
<Date>Jun 30, 2008

<Author>andy1954
<Content>Hated The Hilton Hawaiian Village Dont Come Here!I've been to Hawaii a total of 10 times over the past 20 years, and this place is by far the worst place I've ever been to--anywhere (not only Hawaii!!). Just to let you know, I am NOT affiliated with any travel agency, hotel or service. I am a person who does a lot of traveling and enjoys going to tropical locations for vacations. This place is awful. First, it is 4 huge towers. Only one is on the beach. The others are set back. They claim to have ocean views, but you really have views of other towers. If you stick your neck out far enough from the balcony, you get a glimmer of the ocean. The four towers completely shadow the pool--the pool does not get sunshine after noon! I go to Hawaii to enjoy the ocean and the sun, and there isn't any by the pool. The service is arrogant. The hostess(es) in the restaurants couldn't care less if you are there. The beach attendants are worse. I asked for a beach towel and the attendent wouldn't give it to me, claiming they weren't open yet (even though the towels were there, attendants were there, and it was nearly 9 AM, when they are supposed to open at 8:30; the attendant told me they were on Hilton time, which meant that they would open when they felt like it). I went to the men鈥檚 room one afternoon and the Janitor was in there cleaning. After washing my hands, I noticed that there weren't any hand towels. I asked him for some, and he told me they were out. This is a 2000 room hotel and they are out of hand towels? I called up house keeping to send me some pillows, and it took 3 hours. They arrived at midnight, after I was asleep for an hour. I put a do not disturb sign on my door, and so, they called my telephone to ask if they can come in (after all---they wouldn't want to knock on my door, since I had the sign up! Instead, they figured that they could telephone me and that somehow wouldn't disturb me!)I get the impression that the employees truly don't care about working there. They have no pride in their work whatsoever. The location doesn't help. The hotel is near downtown Waikiki and the traffic in and around the place is awful. It takes 30 minutes to get away from the hotel to drive anywhere. One day, I drove around the island to look for other sites that I might consider for future stays. I would stay away from any hotel on Waikiki. It simply is far too congested. The traffic is like downtown New York, Tokyo or LA. It is just bad. I did find two places on Oahu that looked good; the Marriott Ihilani (NOT the Marriott in Waikiki) and the Resort at Turtle Bay. I have not stayed at either place, but they have nice beaches, friendly staff and are full resorts, so that you can get anything you want. I stayed a half-day at both places, just lounging on their beaches and eating their food. I think that the prices are similar (or lower) and you are better off at these places than the Hilton. Unless you have a strong desire to spend a lot of money and get frustrated, I'd recommend staying away from this place.  
<Date>Jun 23, 2008

<Author>Panthersfan
<Content>Kalia Tower is a great place to stay! My husband and I stayed at the HHV for one week while we were on Oahu. We loved it! Here is what you need to know: Waikiki is very touristy and this hotel/resort is no exception. There are a lot of people and there is a lot of activity. So, if densely populated resorts are not your thing and you would rather be in a tent cooking your dinner over an open flame, the HHV is not for you. However, if you enjoy getting out and doing things but having a beautiful, spacious, clean, quiet space with a comfy king size bed to fall into at the end of the day, the Kalia Tower is for you. Plus, the HHV has beatufiful grounds, several shops and restaruants, and it is within walking distance of many more restaurants and much more shopping.The Kalia Tower is beautiful, clean, and QUIET. They have their own check in desk at the tower, so we did not experience the long, rude check in process that some of the other reviewers complained about. (However, to be honest, we did walk by the main check in counter a couple of different times and the line was long and the lobby crowded). When we were in our suite we could hear nothing from the outside. It was awesome! We slept like babies every single night. We had a suite with a full kitchen and living area, and it was the perfect home base for us on Oahu. We rented a car so that we would not have to spend all of our time at the resort/at Waikiki. Our suite at the Kalia Tower was always a great place to come home to because it was so nice and quiet. There is also a smaller pool in the Kalia Tower, so you don't have to leave the tower to go sun yourself. The pool is much smaller and intimate then the big super pool at the resort. However, we were very disappointed that there was no pool bar at our pool. If you like a cocktail or a snack while sunning yourself, no dice at the Kaila Tower. FOOD: There are a ton of chain restaurants in Waikiki---don't be a slave to them!!!!!!!! You don't have to! Eat lunch for the sushi at Todai which is right across the street from the HHV. Ask the concierge where the Chart House is and eat dinner there; it is within walking distance. Go to dinner at the Hau Tree at Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel on Waikiki---very romantic! Aaron's at the top of the Ala Moana Hotel is delicious with an amazing view of Honolulu! Both Aaron's and the Hau Tree are either a very cheap cab ride or a short drive from the HHV. Do go to Duke's on Waikiki. While it is a popular tourist spot, it is a really cool place and the food is good. Since we had a suite with a full kitchen, we ate breakfast in every morning and we ate lunch on our lanai a couple of times. We ate only one time at the HHV resort--at the beachside place. The view of the ocean was fantastic, the food mediocre, and the waitress rude. GO: To the North Shore. It is so beautiful and it is a world away from the busy Waikiki. Eat at Halewia Joe's and/or at Giovanni's shrimp truck while at the North Shore. Have some shaved ice. GO: if you are in the hunt for souveniers and gifts, it is worth getting up early and heading to the swap meet (Weds and Sats) at Aloha Stadium. Much better prices than in the shops on the island. GO: If you have never been to Pearl Harbor, you must put this at the top of your list. GO: Hike Diamond Head. It is a good climb and the views are amazing. I know there are a ton of other places, restaraunts, and things to do on Oahu. These are just some of the things we had time for in our one week. But no matter what you do, the Kalia Tower at HHV is an awesome place to call home while you are on the island!  
<Date>Jun 18, 2008

<Author>tomcat76
<Content>A theme hotel for families with children My wife and I stayed six nights at the Hilton Hawaiian Village and determined that this hotel would be great for families with children. But we do not have children. The hotel offers an opportunity to spend every dollar you've saved for your vacation and more. The nickeled and dimed posts are accurate. Expensive but very mediocre food and drinks. We ultimately decided not to eat in the hotel, except for at a few of the restaurants in the Village section of the property. They have a decent Japanese restaurant, noodle shop, and ... well, that's about it. The hotel dinner buffet was disappointing. At $25 or so (which is on the low side for a dinner buffet on Waikiki), I didn't expect much and got about, if not a little under, what I expected. The breakfast buffet, though, was shameful. $25 for a poor spread without any of the custom omlette, waffle bar, or meat stations that one generally expects for that price. Just eggs in a tub, meat in a tub, etc. And if you order coffee or juice, be prepared to pay around $3/each for those orders in addition to the $25 breakfast charge. My wife and I found that we could walk down to Duke's Canoe Club, a restaurant on the beach -- a half mile or so walk down Waikiki in the morning -- and get all of the services one expects at a breakfast buffet for under $14 each. The hotel was decently furnished, but a little dated, and didn't seem like much of a value for the $350/night we were paying. The beach area is nice compared to the other hotels. The pools are nice, but very crowded with chairs and understaffed by waiters. And be prepared for the $9 so-so drinks. And you can't take that drink you just bought on the beach (or at least you're not supposed to). The hotel offers many accomodations for the beach bum -- chairs, umbrellas, floats, etc., but at a posterior puckering price.Overall, this is a theme hotel, for those who either don't want to take the effort to see the real Hawaii and are content to have a manufactured version at their doorstep (like a Vegas hotel), or those families with small children who need a hotel where they can experience a Hawaiian feel without having to leave the hotel property much. If you're after the real Hawaii, you'll be able to find it no matter where you stay by venturing out on day trips. See Chinatown. See the north shore. See Pearl Harbor. Eat at the places your guidebook advises you to eat. But its a bit of a waste of money to pay for this hotel only to need to escape from it on a daily basis. Its an expensive place to use as your base to come sleep at night. For families with kids, go for it. For older persons who are limited in ability to do long walks or frequent travel, go for it. For young people, singles, DINKS, or business travelers, you'll probably feel like this hotel was designed with someone other than you in mind.  
<Date>Jun 12, 2008

<Author>hulahunny
<Content>Tropics among the high rises Let me start by saying that we have stayed at this property probably between 8 and 10 times. I will start with why we select this hotel. Honolulu is a concrete jungle and although there are palm trees everywhere, you never feel like you are in the tropics until you come to the Hilton. The entire property is Hawaii at its best, palm trees swaying, tropical fish and birds, and beautiful florals. The beach is huge and uncrowded. On a busy day, you can still find plenty of sand space and room in the ocean. The hotel has very calm waves that are great if you are a non-swimmer or have small children. We always stay in the Rainbow Tower because of the proximity to the shoreline. The odd number rooms all face Diamond Head and are preferred over the marina view rooms (although those rooms get the sunset). You really can't lose if you are in the Rainbow Tower. Rooms also have refrigerators which is a huge plus. You can stock up on your favorite items and avoid the high prices at the bar and convenience stores. The location of the Hilton is perfect for us. There is the village that is nice to stroll through and of course there is an ABC store for necessities. Additionally, it is an easy walk to the heart of Waikiki, yet you are a world away from the hustle and bustle of Kalakaua Ave. Shuttle buses are available to the Ala Moana Mall and Waikiki. You can easily stay at the Hilton and not need a car.Now for the things that the Hilton can improve on. The property is getting old and beginning to show wear and tear in the rooms. The carpets aren't as fresh as they used to be, the furniture is dated and worn and the bathroom fixtures need updating. New management has taken over the property and they are really pushing the time share aspect. It used to be that you got two waters per day in your room. Now you get two waters per stay and you need to collect them from the time share (oh excuse me, vacation ownership) desk. If you are annoyed by time share pitches, skip the two 8 oz. water bottles. You won't even miss them. I really think the hotel needs a face lift. The other major properties in Waikiki are renovating (Moana Surfrider, The Royal Hawaiian, The Outrigger Reef, and the Sheraton to name a few) and if the Hilton wants to remain a premier property, they should follow suit. Eventually, it will hurt their return business.I have stayed at other properties on Oahu, but we keep coming back to the Hilton. For the most part, the property is great and the positives out weigh the negatives. If you are in Honolulu and want peace and quiet, this is the place to be. If you can overlook the wear in the rooms, you will not be disappointed. FYI, I cannot speak to the food at the hotel as we have only eaten breakfast at the Rainbow Lanai. It is an excellent buffet and has a large assortment of food. We get the meal included with our room, so I am not sure if it would be worth the full cost everyday. Unfortunately, I have an aversion to hotel food when it comes to dinners and opt for other favorites such as Duke's, Hula Grill, Chart House and the Yard House.  
<Date>Jun 8, 2008

<Content>Lovely grounds! Very nice! We stayed here one night on our way to Australia.The hotel is lovely with beautiful grounds. It is large!! <Author>Tredpositive
<Content>Hilton Large But Gorgeous  Hilton Hawaiian Village is size/capacity of some towns, but yet it manages to be personal and efficient! Want to first thank HHV for making our 30th wedding anv'y/family reunion a memorable week by upgrading us to beautiful suite in Tapa Tower and promptly taking care of every request! We were greeted with congratulations note and fruit platter in our room.Upon arrival bell staff asked if we were checking in, which tower and would we like baggage service and parking. Quickly emptied our vehicle and gave us ticket explaining to give to front desk, they would handle the rest. Luggage was immediately waiting for us with very friendly bellman by time we reached our room! By way, open air check-in foyer is large with sweeping views of Super Pool onto Waikiki Beach, with lush gardens, waterfall, koi river, huge fresh floral arrangements (found all around resort), couches and chairs, bar to right and tropical birds, welcome to Hawaii and Hilton Hawaiian Village!!!Highly recommend anyone staying at HHV to join the Hilton Honors Program which provides many benefits for their members. Some immediate benefits for HHonors members is their own check-in line upon arrival! Honors front desk knows exactly what complimentary items members should receive ie breakfast coupons, upgrades, coupon booklet, etc. and moves their line quickly and efficiently. Do recommend contacting HHV at least week prior to arrival to request specific tower and/or upgrade. There are 5 towers (6th being finished), Rainbow Tower and Ali'i Tower (has it's own fitness center and private pool only accessed by Ali'i guests) are directly on Waikiki Beach with fabulous views down beach to Diamond Head, Super Pool or harbor/lagoon side. Lagoon Tower which is all timeshare placed other side of Rainbow Tower (toward harbor) right behind the newly redone lagoon area with views of lagoon, harbor, Waikiki Beach and resort. Hilton is building Waikikian Tower which will be all timeshare as well, placed back from Lagoon Tower (toward harbor). Diamond Head Tower is behind Ali'i Tower, with Tapa Tower back further with views inbetween Rainbow and Ali'i Tower to beach/ocean, Super Pool, resort, harbor and moutain/city. Back further from Tapa Tower is Kalia Tower with views between Rainbow and Lagoon Tower. Kalia Tower is part timeshare, but has resort fitness center and Mandara Spa. Hilton has very cleverly spread placement of their towers with their individual pools and restaurants, within their meticulously manicured gardens, flowing koi river, waterfalls, penquin habitat, shopping areas, restaurants, entertainment/bars, beach and lagoon to optimise every possible view from room's balconies and windows! HHV never seems to be overcrowded because of it's spreadout layout and so many varied areas.Benihana in village is both delicious and entertaining, also found prices reasonable based on other restaurant tabs in downtown area. Bali By The Sea is magical evening with sunset and exceptional pacific rim food. Rainbow breakfast every morning with omelet station and variety of food was excellent. We upgraded our HHonors free breakfast coupons to hot breakfast late morning, for more of brunch, skipping lunch. Open air beach restaurant at Ali'i Tower was quick good food with great tropical drinks and relaxing beach/ocean views with tropcial breezes. Don't miss treating yourself to ice cream store on corner across from foyer/check-in lobby! ABC store near Benihana is great for stocking up your room's refrig and inexpensive quick snacks. In the evening there is free live entertainment to be found at inviting bar areas. Don't miss the Hula show and fireworks every Friday night around the Super Pool! Romantic walks around the grounds, lagoon and Waikiki Beach in evening with torches glowing make for perfect end of each vacation day.Beachwalk shopping area has great shopping, restaurants and bars with entertainment. Ala Moana Shopping Ctr is unbelievable shopping and dining experience. Don't forget to rent vehicle and tour the island of Oahu with it's historical area of Pearl Harbor. Drive East (Leeward Side): hike up Diamond Head (paved/stairs, bring water, sunscreen  camera), snorkel at Hanauma Bay, visit Sandy Beach and if you would like some hiking on paved path with more spectacular views hike up to Makapu'u Lighthouse (again bring water etc). Can drive around top island to North Shore with countless beaches and views. Or drive directly to North shore to Turtle Bay and Waimea Falls Park area another day. The manmade Ko Olina lagoons and beaches on West (Wai'anae Side) are good for families as well as couples. The island of Oahu is rich with natural beauty as well as city life!Highly recommend purchase and use of Oahu Revealed/The Ultimate Guide to Honolulu, Waikiki  Beyond guidebook. We found it to be accurate and essential with directions, reviews and suggestions!HHV is very centrally located for touring Oahu and enjoying downtown areas. It's also very convenient from Honolulu Airport. We hope you try HHV and find it as unforgettable of a vacation experience as we did.  
<Date>Jun 7, 2008

<Author>pinkwater
<Content>FANTASTIC! Right on the beach with a great pool This was a fantastic hotel. I knew it would be since it was a Hilton and the list of amenities is endless. This was my first trip to Hawaii. We booked the Hilton for only one night as we were boarding a cruise ship the next day. As we pulled up to the front of the hotel, there were cute tiki torches all lit up to greet us. Our room was perfect with a great view overlooking the huge pool and beach. The hotel is right on Waikiki Beach and there were lots of people out enjoying the beach. My only complaint is that it's a very kid friendly hotel. Lots of kids in the water hogging up your pool space. Oh, well. I would definitely stay here again. Overall it was fabulous!

<Author>KitKate68
<Content>Excellent choice for families We stayed at the Diamond Head tower with a view of the ocean. It was a very comfortable, quiet room with a beautiful view. Our two children, ages 9 and 11, had a blast at the resort, taking surfing lessons, hanging out at the beach, and exploring the resort which is quite large. They got a kick out of the resort's animal residents, the tropical penguins, flamingoes, parrots, and more. The resort staff are extremely helpful--they showed us how to get to where we wanted to go. Public transportation is a breeze, whether by city bus or trolley. The only drawback: the high prices. This wasn't just the resort--Hawaii in general is very costly, partly due to high gas prices (since they have to fly so much into the islands from elsewhere). You have to be prepared to spend more than you ever thought possible! Compared with this vacation, Disney World was downright affordable (we went there last year, in May '07). But it was a spectacular experience, and well worth the high price. I highly recommend this resort.  
<Date>Jun 3, 2008

<Author>olymatsu
<Content>A very comfortable resort We just returned from six nights at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. We had a great time! The place is huge, clean, and very well maintained. Everything we experienced was top quality, the carp ponds and birds are outstanding. The only reason I'm not giving them 5 stars is that I felt nickel and dimed at times. Some of the conceirges seemed more interested in selling me timeshares than giving me information, but others were very helpful. Something like $30 to rent an umbrella for the day (we bought one for $19 at the ABC store, it was smaller and we had to rig it up ourselves, but it worked), and $15 per beach chair for the beach seemed excessive to me for guests of the over $300/night rooms. Things like no free internet, $4 muffins, $3.50 sodas, and $25 for a chair at the friday night parade all added up quick. And the place is so huge it was inconvenient to get off the grounds to eat.On the other hand the place is so huge that you never have to leave, and once you stop worrying about the constant outflow of money, it's a very nice, clean, safe place to spend relaxing time with the family at the beach or pool by day, or walking the torchlit grounds at night, or just sitting on our balcony in the rainbow tower looking out at diamond head and down at the beach. Everyone told us Waikiki was a terrible beach, but the beach by the hotel was wide enough that we easily found a nice spot, and the reef and jetty there made it calm enough for kids to swim. We did walk down to central waikiki and it the beach was much narrower with more people and crashing surf, I wouldn't have wanted to lay on the beach there, but the hilton beach was relaxing, albeit crowded, but hey, it's waikiki.The polynesian parade was fun, you can sign up your small kids to lead in with the parade, and they get to sit up front without the $25 charge for poolside seating, my five year old daughter loved being in the parade. The hula and firedancers were entertaining if contrived, and the fireworks were nice.Is the Hilton Hawaiian Village at Waikiki the most touristy spot on the planet? Perhaps. Does it cost $50 every time you turn around? Definitely. But if you can embrace your inner tourist and enjoy it for what it is, you'll have a great time. I will return, but probably for 3 or 4 nights next time on my way to (or from) more off the beaten path locales.  
<Date>May 30, 2008
<Rating>4	3	5	5	5	4	4	-1	
<Aspects>

<Author>AnnGables
<Content>The Best Place to Stay in Waikiki I have tried every beach front hotel in Waikiki and none of them can compare to Hilton Hawaiian Village. It has the widest stretch of beach. If you look at an aerial view of Waikiki Beach, you will be amazed at how large the beach is. Plus is always uncrowded. The hotel grounds are beautiful with ponds, waterfalls, lush foilage and lots of wildlife...even a pond of African penguins. They are so cute. They have a little one named Baby Mana that they even have a stuffed animal that you can get when you just eat 5 meals at the hotel. We got several of them for the kids and they were thrilled. I really don't know why so many of hte reviews say that the food is so expensive at the resort. It is simply not true. The resort has a variety of places to eat. We counted 18 different places to eat and they ranged from a beautiful beach front restaurant called the Bali by the Sea (the food and views are excellent). If you've never tasted island pacific rim cooking, you have to try the food at Bali by the Sea. They have two more ocean front restaurants that are very affordable: a steak and seafood restaurant and a coffee shop type restaurant called Rainbow Lanai. Other restaurants include Benihana, Sergios Italian Restaurant, Roundtable Pizza, a deli, a Japanese restaurant, a beach cafe and others. Here's another tip: the hotel has great kids meals (very large) and only cost $7.50 and they give they a cute toy with it. The kids wanted to go back everyday. We did most days but also went to other restaurants at the hotel and outside. Don't forget to use the great coupon book that they give you at the front desk. it has great discounts at all the restaurants and the 80 shops at the hotel. The best things about the resort are these:1) It is on the largest, uncrowded beach 2) It has the largest ocean front pool and there are about five other pools that you can use all over the resort. They are also building another pool with water slides. All of the other hotels in Waikiki have postage stamp sized pools.3) There is a huge ocean fed lagoon at the hotel that you can kayak in or ride watertoys in. It is fabulous for little kids and only 5 feet deep. We had so much fun there.4) Beautiful grounds5) Very nice staff that are always willing to help. We have made some great friends there. There's a waitress named Kacie at the Hau tree bar that sings when she speaks. She is a sweetie pie. 6) Safe. The hotel is actually a resort on 22 acres and is set apart from the crowded busy side of Waikiki. It's fun to go to that side, but it is nice to come back to the quiet Hilton Hawaiian Village. 7) there is so much to do at the resort. They have a great chldren's program that my kids just love. 8) Rooms are nice (Hilton does a good job)9) Stay on a Friday night. There is a great Hawaiain hula show with fire dancers that takes place at the pool. It is cheap. Only $25 per person and includes a free Mai Tai or soft drink.. The best thing is that it ends with a huge fireworks show over the beach. We were amazed. It was beautiful and it happens every Friday night right there. If you don't want to go to the show, you can watch the fireworks from the beach or from your guest room.I would highly recommend this resort because it is clean, safe, fun and great value. Remember, you're going on vacation and you're going to spend money. I found that the hotel went out of its ways to make it possible for families to have a great afflordable vacations. You can't go wrong with this place!!! You will love it.  
<Date>May 29, 2008

<Author>bechols7773
<Content>Hilton Hawaiian Village, a great property The family and I just returned from a 7 day stay in the Hilton Hawaiian Village and we had a great time. The wife and I were celebrating our 10th wedding anniversary and decided to stay at the village because we were going to have over 12 people in total with 4 children under 11 and thought this would be a great place to spend our 7 days. While the Village is a great property there were a few proplems. We stayed in the newer Kalia tower the newest of the 4 towers on the property and we had an ocean view. The room was average size, a little small for the amount of money the hotel charges, but the view is probably the reason for the rate. A plus about the room is that there was a little mini fridge in the room which would play a major role in our stay. We had 2 doubles in the room which were very comfortable. There was a standard 32 inch TV in the room with many cable channels. But again for the money that was charged there should definately be a flat screen in the room. But that is a minor issue. In the room were also a wet bar, a safe (which you can use for a minor fee) a writing desk and a recliner. High speed internet was also available for a small fee. The bathroom was a good size with a bath and shower. In our tower itself there was a spa and pool on level 4 and a Starbucks and a store selling those miniture guitars that are so popluar in Hawaii in the lobby.  The grounds at the Hawaiian Village were beautiful and big! To get from one part of the property to the other it took a little walking but at least you had a lot of eye candy to look at while you were walking. There were flamingos, penguins, parrots, many types of birds all walking around on the property. Also many different types of flowers, trees, and other plant life. I definately had the feel of being in Hawaii just by walking around the resort. My wife and mother loved the fact that there were over 90 different types of shops on the hotel grounds. So any time we had to walk across the grounds for any reason it gave them an excuss to just look. The only drawback with the grounds that I can think of is the traffic. Because there are a lot of people in the Village there are cars that constantly come and go out of the property. So you always have to be careful that you watch were you go when you cross the street within the property when you go to the other side of the Village. Within the property there are many different resturants serving a variety of foods. There was an Italian resturant, a Japanese steakhouse were they cook the food right in front of you, Bar and Grills, and even a Round Table Pizza. You could also find on the property an Ice Cream parlor, a Hot Dog place and a buffet resturant that was open to the outside private beach. If you decide to eat at the resturants, however, make sure that you bring plenty of cash because they are not cheap. Each resturant is at least 2 times as much as the same type of resturant would on the mainland. Even Round Table and the Ice Cream parlor were much higher then normal. But, I guess that is the price you pay for being in Hawaii. Many of our dinners were spent outside of the resort (luau, dinner cruise and others) so we didn't have to spend the high prices. When we did want lunch we went down to the ABC store right on the property and bought lunch meat, bread chips and sodas and used the fridge in our room. We saved a lot of money doing that. Not that we were being cheap, but i just couldn't see myself spending $30.00 for a kids lunch that they probably would even finish. On the property there were many places to swim. There was the swimming pool hot tub on the 4th floor of our tower. They were a little small so we were only there 1 time. We spent much more time at the Super Pool, private beach and lagoon on the property. Every time we went to the Super Pool we had a good time. We always had chairs to sit our stuff on, there never seemed to be a lot of people there, and the pool was so big we could splash around a little. The lagoon was lovely. Again not a lot of people when we went so we could spread our stuff out of the beach and have a good time. We rented a paddle boat and went around the lagoon which the kids loved. The only drawback with the lagoon and also the beach was you had to rent beach chairs. I felt for the amount you pay for everything they could at least let us use the beach chairs for no charge.  Overall we had a great time at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. They have everything you can think of right on the property and the service was great as well. If a person wanted to they can stay right on the resort and never leave; I wouldn't recommend it because there is so much to do on the island, but you could. The only problems I had with the resort is the size of the room for the money, the price of the resturants and you get nickel and dimed for things that could've been included. But with that said, if your looking for a hotel for the family I would recommend the Hilton Hawaiian Resort.  
<Date>May 26, 2008

<Author>oaktohi
<Content>Family friendly oceanfront in Waikiki The *only* reason we stay in Waikiki is because I want to be near the ocean when I come to Hawaii and we are visiting our family in Honolulu. We spend as little time in Waikiki as possible outside of the hotel, taking drives to North Shore or other areas far from the concrete jungle of Waikiki and eating and shopping away from tourist areas. Even the large Ala Moana shopping center is better ambience than Waikiki, unless you are on the beach! When you don't feel creative for a meal, either walk to the coffee shop across the street from the hotel (prepare for a line) or drive to any Zippy's--and on your way back from Zippy's stop at the grocery store for some drinks and snacks to have in the room instead of paying $4 for a coke and $7 for a beer.Since Hilton Hawaiian Village is away from the heart of Waikiki, the beach isn't too crowded and it's a mix of hotel guests and a few locals. The pools are perfectly nice, not fantastic. Hilton will give you all the towels you need, which is a very nice convenience. We have only been here slightly off season (like April after Spring Break), other reviews have said the quality of their vacation goes down when the village is more crowded. The kids love the pools, the beach, the animals, and walking around the shops.We stayed in a Diamond Head Tower suite. The suites are on floors 14-17. Floor 16 allows smoking on the balconies, the hotel advises not staying on Floor 17 because you are above the smokers. Floor 14 has longer balconies, which we ended up not using because we spent practically all our hotel spare time at the beach or pool. You enter the suite in the bedroom, then past the bathroom there is a living room and the balcony.The view from the suites is enough to know you are on the ocean, but not that special. The best thing about the suites is really having that extra room, especially if one or both of you is awake while the kids are sleeping.  
<Date>May 16, 2008

<Author>peggysue930
<Content>Love the HHV!!!!!!! This is my second time staying at this hotel. The first time I stayed in the Tapa Tower for about a week and had a lovely, but average, Hilton room. It was very clean and the view was nice. But I wouldn't necessarily go out of my way to stay in Tapa again. On the plus side, it was relatively close to the parking garage- which I had to use each day to get my car to get to my work site. The bad- the elevators were always crowded.This past trip I stayed in the Diamond Head tower for 16 nights. I was there for work again, but brought my boyfriend with me as he had just returned from Iraq and had terminal leave. By this time I was a Diamond member and they upgraded me from a regular room in Tapa to a one bedroom, ocean front suite with a separate living room and huge balcony. It was wonderful. We could choose whether to go out in the hotel for a drink or just relax on that balcony in our own little (beautiful) world.Beyond the room, I have to say that the staff was excellent. The housekeeping staff was frinedly and did a fantastic job. The reception staff were extremely friendly and helpful. When my boyfriend lost the waterproof container with his room key and credit card even the manager on duty got involved- calling everywhere she could think of to help us.Here's a funny tip that remained true throughout both trips- the mai tais and tropical itches suck at the Tapa Bar, but they are wonderful at the Shell bar and in the little restaurant on the beach. We had no complaints about the restaurants or shops and found the American Express travel desk representatives very helpful in booking trips.In a nutshell, the HHV is clean, has great views, good service, and is its own self contained village.

<Author>suzq22
<Content>Nice stay at the Hilton Just returned from business trip and a 6 night stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village Resort. If you are looking for a resort like feel this is your place. After hearing stories about checkin- I was pleasantly surprised. It took 10 minutes and I quickly got my partial ocean view room which was quite lovely and clean. All the rooms have balconies and offer pretty nice views. The prices in the resort were affordable for regarding snacks,etc. The breakfast/lunch prices were overpriced.Pros and cons of location:A bit out of the way from the Beachwalk- restaurant row in Waikiki - about a 10-15 minute walk. However, what you gain is pretty much the quietest strip of beach in Waikiki. Not only is it a pretty large beach compared to other hotels down the strip it is also pretty calm water and not full of large crowds.Restaurant Recommendations:Roy's on Lewer Street is pricey but is a must go! We took trips into Chinatown (about $14 cab ride from hotel) and recommend the restaurant, Indigo.Other suggestions:Take the time and rent a car and explore the island- any beach on the island would be well worth it and in addition recommend the hike to the Maunawili Falls  
<Date>May 11, 2008

<Author>yolicain
<Content>Rent a Condo or House instead We stayed four days at the Hilton Hawaiian Village to celebrate our 18th Wedding Anniversary. We had an ocean view room which was nice and comfortable but nothing special. The resort has many amenities, plenty of shops and restaurants, but if you鈥檙e on a budget this is not the place to stay. The beach was really crowded, so we were happy to have a rental car to get out of there. Self parking will cost you $22.00 per day, but it will be more cost effective than eating at the resort, since the food is mediocre and extremely expensive. The island is beautiful, once you get out of the Honolulu area with all the mega resorts and traffic congestion. The hotel stuff were not very friendly, we found it very strange that they never bothered to ask about our stay when checking out and most of them look like they were chewing on a lemon. We do a lot of travelling and we are always willing to try new places, but if we ever visit Oahu again we will either rent a condo or a house. If you don't mind big crows, noise and a prefab experience go for it

<Author>a12barblues
<Content>Great Stay Aloha , my wife and I stayed in the Lagoon Tower which is part of the Hilton Grand Vacation Club 4/20-25. Took a shuttle from airport for $18 rather than the $35+ for a cab and also got a free tour from our driver cousin john who pointed out stuff to us on the way. We were one of the first stops so the ride was about 30 minutes from the airport.  Check in was a breeze and our room was ready when we arrived at around 1pm. Our one bedroom came with a separate living room, full kitchen and balcony with a table and four chairs, which over looked the marina next door (which cousin john said is where the minnow took off on it's three hour tour). Very nice view especially sunsets, howvere it's also the side that most of the construction is taking place so from 6:30 am to 4:30 pm it was very nosiey. So if that bothers you ask for a even number room .  As mentioned before prices our very high even for Honolulu, paid $11 for a pina colada and $4 for a scoop of ice cream. However there are coupon books availble with discounts for just about every store and resturant at HHV. and the ABC store is a must for snacks ect. However if you can't find anything to do there you aren't looking hard enough , from every kind of water adventure to ukeleli lessons. The walk from the hotel to waikiki is about 30 minutes which you can navigate either by sand or street.  If you rent a car from hertz at the hotel you get 1 day free parking which is $21 per day self park. A mustang convertable cost us $100 per day which included taxes. By the way sales tax is only 4%. All in all the property is very nice with plenty to activities both in and around the complex. We ate at Hatsuhana's several times as it had reasonable lunch specials (try the Loco Moco) and the rainbow lanai , which i thought was pricey from the quality , but the service was excellent. We even ate at Roundtable Pizza after all how much rice can one eat! Best advise I can give is just enjoy your self in paradise and take pleanty of sun screen . Aloha  
<Date>May 6, 2008

<Author>tbugvan
<Content>Beautiful family friendly resort We had a wonderful stay at the HHV for one week. It's a great family resort with beautiful, lush grounds and plenty of animals/birds/fish on site to keep our kids fascinated, especially getting to feed them is a bonus. Although it's a little walk away from the busy downtown Waikiki, we love the fact that HHV is a little away from all the peole and tall buildings downtown and it feels more relaxing and lay-back. Comparing to the nice 4/5 star hotels right in downtown Waikiki, we love the HHV much more because of the wide beach access and the bigger and more numerous pools we have at HHV. The local transit, the Bus, is very easy to access and it's just outside the HHV if you want to take the bus to the gigantic Ala Moana Shopping Mall. The down side of the HHV resort is the expensive restaurants, although the Benne Hanna Japanese restaurant is a great deal for lunch with tasty food cooked right in front of you with the skilled Japanese chef doing a very fun show, which our kids loved...don't forget to use the discount coupon in the coupon book inside your hotel room. We would stay at the HHV again next time we go back to Waikiki.  
<Date>May 5, 2008

<Author>nicros
<Content>Loved it I booked a Deluxe Ocean Front Room in Rainbow Tower for 4 nights as part of our honeymoon. Room was not high up (only on the 7th floor) but view was amazing, straight down Waikiki beach to the Diamond Head in the distance.Room itself was average balcony was good sized though. Main pool was fantastic, I did have a pool side massage which was also good. We grabbed a take away from one of the restaurants on property; the variety is fantastic, one night and settled on our balcony for the Friday fireworks.Over all a very good stay, whilst the Hilton wasn't our favourite hotel of the trip, Oahu was our favourite place! I recommend you hire a car and explore the sights of a truly amazing island.

<Author>Gracie99uk
<Content>Ali'i Tower - not up to expectations the Ali'i were royalty. At the Ali'i Tower, you'll experience superior luxury, subtle elegance and personalized services fit for kings and queens (Quote from Hilton Website)A case for misrepresentation I feel. Don't get me wrong I liked this hotel but our experience in general was the same as any other hotel in terms of service ... I certainly didn't feel like a queen! Just one of many ... :)This hotel is huge! We self-parked - easy. Check-In was smooth but the staff could have been friendlier ... the woman at the counter spent what about 10 minutes typing on the computer without saying a word to us ... not exactly a warm welcome. Our room wasn't ready so we went to the Ali'i Tower pool for lunch ... service was very very slow and my deli turkey sandwich wasn't well presented (basically a burger role with a mass of deli turkey shoved in the middle).Pool area was is smallish with comfy pool beds - there is a sign up saying that the beds are allocated on arrival and that you can't reserve them by leaving towels on them at the crack of dawn. A good idea we thought but it wasn't enforced (maybe they only do this in the busy season). Pool was fairly small but adequate for a quick dip to cool off. There is a hot tub too.Our room was on the 11 Floor and overlooked the main pool with a slight sea view (we had a good view of the Aloha Friday King's Jubilee  Fireworks). Room nothing to write home about ... average hotel room ... no complaints.We didn't eat dinners at the hotel (we had hoped to eat at the Village Steak Restaurant but it was closed). We got complimentary breakfast in the Tropics Cafe - bagels, banana bread, donuts, yogurts, fruit selection, juice - adequate for our needs.The hotel's main pool is larger (but cold) but the thing that put us off is the crammed in sun loungers - the hotel has put far too many in for people to be comfortable - unless you want to get up close and personal with a total stranger.The beach is steps away from the hotel and was nice. We also used the Lagoon - I didn't like this area as much.The hotel is a ten minute walk from busy shopping area (high end shops mixed with average joe's price range) and a number of restaurants. We enjoyed the stroll through the park over to the shops each evening. Overall this hotel is large with lots of people milling around but it does what it says on the tin and is a great location for Waikiki. Staff could be a bit friendlier and service in the Ali'i Tower needs to improve a lot before it's king and queen standard. I would still choose this tower though simply for the use of the Ali'i pool.  
<Date>Apr 30, 2008

<Author>touring the globe!
<Content>Great Stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village We just returned from a fantastic stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. I would highly recommend this hotel for anyone wanting to stay in a nice place in Hawaii. The room was very large and comfortable. There is a small bar fridge in the room that you can buy cold drinks/water and keep in there. The hotel is lovely and clean. We were upgraded to a room in the rainbow tower which is the one closest to the beach. Some of the other towers are a little further back, but I would stay in any of them. We were there in April, I think this might have been a less busy time in Waikiki, but there were plenty of pool lounge chairs available at any time of day. The beach right out in front of the hotel has plenty of room (unlike the main part of Waikiki beach which is very busy and constantly has people walking by you.) The ocean was very enjoyable but we did walk down the beach sometimes and went in the water in front of the Royal Hawaiian (the pink hotel) and found that when we went in the water the sand was much softer than at our part of the beach. Not a big deal at all, but it was nice some days to have that soft sand in between your toes!!! As I said, this part down by the pink hotel is VERY busy so I always enjoyed going back to the more quiet part of the beach in front of the Hilton. On Friday nights at around 7:30-8:00 they have a little show and fireworks display which was kind of fun to see.  Our flight didn't leave until 9pm but we had to check out at 11am. We gave our suitcases to the bellhop and were able to put all our valuables (wallet, passports, jewelry etc) in the safety deposit box at the front desk. This was great because we didn't have to worry about our bag getting stolen at the beach with all of our valuables in it while we were in the ocean.  As far as restaurants in Waikiki, we really enjoyed Dukes and the cheesecake factory. If you are going to either of these, I suggest you make a reservation for both as they are very busy. We only waited 5 minutes with a reservation and the couple beside us said they were told it would be about a 50 minute wait. If you are looking for a quiet romantic spot to have drinks and appetizers at night I highly recommend the patio at the Royal Hawaiian Hotel.  Hope any of this helps and have a wonderful time!  
<Date>Apr 29, 2008

<Author>pillowsofwanderlust
<Content>Vegas-sized hotel in Hawaii We spent a 4 day spring break here early this month on a somewhat last minute package through Pleasant Holidays. Although this was our first stay here, I had explored the grounds on a prior HI visit. Unlike outer islands with their large resort properties, space is at a premium in Waikiki--most hotels are like urban hotels excepts with better views. I chose HHV because it has the most acreage and has a larger beach than central Waikiki, a larger main pool, a lagoon, plus lots of shops and restaurants.This is probably the largest hotel in Waikiki--3000 or so rooms in 5 towers, plus a time share tower and another one being built. It's like a Las Vegas hotel, except everything is real and outdoors, and there's no casino, but there are flamingos, penguins and koi. Needless to say, the place is quite crowded. Public areas, however, are well landscaped and maintained. HHV has its own ABC and Louis Vuitton stores and post office. It's not the place for peace and quiet or solitude, but neither is Waikiki in general.The beauty of Oahu is that is has the bustling metropolis of Honolulu with its shopping, dining, nightlife, culture and Pearl Harbor, plus the north, east and west shores with their myriads of quiet, scenic beaches, surfing and outer island feel.The check-in area always had a line--you can save time if your a HHonors member. Our rooms were in the Diamond Head Tower--the least expensive, shortest, oldest tower. I felt lucky we were able to even see the ocean from the lanai. The rooms were quite basic, housekeeping average. There was a small fridge and a coffeemaker, but no coffee pot.  Service on the whole was not too friendly--it's as if the employees are numbed by the large number of guests. We mostly ate off-site because the hotel's restaurants are on the expensive side, and we like to go where the locals go.The beach, while large, is quite coarse in areas, and an offshore breaker means minimal waves--too calm for some. The main pool was large by Waikiki standards but not particularly fancy. The only jacuzzi was at the smaller Kalia Tower pool. The hotel is on the western edge of Waikiki, which is an easy 10 minute walk away along the beach. The Ala Moana mall is a longer walk in the other direction.All in all, a good choice for Waikiki because there's a lot of activities for kids and adults. Just don't expect a highly personal experience (the upgraded Alii Tower may be different). I would recommend renting a car for at least part of the trip to easily access Pearl Harbor, Diamond Head, and the North Shore.My favorite hotel in Waikiki remains the Halekulani with its superior service and calm, quiet grounds. It is more expensive, however, and the beach there is almost nonexistent.  
<Date>Apr 24, 2008

<Author>HotelGuru9
<Content>Rip-off Central Simply put, they rip you off, bad. Parking is $22.50 per day, for hotel guests. Visitors pay $84 per day. A Cheeseburger and Coke costs $35. To work out once, costs $14. Internet costs $10 an hour. Wetbar is empty. Breakfast not included. Enjoy!The parking fee's alone justify a 1 star review. The arrogance required for the hotel staff to have sat down at some point... and agreed that its okay to charge visitors $84 per day... and hotel guests $22 per day... tells me that they are intentionally taking advantage. Parking isn't the only problem...The $22 cheeseburger is met with an additional 17% service fee. On top of that they charge a $6.00 .... per person.... cover charge. On top of that they charge sales tax. By the time they were done, my cheeseburger with coke cost $35.00. Thank goodness I hid my girlfriend under the bed. My burger would have cost $41. Oh wait, it did cost $41... because I tipped the lady. Because she told me the hotel, in its infinite greed, does not give them the 17% service fee. Its part of the whopping $7.00 per hour they pay her. At age 45. Nice.There are no complimentary water bottles in the room. There's a wetbar (and mini fridge) but its completely empty. If you have a rental car, they force you to park in their parking garage at $22 a day. There is nowhere else to park. They have a fitness center, but they charge you $14 per visit to use it. There is nowhere else to work out. They have internet through the television, but it costs $10 an hour. They have no Wifi. Haha!The room does not come with breakfast. Nothing is included. The cheeseburger took over an hour to make. The delivery person told me they have 3,000 rooms and only one small kitchen. She said they once charged a room of 10 people an additional $60 cover charge for their food. The elevator roars like its about to fall apart. The door on the inside is a dark, stale, rusting steel sheet. The beds are amazing. You will sleep like a baby, but only if you aren't under anyone else. Three kids in the room above, jumping up and down kept me awake. Front desk staff acted annoyed, as other reviews here reveal. Changed rooms and ended up with a sliding glass door that creeked every time the wind blew. Four star hotel? Slept with the door open to avoid its movement and noise due to the wind. On its own merits, this hotel might warrant a 3 star rating. However, the crappy elevators, the rickety sliding doors, and the thin floors all show a general lack of attention to detail. A lack of attention that the hotel has no excuse for, given the outlandish fee's they charge for everything. If this place were plated in gold, I would give it a 3 star review despite all the extra charges. But... it's not.  
<Date>Apr 23, 2008

<Author>JSGKBERG
<Content>Great Stay, Great Service, Great Room and Great Hotel We stayed on the property using H.H. points. We were a bit concerned because of some of the reviews and the way they apparently treated others using frequent stay points however, our stay was just great. We were there for nine great days. The hotel upgraded our room to a 25th floor, corner room with a great view of the ocean, beach, and Waikiki strip.The people were friendly, courteous, and couldn't help us enough. We didn't leave until 9:00 P.M. our last day and they gave us another room so that we could shower and get ready for the air port. The food was phenomenal at the resort but a bit pricey as is all the food on the island.I really can't say enough good things about our stay. I would recommend this to hotel to anyone, it has the best beach on Waikiki and the best amenities. We had the kids with us on the trip and they were so happy it was a great trip.Kudos to the staff for keeping up a great hotel. The rooms are clean and well cared for each day!Thanks Hilton Staff!

<Author>IslandTripod
<Content>Lovely hotel in beautiful Hawaii Stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village from April 1st to April 7th, 2008. We chose it for the locaton and because it had the largest pool around. It is huge and is a city unto itself. If you like to shop at high-end stores, then this is the place for you. There are thousands of guests at this hotel at any one time, and it is very busy and crowded. Our hotel room was clean and well appointed. The beds were comfy and it was no problem getting extra pillows. One problem: the birds were overly friendly and came right inside the room. It was amusing for a day or so, until they decided to poop all over the lanai. We were upgraded to an ocean view room at no extra charge. We could definately see the ocean, however, we could also see the parking garage, the sidewalk, and the other tall buildings. The walk to the pool and the beach was lengthy, so be sure you are ready to parade around the grounds in your wet swim suit. Took a drive around the Island, which is a good idea so you do not think that this entire island is paved. Yes, there are some remote and wild areas out there beyond Waikiki Beach!
