<Author>Ladyleah
<Content>Not a bad place- just not our thing..... Greetings!Stayed at HHV w/my spouse (we are in our early 30's) and my parents (early 50's) for a week at the end of March. We stayed in the Tapa tower (26 floor) and they they Alii tower (8th floor).I knew from the get go- from reading the helpful advice on this site- that this place was a zoo-- but I was there for a conference which was headquartered there w/a decent room rate, so this was the easiest place to stay. Although the grounds are quite nice, this place was waaaaay too crowded for us. We actually considered checking out and moving to the Marriott out of town, but didn't want to pay the early check out. We all agreed that we would never consider staying here again, unless you had a few small kids in tow or something. We basically left every day (all day) in our rental car to enjoy the beauty of the island, and hang out its other amazing beaches (FAR better then Waikiki). I feel quite sad for people who don't leave this mega resort-- as they see such a small slice of Oahu!Pros--Location on Waikiki- some people find it removed, but I enjoyed it much more then the downtown area that was swarming with tourist traffic and a ton of shopping.-The rooms were fine, and pretty quiet which was surprising considering the volume of people there. (Not 4 star by any means though)-The ABC store on property --cheap alcohol, snacks, t-shirts, etc.-Pretty grounds, very friendly staff.Cons--Too crowded. Main pool had stadium seating of pool chairs 5 rows DEEP to the pool! Yuk! We only used the Alii pool- and it too was smashed and crowded.-The beach. I admit, we are beach snobs...but the beach in that area (and most of Waikiki from what we heard) is VERY rocky. The water is clear and calm, but we much preferred the soft sand of every other beach on the island-The food on site was not good. Typical bad overpriced resort fare- after trying 3 places for 2 lunches and a dinner we gave up and went to many great places offsite.-Because we live in the NYC area- we didn't find the prices in Hawaii to be bad at all---but the HHV charges just got SILLY- example- eggs benedict $21, a nature tour of the property $25 per person, room services charges crazy prices plus a $6 per person set up fee, 17% gratut., and of course tax. (So you eggs benedict would be $30)...I could go on and on.....($22 parking....)Thanks to the great advice here- we had some of our beach cocktails down at the military hotel next door ($4 as opposed to the HHV's $9 for a mixed drink)-- and got some cheap food there as well ($3.75 for a burger at lunch as opposed to the HHV's $13 burger). We also took advantage of the beach chair and umbrella rental right past that hotel-- 1/2 the price of the HHV ($60 per day!)We had excellent dinners at the Ocean House, and Singha (sp?) the Thai place--great dinners at the Shorebird and Dukes-- good (and cheap) breakfasts at the Wailea Coffee Shop-- and awesome lunches at Teddys Burgers and a little sushi joint in the same plaza.Again- we will return, but we won't be staying at the HHV!  
<Date>Apr 6, 2008

<Author>Mr-Big-Cat
<Content>Impressive Grounds This Hilton property is very impressive and huge. There is heaps to do, shops, loads of pools, boarders onto the beach, bars resturants, free live shows by the pool - it has everything. Staff and Service: I found to be top notch, staff actually looked like they enjoyed working there. Everyone was helpful and friendly and all request were met. Room: Alright, I guess not as good as I had hoped for which I find often happens under the Hilton name. However it was clean and comfortable with everything I needed. I also expected it to be bigger.I probably wouldn't stay here again as there are just better options for singles, under 30's etc for the same price. However this would be a perfect property for familys and older travellers.

<Author>FloridaWanderlust
<Content>Disappointed by the service The Hilton Hawaiian Village is a lovely property in a central location. We were there for a conference and planned to stay following the close of the conference for vacation. We stayed in the Alii tower.The positives:Everything available onsiteLovely exterior propertyThe housekeeping staffBeautiful beach (but crowded)Bell staffThe negatives:Front desk staff at Alii towerAtypical charges (there is a charge to use the room safe)Rooms are adequate only; not 3 or 4 star levelSelf parking (due to the size of the resort)I contacted the hotel directly to make reservations; assuming this would create less room for error. I was assured I would receive an oceanview room (not partial oceanview) with 2 double beds. On check-in, we were assigned a partial oceanview room directly across from the elevator. We informed the front desk staff person that we were assured an oceanview room and she was less than accomodating, emphasizing the excellent rate we had received for the room because of the conference and informing us how fortunate we were to be there for that rate. We were traveling with children, ages 2 and 6. I specifically asked not to be placed near any ice machines or elevators. Our partial oceanview room had no view of the ocean, unless you leaned over the balcony and twisted yourself virtually in-half. After sitting around and waiting for someone to help us, we eventually ended up in an oceanview room with king bed (we were told a king bed was all we could have).We decided to leave this hotel as soon as the conference ended. Front desk staff ignored us when we walked by (holding their own conversations). We were particularly disappointed because thie Alii tower was supposed to be the HIlton's best tower.Because we left early we were supposed to pay a $100 cancellation fee, however we did get the management to waive the fee. We were particularly disappointed overall because my spouse is a Hilton Honors members and has been loyal to the hotel for business travel. This is a good hotel for persons who like lots of activity (or congestion depending on how you interpret it). The penguins, flora, and grounds are lovely. There are many shops and restaurants to choose from. For context, we typically stay in Four Seasons (e.g., Great Exuma, Nevis), Ritz Carlton (e.g., Palm Beach, Amelia Island), Rosewood Resorts (St. John) for personal travel so we have high expectations. Hilton Hawaiian does not remotely compare (we did not expect it to; but we did expect better than it provided). It is a 3 star property at best. We left and went to the JW Marriott Ihilani -- WONDERFUL! If you want rest, helpful staff, attention to detail -- go to JW Marriott.

<Author>bouchat
<Content>No Cost Parking Options!! Just returned from 10 days at the HHV and since I gained valuable information from these reviews I thought I'd add one important one I never read. The daily parking charges are very high and I actively sought alternatives. I found a great one. Behind the large lagoon type swimming pool, directly behind the Rainbow Tower on the ocean side, there is a large parking lot that beach goers, employees, and those in-the-know use daily at no charge. We parked out there every evening and had no problems whatsoever. Depending on which Tower you are staying at, the walk to your room is probably closer from there then the costly parking lot. This saved us almost $200 in fees.Use it and save!!!  
<Date>Apr 4, 2008

<Author>TMF1968
<Content>Great location We just had a one night stay (after our 1 week stay on the Big Island) before our long flight home to Chicago. This place is busy! We arrived on Friday 3/28/08. I am really glad our stay was on the night thay have the weekly Kings Jubilee Celebration.If I had known how nice the show was I would have saved some money but seeing that free show instead of a luau.Fireworks after show can be seen from the SuperPool where the show is held, the beach or from our ocean view room! Lynn at the front desk was very friendly and made us feel very welcome there. Our room was clean and no housekeeping problems. Beautiful view from the 24th floor of the Rainbow Tower. Rooms with odd numbers have a view of the ocean, Diamond Head and Waikiki. Lots of shopping on site. Would recommend this hotel if you don't mind lots of excitement, people and walking on your trip. If you are looking for peace, quiet and seclusion on your Hawaiian vacation this place is not for you.

<Author>MsAmer1693
<Content>Overated and overpiced! Staff (except for a few exceptions) were rude and could care less about the guests. Concierge always acted bothered when we asked questions and rushed through the answers, tour/activities desk the same, and the front desk and guest services were completely unhelpful. It took forever to check in - we had just spent 15 hours traveling - and all we wanted to do was take a shower but there was no shower curtain! We called guest services who said someone would be right there. A maid showed up about 30 minutes later, handed me the shower curtain, and took off fast so as not to have to do anything else. I had to teeter on the edge of the bath tub to put it up - INSANITY, but i could have cared less at the time because it was 5 am my time and I wasn't about to wait another 30 minutes for someone else. The bed was right next to the door so we were woken up every night by hall noise, and we were two doors away from the ice machine (and people were getting ice at all hours of the night). But I should note we saw other rooms, which were set up differently. ALL food and drink at this establishment is overpriced! Bad food and extremely expensive. Breakfast was $26 per person, hot dogs at the casual restaurant on the beach were $11, all drinks $4, and even the other restaurants on site were awful and overpriced (like the Italian restaurant). Not an easy walk to other restaurants, have to cab it every where. There is a trolley stop by the hotel which can take you several places though. And a bus stop too. And there are a few convenience stores on site, but crowded and expensive.Also, we think there might have been bed bugs as we both ended up with unexplained rashes. I see other people have said the same thing. There are several towers there and we stayed in the Tapa tower.Beach was ok, we ended up driving to much nicer ones though.They messed up on our bill and tried to brush us off about it. I kept at it until it was corrected, then when we checked out there was another problem with our bill. The whole thing was a mess.The one thing we liked was the flamingos, parrots, penquins, ducks, and other birds they have on site.Bottom line - stay somewhere else!!!

<Author>NCinWV
<Content>Generally good experience In general, the Hilton Hawaiian Village is an impressive property. The grounds are beautiful, with koi ponds, exotic birds, and even warm climate penguins on the property. Great beachfront location. Staff we encountered were friendly and helpful. Shuttle service (for a fee, various companies) from the hotel makes it easy to get around to area attractions. The conference center and the Ala Moana shopping center are within reasonable walking distance. Rooms are comfortable and clean. Bedding was very comfortable though different from what I'm used to...no top sheet but a sheet/duvet combo that was a nice weight and seemed to regulate tempature well. Sheets and towels were of good quality and ample supply. Stayed in the Rainbow Tower which has great views of Waikiki Beach. Room had a wet bar area with sink, counter space, and a small fridge. Coffee maker utilizes a coffee pod system, with 10% kona coffee blends provided. We made a run to Wal Mart (by the Ala Moana Center) for bagels, cream cheese, water, juice etc to keep in the fridge during our stay. Expect to pay higer prices on the resort for food and souveniers. The ABC store (food, drinks, sundries) had more reasonable prices however than some of the other locations. Stayed here as part of a conference and got great rates. I'd stay here again but not sure that the regular rates are within my budget. We did run into a problem during check in. We needed to charge the room to a different card than the one we used to hold the initial reservation. Though we were told that would be no problem, the charges were applied to the wrong card and resulted in a negative balance on our debit card. Fortunately the manager on duty was very helpful in rectifying the mistake and even comped a room night for our troubles. Also, we asked for a king room but got a double. We were told it was because we were with a conference but other attendees booked via the conference rate and were given king rooms.  
<Date>Apr 2, 2008

<Author>hoohiki
<Content>No aloha in the service department Maybe it was just a busy time of year, right after Christmas and before New Year's, that the hotel attendants had a lot on their minds, but I didn't think it should've deterred from their responsibility to make guests feel welcome. I've traveled quite a bit and stayed at various deluxe and luxury hotels in Hawaii and Hilton hotels throughout the country and this one situated in Waikiki was not up to par. When we drove up to valet our car, there were 6 attendants just standing around and talking amongst each other when there were 3 cars in line to valet. After several minutes, I had to approach one attendant to help us. In other deluxe hotels, the valet attendants would be opening the passenger door as soon as the driver puts the gears on park. Then we were told tostand in line to register where we waited for 30 minutes to get our room and in the mean time, the bell boy was no where to be found. We went ahead to our room and waited another 30 minutes for our luggages to be sent up. After waiting in the long registry line, we were told that the partial ocean view room we requested were all booked and offered us a garden view which I promptly declined. We were then given an upgrade to an ocean view room for the price of the original room we requested.Our room overlooked the beautiful new man made lagoon which opened up on the day we arrived. My 2 young boys were quite excited to swim to the man made rock island with a waterfall in the middle of this lagoon. When they touched the bottom, instead of feeling the anticipated grainy sandy feeling, they felt a squishy, clay- like, muddy consistency which brought about a cloudy film in the water. It seemed unsanitary so we left for the beach about 50 yards away. There were positives: beautiful grounds with South African penguins, flamingos, parrots. The many shops and dining were all within the hotel premises. Many lounges with live music and entertainment. It's very close to the zoo, aquarium, and the biggest shopping mall in the Pacific, Ala Moana shopping center. Another positive is it's location- at the edge of Waikiki; not in the hustle and bustle section. Our room had a magnificent view and was a good size with a refrigerator.I would recommend making reservations at Hilton Hawaiian village during off peak season when it's not so crowded because despite the unfortunate service we encountered, it does have a lot to offer, especially families with kids.  
<Date>Apr 1, 2008

<Author>packmyluggage
<Content>Hilton Hawaiian Village We have stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village 4-5 times (both in the Lagoon Tower and Rainbow Tower) and have been very impressed with the location, accommodations and staff every time. One of the best things about the village is that you do not need a rental car since most of the tours pick up right at the village. However, if you want to drive around the island, you can rent a car right at the village. There are numerous restaurants (each one we have visited has been excellent) and shops in the village and the spa is great!

<Content>Not good at all! My husband and I stayed here for Valentine's week and were not happy at all with our stay. The room was unclean. Housekeeping was awful and NEVER cleaned anything. We put a pizza box in the trash which housekeeping REMOVED from the trash and placed on our bed. Our dirty glasses were not replaced and were actually flipped over on the tray for reuse. Coffee and coffee cups were NEVER replaced, even after complaining we could not get this done 100%. No trash was ever picked up- and we are neat people.The bathroom was filthy. I complained and it was marginally cleaned. At least the hair and crud was wiped off the toilet. It was a mess. Yes I did complain to mgmt who really did not care beyond an apology.The bed had no topsheet which I complained about. The housekeeper told me if I wanted a topsheet she would need to remove the comforter! I said I wanted to keep the comforter so she told me to put the sheet on myself. I am not kidding.The elevators took forever,sometimes 10 minutes in the morning, and there were no stairs we could take.We tried the Sushi place and wound up walking out when we were totally ignored for 15 minutes after being seated. Noone ever waited on us.We did much better venturing off the grounds and finding local restaraunts.We travel a lot and have never had such a letdown as this resort. Stay elsewhere!

<Author>roaming_review
<Content>Definitely give this place a go! For some reason, I was really surprised at what a fantastic hotel this was! The staff were very friendly considering the number of guests that they would attend to each day! The lobby is busy 24/7 and still manage to keep a smile on thier faces. We stayed in the Rainbow Tower (highly recommend) on the 27th floor with the most spectacular view of Waikiki, looking all the way down to Diamond Head) and is right on the beach. The rooms were spacious, clean and comfortable, and well above our expectations, considering what we had paid to stay there! I have paid far more to stay in other hotels in Waikiki that I would not stay at ever again. Shop around online.Of the many hotels that I have stayed at in Waikiki, I would without question, return back to the Hilton Village. There are lots of restaurants (Benihana's) and bars to choose from, with quick and easy access to the beach. Of course, plenty of ABC shops too!! haha! It is quite an enjoyable walk into downtown - about 10 minute walk, if that. There is always plenty happening! The only thing that I did not like was the Grand Vacation Time Share guys hassling you - they call you in your room, leave notes in your room.... go to the concerierge to ask a question and you get Have you heard about out Hilton Grand Vacation plan? - ENOUGH! I didn't go there to buy [-] Time Share! The other small thing was that the airport bus dropped us off in the bus area and wsa no where near where the lobby was. I thought of older and less fit travellers with bags, it is a long walk and no one there to assist you. I really enjoyed my stay there - good for just about any type of traveller.

<Author>orchid_8
<Content>Hilton Hawaiian is Beautiful and Spacious but..... We stay there during our Spring Break for 1 week. Hilton Hawaiian is at the far end and the beginning of the Waikiki Beach. Depending what you are looking for, it is quiet and relaxing when you stroll along Waikiki Beach. But if you are young and looking for excitement, then you should stay closer in the middle of Waikiki Beach where all the young people hang around such as Hyatt, Marriott. Expensive food in Hilton but there are many restaurants along Waikiki Beach that offer better price and don't forget to use the coupons!Go to ABC store for everything. I am very disappointed that Hilton does not have a warm pool or a hot tub. My children were freezing and reluctant to go for swimming. Otherwise, the weather is great there.

<Author>TwinTourists
<Content>"Don't Bother With This Hotel!" If you have never been to Hawaii before, I do not recommend you stay here!I totally agree with 鈥楴ever Again鈥? I have been to Oahu over 20 times and have always wanted to stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. Well, I finally got my chance when I received a special offer to check out their time share. At check-in, after waiting a long time in a long line, I found the staff was very indifferent and not friendly. They barely look at you and hardly give you eye contact. They could have cared less if I was there at all! The property is so big, it seemed only like a convention hotel 鈥?moving the guests in and out like cattle.The first room they gave me was very average and over-looked the roof of the shops. Even though I requested a non-smoking room, when I first walked in it smelled of smoke so I immediately had my room changed. They just gave me another very average room, also with no view at all. No apologies or mentioning any kind of better room. They didn鈥檛 seem to care that I was a prospect for purchasing one of their time shares.If you self-park, it is a mile to your room. And, if you want to walk to the center of Waikiki, you have a nice little hike ahead of you. The hotel is at the very beginning of Waikiki. There is nothing near the hotel to walk to - only the Wailana Coffee House across the street (which by-the-way has excellent food) or the Kobe Japanese Steak House with the little bears in front.I had a voucher for The Bali Hai restaurant. Otherwise I wouldn鈥檛 have eaten there because it was overpriced. But it was lovely. I had complained at the NY Deli, but the owner was in and he was very nice. The shops are over priced, as well. Other reviewers said there is an ABC store on the hotel grounds, but there are about 30 ABC鈥檚 in Waikiki alone!The smaller swimming pool is tiny and the big pool is just average.There are other better hotels in Waikiki, I can鈥檛 understand why the Hilton Hawaiian Village gets such rave reviews. It seems to me that some reviewers had never been to Hawaii before and this is their first impression of it, so they think the hotel is wonderful. If you want a great hotel, I suggest the Moana Surfrider, the Royal Hawaiian, the Outrigger or the Outrigger Reef. They are all in the price range of the Hilton. The Kahala Hotel is also a wonderful hotel, but it's around the other side of Diamond Head. If you really want something special and romantic, the only hotel to stay in is the Halekulani. In my opinion, it is the most grand and elegant hotel in Waikiki with superb service and a friendly, accommodating staff (no, I am not an employee, just a big fan!).Don鈥檛 bother with the Hilton Hawaiian Village.

<Author>HawaiidanKailua_Kona
<Content>more like a city than a village Ok...I live in hawaii...and its been a few years since I went to Honolulu...I got a outstanding rate which is why I stayed there I was even upgraded to the Rainbow tower. and am not a Hilton points member and over looked the boat harbor..which is the best location for restauraunts and pool access There is no smoking in the rooms or anywhere on the entire Hilton grounds and it is enforcedRoom had a small bath, nice bed...and a 30  flat screen sterioTo say it is a village is misleading as I dont know many villages anywhere that are comprised of 30 to 40 story buildings in all there are 4 with one 40 story tower ( condos) under construction and a 6 story parking garage and a shopping mall in every building plus the Rainbow Bazzar...a huge collection of non hilton shops and restauraunts....which I will ge to later.The majority of hotels and buildings in the area all run well over 30 storiesIt reminded me of New York or down town San Francisco...if they had palms.It has a big metropolitan city feel....with a tiny touch of Hawaii...very tiny. it can take 20 min to walk one way across the grounds and will take over an hour to walk around....huge.2 of the towers are concierige towers and have their own private pool....which were the same size as mine at home......Living in Kona... it was funny to realize that with 5000+ rooms and who knows how many condos...and staff( 600 in just housekeeping) ther there were more people in tha hilton than in the town of Kailua Kona and Keauhou together. well over 15,000Traffic was 24 -7 parking costs $22 a day self park and $29 valet It is not a place to get away from the world... I took a cab...$30 fron the airport. Roberts shuttle $9 pp.The pool was a rather normal pool...that was packed from 8 am to 6pm when it closed. ..with ever size shape and age andnationality .... I thought Icaught a glimpse of Osama Bin laden talking to Hitler.... it was that diverse .The grounds were manicured and totaly clean, the staff excellent and efficient and plesant... the beach ....marginal the water somewhat mirky and the kids lagoon...was beautiful but nothing more than a sand bottom swimming pool.. it was mirky as well.Everything...is for sale....or rent....for a price. Itr is very easy to spend double your room.. $80 for 2 for a simple breakfast coffee 2 eggs, a meat, hash browns and toast.... The buffet was about $30 pp..... Dinner Buffet runs about $35 per person 18 kids...thats any living breathing kid under 12. The restauraunts all start alacarte at 35 to 50 a plate.....I talked to several guests ant they told me that dinner ran them arounf $200 a night. with drinks. Speaking of drinks my wife and I had 4 frozen maitais and 5 pot stickers and 4 spring rolls for about $60. at a beach bar. SInce My credit card has only a mid range 5 figure credit, I did not order room service..... (and the mini bar require a written contrat....with payment terms and a down payment min.)Here are some room service prices I took for fun: ( inclludes tax ans service charges)14 chicken pizza...$47......Mai Tahi for one...$20.521/2 a chicken with fries..$33.Cheess burger with fries...$31.NY steak.... $57.Bottled water r soft drink $5.Pancakes (3)$28.Case of beer ( 24) budwiser... $133.......So I went looking and found this fantastic place in the Rainbow Bazzar......CJ's a classiic NY style deli-dinner meets hawaii....It had a fun happy staff, was family run not a chain....and prices 60% lower than the Hilton.....portions so huge you could not finish. We had breakfast for 2...huge the works...home made hash. 8 oz of it..3 eggs, toast, coffee, hash browns.. sliced tomators, tip tax... for under $35....... Dinner was the same... we ended eating 90%of all our meals there......it was exceptional in every respect.Over all felt sorry for people who, the staff told me never left the hotel for a week..... They also related that our own Hilton on the island of Hawaii was their favorite......total different feel .Check out was a breeze and everything went smooth..... only caution is food..... go to CJ's

<Author>SouthCarolinaCynic
<Content>Mixed Opinion We are currently at the Hotel in the Diamond Head Tower. The rooms are reasonable in terms of size and cleanliness. We have adjoining rooms with a door between them which is a good way to go when travelling with teenagers.The resort is pleasant with a variety of pools and a nice beach. My 13 year old son was shocked to find there was no arcade.Prices are very high. It was $14 the other day for chicken tenders and fries. Don't even consider room service unless you have a seven figure income. Parking is $22/day for self park and $26/day for valet. We took the valet but found they won't let you call down to get the car ready. You have to actually come to the valet stand before they will get your car. They usually have it within a couple fo minutes though. I have never understood why inexpensve hotels can offer internet access for free but expensive places charge for it. I paid $65 for 5 days access, about as fas as dial up. There are dozens of stores and places to eat on the property which is actually pretty nice. If you want to charge something to your room account though they have to physically call the hotel to approve the charge. It is extremely inefficient.The hotel services are average. I have called the guest services hotline a few times. Two of those times no one ever answerred. I just got put in to that endless loop of recordings saying how important my call was. When I did get through they were pleasant and helpful.IThe primary purpose of the concierge desk, as far as can tell, is to try to get people to sign up for the time share sales pitch.If you don't mind the price of the food, it isn't bad.  
<Date>Mar 26, 2008

<Author>Elenriel
<Content>Never Again My recent experience at the Hilton Hawaiin Village has left me cold on any future booking with the Hilton resort chain.Upon arriving, after a long overseas trip, I was confronted with a long wait at check in, after having to carry my own bags as the bellmen were too busy chatiing with each other. The check in clerk was hopeless. Either very under trained or plain incompetent. Could not find my reservation, could not find a room, and had to check with her supervisor several times. I asked for a early check in, at 10:00 am (check in is at 2;00pm)and they insisted on charging me a full nights stay, even though she admitted they were only at 70% capacity. I was so tired I paid very reluctantly. I am a hilton honours member since 1982.The hotel itself is unremarkable, and I have stayed at some of the best resorts around the world, and I have difficulty understanding why some rank this resort highly, other than they may not have had many other experiences.The location is right at the end of the beach, not the best in my opinion. This is a large resort with a huge amount of people, so if you are looking for an intimate holiday forget. Get in line with a cast of thousands for everything. And as another reviewer has commented don't try to get a drink after 11:00pm, all bars are closed, including the beach bar that closes at 8:30PM! . Room service told me to walk down to the local liqour vendor if I wanted a beer after 11:00.The rooms a typically Hiltonesque. Comfortable and reasonably modern, but no wow factor which you might expect at a resort. Balcony was very dirty. The pools are very small compared to most hotels of this size, and the beach really over crowded. Forget about the romantic sunsets, unless you don't mind a view across a breakwater and parking lot. Surfing is hard here as well due to the long paddle required to get to the break and shallow coral, making it dangerous for beginers.The restaurants are completely uninspiring, for the exception of Bali which we enjoyed a good but overpriced meal, with no resembalance to the cusine of its name sake island. The Italian restaurant is a utter disappointment, the New York Deli very average. The main restaurant where you are herded for breakfast, and then oversold on the unbelievable buffet at $28 was a disaster. Lack of variety, presentation and importantly quality. The onsite shopping gallery is very overpriced and a tourist trap. Save time and money and grab a cab to the premium DFO about a $50 cab ride away.I found most of the staff uninterested, and not particularily friendly, except for a couple of the girls in the beach bar. Maybe they were happy because they were off at 8:30 every night!!!When I checked out of the hotel I again was met by rude and disinterested staff. When I suggested her politley that an improvement in attitude might improve customer retention. I was instructed to go see the duty manager he might listen. He doesn't need to now as I won't be back. In summary, I truly see little redeeming qualities in this Hilton property, and believe there are infinatelyy better choices available for discerning travellers. Spend your money elsewhere, you will be glad.  
<Date>Mar 25, 2008

<Author>kevnjen
<Content>A 'True' Review After reading many reviews on this campus, my wife and I are ready to give it to you straight... This hotel campus is awesome for starters. We'll give you the do's and don'ts. The plush tower is the Ali'i; however, they don't participate in the Hilton Honors program so don't expect to get upgraded to this tower. What makes this tower so fantastic are the following: Very nice wooden pool side chairs with pillows. Fitted towels for the pillows on the lounge chairs All the towels you would ever need while sunbathingThe pool is located on the second floor and has a nice whirlpool as well as a fantastic view of the beach and ocean. The very nice fitness center right off the pool complete with free weights and cardio machines. The pool side bar is where you can enjoy your breakfast, lunch, and 5 p.m. complimentary snacks. The staff is fabulous. This is a private pool and is only for people staying in the Ali'i tower and their guests. The Rainbow Tower is the second best tower in our opinion due to the fabulous view. You can use your points here and we recommend trying to get a dual balcony room over looking the ocean/lagoon or ocean/pool. We stayed in R2800 after leaving the Ali'i and used our points. The view can't be described it was so beautiful. We awoke each morning to a beautiful rainbow. The elevator ride can take a little time but you're in a big hotel and it happens. The other 4 towers: Kalia, Tapa, Diamond head and Lagoon (time shares) are dealers choice. Kalia is nice as far as having in our opinion the best pool. The super pool located by the ocean gets very crowded and the chairs are touching one another. Kids love it but if you want a little privacy go to the 4th floor pool at the Kalia tower. Nice water fall and not real populated. The fitness center located here (4th floor) is awesome. Large windows with a balcony that face Diamond Head and the facility has everything you would want. The Spa is also located in this tower. Gold and Diamond members can use the fitness center at no charge. Tapa tower from what we were told by people we met is not the tower to stay in if you want a beautiful romantic view. There is a pool located by the Tapa tower that is also not too heavily populated and is a nice area to relax. Diamond Head if you're on the side facing Diamond Head gives you a nice view, other than that not too much. Let's now address where to eat and shop on the Hilton Campus. We never left except to drive to North Shore, which we'll address later. GO TO THE ABC store on campus to purchase your drinks, booze, snacks, suntan lotion, etc..... KEEP YOUR RECEIPTS... They give you a gift when you leave based on what you spent. We received 2 very nice coffee mugs for our $257.00. Prices are very reasonable and after you purchase a view drinks at the bar (cokes, etc) you'll understand. There is a Starbucks located on the 1st floor of the Kalia tower. This is the fastest Starbucks we've ever been to; however, Lappert's located directly across from the main check in area has fabulous coffee and ice cream. They also give you a card and after 10 purchases (ice cream or coffee) you'll recieve one free. There Kaui Pie coffee is to die for. Pricing for the specialty coffee is the same as Starbuck's but you can't get the Kaui Pie and you at least get one free after 10 purchases. There is also another grocery type store located in the shopping area by the Diamond Head Tower, they have a nice selection with good pricing as well. Don't do the Rainbow Lanai dinner buffet. NOT WORTH IT AT ALL..... Use your coupon books that you get at check in. They have great deals at all the shops on campus. 10% off to free items. When you go to claim your free gift on the scratch off card with the penguin, be ready for a time share pitch.. You'll have to go to a sales pitch but it's worth it. Listen, it's not for everyone but we may end up doing it. Plus you get $100 hilton honor bucks that can be used at several shops. This campus is not cheap or inexpensive, remember your going to Hawaii.. But, if you take time to check everything out you'll find that you can have a blast and not have to spend $80.00 per meal. Use the coupon's they offer from food, car rental, clothing and coffee it saves you money. If you're going to sun yourself on the beach you can rent lounge chairs and umbrellas or just use the Free towels they have. (remember to ask for 2 per person.) Get a car and tour the island. North Shore was cool and we recommend going to the Turtle Bay Resort for breakfast or lunch. It's a cool get away and a nice location right on the ocean. We used Hertz (Tapa Tower) and if you book on-line you get a discount plus your coupon book has a $5.00 off voucher. The staff was awesome, we felt like everyone wanted us at the hotel and we will be back next year. Here is a sample of what we spent per day: (2 people)Breakfast: Free for Gold/Diamond members (get voucher at check in)Lunch: $14 to $45 depending what you want . Bar/Grill(awesome hot dog shop in Rainbow tower)Dinner: $40-$115 We used a Limo service to pick us up and take us back to the airport. We used ABC Limo Service: [-]Email: [-] Melvin Kim (owner) picked us up and we highly recommend using him. He waited for us over 45 minutes due to our flight getting in late. We walked up to baggage claim and there he was... He told us to be ready at 2:00p.m. for our ride back to the airport and he was very promptly on time with refreshments during our drive. FIRST CLASS!!!!We hope this helps, we used this site to pick this destination and read some great comments and also read the complainers... In a nut shell. For a beautiful fun filled trip this is your hotel for couples or the whole family!! Aloha Kev and Jen

<Author>Bigmonkey13
<Content>Great experience again My wife and I just returned from our trip to Hawaii where we stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. This was my second time at this hotel and my wife's first and we were both impressed. The rooms were clean and well-maintained throughout the five days we stayed there. The hotel complex has anything you could possibly want there: convience store, various other stores, restaurants, etc, although prices for all items have the typical Waikiki premium associated with them. The restuarants that were actually part of the hotel, particularly the Rainbow Lanai, served some really good food for breakfast and dinner (didn't try lunch there).The thing that I like the most about the Hilton Hawaiian Village was its location. Located at the beginning of Waikiki (the part closest to the airport/downtown Honolulu), it is easier to access than other hotels since you don't have to deal with all of the traffic congestion associated some of the other hotels, like Outrigger and the Royal Hawaiian. Also, there is a little less traffic on the beach, making for a much more enjoyable experience. All in all, I would definately recommend staying at the Hilton Hawaiian Village for your next trip!  
<Date>Mar 24, 2008

<Author>patswamber
<Content>Great Family Destination It always surprises me when I look at previous reviews. It's amazing how travelers can have such different experiences at the same resort.Our family stayed at the HHV March 9th - 14th. We booked a gardenview in the Ali'i tower and were upgraded to an oceanview room during check-in. The process was smooth, there were no issues with our room type and there was no wait. The Ali-i tower was perfect for our family as it was close to the beach, had it's own fitness room, and overlooked the pool. We loved everything about this resort - the beachwalk, on-site restaurants, shopping and the wildlife. We found it to be relaxing and fun - I was able to read by the pool and the kids found lot's of other children to play with on the beach.The superpool was colder than I expected and the lifeguards do a good job keeping the area calm - they do not allow sport balls or inflatables in the main pool so most of the activity occurs at the adjacent beach. There was no problem finding a lounge chair, maybe because most of the pool area is in the shade until mid-morning. In late afternoon, there is great local music at the Tropics bar which is outside and overlooks the beach area. Most afternoons were spent there or at the Ali'i pool where you could enjoy appetizers and look out over the beach.The resort if off the main strip and it takes about 15 minutes to walk to a more central area. We normally walked to dinner and then cabbed it home (in hindsight, we probably should have done the opposite!). At departure, we were able to schedule time in the hospitality room so we could clean up before heading out - this is rare as most hotels do not let you pre-schedule this room. Housekeeping was great and left lot's of chocolate and bottled water at turn down.Other Pros:beachfront, no wait for cabs, ABC, Starbucks and bookstore on site, backs to the beachwalk path, quick poolside bar sericeCons: The Ali'i fitness area needs to be a bit cooler- it gets too hot. Also, the Hertz office on-site needs more flexible hours and additional staff during the morning rush.This resort was perfect for our family and we will return  
<Date>Mar 24, 2008

<Author>Glav
<Content>Worst Experience in Years We were a group of businessmen staying at this Hotel for 4 days for various business meetings. We had travelled from various parts of the world but mainly from the USA and Australia. Everything is bad about this hotel. We booked and extra night as we were not arriving untill 6am the following morning. On arrival they had cancelled all our rooms as no Shows even though they had been advised of the early booking of the rooms and the reason why. The check in staff are so poorly trained one of our party took 40mins to check in even thought we were all Hilton Club members. In addition to this the staff are rude. My room was OK but I had a dripping toilet for the 4 days I was there. I kept expecting housekeeping to report it each day and yet it was never fixed. Wake up calls came through on times different to what I ordered. You can not get a drink in the hotel after 11pm at night as all bars and restaurants are closed. Ridiculous for a so called resort. On the Sunday evening half the restaurants are closed so it was difficult to get a meal. My balcony was never cleaned during my visit. We were all charged different rates and our rooms were spread out on various floors in different buildings. This whole terrible experience will make me reconsider ever using a Hilton Hotel again and I would not recomend this Hotel to anyone either for business or pleasure. It is a poor value for money proposition

<Author>earlOnario
<Content>Can"t Wait to Go Back Just returned to Canada and miss the surf and beach at the Hilton already. I am writing this review because I research trip advisor routinely for all the trips that we take and I find the reviews informative. I always evaluate the tips and use the information at our destinations to find the best excursion, restaurants, shopping, etc. Hope this review assists you in making your decision about the Hilton in Oahu.The hotel complex is massive and amazing. We were truly delighted to be there and enjoyed the facility. STaff are friendly, helpful, and there is a lot to enjoy. The problem is cramming everything in before you have to return home. We loved the exotic wildlife, the waterfalls, the shopping, the floral gardens, the entertainment that is on site.and the tours that were arranged for us by the staff. In addition, great location to take city busses, or walk to Waikki beach. The bus stop is just out front of the property. We used the tour desk on site to book tours and they were excellent. We went to the Arizonza Memorial 4 hour tour which gave us a tour of the city and the Punchbowl Cemetary. Tour guides were friendly and informative. If you have the opportunity go with cousin Paul, he was amazing with the ALoha tour group. ,Did the whale watching tour with ATlantis which included the lunch. It was OK. if you have not seen whales before. We have ,so it was not a huge exciting trip but well worth it for 62 dollars each which included a nice buffet lunch. Kids on board loved the action and we enjoyed the view of the hotels from the water. Whale sitings are guarenteed or your money is returned. Also rented a convertable to tour the entire island on one day, and that was amazing to say the least. DO IT and you will not regret signing up for a bus tour . We stopped many times, saw the whales, the surfers on the north shore, Visited the pine apple plant, a few bars and some shopping along the way completed the day. Having our own transportation made it so easy to pick and choose where we wanted to stop and sight see and how long we wanted to stay at one particular spot was up to us and not a tour operator. Car cost 55 dollars with Hertz for 24 hours and we booked it on site. It was a deal for the day because we took it as is, and not cleaned. It was still emaculate and ready to go, with our bathing suits packed and a few snacks we were on our way. What a day!WEather was fantastic, lots of sun by the pool and beach, and lots of entertainment to choose from. The tropic bar was our pick every day from 3 p.m.on into early evening. Local talent was great. The Friday evening show was exceptional, the lei making classes were fun, we even did the timeshare tour and were not hassled when we declined. Check out the deal if you sign up. It worked really well for us. HIgh end and low end shopping if you want is within walking distance and particularly at night along Lewers street is fun. Hotel room was very large complete with alll the amenities you could wish for. If you needed anything extra just ask and you shall receive immediately. Be patient with housekeeping if you want your room cleaned before noon, as it is a large facility but it always get done.Being Canadians we took our own TIm HOrtons coffee and filters and it worked each morning for us on our balcony. We quickly figured out how to make a two cup individual cup coffee maker work to our advantage. The hotel supplies individual cup servings of Kona coffee that just don't cut it when we are used to our own Tims Brew. If you choose there is a STar Bucks on site in one of the buildings that on some days we went to just to sit by the many waterfall areas. What a way to enjoy a cup of coffee. We stayed in the Diamond Head building overlooking the garden and one of the five pools. It was great. WAlked every morning along the beach with our coffee thermos cups and watched the most incredible sunrises and sunsets in the evening were even more breathtaking. The beach front is unparalled by any other hotel along the strip. It is clean, safe ( police regularly patrolling) and groomed each morning for a new day. Ladies, dress is from casual to very upscale. REstaurants are the same so be prepared. SHopping on site is very expensive for clothing, just as are all Hilton sites tend to be.THe ABC store on site , however offered reasonably priced food to go, liquor, souveniers, etc. WE used the coupon books to our advantage and you receive those upon check in. EAting on site is expensive but you can modify. Yogurt, bananas, sandwiches in our mini fridge worked for lite meals and snacks. We often shared a breakfast at the restaurant kiddy corner to the resort in the mornings and we were happy campers. Servings are large and prices are less than half you would pay on site. On site the Brfst buffet starts at 17 US, coffee is 4 US, alcoholic drinks are always 10 US or more. Many late afternoons we shared tacos for two at the Tropic BAr for 10 US and we loved it as we listened to the entertainment. Take along a thermos cup and fill it from your room if you wish or during the day take a cooler bag and ice to where you wish to enjoy the sun, beach and or pool . It is a tip I picked up on trip advisor and used a lot during our stay. Room service ....... well we were tired after a 17 hour treck through the sky from Canada, so we did it because we knew what jet lag was going to do to us in the next few hours.Two sandwiches with water only were 54 US. Be prepared for that. Dinner for two at the restaurants will be 150 t0 200 US, without alcohol. You can eat off site very well and inexpensively if you look. for it in the main district along Kalia street and Kelawana street.. Happy hours work with half price appetisers too! Don't let the high cost of meals deter you from this hotel. It is well worth it to stay there and eat off site. Our visit to Oahu was fantastic because we stayed there and explored the island at our pace using what the hotel could offer us for enjoyment, relaxation, car rentals and tours. You won't be disappointed, so enjoy your vacation. We will definately return and would recommend this hotel to any age group.  
<Date>Mar 15, 2008

<Author>Jenz99
<Content>Good pre-cruise hotel We stayed in the Ali'i tower for two nights before our cruise and really enjoyed it. Particularly the free use of the exercise facility as well as the separate pool with very comfortable beach chairs. Was much more relaxing than the main pool area and still had access to the beach. Room was clean and quiet, with a quasi-ocean view if we leaned over pretty far on our deck. Good space in the bathroom with the sink and closet separated from the shower and the toilet. Had no problems with housekeeping or other staff, and easily got a late checkout so we could head right to our cruise ship when it was available for embarkation. I enjoyed the overall layout of the resort, many of the hotel entrances were integrated with bars and shops so you couldn't tell you were surrounded by 5,000 rooms. Agree with some of the posters that the food choices at the resort leave something to be desired and are a little pricey, even for Honolulu. Had dinner at Bali By the Sea one night and ate at the pool restaurant for lunch, but otherwise ventured off property for the rest of our meals. Really enjoyed Duke's down by the Outrigger for dinner, and had both breakfasts at the Eggs  Things a couple blocks away from the hotel. Location was convenient to the main shopping areas, and within walking distance of Diamondhead if you were motivated - we took the bus there and walked along the shops back. Overall was a good prep for the cruise, and would recommend it to other travelers.  
<Date>Mar 15, 2008

<Content>Great View, Clean Rooms, Great Staff Very good hotel! Great room view, clean and quiet room, and great staff. I stayed for almost 2 weeks and was very impressed. Room was a little older but was stylish and very clean. On site food and drink is a little pricey but other resturants and the rest of Waikiki are only a short walk away. The grounds are exotic and beatifully maintained. I will certainly stay again.I have been traveling to Honolulu for business for almost a decade and have stayed at several of the hotels. Hilton Hawaiian Village is my favorite palce to stay.

<Author>mcbpinky
<Content>very good experience We just recently came back from a 13 nights stay at the HHV. A very good experience overall. We had problems however at check in. We had checked in in advance earlier in the day via internet on the Hilton site being hilton honnors members. We had been assigned a room with King size bed in the Rainbow tower oceanview and 32nd floor which sounded fantastic. Upon our arrival on the property around 9 pm she wanted to give us a room with two beds.. this was our first wedding anniversary and 13 nights in two beds.. could not do. It was very frustrating since we had reserved months in advance a king size bed and had been assigned a much better room on the web site earlier in the same day. She managed to find us a king size bed in another tower but we really did not appreciate the treatment and it took her a long time to find something else. She never really explained who had gotten my room or if it was available or not.The rest of our stay was very pleasant. The hotel is big and very busy but it is the best section of the beach in Waikiki by far and it does not feel too crowded on the beach. The fact that it almost never rains in Waikiki beach (20 inch per year) compared to other beaches and the rest of Oahu ( up to 200 inches per year..) is to take into account and can make up for it being more busy then elsewhere. The umbrellas and chairs rented by the company on the beach is a major rip off (60 US each day..) but at least you don't worry about having to rush there early morning to reserve one to be sure to get some shade in the day since if you are willing to pay there are always some available.The hotel has really made an effort to integrate Hawaiian culture in the decorations which are quite impressive everywhere on the resort. You also get cultural activities like Lei making, Hula dance classe and Ukulele lessons opportunities almost every day on site which is very nice. The resort is very impressive with well laid out lush vegetation and nice animals of varous kinds which makes it quite unique in its kind. /They had a show every night around 6 pm of hula dancing which was quite fun and on Fridays it is longer with fireworks. Some live music at different places on the resort starting at 4 pm every night is also very good. They light up the property at night by torch and they do a ceremony of this lighting every night at the beginning of the show.We really appreciated to have in the resort many boutiques of all price ranges from the ABC store to get cheap snacks and things to L Vutton accessories. It was pleasant to stroll the boutiques at night and it was not more expensive here then elsewhere in town. The proximity of Ala Moana shopping center at a few blocks was also nice. The Borders music and book shop of Ala Moana shopping center has an amazing selection of Hawaiian music if of interest to you. The restaurant were also varied and very good. We tried most of them. Some things are overpriced like the tropical drinks which cost almost $10 each but the location of the bars being directly on the beach kind of made us feel it was ok for them to ask that much. It was possible to eat for a reasonable price at other meals without being too expensive.You do feel a little pressure to go visit their timeshare being built next door and they take every opportunity to invite you, I think they should avoid doing that too much..Rooms were very nice but our room was an adjoining one and we were woken up some nights by our neighbors coming in late. The rooms were kept clean and the view on Diamond head and the rest of Waikiki really makes it worth your money to get a ocean view room. Luggage handling and every other services were very good.We did many private tours with a local company Hina adventures who do eco tours and historical tours. We booked hiking and a tour of the monarchy and archeology and we do recommend their service very much it was just great. We also really enjoyed our day at the Polynesian cultural center where we got super ambassador tickets and this really gets you the vip treatment with reserved seats everywhere including in the shade when everybody else in under the blazing sun and also a private guide even only if you are a group of two which is really nice. The submarine Atlantis is ok but not the highlight of our trip since there are not that many reefs in Hawaii, the ones being there are artificial and there are not that many fishes. But we did see some giant turtles so it was worth going but not the best.  
<Date>Mar 2, 2008

<Author>GypsyAtLast
<Content>Good Trip In the heart of downtown Honolulu. Property is tropical  lovely. Enjoyed seeing the parrots  other birds plus penguin exhibit was neat. Rooms were very good but wouldn't consider them exceptional.Shopping on the property was high end - Louis Vuitton, Chanel, etc. Car rental kiosk on property is convenient. Several open air restaurants  bars; good choices for eating both casual  upscale. Loved the Asian restaurant.Tour options are good -- favorite was visiting the USS Arizona Memorial. Very moving.Beach was just so-so. Small pebbles made lying on a towel uncomfortable. We rented a car and visited several other Oahu beaches that we found much nicer.Spa was good...but layout was a bit strange. After you check-in and change into robes, you must get on an elevator to get to the treatment rooms. I didn't enjoy the co-ed elevator ride - not relaxing.If you have children, this would be a good spot for them. The hotel had programs to keep them entertained and they all seemed to be enjoying themselves. We were NOT traveling with children...so sometimes it got noisy, wet elevators  noise in the hallways but not too unpleasant.Travel time/time difference from the East Coast is the biggest handicap for me returning. For the money  time - I'm heading back to the Bahamas. But if I'm ever back in Honolulu, I would likely stay here again.  
<Date>Mar 1, 2008

<Author>tomlo
<Content>Loved the view My husband and I booked the Hilton Hawaiin Village standard room for 8 nights through my corporate travel agent for $239/night more than a month ago. I was on business and my husband was tagging along. When we arrived at check in around 3 pm, we were told the hotel was oversold and they were taking volunteers to be relocated at the Embassy Suites. For the inconvience, they offered to pay for 1/2 of the stay, or 4 nights. Well, the Embassy Suites is where I often stay for business and because I was on expenses, I was not interested, least of all in Hawaii. We were told it was still voluntary at this point. Well, the desk clerk started typing away at his computer, and then suddenly disappeared for about 10 minutes in the back room! We knew they were going to send us to the Embassy Suites anyway. My husband reached into his bag and slapped his TRIPADIVSOR.COM baseball cap on his head. Soon, another desk clerk came by to let us know that the desk clerk was still working on a room for us. She asked if my husband worked for Trip Advisor. He was a little vague, and said that we traveled often and blogged about sites. Next thing you know, they magically appeared with a corner room in the Rainbow Tower, 5th Floor. We had a view of the sunset on one balcony and Diamond Head on another. The view was great, although they start dragging the beach in front of hotel around 4 am. I like to sleep with windows open, but not an option with the early morning noise. The firework show on Friday night was right below our window and was spectacular. The other thing I didn't appreciate was that when we checked out, the desk clerk inquired as to how many days we used our in room safe and then were charged for the use. I don't recall seeing that this was an additional charge. Still, I paid for one day internet usage, and was able to continue to use for the entire week at no extra charge. By the way, the TripAdvisor.com baseball cap is now affectionately called the MAGIC HAT by my husband. He swears we get better service when he wears it. Thank you Trip Advisor  
<Date>Feb 29, 2008

<Author>FRKFN8R
<Content>Great hotel, room and beach We stayed in the Ali'i tower 3rd floor with partial ocean view. Positives:The room over looks a beautiful public park and partial view of the ocean. The room itself was very clean, the beds had nice crisp sheets with mattresses that were vey close to my own. The room really was great, no complaints at all. The maids cleaned just enough not to disrupt your personal belongings. There is a outdoor pool, hot tub, exercise room and a lounging area on the second floor of the tower. Free appatizers every night between 5-7pm(finger food). There is a couple of large pools outside at ground level with a huge lounging area as well. The beach directly out front is kinda busy, but if you walk a couple hundred feet it turns to a public beach which is not as busy. The sand is nice and not too much coral or other obstacles to walk over. Take a stroll down the public beach and hit a food stand under the first condo/hotel called Wakiki Pizzaria? ( I think) Great food and good value. Subway is also there and a few other good ones. The hotel and grounds are on it's own at one end of Wakikii beach so it is definetly much quieter than all the rest that are side by side. You can walk or take a city bus practically anywhere on the island. If you walk to the International Market don't buy the first thing you see because, almost every vendor sells the exact same thing and some do barter very very low. My wife and I felt very safe every where we went.Negatives:There is lots of shopping and resteraunts around the hotel grounds, but most are a little expensive for my tastes.Overall 9/10  
<Date>Feb 27, 2008

<Author>KAllan07
<Content>Enjoyed our honeymoon at the Hilton Hawaiian Village! My husband and I stayed at the HHV for the second stop on our two week honeymoon in June 2007. He is a Diamond Hilton Honors member so we were able to cash in some points for a week free and it was well worth it! The grounds are AMAZING with the wildlife (I loved the African penguins) and it was nice to have a small little city within the hotel grounds. We enjoyed browsing the shops and buying souviners and admiring all the beautiful ponds and landscaping. The beach was pretty good - except you need to rent a chair which is a little much in my opinion. The location of the HHV is great - within walking distance of some great restaurants (there's an excellent Thai restaurant right on the corner near the main entrance to the HHV). All of our meals, although pricey (what isn't in Hawaii?) were really good - no complaints about the food and we had some wonderful dinners in the resort restaurants. I loved the breakfast each morning - very, very good!My one big complaint was how compact the main pool was - the chairs are on top of one another and you have to get down there early to get a good seat with total sun. We ended up spending more time at the smaller pool near the hot dog place as it was quieter and more relaxing.If I were to return to Oahu, I would absolutely stay at the HHV again. It was clean, with beautiful grounds, nice staff, and local to many other attractions. In general, however, I'd probably try and stay on the North Shore as it is less of a city than Waikiki and more of what I consider relaxing. It all depends on what you're looking for and we were happy having things to do and see at the HHV.  
<Date>Feb 25, 2008

<Author>canucksweethearts
<Content>Fantastic Resort! Loved it! My husband and I stayed here Feb 9 - 16, 2008 and we had an amazing trip! The stay started off with a bit of a wrinkle... we booked through a travel agent, paid for a full ocean view room. Our agent requested a king size bed for us, but when we checked in, we were booked to a room with 2 double beds. When I mentioned that my agent had requested a king size bed, after quite a bit of searching on the desk clerk's part, a room was located for us, and we were upgraded to the Rainbow tower.. however... when we got to our room... we were on the wrong side of the hotel for our full ocean view! I immediately called the front desk to complain and will give this advice.. when you have a complaint, remember to be polite! I read on this website before leaving that if you were rude to them, they did NOTHING for you, so I nicely explained that though I appreciated the upgrade to the Rainbow tower, I didn't get the view that I had paid for. At first they tried to sell me on the Rainbow tower to prevent having to move me, but I didn't relent, so I was put on a waiting list for the next morning since there were no more roms with king beds available. The next day were received a room on the 23rd floor of the Tapa tower facing the ocean and Diamond Head... we LOVED it!! They even let us view the room first and decide which one we liked better before packing and moving our stuff... wow! Very Accomodating!!We felt that the Tapa tower was a better tower than the rainbow because it was a bit back from the beach and less noisy, it had express elevators for the higher floors (the rainbow did not) and it had it's own pool and bar which were NEVER as busy as the Superpool and bar were. No matter what time of day, we were able to get a seat at the Tapa pool, though the pool stays fairly shaded until after 1:00 pm. I recommend the Tapa over Rainbow anyday!!Other things you should know:CAR RENTAL - There is a Hertz on site... don't use it! It's twice the price of any other rental company and they don't offer free parking even though the lot is on their property! We rented from the airport which was by far the cheapest deal (dollar rent a car, book ahead of time on the internet, it's cheaper!), and self parking was $22 per day, though you have to valet on your arrival, prior to check in. Just tell the front desk you only want valet for one day.LATE CHECKOUTS - This service, the hotel doesn't offer, but they do have a service called Hospitality rooms. The day before you leave, call the front desk and make a reservation for a hospitality room.. it's basically a regular hotel room stocked with towels and soap and you get 20 mins per person to use the room to shower and change before you head to the airport. Also, you are still allowed to use all of the hotels services until 7:00 pm the day you checkout.FOOD AND DRINK - These things can seem pricey, but it ain't Mexico! If you've been to Vegas, the prices are about the same... and we found the onsite restaurants to be no more, or less expensive than the restaurants downtown. In addition, there was a huge variety of restaurants onsite to choose from , and downtown is only a 15 minute walk with even more selection!IN ROOM INTERNET - The TV feature is terrible!! It's $8.95 for an hour and extremely slow! The options say you can check your home e-mail... you can't! The good thing is, the front desk gave us a credit when we complained, and even the assistant manager of the hotel didn't recommend the service.SPA - We went in and asked for a price list... they didn't have one...??? In addition, they tried to sign us up for the Time Share presentation in there!! ?? If you want a massage, I recommend booking at the Superpool massage station, no sales pitch, prices are the same, and the massage was great! One final footnote - be prepared for the Time Share sales pitch, we just ignored them and didn't sign up. You get $100 in Hilton bucks to spend in the resort, but we couldn't be bothered.Other than the few minor glitches, which can be expected on any trip, we absolutley LOVED this resort and highly recommend it. The staff were extrememly accomodating and friendly, and the roons were clean and beautiful.. ocean view or not! Have fun!  
<Date>Feb 25, 2008

<Author>TravelingManAlberta
<Content>Fabulous Time at The Hawaiian Hilton Village My wife and I just returned home from the most wonderful 2 weeks that one could ask for. The staff and the Resort itself were second to none and it simply couldn't have been any better. We were upgraded to the Ali'i Tower with out even asking for an upgrade, certainly cannot complain about the check-in staff. We found all of the staff that we encountered to be wonderful and certainly they knew how to spread the Aloha. We were more than pleased by this beautiful resort and we would certainly recommend it to anyone. There are so many great restaurants in Waikiki Beach that you don't have to worry about the cost of dinning out. There are so many positive things about the Village that I found it hard to imagine that anyone would not enjoy staying there. We have travelled extensively and stayed in many 5 Star resorts and this was certainly one of the best. Don't let the negative reviews scare you away from the Hawaii Hilton Village, you must experience it for yourself as we did and you will find the best beach area and a first class hotel will make for a fantastic holiday. ALOHA

<Author>gail_wilson
<Content>Great stay! Beautiful hotel! Beautiful location! My husband and I stayed for 3 nights in the Rainbow Tower. Our room had an ocean view. The room was beautifully decorated. The weather was gorgeous and sunny. It is a full-service property. I was tired and was there to relax. I loved the fact that I didn't need to leave the property for anything. The property is lushly landscaped. You feel like you are in a tropical garden. There are palm trees, waterfalls, tropical fish, turtles, penguins, birds, etc. There are several pools. The main pool is the Super Pool. We had a balcony and basically slept with the doors open, because we loved it so much. We had the breakfast buffet each morning downstairs in the Rainbow Tower. My husband is a Hilton Honors club member; hence we received a great discount on the price of the breakfast buffet. We also had lunch and dinner at the property (Hanajuban Noodle Shop, CJ's New York Style Delicatessen, Lappert's Ice Cream, Tropics Bar and Beach Caf茅). Some of the restaurants have Early Dinner Specials (i.e. Benahana). We spent each day on the beach or exploring the property. We did venture down the beach to the Outrigger Reef Hotel to have dinner at the Shorebird one night. We remembered it from a previous visit to Waikiki and enjoyed it. On my next stay, I plan to spend several hours (if not an entire day) at the Ala Moana Shopping Center.

<Author>West_Linn_Travelers
<Content>For the business traveler overpriced, noisy, and crowded I am a Hilton Diamond HHonors member and recently stayed in the Ali'i Tower on a business trip to Honolulu as I have for over ten years. Sadly, I plan to not return to the Hilton Hawaiian Village, but shift to the Hilton Prince Kuhio.For the rates one is charged to stay in the Ali'i Tower - presumably the best lodging offered, one would expect a higher level of guest service and certainly a better stay experience. Unfortunately, both were lacking from the time I checked in right through my stay.Making my reservation using the Hilton Family website was effortless as is always the case.The only way I can desribe checkin is the word bedlam. The valet parking ($28 a night) personnel were overwhelmed and cars were backed up for a 20 minute wait. After leaving my car, I went directly to the Ali'i Tower, which touts its separate check in facilities. Unfortunately, the check-in counter was innundated with groups of guests. Checking in involved a wait of almost 30 minutes and I was disappointed to find no automated check-in kiosk.The greatest disappointment of my stay was my room. I had requested a quiet room. As an aside, at the Ali'i Tower, you can reserve - and of course pay for - one of three room types (full coean view, partial ocean view, or garden view). Frankly, the only way you'll see the Pacific Ocean if you're in a partial ocean view room is if you're an acrobat and hang over the balcony. If you want a view of the ocean, plan on paying $100 or more per night. Otherwise, save your money and content yourself with a view of the pool or a view of the wedding chapel. When I arrived at my room on the 6th floor, I found that I had been assigned a connecting room, a room with a single key-locked door separating two guest rooms. The result is like having no door at all between rooms. The desk staff claimed that no other rooms were available in the building and that, in essence, I was stuck with what I had been assigned. A family with two or three very, very young children were in the connecting room and the noise throughout the night kept me from getting much sleep. My adivce to you is that if you're assigned a connecting room you refuse to accept the room and seek a replacement room.The simple truth is that a stay at this property is a process to (a) separate as much money from you as possible and (b) incessantly market the Hilton Grand Vacation Club to you. DIning prices (let alone room service prices) are obscene, even by resort standards. I agree with others who have recommended that you buy food and beverages at the nearby ABC stores and/or dine off-property. Frankly, if you are staying here with your family, my advice to you is this: if you have a rental car and a Costco membership card, stop at the Costco that's just off the Nimitz on the way in from the airport (right across the parking lot from the Dole Cannery). Stock up on pretty much anything you'll need (the Costco even sells hard liquoir!!!) before going on to the hotel. All the rooms have small fridges with a tiny freezer.The HIlton Village is crowded with conventioneers, grumpy families, and an almost endless stream of wedding parties. If you want a quiet island vacation, the Hawaiian Village is not for you.  
<Date>Feb 19, 2008

<Author>TexasLonghornmom
<Content>Don't stay here if you want to get away from it all! We stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village for a conference that was being held at the local convention center. What a zoo this place is! It's absolutely huge with just about anything anyone would want, but if you really want to get away from it all--DO NOT STAY HERE!! From the pools at the base of the hotel towers with people partying into the night, to the price of everything, aka: $15 to rent one lounge chair, $30 to rent an umbrella for the day. That's $60 for the two of us and we have not even bought a drink yet! Hey, I don't wanna buy your stuff - just use it for the day! Oh, and want a cup of coffee? The urns of coffee in hotel lobbies that usually is complimentary--try $4 - YIKES! Hey, can't you get a Starbucks for the same price? The best days of our trip to Oahu were spent in a $59 dollar-per-day red convertible - hawaiian music playing on the radio driving around the island-the North Shore, the shrimp trucks on the east side, Banzai Beach. and the beauty of the Pali look-out. The locals with ice cold coconut milk stands and freshly cut pineapple. THOSE will be my favorite memories--NOT the overpriced, 3000 room Hilton.  
<Date>Feb 15, 2008

<Author>45statesandcounting
<Content>Beautiful, but just not for me I have stayed at The Village numerous times for long visits. Even as a repeat guest and Diamond Hilton Honors member (if you don't know what this means, join Hilton Honors and find out -it's great!), I find that my treatment at this hotel varies. My first trip, last year, was wonderful. I received an upgraded room with a lovely partial ocean view. Subsequent trips ping-ponged between good and ok. My last trip was horrible. I was treated extremely rudely on check in, given a sub-par room (the lady claimed there were no better ones, but others in my party were given much better rooms even though they are not frequent guests), harassed when my husband stayed with me for two nights (which is supposed to be free for hilton honors members), and treated horribly both times I tried to eat on the premises. One waitress at the Tapa Bar ignored us for twenty minutes while she chatted with the bar-tender - and then told us that the bar was closed! As I walked away from the bar, I heard the bar-tender offer another patron a drink. As a general rule, the food at the Village is over-priced, not that great, and totally unavailable after about 9PM - but it's a walk to the main part of Waikiki. They were even rude when I tried to leave my luggage at the Bell desk while I went to get my car at check out. I was not feeling the aloha.As a business traveler, I also find The Village a bit crowded. The pool area is busy and exposed, there is no hot tub, and it's not relaxing. To be fair, the Village is lovely - the pools, flora, fauna, and view are all beautiful. There is live music every night and it is right on a gorgeous stretch of beach and a lagoon - but I can't help but feel that I'm in a mall every time I stay there. It is so crowded - and a little like Disneyland. The amenities are just not what I'm used to when I travel for business. They simply do not cater to executive travelers. Everything feels like it is costing them extra effort - from charging a meal to my room at one of the over-priced and sub-par restaurants to the little details that make my constant life on the road bearable, like picking up my dry-cleaning, or rectifying an incorrect room charge. I find this very strange, since the only reason they are not empty like many other Waikiki hotels is the fact that they host so many conventions and business travelers.I guess the bottom line is - it is beautiful, but it's not for me.  
<Date>Feb 11, 2008

<Author>scrambler329
<Content>One of my favorites!! I have stayed at this property many times over the years. I enjoy the grounds and the amenities. I just stayed in the renovated Tapa Tower. Nicely remodeled. The TVs were older though. Nice view and balcony. I have stayed in every tower at this property. Of course Alii is the best but Tapa and Kalia are nice. I like Tapa because it is closer to pools and main hotel area. Having all those shops and restaurants so close is convenient. But, if you like being in the heart of the Waikiki action this is not the property for you. It is a long walk to the Waikiki beach and shops. It is a shorter walk to Ala Moana Center. I like being isolated as I feel there is less crowded feel to the beach.

<Author>DennonD
<Content>Our Hawaiian Paradise We recently stayed 5 nights at the Hilton Hawaiian village. It was by far our best experience of all of the hotels that we have stayed in. (Sheraton Waikiki, Waikiki Marriott, The Hyatt, Ala Moana Hotel, Marriott Koolina, The Prince) We were in the lagoon tower. When we first arrived, we unloaded our luggage and I asked for self parking. I hate to wait for the valet to retrieve my car. I was told parking would be difficult and some have even gotten lost, perhaps this was their effort to get me to valet park. I told the attendant that I was pretty smart and I think I can find the garage. I found a parking spot which wound up being just outside of the entrance to our tower. Our room was amazing. It overlooked the lagoon as well as the ocean. We were able to watch the evening entertainment they had for special events on the lawn. We were close to the beach as well as the walking path along the beach. The restaurants and shopping inside the village were real convenient. Our room had an oversize lanai with large sliding glass doors. When left open, it just added more space to our living area. We left thinking that this is the place where we want to come back to.
