<Author>TravelPrincess3
<Content>Great location We stayed at the HHV for only two nights before a cruise and really enjoyed it. We found the service to be excellent, always a smile on everyone's face and a real willingness to help. We were upgraded to an ocean view room and the room itself was very clean and the bed was comfy. (We stayed in the Kahlia tower that I think was the most recent to be renovated so that could be why it was so nice). We did a spa treatment for my boyfriend's birthday, the spa was gorgeous and very relaxing. Only one problem, they gave us our robes to change into and when I was done changing I came out and the woman told me to go back into the changing area and wait until she called me-a lovely area with magazines, coffee, etc. so I didn't mind waiting. After about a half hour she came and got me and brought me down to the massage room area where my bf told me that our masseuse had been waiting for us the entire time and everyone had been looking for me.....???The pools were REALLY cold, one of the days there was only one person in the super pool. The prices are outrageous for drinks so try to stay away from the hotel bars. The location is probably the best part of the hotel, the beach is right outside and downtown Waikiki is within walking distance. A short cab ride away is Diamond Head, the zoo, and the aquarium (the zoo and aquarium are right across from each other and we actually walked back to the hotel from them through downtown Waikiki).The hotel is really expensive and there is nothing included with the price. The only restaurant that we ate at (besides the little beach bar) was the Village Steakhouse which was excellent, the service and food were well worth it. There is a 24 hour diner right across the street from HHV which is cheap and good, we went for breakfast and the night that we got in at midnightish. All in all, kids will have a blast with the beach and the pools. The grounds are beautiful and there are penguins, fish, and birds. It is a really beautiful place but not many perks for your money. But I would definately return!  
<Date>Feb 4, 2008

<Author>VirginiaDoctorlady

<Author>Neilb62
<Content>Excellent. We stayed here on Honeymoon in March 2007.A very impressive complex, right on wakiki beach.A typical American resort hotel, clean , excellent food with great service. Lots of different restaurants to choose from, also several bars serving almost any sort of drink you could want!The room (in Diamond Head Tower) was large and modern with a view along the beach from the balcony. A minor problem with the plumbing was fixed within 20 minutes.No doubt this is an expensive hotel, but we were spoiling ourselves and felt it was well worth it.

<Author>notrevol
<Content>3 star experience and 5 star prices From check in, and throughout my stay, it was clear that the staff and service levels were significantly substandard for a 5 star resort.Upon arrival I was confronted with 2 long queues for check in, with no signage and no staff direction. Having finally determined which queue to join by other patrons, I then had to wait 45 minutes before being served by a clearly grumpy attendant (although I can sympathise as she was very overworked). Given that a conference was on and it was known that there would be a high volume of check ins that day, I'm surprised that more staff were not put on to deal with the workload.Despite requesting an early check in, I was required to wait until 3:30pm to get access to my room, at which time, despite having checked my suitcase with the bell boy 4 hours earlier, it sat sitting on the sidewalk next to the concierge desk.When finally given my smoke free room, I was disappointed to find that the room reeked of smoke - right through the bedding, and all soft furnishings. Even as I was attempting to get another room booked, the bell hop was only concerned with getting a tip, not helping to resolve the issue. This that's not my job mentality was rife throughout the entire staff.The facilities in the room were woefully lacking, with no mini-bar, no robe, and very basic toiletries provided (no body wash, no moisturizer, no cotton buds or cotton balls).The location was quite good, although a little too far from the main Waikiki strip if you wanted to eat out of your room (you'd need to walk over 1km to get to the resto area).There are many other luxury resorts in the Waikiki area, many with lower room rates, that I would recommend over the Hilton.  
<Date>Jan 31, 2008

<Author>NavyDawg
<Content>Go With An Open Mind. My partner and I just returned from an eight night HHonors award as a HHonors Diamond member. A lot has been said about this property - both for and against. Here's my two cents: it's clearly not for everyone. Like any hotel anywhere, a traveler needs to perform due diligence and research all options. It's a very large hotel that has to cater to a wide selection of guests. Are there better options such as time-shares, house rentals, other locations like the North Shore? That's for you to decide. Are there less expensive options? Once again - only you can decide. But for a full-service, beach-front Waikiki hotel, you're going to behard pressed to find this amount sheer activities, shopping, and dining in one place. Overall, we were impressed with the cleanliness of the resort, and the attitude of the staff. The FB options were no more expensive than any other Waikiki beach front resort. And that is very important aspect to remember: sure, you can eat at the Waialana Coffee House around the corner for $10 - but you can't at any other Waikiki beach front resort.We e-mailed the GM one week prior asking for best available upgrade. Response received approx. 48 hours later from Front Desk manager assuring top level treatment (Rainbow Tower, corner king). Also guaranteed usual Diamond/Gold Breakfast Coupons, and gave us access to Ali'i Tower Oceanview Terrace Pool, and evening pupus. There is a small gym located there as well. So right off the start - on an award - we were offered everything we wanted.Arrived approximately 830PM from Mainland. Reception area pleasantly uncrowded. First room offered was 8th floor Rainbow Tower Corner King. We were not impressed. Yes, it was beachfront, and it had two balconies - and it was exactly what we had been promised. But it was just a standard room. And not very high up. Second offer was for 14th floor Rainbow Tower Executive King facing the lagoon - but we couldn't occupy it until the next day. Not happy about that. Third time was a charm for us. 20th Floor Tapa Tower 1 bedroom Suite - directly facing the Super Pool and the Beach. The room was newly renovated: entrance hall, living room, wet bar, dining room, 1/2 bath, large king bedroom, dressing area with sink, and full bath - with window sidelight in the tub. Two balconies: one facing the Super Pool/Beach, the other facing the City. For our purposes, we were very happy. We also asked for and received free internet access for our entire stay. Maid service was excellent - especially with a small tip.Breakfast every morning at Tapa Cafe since Rainbow was closed. It was always busy, but never more than a 5 minute wait. We had the option of using the Diamond/Gold card at Tropics or at Ali'i, but Tapa was by far the best. Upgrade at Tapa is currently $10. Ate one meal at Golden Dragon and enjoyed it. It is closing permanently sometime around the first of February. Ate twice at Hatsuhana, and twice at Tropics. All good, and service was great.The Executive Lounge in the Kalia Tower is permanently closed. I guess the reason we got the access to the Ali'i was because we complained about that.The evening pupus at the Oceanview Terrace at Ali'i were very nice: two hot appetizers, and a large cheese/vegetable/fruit display. Nice place to watch the sun set. Mixed tropical drinks run about $9.We did the HGVC spiel because we wanted the $150 HHV Vouchers which came in handy for meals. I would rate the pressure level as medium. If you can spare the 1.5 hours and don't mind it - I would recommend it. If you don't want the $150 HHV Vouchers you can get 30,000 HHonors points.Lagoon is open, clean, and waterfall is running. Of all the pools, we thought Ali'i was by far the best. If you can get the access, do it. All the pools were cold. One attendant at Ali'i told us that they had stopped heating the pools.For approximately $8, you can get a day pass at Mandara Spa in the Kalia Tower which allows you use their japanese style hot-tub, steam room, sauna - but no spa services.Asked for a very late check out (5PM) on our day of departure - no problem. Used one of the Hospitality Rooms in the Diamond Head Tower for 45 minutes prior to departure for no charge. Shuttle back to airport then back to Mainland.We got a lot of extra perks for being HHonors Diamond members, but putting that point aside, we still thought it was an enjoyable vacation and would recommend it again. Feel free to contact me if you have further questions.  
<Date>Jan 31, 2008

<Author>travelko
<Content>Not bad for a Convention Site Just returned from a weeks stay. Purpose of the trip was to exhibit at a convention on the property. The hotel convention halls were very clean and the staff helped out. Needed extra hangers for my display, called bell desk and bell man brought the hangers right to my booth within 10 minutes. Stayed in a garden view room in the Tapa Tower. Had very good view of the pool. Room was cleaned on a daily basis. In the evening I could hear the nightly entertainment from the balcony outside my room, but when I closed the balcony door I could not hear noise. The food in the convention hall was very good. It was provided by the hotel. Fresh fruit and fresh sandwich wraps. From other reviews on the site I did go to the all you can eat pancakes at the coffee shop across the street. At $5.75 for two eggs, two pieces of bacon and endless pancakes this might be the best deal on the island. Did not have much time for the beach, but I did take a stroll on it and it was very clean. Would go back with my family.

<Author>murrayhill
<Content>What You Expect, Minus A Little Aloha My family wrapped up 11 nights on Maui and Oahu with a two-night stay using Hilton HHonors points.Check-in was relatively brisk, though the bellhop taking our bags out of the car was a bit brusque.The room and view were fine, as was the free breakfast we were entitled to. Though this is an immense hotel, it's eminently possible to find places where you're not amidst teeming crowds. Overall, we found the pools, food and amenities to be what we expected or more.The only exception was with the valet parking, which cost $26 a day. It used to be a dollar less, but for your convenience added a dollar to include a tip.However, the first time I retrieved my car and didn't slip the attendant a dollar, I was given a dirty look. To avoid that, I gave the next guy a George Washington the following day. Upon returning home, I wrote to the hotel's general manager, who explained that the extra dollar was negotiated into the valets' contract because many people weren't tipping. All well and good, except when they try to guilt you into effectively double-tipping.The GM agreed that was not acceptable, and I'd be curious to see if it's been policed more aggressively. Overall, though, this was a nice stay if you positively, absolutely have to be on Waikiki.If you don't, I'd recommend renting a house or condo a little out of the city in a place like Kaneohe, just 20 minutes or so from downtown.We did that the first four nights and got a beautiful house at the top of a hill for just $160 a night, and got to experience Hawaii amid the locals rather than tourists for some nice slices of life. You can save a lot of money and get a more-authentic island experience at the same time. Pretty good deal in my book. Vrbo.com has an ample selection of listings.  
<Date>Jan 28, 2008

<Author>optimist1
<Content>Highly Recommended!!! This is a gorgeous property. There are multiple towers, we were in the Kalia Tower on the executive floor which was very nice (we were upgraded for free!). The rooms were exceptional with Crabtree and Evelyn bath products, spacious balconies, and attention paid to detail. Included with executive status is continental breakfast from 8-10 am each morning with a nice selection of fruit, pastries, cereals and an afternoon tea starting at 4pm with snacks (quiche, cookies, veggies, etc). The pools are nice and there is a lagoon as well. The property is on the beach and in the midst of high-end shops. A short 10-15 min walk gets you to Waikiki Beach. There are many restaurant options in the hotel vicinity, though, so you can consider this a complete resort with pool, shopping, spa, and restaurants all on the premises. Aquacylces, kayaks can be rented on the property as well. We had a great vacation here and would recommend it to anyone......  
<Date>Jan 27, 2008

<Author>premiumpdp
<Content>Subpar standards due to buyout this past year!!!! BEWARE!!!! For those who have visited Hiltons in the past, please beware! I am currently a diamond VIP for hilton and i must say i was very dissappointed with the standards at this hotel. However, i will point out the wins and opps separately to be fair.Wins:Huge village, lots of shopping, nice weekend evening shows with fireworks, very nice beach which is not too packed, great view of Diamond head from the beach as well. Pool and scenery is great and there are nice animals within the village including penguins, turtles, birds, and fish....Staff were also very friendly overall within the restaurants and shops and the front desk as well..Opps:1. Room Standards - extremely subpar. Our first room was at the diamond tower and the room had a horrible smell coming from the bathroom...the sink was somewhat clogged which caused alot of odor to permeate through the room. The closet door was broken, only 3 pillows were given for a king size bed, NO lotion as an amenity? (i get lotion even at a motel 6....) and as a diamond member, they forgot to provide me with two bottles of water...the worst was that they had a welcome letter since i was a diamond member stating that there would be two bottles in the room...address these concerns to front desk manager Jin, and he gave us an upgrade to the Rainbow tower which gave us a wonderful view but still, the amenities and room itself were average at best. 2. Food - Breakfast was standard, however, as a diamond member, you only get free continental breakfast....other food was subpar as well...we tried some japanese noodles which was awful, we had a buffet one night which did not match to what the pictures looked like....prices were extremely high3. HHONORS priveleges - no more exec lounge due to buyout, no access to gym unless you pay, no complimentary ANYTHING...besides a continental breakfast....Overall, b/c the hotel was so big and busy, i did not feel the personal attention i usually get at a smaller resort...for a honeymoon, they did not do one special thing for us. If i did not complain, i would have settled for an awful room. I suggest anyone who stays here to go out to eat. Several nice places and some hole in the wall places if you go out to eat. Better quality and prices. Yes, everyone says hawaii is expensive, but like NYC, you can always find a good deal if you look hard enough...if you choose to stay as just a tourist, then tourist prices is what you'll pay...Island itself has alot of shopping, hiking tours are great...try out Oahu Nature Tours....staff is really friendly. North shore was sometime to see, and get some sun on the beach!Feel free to let me know if you have any other questions...  
<Date>Jan 26, 2008

<Author>aimee_80
<Content>Beautiful Hotel My Husband  I took our 3 year old son there and had a great time. The hotel  it's grounds are lovely, and very well maintained! The rooms are small, pretty and very clean and the beds  bedding were very comfortable! The location cant be beat! The beach is so beautiful, and not so crowded in front of the Hilton as in many other places. The pool is nice, but it is very hard to get a lounge chair because people always leave their towels on them. They hand out towels by the pool but, there are no towel bins to put them in when you are done, so many of the towels that are reserving the chairs are actually from people that aren't even swimming any more. Even without chairs, we really enjoyed this resort! We would come back!

<Author>George_P_Burdell_67
<Content>Million Dollar View The Hilton Hawaiian Village (HHV) is a huge resort right on Waikiki Beach that does not feel like one. The open air lobby sets the tone -- informal, lush plantings, talking parrot, lots of water splashing in fountains, a view through to the large pool and the Pacific beyond. We arrived late from the mainland and our room was not ready, so they comped us a couple drinks and after 15 minutes led us to room 1203 in the Rainbow Tower. What a suprise -- a fabulous view over Waikiki Beach and Diamond Head that was worth the wait. For folks who normally end up looking at the air conditioners or dumpster, it was a revelation. The room itself was fine -- nice linens, excellent bed, AC worked. The Rainbow Tower is a landmark that is 40 years old, so some of the other towers are much newer, but the location is ideal -- right on the beach, close to the shopping village, lobby and parking structure. HHV is close enough to the rest of Waikiki that a 10-15 minute walk puts you high on the hog in shopping heaven. Our only quibbles were the $15+ per day they charged for internet access and the $20/day they charged for self-parking. We would definitely stay at the HHV again.  
<Date>Jan 25, 2008

<Author>amwhite03
<Content>Loved the Hilton Just returned from a seven day trip (Jan. 12-19). What a perfect hotel. We stayed in Rainbow tower, Room 2500 (25 represents the 25th floor). I strongly encourage everyone to stay in the Rainbow Tower. I think it has the best views of all the towers. Rooms ending in 00 or 01 are the corner units facing the ocean. Any odd numbers are great rooms as well, as they face down Waiikiki towards Diamond head. The even rooms face towards downtown, but you still have a partial ocean view. The hotel made this trip. Waikiki is very, very busy beach and Hilton has the best location at the end of the beach. It gives you a very expansive portion of beach (we had plenty of room), unlike other hotels that have literally no, or less than 10 yards of beach. Plus, you can easily walk down to Dukes (overrated in my opinion) or the Royal Hawaaainn (you HAVE to go here for Mai Tai's...simply the best on the island). Also recomend HY's Steak house and Michel's at the colony surf for two of the best dinners i have had. Hy's was one of the best steak places I have been, and it had the best ceasar salad. Table side cooking is great for some items. Michel's is the perfect place to have a 6pm reservation, as you get the sunset. The hotel looks out on the ocean (other end of Waikkiki). Also recomend the hike up Diamond Head, the visit to Pearl Harbor, and a nice drive around the island and visit to the North Shore. We hit diamond head early a.m (7) and it was fine. You have to get to Pearl Harbor early (we got there around 645) to beat the busses which show up b/t 645 and 7. We were back to hotel by 945 and had the whole day. Should get a car so you can drive as you want - we put over 500 miles on it adn still were on the beach everyday. Its great to drive to dinner, and you are not at the mercy of the bus, especially diamond head, pearl harbor, etc... Worth a day trip around the island - spend some time on North Shore (Cholo's mexican was great for lunch) and spend some time at beaches on east/southeastern side of island. Any questions, please feel free to shoot me an email.  
<Date>Jan 25, 2008

<Author>ELLIEWickfordEssex
<Content>Hooray for Hilton We stayed here from 23rd December to 29th December 2007, and WOW!!! what a winter wonderland, the perfect Christmas location!!! The hotel stands on the widest stretch of Waikiki beach in the perfect setting.The resort is huge with many places to eat, and many enticing shops. The large pool has a wonderful bar serving many delicious cocktails with or without alcohol. It can be expensive to eat here every day, but a 10 minute walk brings you to the main stretch along the beach, with many cheaper bars and restaurants.We stayed in the Tapa Tower, with brilliant views of Diamond Head [volcano], and city, and a partial ocean view. The room was huge, as we were upgraded. We have a 13 year old daughter who thoroughly enjoyed turtle watching whilst on a pedalo in the amazing clear waters of Waikiki. This hotel really does have it all, and never feels overcrowded as it is so vast. Also the people are helpfull and friendly this really added to our enjoyment of our stay here. Checkin is very fast especially if you are a Hilton Honours card member as they have their own checkin desk.This was a truly fabulous hotel, and we will hopefully return as soon as possible.  
<Date>Jan 25, 2008

<Author>rileyscountry
<Content>Ho Hum at the Hilton My husband and I stayed at Ali'i Tower for 5 nights this January. I was immediately disappointed when we first walked into our room, as they are slightly outdated (even with the flatscreen TV). I laughed at the miniture TV mounted to the bathroom counter... I think it was from 1988. The rooms are good sized with large bathrooms and seperate dressing towers. I can't believe they actually charge $3.50 a day for the in-room safe (even in the Ali'i Tower). The maid service was on the ball, however, and we had great twice-daily service.However, the place did grow on me over the days we were there. The 5-7pm hot and cold appetizers were a nice touch (complimentry). The drinks are strong (should be for $9.75)... try their Mai Tais or Tropical Itch. We did enjoy the nightly live music and sunsets from our room (room #1026 overlooking the superpool and if you walk out on the deck and look left, the ocean). The Ali'i tower pool is small, but not very crowded and has the best lounge chairs if you're a layer. They're teak with large cushions (vs the vinyl chairs around the super pool which are crammed in).We heeded the warning and did not eat much at the Hilton property. Yes, the food and drinks are very expensive (think $14.95 for a burger). We bought quite a bit of snacks at the ABC store on site. We had a great dinner at Kobe Japenese Steak House which borders the Hilton property (think Benihana but its independent and been there 27 years... or was it 37?). We also had a great dinner at Nobu which is a 15 minute walk.Considering everything else on Waikiki, this is a resort with multiple pools, a great beach, and easy access to the stores/restaurants/front desk/etc from your room. However, the resort is large and very mixed and just not on par with the other Hilton's we have stayed at (our favorite is the Hilton Los Cabos so far).  
<Date>Jan 25, 2008

<Author>Mojo8
<Content>Alii Tower is better but still not up to snuff The hotel is nice overall. The resort is huge. It is both a blessing and a curse for it to be so large. There are many options, but it lulls you into not leaving. The Alii Tower rooms were nice and pretty good size. The dressing area and separate bathroom areas were very nice. I was disappointed that despite this upgraded section of the hotel that there was no lei greeting, and no doorman. We had our 9 month old with us so we had a stroller and the doors were always closed, so it was just a pain to open it every time to go in. For an upgraded section of the hotel, I was a bit disappointed with the lack of such details. The Alii Tower pool deck is fine with nice chairs. The breakfast was very disappointing, even though it was included with our room. There are no hot dishes for your $15.25. I think this is good option for the price, but it is unexceptional. I would recommend skipping the very expensive dining options at the hotel. They seem ok, but not worth the price. Nobu is about a 10 minute walk down the boardwalk across from the Halekulani. Roy's is also next to Nobu. You'll spend less than at the Golden Dragon or Bali by the Sea, and the quality is so much better. There is a Thai restaurant at the corner of Ala Moana and Kalia that is quite good with live dancing. It's a bit expensive, but still better than Benihana at the hotel.  
<Date>Jan 24, 2008

<Author>faeryfires
<Content>Not worth the price! I've stayed at the Hawaiian Village before and the grounds are what brought me back, but i was sorely disappointed after my last visit. I stayed from December 27th-Jan 2nd then went to stay in Maui for 5 more days. When we first got to the Hilton we tried checking in at 1:40 pm, i had been up since 4 am pacific time and desperately wanted to change. I was told the check in time was 2 pm and a room wasnt ready also i was told to leave my number and i would be called as soon as it was ready. At 3:25 i got tired of waiting for a phone call and stood in 2 seperate lines and finally was given my room key. The room was a disappointment. i was being charged $525/night for a room with one pen in the whole room (i looked), and not so much as a complimentary water. Above that the restroom was questionable. The toilet seat was peeling and when i tried to take a shower the drain backed up and i was ankle deep in water. I stayed at the Diamond Head Tower and on New Years night couldnt find my room key so i tried to find a desk to get another, i was sent from tower to tower because the computers were down, it was a real waste of time. All in all for that much I expected better service and anemities. The grounds are still gorgeous but i'd really reconsider staying somewhere else and just visiting  
<Date>Jan 16, 2008

<Content>Awesome We stayed here for 14 nights on honeymoon and I wasn't disappointed with my choice of hotel.This Hilton is huge, like it says, it鈥檚 a village with about 4 hotel towers surrounding the inner circle of restaurants, swimming pools, shops etc... But it鈥檚 not packed in and you鈥檙e not overlooking anyone. Check-in was fast and friendly. The room was lovely with stunning views from our balcony of the resort and beach! <Author>vacationer28216
<Content>It was OK Our family traveled to Honolulu for 2 weeks during Christmas and reserved 3 rooms for 17 nights at the HHV. To be brief, it was ok......but that is about it. We would not stay there again, but it was nice.We found the rooms to be clean, and well maintained. We were promised one upgrade since we were renting 3 rooms for so long (and because we are Hilton Gold Members) , but there were none available. This was disappointing. The manager and the reception staff are adequate, but not overly friendly or helpful.The pools are VERY crowded, and it is nearly impossible to find a lounge chair by the pool. The thing that we could not believe is that the pool and ocean front bars all close before 9pm. The only places open to get a during have really bad live music 7 nights a week.If you are planning a trip in the very near future, please be aware that most of the restaurants are closed for renovations. They knocked power out to our building and we had to walk up to the 31st floor for a full day.....and the managers did not apologize. We had Christmas dinner at Bali By The Sea restaurant, $150 per person. The service was fair, and the food was not very good. The Chinese restaurant was great, but they are closing very soon....which is sad. I had read so many reviews that were complaining about the prices of everything....and it was really not as bad as I expected. The drink prices were all about $10, but most all of the other places on the beach are much cheaper. They are about $5 at Dukes. The ABC store is very nice, and reasonably priced.The lagoon opened when we were there, and it is a nice addition. It offers swimming and other water sports, and there is a nice sandy beach.Things not to miss.....A Lava Flow Drink (from Duke's)The King's Jubilee Show at the hotel....very nice and only $10Snorkeling the Coral Reef right outside of the HotelA Helicopter tour of the island (THIS WAS GREAT!)And if you are interested in the Pearl Harbor tours, check out Home of the Brave tour. It gets to Pearl Harbor earlier in the morning. If you get there after 9am, there is a 3-5 hour wait.....but get there by 7am and walk right in.  
<Date>Jan 15, 2008

<Author>degroohj
<Content>Absolutely fantastic! My new husband and I had the opportunity to stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village for our honeymoon from January 5th through the 12th of this year. I must say, after reading some of the reviews on this resort, I was extremely anxious to arrive to either confirm or deny the comments of other travelers. I am happy to report that our stay at the resort was met with pure optimism and an amazing experience.We arrived at the Hilton late in the evening on a Saturday after a long flight from New Jersey. My parents are Hilton Grand Vacation Club members, and were gracious enough to give us their timeshare for our honeymoon as a wedding present. Therefore, we stayed in the Lagoon Tower. When we got off the shuttle, our bags were taken immediately to our hotel room without hesitation nor pressure to be tipped. We were guided to our tower and immediately checked in without any problems. I had heard on this site that the resort was currently under construction in certain areas, which is true. However, we were lucky to be placed in a room on the 14th floor facing the lagoon and the ocean. We had a fantastic view from our room, where we were able to see almost the entire resort as well as the water. The room was very clean, as well as the balcony. My only complaint concerning the room was the bathroom, where I was expecting a separate tub and shower after staying in other 1 bedroom condos through Hilton in the past. However, this is not a necessity.The places to eat in the resort can be very expensive. However, with the location of the Hilton being in the midst of Waikiki, dining options are endless outside of the resort. I would recommend dining at Bali at the Sea in the Hilton, due to the quality of both the service as well as the food. It isn't cheap, but if you go at 6pm Monday through Thursday, ask for the Sunset Dinner Special, where you receive a special menu with dining entrees at a reduced price. As for the resort itself, it has absolute character and appeal. I found it to be absolutely beautiful, whether you were at the beach or on the sidewalk on Kalia Rd. The service was fantastic. We were always greeted whether we were arriving or leaving our tower in the resort. Questions were always addressed on the spot and handled accordingly. I would definitely recommend this resort for couples despite past reviews saying it is more family oriented. Vacations are what you make out of them. Yes, there were families with small children at the resort during our stay, but in no way did it hinder our awesome experience.If you're looking for an active honeymoon full of activity as well as relaxation, the Hilton Hawaiian Village will provide just that.  
<Date>Jan 15, 2008

<Author>mkent924
<Content>Expensive, but Superior Resort The Hilton Hawaiian Village on Wakiki Beach is a sure-fire way to have a superb Hawaiian experience. There is a reason why this is the top-grossing property in the Hilton Family of Hotels. A meticulous, well-run, family resort right on Wakiki Beach, this property boasts exotic birds and wildlife, numerous shops and restaurants, an immaculate beach, a number of swimming pools, adult and children's activities, fireworks on Fridays, tour services, and a hospitable staff that will make your stay comfortable and enjoyable. Be prepared, the hotel and food are not cheap, so plan accordingly. Beachside hamburgers at Tropics Cafe for a family of four will give you a tab of over $60.00. That said, you can book this hotel in confidence that you will have a truly memorable stay at a superior resort.

<Author>Sweetsugar1621
<Content>Needs Updating We chose the Hilton Hawaii Village resort for our honeymoon as it look gorgeous in all the brochures. On arrival the Hilton Village ticked all the right boxes, beautiful lobby, wonderful swimming pool, gorgeous gardens, great shops etc etc. However, when we made our way to our room, which was situated on the right hand side of the Rainbow tower, my expectations were clearly too high as I found the communal areas and corridors to be a little bit dated. Our room was pleasant and clean, but it definately felt as though it had seen better days, and the bathroom needed a lick of paint! Overall however, it was a lovely stay, the 30 second stroll to Waikiki beach certainly made up for the disappointing decor and the swimming facilities were fantastic! Eating out wasn't a problem either as you are central to so many things (we decided against eating in one of the many restaurants at the village, as they were quite expensive)!! The experience certainly hasn't put us off Hawaii, but we would think twice about staying at the Hilton.

<Author>Meech123
<Content>Not a hotel for Hilton Diamond Members I booked my stay at this hotel in April 2007 for the period December 25th to December 31. I checked at least 3 times (two in December) to ensure that I was on the list for an upgrade. I have been a Hilton Diamond Member for over 4 years and have a continuance until April 2009.Arrived on December 25th to a sold out hotel. They did have a king size room reserved in the Tapia Tower overlooking the garden pool and over the band area of the cocktail lounge. The band played from 7:30 p.m. until 11:00 p.m. I asked to be notified of any potential upgrades over the 6 day stay and was told by the manager Kim that all rooms were pre-assigned.They did provide a complimentary continental breakfast coupon. I was advised that all executive floors are closed and there will no longer be an executive lounge. In other words this resort is not seeking or rewarding business members.Imagine my surprise re upgrades when on December 31st I was referred to the refreshment room in the Tapia Towers to find this room was a suite overlooking the ocean. Why use a suite for a quick change room prior to travel?Food and beverage was expensive. Room service was good. This hotel is for tourist groups and families. I do not recommend it for business or single person travel.

<Author>VictoriaLA
<Content>Nice If You Choose the Right Tower This is our second trip to this hotel. First trip during summer of 2006 seemed much better - property was better taken care of, food was better, less construction going on. We were hinted by the check in staff that management changed since then and that the property now should be rated as 3 stars. They even closed some restourants and are closing others. In order to get better experience, you should stay at Rainbow Tower. We booked our trip through American Express, and, while booking, we asked to make sure we will get a room in a good tower. AmEx assured us that was the case. We then called the hotel and they said that AmEx uses Travelosity to book packages and that you get no choice of room/tower (warning)! We were placed in a Diamond Head tower - at best the room is 3 star. Moreover, right outside there was loud banging due to construction on the tower next door. Yes, this was an ocean veiw room, but you would have to put up with the loudness from construction to open your balcony and get out to look at the ocean. After spending one night at this tower, I went to the front desk and asked for a change of room. I was offered a room in Talia tower (not sure of the spelling). The room was nice, but, again, construction right outside. I asked then to be moved specifically to Rainbow tower. That cost me extra $80 per night. No comparison - the room is nicer, the view is amazing, and the best part is - you take the elevator down and you are on the beach. The good:- Rainbow tower views - amazing- Beach is close, no waives, weather is beautiful, sand is nice- City is fun and only a $5 cab ride away- In room movies are fresh from the theaters for $14 bucks a show- Beds and bedding is nice- Sergio's restourant - very nice italian food, not too expensive.The bad:- The hotel is extremely expensive - they will charge you for everything and a lot. For example - coffee bags or tea bags - first is free then it's not free, and nobody notifies you about that until you see it charged. Umbrellas/snorkling equipment rentals - crazy expensive. Drinks/food - very expensive too. In comparison, Maui Four Seasons where we stayed summer of 2007 does not charge for umbrellas and water at all.- Check in took 40 min of standing in line - I saw this happening every day as we walked by- Water in December was a bit cold- They do not allow floaties in the pools for children - how strange is that? Pool is also cold.- Room decor/furniture/bathroom fixtures are all outdated, bathroom is tiny.- Housekeeping does not clean well - you can notice some amount of dust on the phones, lamps, so on. I found a nail clipping from a previous traveler on the floor when we checked in. - Beach rentals staff in the little cabin on the beach that pass out towels and set up umbrellas are rude and spoiled.- Bali by the Sea restourant - over rated and not good.- Room serivce - very expensive.- Rainbow Lanai all you can eat breakfast - OK, but if you go to CJ's Deli inside the property away from the beach - way better and one plate can feed two people.- Spa is OK, but the massage was too light and they push you to buy products. Check in at the spa took 30 minutes. Overall, our first stay in 2006 was much better than in 2007, but they are updating rooms so it might get better. Still this was a nice vacation and we had lots of fun - who stays in the room when there is a beach outside anyways?  
<Date>Jan 8, 2008
<Rating>3	3	2	5	2	2	4	2

<Author>rpb2654
<Content>HHonors Diamond Disappointment I have been a Hilton Honors Diamond Tier member for over 6 years. When traveling for business, my overall experiences have been worthy of such loyalty. However, I redeemed points for my stay at Hilton Hawaiian Village and received such substandard treatment that Hilton is no longer my first choice for business travel. This trip was a special occasion. My reservations were completed via the Diamond Member direct line. Reservations were confirmed and I relaxed knowing that the details were taken care of. A month prior to my arrival, a member of the property management contacted me via voice mail and email with a request to adjust my stay to another property on the island, as the hotel was oversold. Five return calls and two emails on my part over the following two weeks with no response left me concerned and unclear on my reservation status until my arrival. Upon arrival, I checked in, and was provided an average room, in a back tower, overlooking an active construction site. A call to request a room change was flatly declined due to the hotel at capacity. Zero effort was made to make the circumstances better. Actually, I felt marginalized when hotel management made it clear to me that since I was redeeming points and not a 鈥減aying鈥?customer, I was placed in the least desirable tower in order to accommodate 鈥減aying鈥?customers. Mind you, I have been a loyal, 鈥減aying鈥?customer at various Hilton properties over the past 10 years with enough stays to achieve Diamond Tier membership. Other less than positive highlights: Being reprimanded for attempting to remove half a glass of milk from the HHonors Lounge. Other guests in the room turned and looked at me, the milk thief, standing in the doorway with my cup of milk, a determined staff member (who I'm confident is simply following instructions) is set on protecting the $.30 cents of milk I'm about to walk away with. Assessing the situation, I asked myself at what point did my hotel no longer recognize me as a valuable, loyal customer... and no less, an adult? I imagined the HHonors guests, the most loyal and cared for guests, pillaging the lounge of all its contents on a daily basis to warrant such security. A smile, calmly setting the glass down, and walk across the street to the corner coffee shop resolved the situation. On another instance, a security officer reprimanded us for crossing outside of a crosswalk. Add to this inaccurate billing issues, charging for wireless internet access, the non-return calls from property management, and the sum is an exceptionally sour part of the trip.It is worth adding, that prior to checkout a call was placed to the Diamond support line, lodging a complaint. The person at the Diamond Help desk informed me that the property management would be notified, and committed to have the property management contact me within 24 hours. No return call was received.  
<Date>Jan 6, 2008

<Author>elf.dml
<Content>Great Location We spent 10 nights at the HHV, the location is the best in Waikiki, close to high end shopping and restaurants plus all tour companies pick up at this hotel. The good points of this hotel are 1) the beach infront of the hotel is huge in comparison to other hotels along the strip 2) a large selection of restaurants on the hotel grounds itself 3) alot of shopping on the grounds itself 4) the surfing lessons at the hotels beach were wonderful, great instructors and reasonable $ 5) free childrens activities including snorkeling lessons, hula dancing which all were well taught 6) our room was large and updated w/ nice bath, I think it depends on what tower you are in. The adequate/ok points are 1) the gym/fitness center 2) the Friday night Hawaiian show for $12/seat 3)breakfast in the restaurants 4) check-in/out 5) overall cleanliness of the hotel grounds and roomsThe bad points are 1) if your looking for a romantic getaway, this is not the place, this is a family w/ kids hotel 2) pools are way to small for the complex w/ pool chairs pushed smack together and you have to wait in line at 8:30am for a pool chair unless you want in the back under a palmtree w/ no sun also pool towels are limited, all parties must be present to get a towel and they ran out each day around 12noon 3) buffet was ok-not good vs. price- quality of food 4) alot of traffic, people and cars from outside visitors not staying at the hotel 5) attention Hilton Diamond VIP's, there is no executive lounge w/ free bev/food as in other Hilton resorts, you get a free continential breakfast and free access to the fitness center, no other bonus like free water in your room daily,etc... 6) the towels in the room/bathroom, you get 2 sets, that is it, we asked the maid, wrote notes for an extra set included tip but no extra towels.Overall, a middle of the road 4 star hotel, if you have little kids you will like this place if you are a couple you won't.  
<Date>Jan 5, 2008

<Author>sciencecoach
<Content>Stay away from the village My family and I stayed at this hotel from Jan 3rd through the 6th and have no intentions of ever staying there again. The elevators broke and we were forced to use the service elevator to get to our room. The rooms were over priced at 300 + per night and extremly small. The service was very poor . The pools close at 4:30 pm and guests are charged $13.00 a day to use the gym facilities. No one walks around the pools to take drink orders and it is very difficult to find healthy alternatives to the 12 dollar hot dog. The beach was beautiful with a diamond head view but be sure to bring your water shoes because it is quite rocky and and many guests had been stung by sea urchants. The one positive was that they did upgrade our room to an ocean view because it was not ready when we arrived.

<Author>pikku
<Content>A mini-waikiki in itself We stayed here during the peak Xmas holidays and was definitely worth it.We never stepped out of the hotel for shopping/dining. Didnt waste time commuting to other places in search of food or cultural activities.Totally relaxed at HHV as it houses many cosy to exotic restaurants and has reasonable to sophisticated shops.Bus and trolley stops are at a stone's throw. Plus point was ABC convenience stores to buy water and souveneirs.Enjoyed the collection of books and novels in their library and all guests have the privilege to borrow books/novels for free for 5 days.Kids are provided with board games there.Kids enjoy the penguin and turtle feeding.Also crafts village near rainbow tower holds so many activities like hula dance, garland making etc . Guests can get a feel of Hawaiin culture.Pools were clean but the snack bar by poolside(TAPA tower) offers very limited snacks and drinks.Rooms are clean with comfortable linens. bathroom was tidy and towels seemed very new.Room service was expensive though.Overall, an overwhelming experience at HHV. Though on the expensive side,will recommend this hotel for a family vacation in Honolulu.

<Author>travlinmomz
<Content>Very disappointed with service this time We've stayed at the HHV before and had a great time, but found the service to be far lacking this year. Several months ago, we booked two adjoining rooms for the week in the Rainbow Tower, but when we checked in, they gave us separate rooms (doesn't really work to have three kids under 10 down the hall from mom and dad). For the first 30 minutes of discussion they said too bad, can't do anything for you, you're lucky you're on the same floor, then they decided to comp us on a roll away bed, so all five of us could get in one room for the night. Then another hour of discussion later and facing written confirmations that we booked (and paid more for) connecting rooms (as well as our plan to perhaps start asking our neighbors in adjacent rooms if they would mind swapping so we could be together), they magically (although unhappily) found connecting rooms for the remainder of the week. The issue wasn't so much the lack of the rooms we had booked and paid for (which was annoying, but we understand that mistakes happen), but more the really bad attitude with which each of our questions was met....there was definitely no Aloha spirit in the hotel. A simple we're really sorry for the error, how can we make it up to you? goes a lot further than a defensive and rude oh well, it's not my problem attitude. This used to be our favorite hotel and a place we looked forward to visiting. Unfortunately, we will be looking for a new place to stay in Waikiki.  
<Date>Jan 2, 2008

<Author>marino22
<Content>Great Hotel Stayed 12-22 to the 29th. Very nice hotel with excellent staff. Mary Jane at the front desk upgraded us to the rainbow Towers and it was a fantastic room. Yes its a Hilton and the prices are high. Draft beer is $7.00 and internet is $14.99 but its a beach Hiltlon! Tons of stores on the property with shopping close. Lots of great places within a short walk to eat and shop at for a lot less. Senior Frogs...Spagetti Factory..ect. The time share presentation is about 1.5 hours and they will give you $100 in hilton Dollars to use at stores and resturants. The place is packed so if you want seclusion dont go here. About a $30 taxi ride to the hotel from the airport.

<Author>Laurie_loves_gators
<Content>Fantastic property!!!! I travel with Hilton quite a bit for work. While I often get upgraded, nothing could compare to the room, the service, the staff, the location, and the ease of staying at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. We were upgraded to a suite on the 26th floor of the Rainbow Tower. It was bigger than my first apt. It had 2 balconies (overlooking the harbor) and 2 full baths. We enjoyed the room so much that we didn't want to leave. Also, it is extremely convenient to shopping, restaurants, etc. The staff was so warm and friendly. We could have spent a whole week there instead of just the 2 nights we were there. The free buffet breakfast was outstanding, the beach was quiet (considering it is on Waikiki). The grounds are very well maintained - don't miss the penguins! so cute! There is even a beautiful little chapel if you are getting married or renewing your vows. There is live entertainment in the evenings and it was just so-so.

<Author>vabelle77
<Content>Would not stay here again We loved Oahu, but we would not stay at the Hilton again. We chose it b/c it was the only resort listed with a kid's pool, but when we got there, we realized there were only 4 lounge chairs at the pool, and the rest were tables belonging to the Hau Tree Bar and you had to buy something to sit there (the wait staff bugs you until you do). Also, they charge for ridiculous things like .50 cents a minute to check your email and then you have to hike to the front office to pay before you begin. The towels are a huge pain (you have to walk down to the beach to get them and then stand in a raft rental line.) If you get them from the Tapa pool, you'll be charged $20 if you don't return them there (hope someone's on duty when you do!), which they fail to mention when you pick them up. For some reason, this is the only pool that does this. The beach isn't very nice there (looked like any old beach in the US) and it's a 20 minute walk to all the shopping and restaurants. There were too many annoying things to list here, but believe me, if you are booking this resort for the amentities, DON'T! We never even found the gym, but were told it was on top of the spa and you had to make an appointment to even get in. Ahhh!!! Try the Mona Surfrider or the Sheraton. They both looked beautiful and are in the heart of Waikiki.

<Author>deenmatt
<Content>A Great Resort! I have worked for a major airline for over 20 years, and have had the opportunity to travel to many places and stay in many hotels. This truly was one of the best! We went to Hawaii for the Hawaii Bowl, and didn't make a hotel reservation because of the stiff penalties for cancelling last minute. (traveling standby you never know if you are going to get on the plane or not!) So, we walked into the Hilton and were accomodated in the Ali'i Tower (nice sized rooms with concierge service and amenities) at an airline discount Christmas week!! Room was oceanfront, very large, very clean, flat screen, twice daily maid service, turn down service, private lanai etc. Beautiful wide beach, biggest on Waikiki. Tons of shopping and restaurants on property plus within walking distance of many stores and eateries off property. Spa (pricey). Childrens village (for a fee) Several pools/bars. Everyone was very polite and gave great customer service. We were granted a late check-out AND were given a courtesy room free of charge in the evening to shower and change after a long hot day at the Hawaii Bowl before going to the airport for our 11 pm flight. So great!! This is an option for everyone. Just request the service a day or so in advance so you can get the time that works for you. I would definitely stay at the Hilton again!  
<Date>Dec 30, 2007

<Author>Canadaontario
<Content>OK - but, I guess it's a good place to stay , I don't have anything to compare it to as it was my first stay in Hawaii.If you like visiting another US state, but with ridiculously high prices and clogged roadways, I guess Hawaii (Oahu) is the place to go.As far as the Hilton goes, stupid rules for getting towels (my 6 year old son had to be with my wife in order to obtain a towel), and $35 umbrella rentals and no chairs or lounge chairs on the beach unless you forked out cash, set me off the 1st day. After that I was just annoyed with the lousy elevator service, and theoverpriced cost for food. (Note: the food of choice for Hawaiians is SPAM, they serve it everywhere ). Sushi can be found inexpensively off 'Hilton Campus', (Aloha Sushi up the road is very reasonable), but like other reviewers I feel that $9 for a Heineken on the beach (at Tropics bar) is a bit much. (Actually there were signs on the beach that you couldn't take alchohol beyond a certain point - OOPS - didn't see that sign and packed my 6 x $1 a bottle Heiny in a ABC shopping bag with ice.) Maybe it's where we stayed, but the cost for food was ridiculous.(eg.$11 for a pastrami sandwich - $35 for a pizza delivered to your room) - I'm not cheap and we actually paid some of the prices being asked - but I felt that we were Royally being taken advantage of. A good place to eat was The Cheesecake Factory - large portions (sharehe Appetizer Ceasar), and quick friendly service. All the pools at the Hilton were VERY cold (on Christmas Day - maybe their busiest day of our stay - I saw at most 10 people in the 'Super (cold) Pool' ) Usually my son leaves a pool because he's exhausted - this time he would leave because he was shivering and his lips were blue from the extremely cold temps. (The pools 'open' at 8:30 am and 'close' at 5:00pm - What's with that ? - I've never run into such restrictive'rules' in the past. They will actually blow a whistle, make an announcement and let you know when you have to get out of the ice-bucket.) The only warm pool (Tapa Tower) childrens pool was closed due to ??? -puke/baby [--]in the pool - who knows - no explanation was provided. This was probably a blessing as the Spanish inquisition for the 'towel sign-up' process was avoided.  I highly doubt that this review will be published, so I'll stop now - but next year I'll be booking Cancun....  
<Date>Dec 29, 2007

<Author>jonathanmwood
<Content>Impressed with the Hawaiian Hilton Village In Oahu I was a bit hesitant to stay at a Hilton, but was pleasantly surprised by this hotel. The HHV has the most beach of any hotel on Waikiki. I was shocked to see how little beach space the other hotels had.This Hilton is on 22 beautiful acres - waterfalls, penguins, flamingos. it is a great location, in between Ala Moana Mall and downtown Waikiki. The rooms were nice and comfortable.My only complaints - the food is horrible and overpriced and the service is mediocre at best.Overall, this hotel is great and worth the very reasonable price.

<Author>SOBEMiamiBeach
<Content>Nice on the outside but... Honolulu is definitely not the Hawaiian paradise that you see in those nice travel brochures, TV shows and movies. It seems as if the city hasn't really kept up with the times, at least the Waikiki Beach area. Things seem to have gotten stuck at about 1985 here (although there is a lot of new condo apartment construction going up).The Hilton Hawaiian Village is a perfect example.The good:Several large swimming pools - great for families with kidsCheck-in was quick and upgrading to a room with a better view was easy.The bad:Upon arrival, nobody to greet the taxi and assist with bagsRoom contained the green room service menu which was the old one - was informed by room service operator to look for the orange menu which was the new one (and had only half the items as the old one).Room service food awful. Chicken noodle soup came straight out of the can. Asian teriyaki chicken salad contained 3 slices of chicken with the skin still on the chicken - expected to find chicken feathers in the salad too!No water pressure for the shower, and I mean NO water pressure at all.No hot water - not even any WARM water.Room came with a baby crib for some strange reason.Wallpaper is peeling off.Furniture is 20 years old (though the bed is the usual very comfy Hilton bed).Bathroom as big as a broom closet.Elevators old and noisy.So, with that said, we are cutting short our 4 night stay after just 1 night and heading to one of the other islands.I would suggest to anyone planning a visit to Hawaii to consider Maui or, if you have the money, Lanai. Skip Honolulu.  
<Date>Dec 24, 2007

<Author>OperaOnTheTurnpike
<Content>Incredible experience My wife and I chose the Hilton Hawaiian Village for a three-night pre-cruise stay in late September 2007, and we were so glad we did. You really cannot go wrong with this fantastic place. The whole resort is extremely pleasant, and this was definitely one of our best stays ever.The rooms were very comfortable, decorated in good taste -and with great balconies (oceanview, in our case)-, and the staff was always kind, helpful and efficient. The pools were large and beautiful, and the general atmosphere was really lovely.Sure the Halekulani is the most luxurious one, but at the Hilton, with a room so nicely appointed, with grounds so beautiful and immaculate, and with restaurants so inviting (the breakfast buffet was excellent and the rest of the food was more or less average, but the atmosphere was always incredible, especially at night), one really gets the feeling of having got it completely right at a quite reasonable room rate.  
<Date>Dec 23, 2007
<Rating>5	3	5	5	5	5	4	5

<Author>AZSage
<Content>Great view, Bali by the sea is great, avoid the other restaurants We stayed Dec. 8-14. My wife was on business so I had all day to explore. First the good: The hotel room was much better than I expected. We got upgraded to 30th floor of the Rainbow Tower and had a great view of Waikiki beach, the city and Diamond Head crater. It was unbelievable! In addition, the room seemed recently renovated, and the bath had granite counters and nicer tile. The maids were very efficient and seemed to know when we were gone, and always had our room done before we returned. It has a nice pool (no Jacuzzi) but the chairs are somewhat haphazardly arranged, and you can't see the ocean from the pool. There is a little village on the premises with a good sushi place, an ABC store for booze (like a 7-11) and some high end shops. There is also a high end restaurant, Bali by the Sea at the Rainbow tower which was excellent but expensive.Now the bad: Avoid the Tropics Bar altogether, as the food was terrible and overpriced ($12.50 cheeseburger on stale bun with plastic utensils + $9 beer in plastic cup). The breakfast is just as bad (lousy continental breakfast), to make matters worse it is about the only place to use your breakfast coupons. The only redeeming factor is the view. You are better off walking 5 minutes down the beach to the Shore Bird where the prices are lower and the food and the service is better. Walk another 5 minutes and have a gourmet lunch at the Royal Hawaiian. We had one breakfast at the Rainbow Lanai, which was only fair and a $10 upgrade from the breakfast coupon (for eggs, bacon, etc), not a good value. Also, they charge an extra $12/day to use the exercise room, just jog on the beach.Altogether I liked the hotel, Bali by the Sea and the sushi place, I would avoid the Tropic bar and Rainbow Lanai.  
<Date>Dec 20, 2007

<Author>MauiDiver
<Content>Used to be a Diamond Members dream - not any more I've been staying here for business and pleasure for the last 5 years and it was great - that all changed after Hilton was purchased by the Blackstone group - the Diamond member floors and lounge have been discontinued, parking is now $25.00 plus $1.00 tip per day, the diamond member breakfast is a stale role and juice at the beach juice bar. They now charge $3.50 per day for your room safe, the room service prices have gone up 3x (Supreme Pizza (14) $35.00, Spinach Salad $19.50, Coffee $8.50, American Breakfast $28.50 - all have a 17% surcharge and a $4.00 PER PERSON additional room service fee aka $40.21 for that 14 inch pizza.All mini-bars have been pulled from the rooms, and they have had large staff layoffs so the cleaning is suffering and the staff is not in a good mood. During my visit they did not changing the bed sheets unless you called housekeeping and insisted - at check in I pulled a towel out of the rack to find fresh human feces on it, not washed and did not come out but fresh feces.Talked to the Night Manager who would do nothing and really gave me the impression that if you鈥檙e not from Japan they don't have any interest in your business and being a Diamond member get's you little.They have even cut out little things like moisturizers in the bathrooms.If you've got money to burn and have to be at a beach resort this is your place - I'm taking my business back to the Price Hotel. Really sad to see such a fine property go south when the bean counters start twisting the screws.Do yourself a favor and book at the Hawaii Price Hotel in Waikiki for the same or better per night rates.

<Author>dcminors
<Content>Had a Great Time We stayed at the Hilton on our Hooneymoon from Dec 4-14. The hotel staff are so great. I felt so welcomed from the time we checked to the time we left. They could not do enough for us. The hotel is huge like some people have said however we like big hotels. There is so muh things and so many places to choose from to eat. Some off the resteraunts are pricey. There is a 24hr coffee shop right arcoss the street which is cheaper and the food it great! It was called the Wailekea.A bit of advise when staying there on a budget. Try to eat off property. There are some other resteraunts off site as well that are good on a budget. We went to Red lobtser,  Subway there are a couple of Star Bucks as well. American Express Tours help desk at the hotel was great and helped us a lot. If you go ask for Julie she is great, well they all are but that is the only persons name I can remember. Try to go the International Marketplace to get soveners before you buy at the hotel because you can bargain for some of your prices and get more for your money. It is about ten minutes away from the hotel. Bali by the sea was wonderful but it is pricey however, if you are there to have a romantic time then this is the place. Food  service EXCELLENT! Along with Rainbow Lanai.I will deffinately stay here again. We stayed in an ocean view Rainbow Lanai Rm it was wonderful overlooking the beautiful Lagoon, From our balcony we could see the ocean and the mountains. Loved this hotel and can not wait to go back!

<Author>MsTravela
<Content>Nice, if bland hotel Was here for a conference in September. Definitely recommend the check-in at the airport which was a big time saver. I waited in line to use the ATM-like machine for check-in while my husband waited for our luggage. When we got to the hotel (about $30 taxi ride) we skipped a very, very long check-in line.We had a partial ocean view/balcony room in Tapa tower which was a nice size. The crib we requested was not in the room, but after a phone call it was brought very quickly.Pools - the pool at all the towers (except the super pool) are small. More of an issue is that there is no shade at the pool. This was an issue as we were travelling with an infant.The hotel restaurants are pricy. We went to both buffets for breakfast (Rainbow Lanai and Tapa Cafe). The Tapa cafe has a nice selection of Japanese foods and Rainbow has an omelette station but otherwise they are pretty boring buffets and not worth the $30+. We also went to CJ's NY style deli, which was fair. It was our first night and we were jet lagged and starving so it suited our needs - but we didn't go back. Round table pizza was fair and slow for lunch. The Kahuna dog at the tapa pool was out of shaved ice for a while one day which was disappointing. Tropics bar  cafe had the best service overall at the lunch we had there.THere are many fancy, overpriced shops in the hotel. Overall, the hotel has nothing special to offer although it is clean. Location-wise it's good if you want to only go to the mall, but it's a little far from the main strip in Waikiki which is where I'd rather stay.  
<Date>Dec 12, 2007

<Author>sueruth
<Content>The best yet in Waikiki I recently stayed at the Ali'i Tower at the Hawaiian Village Resort.I was upgraded to a higher floor with a partial view, I thought is was because I was Hilton Hotel Club member. WRONG !!I may have been given a little upgrade because of this, but this was special and made my holiday the most memorable of many, many visits to Waikiki.I use a walking stick, 3 broken legs, I do not flash it around, but put it on the desk at check in.Check in staff must have noticed and gave me the upgraded room with Handicap amenities - I only realised this the past few days, when I went to purchase a hand rail for my shower at home, there was one over my bath in the hotel, also my room was very, very large, as was the bathroom.My upgrade to this room was discretely handled and I never ask, I don't want to draw attention to myself.Mahalo to the kindly front desk staff, you made one guest supremely happy.Joshnoah

<Author>Happiest_Wanderers
<Content>Surprise by how much fun we had; best beach on Waikiki Okay. So we've travelled all over, but never to Hawaii. Hawaii just never made our top ten. But by a stroke of luck, I was offered the chance to go on a business trip to Hawaii. So off I went expecting something like Disneyland-by-the-sea. It WAS very touristic. But here's the catch: the water is warm so you can swim in the ocean without wearing a wetsuit. Who needs tourist attractions when you have the ocean? Also, we walked the full length of Wakiki, and although Hilton Hawaii Village is at the end, it really has the nicest beach. Finally, I was worried that I would be surrounded by gorgeous women in bikinis and as a result just feel my full fifty year, but I was pleasantly surprised that the people on the beach came in all shapes and sizes.So about the hotel: the room was nice. An ocean view would have been great, but I was not in the room that much, so I don't think it would be worth paying the extra for an ocean view. It was somewhat generic, but pleasant. I think it would be a fun place to go with my family. It also could be pretty romantic, but not recommended if you are going for an authentic, close-to-nature tropical vacation. Or if you are girl watching.  
<Date>Dec 2, 2007

<Author>jimvad
<Content>Great resort!!! This place is huge!!! Only one of two resorts actually located with beachfront property (Sheraton was the only other one I saw on the beach...everything else seemed to be across the street).We stayed on the 34th floor of the Tapa Tower. We booked a ocean view and that was about it...a view...mostly city. Had to go to the far corner of the lanai to see the ocen or view it from inside the room out another window.Huge room, kind of laid out strangely but really spacious with a bar space and dressing area outside the bathroom.Room service was tasty and prompt.More people than I would have liked to have seen in one area unlike our stay in Maui, but that is no fault of the hotel...the entire Waikiki Beach area is way overcrowded anyways. The Hilton Villiage is a little further away from the rest of the big crowds and is less rowdy, although it was hard to get onto the beach due to the number of people on the grounds.Located in close walking distance to the main drag with the rest of the resorts and around the corner from other restaurants. Forget the walk to the other resorts and just stay here...Rainbow Bazaar with all it shops and restaurants located on the grounds between all the other towers makes this a must-stay location.

<Author>suzWex
<Content>Hugh Resort We stayed at The Hilton from the 2nd - 9th November as part of our Honeymoon. We stayed in the Tapa Tower on the 18th floor. The resort itself is hugh and ideally located for Waikiki beach. There are plenty of shops, restaurants and bars in the resort if you choose to eat and drink in the resort. The food and drink is quite pricey and we chose to eat in the various restaurants and bars along the main street. We would highly recommend Wailanna' s a 24 hour diner which is about a 1 minute walk from the gates of the resort. The food here was lovely and extremely cheap. we had dinner there twice and enjoyed a nice few beers while we were there. There is also a bar on the Waterfront called the Harbour Bar which was also very reasonable.The resort is spotless and we never had any problems getting seats by the pool. The ABC shop on sight is also very handy.The room itself was spotless however there are works going on across from this tower. If you were to sit on the balcony during the day you would be looking straight across at anconstruction site and it was quite noisy. There is a shoppping centre Alamona (I think) and you can get a trolley to it for $2. Its worth a look.

<Author>SarahASeattle
<Content>Reliable hotel, great ammenities Have stayed here before on another occasion. It is a great hotel for Waikiki. At the end of the beach so not in the midst of the beach crowd so the beach in front of this hotel is comfortable. That said, the hotel is huge, with every amenity you would want. Tons of shopping, some great pools, though they get busy by late morning. We stayed in the tower that had it's own pool area and I do recommend that as it was less crowded. I would splurge next time for an ocean view room, we had garden view, it was nice, but come on, you're in Hawaii, if you can just do it. There was a bar and eating area at this pool as well so it was the perfect place to spend the day. It is a walk to downtown Waikiki, about 15 minutes or so. Nice to be away from the crowd a bit. I am not a huge fan of Waikiki because of the crowds, but I think this hotel helps make it a more comfortable stay.

<Author>2shopaholics
<Content>Peaceful, friendly, welcoming, and SO SO SO warm! Such a friendly place to stay, everyone had smiles to exchange! Our room was on the 7th floor of the Kalia tower - it certainly wasn't the biggest room we've stayed in, but was clean and comfortable for the 4 of us.We didn't eat at any of the restaurants on site at the hotel - choosing instead to eat at McDonalds and Subway across the street, and getting coffee and snacks at the ABC store at the Hilton.All of the pools were remarkably clean, and were not once over-crowded. The show and fireworks on Friday night are spectacular.For fellow shoppers, the Ala Moana shopping centre is a short (10m) Wikiwiki drive away - $2 each way. (We thought we overheard the driver saying that it's free on showing your hotel key, I didn't get a chance to confirm this - was our last day. Definitely worth checking out though) Many buses also go to the centre (pick up at same place as Wikiwiki) $1 per trip and ask for a transfer as can be used for the return trip up to 4 hours later.The International Market Place at Waikiki is a great place to pick up jewellery at a fraction of the price at the mall or Hilton. Exact same items for under half the price.Would definitely stay again! :0)

<Author>alexandriava
<Content>Ali'i Tower much superior, Diamond head nothing special I just returned from HHV. I stayed in the Diamond Head Tower, and spent 1 night in Ali'i Tower and used its facilities for the rest of the stay. Both of these towers were away from construction, which you could hear during the day even from these towers so would not want to be any closer. The differences btwn the towers was shocking. Ali'i- much better bathroom, newer furniture, newer HVAC system, nice private pool and gym with free apps at night by pool. Diamond head- halls not air conditioned, old HVAC in room with one vent on far side of room so bathroom was always hot, furniture in room and on patio not nearly as nice as Ali'i, tv not as nice, bathroom about half the size of Ali'i. As everyone said, food and drinks very expensive. Only good meal with some flavor was at Bali by the Sea (make reservation and don't wear shorts). Front desk staff unhelpful and rather dim overall only once did I speak to someone who was helpful! My friend and I asked for late check out. I was given 12pm, he was given 3pm. I was told no late check out for hilton honors members, he was told something different. When I asked asst. mang., I was told he gets 3pm and I get 12pm and that was it! HHV's beach and pools much nicer than any of the other hotels. I walked entire beach, which at times was maybe 12 feet wide by other hotels. The HHV protected its beach so not rocky and very wide. Seemed to be place where locals went for beach too. There was lovely live music everynight and the grounds were beautiful, but a bit packaged and a lot of kids, even in nice restaurants.  
<Date>Nov 23, 2007

<Author>Lobbster
<Content>A massive, wonderful resort! Amazing service. My wife and I returned from 5 nights at the HHV yesterday, and we couldn't be happier with the resort. We were on the 34th floor of the Tapa Tower and were upgraded to a partial ocean view room (really was a full ocean view in our opinion), that was quite large. Yes, the resort is a little pricey (especially the drinks), but you can get around this partially by buying drinks and breakfast in the ABC store on the property. The only thing that really bugged me was paying for local calls.The service is top notch in all respects. We were especially happy with the Hilton Grand Vacation Club staff (Reinna), and the entire team at Bali By the Sea (one of the best meals, if not the best, I have ever had). Because the Hilton has its own section of the beach and is on one end of Waikiki, the beach is much less crowded than in front of the other Waikiki beach hotels (where you are lucky to see the sand). You could spend your entire vacation on the property and never eat in the same restaurant or shop in the same store twice, it is really like a Vegas resort (without the gambling). We would definitely go back and recommend to anyone (other than the very frugal).  
<Date>Nov 23, 2007

<Author>Betty_Baylor99
<Content>Pleased with our recent stay at HHV I stayed here recently for a night with my husband and 7 month old daughter during a busy Veterans' Day weekend. From the moment we checked in, we experienced nothing less than outstanding customer service. With our HHilton Rewards, we were upgraded to an ocean view room on the top floor of the Tapa Tower (we requested a king, but to get this room, we had to settle for two doubles). Our room had an incredible Diamondhead view- was nicely appointed with a seating area, bar/fridge, huge closet space, etc. There really is a nice variety of activities and restaurants on-site which does give it a Disney Worldish feeling for those who don't want to venture off-site. Yes, it is expensive, but you're in Hawaii and in all honesty, there are plenty of other resorts that charge way more than what you see here at the HHV. We ate breakfast at CJ's Deli which we highly recommend. Valet and bell service were top-notch for us. Would definitely recommend this hotel for anyone coming to Oahu that doesn't want to spend an arm and a leg to stay at a 5-star resort, but have a comfortable stay in a clean room with access to a pretty decent beach.

<Author>henulj-lse
<Content>Very nice property My son and I were in Oahu for a conference and stayed at this property for a great rate. Our room was in the Diamondhead Tower on the 13th floor with a garden view. We actually had quite a good view of the beach and ocean from our lenai. The room was very comfortable and quiet. The only problem that I had with the room was that the bedding (pillows and comforter) were down filled. Since I am allergic to down, I woke up stuffy. I made a call and the maid switched them out for me which solved the problem. Our room was directly across from the elevators and we did not hear a thing. The beach was right outside our tower and there was a very nice beachside restaurant just around the corner from us. The pools were nice and the beach is excellent. My son is 19 and was quite comfortable wandering around here. Plenty of room and so relaxing. It was expensive and you had to pay for everything, but the property has a lot of overhead. The parking garage was quite full and it was a hike from there to our tower, but our party of five worked well with a minivan. Parking stalls are smaller, but we had no difficulty parking the minivan. I would definitely stay here again.

<Author>profpsg
<Content>Great Place in Honolulu After a disappointing stay at another hotel, we drove to the Hilton, and we are so glad we did. Everything was wonderful: price of the room, service, room, pools, beach, restaurants. Service, in particular, was wonderful; not always the case with American hotels. The Hilton is so large that it offers many choices for dining, along a wide range of prices. Other luxury hotels often require us to eat only in their high priced restaurant. If you want a hotel on the beach, this is the place: lively where you want it, quiet where you need it.  
<Date>Oct 30, 2007

<Author>NABISD32
<Content>Hilton Hawaiian Was Great!!!! My husband  I went to Oahu for our 1 year anniversary, and to renew our wedding vows. We decided to stay here because of a great discount we received on our stay. Well... we were not disappointed.. Check in was fast and efficient.... The room was on the 11th floor, and the room was very nice... The hotel was definitely a little village.... I mean there was nothing you could possibly not find on the hotel's grounds... The staff were extremely nice, we did order room service the first night and didn't do that anymore.. It was so expensive, $70 for two sandwiches and two sodas.. We ate at a great diner across from the hotel for breakfast every morning, it was wonderful... We also ate at the Japanese steakhouse and sushi restaurant at the hotel, and both places the food was wonderful... Very reasonably priced... The room attendants were wonderful also, everyday we came back from our busy day, our room was exceptionally clean, and neat.... Anyway, this was a great time, our renewal vow ceremony was great... If anyone on here is looking to renew their vows or getting married, visit: [--]This company was wonderful also.. All in all, the hotel was great, the weather was great, the Paradise Cove luau was great... This was the best trip I have ever been on.. And we can't wait to go back and visit the Hilton Hawaiian Village...

<Author>Faketanrules
<Content>Just brilliant This hotel is a little overwhelming at first due to the sheer scale of the complex, number of towers, and height of the towers. But once we settled in, it was utterly fantastic. The staff can't do enough for you, the location is tremendous, you are in utter luxury, the rooms are fantastic, and the pools and beaches are picture perfect. Take advantage of all the facilities, but make sure you also walk out of the complex as there is so much more to see! Try Dukes for great food and drinks at a bar overlooking the beach. Eggs 'n' Things is my favourite diner in the world, and 3 minutes from the hotel entrance. And definately walk the couple of blocks to Ala Moana shopping centre, to catch a bus for $2 which takes you to anywhere on the island! Get the bus up to the North Shore for the legendary surfing; also go across the island to the Windward Coast for white sand beaches. For the latter journey you have to change to the number 70 bus (opposite a shopping centre and book shop) which is fairly infrequent, so grab a timetable for the return service! But well worth the effort.  
<Date>Oct 28, 2007
