<Author>Dianeddd
<Content>Heavenly Hilton My husband and I stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village prior to taking a NCL Pride Of Hawaii Cruise.I have a Hiltons Honors AX Card--easiest card to earn miles and free rooms I have ever used. We had enough for 3 nts.First awesome thing. I checked us in at the airport. There is a kiosk at the baggage area. My husband picked up our luggage and I checked us in and got our room key and we were on our way in less than 20 minutes. It was awesome! There was a person at the kiosk to help and she asked me if we would like an upgrade, of course , I said yesWe got to the hotel , went direct to our room. We were on the 11th floor oceanfront. My hats off to Hilton, they do their freebies with class.There was a concierge floor that offered a huge breakfast buffet, luncheon, and snacks in late afternoon. We did not eat on the property as it was rather pricey and we figured we would be getting great food on the ship. Just a hint. Walk out to the main road and go to your left. About 3 blocks away is a family style restaurant that is very reasonable.Our room--large area, with a very large patio. The bathroom had a walk in shower-very handicap accessible. Also a bathtub.The grounds are beautiful. The hotel is constantly upgrading but they are very good at keeping any construction away from the guests.Hawaii is such a paradise. This was a great way to start our trip  
<Date>Oct 26, 2007

<Author>jgarcia21
<Content>Hilton Hawaiian I just returned from 2 weeks at the Hilton Hawaiian Village, and it was a truly wonderful experience. I've been there before, and it is very separate from the noise and franchise food world of Waikiki. It is also a very good value. Before leaving, I priced several other hotels, all of which charged either nearly as much or more, and none of which had the trees, plants, birds, fish, the gracious amenities of the Hilton. There are multiple pools, shops and restaurants, and so always someplace to go.One problem both at the Hilton and elsewhere on Waikiki is the ongoing construction. However, even with an ocean-view room, the construction was off to the side and generally not that noisy. Hawaii itself is lovely, and a great place to visit, and well worth the trip from the continental US.  
<Date>Oct 25, 2007

<Author>hulagirl4ever
<Content>This place is gorgeous This place is gorgeous. There is so much to see and do here that you never really need to leave this resort. It was great for a famliy with kids...probably not so great for a romantic getaway as a couple.Before I went to this resort I checked out many of the trip advisor reviews, and made a list of helpful hints. Here are the ones that were MOST useful to me....While sitting poolside, dash over to buy snacks at the miitary resort poolside snack bar next door. It's MUCH cheaper, and literally just steps away down the boardwalk. The food was great.The ceasar salad from the pizza joint on-site was awesome, and a nice poolside snack in the afternoon.The food at this resort is VERY expensive.....the 24 hour coffee place (Wailana?) on the corner outside the resort was cheap with great food! That was our best hint. NICE and cheap breakfasts!Walmart was the place to go for presents. For example, an $11 coconut bra was $2.50 at Walmart. Everything I saw in the gift shops on-site that I wanted I could find at Walmart.We used a limo service to get from the airport to the resort and back. Mr. Melvin Kim of ABC limo service was fantastic. We booked on-line with him after reading some on-line reviews and we were not disappointed. He showed up on time, brought nice leis (not the cheap ugly ones...but the nice purple ones that smell fantastic). Mr. Kim's limo was clean, the snacks and drinks were exactly as described, and he was on-time and reliable.One thing we also loved...you can book a suite to use for an hour on the day you check out. You can check out, leave your luggage with the hotel...play on the beach all day...then re-claim your luggage and go to a room and get cleaned up. Make sure you book this in advance...they don't seem to publicize this service.....but it's available and fantastic to get cleaned up before you travel home.Oh, and for the kids...bring your inflatables and buckets and shovels with you. They are really expensive to buy them at the resort and you can just pack stuff from the dollar store before you leave home and leave it behind for others to play with.  
<Date>Oct 18, 2007

<Author>Memphistraveler007
<Content>Village feels like Home My wife and I stayed at HHV Oct.3rd - 6th, my only wish was for us to stay longer. We had an Ocean front room in the Rainbow Tower on the 8th floor. The view was perfect for sunset and we enjoyed every moment on the property. We had breakfast in the Rainbow buffet a couple of mornings it was great. My wife and I are Diamond Members and HGVC owners, but on this trip I was using Points so the breakfast was discounted for only $5; we ate from the entire buffet and there was plenty and more. One morning we ate at the Tapa Tower breakfast area it was good as well; less selection that Rainbow though. We ate at the round table pizza place, it was good as always. We have stayed at HHV now 7 times and each seems like a trip to our second home. Well, in fact it is our second home and we both love this place. I would gladly recommend anyone to stay here. There is plenty to do, the beach is right in front of the property. The grounds are well taken care of, and the staff was great. The only problem we had was one evening we went to the tropics bar for a late snack, and we were informed incorrectly that the place was closed at 7:30 pm when in fact it closed at 8:00 pm. We spoke with the manager and she spoke to the staff about this. She was very nice and gave us a $50 credit for our stay, which ended up paying for most of our parking. Finally, we had a great time and enjoyed our stay at HHV yet again. Thank You HHV for a great trip back home.

<Author>iklemisdynomite
<Content>Hilton Hawiian resort What can i say ?We travelled here in march 2006 for a 15 night stay but ended up extending to 20 nights!This is just such a beautful hotel!Very, very clean. Everything you would expect from a high class hotel as this!As soon as i told staff i was allergic to feather pillows, within minutes they had two maids changing the bedding which was of course lovely and was changed everyday as i would expect.We travelled there with our two children (11 and 13) for 20 nights and they upgraded us to a beautful suite. We were in Tapa tower, about the 30th something floor, two balconies.one over looking the ocean the other the city.....just beautful!During the day they have lots gong on HULU dancers etc..Friday night the show they put on is just fantastic, with dancers telling their stories and the firesworks.well what can i say?We did get a better view from our balconie though as tourist will be tourist and only think about themselves!I am disabled but then again, no matter where you go in the world the tourists always think of themselves!The hotel staff were wonderful at all times and went out of their way many times to accomodate any requests!Mind you, not that we needed to ask for much.Only complaint...it is expensive to stay on hotel grounds for food and clothes all the time..etc. so sometimes look for a nice clean restaurant of the grounds.Also it would have been nice to have had a microwave and kettle in the suite instead of just the coffee makers!I hate coffee!I must also admit that i found it rather insulting having to pay for hot chocolate that was in the suite, if we used it.When i did complain they then gave me it complementry!I did miss my morning cuppa but of course just being here was enough but it would have been nice to make a cup of hot decent tea but then you cannot do that anywhere outside of England!I am the first person to find fault with anything but Hawaii and the Hilton is just paradise!If anyone says different then im sorry but they just like to moan lol and i thought i was bad!We will defently be going back there and the hotel will be the Hilton Hawiian!So much to do or just relax and the kids loved it!Just to much to praise that it would take me forever! lolWe will be returning ASAP!

<Author>chattycs
<Content>Love the Resort...Stay away from the Spa This was my second time staying at the Village. My daughter and I stayed in the Rainbow Tower on the 15th floor in an oceanfront room...We arrived just in time to watch the Blue Angels from our lanai and then there was the fireworks show that night. We couldn't have asked for a better welcome. The nightly entertainment was fantastic and you would be hard pressed to find better musicians anywhere. We walked around the village all night wanting to soak it all in. The beach can't be beat. Even though the hotel was completely booked, you really don't feel like the resort is overcrowded. Plenty of open space. The only negative I can say is that the receptionist at the spa was very rude. Even though I spent a pretty good chunk of money at the spa, I was treated with disrespect. At one point, after waiting for 15 minutes for someone to come to the counter so that I could request a robe in the spa, the girl rudely said I am not an octopus and can't do everything, you'll just have to wait. Now that was after already waiting for 15 minutes and I had to check out of the hotel within 2 hours and was running out of time. So, while she was on the phone FOREVER....I reached behind the counter and retrieved my own robe so I could get on with using the spa. Then the girl actually started yelling at me and at that point, I told her I wasn't going to take this kind of treatment and left. I reported her to the HHV manager on duty and they were great. They offered to pay for our breakfast that morning and apologized for the treatment in the Spa. We still felt that the spa should do something about this employee but I was too upset to talk to the manager at the spa so my daughter did this for me. She recieved absolutely no satisfaction from the manager. They took no responsibility for their employee's actions and could care less whether I was satisfied or not. Thank goodness the Hilton corrected this and took the liability on themselves. They even told me that there were other spas OFF-SITE that they recommended would give much better service and apologized for the spa on site. So, overall, I would highly recommend the Village but stay away from the spa. I am glad to say that I didn't let them ruin an almost perfect vacation.  
<Date>Sep 27, 2007

<Author>Trippers123
<Content>Loved it !! We stayed in the Hilton's Ali Tower for 5 nights as part of our honeymoon. I don't know about the rest of the towers but I recommend that if your on honeymoon that this is the only tower to stay in. We stayed in a 5 star hotel in las vegas before we reach oahu and it wasn't a patch on the service we received in the Ali Tower. The room might not have been as fancy as a five star room but it was without doubt more comfortable and we loved it. We were upgraded from a garden view to ocean view and received cava and fruit on arrival. The beach at the hilton is lovely and not so crowded and if you go to the bar between the super pool and beach you'll get some great service and a laugh !! If your idea of a honeymoon is being on a desserted island than its probably not for you but if you like a more lively honeymoon with paradise thrown in, its great.

<Author>MallomarNY
<Content>Good for families, not great for honeymooners My husband and I planned to spend four romantic days in Waikiki, but this wasn't what we expected. The Hilton is just like a village--a large property of 3,000 rooms, many shops and restaurants, and lots of families. It may not be what honeymooners are looking for: It's low on charm--the shops give it a very mall-like feel; it's a very family-friendly place, which means little kids are everywhere; and it's quite noisy--we could hear children squealing with delight over video games next door, people in the hallway, toilets flushing in the middle of the night... We actually left the next day. To their credit, the hotel is very clean and the staff is extremely cordial and helpful. Maybe we'll go back for our fourth honeymoon with our future kids ;)

<Author>rjp2001
<Content>Ali'i Tower Stayed at HHV last week of August in the Ali'i Tower. The accomodations and service were excellent. Booked a Garden View and was upgraded to an oceanview on the 3rd floor. We asked for a higher floor and although the hotel was full they called us the next morning and gave us a 10th floor room with a spectacular view.The hotel food and beverages were very overpriced so we walked along the beach each night and went to a different restaurant........the best were......Orchid, Ocean House and of course Dukes. There were also some nice bars with music at the Royal Hawaiian and Sandshore. We did eat at The Bali Restuarant at the hotel and it was worth the price.......our best meal and service on the trip.Renatal cars........Hertz at the hotel was a total ripoff $140 for a sub-compact. We used Enterprise....$39 for a convertible......Dollar also had good prices and they both pick you up and drop you off at the hotel. Traffic is horrendous in Honolulu 3 days was enough for me and I live in NJ!Parking.........plenty of FREE parking in front of the lagoon right at the beach....just as far from the Ali'i tower as the parking garage.Internet...........many free wireless connections although service was spotty.........CJ's deli in the village has it's own free wi-fi.Breakfast.........Wailana Coffe House across the street from the entrance was great and affordable......we even met one of the stars from LOST eating breakfast there.Teens........we had 2 teens with us........besides all the beach activity (the surfing lessons were their highlight) there wasn't much for them to do or anywhere to meet other teens......no arcade,gameroom or organized activities....the only drawback to the trip.All in all it's a well run property and the grounds were maintained meticulously. There were always seats by the pools, towels and no service problems. Cocktail hour at the Alii tower was a nice perk. You won't be disappointed staying at this hotel.  
<Date>Sep 9, 2007

<Author>luvtotravelnasia
<Content>Good Beach...but not a Great Hotel My fiance and I stayed here for a week in July. We had stayed here once before 2 years ago. We were put in the Kalia tower on a high floor but with a view of the city. We had access to the lounge on the top floor which was nice for a decent continental breakfast and evening snacks. Unfortunately the alcoholic drinks still cost money in the lounge which is disappointing! They do have delicious cookies. Staying in the Kalia tower also gives access to a special pool only for guests in this tower...I think the Ali tower also has this benefit. The property itself is huge and in many ways feels like it is designed to get you to shop and spend as much as possible. We avoided all the shops and spent our day on the beach which is the best part of the hotel...it is definitely the nicest/widest section of the Waikiki beach. We never once ate at any of the hotel restaurants as the prices were outrageous, even the drinks are more expensive here than at any other hotel on the beach. We did go to the Coffee Shop across the street a few times and really enjoyed a good and reasonably priced meal. Its an easy walk from the hotel to the main part of Waikiki and we even walked all the way to Diamond Head and back. The hotel in nice overall but I think its a bit overpriced for what you get although I think it would be great with families.  
<Date>Sep 9, 2007

<Author>tikigirl44
<Content>Great hotel and Service but.... My husband and I booked the Hilton for our honeymoon, and it was a great stay. We rented a car to get out of Waikiki and see the island which was the best advice we could have gotten. The cars in Hawaii are super cheap to rent compared to mainland standards, however the Hilton charges $20 PER DAY to park in their lot, and there is NO parking anywhere else around Waikiki unless you want your car broken into...Other than that, the Hilton was fabulous, and the friday night fireworks were not to be missed. The shops inside the complex were overpriced, but other shops werent far away. Overall a very classy establishment with great service. We had to call security to open our safe at one point, and it only took them 5 min to arrive- it was very impressive. I dont think we'd stay there again- as we much preferred the North Shore to Waikiki, but its definitly a nice place to stay in Waikiki.  
<Date>Sep 6, 2007

<Author>hakafos
<Content>Wonderful Resort. Loved it! The Hilton Hawaiian Village surpassed my expectations. I had a wonderful room in the Rainbow Tower that was an upgrade to an ocean view. I was pleasantly surprised since I booked on the website for Hilton and did not express a preference.The staff was courteous and efficient. Check in was swift.The pool contrary to earlier reports wasn't crowded at all and neither was the beach. Due to jet lag I was up at 4 am and they actually comb and rake the beach every night before the guests use it. Staff is up then too to prepare for the 6 am breakfast crowd.The cons, food is outrageous. Do go to the diner across the street. The food is good and inexpensive and the service is great.If you like chains, Outback and Red Lobster are around the corner and a block down the street. They may serve the same fare cheaper.The mats for $2 at the package store are all you need for the beach. I cannot see having to pay for a beach chair at a Hilton resort. The hospitality suite they gave us to use before we flew out was dirty and wet towels and used toiletries were all over the bathroom floor. Shame on you Hilton!But, other than that I thoroughly enjoyed my stay and will recommend the resort to friends.

<Author>aw19
<Content>Very Convenient. Great Service. Just got back from a 6 nite stay in the Ali Towers at HHV. Was upgraded to an oceanview room upon arrival. Daily breakfast was also included as well as one 3-course lunch for our party. Amex Platinum service also guarantees 4 pm check-out which worked out perfectly b/c I had a mid-afternoon flight. We didn't have to rush to pack and check-out before noon.The rooms were spacious and clean. Definitely looks better than some of the pictures I have seen on TA. The Ali towers has it's own pool on the 2nd floor, which can only be accessed w/ your room key. I can't get over how courteous everyone was. The staff was always more than will to help. I frequent high end hotels like the Ritz and 4 Seasons. The rooms and facilities at HHV may not be of the same par but the service definitely was. Large property with many stores and 4 pools. The beach isn't as packed as the one shared by many hotels on the Waikiki strip.Location was very convenient and central. We were within walking distance to everything but yet away from the hustle and bustle of Kalakaua Avenue in Waikiki. Just a short 2 min. drive away but what a world of difference. All in all, we had a great stay.

<Content>very gourgeous but pricy We just came back from Hilton Hawaii Village, it was really beatiful and the beach is gourgeous. The rooms are nice, a little small. We stayed at Kalia tower, it was nice and quite. There is a lot of construction going on, but it was not noisy. The rainbow tower is nice it has ocean view, but very expensive. The other side of rainbow tower has construction view. The Allie tower is right on the beach. The only negative are the price, they are tooo high for everything. The food in the hotel is expensive. The canned soda is $2.00 but if you go to the bar and ask for soda it's $8.00!!!!!. We spend all of our money on food and entertainment. Nothing there is free. Going to the beach costs $62.00 a day for umbrella and other stuff. But it was nice, just bring a lot of money with you.

<Author>ksgirl8
<Content>Not my Style, but still Nice We stayed here for two days on our way back from Maui and linked up with our family who were also in HI at the time. They chose the hotel. We stayed in the Rainbow Tower. The room was very nice with a decent view. It had a small refrigerator, which was nice. The resort is lovely and the grounds very well kept. We used both the pool and the beach in front of the resort. The prices on resort seemed very high for things like bottled water and food, but this is not atypical of resorts. The stores were often very crowded. I would not stay here again unless I had kids. I prefer to stay in smaller places that give you more of a local feel. This resort feels largely like, disney does Hawaii. I am sure it is exactly what many people want. It's just not really my style. We don't normally stay at national chain hotels for that reason. You could happily stay on property for a week on Honolulu at this resort.

<Author>RN97
<Content>Great Hotel but expensive! We just returned from our stay at the HHV in Oahu. I have to say the hotel is really nice. We were able to get there early enough in the day to get a upgrade room. We had a nice view of Diamond Head and the beach/ocean. Be careful about getting there late in the day. The gentelman checking us in said they typically OVERBOOK in the summer months. People arriving late run the risk of not having a room. I asked the guy what happens in that case and he said they put you in another hotel till a room is open. That would greatly irritate me! I think we got very lucky! We did eat at the hotel occasionlly. Be aware any meal you eat there will be very expensive. This is not a budget friendly hotel! My husband overed a beer glass of wine and a pina colada and it was $27.00. After that bill I walked to the ABC store on the property and bought drinks for the room and a few snacks. That was much cheaper. We would stay there agian anyday now that we are prepared for the prices.

<Author>prcConnecticut
<Content>Recent Visit to Hilton Hawaiian Village Just returned from the Hilton Hawaiian Village. Very much enjoyed our stay. Oceanfront rooms in Rainbow Tower recently renovated and with fabulous views. Construction noise mildly annoying at the beach. Service and food in all restaurants very good (Rainbow Grill, Village Steak, Benihana, Sergios, Tapa Grill, Round House Pizza, New York Deli). Common areas, Pool and beach somewhat crowded. However, this is a particularly lovely stretch of beach with great waves for children. My kids (10 and 14) couldn't get enough of it. Wish big pool were open at night . Overall, best hotel on Waikiki beach for families from what I could see. /If you're interested in the fanciest restaurants (golden Dragon and Bali by the Sea) men must have long pants.

<Author>familyKim
<Content>Bold, Busy, Behemoth We stayed in the HGVC Lagoon Tower Christmas 2006 for three days, and also Christmas 2004 in the HGVC Kalia Tower, and in 2002 in the hotel section at the Alii Tower.. If you are thinking that this is going to be some remote, quiet island destination, just stop that train right here. The name Hilton Hawaiian Village is not a misnomer. There are thousands of guests staying there at the same time you are, housed in about 5 different buildings of differing ages and proximity to the sea. The check in line kind of looks like a bank during lunch hour, with ropes herding the crowds into orderly snake-like lines. But once you're up, they get you check in pretty quickly.The newer, Kalia Tower is furthest from the beach, but has the beautiful granite countertops in its kitchen and new furniture and great high tread count sheets in its one bedroom units. The dining and sitting areas were just right for our family, The Lagoon tower is a bit older, but the 2 bedroom units are really spacious for a family of 4 and equipped with full kitchens and generous size eating areas. The Alii tower is like a small upscale hotel within the village right next to the beach and the executive room we had was huge. Each of these buildings have their own pool, which means you don't have to brave the crowds in the super pool in the center of the village. Watch out for penquin droppings along the way...The rooms themselves felt upscale, spacious, squeaky clean, furnished with fairly recently bought furniture, and well maintained, but the service was predictably kind of slow. It would take the bell people a good 20-30 minutes to come get our luggage (with a family of small children, we're like a baggage train from Accra minus the camels) and getting housekeeping to come empty the garbage might mean a half day wait. Getting our car out of valet parking has taken as long as 30 minutes at the Lagoon Tower. Otherwise the service is courteous and willing to help.The Village has restaurants at all price points, convenience stores, gift shops, and a couple high end luxury shops. If this doesn't satisfy your need to consume, the Ala Moana Mall is only short walk away, since this Village is located on the shopping/hotel strip of Waikiki. If you're willing to drive a bit, snorkelling at Hanauma Bay or swimming (kind of dangerously) at Sandy beach is not far. Of course, the hotel property has tis own slightly rocky beach (bring water shoes), so that is always easy. The location and the facilities offered created a lot of convenience for us.The Mandara Spa offered typical body and face services and the women's sauna was quite good. Massages were diappointingly weak--more in the style of a gentle Swedish with scented candles and body oils rather than a tissue searing Shiatsu. Relaxing but ephemeral.Clearly, we like the place as we keep coming back. It is perfect for families with children that don't want to do much more than play in the sand, swim, and occasionally take a walk around.  
<Date>Aug 16, 2007

<Author>Dazzlers
<Content>The perfect base for a stay on Oahu. Just returned from a ten day stay at this amazing resort.I think anyone who gives the HHV a negative review cannot have done their research thoroughly before booking. Yes it is a big, bustling resort and yes they do 'nickle and dime' you ($3.50 daily rate to use your room safe is just one example). However, we knew all this when we booked but felt the pros outweighed the cons and we were so right.....Arrived at 10pm at night after enduring 24 hours of travelling and jet lagged beyond belief to find we had been upgraded to the Ali'i Tower. Were presented with a lei by concierge before being shown to our room and just collapsed into bed exhausted.Did we get a surprise next day when we woke and opened the curtains, the views were stunning- we had a beach view room and honestly I could have cried it was so beautiful. The Ali'i tower has a very exclusive feel about it, I was very pleased we had been upgraded. Rooms were spacious with a separate dressing area and a small fridge to keep drinks and snacks in. The beds were so comfortable - like sleeping on a cloud. Very efficient and thorough maid service including an evening turn down service - with chocolates. I loved that. The tower has a private pool which can only be accessed with your room key and a private sea view bar.You do get complimentary coffee and bottled water in your room which I don't think you get in the other towers. A continental breakfast is also served here which we highly recommend. Other restaurants on the resort served both hot and continental breakfast buffets which had a choice of everything you could possibly eat for breakfast - including a full Japanese option.The restaurants are expensive but we had no complaints about the quality of the food, although we only ate on resort a couple of times as we preferred to walk into Waikiki to eat in the evening.The resort itself is breathtakingly beautiful - spotlessly clean - and although there are obviously thousands staying here it is so big it never feels crowded or noisy. I knew there was construction taking place but never once noticed it during our stay.I think the resort is in the best location - right on the edge of Waikiki. In this area the beach is large, quiet and uncrowded - although it is artificial - the sand is from California and if you dig down a couple of inches you hit concrete!Further down the beach, it becomes much narrower, especially at high tide and you literally can barely walk between bodies stretched out in any tiny space available. However, the sand here is real.Waikiki is buzzing at night and I would imagine its quite noisy until late if you are staying at one of the hotels further down the beach. Staying at the HHV, we were only a short walk from all this activity but could escape to the peace of our resort when we wanted - the best of both worlds! One memory that will stay with me for ever is eating at Dukes (amazing salad bar), then taking off our shoes and walking back to the HHV along the beach with the moon shining on the water and savouring the atmosphere of the evening entertainment in the other beach front hotels.Also, as the HHV is on the edge of Waikiki, it is a little easier when driving around as you do not need to battle your way through the traffic of Waikiki to access the rest of the island. Having said that driving here is not a pleasant experience - the whole area is a mass of one way streets and the on/off ramps for the freeways seem to be tucked away at the end of residential streets! Thank goodness we had a Sat Nav system in our car as I don't think we would ever had found our way back to the resort! However, we do recommend hiring a car to sample the beauty of the island.I cannot rate this hotel highly enough - we loved it in every way possible and would not hesitate to recommend it to anyone.  
<Date>Aug 12, 2007

<Author>bowwow2gill
<Content>Great Resort This resort is fantastic. There is so much to do - relaxing and watching the world go by on the beach or taking a walk through the resort and seeing the penguins, koi fish, etc. We arrived earlier than check in time (11.00a.m.), due to our flight time, and as there wasn't a room available at that time had to wait until 2.00 p.m. to get a room. However, following this delay we did get a free up grade to the Ali'i Tower. The staff were friendly, as were fellow guests. The worst thing about this resort is leaving!

<Author>ablazej
<Content>Interesting Experience The resort is very spacious. There is a lot to see and do in here. Make sure you take a good amount of time to enjoy all the aspects of the resort (animals, art, etc.). This place is great if you're looking for a really relaxing environment. There are many people at the resort, but there is so many places that it never gets crowded (except the elevators maybe). The pool was never crowded (if it is...you always have the beach). They had live music playing in some places at night. It was great to get a chance to sit down and listen to the band play Free Bird!There are so many wonderful things going on at the resort that you really must make sure you have time to just sit back and relax.My only complaints are that the pool closes too early (5:30pm) and some of the hotel attendents (especially around the pool) were not too helpful.

<Author>JimAtLaw
<Content>Wife  My wife and I stayed here for 6 nights, and had an absolutely wonderful time. Not quite up to one or two of the really world-class hotels I've been lucky to visit (the Hilton Jerusalem comes to mind in this chain), but great overall.Our room was a large suite and had an ocean view and two balconies even though it was in one of the lower end towers for this complex, and the upgrade price of the breakfast buffet was well worth it even if just to watch the fish in the gorgeous koi pond (the food was great too). We also had a great late-arrival-from-the-mainland dinner at Benihana (not exactly exotic, but great for US hotel food, and just as importantly was open for a hearty meal even though we arrived after a lot of other things were closed). Didn't try the nicer restaurants there other than for breakfast because we were out and about most nights. The little cafe will make you a reasonable americano in the morning and has good pastries if you're not sticking around for breakfast. Parking our rental motorcycle in the parking lot was also never a problem, and the service was impeccable. The drinks from the beachfront lounge were not exactly strong, but hey, you can't have everything, and what do you expect at a place like this. :-)The hotel is located on one end of the Waikiki beach area, between the hotels-on-the-beach strip and the yacht harbor, and we had a lot of fun just strolling around the area. If you're looking for an easy beach getaway and a hotel staff that are helpful but not intrusive, give it a try. Two thumbs up.  
<Date>Aug 5, 2007

<Author>oficemgr
<Content>Loved the whole experience When we arrived we were given an oceanview room. Beware that this accomodation considers a partial oceanview to be oceanview. If you can look over your balcony and see any water, it's considered ocean view. After 12 hours in and out of airplanes to get there, I cried when I got to my room! Literally. I was extremely disappointed. My husband told me immediately to step into the bathroom and shut the door. I was oblivious to the fact that he was having to catch a 4-5 inch bug in our room! He put it in a baggie and we immediately took it to the front desk and expressed our disgust for the room. The night manager worked desperately to find us an accomodation that was adequate for us. She upgraded us quickly to oceanfront accomodations in the Ali'i Tower. While we were waiting for our room to be ready, she gave us a $100 food credit so we could go onto the property and enjoy a meal while waiting. While I was horrified at our first room, it made the ordeal manageable after getting into the Ali'i Tower. If you have the money to spare, absolutely request the Ali'i Tower with an oceanview. I spent hours on the lanai soaking up the view. Kona coffee and that view are enough memories to get through to the next year when you're able to return to the islands. I would recommend this hotel because I should have researched better and realized some hotels consider a partial oceanview room to actually be an oceanview. We loved the property as a whole. We actually seldom left the property itself to do any type of shopping. THEY HAVE THEIR OWN ABC STORE! We did it on the massive property given to you by Hilton. This place is my personal recommendation for anyone going to Oahu with no experience on the island.  
<Date>Aug 4, 2007

<Author>Michael-Traveller-JP
<Content>Guests as nuisance The facilities of this hotel are o.k. Seemingly one of the better places at Waikiki, but unimpressive in comparison to the resort hotels in South East Asia. We stayed in an ocean front room at the Rainbow Tower at US $ 360 per night. The room was o.k., spacious enough and furnished quite nicely.The food at the 2 restaurants we tried was reasonable and the prices not overly expensive - just in line with what you pay at Waikiki.The major downside of this hotel is the service. Check-in took us 30 minutes, as we became part of a training program for new front desks trainees... After check-in we wanted to go to the beach. Chairs and umbrellas are rental only, at US $ 60 per day for a set of one umbrella and 2 chairs. We passed on this rip-off. And the guys at the beach facility rental desk were dreadfully rude, not only to us, but to other guests too. Chairs at the pool were plentiful, but all occupied, although there are probably 200 chairs arranged auditorium style with no space in between. Well, the only option left to enjoy beach or pool was placing our towels on the sand in the tiny shade of a palm tree. Then we wanted to eat a snack in the poolside 'restaurant'. We sat there unattended for 20 minutes and left without being served.The flaws in service are major. You may expect friendliness only from staff who are supposed to receive tips. The rest are from neutral to extremely rude.Well, we found that the Hilton isn't unique in poor service and attitude. We felt unwelcome almost anywhere we went. In Honolulu tourists are taken for granted and obviously treated as nuisance. Well, we've taken the point and definitely won't return.  
<Date>Aug 3, 2007

<Author>Katymoo
<Content>Absolute paradise! We stayed at this hotel for 7 days in July, all I can say is, it's awesome! Go see for yourself and enjoy! There's loads to see and do, the rooms are massive, clean, modern and the staff simply cannot do enough for you. We'll definitely stay there again, yes it's a little bit more expensive than other places for food and drink but a short walk or bus / tram ride - you have everything you want to eat or drink, the shops too are amazing!We got married on the beach in the Kahala district of Honolulu, what a beautiful beach, go there if you want privacy as Waikiki beach can get quite busy. All in all, we found paradise and were sorry we had to leave.  
<Date>Jul 30, 2007

<Author>tink47
<Content>Great Location on Waikiki My husband and I just returned from a four night stay July 17 - 20, 2007, at the Hilton Hawaiian Village on Waikiki. (HHV) I would first like to say that the hotel was a wonderful facility with a friendly and helpful staff. (I would be remiss in not mentioning the stellar valet parking staff, first rate)We stayed in a garden view room in the Diamond Head Tower on the sixth floor. Our view was not much to talk about, but we knew this when we booked our reservation. We were on a budget and did not expect to spend too much time in our room. Our view was of a park on the grounds of the military hotel next door, the Hale Koa. A service entrance was also below our window and there were times when you could hear the sounds coming from the delivery trucks below. This was only during the day, never at night.Our room was decorated very nicely. I am not sure when this tower was renovated or redone but everything in the room seemed very new. Our king bed was extremely comfortable with a wonderful fluffy duvet and plenty of pillows to match. The room featured a flat screen TV with the usual array of movies and games for purchase at your fingertips. There was a four drawer dresser, desk with lamp and chair, a round table and two chairs situated next to the sliding glass door and a cushioned bench for luggage. The closet was very large and included a iron and ironing board, and a few hangars. There was a safe located in the closet for use for a fee. Near the entrance to the room was a wet bar with a small sink, small refrigerator, and a coffeemaker(Single Pod type). The coffeemaker included the usual suspects of Kona coffees, teas, and condiments. I will note that I had read on some reviews that the hotel charges extra for coffee. It was included (no fee) and refilled daily as we used it. The bathroom as well as the wet bar countertops were either marble or a look alike solid surface. The shower thankfully worked very well with nice pressure even though they have a sign in the bathroom explaining the restricted low flow shower head. (due to the water conservation laws in Hawaii) The tolietries were Crabtree and Evelyn. I absolutely loved the towels. Plenty of bathroom linens,plush, large and spa like. Other amenities included a blow dryer and a mounted makeup mirror on an adjustable arm. (nice touch) We heard very little noise from our neighbors. Maid service was well done except that I think the room was pretty dusty and could use a good dusting. Other than that the room was very clean and in good working condition. I almost forgot to mention the balcony. I believe most if not all rooms have a balcony. Ours included the usual two chairs and small table.I had heard stories about the tenacious Hilton Vacation Club, timeshare employees at the hotel. We were not bothered in person by the timeshare employees during our stay at the hotel. There was a voice mail inviting us to a complimentary breakfast our first morning which was to pitch a tour of the Hilton Vacation Club. There was also a postcard rub off game in our information packet given to us at check in. We did not eat at the Hilton due to the very high prices. The Hilton did have a variety of restaurants for your culinary moods. They had italian, japanese, steakouse, NY deli fare, chinese, seafood, and good ole burgers and sandwiches. A note of interest, the military Hale Koa Hotel next door has a few eateries and an outdoor bar that is legally able to be used by civilians as well as military. This is due to a law in Hawaii that has something to do with public beach access and such. The prices at the Hale Koa are very reasonable. The food is average but tasty. There is a place called Happy's a little further in past the pool that serves, burgers, chicken sandwiches, hot dogs, premade deli sandwiches, salads, fries, drinks, and ice cream. There is also a small step-up to the window type deal that also serves burgers, hot dogs, drinks and shaved ice. There is lots of outdoor seating in these areas plus a park nearby with picnic tables, plenty of shade and a great breeze from the ocean. The bar if you are hankering for an adult beverage is also next to the Hale Koa pool and has prices almost half the price of the ones at the Hilton. My personal favorite was the Lava Flow. Ono - delicious. The beach in front of the hotel was primo. We especially noticed this after visiting many beaches on the island. There were very little rocks located in the surf here, plus the water was pretty calm here. Great for the kids and those of us that just want to float around and relax. Don't worry though, there are plenty of beautiful beaches on the island that are waiting for the brave and risk taking water babies that seek excitement in the surf. There is also a stand that rents, snorkels, floats, kayaks, chairs and umbrellas and the such in front of the hotel. If you walk out to the beach from the hotel and make a left and walk down toward the Hale Koa (yes, that place again) there is a stand that I believe is not part of the Hale Koa Hotel, however, they do give discounts to the military, where you can also rent beach gear and it is a liitle cheaper than the one in front of the HHV. We rented two chairs and an umbrella for the day for $35.00. This also included cushions on the adjustable lounge chairs, and a bucket of ice that they bring for your drinks.In my opinion the HHV is in a great location, especially for families. You are not in the middle of the waikiki beach where it can be very busy and noisy, fun to visit though, and then go back to the Hilton for the night. You are on a calm part of the beach. There is a sidewalk and concrete walkways that front most of the hotels on Waikiki. This makes it alot faster and easier to get to many of the restautrants on the beach. Driving is crazy busy and frustrating with all of the one way streets and parking is expensive. We paid $2.50 for every half hour we parked in a parking garage near the International Market. The penguins and Ibis birds and turtles that they have on the hotel grounds are a crowd pleaser for the younger set. The Friday night Jubilee and Fireworks show that the Hilton puts on isn't shaby either. The hotel is also great for couples. It has a romantic feel especially at night. The lush tropical gardens and flowers that look like they have OD'd on Miracle Grow sprinkled in with the glowing tiki torches and balmy ocean breeze makes it a very nice place to have some couple time while watching the sunset.I know this review has been long, I did feel like this site helped me so much on my trip to Oahu that I just wanted to give something back. I found this site to be very helpful and pretty accurate. Another source that I found to be extremely accurate and right on the mark was the book titled Oahu Revealed by Andrew Doughty and Harriett Friedman. This book had fantastic information, directions and maps and was worth every penny that I paid for it. This website and the book I mentioned helped make my vacation very memorable and they won't lose your luggage!  
<Date>Jul 28, 2007

<Author>cathyteach
<Content>great view I really liked the HHV. There were some positives and negatives about our stayPositives: Our room in the Rainbow tower was picture perfect. The ABC store on site was great. The grounds were spotless. We were able to find chairs at the pool. The beach was steps away from pool. They came right away to fix the air when it stopped working. Negatives: The people in the stores on the property are very pushy, and will try a hard sell. Not my style. The HHV people wanted you to eat on site, and not leave to eat, so they would not provide info about places to eat. We eat breakfast across the street everyday. We did like the pizza place on the property and they were not overpriced. I do not think they changed the sheets the entire stay of 7 nights, the room was clean, but they never cleaned the floor. We were not messy people so it was ok, but the maid service could do better.

<Author>MrMrsTravel
<Content>Great Resort! My husband and I stayed here for the first part of our honeymoon and were very happy with our choice! We were in the Rainbow Tower (we had already paid for a room in that tower online on their website, the net direct rates), which I agree with other reviews, it is the best tower to be in - it is the only tower right on the beach with the best views! We were on the diamond head view side and never heard any construction. We woke up and fell asleep to the wonderful sound of the ocean! Sitting on the balcony was amazing, the view the sound... You also can't see any construction, they have a wall put up, that you see when you're at the beach so it's not like you see what's happening or feel like you're missing out on the lagoon.We found the staff friendly. They upgraded us to an executive suite in the rainbow tower, so that was a pleasant surprise! The room was huge and had 2 bathrooms! When you check in, if you are a HH member, and if you're not become one online before you go (free and quick), make sure you don't wait in the long check in line, but go to the sign that says HH Members check it! It seriously saved us at least 15 minutes! No lineup there, whereas everyone else was waiting in a long line to check in!Yes, it's a big hotel and whenever you're in the lobby, we did feel a bit like we were at disneyland - always busy! But we didn't spend a lot of time in the lobby. The hotel grounds are nice, the animals on site are very cool! We loved the penguins, flamingos, turtles and fish! We even got to participate in fish feeding, they gave you a little cup of food and you can walk around and feed them! The ABC store is the best value on the property - great prices! The negatives for us: They refused to offer us a late check out, we wanted to check out at noon instead of 11am, but they couldn't accomodate us. That was disappointing.That you have to rent beach chairs if you want them on the beach, they aren't free. We didn't, we bought mats from the ABC store for $2 and lay on the beach - way better and lots of people opted to do this.Overall, we had a great time here and would definitely return!  
<Date>Jul 27, 2007

<Author>SpiKids
<Content>Wonderful stay! We just got back from 4 nights at the Hilton Hawaiin Village and had a wonderful time. Location is great - at end of Waikiki with great beach access and walking distance to variety of shops and dining options. Stayed at the Alii towers which is worth the extra money (we explored all the pools and it was nice to come back to ours for a spa and free appetizers in the late afternoon). Started our stay with firework show as the kids played in the surf (great way to start a trip if it falls on a Friday evening). Recommend renting a car to explore the island and drive up the coast. If your a Lost fan, you will find many spots that you will remember from the show. Pearl Harbor is worth a day trip which should include a trip to the Missouri and Bowfinger sub. Recommendation for a nice dinner would be Ocean View (about 2 hotels away in the Outrigger), also Todai is a fun sushi and seafood frenzy in all you can eat style (highlight of my 11 yr. olds trip). We found staff to be very helpful and genuine from the Bellman's initial greeting of Welcome Home! to the valet's closing remark of Mahalo, have a safe flight and hope to see you again.  
<Date>Jul 25, 2007

<Author>tommy tsunami
<Content>oasis in the city yes waikiki is busy and crowded , sometimes like chicago during rush hour, but we find that the hilton hawaiian village is like an oasis in the middle of all the hustle and bustle , no matter how much you've heard about waikiki its rare blend of sensual ambiance and sophisticated packaging must be experienced to be understood . there's really nothing about waikiki that isn't unique , but there are places that will remain glued to your memory cells like snapshots of your trip to the islands , and the hilton hawaiian village is one of those places with its torch lit path ways and soft night breezes .

<Author>F10nna
<Content>Fab Hotel We absolutely loved this resort. the only downside was some of the staff who were most unpleasant, especially when we wanted to cash travellers cheques. We had a room in the Ali'i Tower which had its own check in desk, swimming pool and complimentary evening hors d'oeuvres in the Ocean View Terrace Bar. It was as you can expect much more expensive than the bars and restaurants which were outside the resort, however, it is the price you pay when you stay in this type of resort right on Waikiki Beach.

<Author>Ogorman
<Content>Loved This Place This was the best out of the three hotels we stayed at during our honeymoon to Hawaii. The location was perfect, we were able to walk into town at night, staff was extremely accomodating, they even upgraded us several levels, champagne was in our room upon arrival and bottled water every day. Only downfall the cost of food, we ate outside of the resort as much as possible, which was easy due to the location. All you can eat pancakes $5.95 across the street. We stayed in the Alli Tower, which has it's own pool, gym, hot tub and bar area, free appetizers were served every night from 5-7pm, three hot trays, fruit and cheese. The bartender ROCKY, very good, we drank his suggested drink the ITCH. The birds, fish, penguins and foilage was just breath taking. Our room was comfortable, clean and big with a nice patio. The beach and water were clean. The shops inside the resort were very nice alittle pricey, but you are on vacation and inside a resort. We went to a nice bar/restaurant called DUKES in town within walking distance if your not afraid of walking, inexpensive and a great atmosphere. We felt very comfortable in this hotel and in the area (maybe it has to do with the fact that I grew up so close to NYC).

<Author>LiquidSun
<Content>Dissappointed in Service Level Our family of 4 just returned from an eight day vacation to Oahu, staying at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. The Hilton is rather pricey , but the description of the property made me think it was going to be worth the extra dollars we would be spending on this beachfront hotel. My husband and I found the the service unreliable (even after repeated, daily requests to stock the room with towels and supplies for 4 people, they just never got it...! And little annoyances like our room key never working in the parking garage, etc.) and for the most part, unfriendly. Maybe it's because the Hilton is such a huge resort and friendly/caring just isn't part of the deal. Also, I agree with some of the other reviews of Waikiki hotels about the nickel and diming that goes on. The Hilton Village does its fair share of this practice, and it's almost a joke. Also, our oceanfront view room was partial oceanfront at best. And we woke to the sound of tour busses and trucks every morning - - all morning...We loved Oahu, but next time we will definitely stay someplace else!  
<Date>Jul 20, 2007

<Author>ajaDenver_CO
<Content>Ask for the Kalia Tower We stayed here for 2 nights. The first night in the Tapa Tower...bad choice! Although we were on the 10th floor, the band playing at the Tapa Bar until 11pm was loud enough in our room to keep us awake when sleep was needed! We asked to be moved and were relocated to the Kalia Tower despite full hotel. The tower was beautiful - quiet, elegant, dedicated concierge and valet parking. In addition, a small private pool on the 4th floor for residents of the tower - nice! The grounds are pretty, although the Super Pool small for the size of the resort. Beach chairs were packed in and tight. You needed to come down at 8a to get a good seat! The village had lots of nice convenient shopping. Restaurant choices were diverse although pricey, and challenging for younger kids.

<Author>suekane
<Content>Honeymoon Surprises My husband booked us a trip to Hawaii for our honeymoon. We were so excited. When we got there, the wait was horrific. They sent us to a room with a view of a parking lot on a rooftop which was not what my husband paid for. He's stayed at this hotel before and he always got a room with an ocean view. He was irritated even more to see that something very important was also left out. My husband wanted to surprise me with champagne and chocolate covered strawberries when we got to the hotel so he requested that ahead of time when he made reservations. They said that everything was going to be perfect for our honeymoon stay. Not only did they put us in the wrong room (smelling of smoke) we requested a non-smoking one, but we had to lug all of our belonging to another building- the Rainbow Hilton (that was the building we requested from the start), they didn't even have my surprise in the room. I felt so bad for my husband b/c he rarely surprises me with such romantic jestures and he wanted our honeymoon to be a perfect start to our life together. By the time he got off the phone with the front desk about the problem, I heard about it and it totally ruined the surprise. I didn't even want the champagne and strawberries anymore, but they insisted on rectifying their mistake by bringing them up but still charged us. Too many wrongs for my liking. My Honeymoon surprises were not so good b/c the hotel staff made too many mistakes and ruined them, but the stay was alright.

<Author>Cool_Aunt
<Content>Consistent, Outstanding Quality We have stayed at this property every year for over 35 years, and it has never failed us. Management of this large hotel complex is top notch, and the hotel is constantly renovating and upgrading its rooms. We had originally booked a stay at the Royal Hawaiian (see my other review) for a change of pace, but came running back to the Hilton after only one night at the Pink Palace....We are Hilton Diamond members (top level) and they took good care of us by upgrading us to a newly renovated suite (par for the course at this hotel). The room was spotless, the hotel staff friendly and helpful and the grounds well maintained.Also, the Hilton makes the BEST mai tais in the islands. Go to the Hau Tree bar and tell them the Jacksons sent you. Aloha!

<Author>bgardne2
<Content>Great for the Family The Village was very clean and had nice grounds. We stayed in the Ali'i Tower w/ a partial ocean view. The room was large but the view was of the park and construction machinery in the distance was the ocean. We wereupgraded to this tower so we did not complain. Most of the food was moderately priced. DO NOT have breakfast here. $60 for eggs and bacon. I agree with others that the VIllage is confused. Is it upscale or affordable? It is not upscale even though it had a Louis Vitton. The room was affordable but I would NOT pay more than $250/ night or you will be sorely disappointed and feel ripped off. My husband and I (no children) were disappointed in the resort nightlife. We went to the military bar across the way. Great times! The rest of our group had a wonderful time! The 13 of us went to the Polynesian Luau, DO IT. Hike Diamond Head, go to the Bay, get out of Honolulu!!! Overall I would stay here if I got a good rate (we're HH members), but I would stay on another island if I had the choice.  
<Date>Jul 12, 2007

<Author>Ireland3
<Content>Fabolous place This property has it all, it is simply a village. It has lots of tower blocks and we stayed in the Tapa Tower which is very central when you go downstairs. They have loads of restaurants, shops, mini market ABC store, they are all over Honolulu. It is directly on the beach and well worth it. You can rent beds etc on the beach. It is about a ten minute walk to the centre of Waikiki, you can walk along the beach at night but a taxi is only 7USD if you are feeling lazy. I originally had booked a cheaper hotel in Honolulu and was so glad I changed. If ever I was to go back, I would definetly stay there.

<Author>notaveragetourist
<Content>save your $$$ the positives: friendly and helpful staff, the room was pretty clean and the location is good. here are the buts: the construction noise is still noticeable from the farthest building (diamond head tower). the walls were also pretty thin (we could hear everytime someone flushed their toilet). they charge extra for everything (parking, internet, gym)--we learned that other hotels in the area do not charge extra for these things. parking: 20/day, internet 65/day.the gym was horrible (old 80s equipment, kids running around, and they charged 17 per day for this (paradise pass: internet and gym)) check out the gym before you sign up, because once you sign up, you will be charged for everyday of your stay. you can't decide to cancel the paradise pass...if you do stay here or in the area, park for free nearby off hobron (kai'oo st.) or on ala wai blvd. watch the signs for street sweeping and such, but for the most part, there's cheap parking around, you just have to take the 15 min. or so to find it. Hilton charges you 20 bucks from 1pm-1pm (daily) which gets to be really expensive if you're staying a while. you can also leave your car on the top floors of ala moana shopping center which is about a 10-15 minute walk away. we did a combo of these things while we were there.also we took a surf lesson with hilton's surf schools and it was pretty lame for what we got. maybe better for kids, not so much for adults. the instructors don't teach you anything but how to stand up on the board (a 12 foot softtop that is a lot easier to ride than normal boards). basically, you get babied. students get towed in (most don't even paddle themselves out to the break), and they take turns waiting to get pushed into waves--if all you're looking for is the sensation of surfing, this might be the way to go. but if you really want to learn to surf, this is a waste of money. i would recommend learning somewhere on the north shore instead. if you want to go out on your own, they will also rent boards for a lot cheaper up there too (7/hour as opposed to 35/2 hours which is what hilton charges). i've never personally taken a lesson on the north shore, but i wish i had. my friends on the island suggested it but i was lazy and wanted to stay in town. anything has to be better, at the very least, equal to this surf school for what they charge.to be fair, i would say hilton hawaiian village is probably great for the average tourist who expects a very touristy and kitschy experience of the island. from someone who has briefly lived here before, my advice would be to stay somewhere smaller, more low key. travel around the island--there are so many great spots off the beaten path. the touristy spots overcharge and you don't get a real feel for the community or the island itself. pick up the honolulu weekly and see what events are coming up--don't limit yourself to generic luaus, crowded pools and beaches, hotel shopping and other tourists as company---get out there and try to get to know the island and its people. the easiest way to do that is by doing some research before and during your stay.best of luck :) hope this advice is useful.  
<Date>Jul 8, 2007

<Author>Franciscain
<Content>Up to its promises After almost 2 months of reading the reviews and comparing hotels, I decided to go ahead and book the $279 ocean view from the Hilton Waikiki Village.I called the day before to ask which Tower we were assigned. They said Tapa or Diamond Head. I knew it would not be the nicest towers (did not pay premium for Rainbow, Kali etc..) but decided to go with it.I arrived after 1am due to flight and luggage delays and still got an awasome service at check-in. The room was in Diamond Head tower. I read in the reviews it is supposed to be the least desirable, but let me tell you it was great. We could see the ocean, the beach, the city , Diamond Head all at the same time from our private lanai.We loved everything in the hotel: service, food, beach, bars, stores...you feel like you do not want to leave it.There is a free trolley to waikiki at Tapa tower by the way if you want to explore.It did not feel crowded even though there was plenty of people due to July 4th.The spa was very good very professional.I had a AMAZING hot stone lomi lomi massage from Cornelius.Kudos to the Hilton. Yes it is pricey but there are a lot of cheap places in waikiki in super crowded hotels with street view and that's not why you came to Hawaii.

<Author>HawaiianHillbilly
<Content>Wonderful Family Vacation We left Tennessee June 9th, for a weeks stay, in hopes of having a wonderful vacation. There were a total of 13 family members, and I can say for a fact not one of us had any problems. I had ordered Lei's form leigreeting.com, and Sheena met us at the airport and showed us to the baggage claim. Our trip started out great with a Limo pickup at the airport by Platinum Limousine Service. You can imagine the surprise when it arrived, especially when I had told them we would be taking a shuttle to the hotel. Mark was our driver, and with 13 of us, he loaded up alot of luggage, but not as much as Chris did when he was the driver of our Ford Excursion Limo back to the airport. Some of us had purchased more luggage to take souveniers back home to members of our family who could not make the trip. For some of us, this was our first Limo Ride. We had family members in the Kalia Tower, Ali Tower and Rainbow Tower. I was originally in the Kalia, but since we were in Hawaii wanted to be on the ocean. Daniel at the front desk was a jewel in finding my husband and I the perfect room. We stayed in room #1201, two balconies, the ocean and the view of Diamond Head, what more could you ask for. It was the perfect place to be with all the family eating pizza from The Round Table and watching the fireworks display on Friday night. My sister Louneil and I really enjoyed the beach. We were there almost every day relaxing under our umbrella and watching the waves go in and out. It was so peaceful. I had read about passing it on where floats were given by people who were leaving to go home, to others on the beach, well we experienced that. My nieces, Cyara and Hailey were given huge blue floats that we passed on to others the day we were leaving. On Sunday night we all went to the Paradise Cove Luau, and had a wonderful time with LeiLana (I hope this is correct) on bus #5, she was great. We ate at Benihana's which was wonderful, and as stated before not that expensive. A favorite place was Surfs Up, really enjoyed the Pink Coral Drink.The resort takes on a different atmosphere at night, with the wind blowing off the ocean, and light from the TIKI torches. At different locations throughout the resort you can stop anytime and listen to the singers. We shopped at the International Market Place. Some family members went to Kauai, and the Big Island. Some hiked to Diamond Head and others stayed on Waikiki. If you didn't want to venture out, you didn't have to, everything you need is within walking distance of the resort. My husband and I are already talking about going back, and staying in the Rainbow Tower, and if we could the same room. I can't stop saying what a wonderful time our family had staying at HHV. We were all together, but then we were not. I guess that was the best part. Mahalo......Vanessa

<Author>GETAWAYPLEASE
<Content>Charged for everything  This was definitely an expensive resort to book. We have stayed at many five star resorts in the past, on Maui, in Mexico, on Kauai. This was the most expensive to book a room in the beginning. But when we arrived, everything seemed to cost. We booked a garden view but when we arrived they put us in a tower very far from the ocean. Oh well. But then they said we could have an ocean view room (it was hart to see the ocean) for $40 more per night in a much closer walk to the beach. We agreed. After that the expenses just kept coming. $25 per day to park the car, $14 for internet service, coffee charges, a sandwich from room service at $23, buffet for $34 per person, The Tropics (cheapest hotel restaraunt) very expensive and TERRIBLE food. All these things make you feel less like you are at a resort and more uncomfortable each day. The coffee, car and internet should be included as with many places we've stayed and if you charge so much for food and drink make it GOOD. We went next door to eat and drink at the military hotel at half the price. The food was still not much better, but it was half the price! We ate at Dukes (the best salad bar ever) and Bennihanas paid the price but had excellent food and dining experience.The diamond head hike was not easy as most hiking books say. I may be out of shape but my kids and husband aren't at all and were still exhausted. The view was not quite worth the crowd and exhaustion becuase usually after a hike you have a great water fall to see or a place to sit and relax to look at a view or play on a beach. Too crowded to even have a place to rest. We LOVE Maui and Kauai. Oahu was too busy, too difficult to get around with unmarked roads etc, and not half as friendly. Everything you do is crowded and touristy.We will never go back unless we island hopped for one day to visit Pearl Harbor again.  
<Date>Jul 6, 2007

<Author>leslieinphoenix
<Content>HHV is your best option when staying in Waikiki I selected the Hilton Hawaiian Village based upon the reviews of the trip advisor website. We stayed for one week, June 6-13. I booked a partial ocean room in the Alli Tower based upon my research and was not upset with our choice. Please note that if you are afraid of heights you should not book an ocean view, or partial ocean view, these rooms are up higher and my husband refused to sit on the patio. Save yourself the money and book a garden view. The hotel and grounds itself, I believe, are the nicest in Waikiki. However, we were unprepared for what Waikiki was and we went there after staying in Maui. We much prefer Maui, to Waikiki. However, if you do go, I believe that the HHV is definitely the place to stay. According to our 9 year old, the best thing about the Alli tower were the penguins. On most days, an employee will teach you about the penguins (1-2 times a day) and have a few penguins out for the people to pet. Every day we had to visit them at least 2 times!I read a number of reviews that talked about how expensive it was, and after being in Maui, I found that Waikiki was actually far less expensive. We ate at the hotel several times for lunch and dinner, and were not totally shocked by the price, although it was not 鈥渁mazing food.鈥?During the morning I walked to Starbucks for coffee and to be more comfortable, we usually ended up eating breakfast in the room. We shopped at the ABC stores (interesting but the ABC store near starbucks was cheaper than the one on the hotel grounds.) We bought fruit, cereal, milk, and drinks. We also ate at a coffee shop across the street from the hotel for breakfast-very cheap and great food! There are tons of restaurants in walking distance. We went to Roys, (if you go, save money and order the appetizer portion, not the meal portion as it is very large!) Benehania, the Yard House, and a few others. There is a subway sandwich shop down the beach that we often picked up lunch at. The HHV definitely has the best beach. The water was calm, and not very crowded. The pool, was better then any of the other hotels, and the property was beautiful. When we walked down Waikiki we could not believe how crazy and crowded it was. We drove to North Shore to go jet skiing. We also ate at a shrimp taco truck called Giovanni鈥檚, which is not to be missed, and had shaved ice in the afternoon. I think that if you don鈥檛 go to North Shore, you miss some of the most beautiful beaches on the island. We went to turtle beach and saw, and swam near, tons of turtles.Overall, I don鈥檛 ever think we will return to Waikiki, but if we did, we would only stay at the HHV.  
<Date>Jul 1, 2007

<Author>larpov
<Content>Best Hotel for mixture of seclusion yet Of all the hotels in Waikiki, this one has the most accomodations, amenities, and attractions in close proximity. The highways in/out of Waikiki to get to Pearl Harbor, Diamond Head, Nu-uanu Pali Lookout, etc. are all close by. The beach was clean, the pools were well kept, and the breakfast buffet was perfect. Although Waikiki is really commercialized, you still feel relatively secluded from the busy strip, but yet you can get to all the hot spots, like Dukes, Shorebird restauarant, etc. I would also highly recommend taking a sunset boat trip, on any of those offered along the beach. We went on the MaiTai, which we could pick up in front of the Sheraton or Shorebird hotel, and it was fun and scenic.

<Author>bamagirl216
<Content>Wonderful stay! Beautiful property. We recently stayed here for 4 nights. Booked a room in the Ali'i Tower. This is the place to stay. Ali'i Tower has complimentary appetizers each afternoon which is good for holding you out for a late dinner- when restaurants are not as crowded. This was a great place to stay.

<Author>engineer64
<Content>Still Great abd Getting Better The Hilton Hawaiian Village is still a great place to stay. The aloha spirit is included with each employee greeting. The hotel is very well maintained and is on a great section of Waikiki beach. The location is pretty good, withiin walking distance of a lot of restaurants, including Hard Rock and Cheeseburger in Paradise. If you can stay Friday, they have a mini-luau (no food) with 2 drinks at $12. This is a great deal. The fireworks are really good. A tip on transportation - Use Roberts for only $30 round trip. Just look for th eyellow vested employees at baggage claim. They are extremely efficient and the Hilton is one of the first stops dropping off and one of the last picking up.The hotel is getting better. With the addition of the new time share buildings going up, they are building huge swimming pools. These are supposed to be completed in 2007. It will be the best swimming pools in Waikiki.

<Author>californiamom
<Content>Consistent, great hotel! We have stayed at the HHV before. Nothing has changed. We never had any problems with our 5-day stay. From the bellmen to housekeeping to all of the staff - absolutely perfect. The beach is large and beautiful. We were in the Alii tower which is definitely worth every penny. Say hello to Mei Ling. She works during the continental breakfast on the 2d floor. She's worked for the hotel over 18 years. Only complaint, if we had one, would be the pools - just wish there was some kind of water feature like a slide or something. Other than that, this hotel is perfect. We are well-traveled and discriminating. The hotel is a cab ride away from all of the Honolulu action (or a long walk in the humidity). There is a lot of shopping and great food choices in the Village. Sergio's Italian is wonderful. I would not hesitate in staying here again, but am very spoiled in the Alii tower. Thank you Hilton again for a great stay.

<Author>krlaWesthartford_CT
<Content>In Honolulu for a Convention A disclaimer first...I do not like staying at large resorts in big cities, and Hilton Hawaiian Village is by any definition a large resort and Honolulu is a big city. Having said that, the (sprawling) grounds were well kept, the staff very friendly and service oriented, the room I had was good (not great by any stretch), and the available activities were numerous. It is located directly on Waikiki Beach. It is truly a village in that if you do not want to leave the grounds, you do not need to. VERY expensive for drink/food...at breakfast, a regular size capuccino and a 12 oz. bottle of water at one of the walk-up bars near the tower I was staying in was over $9.00. I believe that a large pepperoni pizza at the Round Table Pizza outlet on the grounds was approx. $30.Somebody else recommeded going to the ABC store on the grounds...great suggestion. Sandwiches/chips/beer/wine/soft drinks at a reasonable price...sundires also available.The positives (I was attending a convention) was that it was centrally located and near the Convention Center, had many amenities, and the service was especially customer friendly. The downside is it's sheer size (and far too many stores to shop in on the grounds), prices, and the fact that is highly trafficked (to be expected, I guess, since it is in Honolulu).  
<Date>Jun 11, 2007

<Author>KB787878
<Content>Ok, but not great My new husband and I stayed at Hilton Hawaiian Village for our honeymoon the first week of June. We payed extra for the deluxe ocean view room and we were a little disappointed with what we got. We did see the ocean, but we were also over the construction site for the new lagoon, so we got to see and hear that. We asked upon check-in if we could move to the other side of the tower, but we were told nothing was available. Not a huge deal, we didn't spend much time in the room anyway. The room itself was decent. Clean, the bed was comfortable and there was a small fridge and coffee maker (although the maids weren't very good at remembering to leave new cups after taking the old). It just didn't feel worth the money it cost, kind of like a glorified Motel 6 room (which I guess is typical for Oahu). The grounds are nice and there are a lot of dining options at the resort, although they are all pretty pricey. You can definitely eat cheaper elsewhere on the island. We thought the little beach in front was great until we visited the north side of the island (beaches are much nicer over there). Overall it was a pretty good experience, but there was one thing that really bothered the two of us: the staff is constantly trying to get you to their seminars to buy one of their time shares. They slipped a card under our door inviting us about two seconds after we entered our room, we tried to book a massage at the spa and the receptionist tried to sign us up for the seminar, we walked past an information booth and the man inside tried to rope us in and tell us about the exciting opportunity, they even called our room and left us a message not to miss the time share opportunity!! It was a little ridiculous, it got to be a running joke between me and my husband.The hotel wasn't bad, but we definitely won't be staying there again. There are cheaper places to stay on the island where you don't feel bombarded by salespeople.Hope this helps!  
<Date>Jun 8, 2007

<Author>UtahRelaxed
<Content>Ahh... Relaxation and comfort We had the pleasure of staying at this resort in early May. Very beautiful, and well taken care of. The staff were pleasant, and welcoming. The restaurants were great, yet you will pay for the comfort. We had lunch at the Rainbow Lanai and it was over $50 for the two of us, no dessert, and one drink. There is plenty of shops to visit and look at, and even one of the thousands ABC stores on the island. The beach area was beautiful and relaxing. The noise of other areas of Waikiki was gone... just the sound of waves and walkable beaches (no rocky shorelines). A little recommendation... save yourself the headache, and once you get into your room, immediately throw away any card, flyer, note, brochure that refers to free items or scratch-off prizes. Unless, you like to sit and listen to timeshare presentations all day and like to say no alot. I did so, and glad I did (after seeing the faces of many friends who were curious).Also, spend the extra money and take some type of formal transporation. The hotel has arrangements with taxi companies, including Charlie's which for $12.00, took us to the airport in a limo. I took the city bus one day to go see Pearl Harbor, and lets just say, Tyenol and a comfy bed was my friend the rest of the day.Great place, great atmosphere, beautiful views, and several photo opportunities. Even if your not staying there, walk down one night and get some photos.  
<Date>Jun 5, 2007

<Author>Joni010
<Content>Breathtaking Hilton! We stayed at the Hilton for six nights. Check-in was great. We were upgraded from a garden view to a partial ocean view upon request. The woman who checked us in (Jackie) told me that was all she had available, but if I wanted to check with her the next day would move us. We decided to stay where we were as the room was quite large and still had a great view. We were in the Tapa Tower. The property and grounds were well maintained with over 90 stores and 22 restaurants. We only ate on site one day as the prices are a bit steep. It is a short walk to other restaurants, Eggs  Things, Tony Roma's  Cheeseburger Waikiki. The beach was beautiful and towels were complimentary. Rental of chairs and an umbrella was about $51. I also used the Spa as a gift from my husband. It was more than I would have paid at home, but it was worth it. The only thing my husband was a bit disappointed in was the price of a bottle of wine and a fruit tray delivered on the evening of our anniversary. He requested that it be set up with linen and to look fancy. It was placed on the desk without a nice presentation for the $120 cost. Other than that, we had absolutely no complaints. We would definitly stay here again. Enjoy your trip!  
<Date>Jun 2, 2007
