<Author>surfmama3
<Content>Beautiful place to stay! My husband and I stayed at the HHV on Waikiki the first week in April for our 5th wedding anniversary. The entire staff was extremely accommodating. I was 7 months pregnant, and I am sure my big belly helped to upgrade to a nicer room. They originally put us up in the Kalia with a partial ocean view. -But it also included a noisy city street and view of a garbage dump. They promptly moved us to nearly the top floor of the Tapa tower with a gorgeous view of Diamond head, and a much bigger room.This is a BIG resort. So of course, if you plan on staying here, there are going to be lots of people. Although I did not feel like there were huge crowds at all. If they were completely booked, it did not feel that way. The pools stayed busy, but we were on the Beach most of the time. (Who goes to Hawaii only to swim in a pool?). The hotel has a private stretch of Beach, and its nice, but if you just walk 1/2 a block or so up the Beach towards Diamond head, the Beach and water is much more spacious and alot nicer. Also do not rent your lounge chairs from the resort. -Just up the walk are private Beach rentals for ALOT cheaper. There's also a great food stand in the same area that has some great eats!!The grounds at the Hotel are AMAZING! I was very much impressed with the cleanliness and the beautiful landscaping. Although the resort is right in the heart of downtown Honlulu, it is still very much secluded. I dont know how others can complain about the grounds. - I dont think you could make a resort any more beautiful.My only complaint about this resort is the OUTRAGOUS prices at the resturants, spas, boutiques, etc. ! I know Hawaii is not cheap, but you are already paying a pretty penny for your room, and they will choke you from every other angle if you are not careful. We ate breakfast once at the Resort and spent $60 on a basic buffet. After that we had milk and cereal in our rooms every morning. And as I previously mentioned, we ate at the little beach side food stands just up the Beach about a block for lunches. We visited the ABC store frequently for snacks and small stuff, they have everything there -It's the only store on the resort to shop for items like this anyway. And it is always BUSY!Do not buy your souveniors at any of the shops there either!!! Just up the street a few blocks is a Wal-mart with the BEST souvenior gifts. (We took the bus which runs often and is very clean and reliable). And its all the same stuff you find at the Hotel gift shops and boutiques at a fraction of the price. The macadamia chocolates for example are about $13 for 6 boxes and you can mabye get two boxes for that price at the Hotel! We also went to the swap meet at Aloha Stadium. -VERY MUCH WORTH THE TIME AND TRAVEL! This place was amazing! If you are looking to buy authentic Hawaiin gifts, this is the place!Also, do not book any of your tours through the Hotel, they will rip you off like you would not believe! There are free travel and vacation guides all over the place, and I think there is one main stand in the Tapa tower, with tons of great deals and coupons on private companies. All of these places pick you up right from the Hotel. We took a great all day tour of the island including the North Shore and about 20 major beaches and sites for $25 p.p., whereas the Hotel was charging $75 for the same tour!! Even private shuttles to the airport where half the price.Overall, the HHV was a gorgeous place to stay, and if your smart you will save tons of money!!  
<Date>May 30, 2007

<Author>amy_t
<Content>Fun in the Sun My husband and I stayed at the Hiton in May for a week. We're used to Sandals all-inclusives and this was our first non-inclusive trip, so with that said, here's a summary:Resot - Huge! Pretty well kept with lots of ponds through out (penguins, flamingos, coi). Pool was rather small and seemed pretty crowded, but the beach was spectacular and not crowded at all, especially when you saw the rest of Waikiki Beach. Fantastic fireworks show on Friday we saw from our lanai. People at the front desk were polite, but not overly friendly. The best rates were offered through the Hilton web site with AAA discounts. Lodging - we decided to splurge on a Rainbow Tower oceanfront room. Fantastic! Great views of the beach, Waikiki, Diamond Head. Nice that there's a fridge and little wet bar. Stocked up at ABC on wine, beer, water, snacks. Wonderful lanai. We were only on the 6th floor but it was high enough to enjoy the view and felt secure enough to leave the lanai door open a few nights. AC didn't work very well though. I'm a coffee snob, so I had brought my own which we couldn't use in the coffee maker since it just uses pods. Housekeeping didn't show up everyday, but we were too busy having fun to care and when she did show up she left a bunch of Crabtree toiletries.Restaurants - very expensive at the resort for the most part. We were on a budget since we splurged on the room. For breakfast we went to the Wailana Coffee House (open 24 hours) across from the Hilton for big portions and good service. We also discovered CJ's on the property which was only a little more. Great omelettes. For lunch and dinner we tried Round Table Pizza which has very reasonable and yummy pizzas and sandwiches(take out as well). If you like Japanese, there's a noodle place and sushi place side by side on the resort. Sergios is their Italian restaurant and was good but not amazing. We had drinks at the Chart House (off-property) but it was pricey and not very friendly. We loved Duke's at the Outrigger! Try their fish tacos and drinks are around $6 instead of the $10 at Tropics and Hua Tree (both at the Hilton). We also went to Hale Koa for cheap and good drinks and pub fare. There's also a Subway right on the beach. ABC store had great muffins, sandwiches, snacks, souvenirs, everything! We spent over $200 there and got 2 mugs for saving our receipts.Beach - my husband took surf lessons with Rich at PTS half way down the beach and loved it. Much less than at the Hilton. There's a great beach walk that runs along Waikiki and we saw fantastic surfing and body boarding. Beautiful sunsets. All beaches are public, so we'd just drive along and stop when we saw a public way to end up on very beautiful, isolated beaches. Much nicer than Waikiki. Especially liked Sunset Beach and snorkeled at Three Tables. Also tried snorkeling at Hanauma Bay, but it was low tide and only about 2 feet btwn you and the coral. Getting Around - Rent a car! We were planning on taking the Bus, but decided to book through Priceline before we left and had a sedan for 2 days. Priceline had the best prices (we chose Dollar since it was the cheapest and close to the hotel). Definitely book ahead of time - Dollar at the Hilton was sold out before we got there. Explored the North Shore and East Oahu. Also, if you head out to the North Shore, stop at Giovanni's shrimp truck for $12 plates of half pounds of shrimp with rice - amazing! Fantastic views all along the coastal route. There are also trolleys, which we didn't try. For transportation to and from the airport we used the Waikiki Express (Roberts Hawaii). it was $9 per person each way which was a bargain compared with the $26 pp the Hilton was charging. When you get to the airport, just look for the people in yellow shirts outside baggage claim. We waited about 20 minutes and were lucky enough to be the first stop - they hit all the hotels along Waikiki.Pearl Harbor - we went on the 7:30 shuttle from the Hilton and went to the Arizona, Bowfin, Minnesota and Pacific Aviation Museum. Almost no line that early in the morning. Definitely worth it.Asides - if you're going to snorkel again, buy your stuff at the ABC stores or bring it from home. It was great to just throw it in the car and hit a beach. Also, bought towels at ABC, but you could probably just grab them from the pool. I brought a cooler tote bag which was great to fill up with snacks and drinks. Water shoes are a good idea since the beaches can have chunks of coral. Also, I got an inflatable (again the ABC) to use which was a nice way to relax in the water (and use snorkeling). The sun is extremely strong, so I suggest wearing a hat and loading up on sun screen.Before you go - I did a lot of research and found Oahu Revealed to be the best source of info. Also got the Hawaiin Entertainment Book ($18) which we didn't use a lot, but it did save us about $40 at Pearl Harbor for the Minnesota and Bowfin tours.Overall it was a great vacation, but if I was to do it again I'd pick a less expensive hotel since we didn't really use the pool, shop in the stores or eat at many restaurants and rent a car for three or more days since there are such gorgeous places to see all over Oahu. For us the best part was the beach, snorkeling and exploring.

<Author>BreaGymMom
<Content>WoW! Everything and MORE! I really investagated all of these hotels. I must say i really did my homework!! First off ,i picked this hotel for many reasons one being , that I did not want to be in the middle of waikiki. It's too hard to get out of there in a car, and i was planning on driving around the island alot. It;s closest to the airport, and freeway and mostly away from downtown traffic and thier one way streets!! ugg!.It's still close enough to walk down to the middle of the strip of waikik if you want some action or get a bite to eat. Secondly..This hotel offers the nicest,(probably the only) tropical grounds offered in all of waikiki. A lot of hotels even the popular ones don't have grounds and are butt up against the street. This was my familes 1st time,(not mine) to hawaii and i wanted them to get the whole aloha spirit.Okay some of you have to understand that if you pick this hotel it IS going to be expensive. I read reviews of people complaining and bickering about the charges and prices of this hotel,well...don't stay here. You go knowing what to expect and you work around it.It is a fancy ,expensive RESORT. The food was expensive!! Just don't eat there.No big deal. This hotel offers so much more then to be passed on cause of food. ALL hotel food places are expensive!!! You can't get away from it. There is a coffe shop across the street called Waiana Coffee House 1860 Ala Moana Blv. (808)955-1764.It offered reaonable prices,and the food was good.IT was a nice short 4 min walk there. The hotel does have a lot to offer. I brought a family of 5 along. (13,5,18 mos,2 adults.) The hotel offers many fun FREE activities. They offer fish feeding 2 times a day every day. The kids LOVED it! They have penguins on the property,you get to feed them and learn some facts about them. The care takers of these animals,really love thier jobs and teaching , and interacting with the guests. They have tucans and turtels,flamingos,koi fish. We also took a hula class and a lei making class. That was fun. Again all free. We stayed in the ali'i tower highly recomended! You get a door man who, of course opens your door and if your lucky he'll greet you by you last name. Hello,Mr  Mrs Wiemann,how are you today?)You get free water,cofee and tea. to your likeing.They turn down your bed everynight of you stay. They put chocolate and flowers on your bed. You get FANCY shampoo and conditoners. Eveyln and crabtree!!!!!Worth the extra cost to stay here. You get to check in and have your own concierge. It IS ON the opposite side of the busy building they are doing next to the rainbow tower. I didn't hear a thing!!! The parking for the car is EXPENSIVE!!! No LIE! It was bad.Checked around they all cost about the same. 20-25 dollers a DAY! Well, save for it that's what we did. We had a car everyday. 200 smackers for 10 days!! The hotel itself was worth it. We had a 50 dollar dining credit,which we used torward a breakfast buffet in the rainbow lani. (Its another tower on the property grounds. there are5 all together i think. )The food there was Terrific! Ate next to a pond and a waterfall. Life couldn't be better.In the ali'i tower ,They had a private pool for the ali'i guests. free apetizers were served at the pool bar from 4-7pm.That was dinner for us. The hotel offered a friday Night firework show with hula dancers. We got to watch it from are hotel lani. Don't buy the tickets. We were in room 1125 that was facing the pool and the fancy tropical grounds. We saw everything from there.Ask for that side.By the way,..we didn't feel,nickeled and dimedi quess cause we payed extra for the nicest tower there. It was worth it! The hotel staff were soo nice!The hotel also offered a kids club!Bye, kids have fun!!! The snorkeling in front of the hotel was fun. if you swim out a little bit there is a long jetty filled with fish.Please write me if you have any questions. i promise i'll help you. This was truley the best experince we ever has and WAS worth EVERY penny!! Except the parking,but that could not be avoided.In all the grounds were very tropical and had several waterfalls throughout thte property. Call the hotel and have them mail out all the pamphelts they have to offer on the hotel grounds and the activites they offer. that way you can get an idea whats there.That's what i did. it came in about a week. Made more sence when you know what your dealing with and how much money you need to save. they offer activies too. parasailing,etc ask for those pamphlets too. good luck, hope i was able to help.Have fun staying there.  
<Date>May 28, 2007

<Author>travelinghalls
<Content>Construction Ruined Atmosphere We just returned from our visit to the Hilton Hawaiian Village Lagoon Tower. Our room was very large and comfortable, but unfortunately we were overwhelmed with all of the construction noise going on all around us from 6:30 am to 6 pm Monday thru Saturday. When we complained to the front desk one nice man moved us up 2 floors but said that was the best he could do since they were sold out and had several floors closed for refurbishment.No where on the website does it inform you that the Lagoon Pool is closed and that the construction is as an inconvienence as it is. We had to walk down the middle of the driveway to get to the pool at the rainbow tower because they were working on the sidewalks. Also the super pool closed very early. The beach was nice but was littered with cigarette butts and trash. Also the elevators were so crowded on the check out day we had to go up to just be able to get into an elevator that would fit our luggage. The cleaning staff, bell staff and other hotel workers also were squeezing into the same crowded elevators.The drink prices are quite outrageous at 9.75 each, as well as the self parking rate of $20 a day. Over all the experience was nice just being away and being with family but it definitely did not live up to the Hilton experience. The property in Waikola is sooooo much nicer !I definitely won't be returning here.  
<Date>May 23, 2007

<Author>george01
<Content>Fantastiv view Stayed at the Hilton HV at the end of March. Had an ocean front room at the Rainbow Tower overlooking the beach and Diamond Head, and the view was just fantastic. Had no problem with this side of the building about construction noise as posted in one of the previous reviews here. We booked the room for 2 nights, the third was on Hilton Honor points as we're silver members. Later on decided to extend our stay for another 2 nights. Well, all these reservations created quite a bit of confussion for the maid and front desk, who expected us to check-out after the first 2 nights, then after the third night, etc. In few words, they had us under 3 separate reservations for the same room, but their system doesn't cross reference, thus our room card got deactivated. The same thing happened after the third night. Several trips to the front desk, and talks with 2 managers got us nowhere. Along comes a third manager, who got the whole hing straighten-out and sent us a fruit basket as an appology. Other than this, it was a relaxing stay. One thing that I was rather annoyed by is that they charge for loungers and umbrellas for the beach, $50 for two a day. They should be free for guests as it is already a very expensive hotel. The food is good but extremely expensive. Go the cafeteria down the street for breakast and other meals, if you wish. They are cheap. Next to it, there is another convenience store cheaper than the one at the village. Another annoying thing was that unfortunely for us we chose the last week of March for this stay, and every little kid from CA and Japan was on vacation at the hotel. Not at all a pleasant experience. If we ever go back to Hawaii, we'll definetely stay at one of the other islands. Honolulu is by far extremely crowded.  
<Date>May 18, 2007

<Author>mjhill1004
<Content>Nice stay at HHV We just recently got back from our Hawaiian vacation. We stayed at the HHV because it was a work thing for me husband. I'm usually not a big fan of the chain type of hotels but we really had a good experience here. The grounds are kept up very well and it's really very clean. Our rooms were in the Tapa Tower and while they could use some renovations the view of Diamondback Mountain and the ocean were not to be beat. The beds were comfy and sheets of good quality. I would say overall our rooms were pretty clean (although a little Windex would go a long way on the windows/doors but that's a minor quibble). The beach area is beautiful. It is quite expensive to rent chairs and an umbrella for the day but we usually did to be a little more comfortable. We didn't use the pool very often since the ocean was pretty calm and we felt comfortable being in the water there. I will say that the food was pretty awful in our experience. I would get off property as much as possible. It's expensive and truly bad. We walked down to the Royal Hawaiian one night along the beach and we thought the HHV beach was by far the nicest and least busy.

<Author>BerkshireBobbo
<Content>Great Hotel to stay at, but eat elsewhere. A bit slow in the posting here, but time for some honest feedback! 4 of us stayed at the Hilton in September 2006, booked it direct with the hilton website on a paynow, non-refundable deal. Not a problem as we weren't likely to need to change it. Upon arrival we got lucky and walked straight up to the desk (not the case later on as we saw some pretty serious queues), and they gave us a free upgrade to a better room in the Tapa tower facing towards Diamond Head. Rooms were huge compared to what you'd get in Europe, housekeeping was fine and there was no trouble with noise. The grounds are absolutely beautiful, kept spotlessly clean and meticulously groomed definitely a great place. Theres a range of shops selling all kinds of goods from super expensive shoes to polished shells - also a very handy store that sells the little things like waterproof pouches for the beach, tanning lotion, munchies and so on. We didn't use the pool as thats not really something we were interested in (may seem odd, but theres hundred of resorts closer to home for beaches and pools), but it was clean and well kept, plus they lend you towels which is a nice touch. Now, as you start to stray from simply staying at the HHV and you want to do things like eat, better get ready for things to take a downturn. We got a voucher from somewhere that gave us a discount for their buffet, even with the discount, it was overpriced (and remember we're used to pricing in the UK). The food was lukewarm, the selection limited and the service was slow. IMO Don't bother! We checked out the other restaurants on site and they seemed very expensive for what they offered so we went into town to eat all our meals. The cost of doing anything at the hilton seemed excessive actually. A couple of sun loungers for an afternoon on the beach was $28, basically anything beyond just using the room was going to cost you dearly.. One definite negative was the constant pitch to try and get you to go to the Grand Vacations presentations, it was very obvious that anyone who mentioned it was on a commission and so just about all the employees are trying to get you to register. We got round it by telling everyone that we were already registered and going to the presentation tomorrow... Other odds and ends of info that we collected: Public transport is pretty good if you can work it out. The car hire at the HHV sucks, the day we wanted a car we stood in line for an hour only to be told they had 2 cars left, and they were both Mustangs at $80 a day. While we stood there, a line of another 10-12 people built up behind us, but the guy behind the counter didn't think to tell that they'd run out of cars... Book a car a day or 2 before you need it. Can't comment on the Spa as we didn't use it - I considered a massage to ease away the strains on sitting on a plane for days, but was put off by the price and lack of availability. Getting a cab was easy as they flow through steadily, we never had to wait for long.In Summary, I highly recommend the HHV - just go somewhere else to eat.  
<Date>May 8, 2007

<Author>enihous
<Content>Fantastic hotel I stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village for six nights starting Aril 14th with my husband and my son. I had booked a Garden view room and upon chek-in we were upgraded to an ocean view room in the Tapa Tower. The room was quite large and the view of the beach and DiamondHead was fantastic. The hotel has a great tropical feel. There are many restaurants to sample and lots of boutiques. The easy access to the beach is great with kids. The pool is very big and I was always able to get a seat. The buffet breakfast at the Tapa Cafe was okay, nothing great. The Atlantis sub is in my opinion not worth the money. You mostly seeships that were sunken there by Atlantis and very few fishes or other sea life. Go visit the islands. The beaches at Kailua are wonderful and there is hardly a soul there. My son had a great time playing in the big waves there.  
<Date>May 1, 2007

<Author>Raszsch
<Content>Very Average My husband  I started our Hawaiian vacation at the HHV for 2 nights. This is huge resort (which we knew) on massive grounds. We found the resort itslef to be very beautiful, clean, and located in a great area of Wakiki.We did find the service to be a bit lacking. My husband  I are both Hilton Honor Gold members, and had to almost beg for the upgrade that we are supposed to get automatically. (we never even got one, and ended up garden view in the Kalia Tower). I was furious,since I had read many reviews on trip advsior in which people were upgraded for no reason, at all. Our HH guidelines state that upgrades will be granted when available - and they were not (b/c they were given to thers for no reason!!!)The waitress at the Super Pool was non-existant. There was one poor waitress for the whole pool. It averaged 20 minutes to get a beer. We ordered food and the garbage sat around for over 2 hours before it was finally removed.Our other main concern was the concierage. Our first one, Tony was AMAZING. However, the woman that we got later in our stay was horrid. She barley spoke a lick of English. We described that we wanted to go somewhere on the beach - nicer than Duke's....she said she couldn't help us b/c she was not familiar w/Dukes. Duke's is the most popular restaurant in Waikiki - this was laughable - she had nothing to recommend. Shame on the Hilton for having someone this lacking of training in their biggest resort.Overall, our stay was very average - just like any other Hilton, except we were not welcomed as return or valued guests.Sure, I'd go back - but only for the amiance of the beach. If you're planning your trip, I would stay at this Hilton - just manage your expectations low.

<Author>bernyzz
<Content>If youre looking for a Tropical Hawaiian feel...this is the place to stay We just returned from a 4 night stay here.We booked the cheapest room from the net ($229us, Terrace room) but when we arrived i told them it was my sisters b'day and if they can upgrade us for free since it was a special occassion.....and they did!! We got upgraded 5 categories and were soo happy!!They upgraded us to the Ali Tower in a Partial Ocean view room....we had view of the big super pool and the ocean...was awesome!!The Ali tower had its own private pool for guests too which was great, and it's the only tower at the Hilton where they have a doorman opening the main door for you (makes you feel like royalty) ~~ It's Much nicer than the Rainbow Tower.This hotel is the ultimate hawaiian experience, iv'e stayed at 6 different hotels in Honolulu and i have to say that this is the biggest one and it has a tropical feel to it, and also, the beach at the front is really big with white flat sand, not a lot of people...it's very nice! The hilton has 5 pools, the main pool is the biggest  nicest in Honolulu.I love lounging by the pool so this is important to me.This hotel is away from all the hustle and bustle (the main area in Honolulu) it's a bit of a walk if you like being in the centre of it all( the main strip) but u can walk it if u want. This resort has its own little area of shops and restaurants which is quite big and busy.We stayed here for 4 nights then we moved on and stayed at the Sheraton Princess Kaulani, which is right in the centre of honolulu. Nowhere as big as the Hilton but centrally located which we liked.I loved the hilton because it was so big and tropical looking, but i also loved the Sheraton Princess for its location. I have lots of photos....if you want any info or pics, email me at bernyzz@aol.comI want to go back to Hawaii!!!!!

<Author>gfkr2
<Content>Best Beach in Waikiki I just returned from an 8 night family vacation at the Hawaiian Village, including taking 2 teenage girls. The HHV is a very nice resort that exceeded my expectations.The HHV happens to be on the widest and best part of Waikiki beach. In fact, only a select few hotels have actual beach (usable) frontage. Hotels like the Sheraton Waikiki and Halekulani are impressive, but do not have a beach you can enjoy. Other hotels on the beach have only a sliver of sand and are crowded (Outrigger, Royal Hawaiian). If being at a full-service RESORT with all the bells and whistles and directly on the beach, then you can't go wrong by staying at the HHV.We stayed in the Kalia tower 10th floor, which was nice with confortable beds and a good-sized bathroom. Since we booked with Hotwire, we had no choice in room options, and could have been located at the discretion of the resort. However, we asked the front desk for room with a good view, and were happy with the selection. Our room was clean, and the housekeeper worked hard despite the best efforts of the girls to leave their belongings where-ever. Although we could see the constuction of the new Waikiki tower off to the right, it was never a bother. There was very little construction noise that we could hear..The hotel grounds, shopping an restaurant choices were all excellent. Food was available at all price ranges. We ate at Bennihana (food good, prices moderate), Golden Dragon (great food, but the staff rushed us), CJ's (nice breakfast), Roundtable pizza (teen best, pretty good pizza) and Tropics which sits on the beach (nice view, good music, lunch, strong drinks). The grounds also included an ABC convenience store where everything was plentiful and, yes, cheap. Lastly, the Wianna restaurant located across the street from the hotel offered a huge breakfast (good) at low prices.We loved everything about the HHV. The grounds were beautiful, the staff was pleasant and helpful. The choices of things to do were nearly endless. The girls especially loved taking surfing lessons offered through the hotel. We thought the Friday night Hawaiian show, including fireworks outstanding even at $12 pp. The Kalia tower also has a private pool that was away from the crowds. This was a better option for us vs. the super pool, which was busy.Sure you pay more staying here, but everything is expensive in Hawaii. Go the the Hilton. Be impressed. Make family memories that last a life-time.  
<Date>Apr 24, 2007

<Author>technotraveler
<Content>Absolutely first rate hotel I travel alot and stay at many hotels but this is one of the best. Its large but very well staffed. The hotel has probably the best location on Waikiki beach. It's also great for traveling with kids. Not only is the beach right at the hotel but there are some major attractions right at its doorstep. In particular, the Atlantis submarine tour that leaves from the hotel is awesome. And one of the most well-known big wave surfers, Clyde Aikau, gives lessons though the hotel. My 10-year-old son took a couple lessons from Clyde and is now hooked on surfing! Also, some excellent live music is offered at a few venues around the hotel every night. And to top off the week, a Polynesian cultural show on Friday evenings at the main pool with fireworks is very impressive.We stayed in the Rainbow tower which was excellent notwithstanding the construction going on nearby (although this might be an issue if you're on a low floor on the West side of the tower). Not an inexpensive hotel but the Hitlon is a very fine choice.  
<Date>Apr 24, 2007

<Author>pamelaSurrey
<Content>wedding meal Stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village in the Kalia Tower. The room was very spacious and overlooked the sea. Although there was building work going on we were never disturbed by it. Stayed in the hotel with 14 other people, others stayed in the Kalia Tower, Rainbow Tower and one begining with an A I can't think of the name but it was the posh one, with it's own doorman. Whole village was brilliant although a little pricey, as there was more than 7 of us most of the time they autmatically added on 15% service charge. I read reviews about being charged for tea/coffee in rooms but this was not true. We had the wedding meal in the Bali on the Sea restaurant and the evening was perfect, the food was devine and the waiting staff superb, they gave us plastic cups so we could drink our champaigne on the beach after we had finished our meal and gave us complimentary truffles.

<Author>EMSRedding
<Content>Caveat on 'Ocean View' Room We booked an ocean view room in the Rainbow Tower. There was a nice view of the harbor, but the only way you could actually see the ocean from our room would be to step out onto the balcony and lean over to see a small sliver of Pacific. I complained that this did not constitute an ocean view in my mind, but the hotel staff told me that is how the room is classified, and refused to move us. Other then this disappointment, the hotel was great.

<Author>spiderwoman23
<Content>You MUST stay here! My husband and I stayed here, last year during Christmas week. Although a little pricey, it's worth every penny. We had a room with an Ocean view. Within a short elevator ride and a (less than) 5 minute walk, we were right on the beach. The rooms were spacious, immaculately clean and came with small fridges. The beds were nice, fluffy and inviting. The staff was EXTREMELY friendly and ya can't beat the location. It's has a small mall in it with lots of restaurants to eat. We also loved the atmosphere and ambiance.  
<Date>Apr 19, 2007

<Author>mnnat
<Content>Happy at the Hilton I was born and raised on Oahu but have lived on the mainland for the last 16 plus years, during which time I had not been home to Hawaii until now. I spent 4 nights at the HHV in early April.The HHV was fabulous!!!! I had booked a garden view room in the Alii Tower and was upgraded to a one bedroom suite with a great view of Waikiki beach and Diamond Head on the top floor, at no extra charge. The bed was the most comfortable of any hotel I had stayed at. I had read that if you joing the Hilton Honors club on the Hilton's website that they will upgrade you if they can. I joined before booking, it is free.The grounds are lots of fun. I went with two sisters and my 8 year old son. There was so much to see with the variety of birds, koi fish and penguins right there on site. The beach is right outside the Alii tower, the Super Pool was great. My son had the kiddy pool practically to himself the one afternoon we spent there. I had read reviews before my trip where a few people thought it was crowded at the HHV. This was not my experiance. I always easily got a pool chair or spot on the beach. There are always people around but after all it is Waikiki not the rain forest.I loved all the shops in the village, so much to see. There was some kind of hula show I think every night (not toally sure) at the Super Pool which was great free entertainment. I had read that there was a one drink minimum but no night did I see anyone enforcing that.The one draw back was the food is EXPENSIVE throughout the village. Round table pizza was decent price wise. There are plenty of places to eat in Waikiki. You can get snacks and drinks at the ABC store which is in the village for a reasonable price Plan on having a good size food budget and you will be fine. In the Alii tower you get free appetizers (cheese, crackers and veges) from 5-7pm. The Alii tower also has a private pool, which we didn't use as the Super pool I thought was better.A poolside massage in the little cabana they have set up is a must!I recommend paying the extra $6.00 for valet parking. Self parking is $20.00 It is so much easier to pull up and walk away from your car. Plus while waiting for your car to be brought out in the morning you can be entertained by the parrot by the car check stand that says hello and Aloha He entertained my 8 year old the whole time.The staff was always helpful. I found that the nicer and friendlier you were to them the better service myself and others got. Never be rude, even if things get a little hectic. You are more likely to get extras and perks by having a good attitude and treating the staff well.I would go back in a heartbeat and stay at the HHV!  
<Date>Apr 16, 2007

<Author>Bigskylaw
<Content>Excellent, but bring money! (Lots of it) We stayed in the Rainbow Tower from 4/4 - 4/12/07. There were ten of us (four adults, six kids from 9-14) in three rooms. Overall, I can rate this resort as excellent. There were really no bumps in the roadat all.We signed up as Hilton Honors members the day before we left. Based on this we were able to go to the faster check-in immediately upon arrival. We received a free upgrade to the beachfront rooms. We had previously asked for and received our rooms all in close proximity to each other and all with beautiful views of Diamond Head and Waikiki beach.The rooms were fairly typical and clean, new and nice. We received a $100.00 credit because our room had a ceiling problem that we were unable to locate at any time throughout our stay.There was some construction on the lagoon side of the hotel, but it did not bother us in the least. It looked like it will be wrapping upsoon.The Village is very nice, very well maintained, and it was great to give our kids some freedom to roam. The people working at the Village ranged from neutral to very nice. In other words, the worst you would encounter was a staff member going about his or her business without saying hello. The ones we DID engage were all friendly and helpful. No complaints.We went over Easter weekend and at times the property was very crowded. (One bellhop told us that the hotel was over 90% capacity.) These folks do an excellent job handling the crowds, though, and we never felt crowded or bothered by the people at all. (And we all comefrom a small town in Montana, so we would have noticed.)So, just so you don't think I am a Hilton employee, I will put a few negatives in here.First, it would have been nice if the maids changed the sheets every day or two. We're pretty sure they didn't. Think sand.Second, the Village is really up out of the action. To get to the main street for Waikiki, or the more populated portions of the beach,you will need to walk. No problem, though, because it doesn't hurt towalk off all the good food and drink!Last, and definitely not least, this place costs MONEY. Bud Light poolside? $7.50 plus tax and tip. Brunch for 9? $466.00. Beach chairs? $12.00 per day plus $26.00 for the umbrella (plus tip).I went to Walmart the first day. I bought a coffee maker and coffee for $25.00. It isn't just the price of the coffee ($3.50 for two cups), but the fact that you really don't want to walk all over for your second cup and belong. (Be warned: if the staff notices your coffee maker, they won't refill your supply of styrofoam coffee cups.)Also, at Walmart I bought 4 beach chairs for 4 bucks each and 2 boogie boards for $30.00. We left them with a family. If you're traveling there soon, look for the chairs (blue metal with rainbow cloth) and ask their owners for the 'pay it forward plan.' You might get them for nothing.We also loaded up on breakfast and sandwich items (there are refrigerators in the rooms). The $300.00 dinner each night is not such a big deal if you snack and eat other meals in the rooms.If you want to surf, skip the $90.00 surf lessons at the Village, and go down to Waikiki Center Beach where you can get them for $35.00.The Atlantis sub is good, but you're paying top dollar for what you get.You can buy a six back of beer at the on property ABC store, as well as other liquor, and drink your own on the beach. It's much cheaper and more convenient (and technically illegal, although no one said a word to us.)The Hale Koa next door has good food cheap and, if you want to feed your kids lunch, you can walk down to the first on-beach property (look for the subway sign) and they have comfort food for kids, although not cheap.I have been to Waikiki a number of times and it is clear they are trying to change Kalakaua Blvd. from a kitschy fun Hawaiian spot to Michigan Avenue of the Islands. Note to Developers: You might want to ask yourselves why the International Marketplace is still the most full.All in all, a great trip. I am happy to share more at bigskylaw@yahoo.com.Aloha.  
<Date>Apr 14, 2007

<Author>deriko
<Content>terrible service My family has traveled to Oahu a handful of times and every time we stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. Unfortunately, this last time may have been our last time staying there. The property is convenient. There are many shops and restaurants on site. The beach has become filled with debris. Just months ago, the beach was beautiful, however with the groundbreaking of their timeshare property, they have literally destroyed the beach. The staff does not understand the concept that the customer is always right. The room I checked into had 2 double beds. And on both of the beds, the sheets were dirty. I asked for the sheets to be changed. I waited 5 hours! When I complained to the front desk, they were very argumentative with me. They kept telling me that the room I had had only one bed. I can count! I was very surprised when management was rude. They didn't seem to care that there is a problem with their staff. They tried to move me to a room that runs for less than I paid. They clearly need a lesson in customer service. I did have other plans to stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village at the end of this month, but since my last stay, I have cancelled my reservations. I would highly recommend that if you are planning a trip to Oahu to avoid the Hilton Hawaiian Village.

<Author>Mabg40
<Content>I love this place We have stayed here before. 5 years ago we responded to a Hilton Vacation Club invitation and stayed in the Lagoon and Rainbow towers and we had a great time with our then 15 year old daughter.. I wanted to buy, and regret we did not buy. We love Hawaii and have been to Maui many times but our now college age daughter keeps us from going back as often as we would like.We went this past week to Oahu with my sister and her husband (who had never been to Hawaii before). We LOVED it. HHV is the only way to go in Waikiki. It has that resort feel that you need in Waikiki. It has easy access to all the historic sites and nightlife. We stayed in the the Rainbow tower and had a corner room with two lanais, both with ocean view. My sister and her husband had a partial ocean view that was quite nice, if you did not mind all the construction vehicles and noise. YES, there was noise. At one point I told my sister that whenever I heard jackhammers in the future I would think of Waikiki, and probably summon up the aromas of sunscreen and pineapple.This could have been a horrible vacation. I booked sightseeing trips through an internet site that was no longer honored. Therefore, we had some interesting adventures and some melted credit cards, they were used so frequently. (Top Ten should be considered your bottom ten, let us put it that way.) BUT, the HHV was our port in that particular storm and it held up well, construction noise and all. I have to also give tribute to the Royal Hawaiian Luau for honoring our prepaid booking, though they had received no money.Great points-the Resort feel, the views, the friendly staff, the very comfortable beds, the food was always good, too, if expensive, but hey, it's Hawaii.Negatives-construction noise, meal prices, but hey, it's HawaiiA very nice Easter break and introduction to Hawaii for my brother in law. Loved it.

<Author>Woody864
<Content>Aloha!!!! Ok, what started out seeming like what was about to become a horrible honeymoon turned out to be one FANTASTIC trip!!! This was our first time for either one of us going to Hawaii. First of all, our plane landed a little bit late on 4/1/07. I had booked a corner room in the Rainbow Tower facing Diamond Head and the beach (on the other side of the construction). I was staying on Hilton Honors Points from my father (Diamond Member) and had booked the room close to 6 months in advance. When we arrived at around 4:30pm, I was informed that I had no room available for me and my wife. Hmmm...yes, I was furious. We had traveled over 5,000 miles from South Carolina, we were tired, had no sleep, and wanted to relax. They tried to put us in another tower but we would have no ocean view. Finally, Dave, the desk manager stepped in after I requested him. Within just a short few minutes, he told me he had us all set. He also told me that my corner room would be available on Monday if we chose to take it. He confirmed that we were in the Rainbow Tower on the 24th floor but would not give anymore information. Well, I was a little be reluctant but thankful that at least we had a room for the night. Bell service took our bags up for us and when we opened the hotel door....WOW!!!! That is all I got to say. WOW!!! An amazing 2 bathroom suite with 2 separate balconies overlooking Diamond Head and the beautiful Waikiki Beach. Even the bell man was like WOW!!!  I'm going to try not to write a novel but to give the reader's digest version, I was 100% satisfied with the service. And not to mention the upgrade in the room I got. The grounds at the Hilton is amazing. I had never seen a crew keep a place so clean. From morning time when they are raking the beach, cleaning cigarette butts up, and sweeping the side walks...till evening time when tiki torches are being lit and again, side walks being swept. I never had a problem with running out of towels or any other ammenity needed in the room. I was a little bit dissapointed in the service at the restaurants. But hey, if you had to deal with several 1,000 people a day, we would all get a little bit frusrated. My wife and I did not mind the busy Hilton. We are both in Public Service and are use to a hectic life. It is hard to find piece and quiet unless you take a trip to the Spa (recommended). Just to mention a few other things here. We were lucky to be staying on HHonors. We received a complimentary breakfast every morning and for just a mere $5 upgrade a piece, we could get the FULL Breakfast bar. Which to me was outstanding. Without the HHonors, it was well over $20 a person for the buffet. OK, so yes, the food at the Village is freaking expensive. But its pretty much expensive all over Oahu. The only restaurant we found to be cheap was McDonalds...HAHA!!! Oh, and the drinks were expensive. But again, drinks are expensive all over the island. The Valet service was awesome. And we would definitely recommend renting a car. And for the honeymooners and anyone else staying on Oahu for a special occassion, make sure and let the Rental Car company know this. I was upgraded to a convertible mustang with free GPS for a price cheaper than an economy car (Paid less than $40 a day through Hertz).  Heres a list of things I would recommed:1. Stay at the Hilton; The beach is huge; Not bad snorkeling for beginners like myself; Great service; Lots to do; Everything is convienent; The list could go on!!! Just do not be confined to the Hotel!!! Ate once at the Golden Dragon for dinner (not too bad) and ordered pizza from Round Table (impressive and not too pricey). All other dinners were eaten off the hotel grounds. 2. Rent a car; Travel the island; Get lost like we did; Its fun and adventerous3. GO TO PEARL HARBOR!!!!4. Go to Hy's Steakhouse; Hands down, the best steakhouse on the island; GREAT Service; Pricey yes..haha; Just go, trust me here; And also go to Sam Choy's; Very good food and not too pricey!!!5. Snorkel6. Go to other beaches on the island; there are much more quiet beaches that are less crowded7. Get the book Oahu Revealed; Read this book, it was a life saver for Oahu; It tells you all the do and donts and tell you all the good places to eat and the places that are not so good to eat; GET THE BOOK!!!8. Go to enterainment dot com!!! Pay the $37 for the Oahu book; This coupon book saved us well close to $500 on our trip; The book pays for itself with just one dinner9. Relax in the sun on the beach; The pool was just a little bit to busy for us.10. See Randy at the beach bar and tell him that Dustin and Jenn from South Carolina sent you; He is a great bartender!!! But dont get too hooked on the Tropical Itches, great drink and very addicting...HAHA; The drink even comes with a back scratcher which you will definitely need after a few of those!!!11. GO PARADISE COVE!!! Beat Lua on the Island hands down!!! Spend the extra money and get the Royal seating front stage like we did...it was worth it..plus came with 6 drink tickets a piece which came in handy!!!12. There is sooooo much I could say but just contact me if you have any other questions.  Things I was dissapointed in:1. The Polynesian Cultural Center; It was neat and interesting but not worth the money!!! Thank God I had a coupon for buy one get one free cause I would have been upset if I had to pay $80 for the two of us2. Dissapointed in the prices on the island; Outrageous for what they charge!!! Plan on taking a good chunk of change with ya!!!3. Little bit disspaointed in Aloha spirit with some of the locals; I mean, charging $20 for a flower lei...its definitely not like what you see on TV!!! (Dont get me wrong, by far, I have never seen a group of more happier people when it comes to the locals...and that is coming from a southern boy who is used to the southern hospitality!!!)4. Little bit disspointed in the cleanliness of the island; At the Hilton, is was emmaculate; But around the island, there needs to be a little more upkeep done; Lots of homeless people in the parks, lots of graffiti, and there was a good bit of trash and debris on many of the main roads!!! I had to come to the conclusion that Honolulu and Oahu in general was very populated and was very metro....Im sure more so than the other islands (which will be visited next time Im lucky enough to go to Hawaii)5. All in all, that is about all the complaints I have. I will be posting some pictures here soon. Please contact me if anyone has any questions. Im already planning a trip back for our 5 year anniversary!!! Aloha cousins and Maholo Hawaii for making our honeymoon paradise and a dream trip!!!  
<Date>Apr 12, 2007

<Author>skylark94544
<Content>This is Paradise...LOVED IT!!!! My husband and I decided to spend our honeymoon in Hawaii and we went on the Pride of Hawaii cruise ship by NCL. We decided to spend an extra day in Oahu and stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village Beach Resort  Spa. It was beautiful. We stayed in room D1392. and the room could use some new paint on the walls, but everything was very clean. The bed was so comfortable that I wanted to bring it back home with us :) The view was spectacular. We decided on the garden view and we saw a wonderful view of the courtyards, the pools and the ocean. We could not have asked for a better view. They are doing construction at the resort but it was on the opposite end of where we stayed. The landscaping is superb and the staff is very friendly. The price is higher then I would have liked to have paid, but the view and the room was worth it. We would stay there again :) We had a wonderful time.

<Author>IowaGrandparents
<Content>Best City Hotel Ever Yes, Waikiki is city. But where else do you get a city resort with blue ocean palm lined beaches? For us it was worth it to stay in the Alii'i Tower. It was an oasis of quiet and calm in a rather bustling setting. Plenty of staff at the desk and they're pretty helpful. There is a concierge desk but we found them, frankly, pretty unhelpful. The folks at the desk were more knowledgeable and accommodating. In fact, one day I heard the concierge on duty getting advice from the desk clerk about which, if any, restaurants in the area were worth recommending.Overall, this resort may suffer a bit from the fact that Oahu is now so popular that the cost of living makes it almost prohibitive for service personnel to live there. The staff were all pleasant but sometimes a little under trained it seemed.Yet we were really pleased with the Alii'iTower. Perhaps it helped that they upgraded us to a two room suite. But this hotel within the resort does provide a relaxed setting. The pool, for instance, gives the full impression of being right on the beach -- but in reality is a floor above it and without the sand. BTW, if you're staying in Alii'i and are a Gold or Platinum member, you probably don't need to pay the extra for the Bounceback Rate unless you really have to have an omelet every day. At least when we stayed there Gold and Platinum members could have a free continental breakfast by the pool every morning and also use the coupon toward the price of a complete breakfast on those days you would want it. And if you want a really good (and much cheaper) hamburger type menu, there's a new Cheeseburger in Paradise outlet just two blocks away (although we found the walk to the original at the other end of Waikiki to be worth it.)You also might want to skip the thought of using the cab service touted on their website to come from the airport. Unless you actually hire the upgraded limo service, all you get is a cab that meters you the same as every other cab you can get right at the airport -- and we had to wait half an hour for the hotel dispatched cab to arrive.Overall, this was a great way to begin our Hawaiian vacation with five days of decompression before heading to the Big Island.  
<Date>Apr 10, 2007

<Author>biztravelteam
<Content>Very disappointing Looking back on our experience at this hotel, I have a difficult time finding positive things to say. The food was horrible, the facility was in need of repair every where we looked, it was very overpriced and the staff were very unhelpful. There were several mistakes made by the hotel, and we never once received an apology; only an argument. Instead of the 'customer is always right' attitude, there was defensiveness the moment we presented an issue. If we were the type of customers that attacked, I would understand. However, we are often overly-kind; not wanting to ever raise a fuss. However, when we would question this hotel about a problem (an erroneous charge on our bill amongst other things), they would only argue with us as to why they couldn't possibly have made a mistake (when, in fact, they did). We had to take up our billing issue with management who also started the conversation by interrupting and arguing with us. Even when we proved our case, no one ever apologized. There are plenty of wonderful hotels in Oahu. Avoid this one!  
<Date>Apr 7, 2007

<Author>kuri
<Content>Hilton:The only resort like in Hawaii, great for family This is it! We stayed in Alii Tower and we, include my kids (10 and 12) loved it! This is the only resort like hotel in Honolulu. The hotel is very specious throught the property, and my kids like these little zoo like place (penguin, framingo, ducks and much more) wide open and able to touch them. Upon on arrival, we were taken directly to our room by a personal receptionist. He gave us a breif orientation of the hotel. Then there was fruit tray, ice was already in the room. The maid service comes at least twice daily. Unlike any other hotels on Waikiki beach, the beach in front of Hilton is very large and never get into situation when you would fight for a space. We booked through Amex Platinum card, which comes with room upgrade, free breakfast daily, one free lunch in addition to daily evening odvre that Hilton offers to all Alii Tower guests. Coming from east coast and with time difference, the odvre actually served as our dinner so we saved a lot on meal expenses. The only downside to this hotel is a little away from the shopping area (10 minute walk), which was fine as I like quieter over convinience. There is ABC store in the hotel and you can get all the necessities there. We were spoiled with the exceptional services that we never experienced in any other hotels before, we will come back to Hilton next time.  
<Date>Apr 7, 2007

<Author>TennisDiva
<Content>Paradise Found!!!!!!! I can't say enough on how our family LOVED this property! It was a bit pricey BUT when you go on vacation to escape everyday life it is worth it! We stayed in the Ali'i Tower of HHV. It was everything Frommer recommended, trip advisor member reviews and more!!!!!!!!! We loved our stay so much we purchased a timeshare at Hilton Hawaiian Village. The plans for vacation owners at the HHV property is exciting...members only pool (largest in the state), water slides, brand new lagoon access,...We have young children so the HHV property is a perfect fit for our needs. Calm tides at the beach, kid pool, variety of restaurants, ABC store, family friendly environment, babysitting (Keiki club for kids 5-12 yrs old),....Our daughter spent an afternoon in the Keiki club and loved it. Our son is only three so he will be able to do the Keiki club on our next trip there! There is so much to say about our trip I can't even begin to put into words how much of a memorable vacation this was. I have been to Maui and Oahu 4 times and it is even more beautiful than I remember. We liked visiting the islands when the whales and dolphins can be seen. Our vacation was March 27, 2007-April 2, 2007. We saw many whales at the beach just past Hanauma Bay. There are many activites to do on Oahu. We took a surfing lesson from the instructors at the HHV. -Went on the Submarine Tour-Snorkeled Hanauma Bay (awesome especially if you get there when they open at 8am b/c it gets busy!)-Toured the Dole Plantation (took the train ride)-Paradise Cove Luau (food was not that great  show was okay...we didn't like having to ride the bus even though our tour guide/waitress was hilarious  made the ride fun! It's just a long time for young kids 3:50pm-10:30pm)-Hung out at Sandy Beach  Three Tables Beach (spectacular)-Went to the Costco right before Hanauma Bay (had the cheapest lunch there of the trip :) Bought bottled water, beach chairs, booster seat for the rental car, $36 bathing suit since all of my Spiegal order didn't arrive before we left, snacks,...P.S. Costco carries traditional Hawaiian jewelry aka bangle bracelets for alot less than the jewelry stores!!!!!!!!!!!-Went to Walmart near Ala Moana shopping center for essentials and Hawaiian gifts-the island favorite candies-Went to the Verizon Store to get my husband a new phone because it got wet in the beach bag and killed it....the manager was pretty nice and gave me a good upgrade after I bargained with her.There is still alot of things we want to go back and do but the week FLEW by!!!!!!!!!! We would have liked to go to the Shorebird  Dukes restaurants b/c we heard excellent reviews from fellow hotel guests. We wanted to go to Sea Life Park and swim with the dolphins. P.S. We booked our hotel directly through HIlton Hawaiian Village and used our AAA membership. Our rate was $323 for an OCEANVIEW room. Ask for a OCEANFRONT room if you stay in the Ali'i Tower. I didn't know that when we checked in and they are the same price. Our view was good but not as GREAT as the OCEANFRONT rooms.We booked our rental car on Priceline and bid $29 on an SUV and it was accepted. We got a new Chevy Trailblazer from AVIS and we were very happy with that. Even though VALET parking at HHV is $25 a day!!!!! Ouch! We loved having a car and thought is was well worth it and their valet attendants do an EXCELLENT job. Besides self parking was $20 a day...not much difference in price so we said what is another $5 a day!!!!Our flight we booked directly through United Airlines because their major HUB is Denver so we got better flight selections and rates. We had a direct flight to Honolulu from Denver and on the return flight we went through LAX. Our roundtrip fare was $565 a person because we left on a Tuesday and returned on a Tuesday--a cheaper day to fly!If you have any questions, feel free to drop us an email!!! Mahalo

<Author>panwestern
<Content>Hilton best hotel on beach Enjoyable hotel in the best location for families in honolulu. We booked via AAA as we received a better rate then any other web service. Paid 260 per night ( no breaky ) got adjoining rooms as we rented 2 rooms. ( suites were way over priced in this property )We choose the Alli tower based on reviews here. Really dont think the Alii was worth the extra money a 450 sq ft room was better then the 250 sq in some of the other towers, but location wise i would have picked the diamond tower.Our rooms was garden view initially as my preference ( especially with non refundable rate ) is to try and get an upgrade with or without payment after i check out the hotel.We had garden view with a view of the ocean at an angle. Room was clean, well appointed, staff was great and friendlly.Honolulu is like tokyo, full of Japenese (as is the hotel) which is very denselly packed by buildings and people. If you don't like crowds, don't try honolulu. We are in Maui (earlly april) and the diffrence is staggering. Japenese generally like quality and efficiency and you can understand why they feel comfortable in honolulu.Most of the hotels are on busy roads or away from the beach and you could see the families lugging chairs, beach toys and kids on daily pilgrimages to the very very overcrowded beaches.Yes folks we are talking wall to wall people here.I would reccomend the Hilton as a true resort, with a very much less crowded beach, right at the property line.I would make sure to stay away from roads and ESPECIALLY service lanes. Otherwise you will be accosted by the NOISE of the Hawaiin national bird. ( back-up beepers from delivery trucks ) You can hear these beepers from 4:30 am on in honolulu. Especially in the denser areas of honolulu or on the service lane of the Alii tower. In fairness the noise comes from everwhere ( echoes, concrete jungle ) especially the Hale Kole?? Military hotel next to the Hilton.Yes food and drinks are expensive at this property, but we have paid much more.Overall after walking the beach and looking at the 4 other beachfront hotels, i was extremelly happy with the Hilton.Far enough away, with nice pools and a resort feel, yet within easy walking distance of everything honolulu has to offer.  
<Date>Apr 2, 2007

<Author>lolanilio
<Content>Nice hotel too far away from downtown I live on the Big Island and went to Oahu for a few days on vacation. This hotel is ok, the rooms are really nice but it is so far away from downtown Waikiki that it became a pain. We stayed in the Rainbow tower with an Ocean view. The room was a suit and was huge! It had two full bath rooms a sofa sleeper, king bed, dinning table, and two balconies. I really loved the room!This hotel has great wildlife including penguins and pink flamingos along with lots of fish. The pool was a little small but my 1 year old enjoyed it. The sand in front of the hotel is not as nice as that further down Waikiki but it is all right. We only tried out a few of the hotel restaurants. The beach side cafe was nice but expensive for lunch. We also ate at the Rainbow Lanai which was awful. The decor looked like it was out of the 80's and food was bad. I think there was a seafood buffet the night we were there and it smelled awful, none of us had the buffet. I can't remember the name of the place we ate breakfast but they had an ok buffet.The Hilton has a huge shopping area which, for some, may make up for being away from downtown.My biggest issue, as I mentioned, is the difficulty getting downtown. The Hilton sits at the very end of Waikiki and I don't think is technically on Waikiki. But the point is that after you have eaten at all of the Hilton's restaurants it is a 15 min bus ride to other restaurants and with screaming hunger children that is a ways to go. There is a free trolley to the Galleria but it just seemed like such a hassle. I would rather stay at Royal Hawaiian or the Sheraton and be just down the street from everything.  
<Date>Mar 26, 2007

<Author>roger39
<Content>Big and brash-but sometimes even beautiful The Americans really are masters of the large hotel universe. Not for nothing does Las Vegas have 7 of the10 largest hotels in the world-and the Hilton Hawaiian Village, with its over 3000 rooms , is by far the largest hotel in Waikiki.Three things are essential to running a really large hotel successfully. Superb efficiency and systems. We have stayed at this Hilton 4 times over the last two years .It really runs smoothly, whatever the weather and however many tourists throng the complex. Everything works and ,if you have reason to call down for anything, the staff normally come quickly. The check in lines move reasonably fast and the penguins in the fish ponds are happy to perform for the kids.Secondly a massive hotel like this has to appeal to all sorts of people. A small boutique hotel can be targeted exactly at a niche market of potential guests. A very large hotel has to appeal to everyone. So they will have a massive range of rooms. So in a hotel of this size and complexity it is useless to talk about room sizes or types There will just be too many.. All you can say is that even the worst and cheapest room will still be a Hilton double- and the best room will probably rival anything in Waikiki- and most rooms will be somewhere in between. And the hotel has to have a wide range of restaurants running from fast food type burgers at one extreme to Hilton style haute cuisine on the other .The Hilton has 18 food outlets including those in the main towers and the attached shopping arcade.Thirdly a very large hotel, if it is to make money, has to attract large organised groups, whether they are tour groups, conference attendees, or those just enjoying corporate junkets. This Hilton, whenever we have been there, has always had plenty of guests sporting various kinds of labels round their necks and / or pinned to their breasts clearly not shy to announce their identities to the world .The Hilton advertises itself as being on the beach. But if you are in the Tapa or Kalia towers then you would probably be physically closer to the beach if you were staying in hotels not actually beach side like the Embassy Suites or the Waikiki Parc. Location wise then it may indeed be on the seas shore but it is not that close to the centre. It is really a bit out of the way , right at the end of Waikiki beach next to the Alii Wai yacht harbour. Not nearly so handy for downtown as its competitors the Sheratons and the Hyatt. But Waikiki is so compact, everything is still within walking distance.Land is of course highly expensive in Waikiki . So all the hotels are high rise and most of the Hilton Towers are over 30 floors. Few of the hotels will have any kind of garden-but the Hilton does its best with cleverly planted trees and shrubs. And none of the hotels can afford to have a massive swimming pool .But the Hilton , as befits its status as the largest hotel, also boasts the largest pool .This is still on the small side if the hotel is full. But who wants a pool anyway if the beautiful Pacific is just a few steps away? And anyway, if you don鈥檛 mind swimming in the shade, there is another smaller pool by the Tapas towers.The Hilton鈥檚 five major Towers do differ somewhat. The Alii tower,( which we have yet to be invited to grace with our presence) has its own swimming pool and private entrance complete with frock coated porter at the door to keep the ordinary public out,.. The Rainbow tower has great views but is showing its age a bit. In the Tapa tower the higher floor rooms also have good views, and the Kailua tower , the furthest from the beach and , I hesitate to say, shared with time sharing condos, is probably the cheapest. Most of the time sharers however are concentrated in the fifth building the Lagoon tower with their own pool etc .But it is of course open for them to partake also in any of the main hotels amenities .And as always in Waikiki, although it may not be yet quite as bad as Vegas , there is building going on everywhere. So, be warned, by the time you read this review, it may be out of date.  
<Date>Mar 24, 2007

<Author>Roblaw
<Content>Mostly good Ok, to start with, my Wife and I are not the people you see posting that complain about every little thing.. we always have fun and enjoy a holiday and are very much into making lemonade from lemons.. so, with that in mind, I'll give my two cents worth.The HHV is a beautiful hotel complex, has a lovely beach, and some nice restaurants.. we really enjoyed the Deli, the sandwiches, while not cheap, are excellent, and the breakfast there was really good as well. Japanese restaurant was not bad - try the soft-shell crab tempura.. the pizza from the pizza joint was also great - ate it on the beach after dark.. the ice cream shop was also really good (but over-priced). The Friday night fireworks are excellent, and most enjoyable from the beach.. and for a place where everything seems over-priced, the ABC store on premises is very handy and very low-priced for snacks, beach towels, etc.. we were there every day for something..The cons - which in no way created any significant impact on our trip: - they advertise a honeymoon upgrade - which they didn't deliver on - so, while the room was great (partial ocean view, Tapa Tower) - best to assume you won't get the upgrade and not be dissappointed;- they sell the hotel to conventions on weekends, who pretty much overtake the resort.. both weekends we were there (two weeks) they had large conventions and roped off the superpool area for their benefit.. again, we spent almost all our water time in the ocean, so it wasn't a big deal, but be ware - the weekends are busy, crowded and you're not likely going to access the superpool after 6:00pm;- the hotel is a little bit isolated from the waikiki main downtown area, and it's a bit of a trek to walk to the centre of things (though that can also be a plus).. and walking off all the food and drink we had was not at all a bad idea..- parking is somewhat expensive, and they did overcharge us - two extra days beyond what we asked for..All in all, I would give HHV an 8/10 - you certainly will not be unhappy with the rooms or the beach area - and the little reef off the beach actually has some not bad snorkeling for fun on the ocean side of the reef.. though nothing like Hanauma or Makaha..  
<Date>Mar 21, 2007

<Author>NAVYCHASE
<Content>The hidden Jewel of Oahu, Love this Hotel! Our trip to Hawaii was 7 nights. We booked 5 nights at the popular Royal Hawaiian Hotel (we only stayed there 5 nights because the rate was so high but wanted to experience it because of all the great things we had heard and read about it). The other 2 nights we booked at the Hilton Hawaiian Village as Hilton Honors Gold members. We wish now that it had been the entire 7 nights at the Hilton Hawaiian Village! This hotel is beautiful and the staff and service are some of the BEST we have ever experienced! The hotel grounds are beautiful and very well kept. The pool areas (more than one!) are spacious clean and relaxing. The whole atmosphere at Hilton Hawaiian Village complex is OUTSTANDING! We will without a doubt never stay anywhere in Ohau/Honolulu but HERE!!!!!!!!! The Royal Hawaiian can not compare with the Hilton Hawaiian Village in my opinion!

<Author>farawaymum
<Content>Something for everyone Spent 9 nights here from 2 March. Booked the Alli tower and it was wonderful. Room had 2 double beds and was spacious with an good bathroom and dressing area- this meant 2 separate vanities- a great bonus for a mother- daughter combination. Service in this tower is superior-the pool is private for use of guests of this building only, it had a nice feel. Evening canapes were complimentary and quite good - choice of 2 hot finger foods plus a more healthy offering of dips and vegetables, cheese and biscuits.Turndown service with chocolates and evening room refresh made us feel very special. Tons of complimentary tea, coffee , water also provided.As a gold honors there was a complimentary continental breakfast- nothing fancy but more than adequate and a good upgrade deal was available if you wanted the hot breakfast. Being Hawaii the tropical fruit was fresh and sweet. We ate in some of the on site restauants and all very acceptable- expensive but in a resort like this not surprising.There is a 24 hr diner called Wailana across the road- try it- cheap and a chance to see local characters.

<Author>utqiagvik
<Content>Loud, Crowded, and Greedy OK, how is this for starters: You are generously allowed to brew ONE pouch of coffee everyday for free ... use any more of the coffee pouches and there will be a $3.75 charge to your room! If you touch one of the tea bags the charge is $2.50, and each TINY bottle of water is $3.00. Tell me someting, when the room rate starts at $299/night at the lowest of low seasons and can rise as high as $775, is this really necessary? Meanwhile, as some previous reviews have noted, staying here is NO restful island vacation. Come here if you want big city noise, lights, crowds, and traffic. This hotel (which is made up of several high rise towers interspersed with woefully tiny pools and small patches of green areas) has been accurately described by an earlier reviewer as Manhattan with a couple of palm trees. I stayed on the 26th floor at the tower closest to the ocean and when I stepped out onto the balcony all I could hear was traffic and police sirens and car alarms and airplanes ... get the picture? Anyhow, I don't think after this month's trip I'll ever return to this particular property again ... the world has too many beautiful places for me to want to waste my time here any more.  
<Date>Mar 14, 2007

<Author>tamstrat
<Content>Very nice resort experience My husband and I try to get to Hawaii at least once a year and we had not been to Oahu for awhile and decided to try the Hilton Hawaiian Village Resort. It is a huge sprawling complex of different towers that have (I'm told) around 3400 rooms. So this is not some little Mom  Pop hotel. We were booked into the Rainbow tower with an oceanview with a king sized bed. However, the desk clerk told me when checking in that the room had a decent view but was overlooking all the construction going on and asked if we would mind moving to an ocean/Diamondhead view with double beds instead of a king sized bed. We agreed and were very happy. The view was awesome. We could see the ocean, Diamondhead, the beach, etc. This resort has numerous restaurants and shops all throughout the resort. Too many to name or attempt to name here. I looked at prices and felt many were high (of course everything is expensive in Hawaii) so we did not eat on property except for one morning we had breakfast in the New York Deli there. It was good and the portions huge. We did not finish there was so much food!!! I felt considering how much food was given the price was reasonable.There are many high end retail stores in the resort and also an ABC Store (for those of you not having been to Hawaii, these small stores are scattered throughout Hawaii and offer food, drink, medication, tee-shirts, souvenirs, etc at reasonable prices) which was very nice to have there. You can purchase your own beer, soda pop, candy, chips etc. So that was nice to have onsite. If one wanted to youwould never have to leave the resort as restaurants, shopping, swimming, the beach is all right there. There are several pools, bars, etc. scattered throughout the property. My husband and I are not ones to lie in the sun next to a swimming pool, but for those who want to do that, the pools looked clean and well maintained. Of course where ever there is a swimming pool, there are lots of kids. While I don't have small children, the resort seemed family friendly.They have a spa onsite and I went one evening and had a massage which was excellent. The spa was beautifully appointed and very relaxing. I recommend if you are staying there and have the time to work in a spa treatment. I think you will find it worth it.The staff at this resort were all very nice and helpful to my husband and I. We enjoyed our stay here very much and hope to go again. Again, the only thing I would caution against is if you want to go to Hawaii to get away from people, this would not be the place for you. It is a very busy, popular resort.  
<Date>Mar 13, 2007

<Author>Taipei-JMS
<Content>Not For Young Couples On A Romantic Vacation I was in Hawaii for 2 weeks - went to Oahu, Maui and Kona. In Oahu, I stayed at the Halekulani and the Hilton Hawaiian Village. First, my fiancee and I are both 26 - we do not have kids, and this is a family resort. Second, if you go, stay at the Rainbow Tower, as this tower has the best view of the ocean.We had a corner deluxe ocean view room on the 20th floor and it was very nice. Rooms are old, water is not complimentary after the first two bottles and the bathrooms are old as well. If it were not for the view, I would have given this hotel 1 star.Village restaurants were good, especially the japanese cuisine. I found the beach to be very crowded and the pool as well. This hotel was not very relaxing.If you have family, probably nice to go here with the wide range of towers and family oriented atmosphere. Not for young couples
