<Author>Kat24Can
<Content>Bad start, great finish If you are picky about your hotel room, read this! We booked our room at the hilton through a tour company. I chose this resort because I wanted the resort feel and didn't want to stay in the midst of highrises and traffic. Saying that, we booked a run of the house room, which meant we werent gauranteed to be in a certain tower. However, we were slated to have a garden view room. After researching the different towers on the property, I called both the Hilton central reservation line and the hotel directly and requested the Alli tower or the Rainbow tower, since all of the reviews I read listed those two towers as the best. I did say though, that the only thing that really mattered to me was that we had a view of the pool or a garden -- anything troical feeling; I actually didn't care if we were even able to see the ocean as long as I wasnt overlooking the City or the busy road that runs behind the hilton. So, upon arriving at the hotel at 1:00 a.m. with two kids and a 13 hour travel day behind us, I went to check us in, expecting, at the very least, a room overlooking a palm tree. I was informed that we had been upgraded to a partial ocean view room (great, I thought) in the Tapa tower. When I asked to see where our room was on the map, it was at the back of the tower overlooking, you guessed it, the super busy road. Furthermore, I asked her how that was considered a partial ocean view when the ocean was on the opposite side of the building. (to be fair, if you leaned over the balcony and twisted your head as far as it could go, you could see a sliver of the ocean). Anyway, I asked if we could have a different room. I said that I didnt care about the partial ocean view and that I really was fine with something overlooking the garden or the pool or Anything green and not noisy. After dissapearing into the back office for 10 minutes to talk to a manager, she came back insisting that there was not a single other room in the hotel (of 3400 rooms I should point out) that was free. I pressed the point, and finally she told me that we could have another room in the same tower (overlooking another road) but that it would be an extra $60.00 a night since it had one king and not two doubles! I said no and she said I could check back in the morning. She seemed very put out and wasnt friendly at all. We went to the room and while it was very spacious, it was very noisy. Even though we were on the 21st floor, the beeping of delivery trucks woke me up at 6:00 a.m. the next morning. Needless to say, I was back at the desk the next morning. Another girl again dissapeared into the back for 15 minutes and came back saying that my request was in but they couldent gaurantee a move. I have to say I was a little shocked at there resistance considering how often I read that people were automatically upgraded for free. Also, I didnt think my request was unreasonable since they had upgraded me to a partial ocean view and I was asking them to downgrade me to a garden view! Anyway, I was told to come back at 2 in the afternoon. I went back at noon and this time stood in the Hilton honors line (we had signed up before we left) and made sure that I spoke to a Male ( I was tired of the unhelpful ladies that were working there). Within 3 minutes he said that I we could move to the diamond head tower, overlooking the pool. We started talking and I inquired about how one goes about getting into the Alli tower and he said that he would let us upgrade to that tower for only $40.00 extra a night. I thought this was more than worth it since you get free appetizers every night in that tower, plus access to your own pool and hottub. It was a great choice! The room was great. very spacious. He knew we had two kids and that I wanted to be by the pool so he found a room (202) that was actually on the deck of the pool. You just had to go up three steps and you were there. We lived by the pool , and I have to say that it was great not having to fight the crowds in the other pools. Plus, the hot tub was great, with a fantastic view of the ocean. The grounds of the resort are great and whenever we left and headed into the crazy traffic I couldent wait to get back to the resort. Also, the beach in front of the hilton is less busy and bigger thatn other areas of the beach. We found the restaurants to be expensive (ie-$14.00 for a burger with no fries and $3.50 for a small glass of pop with NO refill) but splurged a few times. Try the Shorebird restaurant at the Outrigger down the beach for a great buffet breakfast and a good lunch menu at reasonable prices. We spent a small fortune at the ABC store buying stuff for breakfast, alcohol, sunscreen etc. but the prices were good. We spent a day at Sandy beach (not good for small kids). We were actually told by the lifegaurd that we should not stay there because the waves were so hard, but we loved it. We were just careful not to go in very far because I could see how it is dangerous. Also, we took the outrigger catamaran's sailboat tour and that was great. We saw some whales and snorkelled with sea turtles (the highlight of my trip!). Overall, we ended up loving the hotel, but if we do go back , I would want to book a gauranteed spot in the Alli tower. Stay here if you can!! If you have any questions about the resort or the rooms, email me at jandkgun@telus.net..  
<Date>Mar 7, 2007

<Author>Agrodge
<Content>Wow! Stayed here with a group for a business trip and all I can say is, wow! The hotel is clean, the staff professional and friendly, the location can not be beat, and the rooms were outstanding!! I can't believe it's ranked as low as it is (especially behind the Aqua Plams!!!) Do yourself a favor, spend the extra money, and stay at a hotel designed to give you the best Hawaiian vacation. (By the way, you walk out of the Hilton (the Rainbow Tower) and right onto the beach...you can't do that from some of the others in the top ten.)

<Author>scorpio65
<Content>Paradise! Family from upstate NY recently stayed at this hotel and loved it. Staff was friendly and extremely helpful. Kings jubiliee on Friday night is worth the $12/person. Hotel was clean with new furnishings (Diamond Head Tower) Pools were lovely. This hotel has its own shopping village, which was VERY expensive. Hotel is surrounded by upscale designer stores. Hotel restaurants were very pricey also, and I wouldn't waste my time or money going to them again. Wailana Coffee House is across the street and had more reasonable prices...my kids called it the Hawaiian Friendly's. Ate there every morning. Ate lunch/supper at other restaurants within walking distance of hotel again for more reasonable prices. Would stay at this hotel again, but probably would visit a different island next time for some variety.

<Author>treborwf
<Content>Ruined I've used 'Ruined' as the title for this review as that is what this place has done for the other hotels - I could only go back to Hilton.Spent five nights for my honeymoon back in January 2006  can honestly say it was the best hotel I've stayed at.Hilton Gold member so was upgraded to a sea view in the Rainbow tower and what a view.Apart from a few very minor issues like confusion on the part of the waiter about a dinner deal that was advertised in the room and limited construction noise everything else went wonderfully. (We got the meal that was advertised and the hotel moved us to an even beter room!).The village really is like a village, almost no need to venture from the complex  the beach area is so spacious unlike further down the beach where the majority of the hotels are and it seems like a fight to get any space.Its not cheap but without doubt worth every penny and there are cheaper options to buy goods like an ABC store.Will definitely go back.

<Author>tunasf
<Content>Buyer beware of store rip off -- Phillip Rickard I have no substantive beef with the Hilton per se, but I want all tourists who stay there to be aware of the shops in the hotel mall area. My husband travels to Honolulu at least monthly and usually stays at the Hilton when doing business. Shortly before Christmas, he thought he would do some shopping at Phillip Rickard. When he bought several rather pricey pieces of jewelry, he asked about return policy and was told he could not get a refund but could exchange. The receipt for purchase he was given stated no refund/exchange only. When, a month later he returned to exchange two items, not only was he told he could not exchange them but there would also be a 15% restocking fee. There was no one in authority at the store, but Angie somewhere else finally relented and let him exchange after much back and forth banter, but charged more for the exact same items in white rather than yellow gold AND insisted on this exhorbitant restocking fee which is no where on the sales receipt or was it posted in the store. We all know that these stores sell merchandise at top dollar, but these hidden costs are just a slap in the face to customers/tourists. Do not under any circumstances shop at this store. They don't gift wrap, they just rip you off.  
<Date>Feb 27, 2007

<Author>DltnTrio
<Content>Great Hotel! We loved the Hilton Hawaiian Village. We stayed in the Tapa Tower and were upgraded to an Ocean View room upon check-in. Everybody was friendly and helpful. Our rooms were nice. We traveled with 3 families and children ages 6 weeks through 13 years old. The kid's loved the place and the weekend entertainment. This hotel has everything you need. If you choose to, you would never need to leave the resort. It is walking distance to the International Marketplace and Waikiki famed restaurants. We walked to town everyday for shopping and dining. Oahu has so much to see - venture out to the North Shore and Huaname Bay. The hotel buffet breakfast was adequate, Benihana's was excellent, but we were disappointed with the the poolside dining - food was not very good or of any quality, but the drinks were good.We plan to go back again. We also love the Hilton Waikoloa Village on the Big Island.Eatieries - Try the Shorebird Buffet (in the Outrigger Waikiki), and for the best breakfast in town (and cheapest) try the Coffee House across from the Hilton. Also, go to Dukes of Waikiki for a good seafood dinner.

<Author>peck6427
<Content>We'll be back!! We just returned from our 2nd stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village and loved it agin! Our room was ocean front in the Rainbow Tower with a Diamond Head view. Stunning, awsome view!!We slept with the sliding door open every night because the sound of the waves lulled us to sleep. Our room had no hint of smoke and was clean and fresh. Not huge, but the view and sound of the ocean was why we asked for the upgrade to ocean front. This is one reason we remain a Gold member of Hilton Honuors.......the upgrade is free!!!! Both trips we've asked for and rec'd a room at the Rainbow tower. Keep in mind that this year we were there the week of the Pro Bowl and rooms were hard to come by even for guests paying over $500/night. But, we got the room anyway. We were there using one of the Hilton Honors rewards. With our stay we rec'd a free contiental breakfast each morning at one of three locations. We ate at the Rainbow Lanai and loved it. This restuarant is located right at the edge of the beach and the atmosphere is great. They offer to go boxes which we used a couple of times and took our breakfast out on the beach. Fresh pineapple....very fresh, Mango and other choices plus pastries and meats were more than enough. We could have upgraded for a few bucks and had a full cooked to order breakfast, which looked fantastic, but were so happy with the contiental that we just saved the money.The beach on the Hilton property is the widest in Wikiki and although maybe a litter tamer than some down the beach a mile or so it really has a Hawaiian feel to it. There is a (almost dead) reef only 25 yards out and to our surprise had alot of marine life on it. Even an eel! Not bad for novice and experienced snorklers.The beach is so wide that you can find a spot even getting there in mid afternoon. Not so down the beach a few hotels........elbow to elbow.The big pool filled up pretty early, but they have pool side service and they keep the pool temp. really cold so it very refreshing.There are ALOT of shops on property from the ABC store (if you don't know what this is imagine 7-11 with a palm tree and fresh pineapple) to mega expensive fashion stores.There are about as many resturants as shops. Bali by the Sea is very nice, The Rainbow Lanai has a very good seafood buffet on Saturdays and a Hawaiian one on Fridays. The food at Sergios was outstanding. There is a pool side bar and a hotdog place under the Rainbow tower right on the beach.Yes there is construction going on so Don't get a room on the harbor side of the Rainbow tower. Keep in mind that parking is $20/day and you can get around using the trolley for only $2/person per trip. We have found the Hilton employees very friendly and helpful both of our stays. Be nice and they will be nice back. I saw some VERY demanding/rude guests and I have to imagine I'd be alittle cranky too if someone was that high and mighty.There are many, many hotels to stay in on this beach but we'd ask....why stay anywhere else? Everything we like is at this hotel!!!!! So far the Hilton is batting a thousand.  
<Date>Feb 18, 2007

<Author>suzyav8trix
<Content>I Had a Free Room Two things, first.One, I'm picky.Two, this stay was free for me as a friend was attending a conference and her husband could not join her -- I was asked if I'd like to come along and well, I work for an airline and get nearly free airfare and so, what could I say? I went.So, checking in was a breeze -- huge, open air lobby with plenty of check-in stations and wonderful local girl (sorry, don't remember her name) helping us. The friend I was staying with is a Hilton Gold, so I made a big deal of that to the agent -- to be sure we got a good room as this was also my first trip to HNL. And we did.My friend went to park the car and I went to our room on the 34th floor of the 35 floor of the Tapa tower. The room was made up, but the previous guest's bill was still on the floor on the other side of the door when I walked in... The room smelled like stale cigarette smoke...but I opened the lania door and got a load of that incredible view Diamond Head and the ocean (odd numbered rooms face Diamond Head), and well, I still felt it necessary to call and see if any other room, as nice, was available as both of us are non-smokers. I had also noticed that there were cigarette ashes on the table by the chair by the lanai door -- it appeared that the table had not been wiped off, even. In the meantime, the bellman brings our luggage, while I'm on the phone getting another room and we get switched to 1 floor below, same side of the building. Well, that room stunk like smoke, too. And it just didn't seem as nice, so we moved back up to the original room. They were supposed to send house-keeping up to clean off the table and spray some air freshener -- that never happened. In fact, we were there 4 nights and that table never got wiped clean the entire time we were there. ALL hotel rooms in Honolulu/Waikiki are supposed to be non-smoking, now -- but is that possible with all the guests that still do smoke? Especially tourists -- I mean, how can the HHV, seriously control whether or not someone smokes in one of their 2860 rooms? They certainly do not make you sign a waiver when you check in that says if you do, you have to pay $100 for the fumigation, or anything like that -- that many hotels do these days, at least on the mainland.Should of checked before bedtime (very, very late) -- but the sheets and bed linens reeked of smoke too. We were both too tired to do anything about it and made do. Keep in mind that these are Hilton heavenly beds (I think that's what they call them) and they use down comforters in white, high thread-count duvets. With the window open, and temps dropping down into the mid-60's, I found it much, much too hot to sleep under the thick duvet. And there is no top sheet to slip under. I used my sarong as a sheet and we turned the air on high and cold the next 3 nights. With the window open, there was a lot of noise from below, too. All was acceptable except for the back-up beeep, beeep, beeep of delivery vehicles or ???? I began using ear plugs on nights like these several trips ago and found them to be of great use, again, in this case. Also, the air-conditioning, when on high, was quite noisy and the ear-plugs came in handy (best, most comfortable, in my opinion, are the orange foam ones made by 3M, model 1100. Cheap, too)Next morning, we made sure to have house-keeping change the bed linens -- AHHH, wonderfully fresh that next night...So, as Hilton gold and guest, we received free continental breakfast each morning, too, available at 3 restaurants -- Tapa cafe, Tropic beach cafe, or Rainbow lanai. My friend enjoyed her very, very early breakfasts at the Tapa cafe, while I did 2 days at the Tropics beach cafe and found it to be quite nice -- styrofoam coffee cups that you can refill on your way out and take a coffee to go at no extra charge was a real plus! Food was typical cold buffet -- rolls, toast, bagels, cereal, milk, juice, yogurt, fresh fruit. All was fresh and very good. By the 3rd morning, I wanted eggs, though, and had heard we could upgrade to the hot buffet at the Rainbow lanai for $5. Wonderful! Made to order omelets, pancakes with coconut syrup, meats, etc, etc, etc, as well as all the cold choices and more. Although, I thought the fresh pineapple slices at the Rainbow lania weren't as fresh at the tropics cafe. Both of us had breakfast there on our last day, along with several other of her conference attendees. Come to find out, the hot buffet went for more than $20 a person and the cold was about $13 (or more?) per person. Wow. If I was paying for it, I would not have been eating there...Did not have any other meals or drinks at the HHV. They have an ABC store right on premises (rainbow shops area) and the Whaler's cove general store on the side by the Al'ili tower and Diamond head towers is an ABC in disguise, with all the same prices and much of the same stuff.Pools were gorgeous -- the pool near the Tapa tower, while kind of exposed to all passers by, was actually more calm and quiet than the great pool where there were a lot of children. Although there was no jacuzzi/hot tub anywhere we could find... We heard the Kalia tower pool has a jacuzzi/hot tub -- but you had to be using the over-priced Madera spa in order to use it.I say overpriced Madera spa because a 50 minute massage is advertised at $135 -- but that's not including the 4% tax and 18% sur charge, which is supposed to include the gratuity and brings the total to $164.70. I have yet to meet ANY masseuse worth that price. Happily, we discoverd the Hale Koa hotel, right next door. This is a military hotel; you must be active or retired U.S. military to stay there. But, you can call them and book a massage with them -- you do not have to be military! All they had available was 30 minutes -- for $35 -- in a cabana by the pool. My only complaint was that it was not long enough! If I had known sooner, I would've booked an hour for $65 or 90-minutes -- yes, 90 blissful minutes -- for $85! Ok, so I didn't get a fancy robe and slippers, but the young lady concentrated on my back, neck, and shoulders -- just as I had asked -- and I walked out of there feeling wonderful and well, smug, having saved myself at least $100 compared to the HHV prices! Can't say if the HHV nickle and dimed us for anything -- we did not use the coffee maker or drink anything, not even the bottled water, in the room. Finding out that we had gotten a special rate of $149 a night, and both of us had free breakfasts -- despite all the problems with the smoke-smelling room(s) -- I have to admit it was a pretty good deal for Waikiki. The HHV beach location is wonderful, and while it is at the end of the beach, nothing is too far of a walk. The public bus is only $2 if your feet do get tired, and believe it or not, we found taxis to be quite the bargain, actually - quicker than the bus and only $3-5 each, for 2, depending on where you're going along Waikiki beach area...Would I stay at the HHV again? Maybe. I would be more assertive if I got a wonderful room and had the smokey problem again, however. And, I have to be honest with my readers -- if you're still with me this far. Honolulu/Waikiki is not my style of vacation. So my attitude towards the Hilton Hawaiian Village is probably going to reflect that a bit. It's a huge resort, in a big town (kind of like a Las Vegas with a beach). For the right price, if this is your style of vacation -- huge resort, lots of restaurants to choose from, multiple pools and things for the kids to do, shops, and more shops -- the HHV is probably going to be great for you. If you're looking for peace, quiet, relaxation, lounging, privacy -- you should probably look elsewhere. You can see from my other reviews that I much prefer Kauai, and even Maui, over Honolulu. But, that is not the fault of the HHV. P.S. You can also use the Hale Koa bar -- it's down by the beach and pool, there. Their drinks are less expensive, they don't skimp on the pours, and they make a mighty fine Mai Tai!

<Author>chipper4
<Content>Hilton Hawaiian Village tips--- The Hilton Hawaiian Village is absolutely wonderful as many others have described. The grounds are well manicured and the bedding is to die for. HOWEVER, the construction noise on the north side of the Rainbow Tower makes these rooms unusable during daylight hours. I found this out the next day after a long flight from Atlanta when I returned to the room to take a nap and heard the constant beeping of trucks backing up and the constant pounding of a pile driver. The construction is to be completed in late 2007. Since we were staying four nights, I asked to be moved and was accomodated (Thanks to the management of the Hotel--they moved us, even though the Hotel was near capacity---) The room we received is in the TAPA tower on the 32nd floor. Looking out our patio doors is a framed view of Diamond Head!! Also, upon check in, I asked for the Paradise Pass which is available at a nominal charge. It gives you unlimited internet use as well as access to the workout facility....  
<Date>Feb 10, 2007

<Author>TravelingGypsy16
<Content>Amazing Hotel, Amazing Vacation! My family and I take vacations every summer to a different locale and in the summer of 2006 (due to my mom's constant persistence) we stayed on Waikiki Beach at the Hilton Hawaiian Village - AMAZING resort. I have to say I have never been sadder to leave a hotel in my life! EVERYTHING about it was spectacular! To begin with the view from our room in the Rainbow Tower was breathtaking! Waking up in the mornings and seeing the beach as well as Diamond Head volcano was great. The rooms were very spacious, comfortable, and nicely decorated with everything we needed. The service at the resort was very impressive. Traveling to many different places you are forced to interact with others and at times the people that help you are just so rude - but this was the complete opposite. It seems that they would go out of their way whenever it came to anything we needed.The staff members at the restaurants, bars, and shops were extremely friendly and helpful. Even the girl working in the concierge (which gives the most amazing recommendations for restaurants - definitely encourage you to eat out on the town). Dining at the Hilton Hawaiian Village is an experience unto itself - with its extensive variety of places to pick - you never have to repeat a restaurant!When we weren鈥檛 driving around the island to see and experience the beauty Oahu had to offer, we were able to enjoy our days relaxing by the enormous hotel pool or by the sparkling Waikiki beach. I truly have to say this is one of the best vacations I have ever taken 鈥?and I definitely recommend the Hilton Hawaiian Village to EVERYONE!  
<Date>Jan 24, 2007

<Author>Craigy
<Content>Loved it Booked a two night stay in a standard village view room, and was upgraded to Executive room on the 24th floor in the Kalia Tower.The room was great, spacious and spotlessly clean and the bed, as usual was fantastic. Great view of the mountains and city and part of the ocean. The free breakfast, snacks etc were an added extra, very tasty pastries and evening hors d'oeuvres. Check in staff were very friendly. For us the village had a great atmosphere, it is huge and granted many of the shops were expensive, but hey, don't shop there. We found the restauarnts and bars quite reasonable, compared wit hte rest of fine dining in Hawaii. Only gripe was the plastic cups they serve the cocktails in late at night (don't know if this is normal).The hotel is in about the quietest part of Waikiki we saw, walking distance to the main beach ( the walk along the beach or through the park is lovely) and Ala Moana Shopping Centre. Didn't have any problem with the traffic noise, but we were on a high floor.Cannot wait to stay here again.  
<Date>Jan 8, 2007

<Author>CatMama
<Content>Too big city This was our fourth trip to Hawaii, but our first on Oahu. The Hawaiian Village is a beautiful hotel, first-rate service and amenities. We were upgraded to an ocean view room--one of the things we really look forward to is leaving the sliding doors open and listening to the ocean. Unfortunately, all we heard was traffic noise 24/7--the hotel is located on Waikiki Beach, but also adjacent to a VERY busy highway. We're from Chicago, and this was reminiscent of living next to an expressway. We were booked for 6 nights, and ready to leave after 4. Again, the accommodations were first-class, but the traffic noise killed it for us.

<Author>dgygox
<Content>hilton hawaiian village overrated Hilton Hawaiian Village is a nice property, however it has to be one of the most expensive places to eat in Hawaii. Rooms are decent, small closets, but clean. Property is beautiful, but retaurants are sky high, even the cheap ones. (food was terrible)Not worth staying there while you can get just as nice a hotel at a more reasonable rate with great reasonably priced restaurants. Smokers beware, HHV is pretty much a non-smoking facility. If you smoke, you may as well have leporacy. There are two ash trays on the entire property, located in designated hidden areas that make you feel like a criminal if you lite up. Pools are nice, but beach is a bit of a walk. I would NOT recommend this hotel.

<Author>Jaquesspratt
<Content>Avoid This Property We spent two night at this property, having just stayed at the Sheraton Waikiki and the Marriott Waikiki. We were booked into the Kalia tower, one of six on the property, and situated near the entrance. Our room was on an 'executive' floor, with special key access, and complimentary continental breakfast, and light snacks at noon and early evening. We had a full ocean view but this was compromised by construction cranes. We found the staff somewhat remote and occasionally deficient in English, perhaps because of the predominance of Japanese tourists. The one restaurant we sampled - Sergio's- was excellent. We had booked their pacific rim restaurant 'Bali by the Sea' but canceled after finding difficulty finding a published menu with prices. Once we finally located one - at the restaurant after asking the hostess - we understood why.The property is at the extreme West end of Waikiki, some distance from the heart of the action. One can easily feel a prisoner in this complex. It's designed to keep you there. The sheer volume of guests here, when spilling out of the many high rise towers, can be disconcerting. I can't think of a good reason to stay here. It's too far for many to walk to the Ala Moana shopping centre, and it's a fair walk to mid Waikiki as well. It's pricey, crowded, and fairly noisy.  
<Date>Jan 3, 2007

<Author>Coug1995
<Content>Construction near Lagoon Tower HGVC Hilton Hawaiian Village After spending a week in Kaua'i, my husband and I spent three nights here before heading back to the mainland. As HGVC owners, we actually do this every year to break up our vacation a little and visit Waikiki which has great food and shopping, not something that is readily available on the island of Kaua'i. Don't get me wrong, we love Kaua'i, but it is a different vacation experience than the big city bustle of Waikiki. Sometimes you need a little of both!As HGVC owners (Vegas) we booked into the Lagoon Tower, which as the name implies is right next to the lagoon. What we didn't know is that the lagoon is gone and in it's place is a big construction pit where they are building the new Grand Waikikian Tower, which I think is another HGVC building. Overall the construction isn't bad, it does however create quite an inconvenience if you are not expecting it. Having been there many times before, we arrived on the property in our rental car and proceeded to the Lagoon Tower driveway only to discover it was barricaded because of construction. The parking garage entrance was also inaccessible because it was being used as an exit only, and I think it was the end of a shift because there was a constant stream of cars coming out and they weren't rental cars. On a Hawaiian vacation you should always be relaxed and patient, which I usually am, but for some reason I became really agitated by this situation. I was trapped in a dead-end with no way to turn around because the people coming out of the garage were not about to stop and give me room to turn around. Add to that a really annoying taxi driver who pulled up behind me and refused to back up so I could at least reverse myself out of the dead-end. After what seemed like 10 minutes and alot of screaming on my part he finally moved and I was able to back up. I have two gripes about this. First, couldn't the Hilton have told us in advance that there was construction and the main entrance to the Lagoon Tower was closed? Had we known, we wouldn't have attempted to drive there. Second, there were guards directing traffic and when I made my move to head to the Lagoon Tower, the guard that was standing right there (on the corner near Lapperts for those of you who have been there) could have told me it was closed. You can't see it is closed until you round the corner and by then it's too late to turn around. Other than that, the rest of the vacation was great. If you are another HGVC owner and contemplating a visit here I would recommend booking the Kalia Tower instead. There is nothing wrong with the Lagoon Tower, it's the inconvenience of the construction that will keep me from booking in this tower until construction is completed.The pool at the Lagoon Tower is also closed so you have to use the Super Pool, the Tapa Pool or the Kalia Pool. I recommend the Kalia Pool. There aren't many people who use this pool and if you want to relax, it's generally kid free. That said, kids are allowed, but for the most part they prefer the Super Pool. The other important thing to note is that the parking garage has an entrance near the Kalia Tower as well. For all the years we have stayed here I didn't know this until I was forced to use that entrance due to the closure of the entrance by the Lagoon Tower.  
<Date>Jan 3, 2007

<Author>lambertbunch
<Content>Enjoyable Stay at Hilton Hawaiian Village We stayed Dec 19 and 20th in the Ali'i Tower. Note: this is a peak travel time in Hawaii. The room was spacious and the staff very attentive. I selected tower because I wanted access to the private pool and the evening appetizers. The pool was nice and I did not have a problem getting 4 lounge chairs so we could sit together. The complimentary appetizers worked out great and served as our dinner. Fruit, cheese, veggies, spring rolls, wontons. This tower is right on the beach. Perfect!On Dec 26-28 we stayed in the Kahlia tower. We were upgraded to an oceanview room. I would recommend this tower as well since it has a private pool. The soothing aroma from the spa permiated in the pool area. Tropics Bar (Ali'i Tower) offered a great view but had mostly fried food which I am not a fan of. Lappert's Ice Cream was a treat for the kids. I would recommend Benihana's at lunch time. The kid enjoyed watching the entertaining hibachi chef. Teriaki Chicken at Hanajuban was good for only $8. Overall the food was just ok at this resort. If you have kids you should take a walk to some neighboring restaurants to cut down on cost. The evening entertainment by the super pool of polynesian dancers was great. The kids begged to see it each night. I would recommend this resort.  
<Date>Dec 29, 2006

<Author>LisaandJoe
<Content>Yuk. The main disappointment was the customer service - after arriving in the wee hours of the morning after long flight delays it was very unpleasant to wait on a line (at 3AM!) to check in with the sole counter person - she was inept and spoke poor English at a whisper... we weren't shown or even pointed to our room, and finally got a lounging van driver to point us in the right direction.This continued throughout our stay, staff were obviously bored, resentful or just dying to get off work, we were made to feel like intruders rather than guests. Another annoyance - petty charges for everything from coffee packets in the room ($3!) to beach chair rental ($12). Just up the room charges and skip this nickle and dime stuff, huh?The hotel itself is just one spending opportunity - the village is just shops.The room was fine - spacious and clean - but our high floor looked over the truck and bus loading dock and the backing up beeping of both was very annoying and lasted all night and day. Disappointing in general.

<Author>FirstVoyager
<Content>Dissapointing for a Hilton! We stayed here November 2006, just before thanksgiving. During this time, the hotel is not crowded. ROOMS:The rooms are good size, larger than general hotel rooms and if you happen to have a room in the Rainbow Tower, at the very end facing the sea, they are absolutely amazing! Of all the rooms I have had in any hotel, I think I will always remember the view from these rooms 鈥?we had two. The higher, the better.FOOD:This hotel has very low quality food, for a Hilton, it surprised us. We tried various restaurants in the hotel, yet the food as always old, aged, not tasty and expensive for what鈥檚 offered. And do not, DO NOT eat at the restaurant next to the water way with ducks and fish in it, because you will loose your appetite due to the smell of the duck droppings and fish in the water.GROUNDS:The grounds of the hotel need dusting off! Everything looked like they were covered with dust, just not a clean feeling. Although the hotel has a superb location and is a huge complex with potential, it is not maintained well.CONCLUSION:We would not stay here again, mostly because the food is BAD! But if you are not worried about quality of food, then this is a good hotel. Not very good, not bad, just average 鈥?not worth more than 200 dollars per night.

<Author>djr76
<Content>Ahhhh.... We stayed at this hotel a few years ago when my husband was running the Honolulu marathon and it was spectacular! The room itself was decorated in typical Hawaiian decor and was nice enough (not luxurious but comfortable and pleasant) but....the view from our balcony was incredible and made our stay. We looked out on to the ocean and could hear the waves when we slept. We stayed there in early December and being there early in the holiday season was such a different and fun experience. The hotel had carolers in the lobby and Santa made a few appearances in Bermuda shorts.The pool was nice and fairly large and very easy access to the beach.It was a bit of a walk to get to the shops and main part of Honolulu but it was worth it to stay at the hotel.

<Author>boomerang86
<Content>Beautiful complex, still a work in progress We booked through a travel wholesaler (Gogo Tours) for multiple islands. This was our first stop on a three island tour, December 6-8. We arrived about 6:30 PM local time; this is a HUGE complex and it took us a few minutes to locate the check-in desk. We were told there were no king beds available, so they upgraded us to an ocean view with double beds. Our room in the Tapa tower (29th floor) did have an ocean view, but it's in the back of the complex and faces Diamond Head (east). Our room keys didn't open our door due to a fussy electronic lock; a second set provided by the front desk didn't work any better. Security was dispatched promptly and they got us in with our keys; they had another set made in the keymaster's office to appease us.The room was spacious and included a wet bar. We had several issues; a noisy air handler was corrected, but a cordless phone with no dial tone and roaches in the sinks were not. Hot water in the shower was difficult to regulate.This is a nice resort, but has very expensive shops and restaurants. You can have a very nice stay in Waikiki and spend a lot less money at other properties in the area.

<Author>Cooktolive
<Content>Great village away from it all! I stayed at the Hilton before participating in the Marathon. I must say, the room was very nice and comfortable. Balcony was great , but overlooked construction with alot of noise. This noise was muted once we closed the sliding door. The pool area was fantastic! Very tropical with pleasant cocktail servers, who served the best Mai Tais ever! Beach access and shopping was above par!! On a sour note: At the Hilton Village, you are nickled and dimed for absolutely everything!!! There's a charge for the safe, for the internet, for more than one small packet of coffee, on and on....I would stay here again as it was very relaxing!!!

<Content>Loved HHV! We stayed at the HHV from 12/14 - 12/17, in the Ali'i Tower. I gotta say that we were a wee bit leary of the place after some of the reviews but we love this place! <Author>Stevie1973
<Content>Overall a very nice hotel in Waikiki My wife and I (she's 30, I'm 33) stayed at the Hilton Hawaiin Village Dec 7-13. Overall, we had a great stay and were pleased with the hotel. Here are our thoughts on the hotel: ROOM - We had a room in the Tapa tower. We were originally booked in the Kalia tower, but were upgraded to a partial oceanview room in Tapa. (Apparently upgrades are pretty common. Ask for one!) The room was clean and well-appointed, with a safe ($3.50/day to use), mini refigerator, iron, TV and mini-bar. Some have complained that the coffee, bottled water and other in-room beverages are too expensive. And that's true. But no problem...just go to one of the many ABC stores (sort of like a 7-11) in and around the hotel and stock up on these items there. The bed was plenty comfortable. The TV had standard cable, although we didn't watch it much. We did rent an on-demand movie one night ($9.99), which was nice. I also tried the high speed in-room Internet service on the TV ($10.99 for a couple hours). My advice? Skip it. It is slow and doesn't work well. It is set up for mobile (as in PDA) Internet viewing, so many websites flat-out don't load or are hard to read. If you really need Internet access, bring a laptop or go to an Internet cafe. Two small room complaints: one day, the shower water was only lukewarm all day long. Not a big deal though...it was fine the rest of the time. Also, the room doors slam if allowed to. Other guests apparently felt it was no problem to let their doors slam at 2:00 AM, which was annoying. But all in all, the rooms were nice.FOOD - The hotel has about 15-20 eateries, ranging from very reasonable to very expensive. We went to one of the very expensive restaurants (Bali by the Sea) one night and had a delicious meal. As others have noted, it is fun to have one nice (i.e. expensive) dinner at the hotel just for the experience, but no more than that. Within the hotel we also ate at Round Table (pizza), CJ's (New York style deli) and a Japanese noodle place. All of the meals were good, although nothing spectacular. You'll probably want to eat most of your meals out on the town, where there is more variety both in terms of price and cuisine. But for a single hotel, there ARE a lot of dining options here. Also as noted on this board, there is a 24/7 coffee shop across the street (sort of like a Denny's) that is a great option, especially for families. Oh, while in Hawaii, eat the local fresh fruit! Fresh pineapple and guava just tastes better in Hawaii!HOTEL GROUNDS - As noted already, this place is huge. Still, I don't really understand negative comments regarding crowds, as if those reviewers were surprised that a resort with 3,000 rooms might feel crowded at times. In truth, the entirety of Waikiki feels crowded. If you want seclusion, you're on the wrong island to begin with. But aside from the hotel ABC store and certain eateries, the hotel crowds really aren't that bad. The grounds are beautiful, clean and well-maintained, with small waterfalls and certain wildlife roaming around (never saw the penguins though). We had been warned of construction before our arrival, but in the Tapa Tower at least, we didn't even notice it. The Super Pool is kind of lame, as it isn't very super. (The pool at the military-only Hale Koa hotel is much nicer). But, the pool also wasn't as crowded as I expected. And yes, people do reserve pool seats by putting a towel over one of the lounge chairs, even though in my observation these people often never showed up. In my opinion the hotel should prohibit reserving pool seats. If you want a chair by the pool, then go sit in one! It is rude and obnoxious to reserve a seat you aren't using and apparently may not intend to use. Overall, the grounds are very nice!STAFF - The hotel staff were always helpful and pleasant. They were eager to assist anytime you had a problem or question, or needed a recommedation. We left a $3 tip for the cleaning staff each day (rule of thumb is $1/person per room, so we tipped a bit more). It has been my experience worldwide that if you tip the cleaning staff, your room WILL be cleaned better. Just human nature, I suppose.MISCELLANEOUS - Overall this is a very nice hotel, and I would stay here again. Families, active couples and groups of friends would have a good time here. Those wanting seclusion or who want to avoid people should not stay here. The hotel will help book recreation activities, but you should price shop around. In particular, get a Oahu Gold or similar book (found on most street corners in news racks) and use the coupons for the best deals. If you go to the hotel Welcome Center for your free gift after checking in, know that they will try to get you to attend a 90 minute timeshare presentation. But they aren't too pushy about it. Just decline and get your free gift (A luggage tag in our case, although they do have some nice gifts you can win.) Parking at the hotel is pricey...$3.50 an hour or $20/day. But that is standard Waikiki. If you have a late flight out of Hawaii, you can book a hotel hospitality room for free, for 45 minutes. This allows you to freshen up before your flight if you've been out and about all day.  I should say, this was my second visit to Oahu. Last time, I stayed at the Hale Koa (a military only resort), so that is the reference I have with which to compare hotels. While the Hale Koa is almost as nice as the Hilton, and is only about 1/3 the price of the Hilton, it isn't really a fair comparison since you have to be in the military to stay at the Hale Koa. If I was still in the military I would choose the Hale Koa over the Hilton based on price alone, but like I said...it isn't a fair comparison.If you have questions about the Hilton Hawaiian Vilage, email me and I will be happy to provide an honest, objective answer.Aloha!!!  
<Date>Dec 15, 2006

<Author>mickeymill
<Content>great place great deal My boss and I went to Oahu for a business trip from 2 Dec thru 06 Dec. <Author>CTVacationers
<Content>Much better than expected My family and I just spent a week at the HHV over Thanksgiving. Going in we did not have huge expectations from such a mega complex but surprisingly our expectations were greatly exceeded.We stayed in the Ali'i Tower which is more pricy but with its own private pool and free light hors d'oeuvers. Nothing incredible but a nice snack for the kids after a day in the sun.The pools are quite small for a resort this size and a little boring for older kids, at the Super Pool lounge chairs are lined up for right when the pool opens. No sich trouble with chairs at the Ali's pool and it is adjacent to a nice small work out room.It is not the cheapest resort around, but compared to other areas of Hawaii quie an overall bargain. The food on site is nothing remarkable and avoid The Golden Dragon at all cost. Food is mediocre and service horrible. Nice spot for breakfast is the 24 hour diner across the street.Great location with many shops and restaurants within easy walking distance.Overall an excellent experience.

<Author>bogie27
<Content>This hotel was excellent My wife and i recently spent 1 night of our honeymoon at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. The hotel was more like a resort. It had everything....shops, restaurant, a large pool and easy access to the beach. There are multiple towers. We stayed in an oceanview room in the rainbow tower. The view was spectacular. Try to get a room on the corner if you can overlooking the ocean and the bay. The room itself was spacious, the bed was comfortable, the bathroom was emaculateSince we were only there 1 night, it's hard to say much else about this place. But believe me, you can go wrong with this place. Our only concern was that the majority of the restaurants, shops and nightlife outside of the Hilton Hawaiian village were 2 miles further west of this hotel, which meant taxi rides to and from the restaurant row area. All of the restaurants are expensive, so we enjoyed being able to price compare a little in menus and prices.Also, this hotel is doing a bit of construction on a lagoon next to the rainbow tower. So you may hear noise if you're on one of the lower floors, but of course most of the work is done by 4pm when everyone is on the beach.As a money saving tip, I would also suggest going to the local ABC stores (they are small conveience stores in the hotel and literally on every block in Waikiki) and buying simple things like water, crackers, chips, etc and eating that for lunch. Trust me, we did this and saved a lot.The streets of Waikiki are always busy, especially at night.Take a couple of the tours and learn about Hawaiian culture. We did the Polynesian Culture tour which was all day (leave at 12 noon and get back about 10pm) and we did a luau and saw a Polynesian dance show. We also did a short 3 hr tour where we hiked thru a rain forest (yes there are rain forests in Hawaii).Enjoy!  
<Date>Nov 25, 2006

<Author>pj813
<Content>Huge hotel, but with benefits. It's advertised that there are ~3000 rooms, so it's not the most personal place, BUT, it really is a village! There are shops, restaurants, a beach, 3 swimming pools, grocery store and car rental and travel agencies and more located within the hotel grounds. The village is on the very west end of Waikiki, so you do have to walk awhile to get to the center of the beachy strip and to the main downtown area, but the good news is that the Hilton sits on the beach. It was always busy there, with plenty of screaming children and not much privacy on the beach, at the pools, or at meals. If you want a boutique hotel, or a romantic getaway, this isn't for you, but probably a good choice for families. A cab is about $30 from the airport.  
<Date>Nov 17, 2006

<Author>farmerjohn
<Content>Great Family Vacation We stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village Nov. 5-11. We had booked two rooms in the Kalia tower, mountain view. When we checked in we had been upgraded to ocean view. The rooms were very nice and the furnishings were what I would expect. The rooms were clean and we received excellent maid service during our stay.The location is excellent as you are on the quiet end of Waikiki. We were within walking distance of Ala Moana mall. We didn鈥檛 use the pools much but our children loved playing in the ocean every day. I have to agree with others who say that Hilton is being overly aggressive by charging for beach chairs and umbrellas. This is something that should be free. To avoid paying their high fees, we just bought our own beach chairs at Costco on the first day to use throughout our stay.We only ate one meal at the Hilton and I found it to be sub-par. However, there are plenty of dining options in Waikiki.Many have mentioned that they found the Hilton and Waikiki too crowded. I say that Waikiki is what it is. If you are looking for quiet and uncrowded, pick somewhere else. All things considered, the Hilton is the best place to stay in Waikiki.

<Author>Parvs
<Content>Holiday of a lifetime Me and my husband stayed at this hotel for 10 days on our honeymoon. We did have some problems when we were checking in as there was a room mix up, but the staff did everything they good to make us happy. They finally put us in a room and they had sent us complimentary chanpagne, which was great! The hotel room was very, very clean and as we were there for 10 days, the cleaners did a great job with keeping the rooms clean.The hotel is a little village which is one of the things that we loved so much, we could walk to the beach from our room. There is also an ABC store at the bottom of our tower, which was so convenient and cheap. You can find one of those stores at a few places when you are walking around.I do reccomend the ice cream, it's pricey but probably the best ice cream we have ever tasted!!!!!We had a great breakfast every morning at one of the restaurants in the resort and they have a veriety of different things. The staff there were very friendly and always greeted us by our names every morning.They also have pengiuns and parrots in the hotel resort, which i have never seen before. The fireworks on the Friday night before we went home were amazing - we just sat on the beach and watched the sky. It wasn't busy at all, it was just right.Overall this hotel really made our Honeymoon so great, the service was great and the staff were too. We definatly will go back... maybe for our 25th Wedding Anniversary!!!!!!!!

<Author>rmwh
<Content>Unimpressed with the room and service We're staying in the Tapa tower, in a Partial Ocean View room (which, by the way, means that if we go out to the lanai, we can look over and see the ocean). I would not stay here again at this rate ($205, which was a conference rate).The room is okay -- the furniture is worn (paint chipping off the desk, saggy chair cushions, etc.). The carpet and bedding are clean. The air conditioner is noisy. Places like hallways and elevators could be better maintained (peeling wallpaper, chipped paint, etc.). There's a big construction project going on, so I'd agree with the previous suggestion to request a room on the Diamond Head side. The service has been quite lackluster -- of the polite but not my problem variety. I really didn't care about the room view, but I specifically called the hotel a few days before our arrival to request a room away from the street and any construction. Was told no problem, but what we got was a direct view of a crane, overlooking a construction zone, as close to the street as you can get. I spent our entire first afternoon trying politely to get our room changed but didn't even get an acknowledgement that my request had not been fulfilled. We waited a few hours with the hopes that a room that was being cleaned would improve the situation, only to find that the room smelled awful. I was willing to pay a higher room rate, and apparently even then there was nothing else available. (Their web site was still accepting reservations for the various room categories, though.) Ditto the previous comments about being nickled and dimed... Internet access is now 12.95/day, it's not wireless, and it's slow.  
<Date>Nov 13, 2006

<Author>Trave1spy
<Content>Loved it. My god this hotel is huge! We got lost trying to find check in! We were dropped off round the back so had to walk through all the boutique shops etc. Anyway check in was fine, they upgraded us as we were on honeymoon. We stayed in the Ali tower which was lovely, you get free nibbles round the pool each night from 5 till 8 I loved it (mind you the drinks are quite expensive! so maybe opt for water!) You also get free water through out the day to drink whilst you sunbath round the pool which I thought was fantastic as it does get very hot! The Polynesian show each night is also fun which is situated out by the main pool, for everyone to see, no matter which tower they are in. The fireworks on a Friday night are brilliant too. So your right on the beach, it wasn鈥檛 crowded when we were there Oct 9th till 15th. You also have shops in the hotel complex, so you can buy milk and drinks etc and keep them in your room fridge. We also experienced the earth quake on our last morning there. I have to say the staff were very helpful as we were un sure wether to leave for the airport or not, they called on our behalf to find out etc. Also called our airline so they were great. I would definitely stay here again, it鈥檚 a lovely hotel.

<Author>KHM_JM
<Content>Don't go if you want restful surroundings We stayed for 1 week in June 2006, the hotel was unbelievably crowded. When they say village in the title they mean it, the rooms are spread across 4 buildings and there are lots of little shops and restaurants, tending to be upscale, one including Louis Vuitton which was bizarre, because this is not a high class resort. On checking in we were told only one room was available, although we had a reservation with Virgin holidays. The room was on the top floor of Rainbow tower, 46th floor or similar, which was a no go since I am scared of heights. We were then switched to another room with balcony, 3rd floor, view of nothing. The room was clean, but that was about it. The hotel was packed with kids and families, there is a tiny swimming pool which you have to queue by 8.30am to get a sun lounger at, otherwise the Japanese tourists descend. Waikiki beach is overrated, there are much better beaches in Florida and Caribbean. It cost 拢30 to hire an umberella and 2 sun loungers which was ridiculous.Restaurants in the hotel were overpriced, our saving grace was a Ward Centers mall nearby which had a large selection of restaurants at reasonable prices. They also have a large cinema there.In summary, I think Hilton need to look seriously at what its trying to offer with this hotel -family resort or luxury resort, because at the moment its not satisfying the criteria of either.  
<Date>Oct 30, 2006

<Content>Very nice We checked in 15 Sunday and of course that is the day of the quake. The lines were long trying to check in but all in all is wasn't bad. One thing i think the could change is having a gym in all the towers and wireless in all rooms for free.

<Author>KJUW
<Content>Very Crowded We stayed at the Hawaiian Village for one night during a long stay in Hawaii. We usually avoid Waikiki while we're in Oahu but we had a free night at the Hilton and couldn't pass it up. The congestion in Waikiki is horrible. Traffic is slow and there are people everywhere. I pulled up to the registration desk to check in and was shooed away by a valet after I told him I was just checking in and would then self park. He said I needed to park first and then check in. The check in line was very long, but I was able to use the Hilton Honors express check in line which only had one person ahead of me. The other line seemed to move pretty quickly as the desk was fully staffed. I was upgraded to a suite in the Kapa tower and was very pleased with the room. Two balconies, a living/dining area and then a seperate bedroom with 1.5 baths and a wet bar with mini-fridge. It was a shame we only had the one night to spend there. Since we were flying out the following night, I called the front desk to request a hospitality room for that day. Check out time was 11 AM, but the hotel allows you to reserve a hospitality room at no fee for later in the day so you can freshen up before your flight. The room is a standard hotel room and you are given 20 minutes per person in your group for it. The room is fully stocked with towels and toiletries to allow you to shower and get ready for your flight. We also took advantage of the Hilton Check In computer kiosks in the lobby. Besides allowing you to check in or out of the hotel, they also allow you to check in for your flight and print boarding passes on most major airlines. We didn't have time to experience their pools, restaurant, or the beach. However we did stroll through the grounds a few times and everything was very crowded every time. The restaurants had lines, all the pool chairs were taken, and people were all over the hotel stores. As is true with most resorts, there are a lot of extra fees. Parking was about $12 per day and internet access was also available for a daily fee. Overall its a very nice resort with wonderful service. If you want to be in the middle of everything in Waikiki, the location is perfect. If you're looking to drive around the island and visit other parts, you'll be in for a headache with the traffic.  
<Date>Oct 18, 2006

<Author>HawaiiLover
<Content>Might stay again-only because of the view. Aloha!Don't get me wrong-I would stay here again in a heartbeat. Only for the reasons that A)We know that it is clean  nice, etc.  B)The Rainbow Tower is directly on the beach.Was supposed to be upgraded to Deluxe Oceanfront Room for both us  our 26 year old daughter (2 rooms). Wasn't. They claimed it was. Both had views of the lagoon  Ala Wai Yacht Harbor. Still a great view, tho. Just disappointing. I have heard that you ask for 'Diamond Head side of the hotel'. I just forgot to do that when checking in. Lines are REALLY long when checking in, but, they have virgin Mai Tai's that are really tasty. Guess with all the kiddies, they can't give ya the good stuff! :-( We booked this thru a travel agent who in turn booked it thru Pleasant Hawaiian Holidays. Was not happy with them. Didn't get the things (trivial things-bags, etc) that were promised. We had to attend the orientation breakfast to get all our goodies. The travel agent neglected to tell me this. Also, didn't find out it was Pleasant Hawaiian til we got the tickets-3 WEEKS BEFORE WE LEFT!!!We did get the vouchers for $50 off at various HHV restaurants for each room. What they FORGOT to tell us is that it is for food only. No drinks. Soooo, we racked up the bill for the drinks  when we checked out, that was on our bill. I explained myself very tactfully  the guy went ahead  honored them! Our daughter had no problem because she used hers for our dinner at Bali By The Sea. That part went over well  I was happy with that part.Didn't need to go to the orientation breakfast because it cut into our time  we had already been to Oahu the year before for a month  knew everything already. Now, the hotel itself is just ok. Yes, it is a gorgeous facility  they are pretty good at upkeep on a daily basis. But, half the time we came back at the end of the day  they hadn't even gotten to ourrooms yet. It is such a big resort that it is hard to get that personal service.We have friends who own timeshares with HHV  we stayed with them for a few days during our month long stay 2 years ago. We knew it was a nice, clean resort  didn't need to look any further when booking a hotel when coming with our daughter. But, they are rather pricey. Flight, car  hotel for 8 nites was $2506 EACH!Our daughter gave us a budget for her for $2500. Whew! My husband had his heart set on this place because of the proximity to the beach  no obstructed views. But, the year before on our month long visit, my husband  I stayed in a condo on the North Shore that cost $100 per nite. So, it was a bit of a shock! But, we were in a prime location this time  as I said, I would stay there again. I would just book everything myself. I think it would have been a little cheaper that way.Oh! In one of the shops, my daughter went by herself (gotta get away from the parents a LITTLE!) to one by Bali By The Sea  she said one of the proprieters followed her around like a little lost puppy! So afraid she was going to 'lift' something!The shops are a little 'stuffy' when it comes to courtesy. The shops are great, tho  the restaurants are amazing! Especially Tropics Bar! GREAT drinks  food  right out there in the open air! So, as you can see, for the money, I don't think it is a great deal. But, if you want a sure thing in terms of cleanliness  all that-go for it! I would recommend this resort to anyone who asks. These are just my little 'annoyances'. Didn't affect my Hawaiian experience one little bit! There is no way anything can bother you for long in PARADISE!!!I just had a bit of a disappointing experience. Nothing major or devastating. Just my humble opinions. Not meant to offend.Mahalo!Aloha!  
<Date>Oct 17, 2006

<Author>MarylandMarcia
<Content>The Rainbow Tower was fabulous! After 11 hours of flight from Baltimore,MD... we were greeted with another two hour fight for our ocean-view accomodation we had paid for a year ago,through the Hilton Grand Vacation program. We stood our ground and ended up in the Rainbow Tower on the 26th floor with a fabulous view of the ocean, parts of Honolulu by night, and the mountain region. Even though it was a basic room, the scene from our balcony far outweighed the view of a building we had from the condo. Our room was beautiful, convenient, and surrounded by a truly tropical ambiance. A trip down the elevator and a walk of merely 40 steps placed us right on the beach..We loved our stay and truly felt like we were in paradise. We yearn to return.

<Author>MannMom
<Content>The Hilton Hawaiian Village lives up to it's name I stayed at the Hilton for 4 nights in mid September for a work conference at the nearby convention center. It truly is a village! I never did fully get my bearings and got turned around constantly. I stayed in the Ali'i tower while many of my co-workers were in one of the other towers- I think there are about 5 in all which are a few minutes' walk from each other. In the middle, there are many shops selling local products so you don't have to go far to find a souvenir. On one end is the beach which is great to have just a few steps away. The many pools are great too; the Ali'i Tower even had its own pool for Tower guests which overlooked the beach (I heard from others that the Ali'i tower is the best) When I arrived, lamps were turned on in my room with robes lying out on the beds and a plate of fresh fruit to welcome me. Hawaiian music was playing on the room radio. My room had a fairly good ocean view although not direct. The amenities at the Hilton are terrific. I appreciated the travel sewing kit when a strap on my dress was torn off. Used the room safe, enjoyed the free bottled water. The room and hotel surroundings are clean, up to date and well-kept. The wedding chapel on the grounds is lovely (and busy when I was there). This hotel was a great place to stay with great service. A little big for my tastes but could be lots of fun for a large family or group of friends.  
<Date>Sep 26, 2006

<Author>caramela
<Content>Slightly disappointed Stayed at the HHV for 5 nights for our Honeymoon. Wished we had stayed in Maui longer and never came to Oahu. Maybe if HHV had accomodated us and taken care of us on our Honeymoon it would have made a difference but HHV did not take care of us AT ALL. First of all, our travel agent booked us a room in the Rainbow Tower and confirmed with us repeatedly that we were in the Rainbow Tower. When we checked in, it took an HOUR with some trainee because there was a mistake with our reservation. Our travel agent supposedly NEVER booked us in the Rainbow Tower AND she booked us with 2 double beds. In the end, this was true our travel agent made a MAJOR mistake but you would think that HHV would accomodate us as it is our honeymoon AND september IS low season. But they didn't and they couldn't have cared less about us. They put us in the Tapa tower (albeit in a renovated room with a king size bed) but we were NOT satisfied!HHV is a beautiful resort...the animals are great... the staff at the information desk are extremely friendly! The front desk staff stinks! The housekeeping were very nice as well and our room was always clean.But I will NEVER stay in the HHV again because of this incident. It was our HONEYMOON and they did NOTHING, NOTHING to make it memorable.We are seriously disappointed and disatisfied with the service we received. So... if I were you, if you do wish to stay at this hotel make sure BEFORE you arrive in Hawaii that your reservations are confirmed and that you are in the room you paid for. Believe me, HHV WILL NOT take care of you if there is a mistake.I still can't believe they didn't upgrade us on our honeymoon. Every honeymoon couple I have ever met is ALWAYS upgraded!Oh and about the noise... this is true.... too much noise in the hallways AND the construction at the pier is loud... AND Waikiki Beach is filthy. If you want a nice beach on Oahu, rent a car and drive to the North Shore to Sunset Beach, Waimea Bay or south east to Hanauma Bay... Those are stunning! The water is CLEAN! Water may be a bit rougher so be careful but at least you're not swimming in murky water.  
<Date>Sep 24, 2006

<Author>Flippitti
<Content>Convenience and luxury all in one place This was our 1st stay at the HHV and I must say, I was impressed by how efficiently everything ran. Originally, our room at the Rainbow Tower was too close to the construction noise but we just requested another room and the front desk was pleasant about giving us a better one. The Heavenly Bed was wonderfully luxurious! We were there a week and ate at just about every restaurant on site, except for Benihana's (which was very crowded and had a 45 minute wait the night we stopped by). If you want to make sure you get a table at some of the more popular restaurants, make a reservation. As it is, there's a variety of restaurants with different types of cuisine to satisfy all appetites. We used the Mandara Spa facilities and gym at the Kalia Tower regularly. The pool there is smaller but much less crowded and quieter than anywhere else. I highly recommend the Mandara Spa. I had a few aches and pains from the flight and was able to get a massage appt the day I arrived. We took the 1/2 day Little Circle Island Tour with E Noa Tours which ran from 2PM-6PM daily. It was just the right amt of time to visit the island without getting worn out. You can book tours directly with the hotel. We were going to visit Pearl Harbor but discovered the wait was over 2 hours so we decided to do that on our next trip. Perhaps that's one tour we'll need to book ahead of time. All in all, I'd stay at the HHV again. It's close to everything, the Hilton management machine works quietly and efficiently, the food is great and the location is quite convenient.  
<Date>Sep 21, 2006

<Author>Skye_Viajante
<Content>NOT for rest and relaxation Okay, here we go.The rooms are nice, the resort as a whole is horrible. So if your not going to leave your room, then you'll be ok, just be sure to keep the door shut, so all the construction noise doesnt get in. Otherwise, I would not recommend this resort.We had to extend our stay 3 extra days (total of 8) and though the registration associate said that if we wanted the same rate 249.99 partial ocean view, we would have to move rooms, (Okay, that is fair.) in the end we had to pay 299.00 a night, for lesser rooms and we still had to move to new rooms.The parking garage is a veritable nightmare, and this resort is too far from anything to walk, unless you've got cross trainers on, and who wears socks in Hawaii?The staff is pleasant, but made many mistakes. Two mistakes were made on my bill, bar charges from another party (the name was VERY different, and was still changed to my name and room number (I easily looked at the reciept and read the room number as not mine.), and they charged me a random 22.00 fee, directly to my cc, that I had to call and make sure they had taken off once I got home, since it did not show on my hotel bill. My room service order was messed up, and the food was so-so. The walls were terribly thin, and I dealt with 3 rowdy pre-teen girls next door, a blaringly loud self-help seminar on another I actually had to ask the person to turn it down, and security/maintenance with their walkie talkies turned up full blast at all hours of the night, roaming the halls. There is construction going on, so there is no peace and quiet to be found at this resort, and the view is marred by all the construction going on. Sitting by the pool all you'll hear is loud contruction drilling. The pools are all very small and dirty, and the resort is so packed that you feel like you are at Disneyland, not in paradise. The pool attendent makes you take a receipt for your pool towel, and they are VERY rude about the whole thing. The only pool I didnt notice a receipt being doled out was the one in the Kalia tower. All the pools were crowded, (probably because they were so small.), but this one was the least crowded...mind you it has no atmosphere, being the closest to the construction.The beach/lagoon is manmade...dont be fooled. This beach wasnt here before the Hiltons made their mark.I travel regularly...and stay in this type of hotel as a regular customer, for business. Im really working on figuring out a different hotel to stay at next time I go to Honolulu..(in 3 weeks). I'll keep you posted on the one I pick next time, it wont be the Hilton Hawaiian Village.  
<Date>Sep 19, 2006

<Author>Ashguy77
<Content>Loved the Hilton, here are some tips for you! We recently stayed for a weekend at the HHV. I used my Hilton points for this stay and since I am a Diamond member, the very friendly lady at the check-in (check in counters by the way are in the open next to the pool...very different than I've been used to) upgraded us to a nice corner room on the 27th Floor in the Rainbow tower with 2 Balconies (one facing the marina and the other facing directly over the beach). We were Wowed by the view once we entered the room! She called it a Specialty room!Some things we noticed:*The pool is crowded and free chairs were rare after 10 am* I received Breakfast coupons (after I asked for them) so if you are Gold/Diamond Hilton member, don't forget these!! We ate our breakfasts at 10 am in the Tapa Cafe, others are closed by this time, very nice Guava Juice, Fruits and Cold cereals* The hotel area is nice with designer shops, penguins, colorful fishes and birds!* They charge extra for additional coffee in the room, restaurants are very expensive, Parking is $16 or $19 personal or Valet* The walk to Ala Moana Blvd stoplight is 5 mins and there you will find a good Thai place ($15 per dish diagonal right), Chinese and Sushi places, turn right and walk a block to the Cheese Burger place or turn left and walk 2 blocks to MacDonalds, Subway, Italian or Chinese places. * We rented from Alamo Car, they are 2 blocks left on Ala Moana, you don't need a car while you are at Hilton unless you want to leave Waikiki to explore, there are buses and trolleys and most activities you book will pick you up at the Hotel* The Fireworks were great in front of the Balcony on Friday night* I didn't think the Friday Jubilee Celebrations (They charge $10 for Poolside seating) was that good* The Beach is great, walk a bit towards left (east) on the beach and you'll see better bargains on rentals ($30 for all day Umbrella and 2 Chairs)We loved it there! It is quite commercial but hey, everyone is having a good time and no one is trying to sell you anything except the Hilton Vacation Clubs! Here is a photo from our room! Enjoy your stay!  
<Date>Sep 13, 2006

<Author>WaterEnthusiasts
<Content>HHV was great We spent the bulk of our vacation on Maui and then used a one-night Hilton reward stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village, to have two days and one night on Oahu before flying back to the Mainland. I was a little concerned about the fact that HHV had not been given either a Solid Gold or a Gem in Oahu Revealed, but I had no need to worry, as the HHV treated us well in every way. The room was immaculate and comfortable, as were all other parts of the facility. All staff (front desk, bellmen, cleaning ladies, restaurant workers, pool staff) were polite and competent. They seemed to be laundering pool towels like mad. Waikiki is not everyone's cup of tea. I can see how a huge, hustle-bustle Waikiki facility, and the inevitable crowds that go along with it, are not for everyone. In general, we prefer quiet, low-key, uncrowded destinations, but it was fun to have two days of glitz and glamour. HHV is not a serene, intimate haven worlds apart from Waikiki. To the contrary, it is Waikiki writ large -- big and bold and decorated within an inch of its life, with people photographing themselves by the penguins and flamingoes. But for what it is, it was running like a very well-oiled machine when we were there, and with surprisingly friendly people. The people who offered daytime lei making, hula lessons, etc. for kids in the bar off the main lobby also seemed very nice. I was surprised to find the aloha spirit that I did, in such a big, busy, urban place. We do not enroll our kids in hotel daycamps, but as hotel guests, my daughter and I were able to drop in and partake of these simple activities together for 20 minutes or so, as we wished, free of charge. This enhanced the day for her. We put ourselves behind the eight ball for dinner by enjoying the sunset while bodysurfing, and then heading out to the restaurants with the rest of the crowds, dragging hungry kids who could not endure a long wait. This was our fault, not Waikiki's. We went a few hotels down the beach to the Shore Bird, but the wait was too long, so we ended up out of desperation at Round Table Pizza at the HHV. Suffice it to say that if you live in one of the Italian-American capitals of New Jersey, you do not need Round Table Pizza. Our full American buffet breakfast at the HHV Rainbow Lanai was great -- good food, prompt and attentive service, nice location. We learned our lesson and got downstairs early for breakfast! HHV has a nice, extremely wide section of Waikiki beach, and because it's located on the western end of Waikiki, we had minimal difficulty getting to and from the airport. We found it an easy beach walk to the rest of Waikiki. The surfboard rental concessionaire in front of the HHV seems overpriced, so we went down the beach where competition seems to have lowered the rates. We checked out of our room by 11 a.m., packed a beach bag, stored our luggage, and spent the rest of the day at the pool and beach. By 4:30 p.m., we needed to use the HHV courtesy room to dress for our redeye flight home. We had reserved the room the night before, as you are told to do. At first, I was a little taken aback to find that they did not have a locker room for this purpose, as we have used at the Southampton Princess in Bermuda. They have an unbooked guest room. You go to the front desk for the key, and they tell you where it is. They gave us a 90 minute slot to use it. The woman explained that they list a series of departing guests to use it throughout the day, and that the chambermaids try to clean it between usages, or that they mostly clean it. I took a good outdoor shower in my swimsuit before I went up, not knowing what to expect, and figuring I could at least change in it. We found it immaculate, with fresh complementary toiletries and a chambermaid hovering nearby in the hall. If I were going to Waikiki again, I would gladly return to HHV.  
<Date>Sep 9, 2006

<Author>sgsilva
<Content>Enjoyed our stay I have been to Waikiki at least a dozen times. First on many trips with my family while growing-up and later on my own. I have always stayed at either the Moana or Royal Hawaiian. This time however, my partner  I deceided to stay at the HHV for free using my partners Hilton Honors points. Besides being free, I was curious about the 'other side' of Waikiki. We were upgraded to the top floor of the Rainbow tower and had a spectacular ocean view. The resort is huge, a city onto itself. The Mandara Spa is excellent. Service was pleasent enough and the food slightly better than ok. The HHV in many ways reminds me of resorts on the other islands with its many pools and winding paths through tropical gardens. There are extensive fish ponds, as well as flamingos, penquins and parrots. The beach is wider and calmer than at the other end of waikiki. The only thing that irked me was that it cost $50/day for two lounge chairs and an umbrella on the beach. Though with a free room I really can't complain. Though I was used to them being free at the Moana and Royal Hawaiian. The beach bar also wasn't especially nice compared to my stays at the other hotels. The HHV is kinda far away from all of the nightlife and action of Waikiki so we found ourselves aking cabs frequently, though this might be a plus for some people.To sum it up, the HHV is a nice choice and I would consider staying there again even if I had to pay full price.  
<Date>Sep 7, 2006
