<Author>AlohaFromCA
<Content>Just As I Remembered! Excellent! This property is just beautiful. Our family trip went as planned, we had a fabulous time. This was my 5th trip to this resort but my family's very first time. My husband and 2 daughters, 13  8 loved my surprise of a limo and lei greeting, although I was slightly disappointed in the small, carnation lei's that we paid for in advance, and there were no cold drinks in the limo either. Not a good way to start the trip, but they didn't care, so neither did I. Check-in was very busy but being HHonors member we were able to check in quickly. We had a breathtaking view from our Rainbow Tower Diamond Head 27th floor balcony, unbelievable! That was the closest we have ever been to fireworks, it was like we could reach up and touch them. My kids were in awe.Yes, food prices are higher than we are used to, but we knew this in advance and along with the Entertainment Book we had no problems. Hey, you're in Hawaii! I figure if you can't afford the food at the resort it's best to stay somewhere else in the first place. Although we dined at just about every restaurant on site, our family favorites were Hatsuhana Japanese Cafe and Lapperts Ice Cream shop, and of course, we spent lots of money at the ABC store. Our last night at Benihana's was so much fun, my daughters loved it and the food was delicious. Our favorite breakfast was the yummy all-you-can-eat banana pancakes with Coconut syrup at Wailana (?) coffee shop across the street from the hotel. The food court at the Ala Moana shopping center has many different types of food and was a great people-watching spot. Speaking of shopping, the Ala Moana is a destination itself. Spent WAY too much moolah there! Most fun was the Hawaiian Adventure Water Park, getting belted by the waves at the Bonzai Pipeline, the Dinner Cruise on the Navatek and the Paradise Cove Luau. I had been to this particular luau a few times before, just let me say they have GREATLY improved it. The grounds are cleaner, it seems more organized, but it was so hot we were melting after dark, with no breeze. We happen to be on Oahu during the King K's Celebration so we had a lot of free entertainment, parades, hula competitions, etc...We spent a lot of time at the beach and the Super Pool. My 8 yr old had a blast meeting new friends from all over the world. All in all, everyone at the resort were friendly, service was perfect, weather was perfect, it was a wonderful memory maker for us. We already have reservations for next June, same tower. We wouldn't dream of staying anywhere else.  
<Date>Sep 7, 2006

<Author>BereanBabes
<Content>HHV Has It All! What a beautiful resort! This place as everything you could need and more. We really enjoyed our stay here. My husband uses a wheelchair and we were able to get around without any problems. Our accomodations were nice, the beds are so comfortable and the views were outstanding. We stayed in the Rainbow and Tapa Towers. The super pool was crowded, but we were able to get chairs around 9AM. The Tapa pool was nice also especially at night, no one was there. The beach and beach walk were great. There were beach performers twirling fire a few evenings. We love the fireworks, but we lost our camera and no one turned it in. We ate breakfast one time each at the Rainbow Lanai and Tapa Cafe and twice for dinner at the Rainbow Lanai. The food was good, in fact the Penne Pasta was my husbands favorite meal all week. We rented a car and used valet parking. Our only problem was that the valet's lost our key, it actually broke off and the valet did not notice it was missing. The valet supervisor was very helpful and we were able to get another car from Hertz (on the property). This is a great place for families and is very busy. I did notice alot of business (convention) people there also. There were a few times I could hear the construction noise, but it did not bother us. All in all I would recommend the HHV.  
<Date>Sep 5, 2006

<Author>MikekNZ
<Content>Good but what do you expect for the price Hard to rank something like this - if you take on the hotel, the facilites, the services , the location then its clearly 5/5 however once you add in the cost and value becomes a concern it begins to drop. Spent 10 days at the HHV in the Tapa tower (28th Floor) and it was a great stay - room was large and had a side room with bar etc in - view at that height was mainly of the city but very pleasant - room was what you would expect and like others have noted the bed was exceptionally comfortable. The facilites were top notch - well manicured etc etc Beach was average - sand is very strange like dirt it is much nicer along the other end but no matter The super pool well is not that super its not especially big and is especially packed all day untill 5.30 - given it gets dark about 9 or later its way to early. The hotel is packed basically - apparently up to 7000 people on site anyone time, and you feel it - the abc store and main walkways are often packed like the central city - the tour pickup area is smallish and chaotic almost all day - of course this is no big deal but if your after solitude then go elsewhere and that goes for practically everywhere in waikikiBiggest downside is that everything is very expensive and the service in the resturants/bars - pretty average - i understand tipping is a custom but most of the time it was pretty undeserved - i sat in one resturant for at least 20 mins without service or even acknowledgement - and at least 2 other tables of people walked out while i was waiting. Drinks and food are expensive so if cost is an issue then go offsite, plenty of options nearby - the friday night show was good but once again best seats are for sale but there are plenty of other areas to stand around. Overall a good experience, i probbably would not go back but thats mainly because i like new experiences - if you want a all inclusive resort with lots of things happening and not wanting to leave then this would be a good option - if you want solitude or just a room to sleep while your out and about then its probbably not worth the cost.  
<Date>Sep 5, 2006

<Author>Matt777
<Content>A Great Place To Stay I recently visited the HHV for a total of 11 nights and stayed at three different towers.Upon entering the property, you can tell you've entered a contained resort and not just a 'hotel'. The grounds were well maintained, beautiful flora and fauna, a lot of history and of course, the beach. I will leave the beach review out..as it is just as everyone else says...crowded. If you come to Oahu for the sun and sand..drive to Kailua and Lanikai and you will be pleasantly amused and pleased at the tame-ness of the waves.The Kalia Tower was excellent and so was the service. We were tired on most nights as we kept to California time (up at 6am and out for activities by 9am...therefore tired by 8/9pm). I brought my laptop and paid the daily $12.95 unlimited 24 hour use. I had Slingbox on my computer and watched all the A's and Giants game real time and I was not limited to the channels in the room. The in-room dining was excellent..and the side of fruit (versus chips) they served was usually our breakfast.We moved to the Rainbow Tower which was our least favorite. The shower was a bit dingy and needed caulking, but overall, still okay. Great ocean view. The lobby was too crowded for me. Good for tourists, not great if you're there for business or romance. A two star room, versus a 3+ star Kalia room. The great thing was that we were able to watch the fireworks Friday night from our lanai.Part 3 of our stay was at the Ali'i Tower which was amazing. Comfort wise, it was just as cool as the Kalia tower, but this tower had free finger food at 5pm and for us, that was good enough so that we did not have to have big dinners. The concierge was very helpful. They had a little tv in the bathroom area which was cool but we didn't really use it. On one of the days, our room was not made because we left the Do Not Disturb switch on (but we had brought in the door sign). I guess this confused the cleaning lady. I asked her to clean the room and she did but she did not wipe off the bath (i'll deduct points for that). They had slippers that had a Sanitized sign on it..which we did not use since it meant someone else used it. I suggest that if the slippers are a perk, let it be a giveaway. No one wants to use someone else's feet paraphernalia. At least you know the robes go through a good wash.All in all, this was a fabulous hotel that I hightly recommend. At the Rainbow Tower, they don't offer you robes unless you call and ask for them. They were delivered immediately.The people were friendly and courteous and full of the island's aloha spirit. Reading reviews here made me nervous about my trip but I was more than pleased...in fact...I was tremendously happy with the hotel overall and would definitely come back and definitely recommend it.I would rate this a 4 star hotel overall. Aside from the fact that there are a lot of people...(it's a big hotel!!) if you venture out and plan ahead...you find that you don't have to dish out money ...there are a lot of eateries, beaches, historical sites, etc. A lot of stimulation if you want or none if you don't. You will ultimately make your own stay what it will be. This hotel has it all / offers everything. Don't be afraid to ask. They will give it to you with a smile.  
<Date>Aug 29, 2006

<Author>bplw2008
<Content>Absolutely Disgusted I booked my holiday for early December this year, back in March, I have paid the final deposits this week, and finalised my trip. My Travel Agent was contacted today requesting that both myself and my partner fill out and sign disclosure forms, agreeing to not complain or request compensation for renovation works that the resort is currently under going.Furthermore, it also includes a statement saying that if during the time we are there, there are no rooms avaliable to us due to these works that any cost in relocating us to another resort would be at our expense... I am absolutely disgusted to think that I have paid out so much money, to be given this treatment... Also I would love to know why neither myself or my travel agent were told about these renovations at any point along the booking until after it has all been finalised. It shows extremely bad business practise on behalf of the resorts operators and leaves me feeling completely ripped off! I am now looking into cancelling my holiday and finding another location.I hope that this can help other travellers before you make the mistake that I have made by booking a holiday to this resort.

<Author>REDWINE2212
<Content>Fabulous!!!! Just returned from a 2 week stay at the HHV and had fantastic holiday. We were upgraded to a suite in the Rainbow tower and could not fault the room, view or service.Fortunately for us the exchange rate was very good so everything in the hotel was very reasonably priced (with the exception of wine). Quality and standard of food, service, etc very good.Don't worry about getting sunbed at Superpool (they start to queue at 8.00 am for these) there's always beds available upto about 11.00 at the Tapa Tower Pool and the Mandara Spa Pool is always nice and quiet if you prefer a more relaxing atmosphere. Beach is also good not as crowded as I expected.ABC store on site always very busy - use the once across the road.Don't sign up for any organised excursions its really easy to get about on your own. Enjoyed most things we did but there were one or two things that were enjoyable but weren't value for money; Sea Life Park unless you want to swim with the Dolphins there's not a lot there and it was expensive - don't waste your money. 3 Star dinner cruise food and entertainment was good however you leave about 5pm and you're back about 7.30 pm evening is too short and very expensive - once again not value for money. Polynesian Centre good if you've got kids and unless you enjoy hands on and joining in on activities not worth paying the money for.Must see's Pearl Harbour (get there early we were there at 9.00 and still had a 2.5 hour wait), Battle Ship Missouri, Bowfish Submarine,Punchbowl (very interesting and excellent views of Oahu, Paradise Cove Luau, Bishop's Musuem, Diamond Head Crater - a bit of climb but not as bad as it looks worth the walk excellent views. Hire a car and and drive along the coast - gorgeous beaches and scenery.Good restaurants - Cheescake factory (get there early), Keo's (Thai Food book a table), Hula Grill (book a table), Hard RockCafe (no need to book). Best steak the Chart House next door to HHV on the marina - excellent and reasonably priced.Evening entertainment Sociey of Seven good show a little expensive.Had fantastic holiday, this is the first time we've used Trip Advisor and we got some excellent tips.Can't wait to go back.  
<Date>Aug 27, 2006

<Author>vicgreenak
<Content>I love this great resort!!!!! To us, HHV is the finest resort we have ever seen. No other resort, we have ever seen has the ambience of HHV. I have seen resorts that are at least as glamorous, but the heart and soul of HHV goes way beyond glamor. For those who shun Waikiki because of the crowds, I can say that I have never seen crowds on the fine stretch of beach. I would have to say that my favorite part of staying at HHV is the open lobby -- especially at night, when live entertainment is playing. For those who have a different taste in music, there is always at least one band playing in each of the towers, so anyone can find live music that they can enjoy. We always think of HHV as the perfect resort: perfect for a first trip to Hawaii, perfect for returning vacationers, perfect for weddings, perfect for anniversaries. There are many beautiful exotic resorts, but there is only one Hilton Hawaiian Village.

<Author>gaz330ci
<Content>Aloha!! Well what did you expect? Stayed here for 6 nights on the second leg of our honeymoon(after Vegas).Got upgraded to the Ali'i tower when we checked in at the airport free of charge when they were told it was our honeymoon.Very nice.Private pool+spa,gym and free hor'douves(hope i spelt that correctly)every night.Could not have been closer to the beach,lovely room done in a very tasteful colonial type style+easily the most comfortable bed we have ever slept in! An absolutly beautiful resort with tropical gardens and a vast array of wildlife in and around the waterfalls etc. Only complaint was a lack of a proper beachside bar,but we went a couple of hotels down to the Outrigger,who have a great one,so no real problem at all.Liked it so much my friend is getting married there in September.

<Author>iwanttogoonholiday
<Content>Didn't want to leave.... Like most other people we had read a lot of mixed reviews about the Hilton, but then we've read mixed reviews from other places we've stayed in and loved, so we figured there are always going to be people who'll complain about the incidentals and you're never going to please all the people all the time, so we'd stick with our choice - and we're glad we did.Coming from England, this was obviously quite a big trip for us (parents and 2 'kids' in their early 20's) so we had a quite long stay of 17 nights. This was our first trip to Hawaii and we wanted to make the most of it (and make the 24hr travel worthwhile!)Overall we loved our stay. The grounds are beautiful and despite being such a massive hotel you didn't feel too cramped. It was a lovely place to walk around. Being right on the world famous Waikiki beach was obviously a big plus too. Having walked almost the entire length of Waikiki (to go to the Sunset on the beach movie) we reckon that the Hilton enjoyed one of the largest areas of beach, and with few other hotels in the area, there was plenty of space for everyone.Being away from the main Waikiki crowd meant that access in and out of the HHV was probably easier than at other hotels. We had a hire car for our entire stay and liked to make the most of it.While the Super Pool closes around 5.30, the Tapa pool is open til 10 meaning we enjoyed several evening swims after a day out exploring the island - a lovely way to end the day!We had booked 2 partial ocean view rooms and actually ended up being upgraded to full ocean view (Diamond Head Tower 9th floor) because they were unable to put our two rooms nearby in partial views. If we had booked for full ocean view, we may have been a bit disappointed, but as it was, the views were lovely, and being able to sit and have breakfast on your balcony overlooking the Pacific certainly is a good way to start the day (the view of the beach was just slightly obscured by the Hale Koa next door and all the hundreds of palm trees lining the beach - not that that was a problem with us!!) It's definitely worth buying breakfast items from the ABC store or Walmart etc, as it saves you so much money that can be better spent elsewhere! (oh and by the way, we didn't find Hawaii to be as expensive as everyone makes out, just don't stay onsite the entire time - enjoy the whole island!!)As mentioned previously, we spent a lot of our time out exploring the island - it's not that often we get to drive on a highway by the ocean in the tropics! On the whole we loved Oahu. Particular favourites were the Ko Olina lagoons (OK they're man made, but they're beautiful and have that 'picture perfect' look you're after! Make sure you stop at the security booth for a beach pass - after driving further up the coast we realised why they do this - let's just say, Ko Olina is definitely the nicest spot on the Waianae side!) We also loved Ala Moana beach park which is really convenient from the Hilton - and plenty of free parking (as with much of the rest of the island - except Waikiki!). As the beach is backed by a park, there are plenty of lovely trees around if you fancy a bit of shade. Also at Ala Moana is the shopping centre which is definitely worth a look (especially if you're from the UK and any American shops become that much more interesting!) We also enjoyed a couple of fun and yummy meals at the Bubba Gump restaurant here.We spent a couple of days headed up to North Shore - unfortunately not the right time of year for the world famous surfing, but pretty cool to visit nonetheless, and easier to take a dip in the ocean without drowning! Waimea was very pretty - and completely different to the surf beach image it has - more like a mill pond in summer! Fun to watch all the people jumping from the rocks. We also visited Sunset and Turtle beaches. Turtle beach is definitely worth a visit - but not for a whole day or to swim. Come here to visit the turtles who'll let you take a look if they're feeling nice! We stopped by here 3 times and there were turtles on the beach twice, so I guess we were pretty lucky. It was pretty cool to see these massive prehistoric looking creatures make their way to shore - just don't get too close! Just up the road is Ted's bakery - a favourite of Dad's! Recommend any baked goods! Especially the haupia pie! Mmm...A couple of beaches worth mentioning on the Windward side are Lanikai and Kahlua - gorgeous turquoise seas and off shore islands - good to make the folks back home jealous!!Trips out: Pearl Harbour and Diamond Head are definitely worthwhile. Just be prepared to wait a while at Pearl Harbour - get there as early as possible or you may not be able to get a boat over - the day we went they had given all the passes out by about 11. We arrived around 9.30 and had a couple of hours before our trip. Very poignant though. (We would like to respectfully point out that Pearl Harbour marked the USA's entry to WW2 - not the beginning of the war - we were there a few years earlier!)So, all in all had a great time. Just a few niggles about the hotel:1. Front desk and valet can be a little abrupt verging on rude at times - you can be ignored by front desk, or pounced upon as soon as a valet sees you, even if you're just pulling over to pick someone up.2. The Super Pool. It really was a lovely setting, right by the beach, but nowhere near enough chairs for everyone to enjoy it. People seem to get there earlier, dump a towel on the chair and leave it for most of the day while they go off to eat etc, meaning that if you actually want to use the pool area, there is nowhere to go. There needs to be some control on how long things are left. We managed to spend some time there (one quite early start to get in line!) but not as much as we'd have liked. Still, we enjoyed using the Tapa pool instead - much more convenient.3. Charges. As everyone says, the HHV do like to extract the maximum cash from your wallet. We had no problems with charging for extra coffee - you get a sachet free per day which easily makes 2 cups (how much coffee do you need?!?) but we did object to the $16/day to park - especially as there appeared to be too many places set aside for valet or reserved for 'special' events etc. The cost for loungers and parasols on the beach is crazy so we came prepared - 2 sand chairs and 2 parasols from Walmart for about $35 for our entire stay - quite a bargain!!So, to sum it up, we loved Oahu and would recommend staying at the HHV - just make sure you don't spend all your time there, or you'll miss out on what this beautiful island has to offer!  
<Date>Aug 20, 2006

<Author>Samsie
<Content>Ali'i Tower and HHW overview We visited the HHW for 11 nights and this time around stayed in the Ali'i Tower. This part of the facility has its own reception area for checking in. Although arriving late at night, the front desk staff present were very helpful and we were soon settled into our room. My son (age 7) had a sofa bed to sleep on and he found this very comfortable. I understand that the rooms in this particular tower were all refurbished within the last year.The swimming pool at the Ali'i Tower is nice to swim in and is all at one depth (4ft 3inches). The pool itself never felt overcrowded although the majority of the seats surrounding the pool were reserved by towels and not people. There is key access to Ali'i Tower guests to the beach from the swimming pool area.Some of the massage services on offer at the Mandara Spa are also available at the Ali'i Tower. The Ali'i Tower has two massage rooms; these are both well maintained but both rooms are windowless. I would agree with comments made regarding the chairs at the Superpool; there aren;t enough of them to go around for everyone who wishes to use the pool. It also closes at 5.30pm each evening.We saw the fireworks on Friday night (the HHW have a fireworks display every Friday evening) and they were spectacular. Many people were watching the display from the beach (and a nice view of same can also be obtained from the pool terrace at the Ali'i Tower).The HHW has plenty of shops and restaurants to suit all budgets. The phonecards available from the ABC store represent great value for money and give plenty of talk time for both domestic (US based) and international calls.Our son used the Keiki/kids club at the HHW and enjoyed his half day there with the HHW carers at the zoo. Parents need to book this a few days in advance; the book for reserving such a place for the child is placed near to the excursions desk just off the lobby area (I mention this as it took us a little while to locate it).I note that the main lobby area now has express check in services. We enjoyed our holiday very much at the HHW and will return one day!.  
<Date>Aug 19, 2006

<Author>kimjim
<Content>Overcrowded and not worth the price You will not find a chair at any of the pools if you do not get to the pools at the crack of dawn and you have to pay $12 for a chair at the beach. We called maintainance twice, but no one ever came to the room to fix the hook behind the bathroom door and the loud exhaust fan. One day, when we got back to the room around 5p, we had to call housekeeping to make the room. They came about 2 hours later. The grounds are nice with penguins, restaurants, and shops, but the rooms are only so-so. Friends on our trip stayed at other hotels closer to Diamond Head and had a much better experience.

<Author>Jfeasel
<Content>Great Resort Hotel! 11 of us stayed in 4 rooms Aug. 3-5. We were in the Ali'i Tower. WOW. The beds were the most comfortable hotel beds we'd ever slept in. I had 4 people in my room and we had plenty of room with a great view of the big pool. The Ali'i Tower has free appetizers from 5pm-7pm on the second floor pool deck which was a bonus, plus this tower has it's own pool, whirlpool and workout area. There is a conceirge on the first floor that is very helpful and helped us make dinner and golf reservations.The restaurants in this hotel can be pricey, but if you walk a couple of blocks down Ala Moana (left) you'll come to McDonald's, Starbucks, Outback and the Ala Moana mall that has lots of places to eat. There's also a 24 hour coffee shop across Ala Moana from the hotel that was good.The beach area is nice, but chairs are expensive so go to the ABC store and buy a cheap chair or a beach mat. We highly recommend this resort!  
<Date>Aug 15, 2006

<Author>slamdunk09
<Content>Great spot We just returned from first trip to Hawaii and the HHV. Overall, we were impressed with the property. The grounds are lovely and the pools are nice--much nicer than most of the other hotels we saw in Waikiki. Waikiki itself is very crowded, and the HHV is no exception. It really did seem like a village. We were at the Kalia tower, which I highly recommend as it provided a nice quiet respite from the crowds and has its own pool and check-in. Rooms were new and lovely. Service was very good. Biggest negative was that the super pool closed at 5:30 each evening. Given that this is a family resort, this early of a pool closure seemed ridiculous. Pool always seemed crowded, and as others have noted, chairs are almost impossible to find. If we return to Oahu, we would stay here again.

<Author>BayernFan
<Content>Lagoon tower overpriced..... spotty service Arrived 8/2/06. The water had been out that day, but had been restored by the time we checked in. But the AC was out, and wasn't restored till late in the evening. And when it was, the bedroom AC vents did not work well. I was told by staff that bedrooms in the Lagoon tower were like that, and that they receive many complaints about that. I was looking forward to the Duke lagoon that was right outside of the hotel, but it was closed because of the construction of a new hotel tower, which is scheduled to be completed in 2009. So you can look at the lagoon, but that is it. And the construction noises go on all day... but since I was busy anyway, that didn't bother me much. However, the construction crew did break a water main the morning we were to check out... so no water or showers for us as we were preparing for the 12 hour travel home.The first day we did not receive housekeeping. We inquired about it when we got back from our daily activities, but we were told that housekeeping leaves at 4pm. We went to the main registration lobby at the hotel to complain, and they sent hotel housekeeping to do our room that night.The hike to the beach is long (which is why I was looking forward to the lagoon).... two chaise lounges and an umbrella cost 51 bucks a day. But if you rent them for the duration of your stay, they will set them up for you in the front row and reserve them for you in the morning.. The super pool closes early, and the lagoon tower pool and hot tub closes at 7pm.As expected, you are nickel and dimed a lot there. At 500 a night though, I was hoping for better service and less extra charges for stuff.The beach is nice, the staff is friendly, and you really don't have to leave the resort for anything. As expected, the food at the hotel restaurants is pricey. For me and 2 kids, pizza at the pool and three drinks (one for me and 2 sodas for hte kids) was over 60 bucks. Dinner for 2 adults and two kids will set you back over 150 bucks.We took a Grand circle Island tour with a stop at the Dole plantation which was very nice. Very good tour guide named Ed, around 66 years old. Very knowledgable and informative. The Tapa tower bus depot was very convenient and well run for the tours we took.If you are going to rent a car, don't wait in line at the Hertz desk for a half hour only to be told there are no cars available that day. Instead, walk to Ala Moana Blvd, turn left and walk a block to Alamo at discovery bay shopping center. No waiting. But watch the 70 dollar charge for letting them fill up the tank upon return. They tell you that they will fill up the tank at 3 fifteen a gallon (10 cents cheaper than what the stations are charging) and then try to slip the 70 dollar charge past you for that service. Save the 70 bucks and fill it up yourself.We rented a car and it was nice to have that freedom to go about the island. We went to Pearl, Diamond Head Crater, Huamauna Bay for snorkeling (a must do---it is only 5 bucks a person but breathtaking), and drove to the North Shore.About Pearl.... there are three things there.... the AZ Memorial. The Bowfin Sub and Museum, and the USS Missouri. In the morning ALL the tour groups show up at the AZ Memorial at 7 am and the lines last 60-90 minutes to get in. By 11 am, they are gone. So around noon is hte time to show up in your rental to get right in, and have plenty of time and space to look at the museum and stuff before you go out on the launch. As for the Bowfin and the Mighty Mo, you could easily spend 3 hours at each location. That is what we did. We went out to Pearl three times. One for each of the attractions. Had a great time with no waiting.We really enjoyed the Todai Japanese Seafood buffet at the intersection of Kallii and Ala Moana. Anyway.. the lagoon tower was OK. It was comparable to some other 1br suites w/ kitchen we stayed in in say Florida. However, for the 500 bucks a night, hte service was spotty and we paid about twice as much as compared to similar facilities elsewhere on the mainland.  
<Date>Aug 14, 2006

<Author>dmc123
<Content>Great hotel We stayed at the HHV at the beginning of August for our Wedding Anniversary, it is a lovely hotel and very impressive upon arrival. The grounds are fantastic, with the penguins and flamingos.When we arrived at the hotel I told them it was our Wedding Anniversary and they offered a room upgrade straight away with no charge even though the hotel was at its maximum capacity, this did mean it had to be cleaned and we had to wait 3 hours but we went and ate and had a walk around while they stored our luggage. It was well worth the wait the room was in the Rainbow Tower on the 27th Floor with an ocean view 鈥?it was absolutely fantastic 鈥?the only thing I could say for the first few minutes was WOW. The only downside is that you do have to pay for the tea and coffee and even bottled water in the room whereas most hotels this is complimentary. But we just took others advice and went to the ABC store and bought them all for a lot less. It is definitely in the best area of Waikiki, we walked the length of the beach up to the main area and the beach is a lot narrower there and obviously more crowded, it can get a little busy directly in front of the hotel, but if you turn right then it is a little quieter there but the beach attendants aren鈥檛 allowed to put umbrellas down that area so there won鈥檛 be any shade, but we didn鈥檛 mind this. The sunbeds are expensive to rent 25$ for the 2 all day, but only being there for 5 days we didn鈥檛 mind that 鈥?we did buy 2 airbeds to start with which was only 7$ and sat on those the first day which is a cheaper way of doing it and you see lots of people with the same idea. We sometimes like to sit by the pool but there was no way I was queuing up in a morning by the pool until it opened to get a lounger, it was then in complete shade by the afternoon anyway. We watched from the balcony as they opened the pool and it was funny, as we literally watched them run for the sunbeds!!!The weather was a bit mixed, a couple of days the sun didn鈥檛 burn the cloud off until 11.30 and then by 4pm it was cloudy again but in between these times it was scorching hot! So if you like the sun don鈥檛 take shade and plan on coming back out when it is cooler as you may have missed the sun by then!!We ate both out of the resort and in the restaurants on the resort and yes they are expensive but not ridiculously. The Italian Sergio鈥檚 was fantastic and a lovely atmosphere. We went to Duke鈥檚 which is at the Outrigger Hotel, lovely place and the food was great but had an hour wait which didn鈥檛 bother us we bought drinks while we waited, although beware they have a silly rule there where they only sell you 1 drink per person that is at the bar i.e. my husband couldn鈥檛 go to the bar and buy our drinks they would only serve him his own drink, so we both had to go each time we wanted a drink, they call it stacking!!! We had a fab time, but Hawaii is not what I expected, Waikiki is very commercialised and is just like any other busy American city, but when you are on the beach you seem to forget all that. It is quite handy knowing there are loads of shops close by, where you know you can buy anything. The jewellery there is gorgeous and a really good buy. I think if we had stayed on a quieter island I am sure it would have been the tropical place you imagine it to be, but Waikiki is a lovely place, just expect it to be busy.Hope you find this helpful.  
<Date>Aug 14, 2006

<Author>HappyTraveler01
<Content>What a rip off!!! Just returned from a two week vacation in Oahu and Maui of which our last three nights were spent at the HHV due to its proximity to the airport. The resort is great in terms of it's location, variety of shops and restaurants. However, these traits are overshadowed by how the hotel and staff try to nickel and dime you on everything. For charging you $4 for a bag of coffee to use with the coffee pot in your room to .50 cents for a cup of water by the pool! It's ridiculous!!! In addition, there are 5 towers with one timeshare tower for a total of 6 and 3000 rooms among them but only 2 pools!!! There are no extra chairs so people end up laying out their towels on floor next to the pool to sit or lay down. The hotel caters to the Japanese with their strong yen currency and is very evident in their pricing structure. There are better places to stay in Oahu but i wouldn't want that place to get overcrowded!!!  
<Date>Aug 13, 2006

<Author>slick1979
<Content>Hilton is overrated We stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian hotel for one week. I thought being at a resort would provide us with the amenities we needed since I took my elderly mother and three teenagers. What a mistake!First, it took us an hour to check in. I spent half an hour in line and the other half at the desk. I have never had a more complicated check-in at any hotel and I have travelled extensively. They had the reservation, so that wasn't the problem. They required driver's licenses for the adults who were responsible for each room (even though I was paying for all rooms with a single credit card) and required the names of each person staying in the room. They argued with me about the bed arrangements; I needed two rooms with two beds and one with one bed, which seemed beyond the comprehension of the desk clerk.When we got to the room, there was no water. There was a construction problem and the entire hotel was affected. I called the manager who told me that the desk clerk was supposed to have told us, but that didn't happen. I was also told they did not know when the water would be restored. I requested a move to the only tower which had water (there are five at this hotel) and was told I would get a lower quality room. I elected not to move and tried to get to another hotel. There was a convention (which I was attending) and rooms were scarce. We elected to stay and the hotel finally made an adjustment on the bill .The property, while beautiful, is huge and hard to navigate, particularly for my mother who has some difficulty walking. There are only three available pools, unless you stay in the Ali'i tower, which has its own private pool for its guests. (we were not in that tower). There is no adult pool, so there is no quiet place to enjoy the sun. The main pool, close to our room, has people lining up at least 30 minutes before it opens to secure chairs. I don't want to be on vacation at a resort where I have to line up to sit in the sun.Unlike every other hotel I have ever stayed in, this hotel did not have any information about activities in the city. There were no brochures of any kind. They had a desk to book outside excursions through the hotel (e.g. Pearl Harbor), or activities on premises, but nothing else. You had to know what you wanted to do before going to the desk. This desk had several people there, but they would not make a dinner reservation for you if it was not on the property. There was a single concierge to do that. With a hotel housing thousands of people, this was very odd. The purpose is to keep you on the property and to spend all your money there.Also, while I expected things to be expensive, I felt as though Hilton went out of its way to make it ridiculously expensive. It felt like gouging. To rent just a beach chair for the day was $36. Just next door, at a local vendor, the rental for two beach chairs and an umbrella was $12. One packet of coffee in the room was complimentary; every pot after that cost $3.75. Even simple meals were outrageous. (It was actually cheaper to order the breakfast buffet than to order toast, juice and coffee). We weren't allowed to sit in a patio area near the pool unless we ordered something from the bar/cafe. I've paid less at the Plaza Hotel in New York and the Ritz-Carlton in San Francisco. Our reservations included a dining credit for each room which we were told would be taken off the bill upon check out. Yet on the last morning, our final bill was put under the door, and did not have the credit posted. When I checked out (another half hour at the desk), I asked about the credit and received it. I believe that Hilton deliberately does not give the credit unless you ask; I'm sure there are many people who forget to ask and just leave without insuring this credit is given.There are also no quiet places to sit and enjoy a drink or watch the sunset in the evening. Every bar/cafe has some sort of musical group; there is no way to avoid it. The restaurants are quiet enough, but I like being outside in the evening and we just could not do that. The pool areas are all closed in the evening, so that's not an option.I felt that most of the staff (with a few exceptions) was indifferent to the needs of the guests. I believe this is part of the corporate mindset. At one of the restaurants on the premises, I wanted to put the bill on my room. The way the waitress acted, you'd have thought I was the only person ever to have requested that. I realize she needed to insure that I was indeed a guest of the hotel, but in obtaining information from me, she made me feel as though I was trying to get away with something. Another time when we were at the pool (a small one very far from our rooms, but somewhat quieter than the others), we tried to get a table with an umbrella. The day before there had been several at this location; this day there were only four. When I asked the pool attendant, his answer was that they were doing something with the umbrellas and he didn't know when they would be returned to the area. There was one table near the entrance that had no one sitting at it. Because of the proximity to the building entrance, it was a poor placement, with people constantly running into it. I asked him if he could move the umbrella, since there was a table on the other side without one. He refused, saying there were people using it. (there wasn't anyone at the table and it did not have anything on it) I asked him to call maintenance to get another one. He reluctantly agreed. Finally, another vacationer helped move the umbrella.I felt the attitude of the staff is that they are doing you a favor to do things, even though we paid quite a lot of money for the rooms.I would not stay at this hotel again and will likely not stay at a Hilton again.  
<Date>Aug 10, 2006

<Author>KimDay
<Content>Very nice but quite expensive! Me and me partner stayed in the Diamond Head tower, this hotel was huge!! It had several stores including Louis Vutton! It was very clean and well looked after, staff were friendly but then so are most people in Hawaii. The room was large and cleaned all the time, there was everything you needed in the room. We had a room over looking the tapa pool which was one grade up from the basic rooms, the sunsets where beautiful and the fireworks on Friday nights are worth sticking around for. The only downsides to this hotel were that it was expensive, a cocktail and a beer was around $18 dollars and we didn't eat in the restaurants as they were too expensive for our budget! There were lots of restaurants outside of the hotel, the usual american chains, Outback Steakhouse and Red Lobster are just around the corner. Also the pool was always way too crowded and it was hard to get a seat, for the amount of guests this hotel has and the amount you pay to stay, there should be more swimming pools! All in all the hotel is in a great location and the beach is beautiful, if i was to go back to Hawaii i would go somewhere less commercialised as this is the only major downside. Lots to do in Hawaii!

<Author>FanningAggie
<Content>Great place for kids! We just returned from a 9 day stay at HHV and it was great! We used Hilton Honor points for our stay. Since we are Diamond level Hilton Honors members we were upgraded to a large suite on the 27th floor of the Rainbow Tower with two lanais overlooking the ocean. The view was spectacular! The suite was very large with two full baths which came in handy with the kids. We were also given coupons for a free continental breakfast buffet each day with the option to upgrade to the full buffet for $5 more per adult or $3 more per child over 4. This buffet is normally $21.25/adults and $16.50/children. We really felt like they treated their Diamond members well.The grounds at the hotel are just beautiful with waterfalls and ponds. There are all kinds of fish, penguins, flamingos, etc. on the grounds. The kids really enjoyed this.There are some negatives to this resort. If you are looking for a nice quiet place to stay then this is not for you. It is very busy and crowded. The pool area is very crowded. You can only get a chair by the pool if you get there when the pool opens. We just stayed out on the beach each day instead of fighting the crowd at the pool. The beach area is nice but also got a little crowded at times. The kids didn't mind it though. The hotel is overpriced on a lot of things, but we expected it for Hawaii. The beach umbrella and two chairs cost us $50/day. Valet parking was $19/day - self parking is $16/day. The restaurants are pricey with just average food. We ate most of our meals away from the resort. Bubba Gump' Shrimp in the Ala Moana Shopping Center was our favorite. We did purchase a Hawaii Entertainment Guide for $12.99 before our trip and it had lots of restaurant deals that were great. Most were for buy one get one free meals. There were also lots of deals for most of the attractions. I would hightly recommend this Guide. We do plan on returning to this resort in the future because it is a great place for kids.  
<Date>Aug 4, 2006

<Author>jamesunt
<Content>Love the hotel but eat elsewhere This was our fourth trip to the HHV and it is by far the best hotel on the strip. While everyone knows that Wakiki is busy and city like, the crowds do not bother us because we know we are not on Kauai or Maui. But the beach is great and the pools are fine although one must eat elsewhere unless you are a millionaire.Since we were travelling with a family of four, we could not even consider eating at the hotel. Most meals in the restaurants were upwards of 25 to 45 dollars a piece. Lunch menus saw 13.00 hamburgers and 3.75 sodas. Breakfast buffet was 21.95 each.A family of four would spend more than $250.00 a day on food!We settled for the coffee shop across the street or jumped in our car or a cab to other areas in Waikiki such as the Ward Center or the Mall to partake of more reasonable meals. Dont get me wrong---its a great Hotel and I will stay there again on my next visit----but the cost of food is off the charts (in fact most restaurants were not full when we walked by)

<Author>Traveler_000034
<Content>Here is the deal... Just returned from 8 days at HHV. Overall, a nice place to stay. I was not traveling with kids, but would definitely recommend this hotel to families (lots of kids, made me miss mine!) I pictured the grounds to be much bigger, but actually the towers are very close - you can be around the entire resort in 5 minutes. It is located on the far end of Waikiki Beach (not Waikiki Proper) -- so, the beach is a bit less crowded, and maybe not as pretty. The better bars, restaurants, etc. are down the beach some but an easy walk. Rooms are average, clean and have plenty of room for 2.In general, you have to remember that the Honolulu-area is like many other US cities (except the beautiful beaches and views). It is crowded and commuting is bad. If you get a car (which I highly recommend), you need to leave right after rush hour and be back at the hotel by 4:00 (or wait to 7:30) or you will be sitting in major traffic. Please make sure you don't spend your entire trip in Waikiki - it is nice, but east Oahu is quite nice and has some beautiful beaches and stopping points with great views. My favorite area was the North Beach area... it is what I pictured Hawai'i to be like. Cool, kinda funky, surfer towns, (Haleiwa) with lots of great little casual restaurants and awesome beaches. Everyone seems to recommend Hanauma Bay for snorkeling - it was beautiful, but VERY crowded. Instead, drive up to Sharks Cove on the North Shore. For eating, the resort is fine. The other reviews made it sound so expensive, but it is just like any other resort destination. The pizza place is good for a quick, inexpensive meal. Bali by the Sea is very nice. Loved Roy's Restaurant in East Oahu - great food and great service. Splurged on Alan Wongs (the best restaurant in Honolulu) and was slightly disappointed. Went for the chef's tasting menu with wine ($90/pp).... food was good, service OK, and wine skimpy (desserts were great).Also, if going to Pearl Harbor, it really does pay to get up and leave by 6:00am. The line gets crazy long by 7:30 (tons of buses). Try to go on Wed, so you can visit the memorial and then walk up the street to the Swap Meet at Aloha Stadium- all the Hawaiin trinkets, clothes, jewelry that you see is there and much cheaper. Definitely worth the trip.Have fun, but don't spend your entire trip at the HHV - explore all parts of the island and you'll have a better experience. There is hiking, small, more intimate beaches  lots of food choices throughout the island. Enjoy.  
<Date>Jul 31, 2006

<Author>blevka
<Content>Best Hotel in Waikiki Simply put this hotel is the best in Waikiki! Take it from someone who has been here 5 times over the past 10 years. This is the first time I have stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian and believe me I will look no further and I have stayed at some pretty nice places out there! The landscape is absolutely beautiful with tropical flowers everywhere, waterfalls and the kids will even love the penguins, turtles, flamingos etc. The service was great! The staff was friendly from the time we checked in until the time we checked out and everywhere in between. We stayed in the Kalia Tower and if you have heard stories about the mold in the rooms believe me that is ancient history. They did a renovation about a year or so ago and this is now a very nice tower. This tower even has their own check in and check out services. The only other tower on their premises that has this is the Ali'i Tower. The Super pool is just that. Super!!!! After spending a good day on the beach it is nice to hit the super pool in the late afternoon to get out of the sun. During the later part of the afternoon the super pool is completely shaded which after being in the sun all the day is a good thing. The Hilton Hawaiian does have a reputation of somewhat nickel and diming you to death, but that is if you let them. The smartest thing to do is to eat, shop and spend your money outside of the resort area. There are plenty of nice restaurants and plenty of nices places to shop around the area that are within walking distance. Prices outside of the resort are much more reasonable. There is a Wailie Coffee House just right outside the resort which is open 24 hours a day and has great food and coffee. For Great Ribs there is a Tony Romas close by. Trust me, get outside the resort. Not only will you see more of Waikiki, but you will also spend a lot less money. Parking is about $15 a day for self-parking and $4 more for Valet. The internet service is $12.95 a day and if you do plan on using their on site gym, they will charge you for that too. I never used it so I don't know how much they charge for that. So be careful how you spend your money. A travelers tip: If you plan on renting a car you may want to know that gas out there is about 30 cents more on the gallon than what you will pay on the mainland. Overall this place has it all! Friendly service! A Very Hawaiian Feel about it and as mentioned above Tropical Landscaping and shops everywhere. And oh yeah if you want great pizza go to the Round Table Pizza which is right on premises. Their prices their are very much like what you would pay anywhere at home and the pizza is definitely the best in Waikiki.  
<Date>Jul 27, 2006

<Author>L84wrk1021
<Content>Not worth it at all! As a Hilton Honors Diamond Member I was not impressed at the least. The property was over crowded with two conventions and a whole lot of hotel stuffed on a small amount of property. I was dissatisfied with the condition of the first room (they did not honor my diamond status and I did not get an immediate upgrade and no amenities at all for that matter.) The first night I was in the Tapa tower on the 6th floor. The hallways were dirty and walpaper and paint was peeling. The room had similar conditions and the bathroom was very well used. After complaints to the management I was given a one bedroom suite in the same tower on the 10th floor for the next night. I was not told that with this upgraded room came the construction on the floor above me. I was woken up at 7 am when the construction was scheduled to begin at 9am. I was given a credit of $100 but if you have been to Hawaii, that will just about buy you one fruity drink with an umbrella and a salad. The construction began at the same time on the third morning. Check out is at 11am SHARP and you will not be given any courtesy time what so ever. The pools were small and you had to fight for a seat, make sure you don't get up for too long the vultures will steal your chair. Don't use the pool by Tapa tower the sun will fade behind a building at about 3 pm. The beach was not great either, very rocky and many jelly fish. If you like shopping and eating you will find plenty at this hotel. About the only thing going for it

<Author>McBam
<Content>Lovely Resort with a Fabulous Staff I was fortuneate to have had the opportunity of staying at the Hilton Hawaiian Village for three nights at the Kalia Tower in late April and two nights at the Rainbow Tower in mid-May as the stopover point on a trip to Australia. What a wonderful way to begin and end this vacation!!!!The property is absolutely gorgeous...spotlessly maintained on the widest stretch of Waikiki Beach. Flamingos and penguins, orchids and koi pools, parrots with Aloha greetings all add to the tropical appeal of this resort.The shops offer everything from Louis Vuitton to a very family friendly ABC convenient store. Restaurants are casual beachside to gourmet cuisine. There is truly something for most everyone's taste and budget.However, I was most impressed by the staff. They were professionals in the art of customer service with emphasis on courtesy and helpfulness with a smile. Early arrival rooms were available on both stops with a minimal wait and great attention to our luggage. Shops' staffs assisted with post cards and more expensive purchases with the same great care. Wait staff were personable and attentif. I cannot say enough about my encounters with them. They did a fabulous job representing Hilton Hotels and the Hawaiian Islands!We were dreaming about a vacation in Hawaii before we left for Australia, which is another wonderful destination! Aloha!!

<Author>Suzeque
<Content>Has Anybody Seen Our 2 Bedroom Suite? We've loved Hawaii since my husband and I honeymooned there 24 years ago. In August of 2001 we purchased a lovely 2 bedroom plus suite with ocean view at the Lagoon Tower at the Hilton Hawaiian Village in Waikiki. We've stayed at this resort mutltiple times and have always enjoyed an above average vacation. Yes, they nickel and dime you to death, but having a kitchen and laundrey facilities you can creatively save alot of money. Our room with its two beautiful ocean view balconies was the key selling point for us. To begin each morning and end each night in these lovely surroundings was what enhanced our experience.  We just returned from our Hawaiian vacation and were utterly disappointed. As a previous tripadvisor member has noted, we also were downgraded to a one bedroom suite with an attached studio lockout. The rooms were smaller, older and much less luxurious. The total layout was not what we expected as we usually get a master bedroom with master bath, a separate bedroom with two double beds, and a much larger kitchen/dining area/family area with a central spacious bathroom. In the past, we had two lanais with lovely views of the ocean. This time, hower, there was only one lanai and, being on the 5th floor, the view was not great. When we complained we were told that they had every right to substitute the smaller one bedroom and attached studio as the hotel and HGVC viewed this as an even exhange. During the sales presentation, I specifically asked our saleman, Terry Adams, if we would always receive these exact accomodations and he answered emphatically yes. Since this timeshare cost a good deal of money, not to mention airfare invested to get there, we were terribly disappointed. We also were told that we should have advised the HGVC counselor when making the reservation that we did not want a hotel lockout style room. Since we never even considered that a possiblity, I feel it was their responsibility to advise us that they were changing our style of accomodation and not put the onus on us. I definitely think they knew exactly what they were doing and didn't really care if we were unhappy or felt cheated. We also spoke to people who stayed there who were not Hilton Hawaiian owners who had better accomodations than us. It's hard to believe that HGCV would take advantage of owners in their Home Resort. To make matters worse, the staff seemed to not really care. I put a call in to HGVC headquarters and pretty much got the runaround there, although they did make a courtesy call to the hotel. Nothing could be changed as they were fully booked. I do plan to write a formal letter to HGVC as well as the Lagoon Tower Board of Directors as I would like an answer, in writing, as to this Bait  Switch technique as the previous TripAdivsor member stated. Perhaps there is also a local Hawaiian or Florida consumer advocate that can explain the legitimacy of this policy.We have not changed our mind about Hawaii, though. We still enjoyed the beautiful island of Oahu and its people and culture. That is, after all, what we fell in love with from the beginning.  
<Date>Jul 18, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Give the buffet a miss at all costs! My mate and I spent the second week of our holiday in Oahu, staying at this hotel as part of a package. I was looking forward to it as Hilton has a good reputation and I'd recently had a reasonably happy stay at their hotel in Port of Spain. The grounds of the hotel with the endless fountains and waterfalls, roaming penguins and pink flamigoes are beautiful but the buildings themselves are nothing special. We were in the Diamond Head tower which looks like a council estate block of maisonettes from the exterior and the interior rather reminded me of a tired guesthouse in a British coastal town. The bathrooms are absolutely tiny and as other reviewers have noted, they charge for absolutely everything at this hotel. The charges for the umbrellas and deckchairs on the beach are outrageously high. The best restaurant is Bali by the sea which we had an excellent if very expensive meal at. However I do urge any readers to avoid the buffet in the hotel restaurant at all costs. It is overpriced and the quality of the food is very poor. The staff are rather unfriendly and slow. We were tricked into having the buffet by being told there wasn't a menu. This turned out to be a complete lie and we would have much rather ordered a la carte. We didn't eat there again after that. The breakfast buffet in the Tapa tower restaurant is also to be avoided as the food quality and choice is poor and as an example of the costs, they charge you for almost $6 for an orange juice from concentrate! We were never able to get on a deckchair by the pool as they were always full. This hotel is very much for honeymooners and families with small children so if like us you are young, single and looking for some fun, you should avoid this place.  
<Date>Jul 16, 2006

<Author>KShaw
<Content>You will have a Great Time here The Hilton Hawaiian Village is a great place to stay especially with kids.  I just returned from a trip over the 4th of July with my 6 yr old son, 14 yr old niece, mom and stepdad. We stayed in the Ali'i Tower. It was awesome. We had a fantastic view of the super pool and part of the beach from our room. Even with a child and a teenager sharing a room with me we had plenty of space and the bathroom was very large and compartmentalized so that it could be used by multiple persons at the same time without problem. Even though this tower had extra amenities I don't think you'd miss them much staying in any other of the towers. We weren't in the room enough to really use them and all the towers are beautiful. However the availability of a concierge was very helpful in getting us a dinner reservation at a specific time that I was unable to get calling the restaurant directly. That was pretty cool.The entire place is open and airy and just way cool. I have traveled a lot and my mom and stepdad are very avid travelers. They were very surprised with the hotel and loved it.If you want that tropical Hawaiian feeling this is the place. Huge pools, great beach, friendly people and just unbelievable grounds with ponds and wildlife just hanging out. You can't go wrong with this hotel if you want a fun vacation.PS: But you must make a side trip and visit Kailua on the windward or south east coast. The best beach I've ever been to and you have to eat at Teddy Burger. Oh what I'd do for a Teddy Burger, yummy!You will have a great time so go!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Bait and switch We are HVC owners of a two bedroom unit in the Lagoon Towers. We waited a whole year to reserve what we thought was the same layout of a 2 bedroom ocean view unit with a double balcony that they showed us three years ago. Mind you this is why we feel in love with the place and bought here because of the spaciousness of that type of unit.But on this recent July 2006 trip, we were given two rooms-- a regular hotel room with an ajacent smaller 1 bedroom unit. When we complained about this we were told that when we booked we should have specified that we did not want a room that had the hotel type of lockout rooms or in other words, two rooms that you often find in hotel situations when you want to put two rooms together.  The HVC personnel here said that these two rooms put together equalled a 2 bedroom unit. In our opinion, IT DID NOT meet with what we thought we bought and were going to get on this trip. Don't fall for this bait and switch tactic.These unit cost a lot of money to buy and the sales people should show you every room configuration that you are entitled to at the time of purchase so you know exactly what you'll be getting when you arrive on your vacation and won't be disappointed.Since we now know about this detail that was not openly and honestly discussed during our initial purchase, we wanted to share this information for anyone who's thinking of getting a big two bedroom unit there. Make sure you get the room configuration that you think your getting.Otherwise, the Hilton is a great place to stay if you can avoid all the timeshare yah dah yah dah they want you to hear about.  
<Date>Jul 14, 2006

<Author>DPTChicago
<Content>Too Crowded  My girlfriend and I just spent a week at the Hilton Hawaiian Village where we had a spacious room overlooking the ocean from the 23rd floor of the Tapa Tower. Honolulu would not ordinarily be our choice for a Hawaiian vacation since we are not fans of crowds, traffic, high-rises and tour busses when on vacation, but I was attending a conference at the nearby convention center for part of the week and the Hilton was the official convention hotel which tells you a bit about the overall ambience of the place.I had to laugh at the comments from other writers who were so impressed by the shopping opportunities 鈥?and, rest assured there are many. But for the expense and the time it takes to get to Hawaii from just about anywhere, it seems to me that the shoppers would be better off going to New York or Chicago or the Mall of America. The Hilton was completely sold-out while we were there which was apparent by how crowded the beach was. As other writers have noted, the Hilton charges you for everything imaginable including the use of beach chairs and shade umbrellas. So we went to a nearby grocery store and bought a couple of folding beach chairs for about $20 apiece. Particularly if you intend to drive around and explore some other beaches (which I strongly recommend), this is the way to go.Other than the crowded conditions and the charges for everything, the only other negative aspect of the beach was that the water was somewhat cloudy 鈥?not the beautiful crystalline water characteristic of the Caribbean. I suspect that this is due to the surface run-off which occurs around cities or otherwise caused by 鈥渄evelopment鈥? We were relieved to find that the water was clearer at some of the beaches in less 鈥渄eveloped鈥?areas a short drive up the coast past the Diamond Head volcano. Many of these beaches have great waves a bit closer to shore for surfing or body surfing.The beach itself in front of the Hilton is wide and, except for a few patches of gravel, the sand is soft and beautiful - although it always saddens us to see the amount of trash and litter people leave about 鈥?even cigarette butts on a 鈥渘on-smoking鈥?beach. But by far the best aspect of the beach was the utter lack of jet skis. In our experience, nothing can wreck the character of a lovely beach like the noise, mayhem and pollution that results from waverunner concessions. In fact, we were delighted to have seen very few of these insidious machines around any of the beaches we visited. Perhaps Hawaii has wisely banned them from most of its shoreline.We hiked the Manoa Waterfall hike one day which took about an hour (round trip at a moderate pace) through a lush and cool rainforest which was enjoyable although the Manoa Waterfall was anti-climactic. The 鈥渨aterfall鈥?was really more of a trickle into a small pool that was roped off with signs discouraging swimming (so don鈥檛 be fooled by the brochures). The little pool of water at the base of the 鈥渨aterfall鈥?was really too small to swim or even wade in. Maybe if the area had gotten more rain preceding our visit, the Manoa Waterfall would have been a different experience.The number of good restaurants in and around the Hilton was a highlight and, if you are a seafood lover, you couldn鈥檛 ask for much more in the way of variety or freshness. We had dinner one night at Bali by the Sea which is on the property. The food was good but overpriced. We liked Orchids (in the Halekulani Hotel a short walk down the beach) better. One of the best values we found was the Thai restaurant across the street from the Hilton.Finally, like other writers, we were completely turned-off by the nickel and diming at the hotel. The petty charges for everything is more egregious than I have ever seen before - $2.50 for the tiny bottles of water in your room, $ for in-room coffee if you have more than one pot and it goes on and on. Due to my Hhonors status, the front desk gave us coupons for a complimentary continental breakfast each morning. But for breakfast to actually be complimentary, we were limited to a muffin that had to be served to us by a waiter. If, instead of a muffin, we wanted to go to the cold buffet and get a single bowl of raison bran or a cup of yogurt 鈥?well that is an upgrade for which Hilton will charge you $3.50.All-in-all, if it were our money and choice (versus my employer鈥檚) we would have found a less crowded and commercialized place to spend a week in Hawaii.  
<Date>Jul 14, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>We had a great time! I recently stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village for 9 nights--and it was great. Upon arrival, we were upgraded to an ocean front room in the Rainbow Tower--we could see the show at the pool, Diamond Head, and the Ocean from the balcony. The staff were very helpful--the woman who checked us in gave us advice on restaurants (outside of the resort) and where to go on the Island.The pool did seem crowded--but the beach wasn't too crowded....which is where we spent most of our time while we were at the HIlton. Parking was 16 dollars a day, but it was worth it! We rented a jeep and spent a lot of time at the North Shore. The room was pretty large compared to many hotels and the service was excellent. It was also nice to have a wet bar and mini-refrigerator--that way we didn't have to go to restaurants for every meal. We did have to wait for an elevator a few times, but it was not a big deal.Overall, we had a fabulous time at this hotel and would recommend it to anyone going to Oahu. We plan to to stay here again...  
<Date>Jul 14, 2006

<Author>witlessz
<Content>Great stay Booked an oceanview room and got one in the Rainbow tower with an excellent view of the beach, the superpool and diamonhead. The bed faces the sliding door so if you leave it open at night, you could wake up to a beautiful view of the ocean in the morning. Overall an execellent resort for relaxationComplaints...Everything is pricey here and had a bad experience looking for a decent place to dine after 8pm; one restaurant (Bali by the Sea or somehting like that) requires guys to wear long pants - come on, this is a beach resort!Superpool closes at 6pm - even a motel leaves it's pool open until 10pm! At $300 over for a night's stay, you would certainly expect to use the pool for longer...Too few trees on the beach - guess they do this intentionally to increase the beach umbrella business..Mandara Spa - SKIP IT!!!! had I read an earlier review, I wouldn't have paid $400 for an 80min Lomi Lomi massage session for me and my wife. Place is totally overrated and overpriced. Don't expect that you are paying for the atmosphere etc. The only nice deco is in the massage waiting area where everyone sits around in their robes staring at one another...and then you walk into a tiny room which is basically 4 walls with no aethetics (no shower room in the massage suite, so couples like us have to separate and go to the separate men/ladies shower areas of the gym)...and the therapists have no smiles on their faces, the massages were mediocre and o yes, the massage doesn't include the chest and abs areas...I've paid $100 (for 2) for a similar massage on Bali (yes, yes, Bali is cheap) but the massage area is in a cabana by the beach with herbal tea after the treatment, your own private shower area and the entire experience was wonderful. For Mandara Spa, we walked feeling that we we had been cheated.

<Author>Conchal
<Content>Marvelous Hotel We stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Vilage in the Ali'i Tower for 8 glorious days. The hotel was everything we expected and more. From the complimentary bottled water in the room to the complimentary full continental breakfast, this hotel is an outstanding example of value as well as service and luxury for your dollar. The hotel is clean, lovely, and inviting. The location is awesome and the Village eliminates the need for a car or expensive taxis. Moreover, the prices are fair and one is not nickeled and dimed. I would highly recommend this hotel for anyone. There are abundant choices for couples, kids, seniors, etc. The entertainment at night is great and there are several choices. There are so many restaurant options from casual to elegant within walking distance that it would take several weeks to exhaust them. Of course during the day one has the pool, fitness center, tours, and beach activities. Additionally, the Ali'i Tower has its own quick beach access, its own wonderful pool with food/drink service, and its own fitness center. All in all, this is a marvelous choice.

<Author>CircadianSwing
<Content>$8.25 Beer!!! Hidden Costs!! Very nice grounds, easy to check in and out. Our room was clean and decent in the Diamond Head Tower. They screwed up the 鈥減aid in full鈥?reservation of the other couple we went with, but gave them a nice room in the Rainbow Tower. Unfortunately, they were on the 30th floor, and the elevators there do not work well. Not a great beach outside, due to large rocks in the water which barricade it. You have to walk about 200 yards to get to the beach that has small shorebreaker waves, and doesn't have rocky sand which hurts your feet. The rental hut the hotel owns on the beach wanted $100 for 4 beach chairs and 2 umbrellas. That will cost you 1/4 of the price at the next hut over. In fact, the rest of the hotel is the same way. $100 for the coffee shop buffet for 4 people (buffet eggs and bacon), and $76 for dinner for 2 there. The drinks are $8-$13 all over, and the sushi place Hatsuhana was so bad, they used a butane fueled torch to make baked scallop sushi roll (it tasted as bad as it sounds). For a second I thought the price of sushi was a good deal, only $4, but that is only for one piece. The problem with the hotel is you're stuck there, it's so big. Just getting to a coffee shop on the street is a good walk. I had 2 massages there, they couldn't even be honest about the price. They said it was $98, but then they have a service charge of $15, and you'd feel bad if you didn't give the person a tip on top of it. I decided to have the massages, becuase it was going to be $20 anyway for me just to use the gym, which is included with a massage. Don't bother renting a car and keeping it overnight, that will cost you $30/day to park there. Bottom line, Honolulu doesn鈥檛 have the luxury to keep charging these prices, the city is starting to look like Los Angeles (with freeways and all), and the beach isn鈥檛 much better than Santa Monica鈥檚. The reef looks dead to me. If you鈥檙e looking at this hotel, ask yourself, why am I going to Honolulu and not Maui/Kauai or the big island? We had free airline tickets, so Honolulu was fine for us, but I felt bad for the other couple we went with, who did pay for their tickets.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Customers come second My family and I stayed in a very expensive suite in the Lagoon towers. There were three elevators, but during daytime hours, one was always keyed for hotel workers. Consequently, the elevator wait was anywhere from three to eight minutes with several guests having to wait for the next elevator due to no space available. The parking structure was several floors, with all lower and forward spaces, convienient to the hotel, reserved for the valet staff and employees. The main pool, advertised as one of the islands largest, was open from 830am to 530pm. If you did not arrive at 8am and stand in line, there were no seats available the remainder of the day. My family and I never got to sit at the pool. Of course beach chairs were available for $12 dollars each. The room was nice and the shops were nice, but if you plan to shop in downtown Honolulu, plan on taking a cab. The Hawaiian Village is approximately 2 miles from the center of town where all the best shopping and restaurant activity is centered.  
<Date>Jul 10, 2006

<Author>sommerlovin
<Content>Nice place to stay in Waikiki! If you want to be a part of it all, this is the place!We spent the first four nights of our honeymoon (June 24-28) in the Tapa Tower. We really liked the location of the Tapa Tower in the HHV - it was close to both pools, the entrance, Rainbow Bazaar, etc...The Superpool was not so super... don't be alarmed, it's a nice-sized pool, just not big enough to service all the zillions of guests million around the grounds. We had a hard time getting a spot near the pool all four days - to the point we had to rent chairs in front of the Hale Koa next door ($30/day, not bad w/ umbrella) if we wanted to sit in chairs, not on the ground. So, we sat at the beach - worked out well, but we really wanted to be poolside that morning. Oh well, we hung loose! :)We tried to rent a car at the Hertz in the HHV, but that really didn't materialize - the desk is supposed to open at 7:30 - we were there - but the attendent didn't show up until 8:05. We tried to get ANY car available, but they told us they didn't have any. We were sad, but knew we should have reserved one, but the HHV concierge ended up calling some places, he found us a Geo Tracker for $35.99 at VIP cars. Seriously, it was really banged up, but we fit in with the surfers on the North Shore, so we weren't concerned about getting robbed at all! :) The room was nice - we were upgraded from partial to full ocean view - great touch - and we loved it. It was great, nice linens, nice bed, nothing to complain about at all!The HHV is a nice property on Waikiki. Sure, it's pricey, but you need to try to get over it quickly or you won't be able to enjoy your trip - HAWAII is expensive! Not sure if we'll go back. I think we both felt like we didn't need to go back to Oahu, but if we did, I think we'd go somewhere a little less busy!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Awesome Week in Oahu! My husband and I just returned from celebrating our one-year wedding anniversary in Oahu. After careful consideration and a LOT of research, we chose the HHV due to the location and great reviews. We checked in on June 30th, expecting to be put in the Tapa Tower since we only paid for a generic Garden View room. Much to my delight, we were upgraded to the Ali'i Tower. The room we had in the Ali'i Tower was awesome! The bedroom itself was huge and the bed was so comfortable with it's high thread count sheets and down comforter. What I loved best was the gigantic bathroom that had a little tv on the vanity! Our rooms were cleaned everyday by 1pm at the very latest. Overall, the HHV was a very nice, relaxing place to stay. We never ran into the people selling timeshares and always found the staff to be very nice. The resort is big but it's not TOO big. We didn't eat at any of the restaurants but we did order a Roundtable pizza and some of their garlic parmesan twists which were FABULOUS! My only complaint is the price of drinks...$20 for 2 pina coladas! I thought that was ridiculous but expected it. Buy beer and stuff from the ABC store...oh, and before you go buy a bunch of junk from Hilo Hattie, check out the ABC store. The same candy, wooden trinkets, and other little things were cheaper at the ABC store. We will definitely return to Oahu and the HHV!For those looking for a Pearl Harbor Tour, we did the Home of the Brave Tour which you can view at [---]. My husband and I both agree that the tour was our favorite thing! Olav-our guide-knew his history and he was fascinating to listen to. They pick you up at 6am and we were the 2nd group to get to go onto the memorial. We also got to visit several other places that were crucial on that day and we even had lunch at an old Officers Club. It's a long day (back by 2pm) but you will have a wonderful time if you like history! On a food note, if you go to Duke's at the Outrigger and you like to eat fish, try the Opah with the Macadamia Nut/Parmesan crust. It's out of this world...and I don't normally like fish! Eggs  Things is good but go EARLY...before 8am if you don't want to wait an hour. Wailana Coffee House is good, too. If you're interested in trying surfing, walk down the beach towards Diamond Head and you can get surf lessons/rentals cheaper than at the HHV. My husband surfed 3 times and now he's hooked :)Also, if you're looking for transportation to/from the airport, DON'T use VIP Transportation. We found them to be quite unreliable, especially when we were heading back to the airport. Aloha!  
<Date>Jul 10, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Definitely Paradise This was our first trip to Hawaii and we could not have chosen a better place to stay. The 1-bedroom apartment was spacious and tastefully decorated. Hardwood floors in living, dining, and full-size kitchen area. The grounds are breathtaking. It's truly like staying in an Hawaiian village. Plenty of shopping and dining on the grounds but lots more within walking distance. Trolley, bus and tour services were very convenient. Service was outstanding from the local people; would encourage those who have relocated to adapt the Hawaiian way. Would highly recommend.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Rainbow Tower at HHV is #1 to any other hotel on the beach! We stayed for 2 weeks at the Hilton Hawaiian Village, and I must say that we were not disappointed one bit. The staff is cheerful and very attentive, and our view of Diamond Head Crater and the Pacific Ocean from our balcony was truly a gorgeous way to start and end each day.The Good?:1- Staff is extra friendly.2- Property Grounds show like a postcard. Gorgeous landscaping!The Bad?:1- Bring your own COFFEE! Each bag in the room is $3.95 to your bill!2- Watch your step on the beach. Not all sand is natural and some is very sharp!3- On-site shops are majority designer (i.e.-Coach, Louie Vuitton, etc. and very $$$$!) If you are looking for a cheaper souviner T-Shirt, go off property.4- On-site restaurants are plentiful but once again very expensive!5- 4TH OF JULY WARNING! --- RAINBOW TOWER! The resort sets off the best 4th of July show on the island. However, if you are staying in the Rainbow Tower and facing the pool  Diamond Head, you will NOT be able to see it. Go down to the beach or make friends with someone who has a view of the Marina!
