<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Absolutely paradise We just returned from our vacation at the HHV. My husband, son, daughter-in-law, and I stayed for 7 nights in the Rainbow Tower at Hilton Hawaiian Village. Beautiful place!! Staff is awesome!! We, as visitors, had to keep going down to the information desk in the main lobby to obtain help with travel plans. Staff would go out of their way to help. They would suggest cheaper, safer modes of transportation (other than taxi). Any encounter with staff was excellent, whether it be the maids, busboys, reservation desk, waitresses, etc. Everyone was very helpful. Our room had an awesome view of the ocean and the city lights of Honolulu. We were upgraded from a deluxe oceanfront king to a corner oceanfront king room. Room was beautiful with modern amenities. Complaints are: only one free 4-cup coffee pot of coffee per day, expensive food (except for CJ's and Round Table Pizza). All food was good, though. Oftentimes, we'd just go to ABC Store in the hotel and get sandwiches, chips, milk, and muffins for breakfast and lunch. Whenever we'd have to call for towels, more cream/sugars (Hawaiian coffee is strong), staff was very pleasant and would accomodate us promptly. They would not hear of us coming down to get things. They always brought them to us and never had a hand out!! We really enjoyed that! All in all, great resort and we'll return if ever in Oahu!!  
<Date>Jul 5, 2006

<Author>tripsntraps
<Content>Hawaiian Oasis We stayed at the Kalia Tower at Hilton Hawaiian Village from 6/19 - 6/24 in a one bedroom condominium and thoroughly enjoyed our stay. This is our third stay there in 18 months and even though the beachfront Waikiki hotels such as the Outrigger make us sometimes wish we were smack in the heart of Waikiki, we always fall back to the less-crowded and more laid-back atmosphere at the Hilton. Besides, it's only a 20 minute walk to Waikiki. The key to staying at the Hawaiian Village and not overloading your credit cards is to enjoy window shopping there but buying elsewhere. Likewise with the onsite restaurants which tend to be pricey. A few exceptions -- Lapperts Ice Cream is a must, CJ's Deli and the Noodle place are fairly reasonable. What I like most about the place is that I can meander down to the spacious airy lobbies and listen to music without necessarily having to sit at the bars and actually have a choice to have a swinging time or go for a quiet retreat. There's hawaiian entertainment by the pool at around 6pm and the American Express Travelers Activities center is full of knowledgeable people who actually try to save you money. They saved my husband $100 by suggesting he drive our rental car to one of the many golf courses around -- look for a threesome in need of a 4th, rather than using one of their package deals. Ala Moana shopping center is a few minutes away by foot (probably quicker that way vs a car during rush-hour traffic). Accomodations were superb--clean and new (except for a leaky kitchen faucet). One warning--don't use their Mandara spa which is over-priced all the way around (and unremarkable in their service) --including charges to use their steam room and exercise facilities. If you want a massage, look up the Shiatsu and Massage Center on Lihue street--nothing to look at--(you'll be face-down anyway) but a great massage at 1/3 the price! Downside for boogie boarders -- unless you wake up really early, you're better off catching the waves in front of the Outrigger. Besides, they nickel and dime you for the umbrellas, chairs, etc. oceanside at the Hilton. Buy a straw mat at the ABC stores for a dollar instead. Some of the staff are downright rude--but get their name and report them. Otherwise, this is definitely a favorite place for us in terms of luxury and location.  
<Date>Jul 5, 2006

<Author>watercolors1
<Content>Could have been better My wife and I purchased points from Hilton Vacation Club and cashed them in on a week's stay at the Lagoon Tower at Hilton Hawiian Village. We brought our 12 yr. old twins and signed up (9 mos in advance) for a 2 bedroom condo. We arrived to find the second bedroom to be a studio style with only one bed - when we were expecting 2. A look out the balcony window showed that we were facing the construction of a new Hilton tower - construction noise and all from 8AM to 5PM, M-F. It looked like they had just broken ground. Our room was also next to the elevators - something I don't seek out due to noise. I asked the manager if they could do something to improve our room and she told me that I would be put on a waiting list to be moved. Needless to say, after 7 nights stay they never changed our room. I felt like I was getting lip service and no action. Water pressure in the shower was extremely low, sometimes down to a trickle. To the hotel's credit, the rooms were nicely appointed and the kitchen had all the conveniences. The grounds were nicely kept and the stores and restaurants on the grounds were convenient. I didn't like the idea of missing out on a pool chair if you didn't get there by 8AM. Staking out chairs and leaving towels to reserve seating seems so petty. Parking seemed a little steep at $16, but at least we had in and out privilages. I would recommend the Sat. dinner buffet at the Linai (?) restaurant at the hotel. In the end we ended up joining the HGVC hoping that this was an isolated incident and that we would expect or seek out better accommodations next time (elsewhere).  
<Date>Jun 30, 2006

<Author>Wutisay
<Content>Excellent location and service Our family of five stayed here in mid-June '06 for a week. We were in two rooms in the new tower, Kalia (2048/2050), with a mountain view. The rooms were beautiful and exceptionally clean. Service was always excellent and friendly. The location was perfect for us: the kids were able to access the pools and beach in a hurry and we were somewhat away from the hustle of Waikiki. Even though we got a mountain view room to save some nickles, the view was great, and included a nice angle on Diamodhead. Overall, this was an excellent hotel for us and we'd stay there again without hesitation. Aloha.

<Author>palpa
<Content>Stay at the Sheraton The positive is that the room was spacious, clean and new - I stayed in the Kahlia Tower, one of 5 towers surrounding the Hawaiian Village. I was on the executive level - advertised to provide  additional amenities offered in the Lanikai Executive Lounge include concierge services, assistance with business needs, large-screen television, newspaper/periodical rack, self-serve espresso, as well as continental breakfast, mid-day refreshments and evening hors d'oeuvres. Continental breakfast included fruit (no bananas for four of my seven days), sweet pastries, four types of boxed cereal, bread for toasting and either orange or guava juice. Since i don't drink coffee (more on that later), I asked for a diet coke. I was told that I could only have soda in the afternoon and that I could not take any soda or food (like an apple) out of the area to my room. Mid day refreshments were Doritos in a bowl with some canned salsa, cookies, scones and strawberries. Evening hors d'oeuvres consisted of either tiny shrimp quiches and beef satay, or burnt potstickers and lumpia, with raw veggies, ranch dressing, same Doritos and salsa and some cheese and crackers. And they close at 8:00 pm with food depleted by about 7:00, so no relaxing in the evening with friends or family.The Hawaiian Village is really nothing more than a shopping center catering to the Japanese tourists. In fact, your room television has eight channels devouted to telling you about the shopping in both english and japanese. The property is overcrowded, the reception area cannot handle the check-in process quickly, the check-in people at Kahlia tower were unhelpful, unfriendly and when I mentioned that the ethernet cable in my room did not work, they just shrugged their shoulders and gave me a different one to plug in, saying that if it didn't work, they might be able to get me a different room, but they weren't sure. Fortunately, I was able to attach to the wireless network - for the hefty sum of $65.00 for my week's stay. It was not super fast, but it was acceptable.Parking is $16/day (valet for $19.00). Two beach Chairs (plastic pvc with no cushion) and an umbrella will cost you $51/day not including the tip for the beach guy to dig a hole for the umbrella and you have to wait in line each day for that priviledge. Coffee in the room (they have a coffee maker) costs you $3.75 for each package of coffee you use. Tiny 6 ounce bottles of water cost you $2.50 and even though you have no choice, the room safe in the closet costs $3.75 whether you use it or not. The super pool is small, crowded and over-rated - with long lines to get towels and chairs. The beach is nice, but crowded and trashy by the end of the week. I think they only clean it once a week. The staff was indifferent and sometimes rude.I usually stay at one of the SSheraton, whcih are a little more expensive - but in the long run, they don't knicle and dime you to death and are a lot nicer to deal with. They even give yo a welcome lei at teh Sheraton - nothing's free at the Hilton.  
<Date>Jun 26, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Fabulous! We stayed at the hotel complex from June 9 - 15 and it was fabulous! We escaped a bad hotel after a two-day stay, and the Hilton was happy to take us in at a moment's notice. We were lucky enough to get a room on the club floor of The Kalia Tower, with included heavy snacks all day in the club lounge on the 25th floor. The room was impeccable, and of course the property has no equal. Service was great in this tower, with its own check in, concierge and pool. I even sat through a 90-minute presentation from the HIlton Vacation Club, and was given $150 in gift certifcates in exchange for my time. We used that money for a spa treatment (which my daughter reports was heavenly) and a night out at Benihana right there on the property. The HHV is busy with tourists, but has everything you could ever need right there. This was our third stay there, and we will definitely stay there again.  
<Date>Jun 21, 2006

<Author>DenverCO-Traveller
<Content>Wonderful hotel - Kalia Tower is great I attended a friend's wedding at the HHV, and the majority of the wedding guests were put up at the Kalia Tower. We loved it. Kalia has its own swimming pool - a bonus because the main pool (Super Pool) gets very crowded and it's quite hard to find a lounge chair after 8:30 a.m. The Kalia pool is small, quiet, has a poolside bar, and if you pay to use the fitness center at Kalia you will not only have access to a great gym (good cardio and weights machines) but you'll be able to use the Mandara Spa facilities too. The steam room, hot tub and sauna are all well kept.I had a king room with a mountain view. The twice daily turndown service was a treat - how nice to come home to orchids on your pillow each day. Another nice feature of the room was the small refrigerator in the bathroom (separate from the minibar) that I was able to use to store fresh fruit, snacks  beer, which I bought at the ABC Store next to the hotel.The reviewer who said they had poor service must have been an exception to the rule. I received nothing but the best service during my entire stay. I was able to request a late checkout at 4pm without any problems. Also, Kalia is one of the towers that offers luggage storage. This was all very convenient since my flight was not until 10pm.I did not eat at any of the HHV restaurants, simply because I was able to find better value off the resort. Eggs N Things breakfast place around the corner (not the one across the street!) is excellent -- wonderful service, delicious food. Also, a tip for buying souvenirs -- go to the Walmart behind Ala Moana Shopping Center. The boxes of chocolate covered mac nuts that you find in ABC Stores for $5/box are only $3/box at Walmart.  
<Date>Jun 20, 2006

<Author>Longears63
<Content>Hilton Hawaiian Village Everything you have seen written about the Ali'i Tower is true. It's a fabulous tower, with excellent service, and if you're already forking over the dollars to travel to Hawaii, and stay at HHV, why not spend a few extra to really enjoy the time you spend on Oahu.Here are some money savers when it comes to food, whether you are traveling with children, or just aren't looking to take a 2nd mortgage to fund your trip.The Maui Revealed guide book ( available in book stores) is the best...their tip was to walk next door to the Hale Koa hotel. While you must be military to stay there, anyone can use their restaurants. If you're at the HHV pool and looking for a burger or hot dog mid-day, you can spend $7.95 for ONE hot dog at HHV, or $14 for the cheeseburger basket, or take a 2 minute walk from the HHV Super Pool onto the beach path, and immediately turn onto the Hale Koa grounds, follow the path a few steps and on your left is a snack bar the has hot dogs for $2.55 ( good ones) fries for $1.50, and even a 3 piece chicken plate for $4. It adds up in savings quickly.Also, if you don't want to pay $21.95 for the breakfast buffet at HHV, just take a 3 minute walk to Wailana Coffee Shop, just off property, and you'll get great food, decent prices ( all you can eat pancakes, with eggs, bacon for $5.25).The best part of HHV is the beach ( lots of sand), the grounds ( tropical paradise) and the Ali'i Tower.The rest of Waikiki is crowded, like Vegas strip on a beach, and some resorts have very little or no beach at all.But, rent a car and see the island, especially Lanikai Beach and Kailua Beach--powder sand and a whole different feel than Waikiki.Avoid the shuttle on Waikiki. If you want you can take the free Hilo Hattie shuttle ( to their 2 stores) which also passes by the hotels on Waikiki, and you get a free tour of downtown Honolulu. Hilo Hattie shutle picks up at HHV bus area every 20 minutes.Aloha, and enjoy your trip!  
<Date>Jun 20, 2006

<Author>tonysbrowneyedgirl
<Content>A great place! We arrived in Honolulu and had Aloha Limo service pick us up. They met us at baggage claim and gave each of us a beautiful, fresh flower lei and a souvenir coffee mug and we were off to the Hilton Hawaiian Village. I had originally booked the Lagoon Tower so we were dropped off there. When we went to check in, we found out that we had been moved to the Kalia Tower with no explanation. However, they assured us that is was their newest tower, indicating that maybe it was the nicest. We later discovered it was built in 2001. The Kalia Tower was a fairly long walk away from our drop off location. No one offered to take our bags although I鈥檓 sure, had we been willing to wait, someone might have. We then checked into our ocean-view, one bedroom condo at Kalia which also had a beautiful view of the 鈥渧illage鈥? It was very nice with a small living room with a sleeper sofa and balcony and full kitchen. The bedroom was pretty with a very comfortable king size bed and balcony. The only problem was we only had one bathroom which was a little inconvenient when we and our daughters (ages 7 and 12) were trying to get showered and ready for dinner each night. Since we never saw a condo at the Lagoon Tower and therefore couldn鈥檛 compare it, we were very happy with where we were. The walk was long to the pool and beach each day but entertaining as we walked by shops, birds, flamingos and penguins each time. I had hoped to cook breakfast or lunch in our room a couple of days while we were there but didn鈥檛 find much to offer in the ABC convenience store on the property. The day before we left to come home, we found the 鈥淲haler鈥檚 General Store鈥?(I think that was the name of it) near the Diamond Head Tower. It was not crowded and had a lot more to choose from as far as general staples for breakfast and lunch.We ate breakfast each morning, except one, at the Rainbow Tower Lanai buffet. It was VERY good but also very expensive. Although my husband and I thoroughly enjoyed each meal there, my daughters usually only ate a bowl of cereal and maybe a little fruit so it would have been much more cost effective had we eaten in our room! Each day for lunch, we ate by the pool. They have great pizza and 鈥渧olcano鈥?french fries! And after 3:00 they serve chicken fingers. For dinner during the week, we at Sergio鈥檚 鈥揺xcellent Italian food, The Village Steak and Seafood Restaurant 鈥揳nother excellent meal(located in the Tapa Tower) Benihana鈥檚 鈥?a disappointment, and the Tropic Bar-our kids favorite(located next to the Super Pool). And one night we walked off the property to The Outback located a couple of blocks away so that our kids could finally have something they like to eat. It seemed that most of the restaurants in the village did not have a lot to offer as far as a 鈥渒id鈥檚 meal鈥? The Village Steak and Seafood Restaurant probably had the most to offer for kids out of the restaurants we ate at. We also ate breakfast at their buffet one of the mornings but it didn鈥檛 have as much to offer as the Rainbow Lanai.The village has several pools. We spent a little time at the pool at the Kalia Tower (for Kalia guests only). The pool is small and is about 4 feet deep (almost over my 7 year old鈥檚 head) and they also have a hot tub. The Tapa Pool is nice and allows small floats and is open until 10:00 p.m. unlike the other pools. Our favorite pool was the Super Pool and seemed to be everyone else鈥檚 favorite as well. It opens at 8:30 and we had to be in line no later than 8:15 to get towels and a chair. By 8:45 there would be no chairs available until about 3:00 in the afternoon. Also you can only save your chairs for 45 minutes. The employees mark them with a card and if you do not return within 45 minutes your chairs will be given to someone else. This was rather exhausting. If we wanted to go to the pool, we couldn鈥檛 sleep in and enjoy our vacation 鈥?we had to be on a schedule and get to the pool by 8:00, stand in line, get our chairs at 8:30, go eat breakfast hurriedly all the while wondering if someone was going to take our chairs while we were gone. Hopefully we were just there at a busy time of year (first week of June)and maybe it鈥檚 not typically that way. We did spend one day at the beach but although it was beautiful, we all seemed to prefer the pool. And if you don鈥檛 get in line by 8:15 to rent your chairs for the beach, you don鈥檛 get on the 鈥渇ront row鈥?One day we took a break from the pool and beach and rented a jeep from Hertz (which is conveniently located on the property) and toured the island 鈥?breathtaking! All in all it was a great vacation and a trip of a lifetime spent at a very nice resort. I would definitely recommend it to any one, with or without kids  
<Date>Jun 18, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Poor service We stayed from 6/7/07-6/11/06. We encountered several, unresolved problems during our stay. Overall, extremely poor service. : 1) tub handle was broken (could not control water temp): reported and took 2 days to be fixed2) A/C-could not control temp: no matter what temp you set it at, it blew constant, cold air. Reported and not fixed. 3) Phone voicemail light not operating: only found out about emergency call because we accidentally ran into the person who left a message. Otherwise we would have missed our return shuttle to the airport. 4) called 3 consecutive days for a wake-up call (once spoke to a person, twice left an automated message): did not receive a call on any day. 5) was charged for a mini-bar fee (charge was made to our Am Ex account when we got home): there was no mini-bar in our room. This was reported on check-in and no mini-bar was ever delivered to our room. I spoke with property rep when I got home and she issued a credit to our Am Ex. 6) Called front desk on several occasions: no answer despite trying at various times throughout the day. 7) clock in room was set incorrectly (type of clock that you must disassemble to reset) upon check-in: clock was replaced with another clock that was also set at incorrect time and was therefore unusable as an alarm clock.

<Author>beavers745i
<Content>Great Hotel My family and I went to the Hilton Hawaiian Village during spring break 2005. I must say it was an excellent trip. Not only did we meet the cast of the T.V. show LOST once, we met them twice. The first time we saw them was the night of the last episode with one of the male castmembers (the brother of the pretty blonde girl). The cast wasa celebrating with a dinner at the five star Golden Dragon restaurant. Other than the celebrities, the animals and scenery was MAGNIFICENT. Oh, and I almost forgot! Watch your children in the ocean, because while we were there, a japanese man nearly drowned in the ocean, and if it wasnt for my parents and a few nurses on vacation, he surely would have drowned. And the lifeguard.....he was too far away to even know there was a drowning person. He finally showed up right as the paramedics arrived. The hotel treated us right when they found out we helped save that man's life. I reccomend this resort to anyone visiting Honolulu!

<Author>mobgirl
<Content>Wonderful stay at the HVV We stayed in the Ali'i Tower for six nights.Our room was on the 15th floor partial ocean view overlooking the super pool. The Ali'i tower has its own hot tub and pool overlooking the ocean. Never had a problem getting a chair by the pool. You have to use your key to get in this private pool area. Also by the pool they offer free hor'derves nightly between 5-7. They also provide very good bar and food service by the pool.Our room was large and everything looked very new.Very comfortable beds. We were provided robes and slippers and the first day we had a complimentary fresh friut plate. The coffee, tea and water were at no charge. The maid service came three times a day. (Clean up, ice, turn down service.) If this is too much you can put out thedo not disturb  sign. The last day we checked out at 12:00 and they kept our luggage at the Diamond Head tower and at 3:00 they gave us a hospitality room to shower and change. These rooms were also very nice but I noticed they charged for the coffee, tea, and water in these rooms. Everything at the resort is expensive but it was a very nice atmosphere. Alot of people but we never waited in line or felt crowded. The resort has the nicest beach in Waikiki. Some of the other resorts had no beach at all. I would definetly stay there again. Information desk was very helpful. She offered us a timeshare review but was not pushy.On Friday nights they have a great poolside show and we watched it from our lanai and also fireworks in front of the Rainbow Tower.Travel tips: Wailana Coffee Shop is across the street good, inexpensive food . For a nice dinner Duke's at the Outrigger is very good. Make reservations.  Rent a car and forget the tours you can do it own your own easily.

<Author>Fla4ever
<Content>Ali'i Tower spoiled us! We recently stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village in the Ali'i Tower and it was absolutely the best hotel experience we've had in a long time. The pampering service is non-stop. The towels are refreshed several times a day, ice and beverages re-stocked, and turndown service each evening. The beds are very comfortable, the furnishings are in immaculate condition, and the rooms are spotless. The rooms are well planned and include a small sitting area, separate dressing area, and several options for storing your luggage and travel wear. There is even a mini tv in the dressing room. The amenities are first class and include complimentary hors d'oeuvres each evening on the pool terrace, newly renovated gym facilities, and concierge services. Plus you are only steps away from world famous Waikiki Beach. The landscaping of the HHV grounds and the various ponds of koi, and birds, including Penguins, are spectacular. The location is away from most of the beachwalk construction, so it is quiet, yet close to shopping and other Waikiki activity. The grounds and beaches are groomed daily and very clean. There are fairly calm and protected swimming areas right in front of the HHV, and several pools are available, including a private pool and spa just for Ali'i guests. Convenience items are easily available in the ABC store, and can easily be placed in your in-room mini fridge. There are many choices for onsite dining restaurant's, so you don't have to actually leave the village unless you want to. We ate brunch every day at CJ's Deli. Great service, good food and gigantic portions. You've got to try the Macadamia Nut pancakes with Cocoanut syrup! The HHV is like a small city, but laid out so well that you never really felt like you were in a crowd. It seems to offer something for everyone and we would definitely go back.  
<Date>Jun 8, 2006

<Author>BeachLover077
<Content>Wonderful time in Oahu My husband and I stayed at the HHV for 6 nights in early May. We loved it. I am a Hilton Gold member and they gave us a room in the Rainbow Tower which was great b/c it was closest to the pool and beach and had a wonderful view of the sunset from the balcony. The other tower that is close to beach/pool is Ali'i. I believe that tower also has concierge service and a private pool - requested to be there but it was apparently full. That's okay -we had no complaints in Rainbow. The resort is huge and it takes a bit to walk from place to place, but we are used to staying at big resorts and don't mind. I actually like it b/c there is more to do - more restaurants, shops, etc. The resort is also about a 15 minute walk from the most of the shops and restaurants in Waikiki, but it's a nice walk that you can do on the beach, and I liked that the location of this hotel was somewhat removed. Shopping is great in Waikiki though! As far as everyday items and soda/beer, you can purchase at the ABC shops - they are all over Waikiki and one right in the hotel. Many reviews mentioned that the restaurants in the HHV are very overpriced. The prices are similar to most resort restaurant prices. Being a Gold or Diamond member, you get free breakfast daily - we upgraded for $3.50 each to a buffet everyday, so that saved us a lot. Also, you may want to order the Entertainment book for Hawaii. There are 2 for 1 discounts in there for three of the restaurants at the hotel - Golden Dragon, Rainbow Lanai, and Villiage Steakhouse; also discounts for Polynesian Cultural Center and Luaus. We used the card at Golden Dragon and they were very receptive to it and it ended up being a great deal for dinner there. By the way - i would recommend that restaurant - it was very nice. We ate at Duke's Canoe Club 3 times. It is in the Outrigger about a 10 minute walk (to the left) down the beach. It's hard to get a table in the bar area, but it's a fun place with reasonably priced food and drinks (for Hawaii), so worth the wait. Sundays are especially a fun party atmosphere. We went to Chart House our last night before we caught our plane, and would recommend it there for cheap apps and drinks as well. It's to the right (when facing the beach) of the HHV about a 5 minute walk and there are views of the harbor. They have Happy Hour specials every night until 7pm. It gets a decent crowd in there - seems like a mostly local crowd. If you are a runner - Diamond head is within running distance - i think about 3.5 miles one way- but obviously quite hilly to get there. We ran there one morning, then hiked Diamond Head (1.8 miles round trip) and ran home - that was enough exercise for the entire trip for us.Actually, the only thing about our trip that i would NOT recommend is the Luau we went to at Germaine's. The bus took about 2 hours to get there and I was quite disappointed when we arrived. It was at a beach near an industrial park and you could either sit on the sand or on picnic benches and watch a second rate show. Soon after we arrived, they lined us up for the buffet line of fried chicken and pork and some other unappetizing salads, so right away I knew it wasn't going to be the romantic (or even fun) experience that I hoped for. Otherwise, the trip was awesome and can't wait to return to HHV.  
<Date>May 26, 2006

<Author>diamondgirl25
<Content>Awesome This resort was the best part of my vacation. The staff was very friendly and somehow, I got upgraded to an oceanview room in the A'ali tower which was spectacular. There were down pillows on the soft bed and marble floors and bathroom. There was even a phone in the bathroom and a little tv on the dressing counter. It was everything I would expect from a resort of this caliber. The Mandara spa was gorgeous as were the grounds of the property. Everything was spotless. I did not find the shops to be overly expensive. After all, they weren't selling t-shirts from street vendors. The food, however, was quite expensive, but there were little cafe's that weren't quite as much. It is very convenient to have everything right in the resort and you always have the option of leaving the resort to venture out for dinner somewhere else. All the shuttles and trolleys stop here so that is convenient as well. If I ever travel back to Honolulu/Oahu, this would be the only place I would stay.

<Author>Ianm467
<Content>Mucho dineros The location of the Hilton Hawaiian Village on the Pacific Ocean is spectacular, as is the tropical landscaping, and numerous high-end shops and restaurants are clustered around the half-dozen hotel towers. However, the rooms (starting at $300 per night US) are average in quality and the housekeeping is unreliable. Entering our room for the first time, we found breakfast cereal bits in the bar sink and fluff on the floor. My brother-in-law, the manager of an international restaurant chain, looked from his room on to an ashphalt roof featuring underwear and a t-shirt left (presumably) by a previous guest. Daily items are costly: a packet of coffee in the room is $3.50, a standard-brand US beer by the pool is $7.50, and two standard coffees in paper cups (pour 'em yerself) plus a small square of dry cake is $10.50 by the pool, with no extra charge for unsmiling, dismissive service. The only way to enjoy the experience is to surrender and watch the dollars fly from your wallet.

<Author>Merlion1
<Content>A Good Family Property...if you keep Service Expectations in Check My wife and I travelled to Hawaii with our 2 sons (7 and 10 yrs old) over spring break. We were looking for a family oriented hotel with a good sized beach and chose the HHV. My expectations were low going in given the size of the property and what I thought would be a very mass market nature to it. I was in fact surprised on the upside in a number of areas.I'll break my review up into 4 areas:1. Room2. Facilities3. Restaurants4. ServiceROOM/LOCATION - AVERAGEWe stayed in the Tapa Tower (for the most part, the farthest wing from the beach - 2 minute walk!). The room was fairly unremarkable, double beds, TV, etc. and a balony. Bed was nice and firm, pillows fluffy, elevators fast. For the most part, we didn't spend much time in the room, so the fact that it was a pretty standard room wasn't a big deal. The one disappointment was room service. Given the size of the property, I probably shouldn't have been surprised, but on a rainy evening, we were told that it would take 1-2 hours for room service to be delivered! In contrast, when we had a problem in the room, guest services sent someone up to take care of it within 15 minutes.The hotel itself is located at the end of Waikiki Beach, but is a very walkable distance to the shops/activities downtown. For families, not actively participating in the night life, the location is fine. You can do a nice stroll in the evening along the beach without the loud music of the hotel bars closer to the center of town. For singles/couples, probably a bit removed from evening activities. In any case, we found it helpful to rent a car to go out to the North Shore, Hanama Bay, Bishop Museum, Pearl Harbor, etc. which was our focus rather than shopping downtown.FACILITIES - BIGGEST BEACH FRONT ON WAIKIKI, DISAPPOINTING SUPER POOLThe biggest benefit of the property is the size of the beachfront compared to other hotels on Waikiki. We had a nice plot of sand every day (even when we didn't come early) to build sand castles, throw the football, and lounge around. This was our priority when we searched for a hotel and we weren't disappointed. It has to be said that you have to pay for beach chairs, but it seems to be standard along Waikiki Beach. The biggest disappointment of the hotel, however, was the Super Pool. While large relative to some of the other pools we saw at other hotels in the area, it is about as big as a large backyard pool in the midwest of the US. Given the size of the property, no surprise that people reserve lounge chairs early in the morning which meant that if you didn't, you wouldn't have one for the whole day! During our week stay at the hotel we weren't able to secure 2 lounge chairs together on any of the days there.RESTAURANTS - PLEASANTLY SURRPISEDThe hotel has a large variety of restaurants, from the casual (Round Table Pizza, a deli, etc.) to upscale. Unsurprisingly, the ones located within the hotel itself (as opposed to among the shops) are pricey. However, for the money, the food in these restaurants was exceptional. My wife and I ate at the Chinese restaurant. Given we've lived in Asia for the last 10 years, we feared that it would turn out to be 'American Chinese food. We were happily surprised that it was some of the best Chinese Food we'd had in the US in a long time. During the day, Round Table Pizza was a staple for the kids and given the volume of orders they have, the turn it around quite quickly. For breakfast, would pass on the over priced buffett and leave the hotel. There's a diner right down the road (can't remember the name, but it's 1 block from the property entrance) which served a great breakfast and meant the kids didn't have to get up too early if they weren't so inclined.There is a small restaurant by the Super Pool which surprisingly has a very limited menu. Wait staff is very nice and attentive, but not much variety in the menu meant we didn't go there beyond the first time.SERVICE - PLEASANTLY SURPRISEDAgain, our expectations were low given the size of the hotel in particular. However, I must say that after a week, I was surprised at the consistent level of service received and the pleasant nature of the all staff encountered. When we arrived, despite a very full lobby, our luggage was tagged quickly and delivered to our room within 5 minutes of us arriving in the room. The event desk staff was very helpful with suggestions and bookings (and changes when oour luau was rained out). Given the size of the property, I think it unreasonable to expect personalized service of the kind seen at a Four Seasons or Ritz Carlton. Put in that perspective, our experience with the service staff at a minimum did not detract from the positive experience overall at HHV and, in several ways, enhanced our stay.Do keep in mind that you'll be nickeled and dimed to death at pool/beachl. You'll pay for beach chairs, lounge chairs, for towels if you don't return them at the pool, etc. CONCLUSIONThe HHV is a good family property with, I think among the biggest beachfront along Waikiki Beach. Rooms are OK, but nothing exceptional relative to other properties in the same price range. HHV is not a hotel where the service will overwhelm, so it is best to keep expectations in check in that regard (in lght of some of the reviews I've read). More than anything, it's a great jumping off point for the many attractions on Oahu with a staff who facilitates much of your stay.  
<Date>May 20, 2006

<Author>zoem
<Content>Terrific Hotel My husband and I stayed for 14 nights and it was absolutely wonderful - we were in the Tapa Tower on the 34th floor Ocean View - it was absolutely spectacular. The room was great - not overly large but really comfortable. The bed was the most comfortable we have ever slept in. Down pillows and duvet. The views were unbelievable. We also had a coffee maker in our room and got one packet free everyday - the only time you paid for it was if you used more than one packet per day....pretty good price for the internet service as well....Tapa pool was great - beach was beautiful....food was incredibly expensive - but if you go off site you can definitely save. The bus service was great - incredibly organized. Went on a great Island Tour which wasn't too long. The only negative thing I have to say about the whole thing is the housekeeping service was not too great. I had to call a couple of times to have them re do the room, but, overall it was #1. We'd go back in a heartbeat.....recommend it to anyone....  
<Date>May 19, 2006

<Author>dogbone1002000
<Content>A Beautiful Stay in the Kalia Tower We recently stayed at this hotel over Easter, and it was definitely an above average hotel. The entire complex is really it's own village. There are miles and miles of shops (extremely expensive) and lots of ABC stores (small convenience stores). I do think that dividing the hotel into 5 different towers was a good idea, otherwise the size of the place would be overwhelming. We stayed at the Kalia Tower, at the executive floors (top 22-25) in an ocean-view suite. The view was fantastic, and the room was nice, but average. Luckily, the executive floors recieved a free breakfast, snack and horderves, otherwise we would have been stuck paying the ridiculous prices ($13 for a regular hamburger, $21 for the good breakfast buffet) in the village. Something that sort of bothered us was that they charged for EVERYTHING, even the coffee for the coffee-maker in your room! Considering you pay over $400 per night for an oceanview suite, you would think they could at least throw in some coffee. Even cheap-o motels throw in coffee for free. All in all, for the money, you get a gorgeous hotel, with multitudes of pools and beach, and wonderful gardens, but you could probably do better to stay at a cheaper hotel near by and just walk through the gardens once in a while. However, if you love spectacular scenery and wish to stay in a place with tons of it, the Hilton Hawaiian Village is the place for you.*Also, a small footnote to add would be that we went on a FANTASTIC tour while we stayed on the island -- it wasn't too long and it took you to places you just don't see in Waikiki, gorgeous scenic photo opportunities too! We'd definitely reccomend it: E Moa Tours, and the Grand Small Island tour*  
<Date>May 3, 2006

<Author>bbydoll
<Content>Ali'i Tower at the Hilton Hawaiian Village the best! I stayed here a week for a conference and it was one of the most pleasant stays I've had in HNL. The Ali'i Tower is first class! I had large king room with ocean/city views that was extremely spacious. I had a small separate living space, desk, and a large flat screen TV. They had an afternoon ice service, turn down service, and this tower has it's own private pool!!! The pool was never crowded, quiet and peaceful. They also have a complimentary breakfast (continental) every morning. The HHV is a village: lots of shopping, excellent dining, lively bar (Tapa Bar). It is, from my understanding, the largest hotel on HNL, so expect a crowd when you venture outside of your tower. But the grounds are absolutely beautiful, the service wonderful, and the views breathtaking. I highly recommend it for families and business travelers alike.P.S. Added plus for business travelers is their 24 hour full service business center (shipping, printing, internet, copying), WIFI spots, and wireless internet in your room with the ability to print to a nearby terminal from your room (front desk or business center).

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Place For Family Vacation This was our first trip to Hawaii and we picked Honolulu, primarily to do as much of the typical tourist activities as possible. Planning for this trip, I researched this site and obtained a lot of great information to make the most out of our vacation. Now I'd like to give back and share our overall experience with future vacationers.We stayed at the HHV in the Ali'i tower for 7 nights, from 4/13 to 4/19. We picked this tower because the rooms are suppose to be bigger, nicer, and with a separate vanity area outside the bathroom (which I figure was needed for a family of four). The separate vanity was nice, but nothing like a 5 star hotel in Vegas. I would consider the room comfortable and the partial ocean view was more or less what I expected. We live in San Diego so an ocean view was not a big requirement for us. The hotel grounds as stated by many are spacious, well groomed, and always full of activities. We liked it, buit It was a bit loud at night when you're going to sleep with live music blasting. The HHV beach is by far the biggest and nicest after walking all of Waikiki beach. We only used it once due to the sewage spillage problem and opted for the pool when the kids wanted to go swimming. The sand is grainy and coarse not like sand you find in California or Florida. During our walk we saw the Halekulani hotel which was one park and 3 hotels to the east of the HHV. We had considered the Halekulani (based on reviews) but they only allowed 3 per room and we weren't going to pay for two rooms at those prices as they suggested. The beach in front of the Halekulani was a complete joke consisting of an area no more than 30' x 30' and a walkway for public access. You would need to use the beaches of the adjacent hotels to find any room. Also loud construction was occuring in front of this hotel. In contrast, the hotel is very clean, elegant, with a well manicured central courtyard. We also liked the Outrigger reef hotel and the Ala Moana hotel further down. At the HHV, my wife and I signed up for the massage at the Mandara Spa. It was great and very relaxing. They also have small shows at the base floors at three of the towers every night.FOODAs far as food goes, there are a million places to eat from affordable to very expensive. At the HHV grounds, we ate at the Golden Dragon (expensive, small portions, but very good), Benihanas (only went cause the kids like to see the chef do his stuff), Round Table Pizza (good pizza large for $25), and ABC store for snacks and drinks. We didn't do the buffet at the Rainbow tower, nor the continental breakfast based on the comments by others about pricing. The Ali'i tower does offer free hor doeurves at 5pm by the private pool. We snacked here twice. We also ate the Tropics bar on the ground floor of the Ali'l tower upon arrival for lunch. Fed kids hot dog, hamburgers, fries and drinks. Food was average but the bill was $50 ! Across the street, the Wailana Coffee House offers great value for breakfast/lunch/dinner as so many have noted. We ate here 3 times. We also went to Leonards Bakery for Masaladas, a Portugese pastry that should be eaten hot. Actually, my son and I walked there from the HHV after finding the street on the tourist map. BIg mistake. It turned out to be about a 3 mile walk, but after eating the Masaladas we decided it was worth the hike. We also ate a breakfast buffet one morning at the Outgrigger Reef hotel 5 minutes walk to the east. It was average and the price is $12/person.MAIN SHOPPING AREAHHV sits on the western edge of Waikiki and requires a short 15 min walk to the main shopping areas of Waikiki. This is well worth the visit for an afternoon or evening to see all of the other hotels and to browse the hundreds of shops. Recommendation: YES.GRAND ISLAND TOURWe signed up for this all day tour on the second day of our vacation. It turned out to be a great move to get an overview of the island. I highly recommend this tour. The tour also scheduled stops at many places for 10-20 minutes at a time for visting/siteseeing. Some stops included Hanauma Bay, Byodo temple, north shore beaches, Dole plantation, and our favorite the Waimea Falls. Our tour guide (Frank) was a riot and we enjoyed his crude jokes and comments, although some passengers didn't. Recommendation: BIG YES.DIAMOND HEADNIce hike to the top with great views of Waikiki hotels. We drove here in our rental car instead of going with a tour. Good way to spend a morning. Shaved ice stand at bottom was a nice ($4 each) way to finish this visit. Recommnedation: YES.PEARL HARBOR TOUR MISSOURI/ARIZONAThis is a half day tour to visit the memorial and to tour the retired battleship Missouri. The tour includes a movie and for me was emotional and rather depressing. The last part of the tour was to drive through punchbowl cemetery, not a big deal. Recommendation: NEUTRAL / ONCE IS ENOUGH.POLYNESIAN CULTURE CENTERDrove here instead of opting for a tour to give us flexibility to explore the island in the morning. The PCC opens at 12pm. We stopped at the Dole plantation again to do the maze and to visit their garden and shops. We didn't have time with the Grand Island Tour. To the near west of the PCC are several food stands that serve fresh shrimp with rice. Stopped for a snack at Giovannis shrimp stand as recommended by others. It was nice. At the PCC we did the self guided tour again for flexibility to see the shows at our own pace. Our ticket included the Ali'i luau. Food was good, not great. The big show at the end of the night was also entertaining. We left early cause the wife and kids were burnt out. The drive back was easy. I found the road well lit with many cars going back to Honolulu, contrary to comments by other saying the road was dark. In summary, the PCC is worth an initial visit, but we would not come back a second time. RECOMMENDATION: YES.ATLANTIS SUBMARINEOut of impulse, we booked the Atlantis sub ride. You are picked up at the pier in front of the HHV and driven out to the sub. The sub ride lasts about 45 minutes. We were very disappointed with the tour as we hardly saw any sealife. The sub goes on a preplanned route to visit man made sea habitats and a couple of sunken ships. For nearly $400 dollars for the four of us, I expected a lot more. RECOMMENDATION: NO.HANAUMA BAYTook my son snorkeling here one morning, while the wife took my daughter shopping. This place is great. We drove here rather than take a tour or bus. It's about 15 minutes from the HHV. I was worried about finding a parking space since the lot is closed after it becomes full. From the previous Grand Island Tour, I found the lot has plenty of spaces and I estimate you can find a spot if you arrive before 8:30am. No need to get here at 6:30am as some have suggested. You can rent all the snorkeling equipment at the beach for less than $10/person. You wil see lots and lots of fish. RECOMMENDATION: BIG YES.In summary, we were very happy with our stay at the HHV hotel. I thnk it's a great choice for a family with kids.  
<Date>Apr 22, 2006

<Author>movedsouth
<Content>Great hotel Hotel is great! We stayed here only two nights during April 2006. The hotel grounds are extensive for the Waikiki area. We stayed in the Ali tower and it was a beautiful and luxurious room. We had a great view of the ocean and Diamond head. We would have stayed longer, but the recent sewage problem in Waikiki made us change our plans to go to another island. I would definitely come back here again when the waters clear!

<Author>WhiteTower
<Content>Ho-hum My wife and I stayed at the HHV on Jan. 4-8, the first part of an 8-day trip that included staying at the Grand Wailea Resort on Maui.On the positive side, the HHV is unquestionably on the best part of Waikiki Beach. It's section of beach is both long and wide, and furthermore is adjacent to Fort DeRussy park, a scenic garden and park that is part of a military monument. As such, the HHV is separated from the crowded eastern end of Waikiki Beach.The HHV is an attractive property, with extensive and lushly landscaped grounds complete with scenic walkways, penguins(!) and flamingos.Additionally, the HHV has upscale shopping including men's and women's fashions and jewelry. The HHV is within walking distance (albeit a long walk) of the Ala Moana Center, the only true shopping mall in all the islands. Ala Moana is mid- to upscale, with a Macy's and Neiman-Marcus. (FYI, a taxi ride to/from Ala Moana is about $7 including tip.)The HHV has some nice restaurants -- we ate at Bali by the Sea and paid $95 for dinner. The HHV breakfast buffet is about $55 for two people but worth it once or twice.(For moderately-priced meals, there are several other eating choices in the Village --not run by Hilton -- that are mom-and-pop style restaurants such as: a sushi bar, a Thai noodles place, and a New York-style deli. The closest most cost-effective meal is the Waimea Cafe, a diner located literally across the street from the HHV. A yummy breakfast for two -- comparable to, say, Denny's -- is about $18, with lunch and dinner similarly less expensive. There are food courts located at Ala Moana Center and at the International Marketplace located in downtown Waikiki -- about a 15 minute walk. There is also an ABC convenience store on the HHV property, enabling guests to purchase soda, snacks, and alcohol for their rooms at much more reasonable prices.)Finally on the positive side, the service was polite and efficient, ranging from the front-desk people, to the restaurant service, to the maid service.Now for the negatives: the HHV is an *old* resort. The Rainbow Tower (where we stayed) was built in 1968 and you can tell. There are, for example, air conditioning problems. The south and east facing 01 corner rooms (#701, #1501, etc) have two external walls that are essentially glass doors that open to scenic balconies. We were booked in #701 but had to be moved to #1800 (the 00 rooms are also corner rooms, but facing facing south and west) because since the air conditioning is evidently so antiquated, all the 01 rooms have difficulty cooling as the eastern sun beats in throughout the day. (The HHV maintenance worker who inspected #701's air conditioning before we moved told me this.) So, despite the breathtaking views, the 01 rooms never really get cool inside.The decor and furnishings are all boring and probably a quarter-century old -- at least they looked it. Then there's the matter of timeshare sales. At the HHV you'll definitely be hit-up to go to a sales presentation. It's all rather bad form. (FYI, the Kalia and Lagoon Towers, I believe, are evidently entirely time-shares, meaning a sizable percentage of the resort is actually condos, and not hotel rooms.)Finally, and I suppose this isn't the HHV's fault, is Honolulu itself. The city is a seedy pig-sty with a definitive Third World feel to it. Go a few blocks outside the resort area of Waikiki and you can see what are effectively shanty-towns. I've lived (and currently live) in cities of over a million people (and Honolulu isn't actually a large city, by comparison) but I haven't seen such a yucky city elsewhere in America.So I suppose if you want a true resort in Hawaii, go to the Wailea coast in Maui or Kailua-Kona on the Big Island. You'll pay for it but you'll also get a resort feel -- which you certainly won't get on Waikiki. All-in-all: a ho-hum experience. Nothing bad or awful at the HHV, just not worth writing home and saying you're in paradise.  
<Date>Apr 9, 2006

31	4(nice):1	6(breakfast):2	10(restaurant):1	19(price):1	26(people):1	42(pay):1	47(eat):1	77(buffet):1	91(guest):1	96(worth):1	117(dinner):2	124(expensive):1	214(property):1	252(lunch):1	255(store):1	273(reasonable):1	347(twice):1	406(snack):1	758(sea):1	814(bali):1	887(purchase):1	925(convenience):1	1267(alcohol):1	1308(soda):1	1798(yummy):1	1813(comparable):1	2051(abc):1	2949(denny):1	3299(similarly):1	3696(hhv):3	3727(enable):1

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Realy enjoyed it! I've just got back from Hawaii where I travelled for a 10 day holiday with my sister. We stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village as we had read the reviews on TripAdvisor and would like to say that we really enjoyed our stay. The location for the hotel was absolutely perfect - a stones throw away from Waikiki beach, which at times, can be a little busy. We stayed in the Tapa Tower - we were pleased with our room which had a bar, two double beds and a balcony with a mountain and ocean view. The only thing which I can say about it is be careful of phonecalls which you may make using the hotel's phone. According to the book it said that numbers beginning with 8 were toll free, but we got charged a dollar for each call. Something to be wary of if you're calling around for trips and quotes. But the hotel does have an American Express desk which does tours to other islands etc. We did a few tours with them which were great. One great one was the 'Pearl Harbor and Circle Island Tour.' Apart from the phone issues, the place was great, staff and guests very friendly - an excellent and thoroughly enjoyable trip to Hawaii!!  
<Date>Apr 5, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Returning again and looking forward to it My wife are going to be there on Saturday April the 8th 2006 so look out :) We used to live in Kailua (dream town) and go back a couple times a year since we moved to SF for work. Hilton Hawaiian Village is classic. I have over 30 years experience there and it is special to me. When my dad was a pilot during the Vietnam war mom and I met up with him in Hawaii (at HHV) when he had leave. He did a few tours so we went 3 times. I can still remember standing there as a 7 year old boy our first day looking at the Rainbow Tower thinking it was magical. Hawaii is magical and so are the people. For that reason I prefer the Rainbow Tower it has a special memory for me. I have seen HHV grow over the years and it gets better. We were there in Sept of 05 last and it was an incredible visit. We do 1 week there and 1.5 weeks at Turtle Bay cottages (incredible but expensive). HHV has everything you need but I beg you go see the rest of the Island have plate lunch at LL (heard they closed? can't be)lay on the beach at Kailua. Drive the coast. I miss living there sooo much. Hint: While I stay at HHV I ALWAYS ALWAYS ALWAYS see several instances where guests are mistreating staff. This is Hawaii people stuff is not done instantly there. It is laid back. In watching outburst I have yet to see one where I am thinking yeah that guy or gal deserves to get ripped a new one. It is always some high strung person demanding something out of the ordinary and freaking out when it is not done right then and there. So here is my hintWhen you make the turn into the driveway, realize you are on vacation at a very magical spot. Expect and demand good service but realize it is slower more relaxed there. I know for a fact the HHV staff do care greatly about giving you a good time but you have to be kind to them. If you stand there screaming or upset over minor matters you are just one of 400 high strung people that week that have lost it. Try this... Screaming at people in Hawaii is a quick way to get nothing accomplished. Trust me.. Smile gently explain your issue, dilemna, problem, keep smiling, be nice and watch what happens. They will bend over backwards to fix it. They will often even give you extra service or something. When it comes to pleasing guests HHV has not peer. You just have to think laid back lifestyle. You gotta realize they have tons of guests there year round and the operation they have going is stellar and tight. I love HHV and look forward to seeing YOU there Saturday April the 8th 2006. I'll be the big goofy guy with a beautiful sweet wife. Enjoy HHV I highly recommend it. We just love it there. Of all the properties downtown HHV is simply the best most exciting place. The staff is in my opinion incredible in all the years not 1 bad experience.

<Author>aloha505
<Content>Kids loved hhv We stayed in the ali tower which was very well done. The beds were very comfy. My favorite was the bathroom setup it was divided into three large areas bathroom , shower and sink, huge dressing area with walk in closet more sinks all separated by doors. It made it very helpful since we were traveling with two boys.Room well done and recently updated. We had a pov which was great because it also overlooked the superpool where the show and fireworks were on fri. night, just watch from balcony . Food at the chinese restaraunt on site was fabulous worth the money, pricy. We also did the rainbow tower buffet breakfast great if free or coupon but not worth full price. The snack bar at ali tower great quick food. You must walk down beach for $2.00 giant shaved ice they were the best.We enjoyed pearl harbor and then walked to famous swap meet a few blocks away cheap to get in and worth it, tons of great deals torists and locals use this swap meeet . I think its only on Sat.,Sun. and weds. at stadium. We took cabs both ways at $35..00 a trip definately could do this cheaper with shuttles but alot more wait time with shuttles. Pearl harbor go early it does sell out.Last Dukes Canoe Club Way overrated our least favorite meal on oahu long waits and poor service and hotel was flooded due to rains and stunk.Loved walking along shops at Wakiki. Oahu is a must do but I wouldn't spend more than a few days then hit Maui or another island. Yes, we were rained out on part of our stay but made the best of it. Lots to do. I hope this helps I read this site alot before my trip and got lots of tips. Such a friendly island.

<Author>lovemypup
<Content>Beautiful location. . .but service sure isn't what it should be. . . I stayed 3 nights in the Ali'i Tower, which is nice, but probably not worth a return trip. It's close to the beach, has its own pool (quite small, but a very nice sundeck) and a nice continental breakfast each morning from 6:30-10. They charge $14, although I received it free with my AMEX platinum card. I am not sure I would have paid $14/day otherwise. The two ladies who work there in the morning are lovely. The rooms are nice, have flat screen tvs, a comfortable bed and couch, and nice lanais. It does include coffee and water, which apparently some of the other towers don't. They are supposed to come with turn-down service each night where they restock, but I needed to specifically ask for it 2 of the 3 nights. Eventually they did come, so all's well that ends well.I laughed at how hard the property tries to keep you on site. Between all the restaurants, shops, and the nice strip of beach, you really would never have to leave.The retailers are top of the line (Louis Vuitton, Maui Divers, etc). The people who work there are lovely and professional (esp Cindy in Maui Divers and both Laura and Laurie in Louis).However, I will say that everyone associated with the hotel is a little strained. No smiles or friendly greetings, a reluctant doorman, awkward bell service where you can't call ahead for your car but need to bring them the ticket and then just stand there and wait for it... it all detracts from the absolutely beautiful property with their pink flamingos and cute little penguins. One of the managers told me that hotel was recently downgraded to 3 stars because of poor service. I found that very telling. They should definitely take some lessons from the retailers.So, all in all, I got a great rate and perfect location for what I needed, but for vacation or personal trips, I will likely not be a return visitor.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>excellent Loved our stay at hilton hawaiian village. my husband and two teenage daughters stayed here - found a great deal on expedia - we got room in ali tower. it was spacious and very clean, the beds were awesomely comfortable. the bathroom was spacious which was great for 3 women trying to get ready! two sinks and a seperate toilet area - the plasma tv, the beautiful view of the garden was peaceful and quiet, the maid service 3 x's daily, the turndown service with chocolates, free newspaper daily, coffee/tea service and comp. water, all nice touches. Loved the complimentary appetizers each nite at the poolside cabana on 2nd floor. all were yummy and we didnt' even need dinner those nights as we were full from appetizers. So we would go out for a great dessert each night somewhere. Having the private pool on 2nd floor for ali tower was great too - and the hot tub! Beautiful views of the grounds and the beach from pool side. The only downside was the price of drinks...$ 8.75 for a cocktail. very pricey. ;o( and the continental breakfast offered in ali tower poolside - very expensive for skimpy offerings. $ 14 a person for basic rolls/toast, some fruit, and cereal. You can get a large buffet for about $20+ Paying $14 for continental breakfast. Crazyespecially when we did go down the last morning as we were rushed to catch our flight, and the girls wanted something quick for breakfast, so we went there and at about 15 min. to 10am, the staff started taking the breakfast items away already! My daughter was getting a piece of bread out to toast, and the waitstaff gal came and grabbed the toaster off the table while looking at my daughter! If it says they serve til 10am, they should leave the items out til 10am. The staff there seemed rushed and wanting to get it all cleaned up by 10am. Other than that we LOVED stay there, and the rest of the staff was very friendly and helpful.

<Author>DiamondTraveler
<Content>HHV got it right, great trip for hard to please Gold Member The HHV got it right. It was my spring break family vacation and not the many trips for business that I stay at Hiltons that have made me a gold member. We paid for an ocean front room in Rainbow tower and did not use points because it was our vacation and the room with a view was a must and did not want to leave it to chance, but was concerned about the size of the room with two teenage boys in tow. I fretted more about this trip after reading some of the reviews. I was hoping that this trip might be a 7 at best and instead I got a 10 trip and it was all due to the HHV taking care of us and realizing what our needs where. On arrival we where upgraded to a one bedroom suite in the Tapa tower instead of the ocean front double. Wonderful!!! Two bathrooms, a master bedroom with a door and two Tv's, 2 balconies and a great view. We loved the room. They also added breakfast coupons for the family for the various places to eat with a very reasonable upgrade fee. The resort is very nice and the food was expensive but good.I would hope other Hiltons would take notice of when thier regulars travel and come to vacation that they upgrade and pamper like HHV did.Before this trip I was thinking about switching to another hotel chain, because many of the other Hiltons are just not doing enough for their Hilton members, a bottle of water and upgrade to the spa, just does not cut it.So great work HHV. We enjoyed the resort and all that the area has to offer. We will be back and I will look forward to it.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Classic hotel I know the hotel very well. As a child my father was a bartender there in the 70-80s so I hung out there a lot. Staying there was a great experience. There was a reviewer who complained that everything had a price. I have travelled much and all hotels now even in Vegas require extra, so I don't understand what world he/she is living in. There is no free bottle water or coffee in any hotels any more unless you have included continental breakfast in the lobby.Cable is mostly basic. Even HBO is a luxury now. And lanudry is always expensive. Most people bring enough for the trip. Just pack febreeze in your bag!Once in Vegas, in a hotel not to be named, I took back some great leftover pizza to my room. The frig was so tiny, I had to take out the bottles of soda and water in the frig to cram the leftover in. I left the bottles and cans in plain sight, unopened, undamaged. I was charged for all the bottles and cans, my leftover removed from the frig to be placed unrefrigerated on the counter and the same bottles replaced. Of course I didn't know this until I got the bill a month later after doing express check out. I ultimately got credit back.The Hilton is very close to the heart of Waikiki, and it's active, populated like any hotel in Vegas. If you are looking for a getaway, research better because any hotel in Waikiki is not the isolated resort some people are looking for. It's fun and busy. It has night clubs, bars, it's own beach, restaurants and shops. If you want isolation the go to the outer islands or look into the Mandarin Hotel or Ka Olina in Kapolei, Oahu.The HHV is a classic hotel, it may be dated in some areas but many hotels that have been around are like that. Even presidents have stayed there. You can't go wrong.  
<Date>Mar 25, 2006

<Author>Travelinto25Cities
<Content>A Great Property This is a small city in of itself. It's an excellent property with literally everything you need close by. Wireless access charges were excessive ($12.95 a day) so I found a third party access point for $29.95 a week. I had to access it on the balcony but that's a great place to hang out.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Loved the Hilton! We stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village in the Tapas Tower in June 2005. The hotel was beautiful. The room was beautiful, clean, comfortable and king size bed fabulous. We purchased the breakfast buffet as a part of hotel cost and it was outstanding. We ate pancakes with coconut and coconut syrup every day! The hotel has everything you need. Drugstores, restaurants, bars, shopping are all over the place. The hotel is not right on the main strip but we took the trolley everywhere. The beach was great and so were the pools. We also loved the warm weather penguins. I recommend this hotel to everyone. If you can afford it the Ali Tower looked like heaven. We were very happy and would stay there again.

<Author>Jabroni99
<Content>Loved this Hotel!! We just came back from here and we really enjoyed our stay. I agree with some of the other reviews on the super pool and the price of beach chairs/umbrella's. But have you checked out the other hotels? We did, their beach area is pretty well non existant, their pool is much smaller and their food prices are just the same. That is to be expected in Hawaii. We found the Hilton Hawaiian to be the best for your dollar, the beach area is spectacular,as well as the grounds. If the food is too pricey, do what we did, buy alot of fruit/bread/snacks etc. at the ABC stores and keep in your fridge. That really cut down on the price of food. As for daily parking, try parking in San Francisco, we paid $36 per day. We asked for an upgrade and received one (not always possible) but if they can they will(Thanks again Rissa, your the best) Don't forget, relax and enjoy this is your vacation everything at this hotel compared to the others we saw is by far way more superior. Loved It!!!  
<Date>Mar 17, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Just enormous! This place was huge, acres of resort! We stayed in the Kalia Tower which is the newest on the 9th floor. The room was nice, very clean and neat - nothing spectacular but modern.It had views of the ocean and the rainbow tower and has it's own pool on the same floor at the health spa which was handy.Staff were friendly, but give Beni-hana a miss if you have been to others, no tricks really even though food was fine.On Friday night's they have a polynesian show by the pool and fireworks. We recommend going to the Golden Dragon restaurant on this night as we did and it is the most beautiful food and you can watch the fireworks from the balcony.Lots of designer shops, but also a few pratical ones such as ABC Convenience store. The Rainbow Lanai buffet was good, but we went to the Tapa tower buffet most days as it wasn't as busy. Has a nice outlook over a pool and the new wedding chapel.There is penguins, flamingos, turtles etc. in ponds around the resort so look our for those.Great place for couples, families etc. We enjoyed the large pool, but getting a deck chair is difficult. The beach is nice and calm, good for families.We self-parked, which seemed easier from our tower than valet parking. Although the Kalia tower has it's own desk (which is handy when checking out), there is sometimes a delay in valet parking from here.They apparently charge you for the in-room safe per day, but it never came up on our bill.As honeymooners we got a nice bottle of champagne. Our package included breakfast which was good.It is about a 15-20 minute walk out of the main street, which was a blessing due to the construction of the Beach Walk.You have to go to the Ala Moana Shopping Centre, it is enormous - we loved Bubba Gump's (based on the movie Forrest Gump), the shrimp is fantastic. We would stay at this hotel again.  
<Date>Mar 16, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>The best place in Honolulu This was our 2nd visit to this island and hotel, so we knew what to expect. Last time we stayed at the Diamond Head tower and had no complaints about the room. This time we wanted to be closer to the beach, so we requested the Rainbow tower. Thanks to my husband's Diamond VIP status with HHonors, we usually get upgraded to a better room. Our room in the Rainbow Tower was a double room with 2 bathrooms, 2 balconies, king size and a sofa bed. No ocean view, but the view is never our priority as we try not to spend much time in the room on any vacation. There are 6 toweres: Rainbow and Ali are the oldest and closest to the beach and the Super pool, Tapa and Kalia are the newest, but the farthest from the beach. Kalia has it's own pool and the hotel's ONLY tiny hot tub. There's nothing super about the SuperPool, but again, not a priority for us. However, if you prefer to spend time by the pool consider requesting a tower with it's own pool. Also, be prepaired to wake up early to reserve a chair by the Superpool, as there's not enough of them. The hotel grounds are nice enough, but pale in comparisson to the Hilton on the Big Island or the Hyatt in Maui, where you truly see Hawaii in it's splendor. The hotel's beach is one of the best on Oahu. Again, don't expect the sweeping beaches of the Carribean, but it's pretty nice for Honolulu. At $51/day the price for beach lounges and an umbrella is unreasonable (in my opinion), so we took a short drive to Wal-Mart and bought those for $10 each. They also sell an umbrella holder, you screw it it the sand and you umbrella stays put in any wind. It worked so well, we brouhgt it home with us and will use it at the beach here. Another advise: look through the travel booklets, i.e.Oahu Today, etc. There's lot's of coupons for restaurants(2 for 1 at the Thai place across the streetfrom the Hilton and many others), Luau (20% off the Germaines) and lot's of activities. Haunuma Bay snorkeling is great, but be there early in the morning or after 2 pm to avoid crowds. We rented our equipment from Snorkle Bob, so you can use it for several days.Food: the only meal we ate at the hotel (Rainbow Lanai) regularly was breakfast. This is only because my husband got a huge discount: we paid $3.50 for a continental buffet(no hot items). We found the selection, service and food quality at the buffet to be excellent, but I would never pay it's full price of $19.95. The food on the hotel property is extremely overpriced, so plan accordingly. I would also recommend to rent a car for at least several days. The island has many beautiful spots and we enjoyed some spectacular drives. The Japanese temple deserves a visit.The hotel has fireworks every Friday and a Luau. It's nice to walk around in the evening with all the nice lights and beautiful music playing. They really try but the Hilton is just too huge to create this warm and fuzzy feeling. One last thing: if your plane leaves at night, request a hospitality suite, where you can take a shower and change after a day at the beach. A very nice touch that not many hotels offer. Overall, our family had a great time, but again, it was a free trip for us and things may've looked different if we paid top dollar for this stay.  
<Date>Mar 15, 2006

<Author>docajenk
<Content>Excellent We stayed 5 nights in the Kalia Tower in a mountain view room. The hotel has beautiful grounds and lots of facilities. The Kalia and Ali towers both have thier own swimming pools and jacuzzi whereas the other towers they are communal. The Kalia tower is the newest and the rooms were really nice, spacious, well furnished, good size bathroom and very clean. Beach is also lovely. The hotel has many eating options, however the service is variable and the prices expensive. The location is such that you are within a very short walk of cheap/good restuarants and shopping malls as well as Waikkiki itself. Our only complaint was the service, being a large hotel they don't really bother and can be quite cold and unhelpful at times.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Everyone Has A Hand Out As a government traveler, I have come to expect that certain ammenities are not part of the accomodations that I expect, and pay for, while traveling on per diem. The Hilton Hawaiian Villiage takes this concept to the extreme. From the moment I checked in, I found that even the most basic ammenities that I expect with a hotel room cost extra. Everything from the short bottles of water and small packets of coffee in the room that are usually considered complementary had an exhorbitant price tag attached to them. There was only very basic cable TV available, unless you paid for more channels. Even the internet service was (very)extra. Most places where I stay include these as part of the package. There is also no self-service laundry facility at this hotel and the cost of their in-house laundry service nearly exceeds the cost of new clothes. (It was a relief to find that the oxygen that I consumed during my stay came with no extra charge.) I felt more like a source of revenue than a welcome guest. It might not seem like a big deal to some, but this constant stream of fees really takes that welcome feeling away.If you do decide to patronize the Hilton on Waikiki and are assigned to the Rainbow Tower, beware. You will be nickel-and-dimed to no end. They never let you forget that you are a government traveler.  
<Date>Mar 8, 2006

<Author>CherylP
<Content>Gorgeous Slice of Paradise We had a wonderful visit to the Hilton Hawaiian Village. We stayed in the Ali'i Tower (definitely ask for an upgrade to this tower) and enjoyed the experience. The rooms are beautiful, the beds comfortable, the lanai's beautiful views. Excellent property. The only negative was the food was so so at several of the restaurants. I thoroughly enjoyed the gorgeously landscaped grounds, the wildlife (penguins!!!), swans, koi, birds and the beautiful flowers, including orchids, growing wild. The beach is close and accessible. Negatives would be everything has an extra cost. Internet access is extra, parking is expensive, coffee in the room is extra, but if you know that you can pick and choose wisely where to spend your money. The shops are delightful and make walking around the grounds very enjoyable. All in all, a wonderful experience.CherylMinneapolis

<Author>our3kids
<Content>great place We got back a week ago from a week long stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. I read some of the reviews before we left, and cannot understand what all of the complaining was for from some of the reviews that I read. We had an absolutely great time. The hotel was completely booked (President's Week), and we estimated that with 3,000 rooms, there were approximately 10,000 guests that week, but you would never know it. You did need to go down early to get a lounger by the superpool, but that was nothing to complain about. The staff was courteous, the rooms were terrific and the view was to die for!! The hotel grounds are beautiful and there really is no reason to leave the hotel grounds. We did go on day journeys but also enjoyed the days sitting by the pool or on the beach (which just happens to be the best part of Waikiki Beach.) I would go back to this hotel in a heartbeat and would recommend it without hesitation.  
<Date>Mar 3, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Tourists abound in a convenient location, classy accomodation My husband and I stayed in the Rainbow Tower for three days while I attended a conference on the grounds of the resort. The hotel was extremely busy, but the room was very tidy, hotel staff always assisted with needs in and out of the room and the resort has a lot of amenities. The most pleasant aspect is the beach on property! We took several day-tours, and recommend concierge advice (for tours and dining) over the American Express travel desk in the lobby. He was able to provide us with better deals and suggestions for traveling in Hawai'i. Don't eat at the Japanese restaurant on Hilton's property (I'm not speaking about Benihana's, but the smaller restaurant across from the book shop). It was the worst Japanese food we have *ever* had. In contrast, the quiche at the little caf茅 in the Kali Tower must have been phenomenal; my husband ate there every morning that I was at the conference!A few highlights for your trip:- Sam Choy's restaurant is AMAZING for a fine dining experience- Visit 'Leonard's Bakery' for fresh, hot malasadas (Portugese pastries)- Seabird Tours - coupon in 'Best of Oahu' (pick up at concierge desk) for $12 round trip transport and gear to snorkel at Hanauma Bay- Polynesian Cultural Center - don't spend extra for the 'Ambassador' package unless you can't navigate yourself around a theme park; don't take a tour with Rob (Samoa)- Chinatown is a lot of fun for an afternoon walk or for a photo-shoot- Go to Hanauma Bay early, early in the morning (otherwise the water becomes cloudy from swimmers)- Take a hike with 'Oahu Nature Tours' - Mike, the owner, is extremely knowledgeable and helpfulHave a wonderful time! Aloha!  
<Date>Feb 25, 2006

<Author>maxwell2424
<Content>Lovely Ali'i Tower We stayed in the Ali'i Tower for 3 nights this past weekend, after a week in Kauai. We booked our room through the American Express Platinum Fine Hotels and Resorts programme. We paid $311 for a partial ocean view room and that included an upgrade, (when available)continental breakfast for 2 each morning, a lunch for 2 at the Rainbow Lanai during our stay and a 4pm checkout upon departure.We, (my husband, 13 year-old daughter, 8 month son and I) arrived at 11:15am and found that our room was not ready yet. We had lunch by the private Ali'i pool and ended up eating for free because the food took a long time to get to us. Our room was ready by 1:00pm and we were pleasantly surprised to find that we had been upgraded to a corner room on the top floor with a wraparound balcony. Very romantic if we didn't have the kids with us! There was a king bed and a cot was provided for our 13 year-old.We tipped our breakfast waitress well and never had to pay for the extra breakfasts for our daughter. We never had any problems with service in the Ali'i Tower and found it to be a nice relaxing oasis in the middle of the hectic HHV. If we could guarantee room A1505 when we return to Waikiki next time without the kids, then we MIGHT stay at the HHV again....but I think that I would still rather stay at the Halekulani. It's smaller, more centrally-located and a lot less Orlando if you catch my drift.
