<Author>jongtheman
<Content>Too crowded but overall very nice to stay I expect peacefulness and senerity when I was booking my trip to Ohau. But Waikiki simply is too crowded if you are looking for relaxation. I was there for 5 nights a week before the Pro bowl and the frontdesk guy told me that it was a slow week but boy the lobby was swamped with people from all over the world. And it definitely was too busy for my taste.Otherwise, Hilton Village is very convenient nice place to stay. There were many restaurants and shops within the hotel. The beach is located right next to your building (we stayed at Diamond Head Tower). Also many beach activities (submarines, dinner ships, ect) is located right at the Hotel. If you requested oceanview room, you have a spectacular view of Waikiki beach. Hotel room itself is just okay. Nothing to awe about.In fact, we had a minor problem with the sink in our bathroom and the room service came and fixed it. Overall I enjoyed my stay at Hilton. Just expect a little crowdness if you are thinking about staying at Hilton. But I am sure you will enjoy your stay.

<Author>Ryanoles
<Content>Great rooms Simply put, the Hilton Hawaiian Village is a great place to stay. Before I go on vacation, I always put in hours of research into the hotels I am going to be staying at and I carefully selected the HHV based on the criteria of location, cost, past reviews, and pictures of the hotel. The HHV exceeded my expectations and I was disappointed when I had to leave the place because I really enjoyed it.I stayed in the Rainbow Tower on the very south side of the village, which is the one that is right on the beach and from what I hear is the best one to stay at. It was Pro Bowl week so the place was pretty packed.The room was beautiful, it had a nice flat screen television but the remote control and keyboard didn't seem to work properly 100% of the time and I'd wind up having to press the buttons several times before they would compute. The beds were very comfortable and I had a great sleep each night on them. The bathrooms were clean and decent sized, so no complaints there.The HHV contains four swimming pools, but I didn't utilize any of them so I can't comment too much on them other than what I saw of them. They all looked very nice and seemed to be pretty popular with the guests, I even saw John Elway (NFL Hall of Fame QB) lounging by the pool so it must be good. The staff was very friendly at the place which is always a plus, and the check-in process went by rather quickly despite the large volume of people. I have read past reviews that say that it took a very long time, but I didn't experience that.The real only negatives with this place is that everything is very expensive, though you do have to keep in mind that if you want to travel to exquisite places you have to pay exquisite prices. The dining also left a lot to be desired, especially when some of the restaurants on site seemed to be closed at certain times for no apparent reason. Also, you better like walking if you are going to stay here because the HHV is a huge property and requires plenty of walking to get around the perimeter.If I were to return to Oahu I would definitely stay here again, I loved the place.  
<Date>Feb 20, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Nickel and Dime Central! My husband and I just returned from a week in Oahu. The first few nights we stayed at the Marriott located just next door to the Hilton and the remaining four nights we stayed at the HHV. In years past, we have stayed at the HHV, The Four Seasons on Maui as well as the Grand Wailea. I have never had such HORRIBLE service or felt so nickel and dimed to death as I felt on this trip to the HHV. Believe me, I was not alone! I was shocked to see the sign in our room next to the coffee stating that for an extra package of coffee the charge would be $3.25, a tea bag was $1.95 and the list went on! For a room that cost well over $400 a night, the coffee should have been plentiful. I've stayed in far more expensive hotels and much less expensive hotels as well to find that we can have as much coffee, or tea as we like. It was insulting! My husband who was on a semi-business trip to the pro-bowl with some clients wanted to get some work done early one morning by the pool. So, at 7:45 I went to get a couple of towels and was told I had to go to the front reception area of the hotel and get ask the hotel Assistant Manager on Duty for a towel. Again, unbelievable. After returning to the pool, we were asked to leave - the pool didn't open until 8:30 and although we weren't IN the pool, we couldn't read the paper and and work on a laptop in one of the chaise lounges next to it. It was against hotel policy. Again, for $400 a night, I found this totally unacceptable. So, at 8:30, we stood IN LINE for 15 minutes to get a chair by the pool. Bottom line is that the hotel doesn't have enough space for the guests it has even though they have four pools. If you want to use one of the hotels beach chairs on the beach, be willing to pay $13 a day for it. Again, silly for a hotel guest. A free service to other upscale resorts we've stayed in. Once as I was getting up to use the restroom, a pool boy walked up with a sign that said if I left my chair unoccupied, they would take my towel and belongings to the pool hut. I told the man I was only going to the restroom and would be back in 5 minutes. His response, Sorry, it's hotel policy. If you aren't in your chair, I have to leave a sign. I couldn't believe it. What a joke!!! One morning we had breakfast in the Rainbow Lanai. The buffet was good and the view was wonderful. After we had paid our bill, I went back up to the hostess and told her we had just eaten in the restaurant and wondered if I could get a cup of coffee to go, she came back (acting totally put out) and brought me a cup of coffee, slammed down the creamer and handed me a bill for $3.65. Like an idiot, I paid it. I should have walked across the street to Starbucks and paid the same price for a decent cup of coffee. It's true the grounds are absolutely stunning - you can walk them all you want for free. My suggestion is to save your nickels and dimes and stay next door where the beds are equally if not more comfortable. I'm not a cheap person and I'm MORE than willing to pay for good service, good food and high quality. I just don't feel like I got my money's worth at HHV. I left there feeling like took every red cent they could from everyone who was willing to give it to them. We talked to reporters and producers from ESPN who felt the exact way we did. We talked to other people from the software industry who said they would never go back. We ALL agreed that the property is nice but you can't even go work out or use your laptop without having to jump through major hoops to do so. It's so not worth it. Feel free to contact me if you want further information. I'd be more than happy to share.  
<Date>Feb 15, 2006

<Author>KayinCal
<Content>Beautiful, beautiful hotel grounds at Hilton Hawaiian Village My husband and I stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village from Jan. 29 to Feb. 3. This was a business/pleasure trip and our first time to Oahu, fourth time to the Islands. Our reservation was for a partial oceanview with king bed; however, we automatically were upgraded to full oceanview with two doublebeds when a king wasn't available. Terrific! I found the staff extremely pleasant and helpful, and the room was clean and comfortable. Great view of, well, everything since we were on the 26th floor. The hotel grounds were what really pleased me, though. Gorgeous landscaping that is meticuously maintained everyday. Exotic birds around every corner with many wild birds encouraged to visit by feeding stations set on rooftops. Lovely waterfalls, koi ponds, winding pathways, Hawaiian statuary, daily beach grooming, etc., etc.! Very impressive for such a large property.  If I was to offer one suggestion to the hotel it would be to add those wall-mounted makeup mirrors to the bathrooms. 'Bet they would be used and appreciated more than the Gameboy systems that are in each room. I was rather surprised that the Hilton didn't have such mirrors, in fact. The only negative I have about HHV -- and I'm uncertain if this is something that the Hilton even controls -- is that some salesladies in the jewelry stores on the hotel premises were EXTREMELY aggressive. What was to be an enjoyable afternoon window shopping was ruined by their pushy tactics and swarmy come-ons. Class-less acts at a classy hotel.  
<Date>Feb 4, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Best honeymoon ever-5 star review see our other 6 night stay review at the hilton waikoloa. as for our 6 nights on oahu, the hilton impressed-BIG TIME!(preface: we only stay at top resorts and love fine dining, we are avid travelers and are picky about hotels) that said, if you know the right buttons to push and go at the right time of year, this will be a fabulous hotel.facts:1. people who say ali tower is best are dillusional, you stay on waikiki for the views, and none better than the rainbow tower. ali tower has only slightly better amenities, if any. rainbow rooms have casually elegant beachy feel, BEST beds and linens, and are recently all rennovated (with higher floor diamond head facing rooms the best (large swiveling flat panels plasma TVs, best views, best wetbars) if you dont stay rainbow tower, DONT STAY. i wont give our room away but any room ending in 01 are the BEST...better than their $2K a night suites. i arranged a top floor double balcony 'suite' for our stay and we were absolutley mezmorized by the views, luxury and service. i am hilton gold VIP and made sure we got upgraded from a standard room as i used points for this stay. you just have to make sure you push for the room you want--call in advance if you have to. rainbow is also central to everything.2. pools great, beach THE BEST on waikiki as is the surfing spot. we went jan 25...all quiet, no crowds!!! we loved waikiki even better than the reknowned secluded beaches--maybe it was the time of year but it was idealic! lots of bars/restaraunts, but all classy. after reading the reviews that said this hotel is a madhouse, i am amazed how different the times you stay will make your vacation here. WE THOUGHT IT WAS MORE QUIET HERE THAN THE BIGISLAND!!!!!3. food=awesome! golden dragon chinese, round table pizza, CJs deli, etc...4. water=clear, lots of coral farther out, pebbly at waters edge, gold sand beach, incredible sunsets...wow.5. staff and housekeeping all 5 star6. grounds, cannot be explained, 5 star.tips:dinner at orchids, sunset catameran with outrigger, hike with samson at oahu nature tours, hanuma bay snorkeling.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Nice retreat from our rain We just returned...good trip. We have a 14, 11 yr old plus an 11 month baby. They upgraded us for free to an end room in TAPA tower....back garden view. huge room. difficult for a family of 5 to share one room, but it was ok. we didnt rent a car but should have. go to ALa Moana Shopping center and get groceries for the frig. everything is expensive, but this is typical. the only complaint is that the pool is not heated and a but chilly in january. this section of waikiki is a lot quieter than downtown. nice to be fully enclosed in a village with everyting right there. the teens could go on their own to explore and i felt it was safe. i would not have let them do this at other downtown hotels. the fridaya night show is perfect and we did this instead of a pricey long luau. it was just right for our family. the hotel was under some construction but not a real problem. we would return.

<Author>waikiki518
<Content>HHV is the best!!! My sisters and I (ages 22, 20, 20) stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village for 5 nights in May. We absolutely loved the hotel! We didn't have any problems during our stay. The staff was extremely friendly and helpful. The grounds of the hotel are gorgeous and extremely well kept. They have animals such as penguins and flamingos. We stayed at the cheapest tower, the Tapa Tower, and we loved it! Since we belong to the Hilton Honors Club we had a quick check-in and we were upgraded to a partial ocean-view room. The room was clean and big enough for the three of us and the view was beautiful. Every night we sat out on our lanai and listened to the live band in the Tapa Bar. The only place we ate at the HHV was Round Table Pizza. It wasn't too expensive and the pizza was good. The HHV has the widest stretch of beach along Waikiki Beach and it was never crowded. On Friday nights the hotel has a fireworks show. We sat on the beach a little ways down from the hotel and we could see the fireworks perfectly above the ocean. The super pool was usually crowded but there was always a spot available at the Tapa Pool which was a little smaller but just as nice. The Kahuna Dog (a food stand right next to the Tapa Pool) was reasonably priced and their coconut shaved ice was really big and delicious!! We bought all of our breakfast foods and snacks at the ABC store in the hotel. The ABC store is a very inexpensive place to buy anything you need on your vacation :)(There is also an ABC store at every corner in Waikiki) Although the Hilton Hawaiian Village is located at the end of Waikiki Beach, it is still only a short walk to everything on Kalakaua Ave. We had absolutely no complaints whatsoever for the Hilton Hawaiian Village and we had the time of our lives!!! Everything at the HHV made our dream vacation come true!!! We also just booked our next trip at the Hilton Hawaiian Village for 10 days this May. We wouldn't think of staying anywhere else!!  
<Date>Jan 13, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>ONE OF MY BEST VACATIONS-EVER I always knew that I was goint to stay at HHV because I like staying at upscale mega-resorts. My only problem was determing in which tower to stay in at HHV. Though the place appeared to be family friendly, I can only write about what my husband and I experienced (both in our 30's and avid travelers).First of all, yes Hawaii is expensive; but you get what you pay for. I was able to see rooms in all of the towers in HHV except the Tapa Tower. I saw a room on the 8th floor of the Kalia Tower. It is the newest tower and very nice but is furthest from the beach. The Mandara Spa is located here on the 4th Floor. The Diamond Head Tower is close to the beach but in my opinion, appeared to be a little run down. I saw a room on the 16th floor and the view was allright. The one bedrooms suites had a seperate living room but the bathroom was small. The rooms here are extremely large but need to be updated. The rooms in the Rainbow Tower are very close to the beach and have a restaurant located here. I saw a room with a partial ocean view on the 16th floor. The rooms appeared to be very nice and recently renovated (it was the first tower built on this property). The Alli Tower is right on the beach and is the most expensive tower of them all. I stayed here on the 10th floor in an ocean front room. These rooms have more amenities than the other towers including a private pool and hourdourves served nightly. The rooms feature sitting areas with flat screen TV's. Was it worth the extra money for the Alli Tower? If you can afford it, YES! If I don't have the extra money, I recommend the Rainbow Tower and then the Kalia Tower.The entire staff was helpful and courteous. I would stay here again in a heartbeat. I hope my reveiw helps:)  
<Date>Jan 13, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Money, Money, Money...MONEY! I read a lot of reviews here before we left for our Honeymoon at HHV and I knew to keep my expectations low and my hopes high for a room upgrade. My wife insisted we be on the beach and stay at a reputable hotel. Due to an unexpected, last minute, change in plans we had to paid for room-select. Which means we get what room is available at check-in, no guarantees...just roll the dice.Most people's complaints are valid. We stayed during peak holiday time Dec. 27-Jan. 4 (wife is a teacher) and were treated, at times, like just another lame touristy couple. However, House-keeping was always very pleasant. Lounge chairs by the super-pool (that is a joke) very limited, fought over, horded because they are free! Lounge chairs for the beach $12 dollars per and by the way the beach sand along and in the water is full of big rocks/reef! I am sorry but Waikiki beaches are lousy compared to lots of places(i.e the New Jersey shore if you can believe). The water is clear and a cool 72-75 degress. I prefer the caribean's 80's when I am wading, floating, and relaxing. The weather was beautiful for the first 4 days...not a cloud in the sky!The food at most of the resturants is mostly average and always way overpriced. I suggest go out side of the grounds for breakfast and lunch. Try the Wailana Coffee House across the street. Fill your room frig. with drinks and snacks from any of the miriad of ABC stores. A Walmart, I read, is a 10minute walk near Ala mona park for cheap beach chairs.Our up-graded deluxe ocean view honeymoon room was clean but the view was bad. Room 304 is the first floor in the Rainbow tower and it looks out at the harbor parking lot and abandoned lagoon. However, the wicked sunset view from just beyond the railing, when I crained my neck and leaned over, was a big plus and something I have to remind myself of when I feel like I spent too much.Alcohol drinks are $11.95. Twice what they should cost, but maybe I am being cheap.Overall, we spent a lot of money for paradise and I guess that is to be expected. Bottom-line stay somewhere else and just walk around the Hilton Hawaian Village as if you have a room...its too big a place for anyone to notice or care and the penguins keep hush.  
<Date>Jan 11, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Still spinning with delight After reading many of the reviews written months prior to our 12day stay,we were somewhat anxious that we had made the right choice--However no need to worry we had a fantastic time(family of 6 including Grandmother and 15,17,20year old) After a not so comfortable 10 hour trip, our welcome was overwhelming,smiles and leis at the airport,more welcome smiles and greetings at reception with wonderful glasses of fruit punch being constantly offered. We were in the Rainbow Tower ,great views,morning noon and night,which we really appreciated even though we live at home mtrs from the beach-- the rooms were a little smaller than anticipated, but spotless and the soft beds were divine. Housekeeping were fantastic and really looked after us. We had breakfast at the Rainbow tower, service was great, and to be greeted by name each morning was really nice.Special thanks to Sue-- Food --who could wish for a greater variety.The gardens, the shops,the entertainment,the service were all excellent. Its true everything is more expensive at the village,but if it doesn't suit there are heaps of other options all within walking distance. We should have stayed longer, perhaps next year.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Typical Hilton --- :-( My family(wife, 18 son, 16 daughter) and I are avid travelers to hawaii, at least twice to three times a year. We are from the chicago area so we always excited to leave. We typically stay at the Manderine Oriental or the Halekulani but we heard so many great things about the Hilton Villige we just had to se for our self.Well let me just say from the start it was no picnic. The front drive through where the limo let us off was unbelievably packed, and with not enough bell staff we had to wait nealry 30 MIN for them to come and take our luggage. UNACCEPTABLEAfter waiting in the long airport-like line to check-in we were told that since we supose to be in at 11 but we were in at 1230 (b/c of an airplane delay and the outside wait) that they gave our suite ($825 p/n) in the ALI'I tower away!They acted graciously and said that they had the same type aroom available in the Kalia tower at the same rate.After wondering the property for a while we found the building hiding in the back of the resort.After getting to the suite--room we opened the door and to our dismay it was just a standrd room with a view of a top of a building w/ maintnence machines.We called down and infomed them of the mistake. they claimed that was the only available room. we then talked to the manager, who upgraded us to a suite in the same tower w/ a city view at the same cost. which is rediculous b/c that is the budget tower! That suite should of been no more that 600 tops. We spent the night (b/c it was late) and moved to the mandarine oriental where we were treated like royalty.STAY AWAY

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>More or less full service resort HHV is a solid full service resort. There are several room types, many restaurants, shopping, and other activities. We stayed in the Kalia Tower, using Hilton points. It was a pleasant stay. This is a resort for people who like lots of people around. The restaurants had fairly average Hilton restaurant food. I would not eat there unless I had to. We were disappointed that neither of the Japanese restaurants were open; we were looking forward to sushi, Hawaiian style. We ended up leaving the resort for most meals.The spa services at the Kalia Tower were excellent. On the ladies' side, there was a lovely outdoor lounge area with lots of fun magazines. The steam room did not function correctly because the door did not fit.At Thanksgiving weekend, the pool lounges and beach lounges were available. I do not mind paying for a beach lounge; pool lounges were free. Towels were unlimited. Several people have discussed paying for coffee and safes. We did not experience this. However, at the price of the rooms and the fact that the service is there, I am surprised that a charge would be made.  
<Date>Jan 10, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>unhappy with service we paid in full for a room with double beds back in oct 05 and got a room with a king and rollaway bed when we checked in dec 26 06. overbooked! resulting in a bad experience for 7 nights. no room change due to high season. checking in took 30 mins or more and the clerk had to check with managment in the back room several times. the hotel advertizes for 5 swimming pools but not all 5 are available to everyone. they are reserved to guests of particular tower. 2 sea view restaurants do not really have a sea view since they are at the same level as the sea, should be at a higher level so the view will be more apparent. swimming pools do not have enough lounge chairs and no umbrellas. if you want to stay in the shade, you'll need to rent an umbrella at the beach. cost is 51 for umbrella and 2 lounge chairs. service people are rude. they tend to be arrogant and impatient. their answers are short and their body language is offending. beach is rocky. you'll need beach shoes to walk on the beach or get into the water. for the amount we paid for the room we expect excellent service all around. reserving an airport shuttle is a complex task, seems like bell service does not talk to concierge or 'shuttle girl'

<Author>lass=
<Content>Pros and cons We spent a long Christmas weekend at the Hilton. This is the second year in a row we have spent Christmas there. Cons: (1) there is construction ongoing. Our long-ago booked room in the Ali'a tower was overlooking it. Upon arrival, I requested a different room. Initially the front desk clerk suggested that I should have known about the construction because it is noted online. I stated that I did not know, and suggested that she see how long ago our reservation was made online. End of discussion. Our room was moved to a nicer room without additional charge. (2) My 14 year old had a sports massage appointment. She disclosed her age when she made the appointment. She checked in (again age was mentioned because I had to accompany her). Only when the massage therapist was ready to take her and realized that she needed a bigger room (because I had to be present) did the spa director inform us that the minimum age was 16. Three spa staff members did not know the age requirement. (3) The 2 restaurants in which we have eaten the past 2 years, the Rainbow room and the steak restaurant miss with their food. I was reminded of how much they miss when we had an early and truly wummy lunch at the Cheesecake Factory on December 26th for half the price.Pros: lovely resort, attentive staff.  
<Date>Dec 28, 2005

11	274(ready):1	314(spa):1	505(age):1	607(realize):1	730(massage):2	817(inform):1	919(sport):1	2124(minimum):1	2651(appointment):1	3747(director):1	5128(therapist):1	

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Trip! My husband, myself and our 10 year old son just returned from seven wonderful nights (December 12-19) at the HHV and had a very positive experience. I would recommend this hotel to anyone except those who are looking for a secluded, do nothing kind of vacation. Honolulu is a big city, and there is always something to do! Our positive experience began at the airport check-in kiosk where the HHV attendant was extremely friendly and gave us an upgrade to an ocean front room on a high floor of the Rainbow tower. We are Hilton Honors Diamond members and were very happy with the upgrade. We also recieved our free continental breakfast coupons. You can take the free continental, which is breakfast pastry, juice or fruit and coffee, or for a few more dollars upgrade to the buffet or full breakfast. If you are not huge breakfast eaters, like us, the served free continental was great. We only ate at the resort a few times during the week other than breakfast. Benihana was good, but crowded, so make a reservation. Our son loved the Round Table pizza, which you can order and have delivered out by the pool. Our room in the Rainbow tower had the most magnificent view of the ocean, Waikiki Beach and Diamond Head. The room itself was nothing special, but was always clean. In addition to the mini bar, however, they do provide a nice little fridge. I would trade the Ali'i or Kalia Tower's newer rooms for this view anyday. It all depends on your preferences. We walked out of our elevators either into the pool or onto the beach. Awesome. We spent most of our time on the beach, but when we did go to the pool, we found three chairs together. The beach and the pool were both filled with people, but we never felt crowded or overwhelmed by the numbers. We made use of the fridge by stocking it with snacks and beverages we purchased outside the resort. There is a Wal-Mart two blocks behind the Ala Moana center, a short cab ride away ($7). I would recommend stopping there early in your trip for supplies. We also purchased three beach chairs and an umbrella for use on the beach. It is significantly cheaper than renting at the HHV beach which is about $50/day for chairs and umbrella. At the end of our vacation, we left the chairs with other vacationers. There are also ABC stores on just about every corner. They are comperable to a convenience store at a tourist destination. Toiletries, sundries, snacks, etc., but at a bit of a premium. We did not notice any of the locals shopping in there. The HHV is a very large resort hotel with numerous restaurants, shops and varied ameneties. There are actually more shops and restaurants than some small town malls. As with any resort, the prices will be higher than those elsewhere, but just do a little research before your trip and you can enjoy window shopping at the resort and purchasing somewhere else. The Ala Moana shopping center, a short Bus ride, $6 taxi ride, or 15 minute walk away, is like a mall anywhere else, except you can pick up all the great souvenier items that you want to bring home. I would recommend Hilo Hattie's, kind of a one-stop Hawaiian kitsch store. There are also some great restaurants in the Ala Moana center, Asaggio's Italian being our favorite. You can get a mall guide online to check out your restaurant options.I would also recommend a visit to the Ward Center where there are great shops and restaurants. It is just West of the Ala Moana center, and you'll want to cab (about $8) or Bus there. The Waialaia Coffee house does have cheap, satisfying food, and its a short walk across the street. There is also a great diner at the corner of Kalakua and Ala Moana St. called Eggs n Things. Only about two blocks from the hotel.As for the hotel activities, take in the King's Jubilee on Friday for the show and fireworks. Use the Kid's club. They are great with the kiddos and keep them really busy. There are penguin feedings at 8am  3pm every day. It is fun  fascinating to watch and listen. The HHV grounds really are a destination onto themselves. We used the Mandara spa and Kalia pool twice and had wonderful spa treatments.We did some research before our trip and decided to rent a car for two of our eight days. It was perfect. There is a Dollar rental car on Kalakua about two blocks behind the hotel. We drove the island, visited the North Shore, snorkled at Hanaluma Bay, visited Pearl Harbor and ate at Roy's on the way to Hanaluma. Pricy, but among the best meals I've ever eaten. The Diamond Head climb is really exhilarating and the view from the top is certainly worth the work. One of our main concerns regarding this trip were the reviews we had read about the service at HHV. We found the service to be comperable to that of the rest of Oahu. Slow, sometimes incomplete, but overall pretty friendly. We travel quite extensively, and will definitely return to the HHV. As with any vacation, there were things that we were not happy with, but we always view our trips as a whole, and overall, the HHV was a destination worth visiting again and again.  
<Date>Dec 27, 2005
<Rating>4	4	3	-1	5	-1	4	-1	
<Aspects>

<Author>mlizBoston
<Content>Great family spot Our family of six (mom, dad plus kids aged 14, 13, 10 and 9) stayed in the Rainbow Tower on the 27th floor for 3 nights in November. We had two connecting rooms with a total of 3 balconies overlooking the city, Diamond Head and Waikiki Beach. What a spot!We chose this hotel because we had accumulated so many Hilton Honors points but weren't quite sure what we'd end up with considering it was such a large facility. We were delighted with the spaciousness of the rooms (1 king connecting to 2 doubles). The bathrooms were small, adequate, but in need of updating. The Rainbow Tower was just right for us.We spent much of our three days there touring the island of Oahu (before we went to Maui for some RR)so the time spent at the resort itself was minimal. The breakfast buffet was good but we found that it got quite crowded if you arrived after 8am. The big pool looked like fun but it closed earlier than we would have liked for the nightly shows that are performed there. There were many shops and restaurant options on-site but we chose to eat and shop elsewhere along Waikiki Beach.All in all, a very good spot for our family.  
<Date>Dec 26, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>AWESOME HOTEL!!! WE HAD THE BEST HONEYMOON!!! The first thing that made our trip special was the fact that we were in our honeymoon, but as you know... honeymoons can go wrong too, but fortunately that wasn't our case. My wife and I stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village for five nights, and this was just the beginning of a wonderful time together. First of all, the hotel is in a great location, and the views are very nice. As soon as we got to the resort, we noticed the great customer service from the staff. We stayed at the Ali'i Tower, the more private and supposedly nice building, usually recommended to honeymooners. We loved the room we had with an awesome ocean view. It was clean and spacious. The resort itself was very big, with lots of restaurants and shops, a little bit expensive though, but you don't have to buy anything to enjoy the beauty of the place. Denny's is near there, as well as some other places to eat. If you want to spend some money in a very romantic dinner inside the resort, go to Bali by the Sea, expensive, but very nice!!!!! I also recommend Sergio's, the Italian restaurant.I definitely have no complaints about the Hilton Hawaiian Village. We could have been lucky, I don't know... but the fact is that I had a great time in this place. If you're going on your honeymoon, I truly recommend the Ali'i Tower, the only building with its own pool and jacuzzi! After O'ahu, we went to Maui... a beautiful PARADISE!!!!  
<Date>Dec 20, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Need to refocus... I just got back from 5 days at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. I was there 4 years ago and had a good time but this time things have definately gone down hills.The room was nicely decorated but unchanged from 4 years ago. The wooden doors under the sink were misfitting. There were cockroaches in the bathroom... killed a handful everyday.The service was spotty. Several good experiences but they really need to hire better valet parking guys. Inattentive... I didn't even get any help putting my bags into the car upon check out. I had the feeling that it was their first day on their first job ever.We ate several meals there. At all costs avoid the buffet restaurant and the Italian place. Both with extremely poor food and service. The buffet restaurant had meals that were overcooked and fresh out of the heater.. probably was served earlier that day. Every single one of the serving plates had broken latches. Come on guys, at $35 per person you can afford new serving plates. The award winning Italian restaurant had noisy groups, inattentive service and Spagatti factory quality pasta/ lamb. Would have done better eating at Denny's. I was very tempted to stiff the waiters with no tip.The Tropics sandwich shop was as good as ever with quick service and quality sandwiches. The New York style deli was also very good. The Japanese restaurants in the resorts were only fair... I expected much better from a community with a significant Japanese population. Most of the Japanese tourist we saw ate noodles from the ABC mart instead of dining at any of the restaurants... They definately got a better deal if not a better meal.We stayed here because of our excellent stay last time and because of the beach and pool which are still excellent. But because of the worsening quality of the service and food. I would not recommend the Hilton to anyone at this time. The other advantage of the Hilton with its large resort choices to include restaurants were negated with the lower quality standard and over inflated prices.  
<Date>Dec 19, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Excellent stay We just got back home yesterday from a fantastic stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. The resort is wonderful. I've read so many different reviews, that before I left I was a little worried. We stayed in the Ali'i tower so I don't know if the tower makes a difference. Our tower was very clean, nice, updated (flat screen TV). Housekeeping was great. Came three times a day. Once to clean, make beds ecetra, afternoon to fill your ice bucket, and early evening to put out chocolates, a flower and to see if you need anything. The doorman (one in particular) was so nice. Always saying Welcome Home. What a nice touch. The resort itself is very nice, clean, lots of restaurants and shops. Be careful with the shopping. Your best bet is to hit the Aloha Stadium on Wed., Sat., or Sun. for the Swap Meet. Best Prices we found! Benihana was terrific. Great service and food was wonderful. We also ate at the Rainbow Lania on a Sat. nite for the Buffet. One of the best buffets I've every had. And, I usually don't do buffets. They had prime rib, crab legs plus lots more. So at $31 a person (yes pricey, But..) great food, and the kids ate free. On the other hand, we had reservations to eat at the Village Steak and Seafood. We went there (a Wed.) and they were closed! Why the girl took my reservation I have no idea! I was a little more then miffed about this as we were celebrating my daughters b-day. But, the concierge got us reservations at Benihana in 10 mins! (We had already been there...but that was OK like I said good food). They have a small program each nite around the super pool. Nice. Nothing Special, but nice. However Fri. nite they do a Kings Jubilee, more entertainment (very good) a parade kids can be in (and they receive a 5x7 free picture). It costs $12 per person to get a seat, and that includes 1 drink. I figured the free pic helped offset the high price. So if you have kids not to bad. Plus, they had fireworks which were great. We sat next to people who had been there before and they said the fireworks were they best they have seen there. Wondering if Christmas approaching had anything to do with it. The pool is nice and big, but like everyone says....very hard to get a chair. If we couldn't find one, to leave our stuff on we just went to the beach and tried later. We went to the beach and pool both each day. Eventually you can spot a chair. But, with as many towers and only 100 or so chairs this will always be a complaint I'm sure. As far as the staff. They are friendly. They aren't out of the way friendly, but OK. At the swap meet they could be rude, actually mostly rude if you didn't buy from them, or in my case my daughter would touch something and they really Got their panties in a wad, what my kids would say to me! O.K. RENT A CAR! You have to get out of Waikiki and see Hawaii! Even the locals will tell you this. Go to the North Shore, and around the island. Get out and see the place! Not just the resort. You can stay in a hotel anywhere, so go and see the beauty of this wonderful island. I know I'm all over the place with this, I'm just trying to give the best tips I can while it's fresh. Across from the Hilton is the Wilana Coffee Shop. Decent food and very cheap. Kids eat for $1.95 a meal. Overall we didn't think the food in Hawaii in general was fantastic, but being from the Midwest in the land of beef it's hard to match. We also found food to be alot cheaper away from Waikiki. Also ask where the Wal-mart is. We went there and bought milk and ceral and saved a ton of $ on eating breakfast in our room. I bought a book on Ohau before leaving on tips and it provided alot of information, highly recommend doing this. Oh and always ask for the upgrade. Our room was supposed to be partial ocean view. I asked for an ocean view if possible. And they made if possible! It was an awesome view! Yes we would return to the Hilton! No matter where you stay they will be some sort of complaint. Be it big or small. So, looking at the big picture this was a fabulous place to stay and worth every penny.  
<Date>Dec 17, 2005

<Author>trvlone
<Content>Loved the HHV My husband, 2 children (7  3), and I stayed here in May, 2005 for 2 weeks in the Alli Tower. We loved the resort and the island as well. The resort was large and imposing but we liked that because there were a lot of shops and amenities and you could blend in and not really be bothered. Rooms: It is true what they say, if you can afford the Alli Tower stay there. We did and it was well worth the extra money. The rooms had a large (about 32) flat panel LCD Tv in every room, there was even a mini TV in the bathroom. The beds were heavenly, with thick duvets and large comfy down pillows. There was a separate dressing/makeup area that is outside the bathroom area with a large vanity, sink and mirror, so two people could be getting ready at the same time. The only down side to the rooms were they were looking a little worn. In one corner the wallpaper was peeling, there were scuff marks by the door nothing major but over all a little lack lustre. They are in the process of renovating all rooms in the Alli Tower right now (according to thier website) and they are scheduled to be finished by Feb 2006. Another thing that bothered me about the rooms was the housekeeping. They did a fine job cleaning the room but we had 4 people in the room. When we asked to have our towels changed most times they only gave us 3 bath towels so someone would have to use a just used wet towel. After 2 kids spending a day at the beach yuck! Also, they put chocolates on the pillows during turndown service. I always look forward to retiring to the room at night and having that little treat, but when you have 2 children and they only give you 2 chocolates the kids get the chocolates and the parents get nothing. I would ask for 4 chocolates and 4 bath towels, sometimes they would leave them for us, most times not. It became a real pain calling housekeeping for an extra bath towel. It's the little things that make service outstanding.Alli Tower in General: Overall the Alli tower was great. The front desk service was quite good. A couple times when we reviewed our account on the TV we found a couple of discrepancies in our account, but they were taken care of immediately. The concierge was quite knowledgable and helped us many times. We loved the hors d'oeuvres upstairs by the pool, they had quite a good selection. We weren't expecting much when we went on our first night and were very pleasantly surprised. They had a good selection of fruit and veggies with dip, and hot foods such as chicken skewers as well. It was something that we looked forward too, every evening we would buy a drink (lava flows are really good and all drinks are topped with orchids)and have hors d'oeuvres while we watched the hula show down by the pool or just stared out over the ocean. The pool at the Alli tower is just for the guests in that tower. It is open later(till 8pm)than the super pool so it is nice for an evening swim and there is a hot tub in one corner that overlooks the ocean. One night the 4 of us sat up in the hot tub, no one else was there and we watched fire eaters putting on a show down on the beach. It was pure heaven.The resort: The resort is a very beautiful place. The gardens and the fish ponds are incredible. The penguins and flamingos kept the kids interested. The super pool is quite cold and you have to be there very early to get a chair. I also did not like the idea that we had to pay through the nose for beach chairs and umbrellas. I think it was $20/umbrella and $20/chair, or something like that per day. It shouldn't cost $100 to get beach chairs at the resort. The food on the resort was good, we especially liked the breakfast buffet at the Rainbow Lanai. Get there early though or you will have to wait for a table, everyone else likes the breakfast there too. Another good place to eat is Round Table Pizza, the pizza was excellent and quite cheap. $25.00 got you a large pizza smothered in toppings, try the Hawaiian, no one does it better. When we arrived in our cab from the airport we were removing our luggage and got yelled at for the cab being in the way even though I didn't feel that he was. I also wanted to know why we were getting asked, no, yelled at to move our cab, perhaps some guests might need to be checking in at the resort? The resort can be a spendy place but if you carefully prepare and don't get too lured in by the shops you can keep your costs down. Another thing, they do cater to the Japanese tourists there. They have these special open air trams that we tried to get on once but were told they were private. Didn't understand that since it was stopping at the bus stop and it was full of Japanese tourists. Most things were within walking distance anyway. Downtown is within walking distance, it is about a 10 minute walk, try going along the beach boardwalk it is a nice walk. Also Ala Moana Mall is a close walk, about 10 min in the opposite direction. If you want do a lot of shopping that is the place to go.Overall: The whole island is incredibly beautiful, and the resort matched it. It was like they tried to make the resort rival the beauty of the island. We rented a car for 8 days and explored every coast and every nook and cranny of the island. Things that we really liked were Pearl Harbour, the Polynesian Cultural Center, Sea Life park, and if you get a chance drive to the North Shore. There isn't alot to do on the North Shore but it captures the essence of Hawaii. You can sit on beautiful beaches and watch the surfers, it is what I envisioned old Oahu to be like. Also go to Matsumotos on the North Shore for Shave Ice, its a nice treat. Also try Dukes at the Outrigger Reef hotel, it's a Waikiki icon. All in all loved the resort, loved the island, want to go back and will go back, hopefully very soon.  
<Date>Dec 14, 2005

<Author>Nangirl
<Content>No Good I'm still fuming. We had a bad stay last February, and it was so bad, I can't help writing again. I keep reading all the latest reviews and it does seem like there is a pattern. During the winter months, the height of the tourist season, it seems like service suffers at this hotel to the point where the staff are no longer courteous and downright rude. We paid so much for our trip, that we were very unhappy that we were screamed at by the valet parking when we pulled up to the curb to check in and were told to move our car! Not the warm welcome you hope to receive after traveling from the East Coast and arriving for some pampering and much needed rest. It is such a change from previous years which also makes me angry. Seems like the meal prices are so astronomical, they're trying to gouge you. Paying for umbrellas and chairs to use the beach is lousy when you pay so much for the room. These should be complimentary (???). You've paid thru the nose for them already. Am very concerned, because I don't think the alternative hotels are much better, certainly they don't look as nice. I guess I feel like the Hilton needs to take a closer look at how they are treating guests. We never even got an apology for the rude behavior or any free bottle of champagne or anything when they lost our reservations and we had to wait four hours to check in, then stay in two rooms on two different floors instead of neighboring rooms that we had reserved. It's gone so far down hill, my fear is that it will continue. Guess it's time to check out other vacation spots. Too bad, I have such fond memories of this island and previous vacation ventures here.

<Author>JeffCedarRapids
<Content>Great Place to Stay in Waikiki We had a great week long stay the HHV. The rooms were very nice, the facilities well maintained and overall everyone was very friendly. Our room was in the Tapa Tower. It was very large. We had friends staying in the Diamond Head Tower. It was decorated nicer with newer furnishings etc, but was consderably smaller. The Tapa pool was little cold being little sun hits this area. The super pool was very comfortable. It is hard getting a chair at this pool as they allow people to get them early in the morning and leave a towel there to hold the chair. The beach is right near by and is very nice.The animals on this resort are great for children as well as adults. The penguins, birds, etc. are great. The gentleman, Kevin, that takes care of the animals is a wonderful person who obviously cares about each animal on the property. He is weatlth of knowledge of the animals.We also appreciated them allowing us the use of a hospitality room the day we checked out. Our plane didn't leave until 7:20 p.m. (check out is 11 a.m.) and they gave us a room to use at no charge for an hour late in the afternoon to shower and prepare for our flight.While the resort is very large with lots of guests, it was perfect for us. We loved our week long stay here and will definitely stay here again.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Beautiful, but not the usual Hilton courtesy The firt night we stayed in the Ali'i Tower. Luxurious room with coffee, mini fridge, bar (extra$) and bottled water. This tower has a doorman, private check in/out desk, concierge, pool and hot tub which are not shared by the other guests. Nice touch for over $200 per night. The remainder of the trip (6 nights) my husband and I were in the Tapa Tower. Room located on the 33rd floor, very clean overlooking the pool, Diamond Head and the ocean. Recommend an upper floor for the view. Only one packet of coffee. We had to keep calling to get one packet per day. Mini-fridge and bar (exta$) were handy to have for the week. Tapa pool closed at 10pm. Other pools closed much earlier at 5-6pm. Cleaning staff very friendly, but that's where it stopped. Most guests were Japanese and we felt it catered to this audience. The restaurants were overpriced. Thanksgiving buffet was $48 per person. Ala carte dinner at the other 2 restaurants were the same price. Regular buffet dinner was $31 without seafood or carving station. Make reservations for the various restaurants on your first day or you may end up eating at 9-10pm like we did. More reasonably-priced places to eat outside of the hotel are in walking distance. Hotel property was simply beautiful and the beach was the nicest in Waikiki. Plush beach towels available at the beach at no charge . We ended up renting a car for 3 days to sight see. The hotel has trolly and bus stops which are convenient, but we didn't want to wait and shuffle. Hertz is located in the Tapa Tower, very convenient and worth the extra parking cost of $15 per night. Business center is located in the Diamond Head tower and was also very convenient to quickly check email, print boarding passes and weigh your luggage. Hotel provided coupon book for various hotel vendors which was helpful. Saving a few dollars here and there didn't quite make up for the 30 minute bar wait by the pool, but it was thoughtful. The hotel has many designer shops which are extremely expensive. If you're looking for souveniors (tikis, jewelry, shirts, mugs, etc.) go to the International Market. You can haggle there also. Hotel also offers several free services such as hula and snorkeling lessons, but you have to sign up in advance; space is limited. Friday night King show at the super pool was very nice. Get there by 5pm. $12 for pool seating includes a drink and fireworks is worth it. We utilized the Concierge to book our first few activities. It was convenient, but not informative. Concierge booked the best and most expensive without discussion. We then used the American Express Travel desk located in the main lobby and were much more pleased with the communication. Attend the hotel orientation. You get great tips on places to visit and a free breakfast. Be aware the hotel offers timeshare properties. You may be solicited. We said no and were not bothered again. The hotel has everything, but it's too large and the restaurants are not great. You don't receive any personal attention. I would stay there again because I know what to expect (I read many reviews). If I didn't, I would have been very disappointed, not the usual Hilton courtesy.  
<Date>Dec 2, 2005

<Author>Marie_TM
<Content>Uneven Service, Too Crowded My husband and I just spent two nights at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. Overall, the service was mixed, and it was too crowded. I am a Diamond HHonors member, but did not feel that welcome there. (Perhaps Hilton hotels have spoiled me--usually I find their service to be exceptional--this was a disappointment.) We stayed in the Kalia Tower, but were not assigned to an ocean view room. The mountain view was still pretty. We had access to the executive lounge, but it was not worth it. They served complimentary snacks from 5-7 pm, but you had to pay for drinks there, and they were more expensive than the mini-bar in the hotel room! The lounge was also extremely crowded--it was hard to find a seat. Moreover, we received a call from the front desk that we needed to pick up our breakfast coupons that they forgot to give us when we checked in. They didn't offer to have someone bring them to our room; they didn't even offer to walk them over to the Kalia Tower to leave with the conceirge there. When we got to the front desk (a considerable walk from Kalia Tower), they said we didn't need the coupons. We had to insist that they had called us to pick them up; they finally found them for us after about 10 minutes. While this property is located on the beach, if you stay in Kalia Tower, it is quite a walk to the beach because the hotel grounds are sprawling. There is a Doubletree hotel literally within a five-minute walk from the Kalia Tower, so HHonors members staying at the Doubletree don't have much further to walk to the beach than those in Kalia Tower. I would like to note, however, that some of the staff were friendly (such as when we checked out, and at the restaurant Bali by the Sea). The food at Bali was great too.  
<Date>Dec 2, 2005

<Author>aug30
<Content>Had a wonderful 8 day stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village Thoroughly enjoyed the 8 day stay here from November 8 through the 15th. Room extremely clean and comfortable..Have not had a more comfortable bed anywhere. We stayed in Rainbow Tower which is the closest to beach and we had an ocean view that was beautiful. Even tho at check in the clerk told us it was a partial ocean view it truly was more than that!! My friend had a Senior Hilton Honors card and we got this wonderful room for $203.00 per night. Food is expensive at the hotel in most restaurants but we ate at other local restaurants so we did not have to spend a lot of money for food while in Honolulu. However, on the Hilton property there are many shops and small places to eat one of which is the pizza place and they have great salads, pizza, sandwiches and drinks. This fare was very tasty  reasonable and the place stayed very busy each time we were in there. Location of HHV is very good; shuttle and taxi service is convenient, staff usually nice, helpful, attentive. I would definitely stay here again!!!! P.S., Enjoyed looking at all of the shops on property and the manicured grounds are full of beautiful flowers and wonderful birds, penguins, ducks and the like. Place is almost a city unto itself!!

<Author>RobnJack
<Content>Excellent Stay Spent only 1 night in the Kahlia tower on the executive floor. I found the staff to be top notch, very friendly and professional. The room in the Kahlia tower was newly built and very luxurious, with a small patio and a great view out to sea. The resort is very large with many shops and a great selection of restaurants. We chose to leave the property and go next door for dinner to Kobe Steakhouse, well worth the walk. Over all this is a great resort for either a stop over before your Hawaiian vacation or even a week long visit. Expect resort prices for food and drink, but good quality.

<Author>merr11
<Content>HHV was just terrific We stayed for 6 days and were very nervous about crowds and expense because of reviews here. We thought that for being fully booked, with 3,000 rooms, they did an incredible job of making you feel there was no one there. We kept asking where all the people were. Yes, the pool chairs book quickly, but we never had a problem getting a couple. The hotel is within walking or free trolley ride to the rest of Waikiki, the staff was friendly to us, our room was upgraded upon arrival. Recognize that you are going to Hawaii and will need to leave your budget at home. But here are some hints if you are dollar conscious - bring your own coffee and filters, don't rent beach chairs if you have a problem with the price - sit on a towel on the prettiest (and most uncrowded)part of Waikiki beach, buy your own alcohol at ABC and have drinks on your lanai while enjoying HHV's free sunset music. We'd go back to HHV in a heartbeat.  
<Date>Nov 16, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Best Vacation Ever This was our first visit to any of the Hawaiian Islands and it was a wonderful experience. The HHV was beautiful and relaxing. Everything was very clean and well maintained. The restaurants are very expensive, however, you can eat off of the resort at a more reasonable price. There are restaurants within walking distance. We had a rental car and did a lot of sightseeing. I recommend getting the rental car, that way you can stop and see what you want. We saw some tour buses just slowing down as they drove past some areas of interest. The ABC Stores are great for souveniers and snacks. They have anything that you will need. We definetly would like to return to HHV.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>1st Time in Hawaii Just got back from 5 nights on Oahu staying at the Hilton Village. We were scheduled to go to Cancun but, well...Wilma took care of that. We had to book an alternate vacation quickly and used I used this site to get a lot of useful info ASAP so I wanted to give something back.We traveled with another couple and we were both upgraded upon check-in which, by the way, we conveniently did at the airport kiosk. We had each booked ocean view rooms in the Kalia tower - they got upgraded to a gorgeous corner (read two balcony) room in the Rainbow tower, while we were given an ocean view Suite in the Diamond Tower. While we commented to management that we should have been kept in the same tower it didn't detract from the visit.Yes food is expensive at the village but it's expensive in Hawaii. Many have mentioned the coffee shop across the street. It was great! I'd even get take out breakfast and eat back in the room on the balcony. I'd recommend the muesli and the eggs bendict. Another great alternative is the military resort next door - you can only access it from the beach if you're not staying there. But a cheeseburger for lunch was only $2.50 vs the Hilton's $7.50 version. But in the Villge, the veal parmigian at Sergio's was the best I've had in years (not an easy compliment from an Italian NY girl) and the Beggar's Chicken at the Chinese restaurant on property was amazing.The beach here was nice - larger than many others down toward Waikiki and swimmable (ie. no coral reefs to cut your feet on). The last day we even rented the chair umbrella combo at the next beach because it was cheaper by $20. Same with surf lessons - they were 1/2 the price at Hans' surf school a few hotels down than at the Hilton. So why stay here??? It is convenient. It wasn't so crowded during Monday-Friday. Pretty grounds. They were kind to give us a hospitality suite to use for FREE before our late evening departure - 20 minutes per person - enough to shower after a long day on the beach. And the beds - it was like sleeping on a cloud. I'm going out to buy a good quality bed topper because it was nirvana to sleep here.Don't go to Honolulu if you don't like crowds or a metropolitan experience!E-mail if you have any questions. Aloha!  
<Date>Nov 14, 2005

You even get a free book in your room by Mr Hilton himself, mind you it tells the story of his rise to fortune! But hay beets a bible. Well done Mr Hilton and thanks for making my wifes dreams come true X

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Hotel with terrible management! I was at the hilton in Waikiki for 10 days. The staff is friendly, but from what I could tell, they seemed to be scrutinized at every turn. I noted 3 instances where they were belittled in front of guests by supervisors or managers. Very unprofessional. Management there should be canned. The whole ordeal makes for a pins  needles type atmosphere. I'd recommend going down the street to the Sheraton, Hyatt, Hawaii Prince, or the beautiful Sheraton Moana Surfrider hotels. They're all in Waikiki and about the same cost. The hilton also needs more signs. There are no signs pointing to the different towers or facilities. And one of my biggest complaints was there is ONLY ONE atm machine on the 25 or so acres there. And it's located at THE FAR END near the street! Wanna eat and need a atm? It's a 15 minute walk there and back! My advice, stay elsewhere...

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Liked it better the first time This was our second visit to the HHV, and both times we stayed in the Ali'i tower. Our first visit in '01 was fantastic, but this trip just wasn't as enjoyable. Maybe it's because we had just spent 4 nights on Maui which is considerably less crowded and more laid back. I've heard Honolulu refered to as a concrete jungle and after having visited Maui I would agree. The Ali'l tower is nice, but I question as to whether it is worth the money. Especially since during our visit, the 2nd floor of the hotel is under construction. So in order to reach the private pool  terrace on the 2nd floor, you were forced to detour to the 3rd floor and walk down a flight of concrete stairs in a humid, smelly stench. It was hardly the upscale atmosphere one expects from the Ali'i tower. Our partial ocean view was laughable. We overlooked the super pool, penguins, flamingos  koi ponds. And if you stretched your neck far enough you could see a sliver of the Pacific Ocean obstructed by many palm trees. Our 2 year old loved looking down at the animals and really the view was nice. However, it was not an ocean view or even a parital ocean view in my opinion and definitely not worth the extra $$. Speaking of money, expect to pay big time for any food on the property. The Ali'i tower offered complimentary Hors d'Oeuvres each evening, and on occasion that would suffice for dinner. They offer a continental breakfast at a nominal charge of $14. Hardly what I would consider nominal. Fourteen bucks for fruit, pastries, muffins, donuts  juice is steep in my book. We tried the breakfast buffet at both the Tapa Cafe  the Rainbow Lanai. Both were marginal. Very undercooked scrambled eggs at both buffets  both catered to the numerous Japanese tourists who prefer breakfast selections (like raw eggs in the shell  raw fish) that I would never eat. If you're thinking bountiful buffets like you'd find in Las Vegas, you'll be disappointed. At $20 per person, it was not worth it at all. It's one thing to pay good money for good food, but it is completely another to pay good money for lousy food. One restaurant I would recommend without a doubt is the Golden Dragon. This is Chinese cuisine at it's best. Plus the restaurant overlooks the ocean and is stunning at sunset. Very romantic and the food is outstanding. And although pricey at $100 for dinner for two, at least I felt it was money well spent. The grounds of the hotel are immense. They are well-kept  truly beautiful with the many ponds, waterfalls, flowers and wildlife. Bottom line is this: HHV is a nice place to stay. However, either bite the bullet and go for a full ocean view or stick with a garden view. Eat some of your meals off property. Or do what I will do in the future and go to Maui! =)  
<Date>Nov 9, 2005

<Author>vacation101Indiana
<Content>Expensive Hotel, Beautiful, Caters mainly to Japanese, small pool The hotel is absolutely beautiful! Clean and friendly yet you pay for it! A sandwich is 10 bucks. Small pools (2) for the amount of people who stay here! The beach is also extrememly small in front of this hotel. Nice but expensive shops in the hotel. Caters mainly to Japanese tourists. If you want to spend all your money on a hotel and get a clean, nice hotel this is the place, BUT this is not a very good deal. Restaurants are a rip off. Stay somewhere else unless you have all the money in the world and dont mind paying top dollar for a plain old burger or sandwich!:)

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great hotel, but overpriced We stayed in the Ali'i tower - definately a good move. Free coffee  water, excellent maid service and good views of the beach. Enormous hotel, so very busy and impersonal. A long walk to the centre of Waikiki though, but a 10 min walk to the Ala Moana shopping centre.Food and drink in the hotel are totally overpriced - a complete rip-off, and service in the restaurants and bars was terrible. Waiting 30 mins for a cold deli sandwich that cost $11! Continetal breakfast $14!Recommend the Wailana Coffee House over the road from the hotel to eat breakfast instead - loads of food and speedy service for 5$. Also for cheap beer and pupu go the the Tiki Bar at the top floor of the Ala Moana shopping centre. Live music, cheap pitchers and happy hour every afternoon

<Author>Winee42
<Content>Wonderful Tropical Resort We recently returned from 8 nights at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. We thought this was a wonderful resort and after reading some of the reviews, I wonder if we were staying at the same place. The Hilton has a beautiful beach  lovely tropical grounds with fountains, waterfalls, penquins, flamingos,  tiki torches (the penquins were a special treat). It is a very large busy resort,but because of its size it never felt crowded. We enjoyed walking around the resort and didn't think there were alot of children, but perhaps it was the time of year (October). There were a few minor inconveniences, but what vacation doesn't have those. Staff was friendly, doorman  conciege at our tower were helpful. Had a partial oceanview room at the Ali'i Tower  room was very spacious. A comfortable king bed, large bathroom, nice lanai, refrigerator, free coffee  bottled water. Maid service 3 times a day with turn down service  chocolates. There is also a private pool, gym,  free appetizers in the evening. Only dissappointment was we asked for a upgrade  were told that the tower was full.(She didn't check so I'm not sure if that was the case, but we didn't push the issue) We were on the 11th floor and had a lovely view of the super pool and grounds, but only oceanview from one end of the lanai (I guess thats why its called partial). Also, they told us the contintenal breakfast was offered in our tower for a nominal charge which turned out to be $14.00! There is a large variety of shops, from ABC store to designer stores. Prices were good at the General Store  the Sundry Shop  had just about anything we needed. Pools were very nice, like other reviews have mentioned, Super Pool gets very crowded. Either get there before 9 to reserve your chair or wait until the afternoon, when we didn't have a problem. (It was good to see that the pool employees remove towels if it seems like hours since anyone had sat there) Also, we found the Tapa Pool quieter. We ate at the hotel a couple of times: skip the dinner buffet at the Rainbow (buffet at Oceananium was much better for the same price) but the steaks were wonderful at the Village  worth the money; breakfast was okay at the Deli or Tropics, but better at the Outrigger Reef where you get a full buffet for $10 or across the street at the Coffee Shop for $5-$10. Beach was lovely  water was beautiful, we only rented the lounges one day, but another day I rented a beach chair for $10.00 which I thought was a good deal. Here are a few other tips: Pick up the Hilton Coupon Book-I saved $$ at their shops  restaurants,(also all the other Waikiki coupon books available can save you money); 10 min. walk along the beach brings you down to other hotels in Waikiki; insist on a bellboy for your luggage, we carried our own luggage as did most other guests we observed; check out the evening poolside entertainment  fireworks; self-parking was convenient  cheaper than valet. After visiting crowded downtown Wakiki I'm glad we stayed at the Hilton. We liked the fact that the Hilton is a little out of way. Maybe you're not in the middle of the action, but it was definately quieter  nicer at the Hilton-exactly what we were looking for. We rented a car  didn't find a problem parking anywhere but if you don't,there are buses, trolleys or taxis to take you everywhere. Unfortunately our vacation had to end but hopefully we will be able to return to the Hilton again in the future. This was definately a resort and a vacation at the top of our list!! (P.S.: We loved Oahu)  
<Date>Nov 5, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Bad Idea, Waste Of Money And Boring! We spent one week at the Hilton Hawaiian Village in Waikiki and aside from the fact that we got upgraded to an ocean view (which was beautiful), the resort was pretty much a rip off. We had spent the weekend at the W hotel before coming to the Hilton (comparable room rates)- we should have stayed at the W! There is no music or stereo in the room number one. When my friend had a sore throat, they charged us 5$ for salt to be delivered to our room (for her to gargle with). When I got sea urchin stuck in my foot from surfing, they charged us another 5$ for vinegar. At the W, everything was complimentary, including breakfast, and the front desk staff carried our floaties, chairs, and towels (compliments of the hotel) out to the beach for us. The food in the Village is terrible, very unathentic, and very expensive. The best place was the sushi restaurant but still SUPER pricey. The best deal is to get out of the resort and get some sushi for half the price elsewhere. The noodle shop consisted of oily, tasteless noodles, Top Ramen would have been better. The pool is WAY overcrowded (and we were there during the off-season), and VERY boring, mostly kids and families running around- which we weren't expecting, thinking kids would be in school by mid september. There was a point where the pool had to be evacuated because a kid pooped or threw up in it or both. The beach is slightly better but not by much: the snorkeling is TERRIBLE compared to the rest of the island- very sandy and cloudy due to the Atlantis Boat coming in and out right there. LOTS of kids running around or people talking very loudly on their cell phones. The rentals are a total rip off. Don't rent any of the flotation devices from the beach guy (even though he's a SUPER nice hawaiian dude), just buy something from the ABC store or any other store! They charge you $50 for a chair and umbrella! This is a perfect place for a family that doesn't want to venture out or deal with real Hawaii. You might as well be at a resort in Florida or any other place with an ocean. EVEN the fireworks were cancelled the week we were there! I lost my beach bag and when I went to the front desk to talk to lost and found they just made me call a voicemail and leave a message with my description of my belongings. The staff was VERY unhelpful, even rude at one point. When I finally did find my bag (by a fluke, a guy who worked at the pool overheard our conversation) my snorkel, mask, book, and sarong were all missing. This is NOT recommended for people who do not want to waste money or who have traveled all the way to Hawaii to really experience Hawaii. I can't even imagine being there for a honeymoon, it is NOT a romantic place at all. It is one huge unpersonal resort full of tourists and money traps. This is a place for SUCKERS! That's how I felt every hour I was there. Fortunately my friend and I met some locals and spent half the week up at the North Shore, the BEST part of the vacation for sure!  
<Date>Nov 1, 2005

<Author>YazBeanSaysMeow
<Content>Crowded, Not-so-special I agree with the reviewers who found this hotel crowded and not-so-special. The property reminds me of a cross between a Bronx, NY high-rise and Disney Village. Lots of little tourist-trap shops, not a lot of scenery. The beach is rocky sand next to a parking lot. Overall, it's a very average hotel in a run-down section of town. Stayed in the Tapa Tower, which is probably the lowest-ticket building onsite. Room was clean but nothing special. Missing hand lotion, paper next to the telephones and any sort of TV Guide. My room overlooked the city and a torn-down apartment building. Concierges were hit-or-miss. One recommended a GREAT sushi place; another recommended a place to get my watch fixed that doesn't actually fix watches. On the plus side: The bed and pillows were some of the best I've ever slept on. Room service was decent and very friendly. Security was very responsive to the noisy teenagers next door. The best time to experience the resort is at 5AM, when it is empty and quiet.This would probably be a great place for families and kids -- and there were many of them here. Not so great for business travellers, although it's only a 10-minute walk to the Convention Center.  
<Date>Nov 1, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Don鈥檛 listen to the whiners! The Hilton is a great place to stay; we just got back from a one week stay at the Hilton. After reading some of the reviews I was a bit worried about my trip as I had already booked it. However it was a fabulous place and everything was perfect. My wife and I travel every year for a vacation and the past few years has been Mexico and Cuba and we always stay in a 5 Star and the Hilton was one of the nicest places so far. I don鈥檛 know what people are complaining about, yes it is busy and maybe a bit crowded however you ARE on Waikiki Beach in Honolulu. It is a known fact that Waikiki is a very busy place and Honolulu is a City! If you want quiet place maybe choose another island. We stayed in the Kalia Tower which I found to be very nice it is the newest tower in the village and even the furniture seemed nicer than in the rooms of the Ali which is strange since the Ali tower is supposed to be the nicer. The Kalia Tower has its own Pool and Hot tub for the towers guests which was nice as it was never crowded. The beach is nice as you are at one end of Waikiki so there is plenty of space not like further down the strip.One warning! Stay away from Maui Divers! It is a jewelry store that has many smaller stores and kiosks all over the island. They have a scam going, what they do is advertise opening up an oyster and seeing if there is a pearl inside, it is $14 and you don鈥檛 pay if there is no pearl. Well every oyster has a pearl most are black. Anyway we fell for it, and we got a black one, the lady will ahh and ohh at you telling you how big and beautiful it is. Then she takes it and drills a hole in it without asking you and then tries to sell you a ring or pendant to put it in. They Are $150 to $350 for this. Of course you think you have scored big with the black pearl so you end up doing it like we did. After that I noticed everyone was getting black pearls and one lady had 2 in one oyster鈥?she was sold a pair of earrings! Anyway beware! It鈥檚 not a $14 pearl it is at least a $150 pearl.  
<Date>Nov 1, 2005

<Author>puppymama1
<Content>Grounds are beautiful, hotel is crowded We stayed here for 4 nights in October, 2005 while on a combined pleasure/business trip. Since our time here was during the business portion of our trip, we did not use the pool or beach at all. While the Super Pool may be the biggest in Waikiki, it was fairly unimpressive. The grounds of the hotel are gorgeous, many tropical plants, flamingoes, a black swan, turtles, penguins, parrots and macaws. All the employees were extremely nice, courteous, friendly and helpful. We stayed in the Ali'i tower since we had read on tripadvisor that is was more upscale. The room was average size, kept clean, but nothing extra special. The carpet was stained in several places, the wallpaper was peeling at the seams in several places. We never got a chance to sample the free appetizers in the afternoon. We did appreciate the free coffee and water every day. We only ate in the hotel once -- hamburgers at the Tropics Cafe, which were very good. As others have recommended, eat breakfast across the street at the Wailana Coffee House -- it is VERY good and cheap -- 2 eggs, 2 strips of bacon and all the delicious pancakes you can eat for $4.95. The dinner at the Kobe Steak House which is not in the Hilton complex, but just outside of it, was also delicious. We enjoyed walking through all the shops -- expensive, but so is everything in Hawaii! We were there in the off-season and it was still fairly crowded -- can't imagine what it would be like during peak season! Waikiki (and Honolulu in general) are extremely crowded and congested. Like any other big city with more palm trees! The Hilton is on the outskirts of Waikiki, which was a BIG plus -- you didn't have to deal with all the crowds unless you wanted to. I would not hesitate to recommend this hotel, but don't expect 5 star rooms since they are in the process of a much needed renovation.  
<Date>Oct 30, 2005

<Author>Marvelmann
<Content>Five nights was not enough! We arrived here after a fantastic 10 day trip staying with relatives in Northern California, feeling as we were so close to Hawaii, we should pop over for a few days.We loved this hotel, we loved Oahu and we loved the people. It always amazes me when I read reviews about hotels we been to (and we travelled to Africa, USA, Asia and around Europe) that other people's experience seem so different to ours. We arrived mid-afternoon, mid August, mid rush and had to wait a few minutes to check in. We are patient people, and were told, by a really nice guy on the desk that because our rooms were not next to each other as originally booked (but on the same floor in the Tapa Tower - at least 30 seconds walk away!) that we would be credited $200 for the inconvenience and for waiting so patiently.The hotel was packed, but we were always able to get a table in the restaurants we wanted, were delighted by the courteous staff, and loved walking on the beach at 6.30 in the morning before things got too busy.So things weren't cheap. When you've travelled halfway around the world to a paradise island, you shouldn't expect to pay the same prices as round the corner. I always expect to pay more on holiday than I would do at home - that's part of the deal!Please don't be put off by other people's reviews. In my experience, if you are polite and courteous, you find other people to be too. We loved it.

<Author>belfast-jj
<Content>1st class resort We stayed a week at the Hilton and here is our review. First the size of the place is amazing - its very clean and well kept resort. They must have hundreds of staff working very hard to maintain it and it shows. Location in our eyes is the best on Waikiki beach - the beach is also kept very clean. Amenities on site are amazing with such a huge choice for dining or shopping.Food at all the restaurants was very good - apart from the Rainbow buffet which was average. Bali by the sea was 1st class along with the Village steak and seafood restaurant. We ordered room-service on our last night and were expecting it to turn up cold -but it was piping hot - a real plus for such a big and busy resort. Rooms were very spacious ( as i said we stayed a week left for Maui - and returned the night before our homebound flight ) we stayed in the Rainbow tower garden view - but it was facing the lagoon which was nice at night with the sunset and the outdoor music on the green. On our last night we stayed in an ocean view room in Rainbow and the views looking down beach and diamond head was amazing. If anyone has any questions feel free to contact me.jj...
