<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Only Place I'd Stay on Waikiki We stayed at the Ali'i Tower from Oct 15 - 21st and just loved it. The Ali'i Tower offers extra amenities, such as maid service 3x daily, free bottled water and the use of the Oceanside Terrace (which includes exclusive use of the Ali'i Pool, Fitness Center,  complimentary appetizers at sunset.) The Ali'i pool was never crowded and had the BEST views of Waikiki. After looking at the other resorts and hotels on Waikiki I felt the HHV was truly the best one there. It's also located on the best part of Waikiki Beach and next door to Fort DeRussey Park. Fort DeRussey Park is a great place to have a picnic while enjoying the magnificent views of the ocean. Yes, HHV does nickel and dime you, but you can find good meal deals close by. Try The Shorebird (down the beach @ the Outrigger Reef). They have a great breakfast buffet for 9.95 w/ coupon (10.95 w/o coupon) compared to the HHV's mediocre buffet at the Rainbow Lanai for 20.00. Be advised: there is construction on site in between the Tapa  Diamond Head Towers. The projected completion date is Christmas '05. This does cause noise during the day (including weekends). If your plans include a stay at the Tapa or Diamond Head Tower before or around Dec. 05 I would recommend changing to one of the other towers, as the noise can be problematic. I could hear the noise from the Ali'i Tower, but thankfully I could escape to the Ali'i Oceanside Terrace.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Can't Wait to Return! Having read some of this hotel's mixed reviews on this website, my husband and I were prepared for a bit of a disappointment, but our experience couldn't have been better. We were in Tapa Tower with a partial ocean view. Having visited a guest room with a full ocean view, we truly appreciated a view of the amazing cityscape from our balcony at night. Our room was large with a lovely king sized bed, flat screen TV, sofa and a great dressing/bar area with a refrigerator and coffee pot. I am a clean freak when it comes to bathrooms, and found ours to be fresh and pristine. On our first morning, we bought two cups of coffee and two danishes at the Tapa Bar which came to $16. After that, we bought a large package of kona coffee and muffins or croissants at the ABC Store made our own breakfast in our room. Also, since Oahu's water is so pure we refilled our water bottles from the tap and stored them in our refrigerator instead of buying water. We bought liquor and mix at the ABC Store as well, and enjoyed relaxing cocktails in our room before dinner a few nights. We also discovered the Wailana Cafe and Cocktail Bar located across Ala Moana Boulevard from the resort, and ate many breakfasts and lunches there. Nothing fancy, but it's clean, the staff is very friendly, the food is good and prices are much the same as the mainland. They also offered half price cocktails from 3-5PM, which was a great place to visit with newfound friends at the end of sightseeing excursions. The bus/limo bay is located at the back of the hotel, and they post daily schedules there for the free trolleys to places like Hilo Hattie and DFS Stores. Our hotel seemed to be a tour bus hub for the other hotels nearby. Our entire trip was booked through Aloha VIP Tours, and included all our transfers to and from the airport. Both times, we were driven by a delightful man named Ernesto who was our first clue as to how friendly and warm everyone on the island would be. Aloha had a Maui Divers van pick us up for a breakfast our first morning on the island, and it was here that we were given an entertaining little show and a chance to sign up for all the tours they offer. After the breakfast, we were herded onto a bus and taken to Maui Divers factory. Once inside, we were given a quick tour of how their jewelry is made and then left to maneuver through showroom after showroom of jewelry. Some of the clerks were quite assertive, so we found our way to the street where a very nice lady summoned the Maui Divers van to return us to our hotel instead of going on the Hilo Hattie factory. We took the Circle Island Tour our second day on the island. This was a good move, as we had a wonderful driver and the rest of the week to revisit favorite spots. Because our hotel was the first stop for every tour bus we boarded, we were able to get a front seat which gave us the best view of the entire day's tour. We took the Duck Tour to Pearl Harbor, which was really intersting, but once you arrive at Pearl Harbor you're left to find your own way around. On the return trip, however, the Duck drove right off a beach and sailed us out near Sand Island. Both the trip and the island history we learned made it a great value. We also went to Germaine's Luau one evening (cheesy, but now we can say we went to a luau and tried poi) and took also took a sunset cruise. As it happened, there was a full moon the night of the cruise so we abandoned the floor show and spent our time topside watching the beautiful sunset and the amazing full moon over the city and the oceain. A word about the tours: the luau and sunset cruise tours were also by motorcoach and during these two trips our tour guides led us in song, told jokes and generally tried to create some fun energy on the way to our destination. Maybe we're not good tourists, because this was our least favorite part of the entire trip. Also, at each of these tours our picture was taken and then shown to us when back on the bus. We got fantastic pictures of our own both at the luau and on the cruise, but felt pressured to pay $20 for pictures that we didn't particularly like or want. Maybe other tour companies are different from Aloha VIP in ths regard. We also booked a bike tour and Diamonhead hike through Eco Tours, which was the best money we ever spent. The guides were friendly and we really got better feel for the island. The scenery was truly amazing, and the Diamondhead hike through the plotters caves was almost as interesting as the view from the top was breathtaking. We caught the Atlantis Sub right off HHV's own dock one afternoon, and this was a thrilling excursion for two people who don't snorkle. My husband is a bit claustrophobic, but he had a great time. One afternoon after our bike tour, we treated ourselves to massages at the Mandara Spa which was a great way to relax. We'd read that there are 900,000 people on the island of Oahu and 700,000 registered cars, and that parking can be problematic, so we decided to wait and see if we needed to rent a car. We picked up a bus guide at the bookstore in the resort, packed snacks, sunscreen and water and hopped the bus a couple of days. We found it to be quite adequate for our independent excursions and well populated with other tourists. Not all drivers announce their stops, but they are happy to l on so many occasions and we only brought one pair. While the hotel had it's own TV information channel, I really missed my laptop as it would have been so much easier to access travel updates online and get directions to restaurants, etc. All in all, this trip exceeded our expectations. The weather was great despite a few little rain mists - no humidity with a constant breeze. I was thrilled that there were no lizards, snakes or bugs to be seen either! We crammed a ton of experiences into our seven days, and we can't wait to return to Hilton Hawaiian Village!  
<Date>Oct 22, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Hilton Hawaiian Village overpriced and over-rated I felt this hotel could have been much more accomodating considering the price we paid - the only thing worth the money was the view from the tower - however, still not worth 400+/night. The food was horribly expensive but we went off the property and found a great diner for breakfast (sorry cannot remember the name of it) - I would not go back to this hotel again - and likely would not return to Waikiki - th eother islands have much more to offer!!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Indifferent Service, Crowded  Before I begin, I suggest every traveller visiting Oahu to purchase a copy of OAHU REVEALED by Wizard Publications. It was most helpful and honest!After six relaxing, laid-back wonderful nights at the Ko Olina Beach Club from Sept. 26 - Oct. 2, my husband and I ventured off into the concrete jungle of Waikiki and stayed at the epicentre of all the madness - the HHV! What a mistake we had made! It all started when we pulled into the driveway of this chaotic resort. We immediately notified one of the captains and told them we are checking into the Ali'i Tower, asked where we could park the car for 30 minutes since we were returning our vehicle after check in. He was very rude to us, pointed to the general check in desk with a huge line up and said, You can't park your car here! Thanks to Tripadvisor, I knew he was wrong and there was a separate check in counter for the Ali'i guests! He clearly WAS NOT LISTENING! My husband and I never intended nor intimated that we wanted to leave our car parked there. All I asked was where the Ali'i Tower guests can check in and where to park the car. I had to ask him several times, Where should we park the car? and he kept responding with a You can't park here!. I changed my line of questioning to, What do you suggest we do right now? He somehow miraculously understood all of a sudden and told us to park in the parkade. Bad first impression already and thought to myself, What a contrast in atmosphere and service compared to in Ko Olina! I agree strongly with the other reviews that this place is CHAOTIC and OVERCROWDED. I feel sorry for those who use the Super Pool because they need to be there at 8:30AM sharp to get a chair! For those travelling in groups, good luck getting chairs together! For those who want to stay out of the shade and not get a tan, you can go to the Superpool after 4:00PM and get a chair because it's all shaded! Oh, and did I mention that there was so much construction onsite including the 2nd floor of the Ali'i Tower! This caused a lot of problems with the elevator service. This was such an inconvenience because they blocked off the elevator to this floor, so everyone had to get to the 3rd floor via stairwell in order to get back to their suites! The so-called supreme Ali'i tower SERVICE is not poor, but INDIFFERENT! I had to initiate a smile and say hello most of the time and I felt it was very difficult and forced for the front desk clerks/doormen to reciprocate. Make sure you take advantage of the CONCIERGE service - i.e. booking dinner reservations. As for the Ali'i Pool, it was small (4 ft. deep all the way) and dirty (winds caused dead bees, flies and leaves to float), but plenty of chairs, less crowded and peaceful, overlooking the beach. There were hardly any children and most of the guests were 40+, retired couples relaxing and reading a book. They have an ice water dispenser at the Ocean Terrace for complimentary use. For those who like to workout, wear your gym gear down to the pool along with bathing suit, work out and then take a dip in the pool. It's nice because there's an open gym exclusive for Ali'i guests at no extra charge! If planning to lie at the pool all day, please note that Ocean Terrace only serves a light lunch and is closed between 10AM-11:00AM and last call is 7:00PM. Please take advantage of the complimentary hors d'oevres between 5PM - 7PM - chicken skewers, deep fried shiu mai (pork dumplings), cheese platter, vegetable platter w/dip. As for the ROOMS, they were comfortable but nothing extravagant. Our bathroom had a shower/bathtub and a separate vanity area with color TV. We also had a 32 plasma TV, fax machine, fridge, mini bar, down-quilted duvet/pillows and an in-room safe (which costs a whopping $3.50 per day!) There are 3 maid services a day, apparently, since we only got two - didn't know about the ice service until after reading about it!) However, I wasn't pleased on the 2nd last day when I didn't have small bills to tip the maid and that same evening noticed the linens were changed to dirty ones! It smelled so bad and the garlic smell was so pungent! I was told they were to use existing linens througout our stay, but for some reason, the maid decided to change it! I knew this because our original duvet cover had an atypical black stitching across the top.FOOD in the resort - not worth it! Even the Round Table Pizza joint - they charge $10 for a personal sized pizza! For breakfast, Wailana Coffee House is a good bang for your buck, but it's your typical greasy diner type food. As for a quick lunch/dinner deal and great taste, go to Fatty's Chinese Kitchen. Cut through International Marketplace (follow the yellow line) towards Kuhio. It's next door to Miramar Hotel. Order the Beef Chow Fun with Choy Sum. It's delicious and as the Chinese would say, it has excellent 'Wok Hay'. If you have a car, you should go to Ruth Chris Steakhouse and order the barbecued shrimp, crab cakes, cowboy cut rib-eye steak and creme brulee/apple caramel pie a la mode! The service was outstanding. Ask to be seated in Pat's section, you'll be treated like royalty!! Oh and by the way, people here like to eat LATE! Make sure you make reservations a couple of days in advance, especially if you're planning to dine at Duke's. As for the Ocean House Restaurant at the Outrigger Reef, it's nothing to write home about. I've read so many great reviews about this place, but it's just average. The only dish that was decent was the coconut lobster skewers (appetizer). Don't order the prime rib here, it's dry, has no flavor and served with boring, tasteless mashed potatoes and creamy horseradish out of a jar. If you want top notched seafood cuisine, take a cab and go to Roy's. It's the best for seafood! Order the misoyaki butterfish - melts in your mouth!In a nutshell, the HHV's Ali'i Tower is overrated! If returning to Waikiki, we would definitely not pay $350USD a night to stay here again! I've stayed at the Outrigger Waikiki, Sheraton Moana Surfrider and during my college days, the Ohana West and must say that they are more worth the money than the HHV. For what you're getting, it's not worth it, especially comparing it to a resort such as the Marriott Ko Olina Beach Club.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>good if you have kids, eat off campus pros: hotel right on beach! this is not so common on Waikiki Waikiki beach is at its widest here and it gets very narrow further downcons: they keep trying to sell you time shares and get you to go listen to their sales talk, food overpriced, not as many stores in village as you'd think---you can't make it your whole holiday  While we also found the hotel food overpriced, we realized we could just walk off of the property and eat anywhere else cheaper. There was even a Mc Donalds and Subway down the street and a huge mall Ala Moana Shopping Mall a 10 minute walk away with a food court, nice restaurants and every shop you could think of. For breakfast we took the advise of others and ate at the coffee shop across the street which also offered fresh fruit and muesli (very good) as well as diner breakfasts. The ABC store on property sold prepackaged sushi, sanwiches and fruit and snacks at reasonable prices--the pineapple is a bargain and a cup of to go coffee only .69 cents The hotel is very convenient--down the elevator you're at the pool, a few steps more the beach. We could run up easily for diaper changes, get things forgotten etc....there is a clean bathroom, changing cabin and showers downstairs too. A few times it would begin to rain and we could run for cover until it stopped. We stayed in the Rainbow Tower which was just fine--no fancy view but we didn't pay for it either. The room had 2 double beds and still had room for a crib (I believe it was provided for free) double stroller all of our suitcases and we still could move around. The room had a small refrigerator and coffee maker so we got some food for the kids and sometimes just ate on the balcony. If we had to schlepp all of our stuff and the kids a few blocks and across a busy street to get to the beach it wouldn't have been so nice or convenient. Also the other parts of Waikiki are right next to aloud busy street---look at a map. Its true they should provide more chairs at the pool but since we got up early we always got some. I believe the beach umbrellas/chairs are rented through a third party--the Hilton provided free towel service. People brought their own food/beverages to pool side from ABC stores to avoid pricey snacks pool side It would have been nice if the hotel provided more activities--a Lua for example. We noticed from our balcony every night shows for groups that rented out the space on the lawn but nothing for hotel guests. I would recommend bringing your guide book too because they can't really help you with anything on the outside world--you are told to talk to the activities counter which tries to sell you a big package tour. To remedy this, we rented a car (Hertz has a booth on property) $9 extra if you want a car seat and you can pick the car up on the Hilton property and did our own exploring---Pearl Harbor for example is free admission.  Also at the mall a there is a grocery store and Longs drugs for diapers baby food etc...they were only a little bit more expensive then what we paid back home in a major city I think that if you remind yourself that this is not an all inclusive Caribbean resort you'll do ok. Staff is friendly enough but not outgoing. A little tipping goes a long way. Also if you compare it to the other hotels in the area, it really is a dream.  
<Date>Oct 7, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Wonderful! Wonderful!....Did I mention it was wonderful? First some background...we are an ordinary working family that loves to vacation but need to get the most bang for the buck, so to speak. This hotel is fantastic. I do not understand why or how or what people could complain about. We stayed in The Rainbow Tower. Our room was nice size and very clean. The beach area in front of the hotel was spotless and deep enough to accomodate not only the cabanas but also all the people who chose to lay on towels. This is not the case down the beach, in front of other hotels. Trust me we walked ALL the way down to see for ourselves. The lobby was open and the common areas had AMPLE seating while you waited for cars, family etc. The pool area clean and the water crisp and sparkling, no cloudy, clorine haze. We chose not to eat at the hotel. Resort food is overpriced the world over----this is a no brainer for us-----we use that kind of money for side trips and sourvenirs.  Just a block away was a local coffee shop that served b-fast, lunch, dinner; much like a Denny's or Bob Evans in selection and price. There is an ABC store on the property and a fridge in the room-we put two and two together and saved on food. A caveat, some of the money we saved on food we chose to utilize for valet parking, our version of splurging. IF you can find good deals on prices stay here. We have been back and forth to Hawaii 3 times and this was money well spent. In fact the vote was from now on stay here or stay no-where. Feel free to email with any questions, our motto is vacation information is money saving power. Aloha.  
<Date>Oct 6, 2005

<Author>KateFL
<Content>A bit too busy I stayed here for 4 days the last week of Sept- 1/2 for business and 1/2 for pleasure. This place is HUGE... it's like a town within a town. It was very busy- the lobby itself was like being in a mall. When we got to the resort, I felt really overwhelmed. The lobby was so busy and there was a huge line to check in. Luckily and easily enough, there was a self check in kiosk that worked well- though a bit impersonal. We stayed at the Aliaia towers. Truthfully, for the description and the amount I paid, I would have expected something a bit nicer. Not that is was not nice, just very average and basic. The ocean view room we booked smelled very musty, and the airconditioner was very, very, very loud. We asked for another room and they accomodated us, though they only had a partial ocean view room. I did not really think it was much of a difference...The room , again, was very ordinary for the price. It was clean and it smelled fine. It had a nice balacony, though was a bit cramped. I found the staff friendly, but not overly speedy. It took the porter 1.5 hours to get our luggage (2 small pieces) to us- making us later for an apt. we had. The resort was so big that personal attention to things just seemed to be lacking. All the shops were nice, the beach was pretty, and the pool looked well maintained. We only had breakfast at the resort. The buffet at the Rainbow Laine was very good, nice vareity, if not expensive- 20.00 per person, though I have paid this at nice resorts before so I was not too surprised.. however, some of the restaurants charged 12-14.oo for a continental and I found that a bit too much- the buffet was very much worth it. I found that most, if not all, restaurants closed at 9 or 9:30- which left late diners very little choice but to order room service. Finding something to eat after a long day was a bit annoying. We liked the Oceantside terrace, but their last call was at 7pm. We were told that the resort held firworks every Friday night, they did not when we were there but no one (staff) seemed to know why. They no longer rent snorkel gear- was kind of a disappointment. We had a fax in our room, which was nice for business purposes, but an incoming fax cost 27.00 for 5 pages.... a bit much I thought. I have paid less at much nicer resorts. This wasn't a bad resort, it just was a bit too busy and lound for what I am used to. Hope this helps!  
<Date>Oct 5, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Very busy! I was disappointed with this hotel. We stayed at the Tapa Tower. Hotel was very busy with conference guests and somedays it was impossible to get a seat by the bar for people sitting working on their laptops. The main pool was very busy everyday, mainly with people leaving towels on the beds and then disappearing. We found it impossible to get a bed by the pool for the entire week. The Tapa pool by our tower was right next door to where they are building the wedding chapel and they were refurbishing rooms in the opposite block so it was very noisy! We ventured out onto the beach one day but at a cost of $51 for 2 beds and an umbrella we didn't bother again.Hotel had nice grounds and plenty of shops  resturants but certainly didn't live up to my expectations of a nice relaxing break at at quality hotel. I would look to stay somewhere else if I returned to Hawaii.

<Author>lynn2
<Content>Kalia Tower was great I used Trip Advisor to plan our once in a lifetime family trip - I love the advice from other travelers and find it to be right on. We stayed 2 nights in the Kalia tower before leaving for Maui and the Hyatt. The Kalia Tower was wonderful. We paid for ocean view rooms even though we are Honors members - everyone on the site says you get upgraded but I didn't want to take a chance on this special trip. The rooms were lovely, service great. We loved the Executive level - the view from the breakfast room was spectacular and we could have spent hours there just looking out at the ocean. Of course everthing's expensive in Hawaii - we knew that before the trip and planned accordingly. Waikiki is wild and the Hilton is a nice calm oasis in the middle of it. The only problem is that it's crowded - the number of people everywhere is a little overwhelming. We didn't go to the superpool until mid afternoon and never had a problem getting chairs. The beach was nice, but it was very hot and I'm too cheap to pay the price for the chairs and umbrella! We had a nice dinner at the Golden Dragon, and one off site at an Italian restaurant with a great view - can't remember the name. My only complaint is the Kalia pool. It is ridiculously small - just kind of funny that this beautiful hotel and beautiful tower would advertise this as a private pool - way below expectations. Our flight was late afternoon, and after checkout. But the hotel lets you use a lovely room - free - to shower and change in after spending the afternoon at the beach and pool after checking out - awfully nice. I think if I stayed here again I would stay in the Alii Tower. My sister has stayed there and it sounds perfect. (Maui Hyatt was fantastic)  
<Date>Sep 29, 2005

<Author>nalani65
<Content>Great experience I recently got married (August 27, 2005) and I chose to stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village for my wedding night. We live on O'ahu, so we've stayed at many different hotels before, but I thought that we would stay at one of the more high end onesfor our special night. Overall, we had a great experience, no problems. We stayed in the Ali'i tower, which was beautiful and all that I had expected. It was pretty pricey, even for a Kamaaina rate(local resident rate), but it was well worth it! I would definitely recommend this hotel to any honeymooners or couples celebrating their anniversaries. As for the busy and crowded reviews that people have been grumbling about, that is so minor! Living in Hawaii, you know that Waikiki is always busy, so if you can't deal with the crowds, my advice is don't stay in Waikiki!

<Author>Bubbles*CMT
<Content>LOVED OUR STAY AT THE HILTON HAWAIIAN VILLAGE! My husband and I just returned from 12 days at the HHV (9/4 through 9/16). We absolutely loved staying there. We had a corner room in the Tapa Tower that was very large with a desk, dresser, table and chairs, chair and ottoman. Plus the bath area had a wet bar, double closet, and another dresser and a full size tub/shower. There was a great view of the ocean from the lanai. There was a tiny little AC leak when we first got there but I called that evening and scheduled an appointment for 10 a.m. and it was fixed as promised. I highly recommend becoming a Hilton Honors member. My husband has a Gold Membership and a very nice continental breakfast was included every day, along with the USA Today paper. Also checking in is a breeze. From the time we left the airport until we got our luggage delivered to our room, it was approximately one hour. We did not use the super pool but did use the Tapa Pool everyday. There was never any problem getting a lounge chair. The bar by the Tapa Pool has great local entertainment. The internet and in-room movie system was great, too - tons of movies to choose from. We knew ahead of time that they did charge for coffee, but took our own small container of coffee and creamer - no problem. Also, the ABC store on the property has all sorts of drinks, bottled water, yogurt, snacks, etc. We walked down Kalia which turns into Ena Road (on the other side of Ala Moana) and about 1 block down is a laundry facility that does bundle laundry. Just drop it off and pick it up later. It is a large property, but we never felt crowded or congested. When we stay in Waikiki again, the HHV will be at the top of my list of hotels to stay at.  
<Date>Sep 19, 2005

<Author>seelyband
<Content>We enjoyed it We stayed at HHV from September 7-14. We were using a Hilton HHonors certificate for 6 of the nights, so only had to pay for one.We rented a car at the airport (Alamo, no problems) and arrived around 7 pm. No wait to check in. With the certificate you generally are assigned Tapa or Diamond Head Tower. We asked if it was possible to be switched to Ali'i or Rainbow (we are Honors Silver, and it makes a difference for this type of thing). They said that Hilton has decreed no Ali'i Tower for certificates, but we were put in an oceanview room in Rainbow Tower. Location was okay, not great. I went back to the front desk the next day and managed to get our room upgraded to a corner room on the 20th floor of the Rainbow Tower -- now that was a view to die for!! We were very pleased with the room, as it had two walls of glass/two balconies. We could see Diamond Head from our bed, and watched the Friday night show/fireworks while enjoying a pizza from Round Table (pretty good) and a nice bottle of wine on our balcony.Elevators are a problem in Rainbow Tower, but the view and the proximity to the beach and pool make it worthwhile.We did participate in the time share presentation for the $100 Hilton dollars. It took just over 2 hours and we did not buy. Not sure it was worth it, though when we used the $$ it was nice to enjoy the things for free.We ate at Goldon Dragon, which we thought was quite good. (Good Entertainment Book coupon, plus you can use the Hilton $$ on top of the coupon.) Also ate at Rainbow Lanai for breakfast once (okay, not sure it was worth the cost) and had pizza from Round Table as mentioned above. We hit the grocery store and the Kmart soon after arriving, so bought snacks, sodas, wine, umbrella and floats to use for the week.Other people have mentioned the charge for coffee. We had a sign next to the coffee maker that said you got one pot for free each day. I did have coffee each morning and was not charged for it, so I think this must be the case.The pool was pretty full, though we didn't have too hard a time finding chairs in the afternoon. If you ask the attendants they will remove towels and other items from chairs if it is obvious that they are being reserved for people that are not there.HHV has some of the nicest beach in Waikiki. Still, we spent more of our time on the North Shore beaches (Waimea for enjoying the sun and water and Sunset Beach for watching the surfers). A car is a must. Parking at the hotel was never a problem.We found the staff (especially the housekeeping staff) to be friendly and happy to help. Check out was no problem, though you should check the bill carefully. We were overcharged for parking, but it was promptly removed when I brought it to their attention. Since we had a late flight we took advantage of the hostpitality suite (need to sign up the day before) to shower and get cleaned up before heading out to the airport.From our balcony we could see the Ali'i Tower pool and hot tub, and they looked nice. Plus, the pool is open into the evening, while the Superpool closes at 6.We used the business center as we needed to get on the Internet for a few minutes. They had 3 computers available, and the charge for 15 minutes was about $5. Cheaper than using the in-room option. Also, if you go to the business center between midnight and 6 am, it would have been only $3 for the 15 minutes. There is a printer available as well.Overall -- we had a great time, and would consider staying at the HHV again.  
<Date>Sep 18, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Too busy We stayed at this resort from 31 August until 5 Sep. We arrived from New Zealand at 11pm. I had specifically booked the Kalia Tower as all the research I had done suggested this was the newest one. There was some mix up - they told us our booking had been cancelled - the tower was full and they didn't think they could accommodate us!! At 11pm at night after a nine hour flight this didn't go down too well. We booked through a travel agent and had a voucher which was the only reason they found us a room for the night. The next day they ended up transferring us to the Tapa tower as the Kalia tower was fully booked (all my research proving fruitless as we didn't end up where we wanted to). This wasted 1/2 day the next day while they sorted it out. The village is lovely but very very busy. Also my husband was swimming one day at the beach and got talking to a guy who asked him if he was attending the conference there. He said no and asked what the conference was - apparently it was for reformed alcoholics and others with a dubious criminal background!! We also got charged $50 for hiring an umbrella and two loungers for 1/2 day while some reformed criminals next to us got away with paying nothing (in fact two of them weren't even staying at the hotel!) Since returning home have noticed an extra $12 charge for something on my credit card. Would not stay here again.  
<Date>Sep 18, 2005

Finally a manager called me on my cell phone to state he was personally in your room to fix the problem...I went up there to our room within 2 minutes and guess what - no one was there. I called him back and he stated he was there and it was fixed. It was not. he lied. <Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>ok - overrated for the service provided We stayed at HHV from 8/30 - 9/7/05. We didn't like it much and would not come back again for a variety of reasons:1. When we booked the Ocean View room, we were told that we'd get a tower closer to the beach. On the day of arrival, we were told they were all booked and we ended up in Kalia tower, which is the furthest from the beach. Ocean View here is a joke because you are too far from the ocean, and behind other towers (Rainbow, Tapa, and Ali).2. After a long line to check in, and got to our room (which took us almost an hour), we didn't get our luggages delivered. We had to call the front desk to track them down before they start looking into it. Couple hours later, we finally got them. This whole process wasted ~ 3 hours.3. We want to use the fitness center, they said it cost $12/day to use it. Shouldn't the facility be available to all guests and included in the room price?4. Same as other people's comments, the superpool is large, but no pool chairs available if you show up after 9am. Standing in line before the pool open is not our idea of spending time at a resort vacation! Beach chair is ~$12/day, umbrella is $25/day.We ate at Sergio, Village Steak  Seafood, Benihana, and other smaller facilities in the resort. We think the quality  service is ok but not that great. In general, it's bit overrated.

<Author>clink54
<Content>Best Overall Honolulu Hotel/Resort We stayed at the HHV on our first trip to Oahu and loved it. Since then we have been back several times and never regretted the decision to stay here. Sure you're going to see people on this forum complaining about the expenses of dining, but I think most of these people either have never stayed in a resort hotel before, or just like to complain. Yes, food is more expensive here than some of the other Honolulu hotels but it's right in line with other resorts we've visited. If you want to economize you can go to the ABC store, or walk to McDonalds, but if you want to enjoy the resort...get out your wallet and enjoy yourself. There are excellent places to eat on the property, in fact the best Chinese restaurant on the island is in the Rainbow tower. We love the Japanese restaurant, and even found the Italian restaurant to be well above average. We were disappointed with the Rainbow Lanai buffet, but we don't care much for buffets anyway. What you'll love: The beach is wide, long, and even during the high season not as crowded as you might expect. You'll enjoy the variety of shops at the HHV, no matter what you're looking for chances are they have it. The staff has always been considerate and helpful, and they've bent over backwards at times to correct small problems. We're Hilton Diamond members and that may have helped us to get great service, but only at check-in...the rest of the staff were unaware of our status in Hiltons system. What might bug you: If you don't like crowded elevators and long wait times avoid the Rainbow Tower rooms. If you choose a high floor for the great views expect your waiting and transit times will be fairly long. Don't pick a room in the Rainbow Tower on the corners facing the afternoon sun (opposite Diamond Head). These rooms have two Lanai's but the AC didn't handle the afternoon heat very well. In fact we avoid the Rainbow Tower unless everything else is booked. The Tapa Tower or the Ali'i have better rooms and fewer children. Valet parking is rather slow sometimes. If you're used to the speed of a Las Vegas Valet you'll start foot tapping and pacing at the HHV. Don't pay for the Friday evening pool side show. The drinks are weak, the show not very well done, and the whole experience not worth the money. Try the Paradise Cove Luau instead. We think you'll enjoy the HHV, but expect to pay for things that some other properties give away. If you know what to expect and can afford it you'll be back year after year.  
<Date>Sep 12, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>The best of the best We stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village Aug 25th - Sept 01 in the Alii tower partial ocean view. What an experience we had. Let me first start by commending the entire staff on the Hilton grounds to include all of the shops and restaurants that we visited. This resort is enormous. The room was beautiful and we felt so spoiled.We had turn down service 3 times a day with chocolates and a flower on our pillows. The pools were great. I am glad though that we had a private pool at the Alii tower because the main pool was very crowded. Everyone we ran into that worked at the HHV (Hilton Hawaiian Village) seemed to be very happy to be employed there. They keep this resort in ship shape. The most beautiful grounds we have ever seen. Great entertainment at the bars nightly. Excellent service and very attentive staff. Overall we have to say that this was by far the most enjoyable place we have ever stayed at. We will be back in the near future!  
<Date>Sep 8, 2005

<Author>sarinasong
<Content>Had a great time!! OK-1st of all, I want to thank the many reviewers on this site for the tips provided about this hotel. That was the main reason I was prepared for what others considered surprising. We arrived Aug 31 2005 and stayed till Sept 5 2005. We were in the Tapa Tower on the 13th floor. 1st let me point out that I have never heard of a hotel in the U.S. having a 13th floor-and every time we got into the elevator and pressed our floor -people always had a comment. However, it was the beginning of a great trip-with no bad luck whatsoever! Our room was of average size and although we booked a village garden view room to save some money-we had a great view on all sides (to the right was a park w/a lot of greenery, front view of Honolulu city, to the left a lovely ocean view) definately more than we bargained for. Also, the Tapa tower in convienently located with the Tapa pool right downstairs, the Tapa bar next to it with nightly entertainment, and the beach not too far away. There were no funny or moldy smells, the AC worked fine, and the beds are the most amazingly comfortable I have ever slept on. The room was cleaned every day, we had plenty of towels, and the sheets are changed only if you put the sign on the bed letting the maids know you want the sheets changed. Definately go to the ABC store, (the one across from the hotel, around the corner from Wailana Coffee House is a little cheaper than the one in the village, but either one is fine) and buy your coffee/filters/tea/sodas/water/snacks/etc. It is indeed outrageous that the hotel would charge for in room coffee (and so much!) especially since you can get it at the ABC store and make it yourself with the in room coffee pot. Other tips: Wailana Coffee House across from hotel for breakfast (from 4.99 to 9.00) lunch and even dinner. Germaine's Luau-below average food, but great show. Book the Pearl Harbor/Circle Island tour thru E'noa Tours w/the American Express Tours/activities desk next to the check in counter with Kit or Julie. An all day tour but worth it! Pearl Harbor, and short stops at Dole Plantation, and a macadamia nut farm, and you see the entire island-great photo ops. Also Round Table Pizza in the Village is reasonable and good.Yes, the pools are shallow- I guess ti limit their liability from people diving -the super pool is only 3 1/2 feet and the Tapa pool 4 1/2 ft. But they are clean and temperature perfect. You want deep? There's a whole ocean a few feet away! And talk about warm water-the ocean is a great big bath (75 to 78 degree water). I came for both a convention and a small vacation, and I was expecting a disneyland-in-California-in-July-like atmosphere, but it just wasn't like that. It was hardly crowded at all-even wth the conventioners in town (about 8500 people, in different hotels of course) along with the usual guests/tourists. Maybe it was the time period in which we went. My son did miss a couple days of school. So I guess this would be a good time to go-after everyone else's vacation time. So we are planning to return here in 2007 but staying at least 7 days. Also if you are in Southern California, I recommend flying Aloha Airlines-they have a non stop flight and they serve food. That way you save on travel time.There are so many good things to say about this trip. But I think I have given a pretty good cliff notes version of my experience with the Hilton Hawaiian Village. I hope it helps others like others helped me.  
<Date>Sep 7, 2005

<Author>janernewcastle
<Content>Overpriced, overcrowded and over rated Oahu was the final leg of our honeymoon trip, the first two being San Francisco (Westin St Francis) and Las Vegas (Bellagio).We paid the top price for a Ocean Front room in the Rainbow Tower, and I have to say that I was very disappointed in the size and quality of the room, way below that which we had already experienced on our trip. We got unpacked, put on the AC, and noticed a really bad smell, when we checked the vent and noticed that it was covered in a black mould, which didn't bode well for what was going on behind.I went to talk to the manager about the standard of the room and the state of the AC, he said that he would have the AC checked, and would see if we could be moved to another room.The vent was cleaned, but that didn't help the smell, later on that day we were moved to a corner room on the 29th floor, with two balconies, one overlooking the complex, and one overlooking the beach. This was a nicer room, and larger, but the bathroom was still small and nothing like four star standard.The pools were very crowded, impossible to get a bed unless you were there by 9am, $51 for an umbrella and two beds on the beach is just a rip off, walk 100 yards towards town and get them for $20 instead.The food round the pool was very low standard, however there were some nice restaurants, the Italian had great food for instance.Overall the resort is too big, too many shops, in dire need of an overhaul (at least in the Rainbow Tower), and it's living off it's location. I would say without the view the hotel would be lucky to achieve a 3 star rating.  
<Date>Sep 6, 2005

<Author>houstonfolks
<Content>Lots of Benefits We just returned from a week long stay at the HHV and were very pleased with the overall experience. I will try to explain both the good and the very few negatives.We stayed in the Rainbow tower with a beach view. I definately recommend a room facing the beach. The view is beautiful looking over the main pool with nightly shows (not noisy) and on to a picture perfect beach. The room is a good size, nicely updated, mini fridge and balcony.The facillity is lovely and truly a village of attractions. There are many features on the property, but we most enjoyed the many (approx 20 restaurants), numerous shops from Louis Vitton on down and the several convenience stores all located on property. Also at the Hilton Pier is the submarine ride which is available through the hotel or we used Cheap Tickets at a reduced rate. Housekeeping does a great job keeping this large property clean. I never saw trash, dirty floors, dirty carpet etc.Buy an Entertainment Book before you leave. At least two restaurants on site (Steak House and Upscale Asian) have buy one-get one free coupons. Other attractions are also in the book.The only negatives I can tell you are about extra costs. The room safe is 3.50 per day, valet parking is 18.00 per day (all parking costs), and an umbrella and 2 chairs on the beach is 50.00. I think some of these charges are excessive, but the hotel is a business to make money.I would definately recommend HHV as the excellent facility outweight any negative aspects.Have a good vacation!  
<Date>Sep 5, 2005

<Author>njmom2
<Content>Great Customer Service, But needs Bigger Pool Stayed at the HHV for five nights, 8/23-8/27. Stayed in the Kalia Tower. Had an upgrade to ocean view, just by becoming a Hilton Honors member, free of charge. Our room was nice and clean, however since this tower is set back from the other towers, didn't get a view of Diamond Head. The major problem we encountered with this resort was that the Super Pool was way too small for the amount of people that can stay at this hotel. While we were there the hotel was completley booked. The doorman estimated that about 9,000 people were occupying the hotel at that particular time. The amount of lounge chairs around the Super Pool,which was the main pool, were about 150. Every morning at about 8 o'clock, we had to stand on line like cattle to get lounge chairs. Once the lines were opened at 8:30 people would literally scream and run for chairs. OUTRAGEOUS!!!!! The other much smaller pools were about half the size of the Super Pool and looked like backyard swimming pools, which we noticed was the case at most of the other hotels in Waikiki. The Waikiki beach by HHV is nice, but you must pay 12.50 for a beach chair and $25.00 for an umbrella. This seems to be the case on other islands in Hawaii. FYI, once you enter the ocean, there are many rocks underneath, which you can hurt your feet on. I didn't enjoy that at all. May want to think about bringing water shoes. Ate at Sergio's in the village of HHV, which was very good and had a great waiter. Also ate at Benihana, which was good and fun, (make reservations ahead of time). Also ate at the Round Table for Pizza, had Maui Zaui Pizza, very good; with ham, bacon, cheese, onions and pineapple. A great place for breakfast was the Wailiana Coffee Shop, down the block on Kalia Road on corner, outside of the HHV. Very inexpensive and very good, great french toast filled with guava, coconut syrup for your pancakes, highly recommend, most prices in the $4.99 to $6.99 range for large portions. Great service as well in and out within 45 minutes even if there was a line to get in.Now for the positive!!. We left 2 personal items behind. Realized it when we were at Honolulu Aiport waiting for our flight to Maui. Called the HHV spoke to concierge and told her we couldn't leave for Maui without these 2 items. She quickly contacted Security they retrieved the 2 items and sent them via taxi to the airport. All was taken care of within a 45 minute time frame. We couldn't be more thankful. That is the kind of service I would give 10 stars for.!Would I return to HHV, yes I would. When I compare it to the other hotels in Waikiki, it is one of the better ones and it's at the end of the beach so it is at a much quieter location. I think it does need to maybe build another pool to accomodate 3,000 room resort.  
<Date>Sep 4, 2005
<Rating>4	5	4	-1	5	-1	5	-1

<Author>Kelly43
<Content>Incredible staff My husband, 10 yr old son and I went to Hawaii for the first time and stayed here. It was suppose to be my dream vacation. I fell in love with the hotel and it's grounds. So beautiful. Then my husband passed away while we were there on our dream vacation. It was the absolute most difficult time in our lives. We felt as if we were a million miles away from anyone we knew. The staff at The Hilton Hawaiian Village were very comforting and helpful in our time of need. They deleted all of the video game charges my son had accrued and all of the incoming phone calls to our room off of our final bill. They also took care of our transportation to and from the hospital and to the airport. They were wonderful. We plan on going back within the next year or two and definately will stay here again. Thank you so much everyone at the Hilton Hawaiian Village for having such great customer service and understanding.  
<Date>Sep 2, 2005

<Author>Bartlett
<Content>Big complex, big bill but still good My family and I have just returned from 7 nights staying in an ocean front room in the Rainbow tower. The whole village is big and is alot to take in on your arrival. The hotel room was nice with 2 double beds and a balcony with lovely view. The bathroom was a bit on the small side. The walls are thin and just hope for quiet neighbours. We did have relatively quiet ones. The grounds are nice and it has the best position and beach section on Waikiki beach.The only things which were annoying was the cost of everything. Even the hire of the sun beds, umbrella costs up to $50.00 a day.The meals in the restaurants are also expensive but it is very easy to eat out close by. Overall a nice hotel if you don't mind big.But generally standards are to a high standard.  
<Date>Aug 30, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Doesn't Deserve the Bad Reviews We arrived on a Saturday afternoon ... we reserved the lowest price room on the Internet (although both husband and I are Honors members). There were tons of people checking in for a convention, however, we had less than a five minute wait through the Honors check-in line.They no longer had any garden view rooms with two doubles (we had our two teenagers with us). However, after a little patient waiting (maybe 10 minutes) and no complaining on our side, they placed us in an ocean view 2-room suite in the Diamond Head tower. Talk about excellent service! Thank you!The beds were extremely comfortable, the room was kept immaculate all throughout our stay and the view was incredible. Every person in every restaurant and store throughout the property was incredibly friendly and efficient. More importantly, we never saw the throngs of people checking in for the convention (they were in meetings all day). The beach was decent (best in Waikiki, anyhow) and the pools were not overcrowded.There were numerous dining options both within the resort and within a few blocks of the resort for all budgets. Overall, we had a great stay and will be returning.  
<Date>Aug 28, 2005

<Author>jsandresen1
<Content>Hilton Hawaiian Village: The Good, The Bad and The Ugly I just came back from a Four Day stay. We were in the Kalia Tower from August 23rd through the 26th. I have to say that every review, both good and bad is 100% correct. The problem with this hotel/resort is that it is not properly managed! The observations from most of my encounters at the Hotel were that customer service has not yet be i integrated in to the workplace.You can be at one part of the hotel and enjoy great service and then at another part of the Hotel you feel you like you've entered the Twilight Zone and landed at the Motel 6. We did a precheck in and noon and were told to we would receive a call at 2:00pm to check in, we never received the call. When we arrived to get our keys for the room in spite of being told everything was ready it took them 35 minutes to get us room keys and another hour to find our bags they had checked for us. I must admit that I have never stayed at a Major Hotel Resort where the employees of the Hotel smiled so little and pretty much were content that the service was poor. I finally spoke to the assistant manager on duty who refunded me $50 for my dinner problems but did little to solve any of the problems. As I said early on the problem with this Hotel is the management.There were some bright spots though, The SPA services and personal, something I did not see many people write about were outstanding, the saving grace of the Hotel and the reason I would consider returning. I later found out from the Manager of the Hotel that the Spa is an independent company which operates separately from the Hotel. Which might explain why the service was outstanding. Also the people at Crazy Shirts were great as well as the people at Benihana's which by the way is a place I would not normally eat at back home. Unlike some other people who stayed at the Hilton I had excellent service from the people who manned the hotel beach/towel services. In fact one of the guys helped to make sure we were checked in right on time. Maybe he should be running the Hotel as he knew more about Customer Service than the people responsible for running the Hotel.Of all the things that bothered me the most, worst than the bad food and lousy food service, (it took 45 minutes for any type of room service and even when the Hotel forgot to delivery us the Soup we had ordered they said it would take an additional 45 minutes to ship us the Soup they forgot with out order,) was the contest sales pitch I got three times a day from Hotel personnel trying to sell me Grand Vacation Hotel Timeshares. I asked them to stop but every time we had a question with their customer service the person tried to sell us something. And none of the Free Gifts we were told we would receive for staying at the Hotel ever arrived.Every time we ventured outside of the Hotel we encountered wonderful service. My Daughter and I went Horseback Riding at the Kualoa Ranch and I highly recommend this to everyone it was a great. By the way all of our outside adventures and travel were found through the great booklet that Hertz Rent A Car provided us. The Hotel Concierges are a complete waste of time. We asked for directions to the Blue Water Grill and we were told this was a ten minute car ride. Thanks to our car being equipped with Never lost we did arrive for our reservations but we were 30 minutes late as it is quite a bit more than 10 minutes away but still worth it.This Hotel is in need of a major management overhaul. I've stayed at other Hilton's, The New York Hilton for example the customer service and rooms were excellent. The manager of this Hotel should be sent out to fix the HHV.  
<Date>Aug 27, 2005

<Author>backfromvacation
<Content>A good time at the Hilton Hawaiian Village The big resort on the west end of Waikiki beach was nice. The pools were clean and if you got there early a chair was always available. The hotel was clean and its employees were very friendly, and helpful. Our room had a partial view of the ocean and was not really that important to us. We only used it for sleep and a place to get cleaned up, so we were almost never there.We saved our Subway club cards while in Ohio and took them to Hawaii with us, 2 cards = 1 foot long sub with the purchase of a drink so lunch was $1.50, we just got lucky that a Subway was outside our hotel. We bought rum and coke at a local store (ABC stores are everywhere) and discreetly mixed our own drinks using hotel cups by the pool, we even had fresh ice and limes. (The pool servers would always ask if we needed more drinks, but every time they cam back we had a fresh drink, they never caught on)A bike rental was also just outside the hotel grounds, we used this as our means of transport, even riding them to the base of Diamond Head and back. Using bikes we saw more of the City and were able to see restaurants and bars that we might have missed in a cab. I felt because the hotel is so far west we were really are not on the hot spot of Waikiki Beach and felt a little left out of the action.I have pictures of the Hilton on my website www.eyestothesky.net  
<Date>Aug 27, 2005

<Author>seani69
<Content>Wasted our time and money. My wife  I spent two nights in Honolulu's Hilton Hawaiian Village before going to Maui for five nights. We shouldn't have wasted our time  money on HHV. First of all, Honolulu is not my idea of a tropical paradise. It is way too crowded with skyscrapers and traffic jams to rival New York City...almost.We had booked our room in the Kalia tower on the excutive floor. The executive lounge served complimentry breakfast  afternoon snacks, both very mediocre in both selection and quality, hardly worth the extra cost.The rooms were spacious and nicely appointed. Private lobby made check in  check out a breeze. We were glad at not having to go to the bustling and chaotic main lobby for check in.The hotel is huge, VERY HUGE, and very crowded. At 10:30 am beach was crowded beyond imagination. Hotel charges $50/day rental for an umbrella and two beach chairs!! We may have spent that money but there was not a single decent spot left to set up our umbrella. Main pool area was no better, way too crowded. Luckily someone mentioned that Kalia tower had a private pool and hot tub on the 4th floor. That's where we spent the rest of our day. On our next trip to Hawaii, we will either skip Honolulu or choose some other smaller resort.

Stayed at other hotels in Hawaii and it was a much better experience for alot less and not so crowded.

<Author>raaam
<Content>Should have stayed in a three star We arrived hoping to relax and get ready for dinner at around 4pm, the room was not ready. I was told (as if it were my fault) to come back in 1 hour and given a pager. Hotel is nice, but when you're in Hawaii, paying good money, you expect more. I did get help from the agents at the american express counter, planning some of our excursions, they were very helpful.Next time I will stay in a condo for less money and more room.

<Author>liveforholiday
<Content>Not the place for a chilling time Ohau has a population of around 850,000.....849,000 of them would seem to be in the Hawaiian Village!! We stayed for one week in the Ali'i Tower. The staff were friendly  helpful, the rooms were great, clean  comfortable, air con, fridge etc but the village  Waikiki resort are absoultely heaving with tourists  locals. We agree with the other reviews about the prices, they are quite over the top....$50 a day to rent 2 sunbeds  a beach umbrella, restaurants on site aren't cheap either [althought the Pizza place is reasonable  good]. Our recommendation is to buy an ice box, go to Wal-mart, pack a picnic  head off over the other side of the island [about 45mins drive] its far less crowded  you can swim with sea turtles all day long for no extra charge!

<Author>redvelvet
<Content>Hilton Delivers Fun and Sun with Flair My husband, 16 year old daughter, 15 year old niece, and I recently enjoyed a refreshing 11 night stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village - a definite tropical paradise. As a Hilton Honors member we were able to have a smooth check-in through the Hilton Honors check-in line, but I noticed a somewhat lengthy check-in line for non-Honors members. Everyone is welcomed with a beverage on check-in. We stayed in a 1 bedroom suite in the Diamond Head Tower. We absolutely loved it. There is a car rental company on site if guests decide to rent a car for all or part of their stay. Although we rented a car to enjoy the island during our stay, one could stay at this resort and use the public transportation to see the Honolulu and Waikiki areas and save money. In fact, we walked around much of the Waikiki area from the resort to avoid the hassle of reparking the car (which usually costs money per hour). Daily self parking at the resort is $15 dollars ($19 if you want valet) and although it may seem pricey, it is less than parking in some other US metropolitan areas. Our suite was very clean with great service although the room was somewhat dated. The beds were very comfortable with plush top sheets. We had a pull-out couch in the living area with good sound control between the living area and sleeping area so the television watchers did not disturb the sleepers. Our room had a fridge which was nice as we were able to stock up on drinks at the local Walmart and avoid the higher priced beverages stocked in the room. We had a partial ocean view and a nice balcony area to sit out on and relax. We liked having the shops and animals about on the property. However, if you dislike hustle and bustle then this is not the place for you. During the day the beach can be very crowded and the umbrellas and beach chairs are extra. We really enjoyed the beach in the evening when it was not crowded at all. The girls enjoyed some of the free resort activities and they were disappointed they missed out on the free lei making classes (be sure to reserve in advance). Snorkeling lessons are available as well on the property. The resort is within walking distance to the Ala Moana Mall which is a plus if you have teenagers. Some of the resort restaurants are pricey, but there is a cafe just across the street from the resort that is reasonably priced and on the property one of the Japanese restaurants (Hatsuhana's) has a cheese omelet special breakfast for $7 with rice that is decent. This restaurant also has a Happy Hour from 3 to 7 with special prices on beer. Be sure to try Lappert's Ice Cream parlor for some excellent tropical ice cream flavors. On Friday nights there is an awesome fireworks display with entertainment that adults and children will both enjoy (come a early for the best seating). We found all of the staff to be very polite and helpful. We did not participate in the timeshare sale, but for those who are interested you can pick up $100 Hawaiian Hilton dollars to spend on the property by listening to a 90 minute sales pitch within 48 hours of your arrival. There is a business center with internet access for 33 cents a minute (daytime hours) with a $5 minimum. It would be nice if complimentary internet access was available. Also, at times there was a short wait to get a computer terminal. However, having a post office on the site was a definite plus and we were able to mail out our packages with relative ease. My husband said that staying at the resort was the best part of the vacation. We would definitely stay here again - I waffled beween rating this resort above average or excellent - judge for yourself. In fact, we had been considering Alaska for our next vacation but we had such a great time here we may come back again next year.  
<Date>Aug 21, 2005

<Author>Chip21
<Content>Exceeded Expectations! I used Trip Advisor as a planning tool for my families recent trip to Hawaii and wanted to share my thoughts on our trip to paradise. We stayed 5 days on Oahu at the Hilton Hawaiian Village and 5 days at the Grand Wailea on Maui. We have a family of four with a 12 year old son and a 9 year old daughter. The vacation was like two trips in one. Oahu is hustle and bustle and lots of things to do...and fun! We stayed at the HHV and it is BIG, but, we had an amazing time there. Service and facitilites were EXCELLENT. We stayed in the Rainbow Tower with OV and would book the same again. We did Pearl Harbor...good. Snorkeled at Hanauma Bay...Simply Amazing. Dolphin Quest at the Kahala Mandarin...best part of the trip for the kids. On Maui at the Grand Wailea, a quiet, tropical paradise! If you're staying with kids...hands down, the GW is the place to go. I walked down to the Kea Lani and Four Seasons, both spectacular properties, but your kids will kill you if you didn't go to the GW and have fun at all the water/pool amenities. Spa was good at GW, but expensive. Only bust for my family was the Road to Hana...I wouldn't waste a day on this...no one in my family really enjoyed this long trip (just us I guess!). My personal favorite experience was taking a snorkel trip to Molikini with Trilogy Excursions...you must go on this trip - it was the greatest! Also attended the Feast at LeLe - another wonderful treat. Not too grown up for older kids. The show was amazing and food was to die for. Can't wait to come back to Hawaii again!  
<Date>Aug 20, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Awesome, fun-filled family vacation! My family and I recently stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village from 8/10/05-8/15/05. From the moment we arrived, the staff treated us like royalty. Our rooms were located in the rainbow tower and the rooms couldnt have been more clean or comfortable. They were spacious and the bathroom was very modern and well lit. The beach was literally steps away from the elevator. Although the restaurants on-site were a bit high priced for our budget, there were plenty of eating facilites located nearby within walking distance. If there is anything to complain about this hotel was that it is just too big, too many stores to see. I highly recommend this hotel for your hawaiian vacation. (Oh, and dont forget to ask about their time share presentations, it will pay off.)

<Author>WorldTraveller84
<Content>Some good, some bad This is a well organised, busy hotel and the staff were very helpful and friendly.The grounds are very picturesque and there are animals such as penguins and ducks. There are also a wide range of shops (although they are expensive) within the hotel grounds. An ABC small supermarket is also available within the grounds where you can purchase water, food etc at more reasonable prices.The towel service on the beach was also very useful whereby you can loan as many free towels as you wish to be returned at the end of the day. Parasols and sun loungers were also available. The parasols were about 拢15 a day to hire.We were upgraded to a partial ocean view on arrival due to space being available. The main negative aspects issues I have with the hotel are the cleanliness of the room. The room was not clean when we arrived and although the towels were replaced daily, the beds were not fully made and the room was never hoovered or surfaces wiped thoroughly. In addition I believe some aspects of the room were a little worn and dated and are in need of a refurbishment. Therefore overall, although my stay was pleasant, I believe there are hotels which offer better value for money along the Waikiki beach. In particular the more reasonably priced Outrigger with it's excellent location nearer to the main shopping street looked like it may have been better value for money.  
<Date>Aug 15, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>You can do a lot better with your money With great anticipation, we arrived at the Hilton Hawaiian Village for a 2-night stay before traveling on to Maui for a 7-day stay.Why is it when you spend $500 per night for a room at the Hilton they nickel and dime you to death with fees for everything but you can stay at a Hampton Inn (owned by Hilton) and get the same services for free? For example, Hilton promised me wireless internet in my room (although it was a vacation, I did have to work each day). Guess what, wireless internet in the Diamondhead Tower doesn't work. I had to go out to the bar in the main area to get access...especially fun at night with no lights and a ban blaring in the bar. When I explained the problem with the manager, her response was, you shouldn't be working on vacaction. We had four people in our room and when we checked in, there were two towels. Two our our lamps did not work (never fixed), the pull-out bed didn't have a blanket (never replaced), the clock radio didn't work (never fixed) and the TV set was missing its remote control (replaced after 2 phone calls). Room service trays sat in the hallway from 6 pm to 3 pm the following day. The rooms were in serious needs of updating. Don't even get us started about the charges for beach chairs and umbrellas. I especially enjoyed the explanation the beach guy gave me as to why chairs were extra (public beach, not controlled by Hilton, a separate business). When I inquired as to why his name tag had a Hilton logo on it, he walked away and would not answer my question. The bed was comfy, the view from our room was great, and the complimentary breakfast we got (because I have Hilton Rewards Gold status) was excellent.However, don't rip me off. Just tell my my room costs $600 per night, I get an umbrella at the beach, two chairs, I can use the safe in my room, wireless internet access, and I can park my car in your garage. We definitely will not stay here again nor would we recommend it to anyone else.  
<Date>Aug 15, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Hilton was okay I stayed at the Hilton from July 31st through August 3rd based on reviews I read on TripAdvisor. While there was nothing specifically wrong with the hotel, I probably will not stay again, it was just too busy. That being said, when we checked in we were told they were fully booked given that it was peak vacation season.Like most reviewers we got upgraded upon our arrival, we has a partial ocean front view in the Diamond Tower. Our room was suffciently modern and had a very nice terrace from which we could watch the sea. On our second to last night, there was a leak in the ceiling and the staff promtly moved us to a junior suite which was even nicer. The suite had a terrace the size of our original room and we had a nice sitting room which gave us a place escape the Waikiki craziness.Like most of Waikiki, the Hotel was very crowded but had it all. As you will read on its website and all the reviews, the Hilton is its own self contained city, with a number of shops and resturants to chose from. Coming from New York City, both prices and options were okay. We were pleasantly surprised by the bookstore which had a number of good titles and the various Japanese noodle bars.With respect to the beach, I had hoped that it would be less busy given that it was at the end of Waikiki...I was wrong, throngs of people. Plus like the rest of Waikiki, there was virtually no shade available (unless you were willing to pay for an umbrella)Again, there was nothing specifically bad about the Hilton, just a little too zoo-ish for my husband and I. Also, while I thought I was getting a bargain at $209 a night, once I added on the various costs such as breakfast, parking etc, I probably would have done better at one of the higher end hotels. Next time, I think we will probably just stay in a BB or resort on the North Shore or just pass on Oahu all together.  
<Date>Aug 14, 2005
<Rating>2	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1

<Author>Jmpserve
<Content>Hilton Hawaiian, Aug. 2005 I just returned from 3 days at the Hilton Hawaiin Village. I was upgraded to an ocean view in the Ali'i tower. Do whatever you can to stay in this building. They have their own private pool, so it's pretty easy to find a chair at any time. Be aware that there are only 5 umbrellas and people will put out towels very early (around 8:0am) and finally decide to go the the pool around noon. this really annoyed me and it's too bad they will not control that. Ali'i tower also serves appetizers from 5:00 to 7:00. The only other thing that bothered me was the parking. $15 to park and $19 for vallet. Otherwise, I would recomend this hotel. If your into diving, use Island Divers. They will pick you up at the hotel and they do a very good job. I did the Corsair wreck and China Wall.  
<Date>Aug 14, 2005

<Author>TrixieT
<Content>A Corner of Paradise I spent 7/30 - 8/7/2005 in Hawaii.First 2 nights stayed at Outrigger Waikiki on the Beach, which was wonderful except that Waikiki Beach is so narrow and crowded.Moved to Hilton Hawaiian Village (to attend a wedding) for the next 6 nights and loved it.It had a beautiful beach, big and wide, not hustling and bustlling but calmer.The hotel had a great location within walking distance of all the other hotels on Waikiki. We stayed in the Kalia Tower and our room had a nice view. Plus the lanais were more private than at the Outrigger. There were no mold or mildew odors as mentioned in another review and the rooms were spotlessly clean. The rooms were quiet. No noise from next door. I didn't hear any construction noises either. The staff was pleasant and cooperative.As at the other hotels in Waikiki, lounge chairs by the pools were hard to come by; people came early, claimed their chairs by leaving towels or magazines on them, then left. The HHV had a policy that if a chair was not occupied for 45 minutes the items on it would be removed; but unfortunately it wasn't enforced. The Kalia Tower had its own pool on the 4th floor which was rarely crowded. The Tapas pool was also very nice - nicely landscaped and near one of the bars which made great Mai Tais. And not a screaming child to be found.I was disappointed with the Super Pool. It wasn't as large as what I imagined from the description or as super. I thought the pools at Disney World's Caribbean Beach resort and Dixie Landings were much more super: very large, more interestingly shaped and better landscaping.HHV also had a variety of restaurants to choose from including a Benihana.There was also a pizzeria where you could take out and it was reasonably priced. The food at Bali's was out of this world. The filet mignon was superb. The breakfast buffet at Outrigger was fantastic. Truly all you could eat and everything was included in the $12.95 price (unlimited coffee, tea, juices: oj. guava, pineapple, papaya, etc, etc.) The freshest fruit and the sweetest pineapple. Omelette station, sausages, bacon,. muffins, croissants, potatoes, hot and cold cereals, waffles, pancakes, french toast, etc. etc.I have to admit I didn't try the breakfast buffet at the Hilton simply because it was overpriced ($19.95) and what more could they offer that the Outrigger didn't. Plus the famous Eggs N Things was very close to the Hilton and everything you read about it is true. The food is great (macadamia nut pancakes and waffles, or pancakes and waffles with fresh fruit and piled high with whipped cream, and, of course, all kinds of omelettes) very reasonably priced, too.A couple of things I didn't like about the Hilton: parking was $15.00 a day, more for valet parking. I thought that was a rip-off. And to use the safe in your room was $3.65 a day, a lot of hotels offer this convenience at no charge. It's in your room anyway, you input your own code. So what are you paying for?? But what annoyed me the most was paying for the coffee they provided in the rooms. $6.00 a bag which only made 1 - 2 cups depending on the strength. We were also charged for tea bags! I have done a lot of traveling - to the Caribbean, Europe, Canada and all over the USA - never was I required to pay for the coffee in the room.Would I go back to the Hilton? Absolutely. It was a truly wonderful resort.But next time I won't rent a car (there's really no need, the transportation in Oahu is great), I won't bring any jewelry and I'll bring my own coffee and tea bags.  
<Date>Aug 12, 2005

<Author>realdeal
<Content>Straight Talk about Ali'i Tower Hilton Hawaiian Village Just spent one week at the Ali'i Tower at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. There were several pros: private pool; great bed; private check-in; Crabtree  Evelyn amenities; Doorman wonderful with lots of helpful tips..... As for the cons:Daily charge for the in-room safe ($3.50/day); Nominal fee for breakfast in the Tower Terrace Lounge is $14 per person - not so nominal; carpets stained in room; furniture just so so; hard to reach the front desk; wireless not reliable.All in all, an OK stay but did not meet expectations set by others in this forum

<Author>psychoscarf
<Content>Paradise with a few problems We took our children, 15 and 10, on a 10 day Hawaiian vacation and spent 5 nights at the Hilton Hawaiian. The grounds are outstanding and the wildlife(penguins and huge goldfish) kept my 10 year old entertained for part of the time. On arrival we were pleasantly surprised to find we had been upgraded to the Rainbow Tower which is directly on the ocean and in close proximity to the pool. The rooms are a good size and the beds got raves from each one of us. A couple of problems with towels and a lamp were corrected immediately. Be forewarned that it is a bustling place and not a serene tropical paradise. All the while we were there (7/35-7/30) finding a spot by the pool was practically impossible. The beach is clean and if you prefer not to spend the $$ to rent the umbrellas locate yourselves underneath one of the palm trees on the right hand side of the beach which offers free shade all day long. Had breakfast every morning at the Wailana Coffee House, which a previous reviewer recommended, and they were right as I had the best coffee there as anywhere on the island and it is a simple 2 minute walk from the hotel. Problems were the fees attached to everything - what hotel doesn't have a fitness room available free of charge? How do you justify the $3.25 daily fee for in-room safes when most everywhere else they are part of the room accommodations! and nowhere on the safe does it mention the fee, however if you look at the fine print in the phone book size directory of the facility it does mention it there. I had read there was a coin-op laundry on site but discovered this is no longer and I would need to lug my laundry down the street approximately 10 minutes to get it done. I waited until we arrived at the Sheraton Maui and did it there. Expect to wait in line for the daily towel dispensing which makes absolutely no sense as they ask for your room number, never write it down and when you return it at the end of the day there is noone taking notice of who returned what??? The high rise aspect did give a different perspective of the island but I doubt I would return to this hotel if I am lucky enough to travel back to Hawaii in my lifetime.  
<Date>Aug 8, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>A Welcome Surprise My husband and I just returned from 4 nights (7/31-8/3) at the HHV (followed by 3 nights at The Fairmont Kea Lani on Maui) with two other couples. We had a great time and were pleasantly surprised at the quality of the HHV. We stayed in the Ali'i Tower because it was advertised as adult only, with an adult only pool. While we did encounter children, it did not detract from our experience. We found the rooms to be spacious and clean. The views were fabulous, the bed was exceptionally comfortable (think Heavenly Bed from Westin) and the service was timely. The decor is a little kitschy, but acceptable. Everyone at the front desk, valet and restaurants were very friendly and accommodating. I was slightly put off by the price of the chair/umbrella rentals and the fitness center fees, but thought the room prices reasonable under the circumstances ($279/night, including continental breakfast, for deluxe ocean view). The free continental breakfast was quite good, with assorted pastries, breads, fruits and cereals. The beach was lovely, moderately crowded and accessible. Overall, I think the HHV compared favorably to the overly generous 5 star rated Fairmont on Maui (see related review). The only unpleasant part of the trip was eating at Dukes. It was uncomfortably hot in the restaurant, the food was average (but overpriced) and the service was awful. While it really is a village unto itself, the HHV is a bit of a hike to downtown Waikiki -- making cabs necessary and expensive. A nice hotel closer to the action was the Moana Surfride. I'd give it a try next time! The HHV was definitely more than I expected and I would recommend it to anyone.  
<Date>Aug 8, 2005
