<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>HHV: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly. Aloha, My husband and I went to HHV for our honeymoon. This was not our first choice as we had to cancel our trip to the Mayan Riviera due to Hurricane Emily in July.The GoodTHe HHV is absolutely beautiful. It has amazing tropical gardens and rare birds and animals. The scenary is breathtaking and the HHV has the best location on Waikiki as it has the largest size beach compared to the other hotels. It is also at the end which gives it a sort of seclusion from the overcrowded hotels on the rest of the beach. We stayed in the Rainbow tower in a corner room which gave us two balconies with a view of the harbor and the ocean. The room was beautful and the bed was vey comfortable. Good service from staff.The BadTHe HHV is very busy. Lots of families. We would have enjoyed a more quitier place. If you are planning a honeymoon, consider a few nights in Maui and Honolulu. Waikiki offers excellent shopping and good night life for those who enjoy it.The Ugly The resort is nothing like an all-inclusive in Mexico. You pay for eveything here: coffee and bottled water in rooms ($1.50-$2.50), room safe ($3.25 per day), beach chairs ($10.00 per day) and beach umbrellas ($25.00 per day). The beach chairs and umbrella was a surprise to me as we have never paid for this before. The restaurants on the resort are pretty expensive, okay for a few nights but will get pretty pricey for the whole vacation. Some tipsGo for breakfast, lunch or dinner to the Wailana coffee house across the street on Ala Moana BLvd. It is very reasonable ($4.99 all you can eat pancakes plus 2 eggs and 2 bacon). Also, walk down Kalakua to the International Market (about 10 minute walk) place for some cheap shopping (this is like Mexico, you can bargain). There is beautiful jewelry here. Have dinner at the Cheesecake factory (across from the market place), has big portions for very reasonable prices and the food and service is great. Other good restaurants include Duke's in the Outrigger hotel next to Cheesecake factory. It has good dining and beautiful view of the beach. Get early to restaurants in waikiki as it gets very busy after 6pm. Do the Pearl Harbor Circle Island tour with E'noa Tours ($47.00 per adult). It picks you up at 6am and return at 5pm, but it is worth it. You will visit beautiful beaches and amazing landmarks. Also, visit the Polynesian cultural center and book the Ali'i Luau package ($97.00 per person). You get the history on the islands of polynesia and get to enjoy a real hawaiian feast. There is lots to do here. Visit the American Express Tours desk in the main lobby to book your activities. It is worth it. I hope this helps. Aloha!  
<Date>Aug 6, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great place if you don't mind spending the money! We recently stayed in the Kalia tower of the village and had a great trip. The room was immaculate with the most comfortable hotel bed we have ever slept in. The service varied depending on what you needed. The place is so big, often the people you asked didn't know the specific answer to your question. I was rather surprised that everything had such a high price tag. With the cost of the hotel, I did not imagine we would have to pay for using the gym, etc. but you do. Of course, many of the pricey items is what you expect when staying in the captive resort environment. If you want to go somewhere else to eat, downtown Waikiki and Honolulu are easily accessible. I would definitely recommend this place to couples or families looking for a nice place to stay who don't mind paying some extra money.  
<Date>Aug 3, 2005

<Author>Shel4556
<Content>Loved It! July 19th -25th 2005Read mostly good reviews and some bad...realized the bad ones were 4th of July weekend! I LOVED IT! When I got off the plane and realized Ohau was a tropical New York I was extremely let down. However, arriving at the HHV saved it. It was nice, clean, elegant for an island and professional. The staff was great. We had a beautfiul ocean view room in the RainBow Towe(the tower to stay in). The room was nice and clean. The balacony was a good size with chairs and tables and a rack for drying swim suits and towels. The beach was wonderful. At bit pricey to rent chairs and umbrellas but they were always available and not sold out. Our week Subway convention had bought out most of the resort..completed booked; however, you could still always find a place on the beach and your own space. We did not spend time at the pools but they were nice and did not seem overly crowded to me. Food: Nice places were not that high and they also had a great pizza place and deli that were extremely reasonable. The ABC store on sight was not overpriced at all. The place really is a village. GREAT shopping on site. Good prices and great salespeople. All friendly and willing to chat it up and not sell you. Tropics on the beach a great place to have lunch and drinks. Good food and good prices. Ohau though: the trollies are crowded and SLOW. Pay the parking fee at the hotel it is worth it. We had a Jeep the first half and then decided we did not need it. Bad decision. Anyway..HHV - great family place as well. If you do not like kids you will not like it. We did not have our daughter with us and I found myself planning all her activites when we return. All the kids were well behaved and not loud. I strongly suggest HHV. All the other hotel are crammed together and no beach space. HHV is on the end with plenty of room and is nice and quiet in the evenings. Still in good walking distance to all other hotels and beaches. Hope I help! This site helped me!  
<Date>Aug 3, 2005

<Author>ladychow
<Content>PARADISE! My family and I stayed at HHV for our first trip to Hawaii and it was beyond belief. From the moment we pulled up to the lobby to check in, we were astounded by how beautiful the property is. The pools, the shops, the restaurants, the bars were all right there. AND penguins!!! waterfalls and tropical flowers and the nightly lighting of the torch ceremony - it was just so amazing. The sleeping rooms were fine and clean - but that's not always my main concern as we don't spend a whole lot of time in the room except to crash each night. A great hint - we stop by the ABC shop each morning to pick up bottled water and pre-made sandwiches before we head off for our excursions each day. It was convenient and inexpensive. Things to do - Polynesian Cultural Center, Diamondhead, Pali Highway, Hanauma Bay (A MUST! get there early), North Shore, Ala Moana Shopping Center. Hilton Hawaiian Village really contributed to our overall pleasure and experience of Hawaii - we loved it so much we bought the timeshare and went back to Hawaii last year and we already plan to go back again in 2007!!!  
<Date>Aug 2, 2005

<Author>craneman01
<Content>Hilton Hawaiian Village - The Lowdown Just returned from the village The resort is truly huge. It's not a viilage, more a town. It's bustling and energetic. After 2 weeks we believe we still haven't discovered all that it has to offer. BUT.....It's not cheap. To start with, we were in the Rainbow Tower . The rooms are ok. We had spent in excess of $1700 for a deluxe ocean view, Hiltons definition of an Ocean View is very generous in our opinion. When we got to the room we looked out on the condominium tower (around 50%) The small boat harbour (around 30%) and if you went to the balcony edge and looked to the left, you could see the sea. We wern't happy  went to the desk  explained. They were suprised that we felt that way and was offered another room further along on the same side of the tower at $80 per day supplement which we declined but eventually got a room further along the tower after 5 days which had a bit better view but not a lot. They charge for a lot of items. eg, If you want to use the safe in the room it's $3.25 per day. Tea/coffee/water in room is all chargeable. We wanted an umbrella  2 loungers on the beach. Certainly for $51 per day. If you have had enough on the beach by lunchtime Hilton will rent out the same equipment that they have been paid for for a full day to someone else for $51 for the day. They are raking it in from the guests. If you hire a car, it will cost you $13 per day to self park it on site  $18 for valet parking. There are things going on most nights but there is no board telling you what's going on. There are strict rules for getting towels for the beach  for using the pool area but you have to find them out. They are not easily displayed. Room service as regards cleaning in our opinion is mediocre at best. We were in 2 rooms on two different floors, so had different cleaners. Not good at all. The hotel is around 1陆 miles from Waikiki so if you want to get to the heart of what's going on  enjoy the place (Highly recommended), it's a taxi, bus or a walk dependant on your constitution, purse. It's a lovely place, but could be better if they stopped trying to get money out of you by the back door.  
<Date>Jul 27, 2005

<Author>Jeff511
<Content>Hats off to Hilton Hawaiian Village What a great Hotel! This Hotel has it all. Spent 5 days here recenty and enjoyed it to the max. Stayed in the Ali'i tower. The room was immaculate and full of the amenities you would expect. Great pool, beautiful large beach area, lots of shopping for the ladies, and great restaurants and activities closeby. My kids had a great time also-ocean area perfect for children. What puts this hotel over the top is the atmosphere and service.Interacted with staff from restaurants, bell service, front desk, activities,doorman etc. -everyone was very friendly and eager to take care of your needs. The only other aspect I would like to mention is the hotel is very busy but the staff handles it well. If you are looking for a secluded getaway this is not the place, but for a family its perfect. One last comment , Hilton does a great job of giving you a resort atmosphere the village which is secluded from the city atmosphere which surrounds it. We would return.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Good with children, just okay for adults Not a bad hotel, but certainly not a great one either. Very reasonably priced and decent, but not spectacular rooms. As with most Hiltons, they could use a few upgrades in the rooms, especially on the bedding, the bathroom, and the carpets throughout the property. And, this is picky I know, but, employees clothing/uniform is severly outdated. Eating in their beautiful restaurant was like being waiting on by Alice in Mel's diner. Still, the staff was pleasant enough - not excellent enough to provoke great tips, but not bad enough to make a complaint.But, if you want a great rate and a good place with kids, this works. The Kids club was good, the pool is great and the prices to eat are very reasonable. And, you can always do what I did to avoid the bathroom if you are picky like me. I worked out and used the spa - which is in the Tapa tower. The spa is nice, but lounge areas are small though well maintained.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>loved the ali'i tower This was our first trip to Hawaii and we stayed in Oahu for 5 days. Since it was only a stop over for our real honeymoon in Tahiti, we decided to stay in a more reasonable hotel and booked an ocean view in the Ali'i tower (compared to hotels in Tahiti $370 a night was reasonable). We loved the Ali'i tower and all its amenities. It was truly worth the extra money for a separate check-in, separate pool, complementary hor' dourves on the patio, private concierge (aloha Sydney!). The beds were the most comfortable hotel beds, the view was spectacular and the location on Waikiki beach could not be beat. I do think that the staff could be a wee bit more friendly as staff in some of the other hotels were, but it didn't detract at all...things were pricey in hawaii, but we're from nyc, so we're used to those prices, my only pet peeve was paying for the safe...  
<Date>Jul 21, 2005

<Author>lawahoo2001
<Content>Great hotel, but stay in the Kalia Tower (not Tapa) This is the second time I've stayed at this resort. The resort itself is fabulous, the best on Waikiki. However, your room experience will vary depending upon the tower where you are located. The first time I stayed here in Sept. '04, I was in the Kalia Tower, which was excellent. It is one of the resort's newest towers. As a Hilton Honors member, we were upgraded to the executive level and had free breakfast and snacks, all for $200/night. For this trip (July '05), we stayed in the Tapa Tower. Not as nice. Was not given an upgrade. The room is older, and the bathroom always had a mildewy smell. Had a partial ocean view, though. When you make your reservation, you should call the hotel and request the tower that you want. Kalia is the way to go, not Tapa.  
<Date>Jul 21, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Nice hotel but too impersonal My husband and I stayed in the Tapa tower July 8-15 2005. We had specifically requested a king bed when we booked 6 weeks ago but they were unable to accomodate us upon check-in. We were put in a room with 2 doubles. The next morning I called to see if they could switch us and was told nothing had opened up and they didn't anticipate being able to move us for the entire stay. I expressed my displeasure again and upon furthur checking they were able to find a king room. The room we were moved to was pretty nice - large room, nice view, but in my opionion was dated and in need of some renos. If you require any assistance from the front desk, don't bother going down there - huge line ups. You're better off calling, hopefully they call you back if they are too busy. It was a pretty nice hotel but it really lacks personality. Not too sure I would go back.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Ohio loves the Hilton My wife, two boys (12  16) and I stayed at in the Ali'i Tower July 1 - 6 and loved it. The Ali'l tower is closest to the beach, offers the best service of the various Hilton towers on the grounds and would be my first choice when we return. Our room was immaculate, cleaned several times daily, and we could be on the beach within one minute of getting in the elevator. Also, the Ali'i offers it's own check-in desk which keeps you out of the BIG lines at the main check-in desk which covers all the other towers. When you go, save money by buying daily supplies (pop, water, lotion) at the ABC store on the grounds...a very busy place. The Super Pool wasn't that impressive and the seats were all filled all day...but we didn't care one bit because the beach was awesome and we were very happy to be out there all day. The Hilton is at the end of Waikiki beach so it felt less congested than the other hotels we saw and the other benefit was its' easier access when driving. Eat breakfast at the Wailana Cafe across the street...$4.99 breakfast w/ all the pancakes you can eat along w/ wonderful waitresses! Do the hike to the summit of Diamond Head early in the day, the view is awesome and it's an easy 25 - 30 minutes for all but the most out of shape. Go to Ala Moana shopping center (which can be walked to) to see everything under the sun. We did the Royal Hawaiian Luau and found it significantly less impressive than the Old Lahaina Luau we went to on Maui a few days later...I'd pass on it. Pearl Harbor: we got there at 7:45 sunday morning and waited for 1 1/2 hours! Get there closer to 7:00 and you'll get right in. Did the Navatek dinner cruise and that's well worthwhile as you go out past Diamond Head for a two hour ride. I highly recommend the Hilton and will go there on our next trip!  
<Date>Jul 15, 2005

<Author>BESnow
<Content>Very nice hotel My wife and daughter recently spent 2 nights at this Hilton. We stayed based on comments from Trip Advisor. It was very nice, but also very large and very busy. This was a bit of culture shock after staying on Kauai for a week in a condo. Despite it's size they are very organized. Our room was immaculate. The maid service was adequate. I agree with others about the expense of eating in and around the hotel area. We did have a very nice and inexpensive meal at the Noodle House in the village and the pizza at the Round Table was very good and not overly priced. The beach and and pool areas were very nice, but also very crowded. We also saw the fireworks from the beach on July 4th and they were excellent. One thing I would do different in the future is not to arrive until at least 3 PM because it is very unlikely you will be able to check into your room prior to 3 PM. Overall the hotel was excellent and there is certainly a lot to do in the area.  
<Date>Jul 12, 2005

<Author>lass=
<Content>What a lovely place My husband and I arrived feeling somewhat jaded from Brisbane and had to queue for quite some time to check in to the hotel. We spent 3 nights in the HHV from 11 to 14 June 2005 and stayed in the Tapa Tower. Our room was very good indeed, spotless and comfortable. It was also very quiet and no sign of screaming children. The gardens were absolutely lovely and we were just happy to be able to relax there before moving on to our next destination in the US. Yes, there are expensive boutiques and restaurants but there are other reasonable places too. We thought the runner holding a flaming torch and lighting the streetlights very effective - we admired his stamina! All in all, we had a very relaxing time and would quite definitely return to the HHV and specifically the Tapa Tower.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Wonderful view For our first time in Hawaii, we think that this was a good place to stay. It truly is a beautiful village, with lots of shops, restaurants of all prices, and a magnificient view of Diamond Head and the beach. The grounds are the best part of the entire property. The rooms were standard and comfortable, ok but not squeaky clean. If you are looking for a quiet get-a-away, this would not be the place to choose. Every area was packed and there were lines to get in pools, restaurants, and elevators. Because we got a great deal (Priceline), we feel like this was a good place to stay. P.S. (Be warned--- they charge for the little coffee packets and tea bags!)

<Author>srizzuto
<Content>Great resort in paradise! Stayed here for 9 nights, including July 4th, and had a fantastic stay. The fireworks show was perhaps the best we'd ever seen, and we viewed it from the comfort of our room! Our package deal included a 'garden view' room but upon arrival, we had been magically upgraded to an ocean view room. It was in the Kalia tower, which is kind of new. It is the farthest one back from the beach, but it still had a great view of the water. It was a comfortable room and included a little refrigerator (in addition to a mini bar) so all the drinks I bought at ABC had a cool home. The grounds are beautiful to see, as there are planters, flower beds, koi ponds, penguins, parrots, and plenty flora and fauna that are entertaining. There are lots of stores, though most are jewelry and touristy-souvenir types. There are several restaurants, and none is particularly budget-friendly, but all we tried were tasty. One bad experience was at the Golden Dragon. We have been to the one at the Vegas Hilton and it was a great experience, but this one, with one bad waiter, ruined the meal. He had to argue with my husband about how and what he wanted to order and rushed us because the kitchen was closing. We got the manager and a new waiter, then all was well. Having shuttle pickup outside the Tapa tower was very convenient. We had a car and used the parking garage too, but traffic can be terrible at times and we didn't know where we were going so shuttles to the luau and dinner cruise were welcome.We also took a shuttle to Hilo Hattie, which is an awesome store for Hawaiian clothing and gifts, but the Hilton was the first stop so we got to go all through town to pick up other people. It made me appreciate the Hilton, because once you get into 'hotel row' it is so crowded with walking tourists (who don't know what the red hand-don't walk sign means) it is very hard to drive through. The Hilton is more isolated, although there are plenty things in walking distance too. Cabs are handy to get you to the crowded places without having to fight for parking. Many of the cabs are Town Cars, which are very nice! The giant Ala Moana mall is pretty close too, and it is pretty easy to get a shuttle to or from there. There is a huge food court, and lots of high-end stores. The Super Pool was not as cool in person as in pictures, and always had a crowd, but was pretty and well-serviced. We very much enjoyed our stay here and definitely would choose it again and recommend it.  
<Date>Jul 8, 2005

<Author>nipper23
<Content>Would not return I really don't understand why people love this place. We just spend 6 nights there using our Hilton Honors points and would not return. There were some good things and I'll list those first. I asked for a view when checking in and we had a beautiful view of the water and Honolulu. We were in the Tapa Tower on the 32nd floor. The room itself was nice and clean. The food choices were many and there were some reasonable prices. The Round Table pizza and CJ's Deli were pretty inexpensive (at least for Hawaii). You're within walking distance of many shops and restaurants on the property and in Waikiki. My husband is in a wheelchair and everything was very accessible for him.Now for the bad: Our bathroom was horrendus. It smelled like mold/mildew and the fixtures were out dated. The closet for the refrigerator and pantry was less than clean. We had horrible housekeeping service. Our maid insisted on leaving only 2 towels every day even though there were 3 of us in the room and we had to request additional towels constantly. We needed more cream and sugar packets for our one free pot of coffee each day and she said she could not leave them, that we had to request them through the mini-bar. Our room was not cleaned until after 3 each day even though we were out of the room by 9:00 every morning. We kept having maintenance workers knocking on our door, once to change all the light bulbs, once to check the locks and once to check the minibar. They said they were doing it all thru the hotel. But I would think they could wait until a slow period or do it when the rooms are empty. The pools are extremely small and you have to line up in the morning to get a chair. Waikiki is nice and we are glad we went there once, but probably won't return. It is a major city, after all and not as slow-paced and friendly as the other islands. We also spent 6 nights on the Big Island using our HH points at the Waikola Village Hilton and we much preferred that Hilton.  
<Date>Jul 7, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Loved the Hilton Our group of 8 ladies stayed in the Rainbow Tower of the Hilton Hawaiian Village from June 23 to June 29, 2005. We had 2 rooms, one on the 9th floor and the other on the 12th floor. It was the first trip for 5 of us and the 2nd for 3. Both rooms had terrific views and wre very nice and clean. They were a little small, but really, how much time do you spend in the room? The Lanai was great, we went out every am and pm to see the night view. I was very pleased with the service, the food was good, I would highly recommend the Round Table Pizza and the New York Deli if you are on a budget, the prices were not bad, we ate there several times, at night we went off the grounds, Dukes was great, as was Cheesburger of Wakkaki. It is just down the road. We didn't even try the higher price eating establishments on the grounds. The beach was very nice, the pool was good, but get out early to get a chair, because it is like a stampede at 8:30. We planned our trip last October through a nice travel agent Nick Monroe through The Vistor Center. He set up our flights with Delta, the hotel accomodations and transfers. He was great. He gave me alot of good tips. I would recommend him highly!! Oh, we took 2 tours, the trip to Pearl Harbour and then on around the Island, Dole Plantation, Macadamia Nut farm, several lookouts, it was great and the next day a Nature Island Tour, saw a waterfall, several points of interest. It was good, not fabulous but worthwhile, had a great guide, he was a Hawaiian studies student, so was very well informed. We also went to the Paradise Cove Luau. It was not that great, but I hear most of them are not really fabulous. The meal was awful. Well, that is about all I have to say, I would highly recommend the Hilton Hawaiian Village. It is the best for your buck, in my opinion. Gor for it!

<Author>jlea
<Content>Absolutely beautiful Went to Hawaii in May 2005 for a vacation with my boyfriend and return engaged! We stayed at various bbs and then treated ourselves at the end of the trip to 3 nights at the Hilton Hawaiian Village in Waikiki. What an amazing resort- it is truly a mini village with several stores, restaurants, a fabulous Ice Cream store (highly recommended), it's own mini-aquarium (swans, fish, penguins and other native birds) and most importantly- the beach! The hotel is at the end of the main strip so it is much quieter than can be at some of the other hotels. The staff is very friendly and attentive. The rooms are great. We stayed in the Tapa Tower on the 16th floor which gave us a partial ocean view. The room was quite spacious for the price. Mai Tais are pretty good at the Tropics Bar by the beach entrance. Lots of tour buses come to the hotel to pick up guests who have booked seats for things such as Luaus (Germaines or Paradise Cove) and other tours. This is a nice convenience rather than having to walk somewhere else to pick up the bus. Also there are fireworks by the beac every Friday night at 8pm that the Hilton provides. We watched from an amazing hotel called Sorrentos which is at the top of the Iliakai hotel which neighbors the Hilton. This restaurant is excellent- with great views of the beach and ocean, great service and great food. Pricing is in the $20s for main entrees so it definitely a good spot for a nice evening out. The Hilton is a wonderful place to stay if you want to treat yourself to a nice hotel in Waikiki. Can't wait to go back!  
<Date>Jun 27, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Nice Family Vacation We just returned from a 10 day vacation to the island of Oahu and Hawaii. They couldn't be more different! Oahu is all hustle and bustle, while Hawaii is definately more laid back. This was our 3 kids' (ages 16, 15  9) first time to the islands, so we wanted to be sure that they saw all the important sites on Oahu. We stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village (HHV)- plenty of action. Be sure to sign up for the Hilton Awards program as they will upgrade you if they have the rooms. We were upgraded to an oceanview room at the Rainbow Tower which is the tower closest to the beach. The hotel was very nice, lots to do and great free entertainment during the evenings. Plus, the shopping lasts until 10 or 11 pm. The ABC Store is great for water, snacks and those fantastic chocolate covered macadamia nuts. And their prices are great. The HHV's grounds are gorgeous! But like others before me have said...you do pay for everything. Only the beach towels were no charge. You do pay for parking ($13 a day), umbrellas and lounge chairs. Since our kids were always in the water, we opted for the beach towels. The Friday night Prince's show was great. It costs $12 per adult (it does include one drink - great virgin pina coladas) to sit poolside, but it was worth it! The entertainment included hula dancing, fire eating and plenty of music. Plus, my 9 year old was able to be in the Keiki parade. Also, there are several gratis activities for guests - my daughters took hula lessons and there were several others that they could have taken (lei making, water aerobics, garden tours etc.) had we not be sight seeing. For a great breakfast, eat at the Wailani Coffee House across from the Hilton. Great prices, very good coffee, excellent Portuguese French toast and the nicest waitresses. All the Hilton restaurants are a little pricey. We did eat at the Golden Dragon which had fantastic service, pretty good food, but dinner for 5 cost about $115 without drinks. They even charge for steamed rice. As for sightseeing, we saw Pearl Harbor (get there early, as we had to wait 2 1/2 hrs for the boat ride over and we went at 10:45 am), the Punchbowl National Cemetary, the Dole Pineapple Plantation, Huanama Bay for snorkling (take your own gear), hiked Diamond Head, did the North Shore drive - eat at Ted's Bakery for the BEST burgers and homemade fries - all for $4! Also visited U of Hawaii (not the exotic local that my 16 was expecting! - cross that off our list) and ate fantastic malasadas at Leonards. We also had beach time. Lots to do in Oahu. We used the next island of Hawaii just to unwind and relax. We definately enjoyed our time. If we go back again with our kids, we'll just go to the big island, but for their first experience, Oahu can't be beat!  
<Date>Jun 26, 2005

<Author>TXOttis
<Content>Lots to see and do at the Hilton Just returned from 6 nights at HHV. Overall the hotel and staff were great. We had the opportunity to see rooms in three different towers (Kalia, Rainbow, and Ali'i Towers) and all rooms were very nice. My fianc茅e and I stayed in the Ali'i Tower and really enjoyed the gym, private pool, and complimentary hors d'oeuvres every afternoon. Staff at the Ali鈥檌 tower was very helpful and accommodating. The Rainbow Tower appeared to have the best views but rooms were a littler smaller. Kalia Tower was the newest tower and the carpet and furnishing were in excellent condition. Food on the hotel grounds is expensive, but not more than you would expect at any tourist location. More reasonably priced food is available off the grounds but is still higher than mainland prices for most restaurant chains. If you have the time, consider listening to the Hilton Grand Vacations Promotion offer. It is only about 1 1/2 hours long and you will receive $100.00 in gift certificates that can be used on property. Certificates are good at nice restaurants such as Bali By the Sea and Benihana. Dinner at the Bali was very nice but if you want a table with a nice view make reservations a few days in advance. We watched the fireworks and Kings Jubilee from our hotel room balcony and I honestly believe the view was better than around the pool plus and you save the money it costs to sit poolside. Super pool was large, but not enough chairs to accommodate everyone who wanted to use it. Pool opens at 8:30 am and there was usually a line to get in. Chairs fill up in about half an hour and people often reserve them with towels for use later in the day. The Ali'i tower has its own pool that we never had a problem getting a chair by. Beach is very nice, not overly crowded and lots of activities. Overall, hotel and staff was excellent. Hotel room was very clean. We had problems with our hot water but they were immediately addressed by maintenance. Maid service was always prompt with any requests. We would certainly consider staying there on our next trip.  
<Date>Jun 25, 2005

<Content>Amazing! Spectacular! We had our wedding weekend at the HHV. It was amazing. Crowds of people clapped as we walked through the hotel. Staff and Guests all wished us well. <Author>Zebras88
<Content>Great Hotel Just came back from 7 nights with 20 family members. The hotel is awesome with nice views and probably the best on beach hotel on Waikiki. I stayed in the Kalia Tower and was very nice. If get assigned to this tower ask to be placed on the executive floors (22-24). You get continental breakfast and snacks. This hotel is very expensive to eat at. Most people would go outside of the hotel. There is a breakfast cafe across the street Wailena Cafe very reasonable (Denny's) type of cafe. The only complaint I have with the hotel is that the staff aren't very helpful. But if I go back to Oahu I will have to stay there again. I checked out all the hotel's that suppose to have beach on Waikiki and can't compare to the Hilton Hawaiian Village.  
<Date>Jun 21, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great value The Hilton Hawaiian Village is a great resort style hotel with all ammenities on the hotel's property. I paid $209/night in June which is very reasonable compared to other comparable hotels. The property offers over 25 different food options, but they are expensive and you can do better walking down the street to some of the local restaurants. The gym is $15/day and doesn't offer anything more than your typical hotel gym. The hotel staff are very hospitable and cater to the tourists. The Hilton Hawaiian Village is definately a treat!  
<Date>Jun 19, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>HHV is fantastic for Waikiki Just back from family vacation to HHV. This site helped me make my choice so I'll share to benefit others. Went for 10 days with 2 small kids(2,4). Have stayed in Maui Wailea area x 3. Was apprehensive about Waikiki being a city on a beach but HHV gave me that Hawaiian experience I was hoping for. Different but comparable to Wailea.Stayed in Alii tower. Upgraded to partial ocean from garden view. Room was upscale with plasma tv. This tower costs more but with extra amenities as others have said. In particular... private pool(but often crowded with business types and not as family friendly as rest of resort)...evening appetizers(quite extensive and all you can eat)...outstanding maid service. To correct an earlier review, you can get a crib (pack and play) at the Ali'i tower. Best part was its central on-beach location.The resort is huge, meaning you never have to leave it. It's that nice. We stayed for 10 days and only left it for 1 afternoon. Tons to do.The beach is the best on Waikiki. Snorkel right from beach and see same fish as when you dive or go on Atlantis sub. Great surfing also(locals use it). Very wide beach with calm waters, great for kids and swimmers. The pools are nice but not fantastic. The grounds are fantastic. The nightly hoola shows are nice (fantastic if you're a little girl). The food has great variety and is of resort quality and price.In sum, it's great, it's big. better for families and conventions than honeymooners (though we saw plenty)  
<Date>Jun 12, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Ali'i Tower is The Best ! My Husband and I have been to Hawaii several times and have even stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village but never in the Ali'i Tower. I must say that it was one of the best experiences we have ever had! We somehow got upgraded to a large corner room on the 8th floor, we took our 2 kids this time and were a little concerned that the room might be crowded. It was not crowded in the least. We had a roll away bed for our older son and our younger son slept on the pull-out sofa. The views were magnificent and the corner lanai balcony was perfect. The grounds are very luxurious and beautiful. The beach was awesome! We were there for 5 days and then left for Maui. Even thought we stayded in a large suite in Maui, it did not compare to our stay at the Ali'i Tower. We already have plans to return. Try the Ali'i Tower at the Hilton Hawaiiam Village, you will Love it.

<Author>Vickie
<Content>Our favorite hotel in Waikiki My husband and I stayed at the HHV for 5 nights in March 2005. We were a bit skeptical because of the size of the resort and the fact that we were staying in the midst of March break. However, we had nothing to worry about. Even though the resort was filled to capacity, it did not feel crowded. We stayed in an ocean view room in the Alii Tower. We were glad we booked this tower. We enjoyed the private pool and had no problem getting a beach chair by the pool. The resort's main pool looked to be quite crowded. We also liked the location of the resort. It's a nice distance from the main Waikiki area (10 minute walk). We also liked the village feel of the resort. We're already planning to return next year.

<Content>Great vacation resort! I've stayed here many times and it is one of my favorites in Waikiki. Pricey but you get what you pay for! The grounds are beautiful - it's a city within a city - you really never have to leave the resort! Some of the rooms need a little work, but overall they're nice. Tapa Tower and Kalia Tower are my favorites - I've also stayed in the Diamond Head tower and it seemed a little run down compared to the others. Lots of shops and restaurants to choose from and the staff is very nice and accomodating. Great for families with kids too!

<Author>CherrieHomes_123
<Content>I guess April is the time to go... Me  my husband just got back from 7 nights in the Rainbow Tower. We had an Ocean Front room on the 20th floor. Wow! What a view! If you're there on a Friday night, make sure you go back up to your room about 15 minutes before the Polynesian Show is over. The fireworks display for the finale are literally exploding in front of your face on the balcony. The absolute highlight of our stay. You'll never have a chance to be so close to fireworks!We bought our coffee and cream from a local market, not the ABC, and made it through the week for about $10.00 on coffee, as opposed to @ $30 if we made their in room stuff...we love our coffee.Yes, the beach umbrella/lounge set is $50.00 a day. We did this one day toward the end of our stay when we were too tired to drive. We thought it was great. You can stay on the beach all day without getting too sunburned, belly up to the bar for a MaiTai at will, and cuddle under your umbrella untill the occasional rain passes.The other days we spent driving to different beaches around the Island. Just beautiful. We must have come at the right time, because it was not crowded by any means.(April 23-May 1st.)Food on site was average at best and expensive. We tried to eat while we were out and about. Our absolute favorite meal was at Kobe Japanese Steak House, right behind the parking structure on Ala Moana. It's prepared benehana style at your table, which made us nervous, but the Rib Eye was probably the best we ever had!Overall, the grounds were gorgeous, the shops quaint and the people friendly. No trouble at check in. No lines. We asked for a late check out and they gave us 'till 5pm for free.It's a grand resort on a grand scale. A great place to have it all close at hand, while being able to get away from it all by day.If you're a smoker, this is a non-smoking facilty. You can smoke on your balcony and at the 2 designated bars. Other than that you have to go out to the beach. Please remember to put your butts in the trash. Always, anywhere you go!Aloha, and I hope this was of some help.  
<Date>May 10, 2005

<Author>WKONewYork
<Content>6Days in Paradise My Husband and I just came back from HHV after staying for 6days/5ngts. We check-in on 4/26/05 and were given a room in the Rainbow Tower on the 11th Floor. The room was decent size with a small (nothing special) bathroom. Our room overlooked the pool, Waikiki Beach and Diamond Head. We enjoyed watching the nightly entertainment at the pool from our balcony. We rented a room for our entire stay but found that it wasn't worth it. We had to pay $13 daily for self-parking which wasn't easy to access from the hotel and there is traffic, traffic and did I say traffic everywhere. It took us 1 hour one night to find parking near the International Market. We learned our lesson and walked 20 minutes the next day. They were having a festival called Spam Jam that Saturday evening on that Strip (outside the Royal Hawaiian) where there was music and food stands. We didn't get to go on any tours since our trip was too short. We did eat buffet breakfast every morning at the Rainbow Lanai. The selection is eggs made to order or already made, bacon, sausage, corn beef hash, hash pototoes, miso salmon, macadamia nut pancakes, salad bar, breads, and fruits. The food was good but how much can u eat in the morning. The pool opened at 8:30 every morning which is late considering we had breakfast at 6:30. You do need to be there early for get a chair since some people reserve the chairs and then go eat breakfast which I thought was rude. There is not enough of pool chairs to accomodate all the people that stay in the 5 towers that Hilton has. Be prepare to pay $53 for renting 2 beach chairs and 1 umbrella daily, which was upsetting. We went to the ABC Stores and bought the beach mats for $2 each. The Ala Moana Shopping Mall is where u can find many designer stores (Chanel, Prada, Dior, Hermes, and LV. There are 3 floors of shops and also a big food court which we ate at many times. The Waikele Outlet is about 45 minutes away with traffic which you'll find Guess, Calvin Klein, Barneys New York, Tommy, Saks, and Banana Republic. There was so much more we wanted to do here but was out of time. We vow that we will be back if not this year then next year.  
<Date>May 9, 2005
<Rating>4	3	3	-1	4	-1	4	-1	
<Aspects>

<Author>atxtraveller
<Content>Paradise on earth! Check-in was easy. I was upgraded at no extra cost to the best tower in the resort, the Ail'i. The room was wonderful and had all the amenities, including free coffees, teas and spring water, refreshed daily. I guarantee you will never sleep in a more comfy bed. 5 pillows and the sheet WAS a pillow. The private terrace for the tower guests had a hot tub, pool, bar and complimentary hor' dourves at 5. My lanai or patio had a view of the beach (the legendary Waikiki beach that is) and a pretty park full of palm trees. They have some kind of Hawaiian activity at the super pool almost everynight, like hula dancers, but watch for the fireworks show on Friday night! The only thing I disliked were all the small kids, try not to step on them. The room service is prompt, but the food was terrible. It's a wonderful village of great restaurants and shops to appeal to any taste, so who needs room service food anyway. Maid service was fine, cleaned and refreshed everything.The Amex tour desk clerks were friendly and very helpful. I took a nice tour of the island. The mini bus stopped at other hotels to pick up passengers and that's when I realized I picked one of the best places to stay. I saw almost EVERYTHING worth taking a picture of on the tour. I got off the little bus and passed a couple of hundred people waiting in line, no kidding, to take a mega bus on a 45 minute trip to an over rated Luau. Also went on a cool little submarine ride, which has a shuttle boat take you zipping off the private dock right there at the resort. You end up getting a free cruise to Diamond Head in the process of meeting the sub. Great stay, great resort!  
<Date>May 5, 2005

<Author>TravelCubed_7
<Content>Splendid Stay Although it's been now over two years since I stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village in Honolulu, I think I can safely comment as to its general features and atmosphere.The location is a little off the beaten path, on the edge of Waikiki. This has pluses and minuses. It's about a 10-minute walk to the action of Waikiki proper. However, the location is less busy and quieter. I liked the respite this location provided while still affording the opportunity to plunge into Waikiki's nightlife on foot whenever I wanted.The hotel doesn't hurt for activities, anyway. There are plenty of shops, restaurants, and beach activities at the HHV. At dusk, a Hawaiian hula show and lighting of torches takes place. HHV is comprised of several towers, some being more opulent and costly to stay in than others. I stayed in a less opulent tower, the Rainbow, but I had a great view of Diamond Head, the beach, and the main courtyard and pool. My tower's rooms were nice and clean, albeit nothing special.Service was friendly throughout the stay. Food was great, although not top-of-the-line. Food prices were on par with what I saw elsewhere in the area.I heartily recommend the Hilton Hawaiian Village and would return there in a heartbeat.  
<Date>Apr 30, 2005

<Author>ruggedscot
<Content>Honeymoon at the HHV Well had a few days at the Luxor in Vegas before coming here and have to say that this hotel is GREAT !The room that we had was good although the view of the beach involved having to lean out and look right the view of the pool area below was nice. The room was good - kept tidy and had no complaints except one - other guests had the habit of banging the room doors. This was a major problem as it was disturbing - other than that the resort was great. Service was without fault.Tips it is an expensive hotel to stay at if you eat on site $45 for two people to have breakfast is a huge difference to what we had in Vegas, so found that there was a good 24hr cafe across the road from the hotel that served great fare and then if you went west or east of the hotel you would find plenty of other eateries.Would I recommend this hotel to others - yes I would as it is really well laid out and the attention to detail is there. The gardens well kept and lots of wild life around the complex.Really enjoyed the atmosphere and the people were very efficient and friendly.Gavin

<Author>Ozzync
<Content>Quite enjoyable My wife and I spent three nights at the Hawaiian Hilton. Our check in was fast and easy. We stayed on the 29th floor (2903) of the Rainbow Tower. The views from our balcony were fantastic The bed was the most comfortable one I have ever slept in.. We found the grounds to be well maintained and the shops to be quite enjoyable. The pool was nice but quite overcrowded. At about 3:00 the pool started to empty out. Our first night we ate at Tropics. It was fine for sandwiches. Night#2 we ate at the Golden Dragon. This place has ruined me forever. I can no longer eat local Chinese food. Their food was fantastic and the views were great.. On top of that the service was impeccable. Day #3 we ate at Bali by the Sea. It was just as good as the Golden Dragon. The service was even better at Bali.All in all I would give the Hilton high marks all the way across. On a scale of 1 to10. 1 being the Swamp Fox Inn in Columbia, SC and 10 being The Greenbrier in White Sulfur Springs WV, I would give the Hilton a 9.Mark

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Very nice Very brief review. Stayed at the Hilton for 7 nights, arriving late on April 16th. Checked in the Kalia Towers without any problems. Our Garden View room was perfect. My 2 kids had a problem with the sofa so I called room service requesting 2 roll-aways. They arrived in 10 minutes. Problem solved.Only used the pool for 2 of the 7 days. I read the boards and was aware of the high food prices, so that was the only meal on the grounds. Buy your snacks and water at the ABC store.Overall a very nice stay at the Hilton. Will probably return again next year.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Perfect for families We stayed eight nights at the Ali'i Tower and were very pleased. I have been to Hawaii before and would recommend seeing another island (Maui is wonderful) but since we had our 9-year-old twins with us, we decided to spend our entire trip on Oahu. The hotel property is lovely--and I'm very fussy. The rooms in the Ali'i Tower are very comfortable and worth the extra cost in order to avoid extra charges for coffee, etc. The separate check in desk is great too. The lines at the desk in the motor lobby are ALWAYS long. As soon as you arrive, have the parking valet point you in the direction of the Ali'i Tower. Hint: Request a corner room if possible. They have two balconies--one facing the ocean, one facing Diamond Head. Gorgeous. The beds are very comfortable, but if you need two, they're only full size. (My husband is 6'3 and he was a bit annoyed.)We had looked forward to the Super Pool from the photos on the website--but it's not as large as it looks. We spent all our pool time at the Ali'i pool which was never crowded.We ate our first breakfast at the Rainbow Lanai--over $50 and the kids were free! It's worth the 5-minute walk to Wailana, a little restaurant just outside of the property. Very reasonable and the food was good--similar to a Denny's.We did eat at Bali by the Sea one night and both the service and food were excellent. Make reservations--it's popular. In fact, we were surprised to be seated two tables from a very well-known television personality. All in all, we really enjoyed the property. Be sure to sign up as a Hilton Honors member before you go. Your points add up fast since you'll spend a fortune and you can double dip and get additional frequent flyer miles. Also, if your flight leaves later in the day (as ours did) you can get a late check out (as late as 5 p.m. if you're a HH member.) Keep in mind, this is only if the property is not booked solid. If it is, they will only extend your check out by one hour--believe me, I begged. However, you may request the use of a hospitality suite--they'll allow you 20 minutes for each member of your party. You may only sign up for this on the day you're checking out. DO IT FIRST THING IN THE A.M. They get booked very quickly.  
<Date>Apr 27, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>nice but sorta a rip off too The room wasn't exactly what we expected location wise...it was about two block from the beach...as the crow flies.....the room itself was comfortable, nicely appointed etc.....But the really frustrating thing is the way this hotel nickel dimes you to death.....you want hi-speed interent......oh sure, about 12 dollars a day---you want a wi-fi connection (wireless available in certain locations) a password available about 12 bucks per day-----We spent 8 days in the same room, and we could only get 10 little bags of coffee for our coffee maker---I had to cry to get those.....instead of the 3 per day, if you checked in lets say everyday into a new room...we got a total of the 10 personal size bags of coffee...then the hotel had the nerve to charge on my card---$19.00 because they said I exceeded my coffee allotment.....(these are the little coffee servings for the 4 cup machines)...This stuff was petty and annoying.....and like other people have said...the food available either thru room service or restaurants on the grounds was very expensive.......like a bagel for $3.50 at a snack bar etc...you want to do pay per view?...rent a movie....try $12.00 for a movie...... Well I found this stuff so aggraving it pretty well made me know where I wouldn't stay next time......not the Hilton Village...

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>A brief but very nice stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village Our family (Mom, Dad, Son 11, Daughter 4) stayed for 2 nights at the Hilton Hawaiian Village in Honolulu on Waikiki after a five night stay in Kona on the Big Island. I booked through Expedia and paid $209 per night for a garden view room. When we got there we were upgraded to a garden view room in the Alii tower which is the concierge tower. (Thanks Hilton!) The Alii tower has a pool and deck area that is exclusively for the use of the guests in this tower, with a continental breakfast and other fare available during the day. I also spoke with the Alii tower concierge a few times and they were extremely helpful. If I were to stay at this property again I would definitely pay to upgrade to this tower. The only meal we took at the HHV was the breakfast buffet at the Rainbow Lanai. We had to wait about thirty minutes to get in. It was not the most exciting buffet and the price was a little steep, as all food on the island was. The HHV was a nice change of pace from the very low-key and remote feeling of the resort we stayed at in Kona. Waikiki beach is really fantastic and the kids really enjoyed it. I would definitely stay there again!  
<Date>Apr 26, 2005

<Author>boyerbuckets
<Content>OK but does not compare to the real Hawaii I have stayed here three times. First time was personal; next two for business where others chose the hotel. Impartial staff. Crowded grounds. Overly crowded pool and beach. Our Deluxe Ocean View room in the Rainbow Tower had a view of a building and a part of the lagood. Turns out you need an Ocean Front view to actually see the ocean. True, we could see the ocean if we stood on our lanai and leaned out to look around the building. We have visited Hawaii over 15 times and stayed at over 20 properties (we LOVE Hawaii). Waikiki just isn't our thing compared to the secluded beaches, spacious gounds, uncrowded resorts, and truly friendly Aloha spirit we have experienced everywhere else in Hawaii. I will stay at this hotel again in August because of a convention there and I look forward to it. But, we would never stay at this hotel again for a personal trip. The staff attitude would fit that found in typical Hiltons in big cities. The HHV is good but not the paradise I think of when I think Hawaii. If you have not yet been to Hawaii, don't stay here! If you want to see Pearl Harbor, the North Shore, and get a look at Waikiki Beach spend a couple of days somewhere on the Beach. But, if you want to experience paradise, go to a different island or at least stay on the North shore.  
<Date>Apr 25, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Good for Waikiki This is the third time we have stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village in the last 6 years. We have now stayed twice in the Diamond Tower and once in the Hilton Grand Vacations Club tower (whatever that's called!). We stayed for 7 nights this visit (April 2005).It was by far the most crowded stay we have had there. There were several conventions going on. It's true that you actually stand in line at 8:15am in the morning at the pool until they undo the ropes and let you go get your lounge chair. It sounds silly, but if you want a chair for the day, that's what you have to do. We never had to do that during our previous trips. We usually went to dinner early so we could get in and out quickly with our 2 1/2 year old. We ate at the Rainbow Lanai - great buffet - and had several lunches at Tropix - ok food, high prices, but VERY convienient. We like to walk down the beach to the Shorebird for breakfast and dinner (in another beachfront hotel). Way better prices for the type of same food.We decided to go back to this Hilton because I had Hilton Hhonors points to pay for our stay. We always enjoy Hawaii, but I can't say Oahu is our favorite island. Maui seems much cleaner, prettier, and laid back. However, for Waikiki, it is the best resort we have seen. We've walked through many of the other beachfront hotels, and nothing compares. The grounds are so large and nice, it's fun just to walk around the place in the evening. Hilton is not in the heart of Waikiki, but is definitely in walking distance of all the shopping and restaurants of Waikiki. The evening entertainment at the Hawaiian Village is great and we were out sitting on the beach with our 2 1/2 year-old every night watching fireworks, listening to music at Tropix, or watching a show by the pool.The pool doesn't have a great area for toddlers which is disappointing, but they have a kids pool that is good for 5 yrs and up. Our son had to play on the steps into the pool if he wanted to stand in the water. Don't get me wrong, we still had tons of fun. I was an early riser, so we had chairs at the pool every day. We had WONDERFULLY warm weather (85 degrees with a nice breeze), so we needed the pool.The rooms are absolutely fine, but nothing special. The beds are extra comfy!! The Hilton Grand Vacation Club rooms are much better, but those rooms are really like suites and you get a kitchen and living room as well.We will go back to Hawaii late next year I'm sure, but I think it will be a long time before we go back to Oahu. Maui and the Big Island are less commercial and we like that. If you haven't been to Oahu before, it's worth the visit, and the Hawaiian Village is a great place to stay. The facility is great, but crowded. Prices are high for services (parking, spa, rentals, etc.) and anything else you want to buy, but you can easily walk somewhere off the grounds for the same things. Aloha!  
<Date>Apr 25, 2005

<Author>thejumpoff
<Content>Hilton Hawaiian Playground!!! I stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village during the first week of April for five days and found it to be quite disappointing. Kids were everywhere, from the time I entered the grounds until the time I exited in my rental car! Did I mention the overly crowded kid-populated pool?!???? I felt as if I was at Disney World!!! Okay...enough of the kids-talk. Let's get to the hotel itself. The grounds are absolutely beautiful with its tropical foliage, exotic birds and koi ponds. However, the rooms are just okay. The beds are nice with cozy and comfortable pillows but the room is extremely small. I stayed in an oceanfront room in the Rainbow tower on the 29th floor. The view was nice as I awoke each morning to blue and aqua waters but I would recommend a lower floor. When I requested a lower floor, the concierge informed me that no rooms were available except for those in the Ali'l Tower for $600!!! I declined being that I was already paying $300 for the one I had already requested. Speaking of the room...on the second night, I heard a rattling noise outside my door as if someone was trying to break in but I figured that was impossible and perhaps, someone was fiddling with the lock of someone's room next door. Boy, was I wrong!!! About three hours later while I was asleep, two men from security burst into my room!!! They had been trying to repair a lock but were at the wrong door--mine!!! They apologized and the next morning, sent a care basket to the room with fresh pineapple, coffee and water. It was a nice gesture but imagine if I had been in the room doing other things!!! Aside from that catastrophe, the food was nothing spectacular. I ate at Bali by the Sea which was your typical glitzed-up, showpiece seafood. DO NOT order room service. It is expensive and everything tastes nuked!!! I ate at the breakfast buffet three times but I would hardly call it a buffet. It only featured a few meats, pancakes, french toast, potatoes, eggs and a small portion of fruits and pastries. It was definitely nothing like the Vegas-style buffets I'm accustomed to. A highlight of the hotel is that it has representatives on sight ready to book your travel exursions. I found this to be very convenient. While there, I experienced the Atlantis Submarine (ok but nothing to brag about), Pearl Harbor (go early in the morning to beat the crowds), an Atlantis dinner cruise (pretty good, great entertainment), Dole Pineapple Farm (educational), the Honolulu Zoo (very large with an array of animals), the Honolulu Aquarium (where's the rest of it?) and the best exursion of all..a day trip to Maui. It was definitely the highlight of my trip. It costs $300 but it was worth it as I got to visit a rainforest, dormant volcano and the lovely oceanfront of Maui. If it hadn't been for the trip to Maui my vacation would have been a complete waste of $5000!!! Actually, my friend and I had attempted to leave Honolulu after only three days and head to Vegas but after contacting Delta, the reservationist informed me that our only escape would have been to travel to Salt Lake City, remain there in a layover for three hours and then arrive in Vegas the following morning. We opted out and went to Maui on the fourth day instead. I have no desire to go back to Honolulu anytime in the near future. Hence, if a traveler is seeking blue waters for a vacation spot, head for commercialized South Beach which is a lot like Honolulu but far less expensive!!! If you want a more serene, calmer atmosphere, go to Maui, trust me!!!  
<Date>Apr 22, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>great time My family and i stayed in the ali tower in march/05. I have always used this service when planning trips and found it very helpful so decided to write in. The hilton was just as most people described it - very large- very expensive - not good restaurants but with those things in mind we chose the hilton and thoroughly enjoyed it. Our room was very clean and quiet and we enjoyed the ali tower pool. The small gym by the pool was adequate although our daughter used the larger gym (cost of $14.00) at another tower and liked it alot better. We ate breakfast at the 24 hour restaurant across the street - i forget the name but you can't miss it .We tried to have a light breakfast at the hilton one morning but after waiting 30 minutes and still not waited on we left. We did get take out pizza one night as our daughter was not well and it was good. We enjoyed all the shops and the penguins and found it to be a nice break away from the even busier wakiki area. We went to pearl harbour one day and that was well worth the trip our 16 year old even enjoyed it. My husband took the city bus around the island for $2.00 one day while we went the mall and although he did not get out anywhere he said it was worth the trip. We went to the paradise cove and luau and were extremely disappointed. We ran into a traffic jam on the way and our bus was over an hour late which of course was unavoidable so we missed seeing most of the displays however it was so jammed packed you really couldn't do much anyway. We basically arrived stood in line for about 45 minutes to get a drink by then it was almost time to eat. The food was terrible and we are not fussy eaters the show was ok - at over $100.00 per ticket i guess i expected something more. We thought the hilton was well worth the price and would go again.  
<Date>Apr 22, 2005

<Author>tifltif
<Content>Loved the Hilton Hawaii Village We had just returned from a week at the Hilton Hawaii Village. The hotel is beautiful and very large. We stayed in the corner room in the Rainbow Tower. The room is small but the bed is very comfortable. The view is spectacular with 2 lanai in each corner.(this make up for the small room size) This is a very good place to watch the firework on Saturday night. Sitting on the lanai, sipping your drink and watch the firework. Aaaahhhh heavenly. This tower is in very good location. It is right next to the beach. The beach is beautiful and calm so it is good for the kids. However, it have alot of little rocks in the water so our feets hurt and it is a bit uncomfortable. I found the service was good. The staffs are friendly and informative. Everything is expensive in this hotel. But then again, I guess it is expensive in any hotel. Overall I would stay at this hotel again. Next time I will ask for an upgrade in the Ali'i Tower. I asked for an upgrade this time but the front desk person assured me that the room I have reserved have the best view which was I asked for. And she was right.

<Author>Satisfaction7
<Content>Hilton Hawaiian Village way too busy Okay, if you are trying to find a place to stay in Hawaii, and you have never been there, stop and think about what you want in a vacation.Do you want a nice, quiet, secluded beach, plenty of nature walks, and some solitude? Then don't go here! Sleeping on Waikiki is like sleeping in Grand Central Station in NYC.If you stay at this hotel, you will find that doors slam all through out the wee hours of the morning. Housekeepers try to get you out of your room at 7 AM. It's like living in a mall. The nicest feature is the beach, but nobody goes there. Everybody is in the retail shops, buying stuff imported from China and being sold as Hawaiian.Food is way expensive. Step outside the hotel grounds and you'll pay half for a better meal.Don't go here unless you have to.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>A Great Family Vacation We just came back from a great family vacation at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. We've stayed at many different hotels in Waikiki and I would have to say this was one was best suited for us, now that we have a two year old. She loved walking around the grounds looking at the koi and penguins and watching the Hawaiian dancing shows in the evening. Apparently, there is even a room where you can rent out toys, but we never did, as she was sufficiently entertained without them. The beach area also isn't as crowded as other hotel beaches and there are several pools to choose from. We stayed at the Ali'i Tower and requested a room on the second floor which is where the pool for Ali'i Tower guests is. Our friends and their two daughters were next door so it was very convenient for all the children to go back and forth from the pool to the rooms. If you are travelling with family or friends and you need several rooms, I recommend requesting the 2nd floor rooms which open up to the pool. In the morning you can all meet outside your rooms on the patio with your newspaper and coffee (complimentary in the Ali'i Tower) or have the complimentary appetizers every evening by the pool, just steps away. (The food wasn't fabulous but a nice service nonetheless.) You can even see the Friday night fireworks from just outside your room. We actually had to move to a different room for the last 3 days of our trip because another family had booked all of these pool-side rooms for a big family reunion. We did move to a room right above our old room which had a lovely ocean front view. The room was much brighter and if it weren't for the convenience of going back and forth to the pool with children, I would say I preferred this one over the pool level room.  As for our meals, we did go to several nice restaurants such as Alan Wong's but we had some great take out meals from the Rainbow Drive Inn and Liki Liki Drive Inn, a favourite amongst locals. We looked at several websites to read restaurant reviews and rented a car to get to them. Another restaurant I enjoyed was Hiroshi, a Japanese fusion restaurant at Restaurant Row. We also had a nice Sunday brunch at Sam Choy's. Last year, we had Sunday brunch at the Haleikulani Hotel which was one of the most beautiful brunches I've ever had, but it was booked up for this trip. As for food courts, the one at Ala Moana mall has to be one of the best I've ever seen. We also drove to Daiei, a supermarket close to the hotel.  We will definitely go back to the Hilton Hawaiian Village again for a family trip. Just a note to those who are travelling with babies - The Ali'i Tower doesn't have cribs (I don't know why they can't get one from the other towers, but I was told it was just their policy).  
<Date>Apr 21, 2005

<Author>Jerri_Blank
<Content>Not a true Aloha experience The Hawaiian Village is like a mini-city in Waikiki in Honolulu. It's exremely crowded. The grounds and beachfront are lovely, very well-kept. The room is fair, the bed is comfortable. I had a double in the Rainbow tower ocean view side. Had a slight ocean view to the left and a nice view of downtown and the mountains. It was ok but on the small side. The shower was weak.They charge for bottles of water. They charge for packets of in-room coffee. I have NEVER heard of any hotel charging $4 for in-room crappy brew-it-yourself coffee. That was just stupid. That plus the parking charge made me feel like I was being screwed.There was lots of animals on the property, ducks, koi fish, etc. Added to the scenery.This is a great place for families. Lots of kids, nice pools, very calm beaches. Lots of cute shops.Not a great place for young single people like me. With all the kids and massive crowds, I didn't feel like this was a true Hawai'ian experience. I have had a much more relaxing time at other properties on less crowded islands like Kawa'i or Maui. Oah'u (particularly Waikiki) is extremely touristy.Families should stay here, definitely. Individuals or couples looking for a romantic and private experience should look elsewhere - out of Waikiki.  
<Date>Apr 18, 2005

<Author>drumillar
<Content>Perfect Honeymoon Location We spent 8 nights of our honeymoon here from the 24th of March till the 01st of April. Idyllic is certainly Hawaii. Oahu Island was fantastic and Honolulu is a bussling city without being to overcrowded.The HHV is fantastic, we stayed in the rainbow tower, actually an upgrade as we were on honeymoon and although on the 04th floor we were delighted with the view and room. Bathroom was massive, we stored our large inflatable airbed in there every evening and my wife actually slept in there one night when I had a virus and sleeping next to me was like lying on a bed of lava.Even being ill for the last two days of our stay can dampen our enjoyment or memories of this place. Bed is fantastic, view stunning, gardens beautiful, wildlife varied and absorbing. We loved sitting in the Rainbow Lanai restaurant and eating our breakfast while watching fish swimming next to us.Yes the food is expensive, not. This a resort and on an island that has to import everything. Maybe the exchange rate is making us biased but everything was superb value. Except for one thing the Golden Dragon, good cheery service shame about the food. Expensive but tasteless. We ate across the road from at the Singha Thai restaurant, entertainment, superb food and for the quality very reasonable in our opinion.We're already planning our return, although some of the staff could do with cheering up a bit.Also we would like to say the Medical facility onsite was excellent when I became ill, they put myself at ease, (temp of 102.5), and made sure my wife and I had all the info we needed to get any medication, even phoning ahead to the Pharmacy to make sure my wife didn't have to run around and find it all herself.The Atlantis sub tour from in front of the hotel is well worth the money, but unfortunately the beach aint as good as I've experienced elsewhere, mainly due to a lot of rocks/coral just under the waters edge. Water shoes definately required. Also getting a seat by the pool is virtually impossible unless your a very early riser.Apart from that well worth the money, look forward to staying here again.  
<Date>Apr 12, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Paradise on the Beach We went to Hawaii for the first time during Easter spring break of 2005. The first impression is breath taking. The hotel is well maintained and the staff are very freandly and helpful. The rooms were very nice and the beds are very comfortable, with pillow top matt. Their is so much to do just at this hotel you would need a vacation just to cover it all. Stores galore, beautiful beach and lots of places to eat, although I suggest eating out do to the prices; unless it don't matter, the food is great. Fireworks Friday nights, Entertainment nightly by the Tapa tower and the Rainbow tower. The beach is right on the hotel property which is great if you like to spend time sunning and swimming, was a plus for our kids. The pools look nice and well kept although we never went in, why when you have the ocean at you convenience. We had a great time and are looking forward to our next visit.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great place to stay My wife and I recently spent 4 nights at the HHV - our first trip to Hawaii. Overall, this is a fantastic resort - It's exactly what you expect when you stay in Waikiki.First of all, for your first trip to Hawaii, Oahu is a great island - However, you need to know what you're getting in to. Honolulu/Waikiki is a CITY - No secluded beaches, no unobstructed views of nature, plenty of high-rises, plenty of people. Now, since you know that, you shouldn't be disappointed - However, the HHV is a RESORT - When you turn in from the city streets, you are essentially in a lush, tropical village at the beach. It really is beautiful with the palm trees, flowers, animals, etc. Definitely join Hilton Honors - We joined the week before and hadn't even stayed in a Hilton anytime recently, and they still upgraded our room. I think this was because we had booked a room through Expedia and they had given out all of their block of rooms by the time we got there at 10PM on a Saturday. Whatever the case, the room was great - Exactly what you'd expect (relatively new decor, nice furniture, etc.) We had a view of the water and the city/mountains. You can see either the water or the mountains from pretty much any room there, so you always feel like you're in Hawaii.The beach and the pools are exactly what you'd expect - Obviously, there are big crowds at each, but that is the same at every hotel in Waikiki (except the Hanelukani, but that is a pricey hotel geared toward older adults with no children, etc). While the beach is crowded, it's probably among the least crowded places on Waikiki per square foot (since the beach is so wide at the Hilton). For the price they charge for chairs, etc, you should just buy one at the ABC store in the village for just a few dollars more. The resort is definitely a family friendly environment, so if you don't want to see any kids, you are at the wrong place. However, I didn't see any large groups of older kids/teens unsupervised, so we really enjoyed seeing all the kids having such a good time with their families. If you are planning on bringing your own kids to Hawaii, this is a great option, not only because of the resort, but also because you can fly directly to Honolulu from many US mainland cities (making the overall travel time less).The city of Waikiki reminded me of any other touristy area of the US - Lots of high end shops and restaurants scattered among lots of markets and other cheap places. You can walk along the beach or along the street pretty much the entire 2 mile length of the city. If you want to hit the rest of Honolulu (Arizona memorial, etc), you should probably just rent a car because the taxis will run you $20 or $30 per trip each way.For restaurants, obviously the resort places are expensive - But let me tell you that everywhere in Hawaii is expensive. For instance, when we went to the suburbs of Honolulu to a local mall, we ate at a California Pizza Kitchen (typical mid-priced type place) and the individual pizzas were $12 to $18 and the soft drinks were $3 each. Once you accept the high prices in Hawaii, you just suck it up, pay it, go with the flow, and not worry about it. You didn't come here to save money, now did you? The resort restaurants are decent, but the best place we found is Duke's Canoe Club (obviously it's about as touristy as you can get). I figured that it would be average because of the fact that it's so famous and gets so much business. Not true. This place will fill you up - The food and drinks are very reasonably priced. Expect to pay about $5 a drink and between $17 and $30 per entree. The salad bar is free with entrees and could be a meal unto itself - Huge salads, rice, bread, etc. The atmosphere is exactly what you want - Loud, festive, Hawaiian. Call a day or two ahead for reservations (or earlier than that if you want to each between 6 and 8). Or you can just get a number and wait in line (at the bar, I recommend) - Usually about an hour or so. Don't miss it.Finally, I would highly recommend renting a car to see the island. The drive up to the North Shore is great - True Hawaiian, slow paced, laid back. You can see the surfers and there are some good low-priced restaurants in the small towns along the coast (Rent a convertible or a jeep. The weather doesn't get any better than this). Also, there are some really good restaurants that are more reasonably priced outside of Waikiki (Roy's is one, and there are many others). Diamond Head is a great thing to do, even for the out of shape crowd (myself included) with a great view. There is a great neighborhood at the base and east of DH with some amazing houses. If you want to snorkle, drive to Hanauamo bay, etc. They have a Hertz counter at the HHV and a Dollar rent a car 2 blocks away. Overally, this is a great resort - You know it's crowded, you know it's expensive, but it's what you probably came to Hawaii for - Warm weather, beaches, fun, etc. If you want quiet, solitude, etc, go to one of the other islands (and expect to pay even more). Dont' let a few dollars ruin a trip this good - Expect to spend about $75 to $100 a day for food and just enjoy it. The Hilton is a great place to get a true Waikiki experience.  
<Date>Apr 1, 2005

<Author>MickT81
<Content>Top choice among Waikiki Hotels We stayed here in March of 2005 just before Easter. I bought the room through Hotwire for about $225 dollars per night. We had a room in the Tapa Tower which was large and spacious - but we were on the side with a poor view.The hotel is absolutely huge and it has great facilities. The grounds are beautiful and well manicured and there is a lot to do right on the property. There are many restaurants (I'm not sure how many but I would estimate 15-20 places) and a lot of nice stores scattered all over the hotel property (including some top designer places). We walked around to some of the other nearby hotels on Waikiki and based on what we saw, we would gladly return to this hotel. The Hilton's grounds and landscaping are VERY attractive. There are some unique things here too - there are warm-weather-African-Penguins and Flamingos on display as well as sculptures and tropical birds throughout the property. Every night, there is a torch lighting ceremony where a costumed Hawaiian Procession blows conch shells and walks around the Hotel lighting torches along all the pathways. Some might complain it's a little too much like a theme park - but it's not juvenile and we enjoyed it.This hotel has the best stretch of Waikiki Beach - much larger beach front area than ANY of the other hotels. Beware, if you want to have a beach chair or umbrella, you'll have to rent it - even if you're staying at the hotel. This is standard procedure for all Waikiki Hotels we saw. The pools at the Hilton were beautiful too and had great waterfalls, etc.The rooms are nice - and every tower here is different. Our beds in the Tapa Tower were to die for. We slept like babies every night on thick pillow top mattresses with fluffy pillows and duvets. Hilton has done a great job at keeping this older hotel fresh and new looking.We ate at the property a few times and had good food - but there are also a ton of dining options outside of the hotel in the Waikiki area that we visited.You can probably find just about anything you're looking for here - a relaxing resort experience or a vibrant hot nightlife. I would hands-down recommend this hotel to anyone staying on Oahu and we would definitely return.  
<Date>Apr 1, 2005

<Author>AlohaHawaii
<Content>wonderful stay in paradise Just got back from 17 days in Hawaii- stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village- the first time on March 10th for 4 days, we were upgrade to the Alii tower- wonderful room- this tower has it's own pool which is very nice as the main pool is very crowded and hard to get a chair. The beach is very nice there- the hotel staff was very friendly and helpful. Food is very expensive- there is a restaurant right off the hotel grounds- the Wailua Coffe Shop and it was great especially for breakfast. When we returned to the hotel after staying on Maui, we were in the Kailua Tower- very nice also- We used the spa facilities and were very impressed. I would suggest you buy snacks, etc. at the ABC store. We were there during easter break and it was very crowded. I have a suggestion for the car rental- we used Alamo and were very happy with it- only thing- they have long long lines- we are Quick Silver Members with Alamo ( which is easy to enroll on the internet). There is a separate counter for Quick Silver and we saved at least a two hour wait!  
<Date>Mar 30, 2005
