<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Not if you want a quiet vacation / Death of 1000 charges... We stayed for a week at the Hilton (2 adjoining rooms ) over Spring break. While it was a better than average place, overall this is not the place to go if you want some RR or if you dislike getting nickeled and dimed (or worse).Check-in at 12:30AM found us pleading to get any room (we did join HHonors, very necessary to bypass the regular line at 12:30AM) despite guaranteed reservations. We were happy to take a room set to be renovated the next day, since the people in the regular line were being sent to other hotels. The next day we were put in the Tapas Tower in 2 regular view rooms. No free coffee, no free water, With over 3,000 rooms and a 1 year old outdated computer system, there is poor flexibility and any changes take a long time, hence the long check in lines. With over 3,000 rooms you cannot expect to find solitude at the Village. There are 2 smallish pools, costly restaurants and a bizillion shops to take even more of your vacation dollars. Morning coffee was $3.25, parking $13 (valet was $18 and slow, particularly on checkout Sundays). Late checkouts were not allowed but you could reserve 20 minutes per person booked in a room to freshen up if you had a late flight and left your bags with the bell captain for your last day at the beach.Restaurants: Wailana Coffee shop for breakfast, Hale Koa for lunch (walk in from the beach and eat at the poolside) and dinner anywhere on the strip .Two other comments: Buy Oahu Revealed, a very useful book, and do not rent the Chrysler 300 - limited visibility in this car ruins any sightseeing for most riders.  
<Date>Mar 29, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Horrible service, Very expensive, beautiful area We stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian village during low season (early december). When we first arrived we were in awe by the beauty of it all. Then the troubles began. I am a diamond level hilton honors member (it doesn't get higher than that). Upon check in, I was practically accused of having a fake certificate to stay there. The service overall at the hotel was horrible. Absolutely rude. The staff made you feel like they hated you being there and that you were bothering them when you asked them to do their job. No one can offer you directions. No one can recommend a restaurant. Everyone just wants to sell you something.The parking is $12 per day (no other choice) a buffet runs $35 per person for less than average food. The shops and restaurants in the village are ridiculously overpriced. Lunch specials starting at about $25 per person (and these don't include anything other than a basic entree, no sides, no drink, nothing) so you'll easily spend $40 per person for a meal. Be ready to pay $50 for a t-shirt... Overall I could have stomached the prices if the staff were half way decent. They were just too rude to even describe. How about this: We were eating breakfast outside at the beach front cafe, where pigeons and/or seagulls would come onto the table to eat our food. No big deal for an animal lover. Well I took a piece of my bagel and crumbled it on the floor so they would keep off my plate and eat from the floor. The floor sweeper then came and slammed a sign in front of my plate that said, Please don't feed the birds. because he was upset that he had to sweep the crumbs up. I mean, if I wanted to, I could have reported this man for assault! What kind of a person slams a sign onto your breakfast plate???It's all too bad, because the place is beautiful. Our room was gorgeous, clean, and had a spectacular view of beach and mountains. So beautiful that I probably would go back again if I got the room for free again. However, I would never pay the $350-$400 per night. Not for that kind of service.  
<Date>Mar 24, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great resort, though pricy We just returned from a weeks stay at the hilton hawaiian village. We thoroughly enjoyed our stay here.Pros- The grounds are well kept and look beautiful. They have penguins,flamingos and other animals to watch whilst there. Plenty of restaurants and shops. It really is its own village.We were stayed in the Tapa tower and were upgraded to a partial oceanview. (I think this is based on availabilty and the fact that we were hilton honor members). Huge room, very clean, great view of the mountains and city. Separate area to hang up or fold your clothing and included fridge and minibar. The beds are very very comfortable.They also have a big pool, larger then most other hotels and they had a smaller one by the Tapa tower, that was less crowded and easy to find a chair.Every night at the pool, they had hawaiian dancing and on Friday nights they have fireworks.Cons- restaurants are very expensive, it seems that they like to charge you for everything. If you take their towels to the beach, they charge you $10. The rental beach chairs and umbrellas are expensive. You are better off buying from the ABC Store.You have to get to the superpool early to get a chair, otherwise there are none. They need to have more chairs, or a bigger pool. Also the pool was freezing for most of the week as the weather was cool and very windy.Other than that, this is a very nice hotel. Plenty to do in the way of entertainment and shopping. You can arrange tours from the hotel and we were able to do late check-out.All in all, I would recommend this hotel, but I would not go during spring break, as it was packed. Plus there were conventions taking place that week and it was very packed. You would be better off going when it is less packed and you would actually be able to get a seat by the pool. Still a lot nicer then the other hotels in waikki and it is right on the beach.  
<Date>Mar 21, 2005

<Author>TravelerfromNJ2
<Content>Absolutely perfect My husband and I stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village March 5 - 12. I can't find one thing to complain about. The staff couldn't have been any friendlier or more helpful. Our room was beautiful and daily maid service was excellent. Prices are typical for any nice resort, in my opinion. This was our second trip to the Hilton Hawaiian Village and I would recommend it to anyone visiting Oahu. We've also visited Maui, Kauai, and the Big Island, which are different experiences from Oahu, but I don't think you can go too far wrong at this lovely resort.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Best Hotel Experience In My Life!!! My wife and I travel a lot on vacations and both agree that this hotel is the best hotel we have every been at. I must first admit that because we were there on my hilton honors points we got upgraded to one of their best suites (which was about 2,100 square feet). So obviously our room was spectacular. We had wonderful views and soooo much space. But besides the room the rest of the hotel was beautiful and huge. There are numerous pools to swim in case one gets crowded you can move to another one. The ocean front property is great because there is so much space you don't feel smothered by other people. The hotel also has a reef to swim over and see all kinds of fish in the water. We chose to not spend the extra money and go snorkeling with a pro and opted to just spend that time snorkeling for free behind the hotel. We loved it!!!! The restaurants were quite expensive but since this is a luxory hotel you have to expect that. My wife and I truly loved this hotel and would recommend it to anyone else interested in traveling to Hawaii. This is the hotel to stay at, trust me!!!  
<Date>Mar 18, 2005

<Author>MSkinner
<Content>Would definitely go back. We just got back Mar 17th from 8 nights in Honolulu. 3 of them were at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. We're a family of 2 adults and 2 daughters aged 10  7.Very simply, there's a reason they call it a 'village' - it's huge. But it doesn't seem overwhelming or anything. There are several towers. Ours was the Alii - apparently one of nicest, if not the best one they have. The tower had its own concierge, own pool  fitness room, etc. You could still use the other ones in the resort, but these offered a little more privacy.They upgraded us from a partial ocean view to a beautiful ocean view room without even asking. The rooms weren't huge, but very nice - one of the most comfortable hotel beds you'll sleep in; like a giant soft pillow. And separate vanity / shower / toilet areas, which helps when you've got 4 people trying to get ready for the day. Big, beautiful beach area. Not as packed as Waikiki beach, either. There's quite a variety of restaurants  places to get snacks, and you're still fairly close to 'outside' restaurants  stores, as well.If you go, make sure you have cash - and I'm talking paper cash, not credit or a bank card. There's only 1 ATM in the entire complex, and it was broken when we needed it. I had to walk a couple miles to the next nearest one. Almost everything can be charged to the room, but we still needed cash for some of the tours / excursions we took.Poolside service was quick, and you could get everything from a full meal to just drinks. A little pricey for some things ($6 for a beer, plus tip??) while others weren't bad ($7 for a personal sized pizza). But it's vacation. And the hotel room has a little fridge, so if you want, you can bring in some of your own refreshments.We couldn't do a late check out because the hotel was full, but they stored our bags for us  gave us a courtesy room for an hour to shower  get changed. It was a nice touch.If we went back to Honlulu, we'd definitely stay at the resort. But we'd probably try one of the other islands (like Maui) first, before returning to Honolulu.  
<Date>Mar 18, 2005

<Author>NewYorkCityJerry
<Content>Great experience if you choose carefully My wife and I came back recently from a 9-night stay at the HHV. We had been there 15 years ago for a convention but this time it was all pleasure. We had an oceanfront with a lanai in Rainbow Towers. It definitely is worth the extra money for an oceanfront, as even when you are not outside, you are in the middle of all of the action (do not confuse oceanfront with the less desirable oceanview). Unfortunately, we ran into a streak of cool, cloudy weather but we spent pleasant hours on the lanai. The beach is pebbly and has broken up coral debris (especially in the shallow water), so bring aqua-shoes. Plan your onsite expenditures strategically, as the HHV sometimes appears to be a huge tropical vacuum-cleaner intent on sucking up all of your dollars. Twenty-four dollars a day for a beach-chair and umbrella is outrageous (although this is operated by a non-hotel beach concession). Instead, get straw mats from the ABC store on the premises ($1 each or free with $10 in purchases) and lay them over with a beach towel. Towels are free from the hotel beach stand. The grounds are lovely to walk through. There is always something new that catches you by surprise, no matter how many times you wander through. Eating can be quite expensive. After a first day of overeating (and overspending) with 3 restaurant meals, and feeling quite stuffed, we returned to our normal at-home habit of a modest breakfast and lunch followed by one big restaurant meal of the day. We were able to stock up on breakfast items at ABC (juice, cold cereal, milk, coffee, paper bowls, etc.) and have relaxed breakfasts on the lanai. Stay away from the locked food 鈥渂ar鈥?in your room. $3.50 for a wimpy coffee refill packet (containing 10% Kona coffee) is really over the top. Instead, get a pack of filter papers and a pack of real 100% Kona coffee for use with your coffee machine. Lunches centered around take-out sandwiches or salads from ABC.If you don鈥檛 object to having early dinners, you can save money by making reservations for early-bird or sunset specials. Look carefully through the room literature and coupons to find these. Interestingly, the non-Hilton operated restaurants on-site tended to be far superior to the Hilton restaurants within the Rainbow Tower. Of the non-Hilton operated restaurants, Sergio鈥檚 was our clear favorite. Our two meals there were as good as any we have eaten in New York City or Tuscany. We also enjoyed Hatsuhana (a simple, straight-forward Japanese restaurant), Benihana (as much a fun performance as a good meal) and to somewhat less of a degree, Village Steak and Seafood. Regarding the Hilton restaurants within the Rainbow Tower, the Rainbow Lanai was pleasant but had rather ordinary food. The buffets were bountiful and of enormous variety but in the end it was largely steam-table food. Bali by the Sea (the most expensive of the restaurants) was a big disappointment. It started off on a wrong note after we had made a clear phone reservation for the 6-pm seating of their sunset dinner. When we ordered, we were told that this special dinner is restricted to the summertime, in spite of the clear up-to-date information to the contrary in our room. So we had the regularly priced dinners. As an example of the pricing, $12.50 for a glass of ordinary table wine was more than I have paid anywhere in the world (it was less than half of this at Sergio鈥檚). The surroundings and settings were beautiful, the wait staff and service were impeccable, and the food was beautifully presented; however, it was mediocre in taste. Their heralded 鈥渃hampagne鈥?dressing ceremoniously spooned over the salad at the table tasted like watered-down mayonnaise. My wife鈥檚 prawns were dry and overcooked; my duck breast was flavorful but with a fatty skin that had to be cut away and discarded. It lacked the skin crispness that one expects at these prices. The complementary chocolate dessert, however, was a lovely touch.Don鈥檛 miss the Friday evening poolside Hawaiian show. Get there early, have a pizza from Round Table Pizza Express for dinner and enjoy the show and fireworks. Most evenings we went to one of the lounges for a drink(s) and entertainment. This varied but the best by far was on Friday and Saturday nights at the Paradise lounge by a marvelous group called Olomana. Don鈥檛 miss it. Another pleasant group of musicans (together with dinner) was at 鈥淗ouse Without a Key鈥? about 15 minutes away in the Halekulani hotel.  
<Date>Mar 17, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>LA in the middle of the ocean If you enjoy going to the middle of the ocean for peace and relaxtion and do not mind spending it with 8,000 of your new friends this is the place for you. Forget bogey boarding. Waikiki and Honolulu in general are packed. Some of the worst traffic I have ever seen. If you want large crowds this is your place. If you want peace and quite go to Kauai.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Over comercialized, non-relaxing, bad service!! ,Chaos, is the order of the day at HHV. You'll notice it right away as you arrive at the front desk. Is this Disneland? There are many people rushing around, hotel staff to busy to help you. Theres a hotel desk with a crowd of people around and your told to wait in three defferent lines. One for early people, one for luggage, one for check in. You cant tell who is being helped and if they are ever gonna get to you.While waiting for our room my husband and I ate at the little resteraunt on the beach which is part of the hotel. The place was a zoo we had to sit at a dirty table and wait 20 minutes before the waitress came back to take our order. We shared nachos and ate half of it to discover a wierd looking twig in it we called the waitress over and she gave us a hard time about saying we ate most of it. She came back and told us the cook identified the big twig as a grape stem. Quality control???! Our nachos were compt but not with out attitude. We waited another 20 minutes just to pay. We check in at the chaotic front desk and went to our room in the Tapas tower. Nice room, well decorated and it had nice bedding, down comforters. My husband went to use the phone it wasn t working it took 2 hours to send someone up to fix it. Then the charges start, they charge you for just about everything here, local phone call, parking, coffee, tea, internet, use of excercise room, towels and chairs by the beach etc. You'll get nickel  dimed here till your stay cost as much as a 5 star hotel price. At night I noticed the bathroom stunk like urine and I had to shut the door but the smell still kinda came through. Over all staff was not very friendly,we went to various shops in HHV to pick up the free gifts got greeted with a frown and a cheap luggage tag shoved at us. hhmmm. The place is good for shopping and the location is walking distance to the main area in Waikiki, better like to walk! I advise not to get your hair done at the Mandarin Spa I had my hair hi-lited there and it came out terrible worst experiece of my life. My hair ended up being a solid, brassy blond color. There wasnt a relaxing moment there. If you come to Hawaii for the island feel dont stay here.

<Author>DianneWashingtonDC
<Content>Was a little more than average My boyfriend and I just got back from Hawaii and we stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village for 7 nights. The hotel was pretty nice, our room was great (very clean) , and we had an excellent view. I believe most of the mattresses at this property are all pillow top, so that was a great added bonus. Most of the staff was very helpful and friendly, except for the front desk. Be prepared to spend money at this hotel, they defiantly seem to have a charge for everything! Parking is $18 per day for valet and $13 per day for self-parking. To use the coffee maker it is $3.50 and to use the safe it is $3.50 per day. To use the gym it is $18 per day for hotel guests. Don't even think about touching the bar provided in your room, it would be best to go to one of the million ABC's stores or to Wal-Mart. Most of the places to eat are pretty expensive that are within the resort, the cheapest thing they have is an $8 hot dog. The hotel only has 2 pools, and in order to get a chair you must go early before 10am and save it (put your towel down, even if you are not going to sit there until later) This is by far a family hotel....it seemed that everything closed at 11pm. However, the hotel has it's own beach (which is sweet!) and it is in a great locations. The hotel has many shops and many animals roaming the property. All in all I was very pleased with my stay.  
<Date>Mar 16, 2005
<Rating>4	3	4	-1	5	-1	4	-1	
<Aspects>

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Not too shabby.... Just recently, my fianc茅e and I went to Oahu for a business/pleasure trip. We were very pleased to find out that our employer had booked us in such a beautiful hotel. In front as you make you way around to the main entrance are some impressive bronze statues of 3 Polynesian dancers. Beautiful. When driving up to the main entrance to the Hotel, you are greeted by large beautiful trees wrapped in twinkle lights, cute little shops and restaurants. Upon check-in, there were little 鈥榰nforeseen鈥?problems that most hotels don鈥檛 normally do. This particular hotel charged up-front the whole hotel stay, vs., waiting for you to check-out and settle your tab. Another unexpected predicament that we could have been informed about is- how they charged an additional $400.00 in 鈥榠ncidentals鈥?up-front on our credit card that took away some extra spending money out of our pockets. Yes, we were refunded the amount, but it was an unexpected fee that we didn鈥檛 see coming. The rooms are clean and there are fresh towels every day. The staff seemed to be friendly and accommodating until we ran into a little problem with the moldy smell of our room. We asked to be relocated to another room with better ventilation 鈥?but our request went unfulfilled. One funny thing that I initially did not find amusing the first day of our stay is that the cleaning staff kept turning on our alarm clock set to go off at 7:am every morning. When it had gone off the first morning, I was sure to turn it off and check it every day thereafter. It became a funny joke afterwards when we managed to foil the pranks of our hotel cleaning staff. The outside of the hotel was constantly being kept up. The walk ways were always clean, the pools were immaculate, and the grounds and ponds were very lovely. The hotel had a few exotic birds roaming the gardens which gave the hotel an aire of 鈥榯ropicality鈥? For a few days stay, it鈥檚 not too shabby. But be advised, have extra room in your credit cards for 鈥榰nforeseen charges鈥?that they may decide to 鈥榩op up鈥?on you. Otherwise, aloha and have a nice time! Mahalo!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>A visit to Paradise Just completed a visit to Honolulu, Hawaii after not having been there for over 5 years. This time we stayed at the Lagoon Tower of the Hilton Hawaiian village in a one bedroom condo. We had a wonderful Ocean View from the 15th floor. The services of the hotel were very much above average. Everyone went out of their way to assist you and to make your stay more enjoyable. Realizing late that we were not leaving the island until late in the evening, we requested the hotel allow us to stay until just prior to going to the Airport. While we couldn't stay in the same room, they did put us up in another room so we could relax during the day. It made the trip even more enjoyable. Kudo's to the staff of the Hilton Hawaiian for making this a great trip. Can't wait until I go back again.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Check-in Nightmare Was initially very excited to be going to Hawaiian Village. However, after a grueling trip that began with 7:30 am arrival at Philadelphia airport, we arrived at Hawaiian Village at about 10:30 pm Hawaiian time (3:30 am, Phila. time.) Hotel was overbooked and we spent another hour waiting for a room, even though our reservations had been made and confirmed since October, and we had guaranteed late arrival. Staff was very courteous though not very helpful. I found it quite interesting that though having a room reservation did not guarantee you a room right away, you could not extend check-out time. Check-in problems cast a pall over the entire time we were there. The place is beautiful but not more so than many Carribean islands.

<Author>PittsburghFamilyof4
<Content>very disappointed We stayed at the HHV for 4 nights following 3 nights at the Rennaissance Ilikai next door. We were there for a conference and had a conference rate room which is probably their lowest standard room. We did not expect much, such as a view(our view overlooked the garage). These are the reasons why we would never return to this hotel:1. They advertise coffee makers in all the rooms(this is very important to us) but they don't tell you that you have to pay $3.50 for each little 4cup coffee pack. They have a cube frig but no microwave.2. This is a huge, impersonal hotel. You start by waiting in line to check in. You wait in line for everything. You have to walk a bit to get to your room.3. Their standard policy is no early check-in's or late check-outs allowed.4. Check out time is 11am. Our flight was at 5:20 so we asked to have our luggage stored. They pointed at a huge tent and said get in that line(it was a very long line).5. Their beach is a disappointment. The sand is rocky, its very crowded, and almost no waves. Their is a pier right there and a commercial type boat goes in and out.6. For a hotel of this size, there are only 2 very small pools.7. There is a village of stores along the entrance. Very commercial atmosphere.Hated this place. For the same money, I'd go somewhere else.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Excellent Experience My colleague and I spent 7 nights at the HHV for a conference - we arrived there 4 days early to relax beforehand. Here are the great points:- the beds (in the Tapa Tower). These things are so comfortable: they have great linens and each bed has four down pillows and down comforters. We were trying to figure out how to pack up the bed and take it home. We fell asleep in seconds.- the Mandara Spa. Included in whatever treatment you choose, you get all-day access to the other spa facilities: hot tub, steam room, sauna, and so on. We chose the Chocolate Macademia Nut body scrub, which was incredibly painful, but which in the end was worthwhile because we were smooth as silk. The prices are very good. $115 for 50 min. of scrubbing, plus 18% tax and gratuity combined.- the grounds. These are meticulously maintained and always interesting. Flamingos, penguins, orchids, parrots, fish ponds, waterfalls and flowers were everywhere. The architecture is bad in terms of the towers - it's the 70s, so you do get the feel of concrete prison blocks, but the groundscaping really makes up for it, as well as the public buildings.- shopping. I did not shop (I spent all my money at the spa and the Tapa Bar), but there was a lot of selection: Louis Vuitton, Lancome and other high-end skin care, a Spa shop which sells the products they use in the spa, and so on.- the Tapa bar: this place is expensive, but it is a great place to unwind. The high ceiling protects from any rain (which we did not experience), but it is entirely open air.- the beach: now, this beach is not the most impressive; the sand is very dull in colour and has large grains, but it was kept very clean and while there were many people there, it was never so packed that you couldn't have a private conversation. I have been to many great beaches, and this one does not rank in the top 5 by any stretch, but I don't have complaints about it at all (by the way, don't hope to find a lover on this beach - it is largely family-oriented)- check in and out was pretty good; rapid and friendly. However, I should note that I had a HHonors member card, which allowed me to use a special line. A woman with whom we shared a cab to the airport indicated that she had a very bad, time consuming experience at the front desk.- Roundtable Pizza is very good and relatively inexpensive.We paid a conference rate of $197 per night for a non-ocean view in the Tapa Tower. Our room had an empty refrigerator which we filled on one trip to the foodstore and which helped defray the costs associated with eating on 'campus' constantly. I think it was entirely worth the price for what you got in return. The only things that were not really very enjoyable were: 1) the entertainment in the evenings. The hula stuff at the superpool was cool, but the music in the bars is sort of like Hawaiian Roy Orbison, as one colleague observed. Also, I really don't like the ROTC kids being involved as an entertainment factor - I wasn't entertained. 2) the prices at the bars were too high. 3). the bars stop serving at 11 pm. This is because they are essentially in the courtyards below the balconies, and the noise drifts up and people then complain. I wasn't there to party, so it was fine for me, but if you're looking for late nights, they'll have to take place in your room.Overall: This was a really good vacation. I would not have vacationed in Hawaii if I had a choice, but it ended up being a great time. This is a very nice hotel with friendly, responsive staff and a lot to offer. I would recommend it. And come prepared to spend money.  
<Date>Mar 5, 2005

<Author>jcarr55
<Content>Had a Great Week Cant go wrong at the HHV. We were considering some of the other hotels but after walking down to the main strip, glad we didn't. Way too busy, like college spring break. And unless beachfront (like HHV), you have to cross a major street or 2 to get to the beach.The HHV has the best beach, is somewhat isolated from the rest of the hotels, yet is a short walk to all the action and downtown shopping. We walked each night but constant shuttles and buses were an option.As others have noted, the on site restaurants are very expensive. We used them sparingly. The best on site deals were the Kirin and Budweiser Happy Hour 4-7 for about $1.50 beer. This was at the Japanese restaurant onsite. Also the KuanaDog stands at the Tapa bar and at the Rainbow Tower beach, had good deals for hot dogs (about $3). Otherwise, bagels were $4.25 for example in the onsite cafes. Pizza and other items were a bit expensive too. The ABC Store, at the hotel, had great prices for straw beach mats ($2), bottled water, and other staples like cereal, milk, coffee. Visit it your first day.Join Hilton Honors before you go. Gives you 5pm check out time (depending on availability) and possible free upgrade, and 2 free bottles of in room water.Snorkel at Hanamau Bay was our favorite thing. We drove the 30 minute drive but package deals are plentiful which include hotel pick up and drop off. Lots of colorful fish and onsite equipment rental makes everything easy.Happy Hour at Dukes (Outrigger hotel) was lots of fun. Right on the beach and really vibrant place. Great place to see the sun set.  
<Date>Mar 1, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>The Hilton is the place for 24 Hours of non-stop action We just returned with my family from 8 days and 7 nights at the HHV in Honolulu.....Honeymooners beware....this is not the place for you to seek peace and tranquility while on your Hawaiian vacation! This is a complex of 5 large towers on a sprawling landscape built for business conventions and large groups of any sort. Don't get me wrong...the hotel room was extremely nice (we stayed in an Oceanfront Room at the Kalia Tower which is brand new with beautiful bedding, bathrooms and furnishings), however, the HHVillage is designed to suit the needs of anyone and everyone with shops, its own grocery store, numerous restaurants and the biggest and nicest beach on Waikiki...sounds good if you want 24 hours of non-stop action. Further down the beach is even more crowded as there are numerous hotels with waterside dining, beach bars, music, surfing lessons.....you name it, it's on Waikiki Beach. We opted to spend our days at different sights and beaches around the island, particularly Kailua and Lanikai on the Northeast shore (about a 20 minute ride)...just spectacular for swimming and watching the locals windsurf and kitesurf...nice group of people. Also, don't go without a day at Hanuama Bay for snorkeling....it's only a $5.00 admission price for the most memorable experience on the coast of Oahu, not to mention it sits on a beautiful beach with nice shade (you will roast in the Hawaiian sun out there unless you find a palm tree or two). Rent your equipment at Snorkel Bob's in Honolulu ($8 per day) and be at the park NO later than 8 AM to get parking! Another good deal near the Village is the Wailana Coffee shop just across the street...they give you a wonderful breakfast complete with pancakes, pineapple juice and Kona coffe that is just to die for at very reasonable prices....much more reasonable than the hotel prices which are way out of line. The other find which helped was the Ena Laundry (just a block behind the coffee shop). Just drop off your bags of laundry in the morning and they will wash, dry and fold it for you for $1.00 a pound.....they do an awesome job and it saved us time, money and alleviated any dirty laundry to fly home with. As far as restaurants go, the best on the island by far is Hoku's at the Kahala Mandarin Oriental Hotel...this is 5-star dining at a 5-star hotel but the food and atmosphere was worth the price for one night. The nice part for my daughters was seeing the dolphins swim at the lagoon which encircles the grounds of this beautiful hotel. Pure 100% elegance without all of the fussiness that you would find in a metropolitan area. As far as luaus go, we did attend the Royal Hawaiian Luau on Waikiki Beach and it was enjoyable but is a huge production for literally hundreds of guests and is anything but traditional if that is what you are looking for. The dancers were beautiful and the music was nice but I missed the more tradional show at the Old Lahaina luau on the island of Maui that I saw several years ago. There is nothing worse than seeing a beautiful, cultural tradition turned into a Vegas-style show. However, if you want to go to a large resort where you never have to leave to shop, dine or sun yourself, this may be the right place for you. Be aware that the pools are not heated and you must arrive by 8:00AM at the main pool to get a chair....and people actually line up early for these! The chairs and umbrellas on the beach are quite expensive to rent for an entire week. The Hilton needs to revise this policy in a huge way. Similar luxury resorts would never dream of hitting their guests up for a simple chair for the day. You will also pay $13.00 a day to park your rental car in the hotel garage. Welcome to the Hilton everyone!  
<Date>Feb 27, 2005

<Author>gazza53
<Content>Very enjoyable stay at HHV Spent 4 nights at the HHV at the end of Jan 2005. We arrived well before the published check in time so weren't surprised that the room wasn't ready. Unlike other guests who had come in on the same flight we didn't complain at check in - which is probably why we were so well looked after. We were allocated a room in the Ali'i tower - which we hadn't booked but definitely the best tower with it's own pool and gym , complimentary breakfast and sunset cocktail receptions. We headed off to grab a coffee and to explore for an hour or so. Our room was ready exactly when we had been told - when we got there our bags were already waiting for us as well as some chilled bottles of water. Our stay continued in this mode - staff were very friendly and helpful throughout, restaurants were good (a little expensive - but what do you expect?) The Polynesia show was colourful - and probably not very authentic! - but the fireworks were great. Best spot to view the show is the cocktail lounge in the Ali'i. Conversely the live act in the Shell Bar - Jennifer and John? - were quite outstanding. All in all a very enjoyable stay  
<Date>Feb 26, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Exactly What You Expect, nothing more, nothing less. We have just returned from the Hilton, we stayed from the 12th Feb for 5 nights. The hotel is modern and clean with all that you would expect from a resort hotel, large pool, bars and 1000's of people. Despite how busy this hotel is, we did still manage to get sun beds at the pool and the beach, even during the Pro Bowl weekend.The service was very good, but we did find it really difficult to get reservations for dinner in any of the hotels restaurants, even booking in the morning is a no-no. Try 48 hours before. (So think a head for the night you arrive, call ahead).The rooms were clean and well maintained and the maid service was prompt and efficient.If you want a quiet time, with not too many people, then this is not the hotel for you. If you are looking for a lively time, then this a good choice for Waikiki.  
<Date>Feb 25, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>When does "Ocean view" mean " Ocean View" Just returned from 3 nights at Hilton Hawaiian Village. Overall a great relaxing time however, not without its annoying bits.Check in - Arrived at 1pm after travelling from Vancouver (up since 5am) room not ready but assured it's beautiful with a wonderful sun set view 28th floor Rainbow tower. After wandering deliriously for over an hour we finally pick up the key. Head to 28th floor open door ..hang on isn't this supposed to be an ocean view? What's that building doing there? Oh I see you have to go out on the balcony and hang over the edge looking left....there it is. Sorry I'm not paying $300us+ per night for this view.Hang on where's the sparkling wine that was supposed to meet us on arrival?Down we go to the assistant duty manager introduce myself advise I'm not happy with the view from the room. They're all Ocean view in the rainbow building is her response. Well long story short if you want a guaranteed Ocean view of the beach you need to book an Ocean Front suite. After being dismissed by the manager to her assistant ( she was the assistant manager so I guess i was now dealing with the assistant's assistant) we got transferred from 2804 to 1815 which had a great view of the beach.However, still waiting for the sparkling wine on arrival...Oh, and don't be taken in by the  Use of Mandara Spa as part of the package. No relaxing therapies here unless you consider a treadmill a relaxing therapy.

Pool is for all hotel guests but parents should remember - the pool is part of the spa!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>First Hilton, First time Hawaii, still suprised My husband and I , along with our 5 year old just returned from a week trip to Oahu. We had decided on the HHV as the Hale Koa was already booked, which is right next door. We were going to visit our son who is in the Navy in SUNNY Hawaii. Not sunny, cold and rainy. The swimming pools at the HHV are very nice but almost unbearable to get into as the water is so cold! The temperature does not get up much in the day, due to the breeze and the mountains. For the beach bring water shoes as it is not soft sand it is rocky and your feet will sink!We were upgraded to the Ali Tower, which was an excellent suprise and the room was very nice. We had a Corner ocean view room, which was also overlooking the pool. The second balcony overlooked the gardens and the common park between the HHV and the Hale Koa. It also gave us extra privelages that other towers did not have. For example the hot tub, which was nice on a cold day, also coffee in the room was included (apparently 3.50 in the other room!). We found the service was excellent everywhere that we went within the village. We had housekeeping services several times a day. As for the bed, comfortable. If you have ever stayed in a Westin, it is just like their Heavenly bed! For our 5 year old this was a dream come true to be here in this room as he loved the views! So if possible try to get the A tower and a room ending in 5.We really didn't see a need for a rental car as a taxi was cheap when we didnt walk places that were close. We did rent a car to see Pearl Harbor , a must see and that same day drove the coast line to view the North Shore! We had purchase a book prior to leaving called Oahu Reaveled, very helpful. Dining options at HHV, Oceanside, Tropics, Bennihanas, Tapa Cafe and Roundtable Pizza is good. Otherwise check out the Harbor bay Pub a few blocks away for Pizza and sandwiches! Also film developing is much cheaper there!! Look for the coupons and go to the Discovery Bay 1 hour photo!I am sure I would stay here again, however I just wish the beach wasn't so rocky and the pool was heated! But then again moms can be picky about cold water, because dad and the little guy didn't seem to mind! If you love to shop this is the place to be, 90 stores to choose from!  
<Date>Feb 6, 2005

<Author>summer1964
<Content>Loved the HHV We just got back from a wonderful vacation in Hawaii. Three islands and ending in Las Vegas. (See other reviews for Maui, Kauai and Vegas)Oahu was our first stop. We could not have been more pleased with our room and service in the Kalia tower. We had a view of the lagoon. The bed was soooooo comfortable and cozy. The room was clean. We spent a lot of time doing tourist things, so the pool and beach expenses were not an issue for us.Pearl Harbor was very sad and the USS Missouri was very interesting. Punch Bowl Cemetary was also sad, but nice to read the big wall.If you can physically do it go to Diamond Head and climb it. It was the best thing that we did. It was hard and we hurt for a couple of days but it was so worth it. Also, we booked the Poly. Culture Ctr at the desk and had the best lady from NY help us. She was such a card and gave more helpful info than necessary. She told us to follow the buses back to Waikiki which was easier. Also, she said not to leave anything in the car, so we locked everything in the trunk each time we left the car. She was right, when we went to Pearl Harbor a car not far from ours had a smashed window.We would go back in a second and stay at the HHV without a question.Yes, the food is expensive, but I agree with a previous reviewer. It's Hawaii what do you expect. Go to the ABC store in HHV and get your water and snacks, it helped.Fantastic trip and thanks to the HHV for making it what we expected.  
<Date>Jan 27, 2005

<Author>ny721
<Content>Loved it! We stayed in five hotels during our stay in Hawaii, including one that was more expensive and supposed to be a lot nicer, but the Hilton Hawaiian Village was by far our favorite - mostly because of the phenomenal, professional service. When we pulled up, an extremely friendly and helpful bellman opened our door, helped us with our bags, and parked our car. The check-in line was short (even at a busy time of day), and the receptionist was extremely friendly and upgraded our room for free when he heard it was our belated honeymoon.The view was spectacular, and the grounds are gorgeous and almost a little city in itself. On Friday nights, there are fireworks at 8 p.m., bands playing throughout the grounds, etc. The beach is great, nice soft sand, and the pool was neat. They also have penguins and flamingoes - fun little surprises like that made this a fun place to stay.  
<Date>Jan 16, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Never Again!!! This hotel was recommended very highly by a world traveler with kids. So we booked it without looking elsewhere or with the help of online reviews. Very disappointed. We stayed in the Rainbow Tower in an ocean view suite which was actually very nice with a great view of Wiakiki and Diamond Head, but very expensive for what you got overall. There were no extras. For example, the pool was too small and crowded, thus no chairs. The beach was also small and the chairs were $20 EACH EACH DAY with umbellas extra. Towels were extra too. Everything had to be returned by 5 pm or you were charged a late fee. Ridiculous and should be included.Exercise room was another extra. Parking was extra and there was no call ahead service so you had to wait. Faxes were not delivered to your room even if requested. Service was really absent. There was also a constant push to enroll in Time Share Property. They tried to entice us with gifts, which our kids really wanted, but were almost impossible to get. (Hotel COMPLEX is so big that staff doesn't even know where things are).We loved our visit to Honolulu, despite the hotel experience. Waikiki and the whole island was fun for my wife and I and our 2 kids (7  10 yrs). There is a lot to do and a rental car is a must if you really want to experience the Island. North Shore Surfing, Turtles and Snorkeling were great. Would recommend getting OAHU: Revealed as a great guide book, it has everything one needs to REALLY know.We would do Waikiki again, but will try another hotel.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Don't honeymoon here My husband and I chose HHV as the second part of our honeymoon. We previously spent a week in Maui before heading to Oahu. We were very discouraged when we arrived at the hotel. Parking was chaos, and even though my husband is a Hilton Honors member, we still had to wait in line. We booked a package online that promised an Ocean View room in the Rainbow tower. When we got to our room there was no view of the ocean and the room was dirty. We spoke to the manager and she finally gave us a different room with a view of the ocean. Forget about laying out at the pool unless you get there at 8:00 A.M. Very crowded and dirty. The food was ok at the hotel but very pricey for the quality. The only good thing about HHV was leaving. I do not recommend this hotel to anyone!!!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Not what we expected We've stayed in many nice hotels, and AmEx platinum travel services recommended the exclusive Ali鈥檌 tower at the Hilton Hawaiian Village on Waikiki beach. Those accustomed to fine hotels and resorts will be disappointed.The HHV is huge- perfect location, lots of shopping, it's right on the beach and the unique varitey of wildlife and landscaping make it one of the most beautiful resorts on Waikiki. If that's all that's important to you, then this is your place. If you're concerned with first class service and dining, skip this hotel.Like the other reviews read, the food is mediocre at best. The breakfast and lunch buffet had a decent selection, but both were overpriced and not particularly tasty. The only exception is the Golden Dragon chinese restaraunt, which was fantastic; priced a little high, but worth every cent.Service was terrible. This is one of those places that's almost too big- management can't seem to handle all the variables. We stayed here during the week before Christmas, which must have been during one of the hotel's busiest weeks because there was a line for everything from chairs and umbrellas for the beach to tables for breakfast. Not what you expect when you pay top dollar for a room.Think we're nit-picking? Read on:We also didn't expect to pay thirteen dollars per day (!!) to park in our own hotel. We opted to pay five dollars more and have our car valet parked-- another mistake. Like the previous days, on the day of our checkout, we waited a long time for the valets to pull our car around. When we informed them we had to get to the airport to check-in on time, they had informed us they had lost our car rental keys.Yes, we missed our flight and had to wait at the airport for several hours, and the story continues. We never stayed in a Hilton hotel before, and this is not at all what we expected. I mean, one night we actually had to call housekeeping to have our room turned down! Come on. Spend your hard-earned dollars on a smaller place where management can handle their guests and visit the Hilton Hawaiian Village for shopping and pictures of the flamingos and penguins. Don't forget your camera.  
<Date>Jan 9, 2005

<Author>NRT
<Content>Good choice for a resort-style hotel in Waikiki We stayed at the HHV in July 2004, and had a good time there. We had previously stayed at the Outrigger on the Beach, which is a nice place. We were attracted by the HHV because it seemed to have more resort type amenities. I would say that overall, we were satisfied.This place is not luxurious, but comfortable. We stayed in the Ali'i tower, which I would recommend. The HHV is a massive resort, and has a very crowded feeling. Staying in the Ali'i tower helps, since you have your own pool and separate bar only for Ali'i guests. The beach in this part of Waikiki is nice because it is very wide. There is surfing and even snorkling (not great snorkling) right off the beach. Overall, the HHV is a good choice if you want something resembling a resort hotel experience in Waikiki. However, if you want an intimate, uncrowded atmosphere, this is not the place (in fact, if that is what you want, Waikiki is not the place to go at all - instead, go to the Mauna Lani or Hapuna Prince on the Big Island, or the Ritz Carlton Kapalua on Maui).  
<Date>Jan 9, 2005

<Author>samelle
<Content>A Pleasant Experience When we checked in we asked kindly for a nice room. This request was accomodated as we were given a spacious suite in the Tapa tower with a pool/ocean view for the same price as our regular room would have been. The hotel's beach was great and much better than any other hotel's beach we saw. The only beach complaint is that a chair costs $12 and an umbrella $20 to rent for 1 day. The food at the hotel was very overpriced and not very good so we went elsewhere - Roy's, Alan Wong's, and Nick's Fishmarket were all excellent meals. The Wailana coffee shop across the street was inexpensive and great for breakfast. The staff was very friendly, the hotel was lively, and the grounds were well kept. Overall, we really liked this hotel and would especially recommend it for families.

<Author>Layover
<Content>Not Again I go to Hawaii on business about once a year and every other year my wife joins me and we hit some of the other islands. My client is on Oahu so I'm forced to stay there. Not a big crowd person and Waikiki is a sea of fanny-pack-toting tourists so I steer clear. My wife is very much the same way; her attitude is that she's in Hawaii to relax and soak up the beauty. Not ride trolly cars and buy t-shirts at an ABC store.With that said, on her third trip over we did a couple of nights at the HHV. Ugh. It was like a Human Warehouse. I'm not anti-complex when it comes to hotels. Some of the Disney resorts get it right. This was simply a churning cauldron of humanity. The beach was littered with cigarette butts. The super pool was right out of a Holiday Inn in Ohio. And so packed you couldn't get within 100 feet of it.The food was marginal and so expensive that we stayed away. To top it off, we were on the top floor but underneath the machinery that powers the elevator. Get the audio picture? The man in the room next to us did something with stocks so he was up at 3 am in Hawaii to handle market issues. How do I know that? I could hear every word he said...between rumblings of the elevator.If you have a family. This might not be bad. If you've never been to Hawaii and aren't here for a cultural experience or quiet, this might work.Suggestion: get your rental car and spend one day going up the middle of the island to Halaiwa, then east and down the leeward shore through Kailua and then down past Sandy Beach (amazing but watch yourself. You can really really get hurt) and then around Diamond Head. Also, if you want true peace and are relegated to Oahu, go to the west shore. Up past Makaha. Miles and miles and miles of beautiful quiet beaches. The last time I was there it was me and two women with a small child. On maybe two miles of beach. THAT'S Hawaii. And about a 45 minute drive from the HHV. Worth it.  
<Date>Jan 7, 2005

<Author>atlas750
<Content>Ali'i Tower I spent 4 days during the late summer and enjoyed every moment of the hotel experience. I personally could care less about all the shops that take up much of the village space, but did find a nice variety of restaurants. The Ali'i Tower offered wonderful - continual - service. I found fresh ice in the room several times daily and the quality of the rooms and fittings were appreciated. I am glad I paid slightly more than some friends and had a larger oceanfront room with a wonderful view and the guarantee of one king bed. Two friends opted for the basic room which was quite a bit smaller and their request for one queen/king bed was not granted and they ended up with these smaller rooms with two double beds crowded into the room.I really do not understand why any hotel, especially higer end hotels, have so many rooms with multiple beds. The only other issue is that it was not made clear that there was a seperate check in desk for the Ali'i Tower. I did not find this out until after waiting for more than 45 minutes at the general check in area for the other towers.

<Author>justme505
<Content>Wonderful Week at the Hilton Hawaiian We stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village from Dec. 19 through the 26th, 2004. It is a top-notch resort and our stay was without problems overall. Thanks to all the great advice I read on tripadvisor before my trip, I registered for the HHonors program ahead of time, and it paid off. Upon check-in we were immediately upgraded from our reserved 2 gardenview rooms to 2 oceanview rooms in the Tapa Tower. (There were 6 in our party - my family of 4, grandmother, and another family friend.)As advised on this webpage, we also took advantage of the Vacation Club (timeshare) offer to sit through the presentation in order to receive $100 in hotel dollars to be used onsite at any of the restaurants and shops. ( - - tell them that their timeshare is the price of a small car, so therefore you can't make that type of decision this quickly - it worked for us!) Believe me, if you can stand to endure the sales pitch and sales pressure, you'll be happy to have the $100 with the resort prices of everything (virgin pina colada - $9, without tip!!) at the hotel! With that $100 our family of 4 was able to enjoy a fun meal at the Benihana one night, thus making the 90 minutes of sales pressure worth it.Our hotel room was a very nicely-appointed regular hotel room with a nice view of the lagoon. There was a small refrigerator and additional small sink provided outside the bathroom, which came in handy with 2 teenage girls. As advised on this webpage, we did not use the hotel-supplied water bottles and coffee-making supplies. (We were able to purchase individual coffee packets and water from local ABC Stores for a much lower price.) The hotel was very accommodating with the holidays. They scheduled the showing of a lot of family-friendly movies in their showroom, so whether the weather was inclement or everything closed for Christmas Day, then there was always something to do. The evening shows at the pool were very nice with the dancers performing a very professional show. At the end of each show some of the members go out into the audience, shake each person's hand, and thank them for attending their show. I think that is a very nice touch. Our only real complaint was that there is no laundry onsite for guests of the hotel. They do provide laundry facilities for guests in their Vacation Club, a point the sales rep was quick to make during the sales pitch. But we still didn't see that having the laundry would make any stay worth the price of a small car! There is a laundry a few blocks away, but we managed to make due without it. I just know that we'd have packed better had we known there was no laundry available onsite for non-vacation club guests. You do pay daily for onsite parking, including self-serve, so plan that into the price of your rental car. We found a great deal for the rental car by riding the Waikiki Shuttle to and from the airport to our hotel, and then walking to the local Enterprise office, 2 blocks away. All-in-all, we'll be happy to stay at the Hilton Hawaiian again. It is a fun place with lots to do, and plenty of people-watching. There are many beautiful places just to sit, relax, and watch the world go by. The hotel wildlife is neat with penguins, flamingoes, a black swan, parrots, and many assorted fish. If you are looking for film opportunities, they are abundant. (It's also a neat place for running into tv/movie stars, too. My teenage girls were thrilled to see and briefly meet two male tv stars who were staying there while we were there.)  
<Date>Jan 3, 2005

<Author>WEARECANADIAN
<Content>Xmas at the Ali'i Tower..Wonderful!! Our family spent 11 nights over the Xmas holidays ath the Ali'i tower. Grandparents, aunts, uncles, cousins and our family of four. Being a platinum amex member and my husband a Gold Hiltonhhonours member maybe gave us the extra privileges of room upgrades, complimentary continental bkfast at the lovely ocean terrace and complimentary evening hors d'ovres every evening while watching the amazing sunset.My parents were in 827 which they truly enjoyed. The 27 ending rooms overlook the super pool and the beach. The wraparound balcony had enough space so that the whole clan could watch the Friday evening fireworks...spectacular. The other families were in an OV category which afforded us a lovely view of Diamond Head and Waikiki Beach.PROS:1. Ali'i tower has amazing service, from the wait staff at the breakfast at the Ocean Terrace, to the front staff, to the exceptional concierge staff (Amelia, Mark, Sidney, Aki), thank you for all your assistance.2. Private pool with hot tub for Ali'i guests was wonderful even for children (who are well-behaved).3. Guest rooms are spacious with a large dressing/washroom.4. Guests are not nickled and dimed for every convenience..i.e. coffee, private gym facilities,newspaper, free bottled water.etc.5. Maid service was exceptional, unobtrusive, 3x daily.6. Lovely wide expanse of beach fronting resort complex compared to almost non-existent beach at Halekulani.7. Lovely grounds with something appealing to all age groups. Feels more like a resort that a city hotel on a beach, which most other properties felt like. 8. ABC store on premises. Great for stocking up for fruit, suishi, wine, etc. in the 2nd fridge in Ali'i guest rooms. (one fridge was a mini-barwhich we didn't use.)CONS:1. Super pool temperature was very cold compared to Ali'i tower pool.2. Rooms are being renovated. There was no noise concern, but definitely will be a cosmetic improvement, although all of our rooms were well maintained and very clean.3. Restaurants were a bit pricey on site.In conclusion, if I would came to Oahu again, I would definitely stay at the Ali'i tower at the HHV. Mahalo, Ali'i staff!P.S. In Maui, I recommend the Fairmont Kea Lani, the Westin or the Hyatt Regency. In Kaui, either the Hyatt or the Marriott. We are well travelled to the Hawaiian islands.  
<Date>Jan 2, 2005

<Author>Shreddie
<Content>Classic view of Waikiki and Diamond Head! We spent our last night in Waikiki before heading back to SF at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. Upon check in I was told we had an ocean view room in the Rainbow Tower. However what we actually had was a room on the 3rd floor with a view of a gravel roof and a large tree. The ocean was out there but you can to squeeze into the corner of the balcony to see any of it.After phoning down and complaining (gently!) we were upgraded in a MAJOR way to the 27th floor, a corner room with 2 balconies, one facing the yacht harbor and downtown, and the other with a dead-on gorgeous view of Waikiki and Diamond Head. It had to be the most stunning view I've ever had from a hotel, anywhere. When the Friday night fireworks went off, we were eye level on our balcony. I told my husband I could've singed my hair, they were so close.The resort itself is as it bills itself..a village...great for a million distractions for children, or shoppers. I don't normally like this busy of an atmosphere, but I knew what to expect and it was fine. The pool is gorgeous, the beach is beautiful and RIGHT THERE.The food was so-so...and the breakfast we had sent up to the room was pretty terrible. Save your money and go out somewhere decent. YUK! Gummy bagel, un-eatable turkey bacon and lousy coffee.But, that view made up for any other minor complaints...just make sure you're getting what you paid for.  
<Date>Dec 19, 2004

<Author>zobark
<Content>Loved It! For never visiting Hawaii and planning a honeymoon in such a short time, I was nervous about choosing the best hotel. I could not have been more pleased when the airport shuttle dropped me off at this paradise hotel. It really has everything you could ask for from nightly poolside shows to penguins and hula lessons. The rooms were equally as perfect as the grounds. I guess the beds could have been a tad more comfortable, but I am not complaining, being there was paradise.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Rest, Relaxation, and Courtesy Father and I ventured for the first time to Oahu. The hotel was splendid we stayed in the Lagoon Tower. It was a frenetic Thanksgiving but we definitely enjoyed the daily activities.Having the shops and restaurants there in the evening made the choice for dining very simple. We found many boisterous patron moments in the early afternoon by the pool-quite a diverse group of travelers by the pool. We had a wonderful time meeting vacationers from across the world. The property was immaculate and the convenience of the location made every venture to Waikiki very easy. The Village Steak House and the Rainbow Lanai Rooms were fabulous. The prices, although not inexpensive, were reasonable for the quality of food received.The parking service was tremendously helpful in locating daily off the beaten path tour destinations as well as the more tourist oriented ones that round out such a vacation. Providing the directions was never a problem for any employee. The staff were always willing to accomodate and assist in ensuring for a very relaxing, restful and enjoyed vacation.Can't wait until we visit next Thanksgiving. We are already booked.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great For Young Families We stayed at the HHV Nov 11-18, 2004 in the Tapa Tower, 23rd floor with our two children ages 4  7. Paid $200 per night. We were very pleased with all aspects of the hotel. Service was courteous and timely. Room was fine, partial ocean view. The grounds were lovely... fish, penguins, turtles, birds, lush vegetation. Nice shops. The super pool and beach access were very nice. The beach area was quieter and better groomed than that further east... Waikiki. Parking was easy (but cost $12/night).We usually ate breakfast/brunch across the street at the Waialana Coffee Shop... inexpensive, but good food. We ate dinner at various locations around Honolulu... family friendly restaurants. We would go sight-seeing each day and then return to the hotel for fun in the water. The kids got a kick out of the evening hula show and torch lighting... though it may not be as entertaining for adults. We did not want our vacation to end!Chaise lounge rentals ($22/day) and beach umbrella rentals ($10/day, if I remember right) were kinda' high, we thought... so we did not partake. There were many restaurants on the premises... but too expensive for us.I would definitely recommend this hotel to families with young children. We hope to return in the future! I think it's a much nicer hotel than many of the cheesy ones along Waikiki beach. Easier to park, quieter, less hustle and bustle.  
<Date>Dec 15, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Hilton Hawaiian Honeymoon We visited the HHV for 8nts in June for the 2nd part of our honeymoon. It was my 1st visit to the USA and I have to say was a little disappointed. We were honeymooners and qualified for a room upgrade with a sea view which apparently we received. We were on the top floor on the Rainbow Tower overlooking the lagoon - we had hoped for a view of Waikiki. The room was OK, but a bit old fashioned.Food and drink wise - not at all expensive. We are from England so same as prices over here really. Mai Tai's in Tapa Bar are lovely but lethal! Pizza place is good and open late. Tropics Beach Bar also good but closes at 9pm! If you want it a bit more lively at night then head for the Shore Bird at the Outrigger Reef on the Beach. The food and atmosphere there is great. Try the Cheesecake Factory too, so long as you don't mind a 90min wait for a table - worth it though.All in all, the hotel was good. If we went to Hawaii again I think I would stay here again, although I would pay the extra and stay in the Ali Tower and receive the luxury I was expecting on this visit.  
<Date>Dec 8, 2004

<Author>formerbelle
<Content>Great time at the HHV #1I appreciate people taking the time to write reviews because the comments I read prior to go to Oahu were very helpful. So this is a thank you for all of you who take your valuable time to share comments. Intially I was going to save money by staying at a less expensive hotel. Then decided to enjoy myself and that was a stupendous idea but it made the difference from an ok trip to a really lovely trip. Had a great stay at the HHV. Luckily it was not so crowded. Must be crazy in high season. Stayed in the Diamond Head Tower and it was acceptable for the rate I was paying (corporate rate) It is probably one of the older towers on the property. It is a little old e.g. the carpet is a bit wornish but very clean and comfortable and quiet. I do think in high season it would have been not quite as peaceful. Next time I would prefer to stay in another tower. Really liked staying on the beach and I liked being in the Village environment. There were plenty of chairs at the pool and the beach was not crowded ( again not high season). Thanks to the advice on this web site I ate breakfast across the street away from the Village and it was only about $7.00. Good breakfast. Loved walking..walking..walking.. thought sandals would do but for walking thank goodness I brought tennis shoes. If I had not brought .. no prob... stores are plentiful to buy anything. ABC stores are plentiful bought sodas, toothpaste, tee shirts,etc. I did not use the entertainment center in the room too much for sodas , coffee, etc.. what also I thought ridiculous is if you use the entertainment center you are charged an additional $1.50 for it to be restocked. That is the responsibility of the hotel. But that is minor complaint. I just did not use it and that took care of that peeve, but I still think it is silly. The view from the room was top of trees but that was ok because I was not in the room much. If I were with a special someone I would def want an ocean view. I do suggest a room high enough not to hear noise from the pool, trucks, vans, etc. I was on floor 7 and that was ok. I would prefer a higher floor. Liked staying at the end of the beach and not in the center of the high activity. Easy to walk or ride the bus. Visited the AZ and that is a must. Looking forward to a return trip and want to visit the Big Island and return to Oahu and will prob stay at the HHV again. I had a great time and it was a wonderful break from a hectic schedule. I used to think that the people who loved Hawaii had never traveled much and had limited frame of reference. I have rethought that concept because I have traveled to many countries and found Hawaii to be a wonderful place as well.  
<Date>Dec 3, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Ali' Tower, Honeymooners, Great Stay My husband and I stayed at the Ali' Tower and had the time of our lives. We were there in early June. This was the beat vacation we have ever had. We were suspose to be in the Kali' Tower but got upgraded for free and paid a very small cost to upgrade a little bit more. We were in the 6 star hotel with a doorman at the door that always had a smile on his face. Especially the man there at night. They were friendly but left us alone. Perfect for a couple on thier honeymoon. We had a ocean view room of the village and the ocean. We got up every morning at sat on our balcony. The food was a little pricey but well worth our trip. My husband loved the pizza there. You need to try it if you are there. He loves pizza and said that it is the best that he had ever had. The only problem we had was that we had double beds in our room. The view, service and that it was our honeymoon did not make it a big deal at all with us. This was the best week of our lives. We would go back there in a minute.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Stay away from the Diamond Tower I did not like this hotel at all. TOO BIG and spread out. The Diamond Tower was horrid with only a partial ocean view from my room. After check-in I was given a map and sent away. I had to ask to be pointed in the right direction, and I still needed help finding my room as there was a function going on. Let鈥檚 not forget the ants, ants, and more ants, they were everywhere in my room. The room size was ok, but it could use a face-lift. If I can help it, I would not stay there again, at least not this tower. The Village area is ok, tourist traps for sure. The beach was fine, but it would have been nice to have comp beach chairs as a guest of the hotel. The food was just ok, with blah service. Clearly, the key to this hotel is to be in an upgraded room or tower or something deluxe. It is too far to travel from the East Coast to only have a lack luster room. Thank goodness my stay was a short one!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>If you can't stay in the Royal Hawaiian - the HHV is next best place We stayed in the Kalia Tower 3 nights in late October) and were most pleased with the location of our room (23rd floor - overlooking the Rainbow Tower, Lagoon and gorgeous pacific ocean). Our room was beautifully furnished - every amenity was available. We were lucky we stayed on a club floor - great continental breakfast, coffee/refreshments and daytime snacks, and evening appetizers - ready when you are and available on the 25th floor. We paid $275/night which I believe is the going rate for high ocean view/club floor in the Kalia Tower. We usually stay at the Royal Hawaiian and as nice as the HHV was -I was happy when at last it was time to move on down the road to the Royal Hawaiian. The moment we arrived at the RHH - felt that our vacation had now truly begun. Either way - both hotels are great and Waikiki as busy as it is - is a wonderful place to just kick back and relax.  
<Date>Nov 26, 2004

<Author>ShelbyJR
<Content>Hawaiian Village Not for Toddlers We cancelled reservations at the W and changed our one-night stay in Oahu to the Hilton Hawaiian Village in Waikiki because it was supposedly a child-friendly hotel. The hotel may be friendly to children above 5, but it was NOT toddler friendly. When we arrived at the hotel, we were greeted by a very unfriendly bellhop that took all of our bags -- including our diaper bag. I specifically asked if it would take long for our bags to be delivered to the room and was told it wouldn't take long.When we arrived in our room, it was nice and clean, but we had someone else's luggage in the room. We called the front desk and it was picked up right away. But, we waited approximately 2 hours for our luggage to be delivered. (Our diaper bag with diapers, toys, snacks and etc. -- almost 2 hrs. to be delivered.) My husband called several times to find out where our luggage was and were told it's on it's way.We also asked for a crib when reservations were made, when we checked in, and with three calls to the front-desk. A portable playpen was delivered approximately 5 hrs after check-in. (Not even a sheet to cover the bottom of playpen was provided.) We called housekeeping and explained that our 18-month old was too tall to sleep in a playpen -- his body length is much longer than the width of the playpen. We were told sorry.We went down and spoke to the manager on duty and were told a playpen was all they could provide. But, if we had requested a crib earlier in the day, we could have arranged a rental. (We told the manager we asked four times for the crib and no one mentioned that all they had were playpens, but we were greeted with a blank look.)Though we booked a king-size bed room, we were given a room with double-beds. I spent my first night in Hawaii awake the majority of the time trying to make sure our son didn't fall out of the bed. (My husband had to sleep in the other double-bed.)The rest of the grounds were nice, the staff somewhat friendly, but not stroller friendly and my son did find the remains of a very dead bird outside the pizza restaurant. (On-site restaurants convenient, but over priced.)We'll try the hotel again after our son is over five, but we will not go back to the Hilton Hawaiian Village until he's atleast that old. (When we returned home, I sent an email letter to Hilton complaining about stay and received an email back from Hawaiian Village Manager saying that they'd look into our problems and look at their policies.)  
<Date>Nov 26, 2004

<Author>usa352
<Content>Better than expected Just returned from a 2 week honeymoon to Oahu and the Big Island. Stayed at the HHV the 1st three nights. Positives:--paid $205 for partial ocean view. Got upgraded to 24th floor of Rainbow Tower, corner room with views of Diamond Head on one side and the harbor on the other. The view was awesome, best of all the places we stayed. I think we were upgraded b/c I'm a HHonors diamond member and it was our honeymoon.--ABC store is great! Drinks and snacks in the room keep costs down. My wife also bought some reasonably priced souvenirs. --Grounds are cool. Pink Flamingos, penguins, greenery, etc.--Service better than expected.--Best and roomiest beach on Waikiki 鈥?and we walked all the way to Diamond Head.Negatives:--HUGE Cockroach in room. Released it to the 鈥渨ild鈥?and no other problems. It was HUGE!--Better be an early riser to get a spot at the pool. --We were directed to order drinks from the waitresses poolside, instead of ordering at the bar. Kind of took a while, wished we could have gone up at our convenience.--Place is big. A little overwhelming when checking in late at night after a long flight.Advise:--Take a Taxi to and from the airport, avoid the Waikiki shuttle. You only spend a couple of extra bucks, but it is SO much more convenient! We had to wait an extra 陆 hour while they loaded the thing up (this was after a 9 hour flight 鈥?we just wanted to get there!). We took a taxi on the way back and it allowed us to spend more time on the beach and have less headaches! (Waikiki Shuttle is totally independent of HHV).  
<Date>Nov 24, 2004

<Author>travelinspiration
<Content>Great Service/Room in Ali Tower If you must stay in Oahu, the HHV Ali Tower is the way to go if you like large/megaresorts. My husband and I visited Nov.5-6th and 19th-20th on the way to/from Sydney to shorten our flight from Texas. We knew the hotel was extremely large, but we were not wanting to leave the property in our short stays - so we very much wanted everything at our disposal. We are blessed to travel extensively despite our young ages of 28/32 and stay in only 4 and a half or 5 star hotels. The Ali Tower is the way to go here. We had booked a partial o.view vs. the full o.view in order to overlook the Super Pool, Beach, and Fri.night show. We requested a high floor and on the end closest to the beach. Our requests were granted with both stays and we thus became Hilton Honors members for we were impressed with all of the great service. The Ali tower has it's own gym ($12 to use the main gym in Kalia Tower) and pool. The room was very large as well as the bathroom. Even had a mini TV. We never heard ANY noise on either stay despite the Ali Tower being at almost full capacity. We did not rent a car, so no parking fees. Just took a taxi to/from airport - only $25 each way and took 25-30minutes with traffic. The reception desk in Ali was great, no line EVER! We did the bounceback package advertised on their website and received free brk. in Rainbow Lanai - wonderful! The pool area was quite crowded for November, but inside the Super Pool and on the Beach were not crowded. We already knew the food was expensive. We only ate at the Tropics Beach Cafe - 2 hamburgers, 2 fries, and 2 alcholic beverages for $41.00. We were given a slightly later check out of Noon upon request and then a hospitality room for 40 mins. before our flight. We did the Pearl Harbour tour with E Noa tours on our last day and it was great - highly recommend this company and our driver/guide - Bob. Overall great experience if you don't mind a lot of people around. I would say if you want to experience the real Hawaii, go to Kauai and Maui - our personal favorite places on earth. Oahu is just a big city but our flight to Sydney was from there and wanted to visit Pearl Harbour. Plus the HHV offered great room, entertainment, and shopping. I originally was going to book the Kahala Mandarin outside of town, but being that we would be there on both occassions for such a short time, figured we needed to stay closer to the airport and wanted to see Waikiki Beach for I doubt we'll ever return to Oahu, unless flying through to another vacation destination.  
<Date>Nov 23, 2004
