<Author>lmg66
<Content>Loved It....Plus Some Tips to Avoid the Problems My trip was through American Airlines Vacations and I couldn't have been happier with their service -- or the Hilton's. My package came with a free upgrade to Ali'i Tower, which was important to me because I wanted the added amenities I'd heard about. Made sure to have AA fax the hotel to guarantee that tower and let them know we were celebrating an anniversary (5th), so we wanted to ensure the ocean view that we were to get with the package.AA Vacations met us at the airpoirt with a lei greeting and instructed us to check in at the kiosk while waiting for our bags to be transported to the bus. I worried that I wouldn't get the same attention (there was just a lady there to help guide me through self check-in). Instead, I was the only one there and she took extra time to make sure I was in the Ali'i tower and had the room I wanted. Handed me not only our room keys right there, but also the bar key and all the resort info. This kiosk is fairly new, but anyone staying at the hotel can use it and should to avoid the lines.The bus dropped us in the transportation area and, when I told the bellman we'd already checked in at the airport and had our keys, he pointed the way directly to our tower and promptly took our luggage. I was excited to see our room and also relieved. On the quiet side (Diamond Head), which in this tower overlooks Fort DeRussey park, the beach and ocean. Within about 5 mins. the bellman called to make sure we were in our room and was there within minutes with our bags.Ali'i Tower is great, especially for the unlimited free coffee and bottled water and lavish rooms. Ours was very quiet. The only complaint was that, because we were on the fourth floor, we couldn't see Diamond Head from the lanai. I thought the complimentary hors d'oeuvres were overrated but they were very popular with the other guests. I did enjoy that tower's private pool, deck, bar and hot tub. Also, since that tower has its own concierge and front desk, they are very attentive and there's rarely a wait for these services.Once when we'd inadvertently left the Do Not Disturb button on all day while on a trip to the Big Island, I was disappointed to return after 9pm to find my room hadn't been serviced. Though the maids come by three times daily for anything from full service to coffee and ice replinishment, they will NOT disturb you if the button on the door indicates privacy (they slide a note under the door). To my surprise, they sent a team of two women up at nearly 10pm and did everything we asked -- new sheets, towels, vaccuming -- while we waited on the lanai. I was impressed. Another time, we needed more coffee, at night no less, and they brought it right up at no charge.Though originally scheduled for seven nights, we didn't want to leave and decided to extend our stay by two nights. Because they were nearly sold out and couldn't keep us in the same room, the Ali'i front desk manager gave us several choices in various towers -- from an Ali'i room with no view to a Deluxe Oceanfront in the Rainbow Tower. We chose to see what that one would be like and they gave us a $345/night room for $275/night since they were asking us to move. It was seamless. They gave us a late check-out until the new room was ready, so we lounged at the pool until they took our bags from one room to the next.Now for the differences. We had a corner room in the Rainbow Tower in the 21st floor. To say the views were spectacular doesn't cover it. Sunrise with downtown, Diamond Head and Waikiki Beach from one lanai and sunset, with the ocean, harbor and western mountains off the second lanai. The downsides: room never really cooled down with the large windows even with drapes pulled during the daytime due to an outdated cooling system (the one in Ali'i was digital and blasted cold air at our touch). Rooms and tower are not as quiet and are older, as are the elevators (which are very crowded), halls, etc. Bathrooms -- unlike the marble ones in Ali'i -- maybe rival what you'd find at a Holiday Inn (Express) and there are NO extra amenities. They charge for the coffee, water, everything. Also, because the front desk serves multiple towers (all but Ali'i), there can be a wait if you need something there. Here you are really paying for the view. All in all, I wouldn't have wanted to spend all nine nights in this tower, but we really enjoyed the ability to savor that view for two days. In the future, I'd still do Ali'i instead, but push for a higher up room for a more complete view.The day we (finally) checked out, we had a hospitality suite, which was nice even though they gave us a key to a room that was already occupied. Luckily we just walked in on their open suitcase on the bed and not on the inhabitants themselves. We had to walk all the way back to the front desk to get another key, but in return they gave us added time in the room and told us just to call them when we left and leave the key in the room.Other things to be aware of when visiting, especially if it's your first time at HHV: As mentioned, drinks and food are expensive, but if you want the luxury of pina coladas by the pool, that's what you can expect. I found drinks weren't all that much less outside the hotel, but food was less. At Hilton, we ate at Village Steak House (courtesy of a $50 dining credit that was part of our package) and Benihana and enjoyed both, but we were also prepared for the bill when we went. Go to the coffee house across the street for a great, inexpensive breakfast like all you can eat pancakes and coffee for $4.99, but get there before 9am or you'll wait on the sidewalk to get in. Skip lunch if you can while you have a drink or two by the pool (or have the free appetizers if you're in Ali'i) then go offsite for dinner. Many restaurants, including some at HHV, have Sunset Specials between 5-6pm and you can get a great deal even at high-end locales. Also, the on-site ABC is a lifesaver for in-room snacks, including sodas, beer, wine and other goodies. Most rooms have at least a mini fridge so it's a great cost saver.I can't stress enough that if you're NOT in Ali'i and have to rely only on the Super Pool, that you do have to get down there by 8:30am to be among the first in if you want a louge chair. Also, if you leave for awhile and try to save your chair with just a towel, the poolside spotters will pick up the towels and you lose your seat. If you must leave for a quick bite or run to your room, leave a paperback book or some sandals on your chair -- we never had a problem doing that. They have to enforce it to be fair, but if you're planning to party at night and sleep in late, you can just expect to head to the beach because all the pool chairs are taken by 9am. We're early risers, so this wasn't a problem. Note also that the vendors on the beach charging to rent lounge chairs, rafts, etc. are NOT Hilton employees. They are not trying to gouge their guests (at least not on the beach). This is a public beach and you'll find those types of stands all the way down Waikiki so I'm always surprised when people on this board complain about that practice in front of HHV.Also, the free torch-lighting show each night was nice -- I recommend catching that over the big Friday Show, which was disappointing. You will wait in line to pay $10 for a hand stamp to get in and that will score you ONE drink per person, whether it's soda or a mai tai. And that's even for Standing Room Only. Alcoholic drinks by the pool during the day, or in other bars at night, are less than $10 so this isn't a value. The show was just an extended version of the one that is performed every night without the drink charge and the crowds. We also RAN up to our room at the end to enjoy the fireworks so we could benefit from the view. I can honestly say that if you blink you'll miss them! Maybe it was that one night, but literally less than five were blown off and it was over. From the 21st floor, we could hear people on the beach screaming, Is that it? If you want a show go to a luau instead (we loved the one at Paradise Cove) and wait for the 4th of July if you want fireworks. : )All in all, we loved the Village atmosphere and the feeling of luxury and relaxation we felt, especially as guests in the Ali'i Tower. We saw no signs of renovation or wear in that building or in our room, as another reviewer mentioned, but if you're concerned you should fax ahead to the hotel and request a renovated room. I also recommend that if you eat off-property, utilize either the Ali'i Concierge or the AmEx Travel Service desk in the Rainbow Tower lobby. They really have connections. With every dinner reservation they made for us, we had the BEST table in the restaurant (while others waited a long time for lesser seating) and were treated like VIPs. It really makes a difference in the experience.Most of all, remember you're there to treat yourself if you're at HHV, so go for the best and you'll get what you pay for. If you try to do it on the cheap, you'll be disappointed. I'm sure due to its size, other smaller properties may have superior service (Halekulani), but their standard non-view room rates are generally more than HHV's Ali'i Tower rooms and you don't get the more isolated end of the beach or the beautiful grounds and premium location away from crowded Waikiki. Those are HHV's greatest assets.I suggest do it right at the Hilton your first time to Honolulu and find ways while you're there to save money the next time you go back (lots of condos with kitchenettes can be rented for less than $200/night if you know where to look). We miss what became our beautiful Island home and can't wait to return! Aloha.  
<Date>Nov 23, 2004

):1	1360(info):1	1395(honolulu):1	1406(deck):1	1430(poolside):1	1465(premium):1	1524(benefit):1	1549(outdated):1	1579(fourth):1	1678(occupy):1	1728(courtesy):1	1741(lanai):1	1753(stress):1	1757(scream):1	2077(unlimited):1	2142(button):1	2327(rely):1	2468(isolate):1	2501(drape):1	2503(daytime):1	2536(fax):1	2647(sandal):1	2753(ability):1	2755(awhile):1	2928(fireworks):1	2950(rainbow):1	3047(fort):1	3330(kiosk):1	3351(relieve):1	3370(raft):1	3416(digital):1	3495(halekulani):1	3696(hhv):1	4074(condos):1	4199(lavish):1	4303(ali):8	4355(enforce):1	4559(rival):1	4913(21st):2	6478(kitchenett):1	7409(benihana):1	8040(savour):1	9844(inadvertently):1	12345(inhabitant):1

<Author>m180
<Content>I mught as well have had a smoking room afterall I recently stayed at the Hilton for 7 nights. In a deluxe Ocean View room in the Rainbow tower. Whilst my room was big and spacious and the view excellent the walls were so thin I could hear my neighbours the whole time. Also my room was a non smoking room however the room next door was not and whenever someone in that room happened to be smoking the smell came into my room under the gap in a connecting door. I really can't see why the whole floor wasn't non smoking and not just certain rooms on each floor.

<Author>vbesanty
<Content>Hilton - Just Disappointing We just got back from the spending one week at HHV in Oahu in the Rainbow Tower for our honeymoon. We spent one week at the Ritz in Maui before heading out to Oahu. I called the Hilton before departing Maui to remind them that I would be arriving in their hotel in the afternoon and we had requested a high floor in the Rainbow Tower with an ocean view room (based on the reviews I read on this website) and reminded them that it was our honeymoon. When we got their, first Go-Go travel lost one of our suitcases (which was not the Hilton's fault). The bell man had a major attitude (which I really didn't want to deal with after finding out that my Go-Go had lost our bag.) Then we proceeded to wait on line to check in for about 40 mintues. Once I got to the front desk I reminded them again that I had called earlier and we are honeymooners. To make a long story short, I get up to the room to find 2 twin beds. I immediately called the front desk and they were unwilling to change the room, saying that they don't gurantee bedding. After a long argument they were able to find a king bed on the 30th floor. But of course they asked me to stand on line again which was way longer then the 40 minute line I was previously on. Overall, I was very disappointed with the stay. The only good thing about our stay was the views from our room of the ocean and diamond head. We ate at the Golden Dragon and the woman that served us was a snob. After that we decided we would eat outside of the hotel. We didn't mind paying the prices in the hotel resturants which are very much like New York, we just felt we should get good service for those prices. We walked over to the Halekulani and realized we had made a big mistake by selecting Hilton for our stay. I am a HHonors member and will never go back to a Hilton. The problem is the hotel is way to big to offer good personalized service which is what honeymooners look for. Next time going back to Maui and will skip Oahu.  
<Date>Nov 19, 2004

<Author>Boeing767
<Content>Grounds Spectacular; Service only adequate If you are into mega-resorts, and don't care too much about spit-and-polish service this place is for you. Several well-kept pools, a huge array of restaurants, shopping and activities. The service is always given with a smile, but is detached, and rigid.As another poster mentioned, upgrades are not handed out freely - we are Hilton Diamond Level members, and couldn't even get a sniff of the Ali`i Tower. The junior suites in the Diamond Head tower are laid out in such a way that the sleeping area is in the front, with no windows or natural light, the sitting area is in the back toward the lanai. We stay there when we have points to spend (we live on Oahu, but we like an occasional visit to a beachside hotel), but if we are spending money, the Royal Hawaiian has superior service.  
<Date>Nov 1, 2004

<Author>UkCarlos
<Content>Perfect We stopped at this hotel from 6th October for 7 nights and got married at the hotel on the 6th night. We stayed in the Kalia Tower which has it鈥檚 own pool/sun terrace on the 4th floor (same floor was the fitness center and spa). The view of the village, lagoon, beach  sea was fantastic from our balcony. As this was our wedding/honeymoon we stayed in four different hotels on our trip and this was the best we stayed in. The gardens and wildlife located all around the hotel are brilliant. This is one hotel we would like to re-visit  recommend to friends. The hotel is located towards the quieter end of Waikiki beach, which we really enjoyed as it is only a short walk to the centre. We did eat evening meals in six of the restaurants and enjoyed the different styles of cuisine. Don't forget to use the restaurant/shop discount voucher book handed to you at check-in!Small criticisms would be that we had to pay a daily charge to use the in room safe, restaurants within the village can be on the expensive side, the Super Pool is suppose to be the largest pool in Waikiki but it isn鈥檛 really that big, small fee to access e-mail and receive faxes.

<Author>Pamcakes0111
<Content>Talk about class! What an amazing place! My family and I went to the Hilton Village and stayed there for 4 days in August 2004. We were in the Alai Tower (excuse my misspelling!). This tower, so I hear, has the best service and VIP services of all the towers in the village. We had our own private pool/hot tub area on a private outdoor deck only for guests staying in that tower. It had a full bar along with nightly appetizers (cold and hot) and our own gym! The deck overlooked the beach as well as a view of the Hilton grounds. Shopping? Not a problem! We didn't ever have to leave the resort for great shopping with stores like Coach, Louis Vuitton, Gucci, cute little gift shops, tons of restaurants on-premise (everything from Sushi to sandwiches and fries). It was luxury at its finest with chocolates on the pillows, marble bathrooms with every amenity (including a mini TV so you can watch while getting ready for the day or for brushing your teeth at night!). I felt like royalty. The amazing views, food and services were extraordinary. Complete with penguins, coy ponds and exotic animals just feet from the hotel tower entrance the property is beautiful, clean and also very romantic! Definitely worth the extra money!

<Author>shedeez
<Content>Wonderful Place to Stay!! My husband and I spent 7 nights at HHV, 10/1-10/8. We wanted to stay at a hotel that was close to where my brother and his family were staying, Hale Koa. HHV is right next door to it. So I decide to sign up for Hilton Honors. When I was booking the reservations on the phone, I mentioned that we had Hilton Honors and asked if we could get an upgrade when we checked in. (we booked a garden view room) The lady told us that mostly like no because we just enrolled and normally upgrades are given to those at highter Hilton Honors level. But she will place that request. We arrived at the hotel late (close to midnight). Our check-in lady was very friendly. She gave us our keys and told us that we were upgraded to a ocean view room in the Kalia tower (11th floor). My eyes immediately light up. I was surprised and happy. She asked us if we wanted the bell hop to take us to our tower, but we insisted that we walked to take the walk instead and enjoy the grounds. The hotel lobby is not that far from the tower. Once we got to our room, we were amazed at the decor. Our room was fabulous. I couldn't ask for anything more. From our balcony, we can see the pool, the village, the rainbow tower, tapa tower, lagoon tower, and the ocean. The view was great! The Kalia tower has it's own pool on the 4th floor (same floor was the fitness center and spa). The grounds were beautiful and clean. There is an ABC store on the grounds. We only ate at one restaurant, which was the Tapa Cafe. We went here for breakfast on our last day. It was pricey for an all you can eat breakfast. Other than that, HHV is a great place to stay. We are planning to stay here again when we come back in Aug '05.  
<Date>Oct 25, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Hilton OK Me and my wife came to the Hilton Hawaiian Village for our honeymoon for 7 nights. Although the Hilton Hawaiian Village is touted as being the best hotel in Honolulu, I beg to differ. First and foremost they did not upgrade our hotel room upon arrival despite the fact that I am a Hilton Honors customer. Second, to be perfectly honest I did not really like the entertainment, let me put it this way it wasn't too entertaining. My suggestion is to avoid the restaurants in the hotel, they are too expensive and not very good. The staff at the hotel are always looking for tips so I would avoid asking for too many amenities. The maids did clean our rooms regularly, which was a plus. Overall our trip wasn't too bad, but I definetly will not stay at the Hilton again.  
<Date>Oct 21, 2004

<Author>Tonya
<Content>Amazing! We recently returned from a 10 night stay in Hawaii. We stayed at HHV for 5 of those, from 9/29-10/3. We had reserved a room in the Ali'i tower several months ago, luckily I checked the rates 10 days before we left and found a package deal that would give us 10,000 bonus HHoners points, a free spa bath robe, and a room upgrade if available, AND was $30 less per night than the previous reservation. So I cancelled our first reservation and re-booked this package. We were celebrating our 10th anniversary, so my husband faxed in a request to have a room on the 8th floor or higher with a view of Diamond Head (someone on Hawaii travel board suggested this). When we arrived, the girl that checked us in was very nice, I could tell she was taking her time reading everthing on her screen, she said she was trying to find us a great room, and she did. We were given a corner room on the 10th floor (1005, I believe). We had a wrap around balcony, with a great view of Diamond Head on one side and the ocean on the other. Needless to say we were thrilled. I enjoyed laying on the chaise lounge each night looking at the stars and listening to the waves. If you didn't want to you would not have to leave the property, there is everything from an ABC store to Louis Vuitton. The propery was beautiful and very clean. The Ali'i Tower has it's own hot tub and swimming pool, as well as fitness center. We did use the hot tub a lot, but I usually laid out by the Super Pool. Another advantage of the Ali'i Tower was the free appetizers 5-7, we did take advantage of this a couple of nights. We ate lunch at the resort a couple of times, and got pizza for dinner one night, but we did not eat at any of the restaurants although we had intentions to do so. Since it is a resort we knew the food prices would be steep and they were about $10 for a cheeseburger. We kept snack and breakfast foods as well as drinks in our room. Since we did not take advantage of the $100 Hilton Dollars timeshare offer to start with, we came in on the second day and had a nice invitation giving us $200 Hilton dollars if we would spend 90 minutes for the presentation. We did the tour, and I had fun spending the money. We can not imagine staying anywhere else the next time we are lucky enough to go to Hawaii, definitely spoiled on our first trip!  
<Date>Oct 16, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>HHV - OK, but nothing to write home about. Food overpriced Stayed at the HHV for a conference, and took a few extra days to do some sightseeing around Oahu and the Big Island. The HHV is great for conferences, and has a wonderful location - right on the beach and handy for both Waikiki and Honolulu (I don't understand the criticisms of Waikiki being too far away - it is only a 5-minute walk from the HHV to the main shops in Waikiki).On the downside, though, the HHV felt very much like a theme park without the rides. Not the place for an authentic Hawaiian experience, but I guess you wouldn't come to Waikiki for that anyway. Charging for coffee in the room strikes me as penny-pinching in the extreme, and not a measure to inspire return visits. Food on-site was vastly over-priced and rather over-rated. CJ's deli was OK but expensive. Much better to go to the coffee shop over the road from the HHV, though the staff there are rather inattentive. Staff at HHV were OK, but I did continually get the feeling that they were doing me a favour by letting me stay there. Payed almost $3 for one of the worst cups of coffee I have ever had at the Tapa bar. Nightly entertainment was mainly fairly poor, and mostly unncessary - just serve good food and drink and allow people to soak up the atmosphere of being in Hawaii.  
<Date>Oct 14, 2004

<Author>DuniaC
<Content>I would go back in a heartbeat We stayed in the kalia tower in July 04. It was 2 children and myself. The grounds of the hotel were superb. There was a lot to do and see in and around the hotel. Food was way over priced. I would recommend the coffee shop across the street from the hotel. All you can eat pancakes for $4.00. The super pool was always crowded but the tower we stayed in had its on swimming pool that was perfect on the rooftop of our tower. The kids enjoyed swimming there. Beach was awesome we never had a problem finding a spot. Staff was always very friendly. We loved the hotel, worth the extra money to be right on the beach. I 'd stay there again in a heartbeat.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Hilton Stay O.K. We stayed at Hilton for 4 nights for the last part of our honeymoon in September. We had a huge room in the Ali Towerand a giant wrap around balcony over the roof of a lobby(and some penguins!). The Ali Tower has private access to the Ali Tower pool. This was nice since we really didn't want to be near screaming kids and a ton of families at the main pool. We did not get upgraded and the hotel was definitely not full. This was our 3rd trip to Hawaii and I thought the hotel overall was O.K. Too busy and overstimulating for my tatse. I love Oahu... there is so much to do and beautiful beaches on the North Shore(must go there). Make sure this hotel is what you are looking for. The service was good and staff was helpful. No major problems just not what we were looking for.

<Author>Luv2Travel
<Content>Hilton Hawaiian Village is great!!! My husband and I just returned from a 9 night stay at the HHV. We were there 9/9/-9/18. We had no problems with check-in, Alii tower has its own front desk. We stayed in an ocean view room in the Alii' Tower. The room was great, and it had a great lanai. There is maid service 3 times a day, and the Alii tower has its own pool for Alii guests only. The private pool was the best part, the super pool is too crowded. In regards to the food, there is many restaraunts to choose from on the property. My husband and I are picky eaters, and didn't care for some of the restaraunts. A few of the restaraunts we tried were: The Golden Dragon-Chinese,Sergios-Italian, and Hatsuhana-Japanese. They were all ok, I was just not impressed. There's the Wailana coffee shop across the street, this no frills restaraunt is great for good tasting breakfast at a cheap price. Lunch we had by the pool, RoundTable Pizza, Hamburgers etc...We usually ventured outside of the hotel for dinner. 3660 on the rise is an excellent restaraunt, the concierge can make the reservations. Also, the Cheesecake Factory on Kalakaua St. is good. The weather in Honolulu was wonderful, occasional showers but that's normal in Hawaii. Overall, the Hilton Hawaiian Village is a great place to stay when in Honolulu.  
<Date>Sep 22, 2004

<Author>Sdevisse
<Content>All In All We loved the hotel but..... Well it certainly has the best spot in the resort. My husband and I spent a week at the HHV having been to Vegas and we wished we'd spent our whole 2 weeks in Hawaii. Don't know why there are reviews complaining about paying for the coffee in the room - we had coffee and didnt pay! The rooms are lovely and spacious. We awoke to a horrible drilling noise the first morning we were there (works going on in the spa) and the duty manager moved us to the 20th floor of our tower without any problems at all and gave us a complimentary breakfast. The buffet was disappointing and somewhat expensive - we paid around 拢30 for a plate of salad and a lukewarm curry! Benihana is well worth a visit and is a lot cheaper than the one in London. I have read a lot of complaints about the prices of food - its a huge resort so venture out and eat in Waikiki itself - we only had 2 meals in the hotel but had wonderful meals elsewhere with Bubba Gumps, Red Lobster and the Cheesecake Factory a short walk away. There is a fab ABC store onsite that sells snacks and drinks at really reasonable prices too.Staff at the hotel were lovely and it is a truely beautiful hotel with its gardens, flamingos and even penguins - oh and make sure you go to the sealife centre and swim with the dolphins when you are there - i would recommend this hotel to anyone - you get what you pay for and coming from the UK we are used to paying high prices so HHV wasnt that pricy really. We are already planning our next visit.  
<Date>Sep 13, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>troubles in paradise My family and friends recently stayed 7 nights at HHV. Very slow check in and check out, even for a Diamond level status with Hilton Honors. One room was infested with ants, staff tried to rationalize that this is a tropical environment. Insects remained throughout stay as staff unable to move both rooms to a different floor. Ice machine was not functioning for several days, billing issues with restaurants (expensive too!), communications appear to be an issue. Requested manager but only able to communicate through staff. Property is beautiful but problems with staff nagged throughout the stay. Totally unexpected for a resort property.

<Author>BigHarleyDog
<Content>If you're single, be forewarned, it's familyland. No nightlife! I just stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village for a week on business. This is truly a family resort, not a good place for any singles looking to mingle. We went down to Duke's or the Outrigger down the beach for bars. Everything around this place shuts down by 10:00 or 11:00PM. Don't get me wrong, the rooms are nice with good views, but the food is all overpriced, and Parking is expensive. When we were checking in, I found the staff at the front desk rude, in fact, the woman helping my colleague walked away for 5-10 minutes during her check in without saying anything. If you decide to stay here, bring your Visa/MC/Amex and Discover, you'll need it. Oh, and lot's of one or five dollar bills, as everyone has their hand out for a tip.  
<Date>Sep 9, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Loved the Ali'i Tower My wife and I wanted to visit Honolulu for 2 days on our way back from Maui. I booked the HHV using my Am. Exp. Platinum card travel services. It cost $260/night with free daily breakfast for 2 and one free lunch. It was a wonderful room (#602) Ali'i Tower: Large, great full view of the ocean with the Hilton pier, robes, slippers, compartmental bathroom, complimentary tropical fruit tray, orchid on the bed after the bed is turned down for the night, ice in the bucket before you even check in, EVERY employee was friendly (without being obnoxious), pool and gym for Ali'i Tower only, huge Koi ponds, penguins (!).The place is huge and you may not feel like leaving the premises (which is probably good for families with children). We are a young couple but did not feel cramped by the crowds or children. I can鈥檛 comment on the other towers but the Ali鈥檌 room was so nice we didn鈥檛 leave the room on the first day except to go for lunch and dinner. We just sat out on the lanai reading or admiring the beauty of the beach and water. The furniture was not outdated and I would recommend the hotel to anyone.

<Author>Vegas
<Content>Hilton- nice, but not great We had a 3 night stay in the rainbow tower this August, room 928. It was a corner room/ king bed with 2 balconies over-looking the grounds in one direction and the pool/beach in the other. It was very clean and a great room. Got in through costco travel at a lower that the advertised internet rate. I would definitely recommend the rainbow tower over the others and I would also request a room no lower than the 9th floor. The beach is crowded in front of the Hilton but the area just to the left of the Hilton is a public park and very nice. The pool closes very early so they can put on a cheesy hawaiian show by the pool. I would rather have the pool stay open. The place is packed with families, mostly Japanese, so forget a romantic and quiet spot, but waikiki is not a romantic place in general.  Definitely eat off property, too costly otherwise.  They have a abc store in the village which is very convenient and reasonable. Staff is not overly friendy, but meets the minimum for service.Overall, a good place to stay if you have to go to waikiki.  
<Date>Aug 28, 2004

<Author>valdereevaldera
<Content>It was just what we wanted! We spent two nights at the HHV on 8/17-8/18, and had a wonderful time. Traveling with our 8 year old son, my husband and I were looking to relax by the pool, on the beach and in the room - we wanted a hotel that was self-contained and did not want to be wandering around Oahu this time. HHV was perfect for that!We staggered up to the check-in desk and must have looked so pathetically jetlagged that we got upgraded from a garden-view room to an ocean view room on the 8th floor of the Rainbow Tower. Fabulous location! Gorgeous view, close to the beach and pools. Even easy to get across the street to the ABC store, Round TAble Pizza and Lappert's Ice Cream...We had the buffet at the Rainbow Tower for breakfast - pretty pricey and definitely skewed toward Asian tastes (ie, no oatmeal, but rice). I would agree that the hotel is definitely geared to serve Asian families..guessing that 75% of the guests were from Japan.I was (naively?) surprised to see LOTS of people smoking everywhere. UGH.Great shave ice at the little stand on the beach just past Tropics Bar and Grill (where we ate a decent not exorbitant lunch)A real plus is the beautiful beach. Gentle waves, very kid friendly and calm, just a little stronger in the aft for budding boogie-boarders. We were in the water every chance we got.If I was looking just to settle in at a hotel on Waikiki and save the sightseeing for another island, I would definitely pick HHV again!  
<Date>Aug 27, 2004

<Content>Home away from home We went twice to Oahu this summer June 26 to July 7, 2004. Brought the whole family including 2 grand children. <Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Couldn't Ask for Anything More My husband and I stayed at the Hilton between Aug. 11 and Aug. 15 and had a wonderful time. Upon checkin we were upgraded to an oceanview room in the Tapa tower and also given free breakfast for each day of our stay at the Rainbow Lanai for being Hilton Honors members. The room was nice, the view breathtaking and the hotel grounds so much fun to explore. The eating options onsite are overpriced but we did eat at the Golden Dragon and it was very good but overall I would advise others to look elsewhere for food. There is a great coffee shop across the street from the Kalia tower that has reasonable prices and excellent food. Also if you walk just a few blocks from the hotel you will find tons of inexpensive chains and fast food places. Just a warning though...if you are looking for a quiet, laid back vacation you might want to avoid this place. Its very busy and crowded and overflowing with families with small children. It didn't bother us at all but I could see where some people could find the HHV less than relaxing.

<Author>WeddingLady
<Content>Great family trip We just returned from a 6 night stay at the HHV with our two boys 5 and 8 yrs. old and it will not be our last visit. We had a wonderful time and it is a great property for families. My husband is a Hilton Honors member and it narrowed down our selection process. We were upgraded to a Jr. suite in the Diamond Head tower with a huge patio (you could have a party of 15ppl on it) overlooking the ocean and side beach area. We had a king bed with separate full living area and fold out sofa. We spent every evening just sitting out on our patio while our boys slept listening to the waves and looking at the stars. The staff was very accomodating in all aspects. The penguins, fish and birds were a huge hit with my boys. We were prepared for the high price of food, but luckily had free continental each morning for the four of us (beverage, donuts, bagels, cereals, amazing fruit and yogurt). It was not very crowded to me. We never waited for an elevator and the beach was never too crowded. The pool area chairs filled up early, so we didn't always have access to seating, but we were in the water most of the time. The kid's club was a welcome treat for the boys and they spent two days there from 8:30am-3:00pm. Very well staffed, kid related and full of activities for them. It gave us time for golfing, shopping and the spa. The Mandara Spa is fantastic. I love to have massages and they do every aspect right. All five of the ladies who joined me were impressed. As long as you expect to spend money while in Hawaii, you will not be disappointed with the HHV. The closing perk was we reserved a hospitality check out room one day prior to our leaving, so on check out day we had valet store our luggage we beach it all day and at 4:00pm we checked into a standard room and they gave us until 5:20pm (20 minutes per guest in the room) to cleanup and get ready for our flight home. It made for a very pleasant ending. Don't waste your money on any of the airport shuttles. They were terrible. The taxi was cheaper for the 4 of us and much more time efficient. Aloha!  
<Date>Aug 19, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>We were in awe of the Hilton Hawaiian Village We stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village back in June for 2 weeks. We were on our honeymoon and after travelling for almost 24 and inevitably jet-lagged we were in awe of this fantastic hotel! I read other peoples comments on this site and cannot understand the complaints abour prices etc. This is the Hilton we're talking about here! I know it's expensive, but you somehow expect it! We too ate at the 'Wailana' coffee house across the road. 'Sergio's' Italian restaurant was wonderful, be sure to ask for Paul, we explained that we were on our honeymoon and we were presented with a Tiramisu dessert on the house with candles! We had a wonderful time and the staff were fantastic  courtious. We can't wait to go back and I certainly won't be staying at any other hotel but the Hilton!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Wish We Were Back! Our family of 4 spent 5 nights at the HHV in July, 2004 and absolutely loved it! It was our first stop in Hawaii and we didn't want to leave. We stayed in the Ali'i Tower, there was fresh fruit in the room on arrival, and the room was serviced at least twice a day with bottled water, chocolates and flowers left in the room in the evening. From our partial ocean front room we could see the ocean and the super pool and every night there is a half hour show with hula dancers and we could watch it poolside or right from the balcony. At night my daughter loved to sit on the balcony and listen to the music from the lounge off the lobby. Everyone was very friendly and helpful - Ali'i Tower was easy to check into, because it has it's own check-in versus the main lobby for the other towers. My son loved the penguins, parrots and fish, including the penguin feeding. There is an ABC store right at the resort for snacks, drinks, etc, and plenty of restaurants to choose from. Food is, of course, pricey, we ate at The Golden Dragon which is supposed to be one of the top Chinese Restaurants on Oahu, however, we found it to be just average Chinese food, and dinner for 4 was $160. Luckily there are plenty of places that are a short walk or drive from the resort - Our favorite was Brew Moon in the Ward Center.The only thing I would not recommend at the resort is seating for the Friday evening show. The show is good. It is located poolside. To sit by the pool there is a one drink minimum - no problem - except drinks are $10 and that's for kids too! OK - still no problem that's still cheap for a good show - but there were so many seats reserved for members of the frequent guest club, that the seats that were left for the rest of us, weren't too great. I ended up having to go stand somewhere in order to see. In addition, you waited about an hour on line for the seating to open. It's not that I'm not recommending the show - but save the $10 pp and just watch it just beyond the pool area or better yet from your balcony if it's facing the pool (our's was, and I wish we had done that).I was worried before we went that because of it's size it would feel very crowded, that was not the case, it had a fun, bustling resort feel, but definitely didn't feel over crowded. Valet parking was efficient and quick. Completely positive experience.Wish we were back!  
<Date>Aug 14, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>A City Unto Itself My husband and I stayed at the HHV while he was attending a conference in late July. I, too, had read many reviews and comments before leaving for Hawaii. Thanks to those who had warned about the no free coffee in room, we brought our own favorite Green Mountain coffee and just used their sugar, which I am happy to report they didn't charge us for. As a public relations professional, I find it incredible that they continue to charge (and relatively quite a bit) for the coffee packets in the rooms. This one little detail has been written about here and on other sites -- and does much more damage to their reputation than if they would simply provide one or two packs in the rooms FREE of CHARGE. Sure, they could charge if you used more than your allotted one or two packs a day -- but it really is cheap of them and in the end, puts a damper on an otherwise splendid and pretty much well-deserved reputation. It is a huge place -- a city unto itself complete with post office. I prefer the quiet, out of the way places -- but at times, these mega resorts are also fun. The convention was fairly big, so it seemed the place was even more bustling than usual. When we first arrived, they had us down for a room with two double beds. Talked about a downer. Nothing like being in the realm of paradise with the one you love, and two double beds. After asking to see the manager, they put us into a full ocean view room in the Tapa Tower (33rd floor) and yes, it had a king bed. So all's well that ended well. We are Hilton Honors members and have been for awhile, which is why I think they honored our request with an upgrade (we were supposed to have a partial ocean view). All in all, you really have to work to be disappointed in paradise. And although crowded and pricey, the resort is in great shape and they take meticulous pride in the property. It was a great stay. Aloha!  
<Date>Aug 10, 2004

<Author>AJSG
<Content>Beautiful hotel but on site restaurants expensive We stayed at the Hawaiian Village for three nights July 12-15. We were in the Rainbow tower which is on of the best located, it is close to beach and pool. The hotel and grounds are beautiful, we were upgraded to an ocean view that was truly lovely. The only complaint that I can make is the cost of the food on the premises. (i.e 2 hot dogs 2 drinks  1 order of fries $25US. Across the street is a very good coffee shop with a $4.99 all you can eat pancake  egg breakfast. We noticed many guests of the HHV going to the coffee shop . We would definitely stay there again and just limit eating on the premises.

<Author>tlwhidby
<Content>Paradise We stayed at the Hilton from July 22 to July 27. We were booked in the Rainbow Tower oceanfront room. The view from the 23rd floor was beautiful. You could see the ocean, Diamond Head, the pools and look all the way down the beach. Be sure to become a Hilton Honors member so you can use the express check in. The lines were very long durning peak arrival times. As for the resort everything was beautiful. It is well kept. It was an adventure just within the resort itself. You have beautiful greenery and not to mention all of the birds and fish. I do have to agree that they should not charge for the in room coffee and water. For what you pay for the room the least they could do is give you some coffee. All in all the stay was wonderful. We walked the beach and found out that we had the most beachfront and the best sand on Waikiki Beach. If you venture out of the resort, there are alot of restaurants to eat at that are not that expensive. Yes, I am ready to go back and I would stay at the Village again.  
<Date>Aug 6, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Convenient but bring your Visa card I just got back from a combined business/pleasure trip at the HHV. Ordinarily, I wouldn't be interested in a hotel you can spend your whole vacation at; however, my wife and I brought our infant son, and that definitely changes things! For families with young children, it's very nice to be able to access everything you need at the hotel-- multiple restaurants, a grocery store, pool, beach, etc. I agree with the previous reviewer, however (probably from the same conference) who felt nickled and dimed. Be prepared to pay top dollar for the coffee in your room, rentals for beach chairs and umbrellas, etc.-- or to go buy that stuff at the ABC store on site. I don't know whether that's a Waikiki thing or a HHV thing. In general, the staff were very friendly but some of the pool attendants were downright rude. I think that if you must stay in Waikiki, the HHV is about as good as it gets, but next time I'm going to go off the beaten path and try something a little quieter and more down to earth.  
<Date>Aug 5, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Alii Tower is a MUST! We stayed here during the APA conference from 7/28 - 8/2. It is like a mini Disneyland (without the rides) and yes there were A LOT of people. The hotel has around 4,000 rooms, so just beware that in the high season, there will be crowds. The Alii Tower is the only way to go (espcially if you are without kids). Our room was really nice, very comfortable and the private pool  fitness center provided a small sanctuary away from the masses. There are 22 restaurants in this Village, some are great, some could use new chefs: The Rainbow Lanai breakfast is pricey ($20 per person), but has one of the best omlette stations I have ever had. The Golden Dragon restaurant is great Chinese with such gracious service. Sergios's is an Italian restaurant that is okay, but much to expensive for too little flavor. No matter how good people say the Village Steak  Seafood is, don't get sucked in...we though we could have been eating leftovers.One more thing, if you do get enticed by the special invitation to tour the Vacation Club (AKA timeshare) make sure you have enough time left on your trip to spend the Hilton dollars you earn (we were given $200) and make the sales rep stick to the 90 minute time frame (ours when over by an hour). If you need a break from the sun and heat, it is a great way to get free money (or golf or spa treatment if you select that gift).  
<Date>Aug 5, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>a mixed bag I went to the HHV for a conference, and read a lot of reviews before I went. The reviews prepared me steep prices and crowds -- but I still felt like I was nickle and dimed everytime I turned around. It is so crowded that you wait in line for everything -- a towel for the pool, to speak to a concierge, to buy a drink. Not the relaxing atmosphere I associate with Hawaii. I've never in my life stayed in a place that charged for a cup of coffee in the room or to use the fitness center or even to make a local call. Even the crummiest motel serves a free cup of coffee. The beach and pool are pretty and we met some nice families so our child had playmates, but the hotel itself was irritating. The staff were not particularly friendly or helpful. We had a mountain view room in Kalia Tower. There were mountains, but the traffic was so loud you couldn't open the door or sit on the balcony. This is my fourth trip to Hawaii, though the first to Honolulu. My advice is to skip the HHV all together and get a nice condo off the beaten path. It will be cheaper and you will have a much more satisfactory Hawaii experience.  
<Date>Aug 4, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Stayed here for business and thought it was great I stayed at HHV from July 6-10 while on business in Honolulu. I was traveling by myself on business and booked the HHV throught the Amex Platinum Card Fine Hotels and Resorts program. I booked a garden view room for $180 a night in the Alii Tower. Upon check in I was upgraded to a very nice oceanview king room on the 5th Floor which was very spacious with a sitting area with a couch and 2 chairs as well as a spacious lanai. The bathroom was very large and in addition the minibar there was a small bar size refrigerator where you could store you own drinks or food. The amex program afforded me not only the upgrade but also 2 lunches at the Rainbow Lanai, free breakfast daily as well as a 4pm check-out (that I didn't need).The resort is massive and a bit Disney but its very well run and if you have kids (I will be returning in November with my husband and 5 year old son) it is perfect. There is a large and relatively uncrowded beach in front of the Hilton with very warm and swimmable water. The Alii Tower has its own pool which was not crowded during the time I was there. They had a terrific free firework show over the beach on Friday night and I understand they do it every Friday. They also had a little hula show every night at the big pool ( which you can see from the oceanview bar deck of the Alii Tower). It's kind of corny but fun. Also the Alii Tower has free appetizers every night between 5pm and 7pm. Nothing fancy but they have cheese, crackers, veggies w/ dip, eggrolls, meatballs, etc.. Definitely a hearty snack if your inclined and for the little ones it can be a complete meal.Dining at the Village can be expensive or not depending on what you choose. Also, as you stroll towards diamond head on the beach path you will encounter several outdoor concessions that sell hot dogs, ice cream, shave ice for very good prices. You coud spend alot here but you don't have to. Also, there is an ABC store on the property which I thought was very reasonable. I bought a bottle of Kendall Jackson Chardonnay for $12.99 about the same as in a grocery store in CA.Overall this is not a romantic, secluded old hawaii experience but it is alot of fun and kids will love it.  
<Date>Jul 26, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Loved our view My husband and our two boys age 10  15 stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village from 7/18/04 to 7/24/04. We were in the Rainbow tower room 403. Our view of the ocean and Diamond Head were outstanding. We loved the the way that we could see the boys on the beach from our balcony. The room was very nice and had a small fridge, iron board, iron and hair dryer. The room seemed newer and was extremely clean and pretty. We did not have much sun on our balcony so if this is a plus to you then you should request this room. My sister and her family stayed in 402 across the hall and they had sun on their balcony all day long. Their room stayed very warm where as ours was nice and cool. They also has a view of the lagoon not the ocean. Hopefully you like to walk if you stay here because you do a lot of walking anywhere you go. The beach is nice but the price of renting the chairs and umbrella is unreasonable. $12.00 per each chair and $20.00 for the umbrella plus tax per day! I believe that the Hilton should provide these to their guests. Self parking is $12.00 a day and valet is $17.00 a day. The bar in the middle of the hotel (I believe it was called the Topia bar?) has wonderful Strawberry Daquiris. The best I have ever had! The mixed drinks run around $8.00 each. Not bad since they are large and have all the bells  whistles with them (little drink umbrella, slice of fruit etc..) I was disappointed that all but one swimming pool closed at 8pm. The one pool stayed open until 10pm. I believe that they should have their pools open longer for the kids to enjoy. Go to the ABC store which is on the grounds and pick up supplies when you get there. Bottles of coke are $1.00 compared to $2.50-$4.00 at the restaurants. A blow-up raft for the kids was $3.99 (much cheaper than renting one for $10.00 a day at the beach area) The staff was great. Very helpful and nice. On the beach you can buy snow cones reasonably priced and the kids loved them. The Tropics snack bar had a hamburger combo for $10.75, nachos for $7.75 and curly fries for $3.75. So bring lots of cash if you want to eat at the Hilton. If you go offsite, the Jack in the box (1 1/2 blocks away) has a good breakfast for $4.19 and there are McDonalds only 2 blocks away from the hotel. We went to Benihana's Jappanese Steak House (right on the Hilton site) one night for dinner and it was great. $18.50 for chicken and around $25-30 for the steak. I loved it but my one son and husband did not. Best service there. To get the real feel for Hawaii you must rent a car and go exploring. Leave the city congestion and take the street that runs around the island. We stopped at one scenic outlook and it was amazing. My sons walked out onto old lava by the ocean, I will never forget the view there. We also visited SANDY BEACH one day and my sons boogie boarded there. They had at least 10-20 foot waves hitting the shore. They had a great time. (dangerous if you can't swim or are not strong though) We went snorkeling at Hanauma Bay , beautiful and fun! Get there early. We got there at 7:30 AM and had no wait but by the time we left at around 12 noon there was about a 3 hour wait to get into the park. This was worth it. The water is clear, calm and the fish were plentiful. Rent the dry snorkel, it is worth the extra $3.00 they charge for it. We paid 1.00 to park, and 5.00 each to get into the park and 9.00 each to rent snorkel, mask and fins. Bring lots of suntan lotion and make sure someone puts lots on the back of your legs and shoulders. We were all red on the back of our legs from floating around in the water. Overall Hawaii was beautiful and the Hilton was a great place to stay. Bring lots of money and enjoy!!!!!  
<Date>Jul 26, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Hilton for Honeymooners!! We honeymooned in Hawaii from June 27th- July 3rd at the Hilton Hawaiian Village- Rainbow Tower- 19th floor. We were thrilled with our whole week at the Hilton! Everyone was very nice and accommodating to us. We had a deluxe oceanfront room with a king size bed. We hardly ever heard anyone in the hallway or in the next rooms. It was very quiet and just what we wanted for our honeymoon! The valet guys were nice and actually carried on a conversation with you while you waited. The wait was not that long. The grounds are clean and very well kept. The beach is clean and not crowded. We felt very safe here and cannot wait to go back in a couple of years. When we left (July 3rd), there was a bunch of people coming in for the holiday weekend, but we left just as they got there! I would highly recommend this place to stay. I am concerned about others who had a bad time here, because we were treated like royalty! There are a lot of things to choose from to do at this village or you can just relax the entire time that you are there! We did a little of both. We loved Benihana's Japanese Steakhouse and for our cheaper meals, we ate at Zippy's down the road ($12 for the two of us!). Try this place, I think that you will love it like we did!! We are looking at a return visit in the near future!  
<Date>Jul 23, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>You Can't Win Em All After spending six glorious nights at the Sheraton in Maui, we spent the last night of our honeymoon here. We were happy to only spend the one night. The room was clean and the grounds are pretty, but the our ocean view was unimpressive since we could see only a sliver of ocean from our lanai. We stayed at the Hilton because the Royal Hawaiian was under construction. The Hilton is huge and rather impersonal; it is definitely less charming than the Royal Hawaiian and it was still very pricey. We love Hawaii and are returning to celebrate our anniversary in January, but we will not be returning to the Hilton.

<Author>We_Love_to_Travel_58
<Content>Why Waikiki? I don't get it? The first question I have to ask is why? Why do you want to go to Waikiki? It's overbuilt. Too many buildings and not enough infrastructure to support it. The traffic is horrible. The smog is bad. I went there to party with some friends. I spent most of my days on the beaches in Kilua and the north shore. I would come back to Waikiki at night only. It's been 8 years since I have been to Oahu and it will be another 8 more before I go back. The beaches in Waikiki are dirty and the water is turbid. It only looks good from far away and in pictures. Well, about the hotel. If you are going to stay here, I would stay at the Hilton Hawaiin Village. The grounds are spread out and the scenery is very nice. The rooms are clean and well maintained. I had very good service. Some people write negative reviews about this complex, but I think you should avoid those reviews, because you may choose a smaller hotel that looks good in the pictures. You will be sorely dissappointed with hotels next to crowded, traffic filled roads and small dingy lobbies. The elevator will always be crowded and you will have to wait forever. Just to inform you, expect to pay for parking. This is a crowded city on an island. Parking is limited. At this hotel, parking cost $12 for self and $17 for valet. In San Francisco parking cost $28 for self and $33 for valet. So I am not bothered by the cost here. I felt it was cheap compared to other big cities. If you come here and you don't rent a car, you are cheating yourself. You should not spend all your time in Waikiki. There are so many beautiful little towns around the island that you won't see with tour buses or by staying in Waikiki. I think most people come here because they are afraid of being bored on the other islands. They should go to Maui. It has a mixture of partying and solitude. It's beautiful. The shopping on Oahu is nothing special. They have a lot of fancy shops mainly for the Japanese tourists. You won't find anything here that you can't buy at home. Well enough said. Enjoy your trip where ever you go. And remember, relax, you earned a vacation and you are paying for it. Don't spend all your time being upset.  
<Date>Jul 23, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>HILTON HAWAIIAN - NEVER AGAIN DONT DO IT TO YOURSELF! I've paid $150 on Priceline for a week 7/12 to 7/19/2004. I was traveling with my wife and an infant son. When we got there, they had put us in room with double beds next to the service elevators. I've complained that I had reserved a room with a king sized bed on the hilton site. They promised me that they'll accomodate us as soon as a king room opened up. 3 days later they moved us to the next side of the elevator into a room with a king bed.They kept saying that they're completely booked. However, when I was at the Front Desk, I'd overheard the couple next to me with a Kama Aina Rate DISCOUNT was UPGRADED to the ALILI Tower. I'm a HH honors member with 10 nights this year and I didn't get ZIP. Rooms are old and musty. Best deal would be the Hawaii Prince and just walk to the beach. <Author>alshin
<Content>Best location on Waikiki I stayed there for 7 days this summer, and I must say that my stay at HHV far exceeded my expectation. I was a little worried at uneven reviews at this site. I booked at their website with the Resort package, which includes free breakfast every day. Daily rate of $279 for a week was not necessarily cheap, but the location and the room that they put us into (top 31st floor of the Rainbow Tower with the whole view of Waikiki) more than compensated. I have kids (6 and 9), and I must assure that, for families, this would be the best place to stay in Waikiki. They have sizable beachfront. Some of the nice hotels do not even have nice beachfront. So many things are going on in the resort itself, with many shops and restaurants. I do not remember any incident that my needs were not immediately met. I would avoid a long weekend, though. As we were leaving at the start of Memorial day weekend, there were mob of people checking in. My kids still ask when we are going back to HHV, and, if we go back within a couple of years, I would definitely choose HHV again.  
<Date>Jul 20, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Not the way to experience Hawaii We visit Hawaii regularly and usually stay at more moderately priced hotels. This time we decided to splurge and stay at the village. We were extremely disappointed. The problem with this hotel is that it is a large complex of buildings that caters to conventions, etc... If you are there on a vacation, you don't feel like you are in Hawaii at all. This is the first time that we returned from Hawaii without that special Hawaii feeling.There are a number of other disadvantages to such a large facility. The attractive looking pool is all full (chairs reserved by other guest) by 9am. Getting your car takes forever, etc., etc. Also, because they cater to business travellers, the staff is not very friendly to tourists. For example, we could not go into the pool with our two year old because they did not allow her to use her floaters. We much prefer some of the smaller hotels on Waikiki and will definitely not be heading back to the HHV.  
<Date>Jul 17, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Trip We made our third trip to Hawaii this summer and stayed at the HHV. I have been reading posts on this website for some time now and decided to enter my opinion. First of all let me say that yes it is on the expensive side. But, I have stayed at many resorts and do not feel it is anymore expensive than other resorts. When you go first class expect to pay for first class. The staff was great. Stayed in the Tapa tower and the room was very nice. The many stores and shops on site are handy and nice attractions. Use the ABC store often. We went to several of the restaurants on site and found the food to be excellent. I will be staying here again on hopefully my fourth trip to the islands at some point.  
<Date>Jul 15, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great time! Well, I went with the previous entry's author so I guess I can't add much to the novel she wrote. In a nutshell, I highly recommend staying at this hotel. Be sure to get at least a partial ocean view or you'll be stuck staring at people walking around within the complex for your view. The beach was packed on July 4th but it was empty the rest of the time. It was clean and the water had some gentle waves (you could definitely still float around in it). Ala Moana and the other end of the beach is an EASY walk...maps will give you a heart attack but the actual walk is pretty short. I'd definitely stay at this hotel again..the staff is very helpful and friendly!

<Author>Patricia6048
<Content>Beautiful, contained, amazing staff, relaxing. The Hilton Hawaiian Village was like a self-contained cruise ship. Everything you wanted was within walking distance in the Village. With multiple pools and the beach, it was easy to find somewhere to go. The staff was helpful and kind, always addressing the guests by name. The onsite American Express staff not only booked all events, but had a solid knowledge on times to go, and best theater seats. All types of food and costs were available or you could hop a bus or trolley to go off site.The suite we stayed in was comfortable for four adults and quiet. I highly recommend the Hilton Hawaiian Village for a single, couple or family vacation. It was worth every penny!!

<Author>BlooBunnie
<Content>Wonderful Time at the Hilton Hawaiian Village 7/3/04 - 7/9/04 Stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village from 7/3/04-7/9/04 and it was great. Finding the main check in desk was a bit of an adventure since we were dropped off at the bus and tour depot instead of the main entrance (that is reserved for taxis and private vehicles). The girl at the check-in counter was very friendly and helpful and provided us with a map of the hotel grounds and directed us to our room. We were placed in a room on the 29th floor of the Tapa Tower with a partial ocean view. We didn't get an upgrade to an ocean view room like we had read about in other TripAdvisor reviews but that's ok. The room was really nice: it was spacious with 2 double beds and a mini-fridge with a kitchen sink. We had an amazing view from our lanai (balcony): we had a view of the beach, the ocean, Diamond Head, and the City. The room was nice and clean as was the bathroom. The only bad thing may have been that the walls were a bit on the thin side and we could hear the people in the room next door to us, we could hear when they flushed the toilet, when they closed the drawers in the bureau, and when they left their room we could hear their room door slam shut pretty loud. But, we didn't spend too much time in the room so it wasn't too bad especially since we had to wake up early most days to go on our island tours. The beach area by the hotel was really nice and not crowded at all as compared to the beachfront by the other hotels. We had taken a walk down Kalakalua Ave. where the bulk of the hotels were located and their beachfronts were JAM-PACKED. It made us grateful that we were staying at the Hilton, especially since we originally were thinking of staying at the Marriott. The walk from the Hilton to the Ala Moana Shopping Mall and the Waikiki Mall and stores wasn't all too bad. Maps make it look like there's a LONG walk but it was only a 15 minute walk in either direction to get to the shopping centers. We didn't ride The Bus or the trolleys. The food at the Hilton restaurants is on the pricey side and you have to dress up in order to eat at the bulk of them so we always ate away from the hotel except for the one time we ate at the Round Table Pizza located in the Rainbow Bazaar. If you are looking for good food, there is a coffee house located across the street from the Hilton: the Wailana Coffee House (good food at good prices ... the first day we went there, there was a LONG waiting line leading outside of the coffee house). You should also eat at (1) the Cheesecake Factory on Kalakaua Ave, (2) The Bubba Gump Shrimp Company at the Ala Moana Mall, (3) Assaggio's at the Ala Moana Mall, and Singha located across from the coffee house. But at Singha's ... don't order the pad thai (I did and it was the saltiest thing I have ever eaten. I complained to the waiter but he said that it was supposed to taste like that ... somehow I doubt that). The restaurants at the Ala Moana Mall were surprisingly REALLY REALLY good, we would definintely recommend eating there. The mall also houses a retaurant named after Jackie Chan but we didn't get a chance to eat there. As for Bubba Gump's Shrimp Company, earlier in the day we passed by one of the shopping malls on Kalakaua Ave. and I took a picture with some guy dressed up like a shrimp and we got a coupon for a free appetizer at the Shrimp Company ! It was big enough to feed 4 people ! The waiters were sooooo nice ! Not like you'd find in some NY restaurants. We did the Grand Circle Island Tour of O'ahu and it was okay but the tour guide only gave us about 5 minutes to take pictures at each stop. We went to Maui for a day and did the Haleakala crater tour and it was great. Much more time to take pictures and wonderful scenery. The flight was only 20 minutes from Oahu to Maui. On the Maui tour, our tour guide was 100% Hawaiian so we all learned how to speak a little Hawaiian and we learned how to properly pronounce the names of the islands and the streets.On Oahu, we also went snorkeling at Hanauma Bay. It was really fun but make sure that you get there as early as you can. It opens at 6 a.m. and by 8 a.m. the lines to get in are long and the bay gets quite crowded, but it's something you should do if you get a chance; do bring a beach towel, beach bag, food and water, and extra sunblock. If you don't bring your own food and water, you'll find that they charge an arm and a leg (for example: a bottle of water is $2.00, fries are $4.00 and a burger is $8.50). We had a late flight (10 p.m.) and we couldn't get a late check-out but that was okay because the hotel will give you a hospitality room. Basically the hospitality room is a regular hotel room that they let you use to freshen up before your flight; each person gets 20 minutes to shower and change into clean clothes so you'd better shower fast ! But it's great that they do that for guests because I don't know of any other hotel that would do that for you. All in all, we would definitely recommend staying at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. It was such a beautiful and clean complex with friendly and helpful employees. It was honestly a pleasure.  
<Date>Jul 12, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Not Bad We spent four nights at the HHV at the end of June and one more night on the way back from Maui. The place is HUGE! Thousands of people roaming back and forth at all hours. It's a major destination for the Japanese - there were a number of large school groups staying there during our visit. Sheena Easton was performing at an outdoor concert for some group one evening.I was shocked to find that the in room safe was not free (a few $$ per day)!! No free in room coffee ($3.95 a pot, $2 a tea bag WOW). Also, every other moment you're being recruited to buy into their timeshare program.The location is a little isolated - not near the main Waikiki shopping strip.Overall the place is very large and rather impersonal.

<Author>bluesky2006
<Content>not for the discriminating traveller Although the grounds are well kept and beautiful, it felt absolutely fake and manufactured. The rooms in the Tappa building were horribly outdated and need remodeling. The pillows are down filled, but the blanket and comforter were cheap motel quality. The 'garden view' on lower floors overlooked not a garden, but a parking garage. The upper floors were much better with a partial view of the ocean, but it took two days of harrassing to change the rooms. Beach was packed and $35 umbrella and chair rental is outrageous. The beach is neither pristine nor relaxing. Skip Waikiki and HHV and head to the smaller islands.On the plus, the hotel staff were very friendly and reponded to all requests and questions on timely manner (except for the room change). and the cocktails were only around $8 , which is better value then the $4 coke. Also, on Fridays they put a good Hawaiian show with fireworks, which anyone can go to.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Beautiful Resort We spent one night at the Hilton Hawaiian Village en route to Maui. I thought it was beautiful--well manicured grounds, lots of upscale shops, and a beautiful beach. A little hassle checking in, but once that was done, all was well. We stayed in the Kalia Tower, and although our view faced the other direction (city streets), the tower is very new and beautiful. My only complaints about the room are that the bathroom counter space was sparse (only a single sink), and there was no coffee pot or blow-dryer. If you are not already, join Hilton HHonors--that allows you to have a free continental breakfast each morning (quite a deal for Hawaii!!). The HHonors lounge in the Kalia Tower is on the 25th floor and has a breathtaking view. It seems there is always something going on at this hotel. Waverunner and boat rentals are available right on the beach. We were there on a Tues. night and saw a neat fire dancing show put on by the hotel. I imagine they do this every night, and it is free. This resort is fabulous. Aloha!  
<Date>Jun 30, 2004

<Author>starnite
<Content>Noisy housekeeping in early hours of morning We booked a partial ocean view room for $205 and were allocated a room on the 16th floor of the Tapa tower. The 'partial' meant that we had to stick our head out of the balcony and look to our left to find the ocean, but it was a pretty view nonetheless. The room was spacious and clean with its own little bar corner and sink. On arrival were give a discount booklet with coupons for the stores in the Hilton - many where they had free things to redeem like a free bag, waterproof case in the shape of the dolphin, pin/pendant (we are trying to get our 200 bucks worth you see). It is easy just to stay inside the Hilton area and not even venture out to Waikiki, after all, it has its own restaurants, ABC store, and the beach as it's backyard. The numerous ponds with big goldfishies, penguins, flamingos and duckies kept my boyfriend fascinated and entertained! The lagoon however, didn鈥檛 seem to have much life in it apart from some small fish - we wondered what it was normally used for. We watched the King's Jubilee and then had dinner at the Rainbow Lanai and saw the fireworks from our table which was next to the giant opening overlooking the beach and next to the duck pond (if you are thinking of booking a luau elsewhere, don鈥檛 bother, just stay at the Hilton, watch the King's Jubilee show which has pretty good hula and other types of dancing, then have dinner at the Rainbow Lanai - Friday night is Hawaiian buffet. plus, you get the fireworks which were pretty good). The buffet dinner was yummo (they have a different theme each night), it cost $31pp but we used the Entertainment Card for 25% off (the info menus in the room have an old pricing on it). We only have one complaint about the Hilton - we could hear housekeeping very early in the morning - the trolleys, talking and banging of the doors - I definately woke up grumpy and spoilt my Hilton experience! We don鈥檛 suggest you stay in the HHV if you wish to explore the sights and sounds of Waikiki since it鈥檚 a decent walk away and you would be leaving a relatively expensive room empty most of the day, not to mention the fact that the grounds of the HHV is so pretty and full of things to do that you might not make it out to see the rest of the town.  
<Date>Jun 30, 2004
<Rating>2	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1

<Author>Out-of-SFO
<Content>Alii Tower Refreshingly Tranquil in Busy Resort Have been going to the islands for years and generally avoid Oahu and opt for other islands, and would prefer Royal or Halekelani if Waikiki bound, but was attending a conference at the Hilton. Initially dreaded it, but Hilton it was. Very careful about room selection (called Alii Tower front desk and talked to them about rooms after research indicated that Alii Tower was probably the best location) and quite pleased with the results and price. Alii Tower is quite nice. Closest to the beach and in the direction of the other hotels. It has the fewest stories, its own private pool and deck area with fitness center that was never crowded even when the main areas of the hotel were swarming with people, private check-in thereby avoiding main lobby, in-building concierge servce, friendly doorman, and several housekeeping visits per day. There is also a terrace cafe next to the pool with buffet breakfast (nominal charge was $14 for adults/ less for kids -- prefer Moana hotel's coffee biz near that' hotel's front door for a bagel/latte and then head outback to beachfront chair in Moana Courtyard when no one is there except the early a.m. surfers -- Aki at one of the beach huts in front of Dukes is a great instructor and it's a blast -- Duke's Breakfast Buffet, while not the greatest, is less... $10 ... than the nominal Hilton charge and included cooked to order eggs) but free pupus b/w 5-7:00 (nothing too special here but nice nonetheless.) From the terrace, there's a nice view of the ocean in both directions and, on the right, the main pool where sunset show/ torch lighting takes place. Our room was on second floor with a nice terrace overlooking the main pool -- Room A226. Plenty big, king bedded and also had a sofa bed. The second floor terraces are deeper than those above, landscaped and have two nice chairs with ottomans as oppposed to the floors above, which have the more typical highrise shallow balconies with tiny chairs and a table. No problem with noise, and I'm sensitive to that. Keycard door to private pool and terrace area, as well as private direct stairway down to the beach were just down the hall. You could avoid the elevators entirely if you wanted to, and in any event didn't have to go up and down and all around to get everywhere. The Room next door ... A227, I believe, is actually considered Ocean Front and has a huge terrace (at least 100 sq.ft.) overlooking the ocean and larger pool area, but then you'd be paying significantly more at which point I'd recommend staying somewhere else (see above). For $225 or below, A226 or the next garden view room over on the main pool side of that hall are very nice and a good deal. You get the added beauty and privacy of all of the foliage from the ground floor plants (palm trees swaying, etc.), so we just left the curtains open most of the time, which you really wouldn't want to do in most rooms. There are some rooms on the same floor (2nd) that are actually accessed via the the private pool terrace, but they are down a few stairs from the pool deck and too low to have much view, hence the garden view designation. But then you would be looking out on lounge chairs and concrete, and they would not be as private either; we'd initially considered those as well but am glad that we went the other way. I'd definitely go back, especially with teens and twenty something year-old kids, but I'd want the same room or the OF A227 if I could get it for a good price. Went to Hanalei, Kauai for the following week and rented a cottage with tons of charm, a mosquito net over the bed and a grill for cooking fish over kiave wood, all of which all reminds me of Waikiki when I was a child. Now that's my paradise -- Aloha! If you're adventurous, visit Chinatown for some Chinese or Vietnamese Food for lunch, the later was great and very inexpensive, and then buy flowers and a lei needle/string ... $4 for a produce size plastic bag of plumeria and the trimmings ... from any one of the lei vending shops, which are all located rights there, and make your own while sitting at the Hilton's Alii Terrace having Mai Tais and pupus.  
<Date>Jun 29, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Don't stay here on your honeymoon!!! I don't know what these people are talking about who enjoyed this place for their honeymoon. It's not romantic at all. If you consider screaming kids and elevators full of conventioners romantic, then I guess this is the place for you. Yes, the grounds are well kept, but it all feels really fake. It has a manufactured atmosphere sort of like a Vegas hotel or something in Disney World. It's probably great if you have kids, but if you are planning a romantic getaway, you can't go wrong with the Halekulani. It's worth it if you can afford it. It's location is cental Waikiki and it has the best ambience for couples.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Don't Judge a Book By Its Cover Looks can be deceiving, such was the case with our recent stay at the HHV. We were assigned an upgraded room in the Kalia Tower at the furthest point from the beach, pools and other activities, but nearest point to the downtown streets. Just the reason for traveling to Hawaii. Directions out of the parking lot were unclear and eventually led us to a ballroom with our luggage, but no clear way to the elevators or to our room. We were finally led through back service passages to the hotel's elevators. We were not told that the Kalia Tower was actually the location for timeshare guests. During our stay, we did not receive any housekeeping service - not by choice. Rooms were small. A limited view of the ocean was available, just try to block out all the rooftops and focus your binoculars. Parking rates varied from $12/day self-park to $15/day valet, but we were charged $17/day on the bill. A far better option is to enjoy the Hilton Waikoloa Resort on the Big Island of Hawai'i  
<Date>Jun 26, 2004
