<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Exceeded our expectations! We honeymooned in Hawaii for two weeks the first being at the Hilton Hawaiin Village Resort. What a place. We stayed in the Kalia Tower which is not one better towers but we were thrilled with everything it had to offer! First thing we noticed were the meticulously landscaped lawns and gardens. Check-in was quick and very easy. The rooms were gorgeous. Everything you would expect from a Hilton and MORE! We had done significant research on hotels in Oahu and I can say after seeing all the other locations we considered such as Sheraton Moana Surfrider, Marriot Waikiki and many others we were thrilled with our decision to stay at HHV. Plenty of pool area (each tower has one and a Super pool in teh middle), teh property sits ON the beach! A beautiful lagoon to take walks along. There were 21 restaurant and 22 stores right on site. You'd never have to leave if you so chose. Fine dining Restaurants like Benihanna, Golden Dragon (chinese), Sergios (Italian), as well as Regular eating places like pizzerias, delis, hot dog stands. Shopping was a bit pricey compared to shops a half mile away but boy was the stuff nice!! I would recommend the HHV only because I don't know how you could have a bad experience here. Think Hilton quality and you will be pleasantly surprised!! A couple of other places that were comparable but a little pricier. THe JW Marriot Gofl Resort in Ko'Olina. This place is away from the hustle and bustle of Honolulu. When we go back we will probably stay there to get some variety. We played the Ko'Olina golf course and it is well worth it!!! We also had the pleasure of going to a hotel called Ala Moana Hotel. Not on a beach but very elegant lobby. No comment on the rooms as we did not see them. If you go to Oahu whereever you stay you HAVE to eat at Aaron's in the Ala Moana hotel. The food is great but the service is incredible!   
<Date>Jun 21, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>PARADISE AT THE HILTON HAWAIIAN VILLAGE My husband and I honeymooned at the Hilton Hawaiian Village in 1984, and have been back five times since then. Our latest trip was last year - 2003. We love it there. We always stay at the Rainbow Tower, Delux Ocean View, is it pricey, absolutely, but you pay for paradise. The grounds are beautiful, the staff does a wonderful job in keeping it clean. The Hilton is in a great location, off the beaten path, but you still have your privacy. It is a town within a hotel, it has everything you need. Drinks are pricey, food is pricey, but you don't have to eat there, that is your choice, you have to expect expensive. If you are looking for a bargain, this is not the place to stay. We love having breakfast at the Rainbow Tower buffet early in the morning, looking right out on to the beach, what a great way to start your day. The only thing I find unfair, while I realize the hotel does not own it, is the beach chair and umbrella stand, I do feel for the price you pay to stay at the hotel, the hotel should find a way to give their guests these items complimentry. We would rather save for a trip to the Hilton Hawaiian Village for two years then go anywhere else, it is well worth it, and YES, it is truly paradise!  
<Date>Jun 15, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Thanks for the Great Vacation Memories HHV! It was PARADISE! Our family stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village from 5/29/04 - 6/8/04 and it was the best vacation ever. We first stayed at the Hotel (Diamond Head Tower - 17th floor) for 7 nights before moving on to our timeshare portion for an extra three nights. Upon check-in, I had asked for an ocean view if possible. Well, it got better, we received an upgrade to a one-bedroom suite on the top floor of the Diamond Head Tower. We had a wonderful ocean view with a partial view of Diamond Head which was great. It was so wonderful waking up in the morning and walking out to our belcony and seeing our gorgeous view Waikiki beach. The timeshare (Lagoon Tower) was great as well. Hilton Hawaiian Village is definitely the place to stay. My husband and especially our two boys had a wonderful time. The staff was very helpful and always had a smile. It is true that when you stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village, you really don't have to leave. Everything is there at the Village. It is also very true that it can be pretty pricey, but it is well worth it. If our boys had their way, we would stay at the beach and pool everyday during our entire stay. We most definitely will return and stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. Thank you for making our vacation a great one!

<Content>Good Time We stayed in the Rainbow tower with a view of Waikiki - which was really lovely. As it is at the end of the beach, I found the beach directly in front of the hotel cleaner, less crowded and not occupied by homeless and the passed out drunks I noticed while walking the length of the beach, which was nice.The only negative observation would have to be, as everyone else has mentioned, the nickle and diming over the small stuff i.e. coffee, water, parking. The ABC store on the property was a big help for the little stuff.Food on the property good, but pricey.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great View from the Rainbow tower !!!! We had an Ocean front view roon on the tenth floor of the Rainbow tower. At check in we were told that we were upgraded to a better view room because my wife is a Hilton Honors member. Our view from our balcony was facing Diamond head and Wikiki beach !!!!The room itself was average to above average, the bathroom was a bit small but clean. Nothing came with the room not even free coffee,everything was an extra charge. We brought our own coffee because we had done our research on tripadvisor.com ! We had gotten a rental car so we could eat off property every meal and we bought a few things from the ABC store which was near by.Since we had a rental car we had to pay $12.50 per day to park in their parking garage, Still we came out better off because taxi's were very expensive. We drove to Pearl Harbor and along the east coast so the rental car was worth every penny.Friday night they had a Hula show and fireworks which was really neat but it was $8.00 to get a seat for it. Although The $8.00 dollars gets ya one drink I thought I'd mention.The pictures I took from our balcony and on the HHV property came out great.Yes HHV is very expensive but the memories are priceless.

<Author>TravelDink01
<Content>Wonderfully Hilton Just returned from a wonderful Hawaiian vacation that included Maui, Kauai and Oahu. While in Oahu, we stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. It is very nice. It is true, you really don't have to leave this place, unless you just want to. As far as location goes, I appreciate the fact that it is on the end of Waikiki and not part of all of the goings ons. We stayed in the Kalia Tower. Brand new rooms, a little on the small side. Very clean and I have always appreciated Hilton's eye for detail. Not the place to go if you want intimacy and romance, however. I find that this Hilton, like all Hiltons, caters to the business and leisure crowd in that functional Hilton way. You either like it or you don't.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Nice LOcation We just arrived back from a 4 island stay in Hawaii. The Hilton Hawaiian viillage was our first stop. The first thing we noticed is how the staff at this hotel seemed so unhappy. We were never greeted by staff as we meet them on the property and they all had frowns on their faces. We were dropped off on the tour bus circle which is a hike to the front lobby on the other side of the hotel. Once we finally got our room in the in the Tapa Tower we were happy with it. It was large with a ocean view. The best thing about the hotel is that every bus and tour makes a stop at the hotel so you will not have to have a car during your stay. Even the malls and stores have free pick up!!!!Our total assessment of the hotel is great place and grounds but don't expect Hawaiian Hospitality because it is not here! The HHV was on the most commercial and our least favorite island.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>wow...breathtaking Paradise...yup that pretty much sums it up, Every turn you take you are completely amazed. My husband and I were there on our honeymoon-first time to Hawaii and his first time anywhere tropical! As you're walking along you are greeted by friendly people all over the islands for that matter, there are flamingos parrots beautiful paths connecting to each tower lined with ponds filled with beautiful tropical fish, the beach is footsteps away and paradise is at your doorstep-only downfall the food is extremely expensive and so are the drinks- like 18 bucks for two cocktails thats not including the tip but not to fear-the hilton is in the heart of Honolulu and moments away from great restaurants where you can eat for a considerable less amount of money but I do have to admit, the best seafood we ate was the first night 54 bucks for a steak and lobster tail and everybit worth it. Anyway I highly suggest it- I've been away quite often and the hilton is by far the most spectacular place Ive ever stayed hilton Hawaiian village I think not...Hilton Hawaiian Paradise..........DEFINITELY! enjoy -have a lava flow for me!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>This hotel has a great view! Overall a great place to stay. Thils hotel was a fabulous deal for me. I got my room for $114 a night on hotwire.com and then when I got here, I upgraded to the Rainbow tower for an oceanview room for an additional $60 per night. Totally worth the upgrade. The view is just like that of those on postcards of Waikiki Beach. As far as furnishings-it's your typical Hilton/Mariott type, but very clean and nice. I had a mini bar with a wet sink and fridge, a nice extra perk for the room. The resort is huge, but offers many activities that are free, such as Lei making. This place has one of the best areas of beach on Waikiki. You are in Hawaii and end up paying for alot. Count on the cost of food being 25% higher than on the mainland. The cost for a burger and fries in the hotel restaurant is $14.50. It's not the hotel overcharging, it's just more expensive period here in Hawaii. As long as you come prepared with the mindset that Hawaii is not a Bargains Galore place, you'll be fine. I wen't to the local grocery store and got some Diet Coke, Bagels, Cream Cheese and Snacks to help combat a bit of the cost issues. I'd rather spend $2.99 on a bagel than $40 for breakfast for two people, but that is just me. I was quite impressed with the staff here. Very friendly. I saw, nor encountered, any discrimination. There are bands that play at night, so if you plan on going to bed at 8 pm, don't get a room on the lower floors in the Rainbow Tower. The outdoor lounge is right there.They are done by 9 pm. As far as the mold issue mentioned in a previous review- There WAS a major mold problem in the new tower built, but they shut it down months ago and spent millions of dollars fixing the problem. It's been reopened for a while now, with a clean bill of health. It was a big deal, as it was in all the papers. All in all- I really liked this place. Lots of tropical birds, and great animals, which ad a nice touch. Lots of shopping and restaurants. This is a very nice resort to stay at. The best views are in the Rainbow Tower. Also DSL is available in the Rainbow Tower. I would stay here again.  
<Date>May 27, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Seeing is believing!!!!! I just returned from an 8 day vacation. I went over alone to relax and it was great. I was in the Kalia Tower with the mountain view and what a beautiful view it was. I arrived and my luggage was taken to my room by the bell service. I checked in and the front desk was polite, full of smiles and ready to meet any needs that I had. The resort alone is breath-taking with so much to see and so many shops to visit. Their are more than enough places to eat at on the resort as well as just a couple of steps away. I didn't have a car but taxi's are available(very expensive) or take the bus that runs directly in front of the resort for a $2 one way and they give you a transit ticket to ride back free. The mandara spa was wonderful, but very expensive ranging from $98 for a facial to $140 for a 50 minute massage. I made reservations Bali by the Sea, and Golden Dragon 48hrs before I arrived and was booked. For 1 person including an appetizer and meal expect to pay nothing less that $75-80. The food was good if you have the money and want to dine like the rich. To rent an inroom movie is $9.99-12.99 depending on the movie. Internet use is $9.99 and Sony Playstaion also. The decor to my room on the 19th floor was beautiful, with everything I wanted and more. You have a safe inroom, a small frig, a love seat, table, dest with 2 chairs, king size bed, large fresh towels, 28-32inch tv, nice size bathroom. The resort grounds are manicured while eveyone is sleeping, security is around the clock, to rent a beach chair and umbrella is $30 for the day. Pop is $3.75 for 16 oz, burgers and fries at the Topic lounge is $12.00. The Ala Mona mall is walking distance (10-15minutes) and 4 levels and over 200. Restuarants on the 4th floor, I ate at Jackie Chan and the price was reasonable and tasted good. I took 2 tours(Pearl Harbor  Battleship Missouri was $45 and a Majestic Island Tour of the entire island at $63. Both tours were great. Visit the International Market, you can find some bargins if you know how to deal and stand your ground, I also ate at the Cheesecake Factory for lunch, reasonable price and the cheesecake list is long, so much to chose from. The Royal Hawaiian mall across from the Market is nice, The ward shopping center is nice also. Overall I had a great time just relaxing, seeing the sights, shopping, and eating at different places. The resort is everything I was looking for and more. Be ready to spend some big bucks also, it is not a poor mans resort.   
<Date>May 19, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Wouldn't stay anywhere else! My husband and I stayed at HHV April 25-29, 2004 after doing a 7-day cruise around the islands. When I made the reservations I explained about the cruise and they said I could get an early check-in. We left the ship about 8:45 am and we were literally in our Rainbow Tower room (1213) at 9:30 am! It was exactly what I wanted -- an expansive ocean view with Diamond Head in the background. It was a large room with a king-sized bed -- very comfortable.The hotel and grounds were very beautiful and lushly green. I was even impressed that the beach was raked every morning! It was wonderful being able to leave the balcony door open during the night and not have the air conditioning going. It was great going to sleep with the waves pounding against the shore.The restaurants were very expensive, but it is Hawaii. We have saved almost 2 years for this vacation, and we weren't going to let this stand in our way. We found a small coffee shop just across the street from HHV for breakfast -- it really did a land office business for breakfast! We did eat at the Golden Dragon our last night -- very good food -- since we had an Entertainment coupon. It was about the price for a very nice meal that we would pay for at home (Chicago suburb).I chose the HHV mainly for the convenience -- car rental desk, trolley stops, on beach front. For some reason I vaguely remember always wanting to stay at the HHV when I first heard about it. And I finally did! And for the final praise -- I asked for a late checkout since our shuttle pickup for the hotel wasn't until 4 pm. And there wasn't a problem!All in all I would definitely stay at the HHV again if I ever make it to Oahu again. All of the staff, including wait staff, were very courteous and pleasant.  
<Date>May 7, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Wonderful View My friend and I had to get out of the house so my partner could study. Where better to go than HI!I had always wanted to stay at the HHV and was thankful that my travelling companion did not object to the $325.00 (+ about $40.00tax) per night room rate.We stayed in the Ali'i Tower (Rm 1306) and were stunned by the wonderful view. Usually and Ocean View room w/2 beds is not as well located as one w/only 1 bed, but we were fortunate.We could see the sun rise, Diamond Head, Waikiki Beach and wonderful star constellations at night. The decor is kind of a 70's throwback, some of the drawers stuck as did the pocket door to the bathroom area.Having stayed at luxury hotels before I was expecting more from Ali'l Tower privileges. I assume that since they are offering Executive floor services to an entire Tower, one can't expect three presentations a day w/complimentary continental breakfast and evening cocktails. I was also disappointed that there is no call down service for the valet. This would be a welcome perk, especially for Ali'i Tower guests.Check in was smooth and the staff was courteous. One Concierge was taken aback when asked for directions to Honolulu's gay nightlife. His demeanor was surprising given the varied clientele that comes through the doors.Overall, the view from the room disapated most ill will for the minor flaws we found. You do pay for everything and everything is expensive, but this is Waikiki in Spring! What are you expecting?I would stay again, but only in a comparable room in the Ali'i Tower. Anything less could be found for a better price elsewhere on the Strip.  
<Date>Apr 29, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>When Only The Best Will Do! We stayed at the Ali Garden Tower. 4/14 - 4/21/04. The first room that was given, I did not like the view. I had ordered the garden view, but it faced another of the Hotel's towers and the garden was too far away. I upgraded for $20 to a partial ocean view and it was GREAT. (Room 1520). Quite a lot of the ocean was visible and the city lights at night were breathtaking. The hotel is beautifully appointed, with many birds, fish, even penguins. Winding paths take you to many enjoyable areas with lush landscaping, delightful ponds and scenery. The village has many unique shops to browse. The food at the many restaurants is fair to good, but expensive. For example a medium size coke is $3.75! Cheeseburger, small salad  coke, was $18.75. Just outside of the grounds there are lots of restaurants with regular prices, however. Our room was very nice, with a large bath. Service was excellent overall. The hotel offers lots of things to do, including Hawaiian dancers at the pool and fireworks. Everything you really need is there, and I highly recommend this complex.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Worth the research.. Although we have visited Hawaii several times we had never stayed on Oahu. We planned a 3 night stay at the end of our visit to Kauai so that we could see Pearl Harbor, North Shore, Waikiki and other well known spots mid-April 2004. Since we are used to the less populated islands I was concerned about the high-rise 'big city atmosphere I expected to find on Oahu. I spent several evenings looking for the right hotel at the right price. I finally selected Hilton Hawaiian Village - ocean front room in the Rainbow Tower. I used the resort maps on Hilton web site to get orientation of towers. It was definitely the right hotel - but price was more than I had hoped to spend. We were on a upper floor and had wonderful views of Diamond Head and the ocean, the beach and sunset. As others have mentioned the hotel is expensive and you pay for everything - even the coffee in the room. We found the the shopping and restaurants on the grounds to be convenient. We accomplished our goal of seeing Pearl Harbor, the North Shore (but the surf was flat) and the Waikiki area. I can't say that I'll visit Oahu again - we like less crowded areas but I would recommend this hotel if you select your room carefully. We had a lovely dinner at Keo's in Waikiki - the flowers in that restaurant are gorgeous!  
<Date>Apr 23, 2004

<Author>rosepetal
<Content>Expensive, nice grounds, get ready to walk I just got back from HHV today 4/22/04 and thought I'd let people in on what my mother and I thought of the place. First the grounds are beautiful and there are birds and fish ponds everywhere. This is really nice. The room which we stayed in Ali'i Tower was ok. It was clean but nothing out of the ordinary for the price you pay. If you don't want a rental car this is the place to stay because there is good shopping and great restaurants on site. The Hilo Hattie free bus will take you there and drop you off down the street at a huge shopping center. There's also a restaurant that is very inexpensive next door to hilo hattie called Zippy's. Food is great, it's cheap, quick, offers huge variety and you don't even need a taxi just use the hilo hattie trolley and walk across the street. Anyway over all the HHV is a safe bet, expensive but clean rooms and nice grounds. You will have to walk a mile it seems to get anywhere because the place is so big. I would recommend this hotel to others if you've got the money and don't mind so so rooms. Also do splurge and eat at Bali by the sea....it's expensive but well worth it. Make reservations, dress nice and enjoy particularly the filet mignion which costes about $35 and try the bali salad with champaigne sauce. One of the best meals I've ever eaten and the service is surperb. Hope this helps narrow the decision in finding a place to stay.  
<Date>Apr 22, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Superb resort Myself, my wife and our two young daughters stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village from 5th April to 14th April. The hotel is superbly situated right on the best part of Waikiki beach. There are numerous bars, restaurants  shops on site, all of excellent quality. All of the staff were very polite, friendly  helpful. We stayed in the Kalia Tower, our room was excellent, very clean  modern. Some people seem to complain about the prices charged at this hotel, but it is no more expensive that any other top quality beach front resort. The hotel complex is beautifully laid out, full of exoitic plants  wildlife. I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone visiting Waikiki. This was our third visit to Hawaii, and we would not now consider staying anywhere else in the future.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Beautiful, Fun Resort My husband, myself and our 16 year old daughter stayed at the HHV over Easter. First off, when you arrive at this resort it is overwhelmingly gorgeous. Breathtaking for sure. We stayed 8 Nights and had an absolute blast. We mentally prepared ourselves to put out a lot of money at this Hilton Resort. We acknowledged prior to going that we cannot generally afford to dine at our local Hilton, much less one in Hawaii. So we psyched ourselves up and prepared for it. We bought a Lonely Planet Waikiki/Oahu guide and found many economical ways to eat and have fun. The Easter Buffet was no more expensive than regular buffets here at home or in Vegas or anywhere else we've been. We stocked up on snacks at Safeway instead of the ABC store which saved us major money and we weren't at all offended at the cost of the drinks. They weren't much different in price compared to our own local bars. We had reserved a standard room with one request, not to be out towards the road. When we arrived, we were upgraded for free, without asking for it. We had a partial ocean view. Not enough of a view I'd want to pay for but for a free upgrade it was great. Our room was large enough for us, the only complaint was no ventilation in the bathroom, which obviously helps contribute to the slight musty odors in some of the rooms, along with wet towels and beach clothes. Overall, we loved the place and had a wonderful time. We were rather disappointed at having to pay rental $$ for beach loungers but hey...we dealt with it. The beach was the prettiest and largest and least crowded than the others. The staff was friendly and very accomodating. We toured a few of the nearby famous resorts and found none to be any better than the HHV. Most had smaller beaches, and an older feel to them. We have already booked another trip to the HHV for next Dec. Would recommend this place to anyone who is not looking for absolute top of the line accomodations. As my husband told our inquiring friends..The HHV is a high end resort for regular people  
<Date>Apr 19, 2004

<Author>jjvac
<Content>Hilton Hawaiin Vacation Just returned from a nine night stay at the Lagoon Tower of the HHV. Overall it was fantastic. The village is the place to stay loads of shops and restaurants. The super pool is located steps from the beach which was great for our teenagers. Everyone was very helpful just ask... <Content>Beautiful Resort We spent 3 nights at the Hilton Hawaiian Village in Waikiki in their luxury tower, and we had so much fun. The hotel and beach area are kept very nice. <Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Ali'l Tower Overated, very average. Village complex itself is very nice, expansive with interesting views (flamingos, penguins). However, the amenities and restaurant prices are outrageous. My kids wanted a pizza ($11 for a small child portion) and a hotdog ($7). This was at the Tropics outdoor casual dining facility on the beach. This being our third trip to the islands we were looking forward to our stay in the much talked about Ali'i tower. The room was very average, in fact we have stayed in more luxurious surroundings for less money at the historic Ala Moana . The room was a partial ocean view, meaning you had to stretch your neck out to see the beach from the terrace. There was a faint musty odor in the room, staining on the wall, and a bathroom without an exhaust fan. The promised three times daily maid service, was actually twice a day. Which was okay since we are not particularly messy folks. The advertised fresh fruit amenity only occurred once on arrival. We did however, receive two bottles of water twice a day and in room coffee at no charge. There is a complimentary excercise room on the second floor terrace next to the private pool for Ali 'l guests which was nice. The pool is small and often crowded as the rest of the hotel pools. There is free appetizers daily at 5 pm which often subsituted for dinner. However, my advice is to avoid ordering drinks unless you don't mind $6 cokes and $7 smoothie drinks for the kids. I guess we were spoiled by our previous experience with the Hyatt executive program where there is free breakfast and appetizers in the afternoon (yes, that also includes free cocktails!). Aside, from that our stay was pleasant. Granted one has to expect a certain amount of spending when on vacation, it just seems that we've stayed elsewhere that provided much more for the value of our money. One final tip, go out of the village for a meal that won't leave you in sticker shock. The Hilton's village Steak and Seafood was offering an Easter brunch that sounded delightful however it would cost $120 for our family of four. Instead, we walked to Todai's Japanese buffet which was phenomenal with all kinds of fresh seafood and pan asian dishes for $48 for all of us ( just across from HHV). The highlight of my daughter's stay at HHV? Seeing Paris Hilton walk through the pool area.  
<Date>Apr 16, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>good, but poor ocean view from Kalia Tower nice place, we enjoyed it, I'd give it a positive review.On the negative side, if I ever come back I will not stay at the Kalia Tower. Although the room was nice, our 'ocean view' that I supposedly paid extra for was rather poor because the tower is about 4 football fields away from the beach, with two other towers partially obstructing the view. Because of the large distance between us and the beach we also got the privilege of looking at the air conditioning ducts on the roof of the building in front of us (about 2 football fields long). So, we had a view of the ocean, but not a 'pretty' view.

<Author>swimswithsharks
<Content>great view, nice little post office onsite, we loved it We stayed in the Rainbow Tower and were amazed at the view. This is the first Hawaiin hotel I've stayed at where oceanview really meant oceanview. No coy little hidden meanings to the word, no oceanview - what you can see of it between those two hotels next door'. No this was a sweeping postcard of a view of Waikiki Beach and Diamondhead and the ocean. And I used the post office in the Tapa Tower daily to mail souvenirs home to relatives and friends. There is a wonderful assortment of shops on the grounds, and you're within blocks of other malls and hotels. Best of all, the shuttle boat out to the Atlantis Submarine leaves from a dock at the beach right outside. One word of warning though, about some of the people you'll find selling their wares on the beach nearby. Look out for a man with parrots perched on his bicycle. he'll be in the shade of a tree near the beach. If you give him money to photograph you holding his parrots, you will never see the photos- he is strictly a con man, in no way associated with the hotel, no matter what he tells you.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Overall great resort! Staff was friendly, attentive, and very organized. The resort had beautiful landscaping and wildlife. The rooms in the Tapa tower were average --- don't expect much of an oceanview (we were on the 17th floor  if you lean over the rail you could see a little water). The pool area was too crowded, not enough chairs! The other downside was the cost of the food/beverage on property. I've been to many islands and yes, things tend to be a bit more than they are on the mainland---but these prices were extremely too expensive. If you go off of the property you can get a large breakfast for $4.99 (Coffee House across the street) versus $19.50 on property. A couple of insider hints---reserve the hospitality room to freshen up before you leave on your late flight (you get to use a hotel room for 20 minutes per person after check out)  use the airport shuttle from the hotel ($9 per person and goes direct to airport). Overall, very nice resort if you are prepared for the costs  general crowding experienced in Waikiki. Please tour the rest of the island---Honolulu is a very large city  you won't enjoy the true beauty of Hawaii.  
<Date>Mar 31, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>There's no place like HHV! Just returned from our third visit to Hawaii and the Hilton Hawaiian Village (March 7-13). I cannot imagine staying anywhere other than HHV. It is like visiting an old and cherished friend. Our last two visits have been spent in the Ali Tower and the staff there is wonderful. You can quickly become spoiled to the twice a day maid service and the nightly turn-down service. You would have a wonderful vacation if you never left the Village. Everything you can possibly need or want is there. I even look forward to the almost daily trips to the ABC store! Just steps away from the beach, HHV is truly a part of paradise!

<Author>Isky
<Content>Best hotel in Honolulu The Hilton Hawaiian Village was wonderful. This time we stayed in the Kalia tower and enjoyed every minute. This is a huge hotel, but in the heart of everything and not as busy as the hotels on Waikkiki Beach. Food very good, spa very nice, room was beautiful. Bus stop steps away to shopping and tourist spots. Friday night fireworks show at the hotel was incredible. Beach very nice...Hotel property very open though, so if it's raining you will get wet. Ate at Benihana on the property and did not enjoy the food even though the cook was entertaining. Pizza at the Round Table restaurant there was very good. Make sure to take advantage of the coupon book you get when you check in, it's full of free and discounted items good on the property.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Better Than Expected Like some others, we won a 5 night stay at the Hilton Waikoloa Village on the Big Island (courtesy of Smooth Jazz V98.7 in Detroit), but decided to tack on a couple of extra nights to our vacation. Since we wanted to see another island anyway, we decided to stay two nights at the Hilton Hawaiian Village on Oahu. We stayed two nights in early February, 2004.I've stayed at a few world class resorts around the world, and also a few dives. The Hilton Hawaiian Village far exceeded my expectations and set a new standard by which I will measure other resorts.Yes, the grounds are sprawling and there is much to do both within the village and the surrounding area, but I want to focus more on their service and amenities - after all, isn't that what a luxury vacation is about ?I had read some other reviews that seemed to indicate the locals could be stand-offish to downright rude, so I got off the airport shuttle with an open mind, not knowing exactly what to expect. What I experienced, instead, was a very personable staff ready to assist me whenever asked. How refreshing ! Each employee I encountered seemed genuinely interested in making my stay a pleasurable one. Worthy of note was a middle-aged bellman named Patrick that met us as we got off the shuttle. Patrick was engaging  informative, and helped us decide where to dine our first night on the island. At check-in, a concierge inquired if anyone in line was a Hilton Honors member. When I answered up, my wife  I were whisked off to a speedy  painless check-in while others continued to wait in line (hint - join Hilton Honors on the web before you go...it's free and worth the effort). Our bags were already at our room when we arrived.As for the facilities, I must say this is a really large hotel, with several towers of rooms (some 3500 rooms in all!) sprawled about the 22 acre complex. I will leave it to others to recommend a particular tower at this locale - suffice it to say that the room was bright, cheery  clean, and nicely decorated. It does take a bit of orientation to learn where everything is and how to navigate around to different areas. I started feeling comfortable (translation = not lost) within a few hours of arrival.Unlike the Hilton Waikaloa Village, this hotel offered little amenities we missed when we moved to the Big Island....like complimentary coffee and direct Internet access (for a fee, of course). Drink all the (appropriately named) Hawaiian Paradise blend coffee you want - they'll bring you more with just a phone call. Want to book a tour ? Make a phone call to the concierge, or stroll down to the open air lobby and ask all the questions you like. Yes, they are extremely busy, but I never once encountered a hotel employee that was less than cheerful.If you offered me another week's vacation in Hawaii, I'd take the Hilton Hawaiian Village over any other. No, I don't have any affiliation with Hilton hotels - I'm just impressed enough with this particular location to offer an unsolicited review....something I don't normally do. Others may have had different experiences, but our's was utterly fantastic.  
<Date>Mar 9, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Exorbitant First, the positive side: the complex is attractive, many nice shops lie within easy walking distance; the view from the Tapa Tower commands an expansive view of Waikiki, Diamond Head and the ocean; restaurants such as Sergio's, and especially Bali-by-the-Sea, are excellent.Regrettably, however, I suggest that vacationers to Hawaii look elsewhere. Hilton Hawaiian Village (indeed all of Waikiki) is overbuilt, overcrowded and waaaaay overpriced. One senses that the resort's policy is to drain as much money from its guests, as often and for as long, as possible. At $280 per night (including tax), should you expect use of the HHV fitness facility? Of course not, it's an extra $12.50 per day, per person. Headphones during your workout? $4 more. A steam bath afterwards? An additional $8. HHV courtesy vehicles running to and from the airport? No, one must take a cab or a shuttle, at $25-35 including tip, each way. A 14 pizza is $30, a bottle of beer $6.If, despite the incessant profteering, you still want to experience HHV, I suggest that you trade into it if you have a timeshare, thereby saving almost $2,000. Then, find one of the nearby ABC stores, buy food and beverages at a fraction of the resort prices, and have meals in your room, going to a restaurant only occasionally. The money you save can go towards your cab fare and those $25 daily workouts.  
<Date>Mar 8, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Fantastic Holiday I won our holiday in a competition with a local radio station in Birmingham, UK. We stayed in the Rainbow Tower of the Hilton Hawaiian Village for 6 nights and the view from our window was breathtaking. After enduring a long flight we welcomed a clean and comfy room. Food and drink on the Hotel complex was expensive but the ABC Store on site was very useful for stocking the fridge in the room with drinks, snacks, fruit sandwiches etc. We found 'The Bus' very easy and useful to use being $2 adult and $1 child and you could get a transfer ticket to use within 2 hours, we travelled to the North Shore and watched the surfers on Sunset Beach and Banzai Pipeline. The trip to Pearl Harbor and the Arizona Memorial was enjoyable although very moving. The Ala Moana Shopping Centre was big with many food outlets and a wide variety of shops. We had an Intenational Buffet meal in the Rainbow Lanai which was enjoyable and meant that our children could eat free off the special childrens menu. All in all it was a brilliant holiday and would definitely like to visit again one day.  
<Date>Mar 5, 2004

<Author>dmouse
<Content>No doubt, the best location on Waikiki No doubt, it's a bit dated (we stayed in the Tapa Tower), but this has gotta be the best location and site plan on the beach. I used the city buses to go shopping when my husband and son were out viewing the ships at Pearl Harbor. Really easy! Bus drivers and local people are very helpful at which bus goes where. We enjoyed every aspect of the HHV, and service was great! The grounds have some surprising guests-- Egyptian ibis, black and white swans, flamingos, wood ducks, and penguins! You can easily find a quiet spot to read a book or enjoy a drink. No stress here.

<Author>inmadridsoon
<Content>better than some say My first impression of this hotel was wow, what a relief. After reading several reviews on this website, I was a little worried...expecting maybe a Vegas like, cheesy Hawaian hotel. Upon turning the corner and entering the property, I was impressed by its appearance and ambiance. This is not only a hotel, it can really be a destination. Its a fun, upper-scale hotel that is pricey but this is Hawaii and so is everything else. While you drive up to the registration desk, you pass several shops and retaurants. I can compare this hotel I guess to a mega-cruise ship, everything you may need in a vacation in one place. The hotel itself has things everyone has already talked about, penguins, flamingoes...things like that. Its things like that that make this hotel a fun place. It is not your Ritz Carlton in elegance, but I was on my Honeymoon, and I wanted a nice, fun place to relax, swim and enjoy my vacation. All in all, I was very satisified with this hotel, its negatives are the $17.00 per day valet parking fee, and the inflated prices on everything else. Aside from that, its great. In my opinion, if you are coming all the way to Hawaii, save up and learn to part with your money, as it will easily slip away. If you can, rent a car. (it gives you the freedom to move around and see Pearl Harbor, North Shore and the other tourist locations)I am not sure if my review was helpfull, I can only write what I was hoping to read when I read the reviews. Calm your worries if you are booked here, it is a nice, family ( lots of kids) well designed place. Unless you are a travel critic that only goes to places to find the negatives of a hotel, and you go there, have a few drinks and enjoy your VACATION, you will like the Hawaiian village.  
<Date>Feb 28, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Best place we have ever stayed! We really lucked into the best deal! We had reserved 2 rooms, one for my husband and I and one for 3 children, 17, 15, and 11 for February break 2004. They were booked solid and could not even find 2 rooms in the same tower when we checked in. After a quite a wait, we were so tired after the long trip from Michigan, we were given 2 rooms on the same floor in the Alii tower. What a great room up grade! On the second floor, 4 steps from the private pool for Alii guests. We had a huge balcony, which had two reading chairs with ottamans, a table with 4 chairs and 2 patio recliners, over looking all the activities at the main pool and over the ocean. We saved so much money on the food served from 5-7 at the Alii pool and we did not have to pay for coffee. The kids were as far as they could be on the same floor but they are older so we were fine. Our balcony became our gathering spot for sun worshiping, book reading and card playing!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Time!! We stayed at the Hilton 02/18-02/20 2004. It was great! My husband, 7 year old daughter and I were serviced right away upon our arrival and given an ocean view room in the Diamond Towers. The room was clean and had a great view!! Before we even got to our room my daughter wanted to stop and look at the flamingo exhibit and the penquin and turtle exhibit they had at the hotel. I thought it was a great touch!! The children seemed to love it. The only one bad thing I can say about the Hilton Hawaiian Village is that it is extremely expensive. For my husband, daughter and myself to go out to dinner it was at least $150/night, lunch was not any better as far as value goes...and drinks run about $8 each. The resort is gigantic so you kind of get lost in going to all the restaurants there...we didn't even leave the village. If you like Japanese food they have a Benihana on site and the food was great. My daughter especially loved the show the chefs put on. There are also about 90 great shops and upscale boutiques right in the pavillion. If you have the $$ I would definately stay at the Hilton, it was beautiful, the service was great and the beaches were calm and clean (although sometimes crowded). If you are a pool lover make sure to get there early for a lounge chair!! Otherwise you will end up paying $12 for one on the beach!!  
<Date>Feb 24, 2004

<Author>pirk
<Content>Great stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village We recently stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village for our 10 year anniversary and had a really nice experience. I was a little nervous after reading such mixed reviews about the HHV. We stayed in the Rainbow Tower -- initially in room 2920 (note: the even number rooms face downtown Honolulu and the marina not Diamond Head). We were immediately not happy when our neighbors arrived next door and we could hear their conversation word for word. We quickly went down to the house manager desk, explained we were on our 10th anniversary and requested a room change. Being the week before the Pro Bowl we thought we'd be out of luck (and I'm sure this review would have a different tone!) but we got switched to room 800 which was at the end of the Rainbow tower with two balconies -- one facing the ocean and the other facing the marina. It was so beautiful! And the fireworks on Friday night felt like they were our own personal show! The food in the village was o.k. Benihana was good. We ventured more into Waikiki for dinner just to get out and see other things. The grounds at the hotel were really wonderful. We wandered through many of the other hotels (the Royal Hawaiian, the Halekulani, Sheraton Surfrider) and the HHV was really overall the best. The pool is huge but that's about it -- nothing special. With all the buildings around it the sun exposure is limiting and we had to get our chairs by 9:00 AM or we were out of luck. Head to the beach if you want to be in the sun all day. I wouldn't recommend this pool if you like privacy. It's a typical big resort and not particularly romantic (but then again neither is the Honolulu/Waikiki area). We like to go there because it offers a slice of classic Hawaii and you can walk everywhere. Also if you want to get a cheap meal there are options. Overall, we will stay at the HHV in the future (mostly because we'll use our Hilton Honors points) and have a great time!!  
<Date>Feb 24, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Way overrated We stayed at the HHV February 15th and 16th. It was very dissapointing. We had a sorry room on the 4th floor. When we asked for a different room we were told by a rude and obnoxious clerk that the hotel was sold out. However, when I offered to pay for the upgrade, they miraculously found a better room (we did not take the room). You have to walk what seems like a mile to get to your room. The room itself was ok, but they charge you for inroom coffee. Most hotels we've stayed at offer inroom coffee complimentary.The stores in the HHV are very expensive as well as the restaurants (if you can get into a restaurant.) The drinks at the bars are outragous. $8.50 for a Mai Tai. We went across the street to the coffee shop. The same drink $2.50; breakfast was considerably cheaper (and better) at the coffee shop as well.We may return to Hawaii, but will never stay at the HHV.  
<Date>Feb 23, 2004

<Author>pleasantpeninsula
<Content>We give the Alii Tower two thumbs up We stayed at the HHV for 3 nights beginning 02-09-04. When we arrived we thought, What have we gotten ourselves into? There were Huge lines in the main lobby--the longest we have ever seen in a hotel. Fortunately, we were booked into the Alii Tower, which is a short walk from the main lobby and has its own check-in desk. where we were first in line. If you read some of the other reviews or check the Hilton web site you will find the special features of the Alii Tower, so I will not repeat them here. While I will not dispute the experience of those who have given the Alii Tower a less than excellent rating, I can tell you that our stay met and exceeded our expectations in every way. We had booked an ocean view room with a Bounceback package. This included a buffet breakfast every morning. The room was large, well furnished, well kept, and had a great view. The breakfast was good (and actually better than at some of the much more expensive out island resorts). Every employee with whom we had contact was pleasant and courteous. As a bonus, the package was quite a bit less expensive than other Waikiki Hotels which we would feel to be of similar quality. So, we can recommend the Hilton Hawaiian Village--but only if you stay in the Alii Tower. We (my wife and I) give it two thumbs up and will definitely stay there on our next tip to the Islands.  
<Date>Feb 22, 2004

<Author>TeeAnn
<Content>Hilton Hawaiian Village is Paradise! We stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village the week prior to the Pro Bowl and a few days after the game. It is a WONDERFUL place and would highly recommend it to others and we will definetly stay there again ourselves. It is truly a resort paradise with great shops and wonderful restaurants. The staff was really nice and very accommodating. You can easily stay at this resort and never have to leave, though we did drive to the North Shore where the beaches are beautiful and not crowded, and only a 20-30 minute drive away, as the hotel beach area was pretty crowded a couple of the days while we were there. The ocean at the hotel is great for swimming and snorkeling. We had a 1-bedroom oceanview condo in the Lagoon tower. This place is paradise!

<Author>scrateef
<Content>Aloha Ali'i! My third trip to Hawaii was the first that I needed to worry about accommodations. I did lots of research (and deliberating) and finally decided on The Ali'i Tower at Hilton Hawaiian Village. I found the Ali'i through the American Express Fine Hotels and Resorts program, and I highly recommend this program if you?re a Platinum or Centurion card holder. The perks (free room upgrade at check in, free continental breakfast every day for you and a guest, and a free lunch at the Rainbow Lanai) along with special attention from the staff make this hotel an enjoyable place to stay ? and a nice value.About Hilton Hawaiian Village: As you'll read in the many reviews posted on this site, the Hawaiian Village is huge. Five towers make up the compound (they?re going to build a 6th), and the beautiful grounds that connect them are immaculately maintained. You?ll have plenty to look at as you stroll the grounds: exotic birds (including flamingos and penguins), fish, and foliage are everywhere. The hotel employs a large staff to maintain all of these, and no detail goes unnoticed.HHV has many shops, most of which seem to be jewelry stores. You?ll find everything from a full Louis Vuitton boutique to an ABC convenience store to a DFS Galleria, so you don?t need to leave the village if you don?t want to.The beach in front of HHV is by far the largest in Waikiki. Just walk down to some of the other hotels, and you?ll be amazed at how small their beaches are. There was plenty of room at HHV?s beach, so we never felt crowded.You?ll find lots of restaurants either in the hotel towers or around the village shops. We ate most meals on site, and most of what you read about the hotel?s high prices holds true. For example, a 7-ounce filet mignon will run you about 40 bucks at the Village Steak House, and lunch for two at the Rainbow Lanai (without alcohol) can easily pass the $50 mark. But all hotels in Waikiki have similar prices. And besides, you?re in paradise, right? Who?s counting? Despite the high prices, you can still get reasonably priced food from the hotel?s more casual restaurants near the pools/beach area and from the independent places in the shops area.The hotel has many activities, ranging from a nightly hula show by the super pool to the Atlantis submarine. We were happy to lounge by the pool or beach most of the time, so we didn?t require too many distractions. But if you want to be on the go, HHV can easily accommodate.About Ali?i Tower: The Ali'i Tower is run like a separate hotel; guests have their own check-in area, a doorman, a dedicated concierge, a private pool overlooking the beach, and towel service by the pool. The pool area also has an adjoining lanai, where guests can enjoy, continental breakfast (free if you?re with the AmEx program), full bar service, snacks, etc...The rooms in Ali'i are larger and better than average. House keeping visits 3 times daily, including nightly turn-down service. Our room was on the 10th floor and had a view of the ocean and Diamond Head. Each room has a lanai (balcony) with two comfy chairs and a table. If you came to work, you have a desk with a color fax/scanner/printer (DSL is available for a fee). The bedroom TV tucks away neatly in the armoire, and the little TV in the vanity area of the bathroom comes in handy as well. The bathroom/shower is tiled in stone, with a pedestal sink in the shower area and a traditional sink/vanity area just off the entry to the room. Each room also has added conveniences like 3 telephones, an iron and ironing board, hair dryer, in-room safe, shaving/facial mirror, cotton balls, basic toiletries, etc.When not in our room, we found the staff at the HHV to be top notch. Everyone was very friendly and personable. The staff in the Ali?i typically addressed us by name, and they were incredibly gracious and hospitable.We had one complaint about our stay: The air conditioner didn?t seem to work well. I called the front desk, and they had maintenance check our unit and make repairs. We noticed some improvement, but still didn?t feel that the room was cooling as well as it should (considering we had the air on the highest setting). The front desk offered us another room, but when all was said and done, we just didn?t feel strongly enough about it to move pack up our stuff and move. The room was never uncomfortable, and we knew we could change rooms if things got bad (They actually had another room on hold for us if we changed our minds.)Overall, Hilton Hawaiian Village is a great property, and the Ali?i Tower was a fantastic place to stay. After reading so much about hotels on this site, I was a little worried because every property seemed to have a horror story associated with it. But I?d definitely recommend the Ali?i Tower at HHV to anyone, and I?ll be back the next time I?m on Oahu.  
<Date>Feb 11, 2004

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Won't see us again Stayed here for 2 nights in July '03. Not impressed. Stayed in the Ali'i tower which is the only tower on the property that is part of the American Express Platinum Fine Resorts and Hotels program. They need to take it off the list. Whe we arrived it was like a mob seen at the front of the hotel. I swear I thought I was at a convention or something. At least they had people there asking for your last nme so I didn't stand in the long lines. I was sent immediately over to the Ali'i tower where there was no line and check in was indoors. The room was okay. Glad we had a private pool because the pool at the entrance of the resort, forget about swimming in there. All you can do is stand in the water and there is someone else standing at least 2 inches right next to you. Why even bother getting in the pool. Personally it was just to crowded for me. The Royal Hawaiian is much quieter and better service and a 5 star resort.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Beach Resort!!! Stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village Resort from 1/24/04-01/26/04. As HiltonHonor member was upgraded for no extra charge from Tapa Tower to Rainbow Tower room#427 with view of superpool and beach. If you get a room at the Rainbow Tower, I'd recommend get the odd-numbered room for better ocean view.PLUS: Beach not overcrowded, exotic landscaping, and location of the hotel (away from the shopping crowd). Room was clean.MINUS: small bathrooms, parking $14/day, expensive onsite shopping stores and restaurants (The Rainbow Lanai: Breakfast Buffet $19.95/person is NOT worth the price; instead I recommend have breakfast buffet for $21.00 at the Plumeria Beach Cafe at KAHALA MANDARIN ORIENTAL HAWAII. It's the best in Waikiki: food selection and ocean view!!!)Overall, the hotel was wonderful because of the direct beach access, the nightly hula dance entertainment by the superpool, and landscaping with exotic birds.Will definitely come back to Hilton Hawaiian Village Resort next time!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>excellent time Me and my partner stayed at the hilton hawaiian village in june. We had a great time, the hotel was a bit pricey but the resort is great fun. I loved the shopping in the resort, theres louis vuitton at your door step, endless souvenir and clothes stores and even a ABC store. I stayed in the ali tower and found the rooms beautifully decorated and very clean. I really have no complaints. The hotel has a private beach which is very peace full, if you like crowded beaches the other end of waikiki beach is best suited, where there are lots of hotels and activities on the beach. When we arrived we soon realised it was sale time and found that Gucci, Prada amongst others stores where 50% off which is great, in England sale time is very hectic, stores cramed full of people but to our surprise it was very pleasant and had a wide range of sizes available. I would definately stay at the Hilton again but as Im travelling from England its very expensive, 8 nights room only for two people has cost me 拢2200 (around$ $3300). I better get saving.

<Author>BAMEmeraldIsle_NC
<Content>disappointed Disappointed best describes our stay at the HHV. I took my family to Hawaii to celebrate my wife and my 25th anniversary. We stayed at the HHV expecting it to be POSH but what it actually is, is beachy. We stayed there 12-28-03 through 1-6-04. Our room and taxes came to over $4,200.00. There are some nice features, but hoped for and expected more for that sum of money. The staff was friendly, but the HHV was understaffed. We had to wait in line for anything and everything. There are a large number of shops at the HHV, but virtually all are top of the line extremely expensive. We are planning another trip to Hawaii in July 04, but will not stay at the HHV. The reason is it is a very poor value. Mike

<Author>Larrythegolfer
<Content>Great Place to Explore Oahu From Stayed from Dec 22-28, 2003. As a HHonors member using points for my stay I was pleased with the options given at check in. They were an Ocean View in the Rainbow Tower, a Jr. Suite in Diamond Head Tower or after asking about the Concierge Floor an Ocean view in the Kalia tower with access to the keyed off 23rd Floor. Traveling with my 12 and 9 year old, I opted for the free food on the conciege floor. The Kalia tower is about a five minute walk to the beach but the tower is new and certainly the nicest of our trip which included the Hilton on the Big island and the Radisson on Kaui. They provided a free role away so my kids each had their own beds. The Kalia Tower is convenient for grabbing the car from the $12/day parking garage across the street and exploring beautiful Oahu. The Concierge Floor was very comfortable and some evenings the Hors d'orves were pleanty for dinner. Breakfast was good, but not as extensive as some floors i have been on. The staff was great.The grounds are wonderful, and the Kalia Tower has a nice pool and whilpool only availble to residents of that tower. It is actually a very relaxing place to hang out. It is adjacent to the Spa. My wife had one of those $100 per hour treatments, but she said it was excellent. Something like a Massage with chocolate and Maccadamian Nut ScrubIf you are looking for water slides, there are none on Oahu except at a Water park about 30 minutes away. Kids wanted to go, but the natural beauty of Oahu was better.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>very pretty My husband and I spent dec.15-21 at this beautiful resort. It was quite expensive but the ABC store was on the property where you could get alcohol and various necessities much cheaper. The staff was extremely helpful if or when you needed anything. My only complaint was the staff at the pool. The pool opened at 8:30am. Dont try to get a towel or just sit at the pool at 8:27am. You will get scolded and told the pool does not open until 8:30. that happened to me twice during my stay!!! Overall the experience was a very relaxing and lovely one at this resort.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Best Vacation Ever!!!Very Co$tly In Dec'02, I stayed at the HHV for 2 weeks. I stayed at the Ali'i Tower. I had a partial ocean. In order to see the ocean you had to stick your head outside the balcony to see the ocean. The room was ok. It wasn't very big but suited us fine. The AC leaked  they fixed it. The table cloth on the nite table was stained  when I requested they change it they did. You have to put a sign on the bed for them to give you new sheets everyday or they don't change them [water-conservation]. I don't think the Ali tower is their best tower to stay in. I looked at the Deluxe Ocean view Rainbow Tower while I was there  thought it was a much nicer room than the one we stayed in. The hotel grounds beach etc are kept immaculately clean. I would look out at the balcony 1 am  watch all the people cleaning the outside of the hotel  grading the beach. The hotel is a village. It has everything you need. That is what I like most about it. Everynite after dinner we would walk around to all the shops, enjoy the beauty  smell that surrounded us. The hotel smells very nice. There is a flower called tuberose that grows on vines  is all over the hotel  when the wind crosses it in your path it smells very nice. The hotel is a beautifully designed hotel that captures the essence of Hawaii. The open breezways at the check-ins  outside shops is just gorgeous. I had the best vacation of my life. The atmosphere set at the hotel was very traditional hawaiin. Friday nites there is a firework show  hula show. I think $10/pp  you get a sml pan pizza  a drink. You need to get there early to get a seat. It is a wonderful show.I like the HHV so much because it is a family resort. When you have children this is really important. There was a nice crowd of people  a homey feeling to the resort. They have penquins, koi,  very loud talking birds.Swans too. The employees were very nice. If you go during a holiday it is wise to make dinner reservations if you want to eat at the resort.If you attend a time-share presentation they offer a $100 hilton certificate.I would definately stay there again. While we were there, we looked at several other hotels to compare. I felt although this was a costly hotel, the resort atmosphere appealled to me the most.Other costs, $15/day for them to park your car.$7/hr if your child plays nintendo on the tv.breakfast for2 at rainbow lanai restaurant was about $45-$50. Lunch same . dinner about 100-150.Remember to bring alot of money. this 2 wk vacation cost about $10,000 [includes airfare, luaus at polynesian cultural center, sea life park, mall, honolulu zoo-very inexpensive. pearl harbor etc. I would highly recommend coming here. This is a prime resort.  
<Date>Dec 25, 2003

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Nice Place, Great Location, Poor Value Since we frequently travel with our young children (2 and 3 years old) we prefer to stay in condos. Hilton Hawaiian Village is (as far as I know) the only resort with condos that are virtually on the beach (on the lagoon in this case) in Waikiki without having to cross the street to the beach. We paid $299/night for a 1-bedroom condo. We decided to stay here for 3 nights before spending a week at the new Marriott Ko Olina, just to see what it was like since I had read so much about it.The condo was new but basic, however still pretty nice, especially when compared to an average hotel room. No laundry in room. Small kitchen and bedroom. Furniture was cheap.The resort is huge, several buildings, most with their own pool. If you go to stay in a hotel unit, make sure you are in the Tapa, Alii, or Rainbow towers. The other towers are in tha back of the resort away from the beach. Most towers have their own pool. There is a Super Pool in the middle of the resort, it is nice, but definitely not Super. Whoever named it has never been to one of a number of Las Vegas resort pools - those are Super Pools. This Super Pool was small relative to the size of the resort.The service at this resort is excellent - very prompt and very friendly and helpful. I figured out why this is.. evryone is probably paid pretty well based on the prices they charge here. $8.95 for hot dog and fries. $7.50 for a draft beer. What a joke.One plus of this resort is that there is a village with a variety of other shops and restaurants that are not part of the Hilton Monopoly so you can get a bit more for your money but not that much. In essence, we walked away from our three night stay with the conclusion that this place is a nice resort, especially if you want to be in Waikiki, on the beach, but, it is best summarized as a rip-off catering to upscale Japanese clientele (and conventions) that are not concerned about getting good value for their vacation dollar - everything is about 25% overpriced compared to other comaprable resorts we have stayed.I would look at some of the other Waikiki resorts for a bit better value and don't get sucked into the Hilton Allure like us and the mobs of Japanese tourists have. Better yet, if you want 4-5 star, go stay out at the Marriott Ko Olina. This is out new favorite place to stay.  
<Date>Dec 15, 2003

<Author>Wolftrapper
<Content>Hilton Quality All The Way Stayed in an ocean view room at the Hilton Hawaiin Village in the Kalia Tower for 6 nights Nov 8-15, 2003. The room was very nice, quiet, comfortable and clean. I can't comment on the price value because I used Hilton points to pay for the hotel. Yes, things at the HHV are expensive, but hey you're in Hawaii, go for a walk. Within a few blocks and you can find anything you want at much lower prices. The Bus has a stop right at the property and makes in simple to get around the island. The beach is by far the the best in Waikiki and the hotel grounds are beautiful. Don't miss the Friday night polynesian show and fireworks at the Super Pool. Arrive early for a good seat. Stock up at the ABC store and you will save money. Take a trip to Hanauma Bay to snorkel. It is one of the best places in all of Hawaii. It's like swimming in an aquarium. This was my 5th trip to Hawaii and 4th to Oahu. In the past I stayed at other hotels but now I can't imagine not staying at the HHV. It is a true full-service resort that exceeded by expectations.  
<Date>Dec 5, 2003

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Tapa Tower was nice Stayed at the Hilton Hawaiin Village in the Tapa Tower 20th floor, ocean view on October 23, 2003. Room was very nice, quiet, with nice view. Not worth 260.00 per night though. Difficult getting elevator to floor due to conference. Had to pay for every little thing., Book all excursions using the coupon book phone #. Hotel charges fees to do it for you. Bus and shuttle services very easy to access at hotel. Hotel food was not good and too expensive. Eat off grounds and experience the Hawaiin Barbeque food. Hotel grounds are absolutely beautiful, beach was great, hotel is a little out of the way from all the shopping but wear comfortable shoes and take a walk to the shops. Malls were huge, Hilo Hatties was fun and can find lots of things. Buy Tshirts along the strip near hotel. Shop at ABC for snacks, drinks, etc. Go on the ATV's at the Kualoa Ranch but book early. Must snorkle at Hanauma Bay and request Dry snorkle. Go ISLAND HOPPING if you can, we didn't and friends said it was the best time ever and true flavor of Hawaii. Go to Germane's Luau -A+

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Wonderful, but not romantic - not a honeymoon spot! My husband and I enjoyed our first three days of our honeymoon here before going to Maui. The hotel is wonderful, with just about everything you need on the property - but it is very croded and I would not call it romantic at all. Th erooms are big and beautiful, service was friendly, but not anyhting out of the ordinary. We had a suite whcih was nice - Th eview from the Rainbow Tower is excellent - we slept with the door open and al you could hear were waves - probably my favorite part! Great for a vacation of activity and fun, but not if you are looking for romance and quiet. It all depends on what you are looking for.  
<Date>Dec 1, 2003

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Loved it - going back for the third time Nice hotel for the money. Ask for an upgrade if it's not crowded. Enjoy the facility, but rent a car and tour the island on your own. We did the tourist thing the first time. They are helpful at the hotel, but to much commercialization once you get on the tours. There are plenty of small outfits that will help you find things to do on your own. We rented a vehicle and drove around the island to see what there was on our own and then made our own agenda. Plenty to do at around the island(s), then fill your time at the hotel. It's a bit of a walk to the main shopping (International Market area), but we enjoy the walk. It only takes about 10 minutes to get there. Overall we recommend it. We've been twice and are going back for the third time for Christmas.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Incredible Hotel! I goto Hawai'i twice a year, and every time I go, I stay at the Hilton. From the open-air, breeze-cooled lobbies in all of the towers, to the incredibly friendly staff, and to the vast number of different views one can get from each of the 3,500 different rooms, this is by far the very best hotel in which this world traveler has ever stayed. I've stayed in regular rooms, junior suites, full suites, and apartments in the Tapa, Lagoon, and Diamond Head towers, and I think my favorite experience is in the oldest of the towers, the Diamond Head tower. The view from the 16th floor toward Diamond Head is phenomenal, and the park below outside the Army RR Hotel, the Hale Koa, is a beautiful site as well. The Hilton is an amazing hotel, unless you're a recluse who doesn't enjoy other people...I'd suggest you go somewhere else if you're an introvert.  
<Date>Nov 21, 2003

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Had a Great time November 6 2003 We spent 6 days in the Alii Tower, We had a great view and enjoyed all the things promised inthe special tower I was a little concerned after reading the reviews but,our stay was wonderful. Overall though I would recomend the Hotel, everyone was very nice to us and we did have maid service 3 times a day, to replace free bottled water and fill the ice bucket and at night turn down service. Oh yeah, try the spa, they do a great job, my husband and I had a massage and facial together and then a jasmine bath , don't do the the bath, it wasn't worth it but the rest was... Very relaxing, loved it.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Nice but crowded A friend and I just got back from a 9 night stay on Oahu. We spent our first three nights at the Hilton Village before heading up to the MUCH more peaceful, relaxing, and beautiful north shore. But if you really like the crowds of Waikiki then the Hilton Village is a nice choice. You really don't even need to leave the village if you don't want to, they have everything you could possibly need. And they charge you for it! I was pretty shocked at the prices and I travel a lot and stay at really nice resorts. $7 for just a hotdog and $4 for a soda seems pretty crazy! When you look past the price for food, this resort has a lot to offer. When we checked in (early) we were upgraded to the Ali'i Tower because the resort was sold out. This business oriented tower has it's own pool and pool bar/caf茅. This was a major plus and I didn't feel so bad about losing our ocean view once I saw how crowded the super pool was. Besides the private pool, I didn't really see any of the other amenities the Ali'i tower boasted about. We didn't have our beds turned down once, no morning paper, etc. BUT, it was worth it for the non-crowded pool area that gave us a little peace in such a crowded place. Our room was nice and the bathroom area was great with an extra changing area with sink and fridge. The fridge was a huge bonus, we went to the onsite ABC convienence store and stocked up on soda, bottled water, yogurt, mixed fruit, etc. to help offset the expensive food prices. We tried a few of the village restaurants but nothing worth mentioning except the ice cream place! One thing not to miss is the poolside night show and the Friday night fireworks. We didn't pay for either so I'm not sure about past reviewers who said they did. Overall I would recommend this resort. Just be prepared for crowds and have a lot of extra cash to buy just about anything.  
<Date>Nov 18, 2003

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>If your idea of fun is a shopping mall, this place is for you I stayed at the Ali'i Towers for the last 3 nights of an 11-day visit to Hawaii. We loved Hawaii but this place was the low point of our vacation. We were very disappointed. This place is very overpriced, but I can live with that if the experience was more pleasant. The service was OK but not great. They will charge you extra for for something every time you turn around which was very annoying given that the Ali'i Tower is very expensive in the first place. What was worst for us was that it was so generic, forget Hawaii, this hotel could be anywhere in America. If you want to experience Hawaii, save some money and stay someplace else. Our first hotel was 40% cheaper and 3 times better. I will not return to this hotel. Don't think it will be great just because it is a Hilton.

I have stayed in many hotels around the world and I have to admit I don't think you get what you pay for in this Hotel!

<Author>webmobile
<Content>My ocean view was a tree We made reservations 3 months in advanced for an ocean view. The tower we're supposed to be in was full so they upgraded (and I'm using the term loosely) us. <Author>lcruzn
<Content>Tropical Paradise Stayed at the HHV 9/27-10/3. First time in Oahu for me, my husband and son. We loved the HHV. Upon arrival, the registration line was long. After standing in line a few minutes an attendant approached me and asked me for my name. He told me I didn't have to wait in line. I was registered in the Ali tower which has its own front desk and is closest to the beach. He showed me where to go and within minutes I was in my room. The Ali tower has its own pool, fitness center, concierge and door man. First class treatment. What gets costly is use of the hotel room bar. Water, sodas, etc. are high priced. I purchased my own water, soda and snacks and stored it in the additional refrigerator provided. The grounds are beautifully landscaped with waterfalls and tropical birds, even peguins, which my son enjoyed seeing on a daily basis. What I found really helpful was the concierge. I used them almost on a daily basis. They booked my activities and the hotel provides driving directions to each activity. This is one hotel that really catered to my needs at an affordable price and that's what a vacation is all about.  
<Date>Oct 8, 2003

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Busy and beautiful! Aloha! Visited Sept 24 - 28, 2003. The village is huge, flowers, birds! We were unsure of where to check in as our driver dropped us in the tour bus area, but the hotel is laid out so you are led right to the desk. Had drinks by the pool until our room was ready. Waitstaff volunteered to make the call to the front desk. We were shown to a marina ocean view room and asked for a beach ocean view. Staff was busy, but if we picked up the key we could change rooms. The room and view were excellent! The location is close but not right in the thick of things. You can find all you need in the village. Enjoy Friday fireworks show from your balcony or the beach! Mahalo

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Bumped on our Honeymoon! My husband and I decided to spend our last 3 nights in Hawaii on Oahu and chose the Hilton Hawaiian Village for its extensive resort facilities, spa services, and beachfront location. Imagine our horror upon arriving at the hotel to learn that we had been BUMPED from the hotel on our honeymoon because they were overbooked due to a drug rep. convention and that there were no other beachfront hotels available. The hotel staff was sheepish but refused our request to be accomodated on the property. We were placed in the Aston, which was neither beachfront nor a resort -- it's sole facilities were 1 bar/restaurant and a miniscule swimming pool. To add insult to injury we were told we could not even use the Hilton's resort facilities because they were too crowded. A call to Hilton's corporate offices finally resolved the situation: their corporate policy is NEVER to bump honeymooners, a policy not followed by the Hawaiian Village. The next night, the Hilton took us back at gave us a nice top floor suite, but nothing could make up for the response of the uncaring, unhelpful staff who did nothing but give us the run-around. Overall, the hotel is nice for Waikiki but not nearly as nice as many the resorts on Maui. Because it's so large, all of the facilities are crowded and getting a chair near the pool is next to impossible.  
<Date>Sep 17, 2003
