<Author>sahdoggiemom
<Content>Another Great HHV Experience! My husband and I just returned from the wonderful island of Oahu, where we stayed at the HHV 8/30 through 9/6.I'll begin upfront by saying my husband is a diamond HHonors member and we stayed at the resort free of charge using his points. This was also our second visit to HHV, the first being at the Ali'i Tower in January of 2002.As before, valet service and check-in were speedy and very courteous. One minor check-in annoyance - three days prior to our arrival my husband emailed the HHonors rep at the HHV inquiring as to upgrade availability to the Ali'i Tower. He was told that we could upgrade to the tower for a fee but wouldn't elaborate. When we checked in we inquired again to the upgrade and was told the Ali'i Tower was not affiliated (?) with the HHV and didn't accept it's vouchers. I almost started laughing when she told us we could upgrade to that tower if we wanted to pay rack rate for the room - uh, no thanks!We wound up with a beautiful oceanfront room in the Rainbow Tower - room 1400. It had two lanais, once facing the end of Duke K. Beach and the other facing the marina with city views. It was beautiful! My husband and I generally stay at upscale hotels so, after reading other Tripadvisor reviews I was a little concerned about the room in the Rainbow Tower being old, musty and out of date. Not the case! To be honest, we sort of enjoyed the 50's kitschy feel of the room. When we first arrived, the outlet that the main lamp and TV came off of didn't work but maintenance was up in 10 minutes to fix the problem.As far as amenities go, my only complaint is that the towels are in dire need of upgrading...but I couldn't complain about too much more. We ran into a lot of people who whined and complained at the hotel to which I responded (more than once), Hey, lighten up! You're in paradise...you'll have plenty of time to complain when you get home.I've read several reviews here where people complain about the price of the food on the resort. My response? GET OFF THE RESORT! You don't have to go more than 15 minutes away to enjoy exceptional regional cuisine at Sam Choy's Breakfast Lunch and Crab, family fun at Old Spaghetti Factory or the world's most expansive food court at Ala Moana Shopping Center. My husband was an officer at Schofield Barracks for three years and knew where to go for non-resorty food...everyone who travels to Oahu should make the effort to get out and experience Hawaii because it isn't like any other states in the U.S.!The weather the week we were out was great...hot, sunny with just an occasional brief shower. One evening we enjoyed drinks and music at the Mai Tai Bar at the Royal Hawaiian and two evenings we spent at the elegant House Without a Key cocktail hour at the Halekulani. Both places had overpriced drinks but great views, great music and great people. If you're going to complain about $7 drinks, don't go to any of these places!The Tuesday evening of our trip, my husband and I dined at Bali By The Sea at the HHV. This was one of the most memorable dinners we've ever had! The food was great, the service was great...we had a wonderful time and the evening was capped off by a great post-dinner surprise (I won't spoil it for you if you go). We didn't make it to Bali the last time we were out so we made a point of going this time.I must say, the funniest anecdote I have to share is from Wednesday morning. After finishing breakfast (great free continental breakfast for HHonors members) we were headed back up to our room when the Super Pool opened. I swear, people were RUNNING to get chairs - it was hilarious! There are 100 chairs sitting around and a dozen people practically knocking each other over to get the prime spots. LOL!The beaches were crowded which was somewhat surprising but then again, our last visit there was in January when the weather is cooler (by three degrees...ha!) and less tourists are out. The Waikiki area is great for people watching and we have the pictures to prove it!The day before we checked out a major (and I mean MAJOR) pharmaceuticals conference was checking in, as well as the contestants for the Mrs. America pageant. I must say, the HHV reallly starts to slack off when they have a full house. From 2 p.m. Friday until we checked out Saturday getting anyone to get us fresh towels, check out our failing cable TV or vacuum our room was like pulling teeth. No one would answer the guest services phone and then once they did, you were put on hold indefinitely. Now, part of the problem I think was that day they had just reopened the Kalia Tower, which had been closed for over a year due to a variety of construction problems. Perhaps they weren't ready for the volume of guests but hey, they've been around for 40 years and really should know better.But, we had a great time and I always enthusiastically recommend this resort to everyone I know.Mahalo!  
<Date>Sep 11, 2003

<Content>paradise found My sister and her family live on Oahu in Lanikai. We go to Hawaii anywhere from 2-6 times a year. We got back yesterday and had stayed here. <Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Mediocre Hilton Hawaiian Village Family Vacation Family Vacation - August 12-23, 2003 - My family recently traveled to Hawaii (the big island and Oahu) flying from Baltimore. In Oahu, I booked a room through the Hilton Hawaiian Village many weeks in advance. It was touted as an ocean view room and the rate was $498.00 per night which is part of the Perfect Retreat package. This package includes coupons for the museum, dinner, and the Mandara Spa. Dinner at Bali by the Sea was so-so and this upscale restaurant actually overlooks an open casual cafe with a glimpse of the beach. Please note that the taxes on our room ran $56.00 per day, which actually cost us $554.00 per day.The location of our room was in the Ali'i Tower, however, the room was situated on the side of the hotel and above a street (alley) where we could hear garbage and delivery trucks, people, and on the week-ends a band. It was very noisy. The Hilton also seems to have a problem with pigeons landing on the lanai's and actually entering your room if your sliding door is open. We like fresh air as opposed to air conditioning when the temperature permits, so we were constantly chasing them off.We were very disappointed. My 11 year old daughter and I went to the Mandara Spa for manicures, pedicures, massages, and facials. The manicurist tried to charge me the 'adult' fee for my daughter, although there are specific charges for a 'child' (age 12 and under) manicure and pedicure. The facials were quite oily and unfortunately, caused the both of us to break out.Three weeks before our trip I called to extend our stay from 6 to 7 days because I discovered that the Hilton does a fireworks show on Friday evenings and I thought it would be fun. I was told that they were booked and wouldn't wait list me. So, I called every day to no avail.When we checked in we received the same story. So, my husband and I got on the phone and made a call to the Sheraton Moana Surfrider. We booked an ocean-view room for 2 days at $340 per day. (I didn't want to move to a new hotel for just 1 night) What a jewel it turned out to be! Our room was a true ocean-view room that was closer to the water. And surprise, surprise, no pigeons! The staff was personable and we three even received leis upon check in. The Hilton Hawaiian Village reminds me of a big conglomerate vacation vehicle. The property is huge with numerous towers. Regular parking is $11.00 per day and valet parking will run you $17.00 per day. Yes, there was a doorman to open the door for us in the Ali'i Tower and there was a separate registration desk. But, automatic doors work just dandy and registration could ultimately, do nothing for us for the extra day.The absolute kicker from the Hilton arrived in a letter delivered to our room on Thursday morning. Management had moved the fireworks show from Friday night to Saturday night (the day we were leaving the island)! Of course, just for that week only!The Sheraton Moana Surfrider was great. I only wish that I had originally booked with them and will do so when we revisit Hawaii.Sincerely,Andrea Hardy  
<Date>Aug 28, 2003
<Rating>3	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1

<Author>kandc
<Content>Hilton Hawaiian is THE PLACE! We went to the Hilton Hawaiian Village on the first leg of our honeymoon. It was a spectacular resort, filled with more things to do than we could have imagined!They were wonderful to us, and we truly enjoyed the 22nd floor room that looked out on the ocean and Waikiki Beach. My husband is not a swimmer by an means, and he was in the water non-stop while we were there.Benihana's was terrific and right there, and definitely find out if the HHV is offering their coupon book with a stay. There were a lot of great coupons in the book and we used them all! Enjoy the open air bar where the music plays throughout the evening. It's a great place to just sit back and relax.We spent the first week of our honeymoon doing a lot of sightseeing on Oahu, and the second week on Maui -- a much needed change!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Hawaiin vacation at the Hilton Our dream vacation at the Hilton Hawaiin on June 22 was not quite what we expected! The staff was wonderful, the facility was beautiful, the food was yummy! However, our room (we had 2, one for us and the other for the teenagers) was left open from a window washer for about 4 hours! It was like, Come on in and take whatever you want! Thank goodness nothing was taken and we did use the wonderful safe in the room for $3.00/day. The Marriott in Fallsview Canada is a 5 star hotel and they charge nothing for the safe, and supply free coffee each morning! The Hilton charges $3.50 for the coffee and you learn quick to visit the ABC store for supplies! The other problem was the electricity on the wall that we shared with our kids. The lights and clock radio would go on and off, then finally off. When the repairman came they gave us two options; move to another room, or they could drill a hole above the kitchen sink and fix the box. We decided against both since we had 2 days left and didn't want to haul our stuff to who knows where. We had a hard enough time to get 2 rooms side by side when we checked in and requested this 6 months in advance! Plus the bathrooms had no exhaust fans so the mirrors steamed up fast. Later I was told none of the rooms at the Rainbow Towers had exhausts? They do nickel and dime you to death! Renting an umbrella for the beach at $23.00/day is rather pricey considering you are STAYING at that hotel! The other problem is the elevators weren't working properly. The doors wouldn't open when you reached your floor, you had to force the doors open by hand! Management was aware of all the problems! I'm unsure as to whether or not I would go back there or not for the pricey problems in the Rainbow Towers. The rooms were average at a cost of $189.00/night.  
<Date>Aug 17, 2003

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Convience and Style Our Hawaii Family vacation (July 28th, 2003) to Oahu included a few days at the Hilton Village. We also stayed at the Hilton Village on the Island of Hawaii, and we loved it there as well. Each is equally unique.We enjoy the Waikiki City excitement and crowds and yet the Hilton is placed in it's own nearby world, enabling it's guests to have a total experience of the hotel itself and the big city only just outside the hotel grounds. It is a perfect blend of complimentary amenities.The restaurants in the area are abundant, which was great because our vacation was not all about FOOD, but rather the wonders of Hawaii and spending quality family time together doing fun things. The beach at the Hilton is great... it is like being in a realtime magically modernized Norman Rockwell Painting...to be part of the many activities going on: The surfers, swimmers, boaters, fishers, readers, sleepers... it was a lovely place to park the family for the day of safe clean surf and relaxation or many activities (diversity and variety). Wonderful people from all over the world shared those days with us in this paradise land.I recommend renting an umbrella and loungers for the day and don't bother complaining about the cost... just do it! It makes life so comfortable and it is so sophisticated a touch to a special day. After all how many days are you going to experience this dreamy beach before all too soon it is back to your normal lives. It is nice to hold on to every memory from the vantage point of the well serviced shady canvas.It was the extra touches that the Hilton provides that really makes you notice that this is not the average hotel. For example there is a Hawaiian Show provided at the poolside at about 6. The staff was very nice and ever present.We loved our clean good-sized room which was an unexpected upgrade in the Rainbow Tower; That's how nice the staff is! The view was endless, the sounds of the ocean waves, the happy guests and the Hotel Restaurant Music way-down-there (the towers are tall) were really special. We slept with the patio door opened and woke up refreshed at dawn with excitement for the heavenly place we arrived at.We will stay there again on our next visit to the Waikiki area of the beautiful Island of Oahu and until then, this place will hold a part of our hearts.Mahalo to the Hilton.  
<Date>Aug 13, 2003

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Wonderful Facility The property itself is beautiful as was the staff. Birds flying all about, penguins, flamingos tropical plants, the pools, ocean, restuarants, shops all come together in a beautifyl setting. Stayed in the Alii Tower which had its own lobby to allow check-in and out. (Nice feature)They allowed us to check-in early and out late. Our room was partial ocean view overlooking the main pool and the ocean. The room funishings were new and the room makeup service excellent. (3 times a day) This tower had its own private pool, steam room, exercise room and bar which was nice. Also free poo poos every evening at the pool. Food however was pricy and we ate off the property a lot. We would definately stay here again and would highly recommend it to couples or families. FIVE STARS

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Place to Stay Stayed 7/14-7/19 2003 Beautiful property, and friendly staff.The only thing that bothered me was the moldy smell in the bedroom. I believe it was from the air conditioning.It is expensive, too. They charge a lot for every little thing. For example, snorkeling at Hanauma Bay: Snorkle $2, mask $3.. (the experience: priceless)... At the Hilton, the mask and snorkle were $15.00. They even charged $7.00 admission to watch the fireworks display by the pool!As for property and staff, they were great. Very helpful and friendly. The property has its own beach, activities, and a great spa. You could easily stay there and never leave the property.Definitely one of the best and most beautiful hotels in Honolulu.I would stay there again.

<Author>wingsovertx
<Content>Good hotel for family vacation  We just returned from a 7 day, 6 night stay at the Hilton Hawaiin Village. I was thrilled to be able to redeem Hilton Honors points to stay free of charge instead of paying $189-219 per night. This hotel has a great location on Waikiki Beach and is virtually a city in and of itself. The grounds are beautiful and well-kept, particularly the pools(there must have been at least 5). Service was pretty good  the staff friendly. There were lines and a few small hassles here and there. Food and drinks are not cheap but then again this is Hawaii. There must have been 20-25 restaurants on the resort and 5 high-rise towers where guests can stay. We stayed in the Rainbow Tower and enjoyed it. The room are not extravagant but they are nice, clean and comfortable. Hitlon should consider updating some of them with more modern furnishings. My family received an upgrade to an ocean view room at check-in. You can walk to the main strip on Waikiki beach in 15 minutes and there is frequent trolley service in the event you choose not to walk. I was surprised to find that Honolulu is as commercialized as it was, but the Waikiki Beach area(its touristy) and Hilton Hawaiin Village make it feel like a fun place to just chill. I'd recommend the hotel to families, singles, and couples on honeymoons. You may want to check into staying in the Alii Tower if you desire very nice accomodations. Each tower is different and provides its own level of comfort - just be willing to pay for it b/c nothing is free, not even the coffee and tea in the rooms. All in all, I'd return to stay at the resort. Lastly, don't forget to bring a camera because there are some really pretty places at the Hawaiin Village to shoot some memorable photos!   
<Date>Jul 25, 2003

<Author>stacie

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Loved HHV We just returned from our vacation on July 2. We have stayed at other hotels in Waikiki, but HHV receives our highest rating yet. It is within walking distance to the heart of Waikiki, but far enough from all the traffic and noise from the 18-20 year- old crowd. This is definitely a family resort, which we truly loved since we have two small children. The shopping, restaurants and entertainment were excellent. The private beach was wonderful with plenty of water sports available. We stayed in the Tapa Tower and had a wonderful view of the city and ocean. We will definitely return to this resort every time we vacation in Oahu.  
<Date>Jul 10, 2003

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Hotel was okay but overrated I was disappointed with this hotel. I thought I had done my research and ended up choosing this hotel because I wanted to stay in paradise. First of all, not all towers are created equal. We ended up in the diamond head tower and it was very disappointing. Our room was on the third floor, at the very end and our balcony looked out over the delivery trucks. The delivery trucks beeped when they were backing up and this beeping would start at 6:00 am every morning. We asked for a different room to no avail. They claimed to be completely full. A cruise ship's A/C had broken down so the hotel was full of all these cruise ship people while the boat was being fixed. The service at this hotel was so-so. One afternoon we were taking a nap and we heard a key jingling in our door and some guy came walking in (no knocking!!) to clean our windows. People should knock before entering a room. We got a statement the day before we were to check out with our incidental charges. You're supposed to get those the morning of check out. So, we had to go downstairs and pay those charges and then re-check in for our final night. ?? I've never had to do that before. It took about 45 minutes of my morning because they had a bunch of new people in training working the front desk. It was irritating. The grounds were beautiful and the adjacent beach was large. The pools were nice but very crowded. If you didn't go claim your sunny spot by 8:00am you'd end up with lounge chairs in the shade. I wouldn't stay at this hotel again because I was so disappointed with my stay. My suggestion is to specify what tower you want. I do not recommend the diamond head tower. I thought it sucked. The hotel shouldn't put people in rooms overlooking the delivery area. Definitely do your research!!  
<Date>Jul 7, 2003

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Paradise Stayed at HHV on recent June trip to Hawaii. I am an owner in the HGVC so we were in the lagoon tower. But, the entire staff of the village were very friendly and helpful. <Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Resort and Service Our family stayed at the Hilton on May 24th through the 28th, 2003. We stayed in the Ali'i Tower and since the Ali'i Tower has a private separate registration desk, we didn't have to wait in a long line for check in. I asked to be upgraded from a garden view to an ocean view and they kept our luggage and gave us three room keys to view the rooms to make our decesion! Wow, that is service! We easily made our decesion and had a beautiful room with a great view of the pool and ocean. The room was very nice and has a mini tv in the bathroom along with two sinks. They had service three times a day. Also, from 5p.m. to 7p.m. they had appetizers for everyone in the Ali'i tower by the private Ali'i pool. The resort has all kinds of shopping along with several great restaurants. You never need to leave unless you want to sightsee around the island, which I highly recommend.The wildlife, (penquins) etc. were so neat to see. Also, they have free classes for lei making, and hula lessons. Every night they have a short neat hawaiian show by the pool.This is a great hotel for the family and I highly recommed it especailly in the Ali'i Tower.  
<Date>Jun 9, 2003

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Loved the Tapa Tower Stayed 6 nights in the Tapa Tower during the Spring Break (April 2003). This was our 2nd stay at the Tapa Tower and we loved it. Our room faced the park (a lower rate), however we could look down and watch our sons in the pool. The Tapa bar had nightly music and the Hilton had daily drink specials (ie Pina Colada) for $5. The tower is closest to the street and we were able to walk across the street to a local coffee shop for breakfast @ a 1/3 of the price of the Hilton. In the Tapa Tower is the bus stop where a free DFS bus takes you downtown to their store where you can walk in and walk out and you are in the middle of Waikiki. Love the Tapa tower.
